Title: Federal Judge Orders Hillary Clinton to Answer Written Questions on Private Email Server

A federal judge has ruled that Hillary Clinton must answer written questions from the conservative legal group Judicial Watch regarding her use of a private email server while serving as Secretary of State. The decision comes as part of a Freedom of Information Act lawsuit Judicial Watch is pursuing against the State Department.

Judge Emmet Sullivan gave Judicial Watch until October 14 to provide the questions, and Clinton has 30 days to respond. Judicial Watch President Tom Fitton stated that the decision is a reminder that Hillary Clinton is not above the law.

The dispute centers around Clinton's use of a private email server during her time as Secretary of State, which has been the subject of an FBI investigation. In July, FBI Director James Comey recommended no charges against Clinton for mishandling classified information, although he did reprimand her for being "extremely careless" in her handling of the server.

Judicial Watch has been pursuing Clinton and her husband in court for years, seeking answers about her use of the private server. The group has released 44 previously undisclosed Clinton email exchanges that she failed to include among 30,000 private messages she turned over to the government last year. The newly disclosed messages cover Clinton's first three months as Secretary of State in early 2009, a period for which Clinton did not turn over any emails to the State Department last year.

The judge's decision allows Judicial Watch to obtain Clinton's "unique, first-hand knowledge" of the basis for her decision to set up a private server. While Judicial Watch had argued that only Clinton could testify about the reasons behind her decision, the judge ruled that written answers would suffice, citing the extensive public record related to the Clintonemail.com system.

Title: Vatican-Reviewed Journal Criticizes Trump Supporters for "Theocratic" and "Apocalyptic" Worldview

A recent article published in a Vatican-reviewed journal, La Civiltà Cattolica, has criticized evangelical and Catholic allies of President Trump for promoting a "theocratic" and "apocalyptic" worldview. The article, written by two authors close to Pope Francis, accuses Trump supporters of uniting around a "xenophobic and Islamophobic vision" that seeks to build walls and implement deportations.

The authors specifically mention Steve Bannon, Trump's top White House strategist, who they claim wants a country where citizens submit to the Bible. They compare this idea to Islamic fundamentalism, stating that it is "no different" from the ideology that inspires Islamic extremism.

In contrast, the article praises Pope Francis for promoting a peaceful worldview, which the authors describe as a "systematic counter-narration" to the narrative of fear. They highlight Francis's refusal to give theological-political legitimacy to terrorists or those who advocate for a "holy war" or the construction of barriers, such as the proposed wall along the U.S.-Mexico border.

The article also references Trump's meeting with Pope Francis at the Vatican, where he presented Francis with books written by Martin Luther King Jr. In February, Francis publicly criticized Trump's stance on the proposed wall, stating that it was not a Christian gesture and that Christians should respond to evil with forgiveness, not retaliation.

Title: Pope Francis: A Leader Who Embodies Service and Humility

Pope Francis, the leader of the Roman Catholic Church, has made a significant impact on the institution and the world in just nine months. His actions, such as kissing the disabled, holding babies, and washing the feet of prisoners, have been carefully staged but reveal his genuine character. Francis wants his church to serve, not strut.

In his first solo papal exhortation, Evangelii Gaudium, Francis emphasized his concern for the poor, which has led to misconceptions about his views on capitalism. However, a closer reading reveals that he is criticizing the pursuit of wealth as a competing religion, not capitalism itself. He believes that having money is not proof of success, but using it wisely is.

Francis has also acknowledged that the Church has become too focused on issues like abortion, homosexuality, and the ordination of women priests, which has led to misinterpretations. He is opposed to these issues and will not change his stance.

Pope Francis believes that the world is unfair and that the Catholic Church should help people. He encourages Catholics to be the first to kiss, caress, and concern themselves with those in need. He also believes that priests and bishops should get out of their limousines and walk among the people they are supposed to comfort.

Francis' actions discomfort some people because he speaks to their better selves and calls them out when they fail to live up to their potential. He is not a communist who hates money, as collections are still taken up at mass. Instead, he is a leader who embodies service and humility.

Few people know that Francis rises early to spend time alone, reading scripture, which gives him the strength to challenge tradition and rattle the entrenched bureaucracy around him. The little girl who marched up to the altar in my parish brought herself closer to God, and Francis offers an example in himself. A few minutes of lost sleep, in the presence of divine wisdom, might benefit us all.

Title: U.S. Role in the World Shifts Focus from Military Might to Economic and Soft Power

The upcoming presidential debate's first round of questions will focus on America's role in the world, with a likely emphasis on military readiness and anti-terrorism efforts. However, experts argue that the U.S. role in the world is shaped by more than just its military strength. According to Joseph Nye, a Harvard professor, leadership is also defined by economic power and "soft" power, such as the country's ability to attract and persuade people to adopt American values.

In the early 1990s, Nye's book "Bound to Lead: The Changing Nature of American Power" sparked a conversation about the need to develop economic and soft power. However, after the 9/11 attacks, the focus shifted back to military strength. With the Iraq War over and U.S. military involvement in Afghanistan winding down, Nye believes the focus may be shifting back to economic and cultural leadership.

Nye notes that the Iraq War caused a significant drop in American soft power, as many people in other countries saw the United States as being too aggressive. Additionally, the 2008 subprime mortgage crisis led to a decline in U.S. economic power. However, with China and Europe struggling with economic growth, Nye believes the wheel is turning again, and the U.S. is regaining its economic and soft power.

Nariman Behravesh, chief economist of the forecasting firm IHS Global Insight, agrees that U.S. economic and soft power are coming back. He notes that the U.S. still has the largest economy in the world, is the No. 1 export destination, and has innovative companies like Apple. However, Behravesh also emphasizes the importance of addressing the budget deficit problem in the coming months. He believes that if the U.S. shows it can discipline itself and control its debts, its economic and soft power may surge.

In conclusion, the U.S. role in the world is shifting from a focus on military might to economic and soft power. Experts believe that the country's ability to attract and persuade people to adopt American values, as well as its economic strength, will play a significant role in shaping its global leadership in the future.

Title: Republican National Committee Chairman Criticized for Prioritizing Hispanic Vote Over Immigration Enforcement

Article:

Republican National Committee Chairman Reince Priebus recently expressed concerns about the impact of discussing strict immigration enforcement policies on the Hispanic vote, stating that such rhetoric "hurts us." However, critics argue that Priebus is prioritizing the party's Hispanic vote-pandering campaign over protecting law-abiding citizens from the consequences of illegal immigration.

At the RNC's annual summer meeting in Boston, Priebus complained that advocating for self-deportation policies during the last election season was "horrific." Critics argue that this stance is overly sensitive and ignores the concerns of families who have been affected by illegal immigration.

The RNC chair has yet to explain what is "horrific" about suggesting that foreign nationals who are breaking the law should abide by the rules and return home. Many countries have strict laws and enforcement mechanisms in place to deal with illegal immigration.

The article highlights the story of Jamiel Shaw, a 17-year-old who was murdered by an illegal alien gang member in Los Angeles. The killer, Pedro Espinoza, was smuggled into the US illegally as a toddler and was later released from jail for serving time for assault with a deadly weapon. The article questions why Priebus has not acknowledged the suffering of families like the Shaws, who have been harmed by illegal alien violence.

The article concludes that the RNC's prioritization of the Hispanic vote over immigration enforcement is a concern, and that the party should focus on addressing the concerns of families who have been affected by illegal immigration.

Title: CNN Counterterrorism Analyst Warns of Growing Tension Between Government and Trump Administration

CNN counterterrorism analyst Phil Mudd, a former deputy director to FBI Director Robert Mueller, expressed concerns about the growing mistrust between the government and the Trump administration during an interview with CNN anchor Jake Tapper. Mudd stated that the government is "going to kill this guy" in reference to President Trump, citing his defense of Russian President Vladimir Putin and the recent FBI raid on former Trump campaign manager Paul Manafort's home.

Mudd emphasized that the mistrust between the government and the Trump administration is evident in the frequency of leaks from the White House and the intelligence community since Trump took office. He pointed to the recent leak of transcripts of Trump's phone calls with foreign leaders as an example of the growing tension.

Mudd also mentioned Trump's recent announcement of a ban on transgender soldiers in the military as another reason some in the government are turning against him. He stated that the military is not pleased with the lack of transparency surrounding the policy, saying "Ain't going to happen."

Mudd's comments come as many in Washington, including Democrats, express concern about the impact of leaks on national security. Former National Security Council official Ned Price warned that the leaks will have a "chilling effect" on the ability of the commander-in-chief to have candid discussions with foreign leaders.

The exact extent of the mistrust between the government and the Trump administration remains unclear, but Mudd's comments suggest that it is a growing concern.

Title: Spending Bill Negotiators Reach Deal, Include Various Provisions in $1.1 Trillion Package

The US Congress has reached a deal on a $1.1 trillion spending bill, which includes a wide range of provisions that aim to keep the federal government functioning past Thursday. The bill, which sets annual budgets for various programs, also contains several policy riders and changes to existing laws.

The spending bill includes a provision that bars the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) from regulating methane emissions from livestock production, as well as a ban on poultry processed in China that might have ended up in school lunches. The Agriculture Department will no longer be allowed to use such poultry in school meals.

Other provisions in the bill include a fix for the Boy Scouts' pensions, relief for Americans living abroad from new Obamacare rules on health insurance, and an increase in the number of hours truckers can drive each week. The wealthy will also be allowed to donate more money to political parties.

Democrats won new limits on federal contracts for certain companies moving their tax addresses abroad, while Republicans secured language that would block any rules aimed at protecting small birds, the greater sage grouse, and the Gunnison sage grouse.

The bill also includes funding for the Environmental Protection Agency, which comes in at more than the White House asked for. The spending bill is a result of negotiations between Democratic and Republican lawmakers, who are trying to avoid a government shutdown.

Lawmakers used to rely on earmarks to get their favorite initiatives across the finish line, but those have been banned for several years. Instead, they looked to their colleagues' favorite causes and included provisions in the spending bill.

The result is a sprawling measure that touches on everything from union pensions to defense procurement, making it one of the most consequential bills to come before Congress this year.

Title: Pentagon-Commissioned Study Raises Concerns About Vulnerability of Nuclear Facilities to Terrorist Attack

A recent study commissioned by the Pentagon has raised concerns about the vulnerability of the nation's nuclear facilities to terrorist attack. The study, conducted by researchers at the University of Texas, suggests that the potential theft of enough nuclear material to construct an improvised fission bomb is a "real possibility." This finding stands in contrast to the nuclear industry's claims about its own safeguards.

The Nuclear Energy Institute (NEI) has stated that the industry undertook a massive re-assessment of its plant security after the 9/11 attacks and bolstered protections. The typical plant features a fenced outer security perimeter, an inner double fence topped with razor wire, and a third layer of protection surrounding vital equipment. The containment vessel itself has multiple layers of steel and concrete.

However, the University of Texas study suggests that these measures may not be enough to prevent a terrorist attack. According to Professor Alan Kuperman, one of the authors of the report, a study by the U.S. National Laboratory in 1982 found that an airliner impact could breach the containment vessel, leading to a loss of coolant and potentially a meltdown, and subsequent radiation release.

The study also highlights the lack of uniformity in the protection of nuclear facilities, with some facilities having more robust security measures than others. The report calls for greater uniformity in security standards across all nuclear facilities, including power plants, storage facilities, and sites where fissile material is stored.

The likelihood of a terrorist attack on nuclear facilities is difficult to estimate, with some experts putting the probability at "very substantially less than one in a million," while others estimate a 50% chance of an attack on U.S. soil within the next decade. The study acknowledges the divergence in research on this topic and emphasizes the need for continued vigilance and improvement in nuclear facility security.

Title: Republican Lawmakers Warn of Major Obstacle to Enacting Trump's Agenda: National Debt

The incoming Trump administration's ambitious plans for infrastructure, tax cuts, and military spending may face a significant hurdle: the national debt. President-elect Donald Trump's proposals, which include a $1 trillion infrastructure package, $5 trillion in tax cuts, and increased military spending, could add more than $350 billion to the national debt over 10 years. The lack of concrete details on how to pay for these plans has raised concerns among congressional Republicans, who are already worried about the nation's $20 trillion borrowing limit.

Senator John McCain (R-Ariz.) expressed disappointment that the issue of deficits and debt was not discussed during the campaign. "I'm very concerned about it. It's the biggest problem we face, by far," he said. Conservative groups, such as the Heritage Foundation, are also sounding the alarm, emphasizing the need for fiscal restraint and entitlement reform.

The expected action by the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates could further exacerbate the problem, as it would increase the cost of the nation's debt. According to Senator Jeff Flake (R-Ariz.), for every quarter point that interest rates rise, the federal government would have to spend an additional $50 billion annually to service the debt.

Congressional Republicans, who assailed President Obama over soaring federal deficits during his tenure, are now concerned about the potential impact of Trump's plans on the national debt. Former Senator Phil Gramm (R-Texas) noted that the debt has doubled under Obama's presidency and would be even higher if interest rates were at their historic norms.

While Trump's transition team has suggested that private sector investments in infrastructure can be triggered without a huge increase in spending, many Republicans are skeptical. Senator John Boozman (R-Ark.) expressed concern about the lack of details on how to pay for Trump's infrastructure plan, saying that his conference will be "very concerned about how they affect both the debt and the deficit."

Conservative groups are also worried that Trump's plans do not address entitlement reform, which is essential to addressing the nation's growing spending. "You can't address the growth in spending without addressing entitlement issues," said Michael Sargent, a research associate at the Heritage Foundation.

The article highlights the concerns among Republican lawmakers and conservative groups about the potential impact of Trump's plans on the national debt and the need for fiscal restraint. While Trump has promised not to touch Social Security or Medicare, his plans for infrastructure, tax cuts, and military spending could still add significantly to the national debt.

Title: Tom Vilsack's Career in Public Service: From Presidential Bid to Agriculture Secretary

Tom Vilsack, the current Secretary of Agriculture, has had a career marked by both highs and lows. After a failed presidential bid in 2008, Vilsack endorsed Hillary Clinton and worked to deliver his home state of Iowa for her. However, his efforts were unsuccessful, as Barack Obama's campaign ultimately won the state.

As Agriculture Secretary, Vilsack has been instrumental in negotiating the 2014 farm bill, a nearly $1 trillion measure that aimed to reform farm subsidies and support for the food stamp program for the poor. He has also been a key player in pushing for the passage of the Healthy, Hunger-Free Kids Act in 2010, which mandated the use of whole grains, vegetables, and fruits in schools and required students to select at least one portion of fruits or vegetables at every lunch.

In addition, Vilsack has been a proponent of biofuels. Recently, he joined Secretary of the Navy Ray Mabus to christen the guided-missile destroyer William P. Lawrence, which was filled with biofuel made from beef fat. Vilsack described the event as an "extraordinary experience" and highlighted the importance of partnerships in extending the reach of the U.S. Department of Agriculture.

Despite being a low-key and soft-spoken individual, Vilsack's job as Agriculture Secretary has kept him largely out of the spotlight. However, he did face a public relations crisis early in his second year in the job, when he fired Shirley Sherrod, an Agriculture Department official in Georgia, after reacting to a video that showed her making seemingly racist comments. However, it was later revealed that the video had been heavily edited by a conservative website, and the full video showed Sherrod offering a lesson in racial tolerance and compassion. Vilsack publicly apologized to Sherrod days later.

Title: Three Rays of Hope for Bipartisanship in the US

The United States is often described as being mired in division and dysfunction, with politicians in Washington struggling to work together. However, journalist Michael Tomasky believes that there are three tiny rays of hope that could reduce polarization and minimize political and cultural divisions over the next eight years.

The first ray of hope is the major demographic shift in the US, specifically the growth of the Latino population. Florida, a crucial swing state, is transforming as its Latino population grows, with Puerto Ricans and Cubans becoming a significant force. This could lead to a shift in the Republican Party's stance on immigration reform, potentially paving the way for a path to citizenship.

The second ray of hope is the Republican Party's internal divisions, particularly around Donald Trump. If he wins, the party may continue to be divided, but if he loses, the party may be forced to re-evaluate its stance on various issues. This could lead to a more moderate approach, as seen in the Democratic Party's shift towards the center after their 1980, 1984, and 1988 losses.

The third ray of hope is the filibuster rule in the Senate, which has been a major obstacle to legislation. Tomasky believes that the Senate may change its rules to reduce the number of votes needed to end a filibuster, making it easier for lawmakers to work together.

While there are reasons to be skeptical about these developments, Tomasky believes that there is a decent chance they will happen. Even if they do, it will not mean an immediate return to a harmonious political landscape, but it could be a step in the right direction. As C.S. Lewis once said, "It may be hard for an egg to turn into a bird. But it's a jolly sight harder for it to learn to fly while remaining an egg."

Title: Senate Reaches Deal to Avert "Nuclear Option" on Filibuster Rules

The United States Senate has reached an agreement to avert the "nuclear option" on filibuster rules, allowing for the confirmation of several presidential nominees and avoiding a historic rules change. Under the deal, President Barack Obama will withdraw two nominees to the National Labor Relations Board (NLRB) and replace them with new nominees, Nancy Schiffer and Kent Hirozawa. The nominations are expected to move swiftly, as the current board members' terms expire in August.

The agreement was reached after intense negotiations between Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid and Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell, with the help of Senators John McCain and Roger Wicker. The deal allows for the confirmation of five presidential nominees, including Gina McCarthy as EPA administrator and Thomas Perez as Labor secretary, and prevents the NLRB from ceasing to function.

Each side gained something from the agreement: Democrats will get seven of Obama's nominees in place, while Republicans were able to scuttle the recess-appointed Block and Griffin from the NLRB. Republicans will still be able to force procedural votes on executive nominees at a 60-vote threshold, and Democrats retain the right to change the rules.

The agreement was reached just before noon, when the Senate voted to move forward with the nomination of Richard Cordray to head the Consumer Financial Protection Board, with 71 votes. The deal was hailed as a "new start" for the Senate, with Reid saying he feels "very comfortable" about it.

The agreement was sparked by McCain's doggedness and Wicker's request to get all senators in one room together. Once they were all in the Old Senate Chamber, it was clear an agreement could be reached, according to Schumer.

Title: The Resurgence of the Equal Rights Amendment: A Constitutional Debate

The Equal Rights Amendment (ERA), a radical feminist constitutional amendment, is gaining momentum as America enters a new decade. The amendment, which aims to enshrine gender equality in the US Constitution, has been revived, with Virginia expected to ratify it, bringing the total number of states to 38, the threshold needed for amendment. The amendment's language, "Equality of rights under the law shall not be denied or abridged by the United States or by any state on account of sex," seems innocuous, but its broad language could have far-reaching implications.

American women are already protected by existing laws and the Equal Protection Clause of the 14th Amendment, which prohibits sex discrimination. The ERA would not add new protections but could be used to impose sex-sameness, potentially threatening laws that recognize differences between men and women. For instance, separate-sex bathrooms or government funding for women's shelters could be challenged.

Proponents argue that the ERA would not have radical effects, but opponents warn that its broad language and addition to existing antidiscrimination laws could be used to force women into combat, disallow separate-sex bathrooms, or pull government funding from women's shelters. In New Mexico and Connecticut, state-level ERAs have been interpreted as requiring government funding for abortion.

The ERA could also threaten laws that provide benefits to stay-at-home wives or young mothers, such as Social Security benefits or grants encouraging girls' participation in scientific fields. Additionally, the meaning of "sex" is unclear, and the amendment could be used to challenge women-only spaces and religious liberty.

While some argue that the ERA is a relic of history, it will remain a live issue going into 2020. Proponents claim that recent ratifications in Nevada and Illinois, combined with those from the 1970s, will meet the required threshold. However, opponents argue that the amendment's ratification process is flawed, citing the 1982 deadline imposed by Congress and the fact that some 1970s ratifications have since been rescinded or had long-expired sunset clauses.

The debate surrounding the ERA highlights the importance of understanding the differences between men and women, as well as the potential consequences of enshrining gender equality in the Constitution. Opponents must prepare to argue on the substance, emphasizing that men and women are already equal under American law but are not the same.

Title: Mark Sanford Wins Special Election for South Carolina House Seat

Mark Sanford, a former South Carolina governor, has won a special election for the state's open House seat, defeating Democratic challenger Elizabeth Colbert Busch. Sanford secured 54% of the vote, while Colbert Busch received 45%.

The election was seen as a bellwether for the 2014 elections, with National Republican Congressional Committee Chairman Greg Walden stating that the results demonstrate the devastating impact of President Barack Obama and House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi's policies on House Democrats. However, Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee Chairman Steve Israel praised Colbert Busch for pushing Sanford into a competitive contest in a Republican-dominated district, citing the strength of the candidate and the Republican habit of nominating flawed candidates.

Sanford's political career was previously marred by a scandal in 2009, when he was accused of having an extramarital affair and lying about his whereabouts. He had been considered a rising star in the Republican Party before the scandal, and had even been mentioned as a possible 2012 presidential candidate. Despite his past controversies, Sanford has maintained a strong reputation among some Republicans, and received endorsements from several high-profile figures, including Senator Lindsey Graham and Senator Rand Paul.

The election was seen as a test of Sanford's ability to overcome his past mistakes and win over voters. While some political analysts believe that Sanford's victory may not have significant implications for the national political landscape, others see it as a sign of the Republican Party's ability to overcome past controversies and win elections.

In the end, Sanford's victory was seen as a testament to his ability to adapt and overcome his past mistakes, and his ability to appeal to voters in a Republican-dominated district.

Title: New Cable Reveals Concerns About Benghazi Security Before 9/11 Attack

A recently obtained cable has shed new light on the situation in Benghazi, Libya, just before the terrorist attack on September 11, 2012, which resulted in the deaths of U.S. Ambassador Chris Stevens and three other Americans. The cable, marked "SECRET," was sent on August 16, 2012, and reveals a clear concern for safety and the growing dangers of al Qaeda in the city.

According to the cable, an emergency meeting was held a month prior to the attack, during which it was determined that the U.S. consulate could not withstand a coordinated attack. The Regional Security Officer (RSO) expressed concerns about the ability to defend the post due to limited manpower, security measures, weapons capabilities, host nation support, and the overall size of the compound.

The cable also mentioned that the Emergency Action Committee was briefed on the location of approximately ten Islamist militias and AQ training camps within Benghazi, including groups such as the QRF Brigade and Ansar al-Sharia, which have since been implicated in the consulate attack. The cable described the security situation in Benghazi as "trending negatively" and explicitly stated that the mission would request additional physical security upgrades and staffing needs.

The details in the cable seem to foreshadow the deadly September 11 attack on the U.S. compound, which was a coordinated, commando-style assault using direct and indirect fire. Al Qaeda in North Africa and Ansar al-Sharia, both mentioned in the cable, have since been implicated in the consulate attack.

The cable further undermines the administration's claims that the attack came without warning, as it explicitly stated that the mission would ask for more help due to the uncertain security environment. The cable also contradicts the administration's public statements suggesting that the attack was sparked by a YouTube video.

In a separate cable sent on September 11, the day of the attack, Ambassador Stevens wrote about "growing problems with security" in Benghazi and "growing frustration" with the security forces and Libyan police, stating that both were "too weak to keep the country secure."

Title: Shutdown Rules Spark Protests and Lawsuits Across the Nation

The ongoing shutdowns and restrictions imposed by governments across the United States have sparked widespread protests and lawsuits, with many business owners and individuals feeling that their rights are being trampled. The liberal media has labeled protesters as "virus deniers," but proponents of the shutdowns are citing science and the US Constitution as justification.

According to data, almost all coronavirus fatalities are among the elderly and those with serious health problems. In Pennsylvania, 68% of deaths have been nursing-home residents, while in Rhode Island, it's 70%. Shutting down stores and restaurants didn't save them, and a targeted lockdown aimed at protecting the highest-risk group, people 65 and over, would slash deaths by half at half the economic cost of a total shutdown, according to the National Bureau of Economic Research.

Unfortunately, social media platforms are censoring science that challenges the shutdown, with YouTube banning content that "disputes the efficacy of local health authority recommended guidance." Google, YouTube's parent company, is also censoring views that contradict the World Health Organization's guidance.

The shutdown's original goal was to "flatten the curve," buying time for hospitals to add beds and gather medical equipment. However, the virus is not expected to be eradicated, and experts predict it will last another 18 months to two years, fading once most Americans have been exposed and developed immunity.

As some states begin to lift their shutdowns, governors are acknowledging the need for a balance between keeping the virus at bay and allowing people to earn a living. In Colorado, Governor Jared Polis explained that it's a "balance" between keeping the virus "at a level that won't overwhelm our hospital systems and allowing people to still try and earn a living."

The article concludes by highlighting the need for a more targeted approach, citing Governor Andrew Cuomo's four-phase reopening plan, which includes benchmarks pegged to hospital capacity. The author also notes that nursing-home preparedness is crucial, as most deaths are occurring among this demographic.

Title: Scotland's Independence Movement: A Global Phenomenon of Secessionism

The recent "Get Brexit Done" campaign by British Prime Minister Boris Johnson has sparked a renewed debate about Scotland's independence from the United Kingdom. Scotland's First Minister Nicola Sturgeon has called for a second referendum on Scottish independence, citing the Scottish National Party's significant victory in the 2019 parliamentary elections. However, Johnson's government has refused to consider another referendum, stating that Scotland will not be allowed to secede from the UK.

This development is part of a larger global phenomenon of secessionism, where nations and regions are seeking independence from their parent countries. This trend has been ongoing for decades, with the most recent wave beginning in the 1990s. Since then, several countries have gained independence, including Montenegro, Kosovo, and South Sudan.

The causes of secessionism are complex and multifaceted, but primarily revolve around issues of national identity, including ethnicity, religion, language, culture, and historical grievances. These factors have led to the emergence of new nations, such as the Baltic states, which gained independence from the Soviet Union, and the Balkan states, which broke away from Yugoslavia.

The phenomenon of secessionism is not limited to Europe. In the Americas, several countries have gained independence from their colonial powers, including the United States, Canada, and many Latin American nations. In Asia, the Korean Peninsula is still divided, with North and South Korea maintaining a fragile peace treaty. In Africa, several countries have gained independence from their colonial powers, including Ghana, Nigeria, and South Africa.

The secessionist movement is not without its challenges and complexities. Some countries, like Taiwan, are not recognized as independent by their parent countries, while others, like the Donbass region in Ukraine, are not recognized by the international community. The ongoing conflicts in the Caucasus, Middle East, Africa, and South Asia are testaments to the ongoing struggle for national identity and self-determination.

In conclusion, the phenomenon of secessionism is a complex and multifaceted issue that requires careful consideration and understanding. As the world continues to evolve, it is essential to acknowledge the legitimate aspirations of nations and regions seeking independence and self-determination, while also recognizing the challenges and complexities that come with this process.

Title: FBI Director Wray Urges Agents to Focus on Work Amid Controversy Surrounding Surveillance Memo

FBI Director Christopher Wray addressed the agency's employees with an internal memo on Friday, hours after a Republican-led House committee released a document alleging surveillance abuses by the Justice Department and FBI. The memo, prepared at the direction of House Intelligence Committee Chairman David Nunes, claims that the FBI and Justice Department improperly spied on a Trump campaign aide.

In his message, Wray emphasized the importance of the FBI's work and encouraged agents to focus on their duties. "Talk is cheap; the work you do is what will endure," he wrote. "We speak through our work. One case at a time. One decision at a time."

The FBI had expressed "grave concerns" about the accuracy of the memo, stating that they were only provided a limited opportunity to review it before its release. The document focuses on a 2016 surveillance warrant approved to monitor former Trump campaign adviser Carter Page, which was based on a dossier prepared by a British intelligence agent whose work was funded in part by Democrats.

Wray's memo aimed to reassure the agency's employees that their work remains a priority, despite the controversy surrounding the memo. "We're going to keep doing that work because we know who and what we are and because we know our mission comes first," he said. "The American people come first."

Title: Record Low Unemployment Masks Concerns Over Student Loan Debt

Article:

The United States has seen its lowest unemployment rate in 50 years, but a recent report from DBRS Morningstar reveals that a record one-quarter of student loans from a popular federal program qualified for easier repayment plans to help borrowers avoid default. As of the fourth-quarter of 2019, 24.7% of $452 billion worth of student loans with U.S. government backing were using income-based repayment plans, up from 21.8% a year earlier.

The income-based repayment plans, introduced by the Obama administration in 2009, aim to help borrowers avoid default by capping loan repayments at 10% to 15% of their discretionary income. The program also offers forgiveness of any remaining balance after 20 to 25 years. This has led to reduced monthly loan payments for over 1.6 million student loan borrowers, with some lower-income students facing no monthly payments at all.

The popularity of income-based payment options has soared since 2011, with the program's utilization expected to remain elevated in the foreseeable future. The report highlights the ongoing concerns over the nation's record $1.5 trillion pile of student loan debt, which has become the second-largest source of U.S. household debt behind mortgages.

The Federal Reserve Bank of New York estimates that 11.1% of all student loans were in default or seriously delinquent (more than 90 days past due) during the fourth-quarter, although it notes that this figure is likely higher due to the fact that roughly half of student loans are in some form of deferment, grace period, or forbearance and not counted as in "repayment."

Title: Virginia's Gubernatorial Election: A Choice Between Two Unpopular Candidates

The state of Virginia will hold its gubernatorial election on November 5, with voters facing a choice between two candidates who are not well-liked by many. Terry McAuliffe, a 56-year-old businessman, and Ken T. Cuccinelli II, a 45-year-old lawyer, are the two main contenders. However, a third-party candidate, Robert Sarvis, a 37-year-old lawyer and entrepreneur, is also running.

McAuliffe's claim to fame is his fundraising abilities, having raised hundreds of millions of dollars for Bill Clinton and his wife. He is involved in two federal investigations and has faced criticism for his business dealings, including allegations of profiting from terminally ill people. Cuccinelli, on the other hand, is a self-proclaimed "homegrown, up-from-the-bootstraps" candidate who has been criticized for his stance on women's issues and reproductive health.

Sarvis, a Libertarian candidate, has a unique background, having studied mathematics at Harvard and economics at George Mason University. He has a law degree from NYU and has worked in software development and founded a company that developed apps for Google's Android operating system. Sarvis has a more moderate stance on issues such as abortion, gay marriage, and marijuana legalization.

The latest polls suggest that turnout could set a new record low, with many voters planning to cast their ballots against one candidate rather than for the other. Sarvis is currently polling at 13%, which is not bad for a third-party candidate but not enough to win.

The election has sparked concerns about the state of American politics, with many feeling that the two major parties do not adequately represent the American people. A Gallup poll in October found that 60% of Americans believe a third major party is needed, and 26% believe the two major parties adequately represent Americans.

While a vote for Sarvis may seem futile and stupid, the situation is dire, and many are questioning the choice between two unqualified candidates. The election has become a "do-or-die" decision, with some calling for a "really futile and stupid gesture" to be made.

Title: Pentagon Reviews Video of Bergdahl's Handover in Afghanistan

The Pentagon is reviewing a video showing the handover of American prisoner of war Sergeant Bowe Bergdahl in eastern Afghanistan's Khost province, near Pakistan. The video, posted online early Wednesday, shows Bergdahl sitting in the back of a pickup truck, wearing white clothing, surrounded by over a dozen Taliban fighters. The exchange, which took place in a valley, is brief, with participants holding up their hands to one another and exchanging handshakes before waving their farewells.

According to Pentagon Press Secretary John Kirby, the exchange was peaceful and successful, and the focus remains on getting Bergdahl the care he needs. Kirby stated that the Pentagon has no reason to doubt the video's authenticity, but is reviewing it nonetheless.

The exchange of Bergdahl for five Taliban prisoners held in Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, has sparked questions about the circumstances of his capture in Afghanistan and the legality of the prisoner exchange. Members of Congress have expressed concerns that they were not given advance notice of the deal. President Obama has stated that the White House had spoken "for some time" about a possible prisoner swap for Bergdahl, and his administration says it had to act quickly to free him.

The Army is conducting a comprehensive investigation into Bergdahl's disappearance and captivity, with Secretary of the Army John McHugh stating that the service is happy to have Bergdahl back. A congressional hearing on the matter is scheduled for next week, with more hearings expected to follow.

Title: Obama's Tax Hike Proposal Faces Skepticism Amid Concerns Over Unintended Consequences

Article: President Obama's proposal to raise taxes on America's highest earners has been met with skepticism, with some economists questioning the effectiveness of the plan in reducing the nation's deficit. The plan, which would increase the marginal tax rate to 39.6% for those earning over $250,000, is seen as a "class-warfare" measure by some, with critics arguing that it may not generate the expected revenue and could have unintended consequences.

Historically, similar tax hikes have resulted in less additional revenue than expected, and the experience of then-British Prime Minister Gordon Brown's 2010 proposal to increase the marginal tax rate by 10% for those earning over $1 million serves as a cautionary tale. The number of individuals declaring incomes above $1 million dropped from 16,000 to 6,000 in the 2010-2011 tax year, according to Her Majesty's Revenue and Customs, the UK's tax collection agency. The wealthiest 9% of Britons, who previously composed 4.4% of the country's tax pool, saw their share drop by half after the proposal.

Economists point to the fact that the rich have more control over their income and can respond easily to tax increases by reducing their taxable income. One option for high earners to reduce their taxable income would be to move their wealth into tax-free bonds, said Daniel J. Mitchell, a fiscal policy expert at the Cato Institute.

Kent Smetters, an economics and public policy professor at the University of Pennsylvania Wharton School, noted that existing tax laws make it difficult for individuals to avoid taxes, but added that the rich already pay a significant portion of the U.S. tax base due to the difficulty in avoiding taxes. Smetters stated that the Treasury Department can deem tax shelters as illegal, making it challenging for individuals to avoid taxes.

The article highlights the skepticism surrounding President Obama's tax hike proposal, with some economists questioning its effectiveness in reducing the deficit and warning of potential unintended consequences.

Title: Mother of El Paso Shooting Suspect Contacted Police Weeks Before Attack, Attorneys Say

The mother of the man charged in the El Paso shooting that left 22 people dead and dozens injured contacted the Allen Police Department weeks before the attack, expressing concern about her son's ownership of an "AK"-type firearm. According to attorneys Chris and R. Jack Ayres, the mother made the call to the police department in the suspect's hometown of Allen, Texas, a Dallas suburb. The attorneys stated that the mother was not motivated by a concern that her son was a threat to anyone, but rather was seeking information about the legalities of her son owning the weapon.

The mother reportedly told the police that she was concerned about her son's age, maturity level, and lack of experience, but was informed by a public safety officer that her 21-year-old son was legally allowed to possess the weapon. The attorneys emphasized that the mother did not identify herself or her son during the call.

A family statement released by Chris Ayres to the media said that the suspected shooter acted outside the family's teachings and values, stating, "He was raised in a family that taught love, kindness, respect, and tolerance – rejecting all forms of racism, prejudice, hatred, and violence." The statement also expressed condolences to the victims of the tragedy.

The Allen Police Department has not confirmed the call, with Sgt. Jon Felty stating, "I have nothing in the database to support this claim."

The suspect, Patrick Crusius, drove 580 miles from Allen to El Paso, a city with a high concentration of Latinos, after posting a racist screed online. He surrendered to police with his hands up about a quarter-mile from the El Paso Walmart where the attack occurred. Crusius faces charges of capital murder in state court and may face federal hate crime charges that could carry a death sentence if convicted.

Title: UN Security Council Divided on Gaza Violence, Kuwait Calls for Independent Investigation

The United Nations Security Council is divided on the recent violence in Gaza, with Kuwait calling for an independent investigation into the deaths of Palestinians along the border fence. Kuwait's Ambassador Mansour Ayyad Al-Otaibi expressed disappointment that the Security Council did not agree to his country's request for an independent inquiry, stating that Kuwait might instead seek an investigation by the United Nations Human Rights Office.

The United States, however, defended Israel's actions, with Ambassador Nikki R. Haley denouncing what she called a "double standard" applied to Israel. She emphasized that no country acts with more restraint than Israel and that Hamas was responsible for inciting protesters to storm the fence. Haley also linked the violence to the recent opening of the United States' embassy in Jerusalem, stating that President Trump's recognition of Jerusalem as Israel's capital makes peace more achievable.

The UN special coordinator for Middle East peace, Nickolay Mladenov, addressed the Security Council, urging both sides to exercise restraint. He emphasized that Israel has a responsibility to calibrate its use of force and not use lethal force except as a last resort under imminent threat of death or serious injury. Mladenov also called on Hamas to refrain from using the protests as cover to attempt to place bombs at the fence and create provocations.

Meanwhile, thousands of Palestinian refugees rallied in southern Lebanon on Tuesday to commemorate the "Nakba" and show solidarity with the Gaza demonstrations. Many were bused in from the longstanding refugee camps in Lebanon, where Palestinians face limited rights and restrictions. Over 450,000 of the five million registered Palestinian refugees worldwide live in Lebanon, where they are banned from owning property, attending public schools, and working in over 30 professions.

Title: Former FBI Director James Comey Admits to Being "Wrong" and "Over Confident" About FBI Procedures in Trump-Russia Investigation

Former FBI Director James Comey has acknowledged that he was "wrong" and "over confident" about the FBI's procedures used during the investigation into the Trump campaign's alleged ties to Russia in the 2016 election. In an interview on "Fox News Sunday," Comey admitted that the FBI's procedures were flawed and that he was too confident in their effectiveness.

Comey's admission comes after the release of a damning report by Justice Department Inspector General Michael Horowitz, which criticized the FBI's handling of the investigation. The report found that the FBI had made significant errors in its procedures, including the use of an unverified dossier as part of the application for a FISA warrant to surveil Trump campaign aide Carter Page.

Comey defended the FBI's actions, saying that the dossier was just one part of a broader mosaic of evidence used to justify the warrant application. However, host Chris Wallace pushed back, pointing out that the Horowitz report called the dossier a "central" component of the application. Comey acknowledged that he and Horowitz may not be saying different things, but Wallace countered that the report's findings essentially refute Comey's excuse.

Current FBI Director Christopher Wray has also weighed in on the report, stating that the FBI is taking over 40 steps to fix the problems identified by Horowitz. Wray's comments were echoed by Horowitz himself, who told the Senate Judiciary Committee that no one involved in the warrant application process should feel vindicated.

Comey also criticized Attorney General William Barr for suggesting that the FBI's errors may have been intentional, saying that the facts do not support such a claim.

Title: Obama Administration Clarifies Contraceptive Coverage Rules, Mandates Insurance Coverage for All FDA-Approved Methods

The Obama administration has issued new guidance on contraceptive coverage, requiring insurance providers to cover at least one brand of contraception in each of 18 different methods outlined by the Food and Drug Administration (FDA). This clarification comes after reports emerged that some insurance carriers were refusing to cover all types of contraceptives, leaving women with limited options.

Under the new rules, insurers must cover at least one brand of contraception in each of the 18 FDA-approved methods, including oral contraceptives, emergency contraception, and the vaginal ring. Insurers can still impose costs to encourage the use of generic drugs over brand-name drugs, but if a doctor or hospital recommends a specific drug or device due to medical necessity, the plan must cover it without additional cost.

The new guidance aims to ensure that women have access to the birth control methods recommended by their healthcare providers. The Affordable Care Act (ACA) requires insurance providers to cover birth control without out-of-pocket costs, but some insurers had been refusing to fully cover all types of contraceptives, leaving women with limited options.

The National Women's Law Center praised the new guidance, stating that it is "now absolutely clear that all means all – all unique birth control methods for women must be covered." The organization had previously criticized insurers for using "medical management" to skirt the rules or plead ignorance.

The new guidance also addresses concerns about insurers imposing costs for certain procedures, such as sterilization. The Health and Human Services Department (HHS) clarified that insurers can impose costs to encourage the use of generic drugs over brand-name drugs, but if a doctor or hospital recommends a specific drug or device due to medical necessity, the plan must cover it without additional cost.

The guidance is part of broader efforts to improve women's health services, including requiring free screenings for women susceptible to certain types of cancer and not charging extra for anesthesia services provided with preventive colonoscopies.

New York Attorney General Eric T. Schneiderman has proposed legislation that would write Obamacare's coverage requirement into state law and add extra consumer protections, including requiring insurance coverage for men's sterilization procedures. The proposal would also allow consumers to get a year's worth of contraception at a time.

The Obama administration's clarification on contraceptive coverage is seen as a step towards ensuring that women have access to the birth control methods recommended by their healthcare providers. The guidance is expected to take effect in future plan years, and insurers can no longer argue that they are using "good faith" in more narrowly interpreting the current rules.

Title: Trump's Decision to Cancel Taliban Talks: A Necessary Step in Ensuring American Security

The recent cancellation of a planned summit between President Trump and Taliban leaders has sparked criticism from some Democrats, who argue that the decision was a sign of uncertainty and a lack of commitment to achieving a peace deal in Afghanistan. However, a closer examination of the situation reveals that Trump's decision was a necessary step in ensuring American security and avoiding a potential disaster.

The Taliban, responsible for the deaths of nearly 2,000 Americans and countless Afghans, are not a trustworthy partner in negotiations. The group's intentions are clear: to continue their terrorist activities and impose their brand of Islamism on the Afghan people. The United States has a responsibility to ensure that Afghanistan does not become a haven for terrorists again, as it did before 9/11.

The administration's decision to seek an alternative to the current stalemate in Afghanistan is a necessary step towards achieving this goal. While some may argue that negotiating with the Taliban is a bitter pill to swallow, it is a necessary evil in order to prevent a return to the pre-9/11 era.

The alternative to a deal with the Taliban is not a simple one. The United States must ensure that Afghanistan does not fall back into the hands of the Taliban, which would be a betrayal of the Afghan government and a return to medieval barbarity. The country's women and children would be left to the mercy of Taliban murderers, a scenario that would be a dishonorable conclusion to the longest war in American history.

While some may criticize Trump's decision as an excuse for his uncertainty about the deal, it is clear that the Taliban have no intention of stopping their terrorist attacks. The president was right to call a halt to the talks once he understood that the outcome would not ensure American security or the security of the Afghan people.

The problem is not Trump's theatrical style, but the process itself, which does not seem likely to accomplish anything but give the United States a diplomatic fig leaf to cover up a desire to bug out and leave a mess behind. The recent examples of President Obama's failed attempts to negotiate with Iran and Iraq demonstrate the importance of a more cautious approach.

In conclusion, while Trump's decision to cancel the summit may not have been a popular one, it was a necessary step towards ensuring American security and avoiding a potential disaster. The United States must prioritize its security and the security of the Afghan people, rather than seeking a deal that would leave them vulnerable to the Taliban's brutal rule.

Title: President Obama Endorses Hillary Clinton for President, Vows to Campaign with Her

Article:

President Barack Obama has formally endorsed Hillary Clinton as his successor in the White House, praising her as the most qualified candidate to hold the office. In a video message posted on Clinton's campaign website, Obama stated, "I know how hard this job can be. That's why I know Hillary will be so good at it. In fact, I don't think there's ever been someone so qualified to hold this office."

The endorsement comes as Clinton is set to campaign with Obama on June 15 in Green Bay, Wisconsin. Clinton tweeted her excitement about the partnership, saying she's "fired up" and ready to go.

Vice President Joe Biden also voiced his support for Clinton, stating, "Anybody who thinks that whoever the next president is – and God willing, it will be Secretary Clinton."

The White House announced that Obama recorded the video on Tuesday, the day Clinton effectively wrapped up the nomination. The video was released shortly after Obama met with Bernie Sanders in the Oval Office.

Sanders, who has vowed to stay in the race until the final primary in Washington, D.C., on June 14, expressed a conciliatory tone, saying he plans to meet with Clinton soon to discuss how they can "work together to defeat Donald Trump."

The meeting between Obama and Sanders was private, with no staff or aides present. Sanders congratulated Clinton on her "very strong campaign" and thanked Obama for his "impartiality" throughout the process.

The endorsement reflects the desire of party leaders to unify the party as the general election battle between Clinton and presumptive rival Donald Trump intensifies.

Title: Lobbying Activity in Washington Reaches Highest Level Since 2010, Reaching $3.34 Billion

The Center for Responsive Politics has released its annual tally of lobbying activity in Washington, revealing that spending reached $3.34 billion in 2017, the highest level since 2010. This surge in spending was driven by corporations, trade groups, and other interests seeking to shape policy on issues such as tax legislation, immigration, and healthcare.

According to the center's data, powerful trade groups like the U.S. Chamber of Commerce and the National Association of Realtors spent the most money to influence policy in 2017. The National Association of Realtors, in particular, spent $22.2 million in the fourth quarter alone, double what it spent in the previous three months. The group's aggressive lobbying campaign focused on shaping the tax overhaul, with successes including preserving an exemption from capital gains taxes and beating back provisions that would have limited the mortgage interest deduction.

Individual companies also saw significant increases in their lobbying spending, with Google reporting $18 million in federal spending, a new high for the tech giant. Google lobbied on a range of issues, including cyber-security, tax legislation, and immigration, including President Trump's controversial executive orders on refugees and immigrants.

The Open Society Policy Center, aligned with liberal billionaire George Soros, reported $16.1 million in spending, a record for the organization since it began reporting federal lobbying in 2002. The center's lobbying efforts focused on issues such as limiting child trafficking and measures introduced by congressional Democrats to prohibit President Trump from making a preemptive strike against North Korea without congressional approval.

The surge in lobbying activity comes as lawmakers consider a range of issues, including regulating online advertising and addressing Russia's use of social media platforms to influence the 2016 presidential election.

Title: Medicare Reform Debate: Romney and Ryan Criticize Obama's Cuts, Obama Attacks Ryan's Plan

The debate over Medicare reform has intensified as both presidential candidates, Mitt Romney and Barack Obama, present their plans to address the entitlement program's financial sustainability. Romney and his running mate, Paul Ryan, have accused Obama of hurting seniors by slashing $716 billion from Medicare, while Obama has countered that Ryan's plan would "end Medicare as we know it."

The Obama administration's Affordable Care Act (ACA) aims to reduce Medicare spending by decreasing provider rates, including those for hospitals and insurers. In contrast, Ryan's plan would turn Medicare over to the private sector by providing seniors with vouchers to purchase coverage from insurance providers. Both plans include spending caps, but under the ACA, providers could face larger decreases if costs grow faster than projected, while Ryan's plan would shift any additional expenses to beneficiaries.

The debate has become a crucial issue in the election, as both parties vie for the support of senior citizens. The future of Medicare is expected to be unsustainable by 2024, prompting both sides to seek ways to curb the program's costs.

Obama's health reform law saves money by reducing payments to hospitals, skilled nursing facilities, home health care agencies, and insurers providing Medicare Advantage managed care plans. The law also creates the Independent Payment Advisory Board, tasked with keeping Medicare costs under control. The law specifies that benefits cannot be cut to reduce expenses.

Ryan's budget proposal would retain a traditional fee-for-service Medicare option but would also allow insurers to offer seniors a range of choices. The government would provide a "premium support" payment to cover the cost of either traditional Medicare or the second-least expensive insurer's plan, whichever is less. Seniors could pay for additional coverage, such as dental or vision benefits.

Consumer advocates worry that seniors would end up paying more for care under the Ryan plan, citing a Congressional Budget Office report showing spending would be between 35% and 42% lower for new enrollees under the Ryan plan compared to traditional Medicare. Supporters of the Ryan plan argue that senior citizens would sacrifice under Obama's health reform law, as many providers could stop accepting Medicare if rates are slashed too low.

Title: ICE's Priority Enforcement Program Fails to Target "Worst of the Worst" as Many Detainees Have No Criminal Convictions

The Priority Enforcement Program (PEP), aimed at expediting the deportation of "criminal aliens," has been found to be missing its target. According to a recent analysis by the Transactional Records Access Clearinghouse at Syracuse University, half of the "holds" placed on immigrants suspected of violating US immigration law had no criminal convictions. This means that many individuals, including those arrested for traffic violations or having charges dropped, are being detained and potentially deported.

The analysis found that only one-quarter of the detainees had committed serious offenses, such as murder or sexual assault. The most common conviction was for drunk driving, followed by miscellaneous assaults and simple traffic offenses. This raises concerns about the effectiveness of the PEP program in targeting the "worst of the worst" as intended.

Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) claims to have narrowed its criteria under the PEP program, which was started in 2008. However, the agency's own data shows that it is targeting individuals with no criminal record at a slightly higher rate than before. ICE's spokeswoman, Sarah Rodriquez, stated that the agency is making "significant strides" to ensure a "common-sense approach" that focuses on convicted criminals and individuals who threaten public safety and national security.

However, critics argue that the PEP program is not achieving its intended goals. Maria Sotomayor, an undocumented immigrant, expressed concerns that the program is not keeping anyone secure and that it may discourage victims of crime from reporting incidents to the police. The agency's efforts to consider "important community policing needs" may also be falling short.

The PEP program has been met with resistance from some local law enforcement agencies, with at least 377 agencies refusing to honor ICE's requests to hold immigrants in detention. The agency claims that 17 of the 25 jurisdictions with the highest number of declined detainers are now participating in the program.

Unauthorized immigration in the US remains a complex issue, with approximately 11.3 million people living in the country without legal papers. The PEP program's effectiveness in addressing this issue is still unclear, and immigration advocates are suing to obtain more details on how the program differs from its predecessor.

Title: Federal Judge Halts Border Wall Construction, Trump Vows to Appeal

Article:

A federal judge in California has blocked the construction of a border wall along the US-Mexico border, dealing a significant blow to President Donald Trump's plans. Judge Haywood Gilliam, an Obama appointee, ruled that the administration overstepped its powers by attempting to redirect military funds to build the wall, which was not authorized by Congress.

The judge's preliminary injunction halts construction on sections of the wall near El Paso, Texas, and Yuma, Arizona, which were already underway. The ruling is a significant setback for Trump, who had been counting on his emergency powers to tap into Pentagon funds to build the wall.

The administration had argued that Congress did not explicitly deny the ability to use the funds, and that the National Emergencies Act allowed for reprogramming of funds within the Defense Department. However, Judge Gilliam disagreed, stating that the Constitution does not require Congress to foresee every circumstance in which the president might make mischief with money. Instead, the president is bound only to spend on exactly what Congress authorizes.

The ruling is a significant blow to Trump's plans, which had been met with opposition from Democrats and some Republicans. The administration had requested $1.6 billion in border wall funding for 2019, which was later increased to $5 billion and then $5.7 billion. Congress ultimately approved $1.375 billion, and Trump signed the legislation in February.

The judge's ruling does not affect the administration's plans to tap into other funds, including $3.6 billion in military construction funds and $601 million from a Treasury Department forfeiture fund. However, given the reasoning in the opinion, it is unlikely that Judge Gilliam would find the use of these funds for a border wall legal.

The ruling is part of a larger legal battle over Trump's emergency declaration, with cases in Texas and Washington, D.C. still pending.

Title: Obama's Second Term Faced with Challenges and Low Approval Ratings

President Barack Obama is entering the second half of his second term, with his approval ratings at a low point. Just a year after his re-election, Obama's second term is already feeling long and fruitless. The president's hopes that his re-election would "break the fever" of Republican opposition have not materialized, and his legislative agenda is stuck.

According to a Gallup poll released Tuesday, Obama's approval rating has dropped to 39 percent, a low point in his presidency. House Republicans consider everything Obama proposes to be dead on arrival, and the major legislation he pushed through during his first term, the Affordable Care Act, remains contentious.

The fact that the law's rollout has been plagued by problems has put the president on the defensive. Obama and other Democrats can blame Republicans for being intransigent, but the fact that the two parties are locked in a cycle of recrimination does not bode well for future deal-making.

Obama has achieved some successes, such as the tax package enacted at the start of the year, which raised income tax rates for top earners. However, he has been unable to replace the across-the-board spending cuts known as sequestration or reach a broader budget agreement with Republicans.

The president's second-term priorities, such as immigration reform, have stalled in the House, and his legislative prospects are not looking bright. Republicans, meanwhile, see no need to compromise and are instead focusing on blocking Obama's agenda.

The election results in Virginia, where the Democratic candidate won by a narrower margin than expected, have given Republicans hope that they can continue to obstruct Obama's policies. The president's broken promise about people being able to keep their insurance plans has also become a liability, and Republicans are likely to continue to blame the Affordable Care Act for any negative consequences.

For Obama, the second half of his second term is likely to be a challenging period, as he tries to sell ideas that his opponents will never accept.

Title: Cruz Campaign Finances: A Look at the Senator's Financial Decisions

The article provides insight into the financial decisions made by Senator Ted Cruz and his wife, Heidi, in 2012, when they decided to put their savings into his Senate campaign. In a 2013 interview with The New York Times, Mr. Cruz recalled that his wife immediately agreed to his proposal, despite being behind in the polls and facing a significant financial disadvantage against Lt. Gov. David Dewhurst, who spent $24 million of his own money on the race.

According to Mr. Cruz, his wife's initial response was "absolutely," with no hesitation. However, Heidi Cruz later told Politico in 2014 that she believed they should apply "common investment sense" and not use their own money for the campaign unless it made a difference in winning. The article does not mention any loans from banks.

The Cruzes' financial contributions allowed his campaign to continue running television ads, including a $300,000 ad buy highlighting Mr. Cruz's father's story of fleeing Cuba in the 1950s. Mr. Cruz went on to win the general election after defeating Mr. Dewhurst in the primary runoff.

The article also provides a breakdown of the Cruzes' financial assets and liabilities, as reported in their Senate ethics filings. At the close of 2011, they had cash and securities worth $1.3 million to $3.4 million, with mortgages and a loan against Mr. Cruz's partnership equity in his law firm. In 2012, they sold securities worth $82,000 to $355,000, and the value of other holdings was reduced by up to $155,000. However, they also added a money-market account with $250,000 to $500,000 and the value of other holdings increased by as much as $435,000. Overall, the value of their cash and securities saw a net increase of up to $400,000, despite the Cruzes supposedly liquidating their assets to finance Mr. Cruz's Senate campaign.

Title: Obama's Claims on Muslim Terrorism Rebutted

Article:

Former President Barack Obama has made a statement about the Muslim community's stance on terrorism, claiming that "99.9 percent of Muslims worldwide reject terrorism." However, this assertion has been met with skepticism and scrutiny. While it is true that some Muslims have condemned the recent attacks in Paris, this does not necessarily translate to a blanket rejection of terrorism.

Pew Research, a non-partisan organization, has conducted extensive polling on Muslim opinions about current events. According to their findings, only 57 percent of Muslims in nine predominantly Islamic countries hold an unfavorable opinion of al-Qaeda. This number is significantly lower than Obama's claimed 99.9 percent.

Furthermore, Pew Research also found that one-third of Muslims support Hamas, a group responsible for numerous terrorist attacks, including the 2002 Passover massacre in Netanya, Israel. This statistic is a stark reminder that not all Muslims reject terrorism.

Obama's statement has been criticized for being overly simplistic and inaccurate. His claim that Muslims have fought in every American war and that 3,500 Muslims serve in the nation's military services today is true, but it does not necessarily translate to a rejection of terrorism.

The article concludes that while it is true that a minority of Muslims support terrorism, the majority of Muslims do not reject it. The author, Wesley Pruden, argues that Obama's statement serves no good purpose by distorting the facts and perpetuating a simplistic narrative.

Title: Trump Denies Campaign Funds Played Role in Hush-Money Payment to Stormy Daniels

The President of the United States, Donald Trump, has made his first public statements since Rudy Giuliani, his lawyer, revealed that Trump reimbursed attorney Michael Cohen for a $130,000 payment to adult film star Stormy Daniels, whose real name is Stephanie Clifford. Trump claimed the money was intended to stop "false" allegations and stressed that campaign funds played no role in the transaction.

In a series of tweets, Trump explained that Cohen, an attorney, received a monthly retainer, not from the campaign, and that the payment was a private contract between two parties, known as a non-disclosure agreement (NDA). Trump stated that the agreement was used to stop the "false and extortionist accusations" made by Daniels about an alleged affair, and that the agreement was in full force and effect and would be used in arbitration for damages against Daniels.

Trump also referred to a letter written and signed by Daniels in January, stating that allegations of an affair with Trump were "absolutely false." However, Giuliani revealed on Fox News that Trump did not know the details of the payment until a couple of weeks ago, and that Trump thought the payment was to cover unspecified "expenses."

Giuliani emphasized that the payment was personal and disputed any suggestion that it was an unreported campaign contribution. "He was trying to help the family... I think he was just being a good lawyer," Giuliani said. "That money was not campaign money. It's not campaign money. No campaign finance violation."

The controversy surrounding the payment has sparked concerns about potential campaign finance violations. Richard L. Hasen, an expert in election law at the University of California, Irvine, noted that if the payments were considered campaign-related expenses, the onus may have been on the president or his campaign to report it as a loan.

Daniels' attorney, Michael Avenatti, stated on MSNBC's "Morning Joe" that if it is true that Trump reimbursed Cohen, it is a "crime" with "serious consequences." Cohen previously stated that the money he paid to Daniels came out of his own pocket, which seems to contradict Trump's and Giuliani's statements.

The investigation into Cohen's personal business dealings is ongoing, and the controversy surrounding the payment is likely to continue to unfold in the coming days.

Title: Homeland Security Secretary Addresses Immigration Policy and Sanctuary Cities

The Homeland Security Secretary, Jeh Johnson, testified before the House Judiciary Committee on Tuesday, addressing the recent murder of Kathryn Steinle, a 32-year-old woman killed while walking with her father in San Francisco. The incident has refocused the immigration debate, with attention shifting from lenient treatment for illegal immigrants to the victims of illegal immigration.

Johnson acknowledged that the administration made a mistake in releasing an illegal immigrant, Juan Francisco Lopez-Sanchez, to San Francisco ahead of the murder. However, he emphasized that there is little the government can do to pressure sanctuary cities to change their policies. He has made personal appeals to San Francisco to reconsider its refusal to cooperate with federal immigration agents and will continue to do so.

The Secretary also stated that several dozen jurisdictions that had previously refused to cooperate have already signed up or signaled interest in working with the new Priority Enforcement Program. He emphasized the importance of promoting public safety and getting jurisdictions to cooperate with the program.

Some lawmakers, including Rep. Trey Gowdy, expressed skepticism about the effectiveness of making personal appeals to sanctuary cities and questioned why the administration did not take a tougher stance. Rep. Steve Chabot suggested that the administration should reach out to the Steinle family, as they had done with families involved in high-profile encounters with the police.

The article also highlighted the controversy surrounding the sanctuary city policy, which allows cities and counties to refuse to cooperate with federal immigration agents. The administration has taken a softer stance on this issue, with ICE Director Sarah R. Saldana initially expressing support for a law forcing communities to cooperate, but later retracting her statement after receiving a talking-to from Secretary Johnson.

In terms of border security, Johnson reported that border patrol agents are on pace to apprehend fewer than 400,000 illegal immigrants this year, which could be the lowest total since the 1970s. The agency attributes this to fewer people attempting to cross the border. However, Homeland Security has focused on deporting illegal immigrants with serious criminal histories, which has led to a decrease in deportations and unused detention beds.

The article also mentioned that over 1,000 criminal aliens released into the community while awaiting deportation in 2014 were convicted of still more crimes after their release, including kidnapping, sexual assault against a child, and vehicular homicide.

Title: Edward Snowden's Whereabouts Remain a Mystery as Diplomatic Wrangling Continues

Edward Snowden, the former NSA contractor wanted for leaking classified information, has been missing in action for over a week, sparking a global diplomatic wrangle. Despite reports of his presence in Moscow's Sheremetyevo Airport's transit zone, Snowden's exact whereabouts remain unknown.

Russian officials claim he is not on their territory, while the US government believes he is still in the airport. Reporters have flocked to the airport, but so far, no one has been able to find him. Even Snowden's father, Lonnie Snowden, is struggling to establish a direct communication link with his son.

Ian Phillips, the Associated Press Eastern Europe news director, spent 21 hours in the transit zone last week, but was unable to locate Snowden. He believes the most likely place for Snowden to be hiding is the Novotel hotel, which has a wing that jutting into the international transit zone. However, Phillips noted that there are many other possible hiding spots in the area.

WikiLeaks, which is helping Snowden, has promised to release more information about his whereabouts and how he evaded detection. The group tweeted that it would make several important announcements on Monday, but so far, no details have been provided.

WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange was tight-lipped about Snowden's situation during a Sunday show interview, stating that it is a matter of international diplomatic negotiations. Russian news reports claimed Snowden was staying at a hotel in the terminal, but The Associated Press was unable to confirm this.

The US government still believes Snowden is at the Moscow airport, but his exact location remains a mystery. The Associated Press sent a reporter to the transit zone last week, who found no sign of Snowden at the on-site hotel or any worker who would confirm his presence. The reporter noted that there are many small rooms where someone could potentially hide, but Snowden was not found in any of the VIP lounge areas.

Snowden's father, Lonnie, is trying to establish a direct communication link with his son and has sent a letter to the Justice Department outlining his son's legal options. The letter includes requests for Snowden not to be detained before trial, not to be subject to a gag order, and to have a trial in a venue of his choosing. However, the attorney for Snowden's father clarified that these are not ultimatums and that the family is respecting Snowden's wishes.

Title: The Importance of Challenging Biased News Coverage

The media has significant influence in shaping cultural guidelines and political discourse. It is crucial that news outlets, along with other institutions, strive to be accurate and unbiased.
