The recent reports that the new chief executive of Voice of America and its sister organizations is refusing to renew visas for hundreds of foreign journalists, potentially exposing them to retaliation for their reporting, have raised concerns that he may be trying to co-opt the foreign broadcasters for political ends. Voice of America and other publicly funded international broadcasters are trusted and popular news sources around the globe, precisely because they are walled off from political pressure.

The reports come on the heels of other indications that the Trump administration may be trying to interfere with the broadcasters' editorial independence. In late April, the White House baselessly attacked VOA as Chinese "propaganda." More recently, Michael Pack, the new chief executive at the U.S. Agency for Global Media, which administers the broadcasters, moved quickly to fire senior leadership and is now reportedly refusing to act on the visa applications, effectively terminating these foreign journalists and depriving the USAGM broadcasters of expertise that is essential for their reporting.

While Pack certainly has the authority to manage the USAGM, he cannot interfere with the legal "firewall" that past presidents and Congress have progressively built over many decades to safeguard the editorial independence of U.S. international broadcasters from political influence. To the extent these moves by the White House and Pack presage a frontal attack on the firewall, all Americans should be deeply concerned.

Legally, the firewall has several elements, but rests on two fundamental pillars. One, under statute, international broadcasters must adhere to the highest standards of journalism, including transparency, comprehensiveness, balance, accuracy, and strict autonomy. Two, political appointees, like Pack and the secretary of state, are barred from interfering in the "professional independence and integrity" of the broadcasting services. Any effort by Pack or others in the administration to dictate news content would likely be illegal.

Furthermore, journalists and editors at the USAGM broadcasters have First Amendment rights independent of their status as government employees and contractors. The news staff at VOA and the other broadcasters are members of the media, and efforts to interfere with their work could trigger basic First Amendment protections, like the right to gather news, the right to be free from a "prior restraint" (were Pack to try and block a story's publication, for instance), and prohibitions on official retaliation for protected speech.

Moreover, particularly with respect to the foreign journalists now facing what amounts to firing as their visas expire, Pack's moves may violate civil service protections. It is well established that career government employees may not be terminated based on national origin. Additionally, the firewall itself may protect journalists and editors to the extent the decision not to renew their visas is an attempt to interfere with the broadcasters' independence.

Putting aside the law, however, efforts to interfere with the independence of publicly funded international broadcasters are just – practically speaking – unwise. For instance, both private and government researchers have extensively studied the role of U.S. international broadcasting during the Cold War. Time and again, autonomy, credibility, and professionalism have been identified as essential factors in their success. The ability of broadcasters like VOA, Radio Free Europe, and Radio Liberty to relay both good news and bad (including bad news about the U.S.) drove massive audience engagement and trust. The appeal was so pressing for officials in the Soviet Union and the Eastern Bloc that they spent the equivalent of hundreds of millions of dollars trying to jam the broadcasters' signals.

The public broadcasters also provided an essential counterweight to state-controlled media. To give just one example, when the nuclear reactor at Chernobyl suffered a catastrophic meltdown in 1986, foreign broadcasters were the first source of hard news on the disaster for millions of people behind the Iron Curtain, and it forced state-controlled media to grudgingly acknowledge the accident.

Finally, and of particular relevance to the foreign journalists who now face a forced return to countries where their reporting may have angered government officials, one other crucial factor for success was the ability of the public broadcasters to tailor their news to the audience. Émigré broadcasters with an intimate knowledge of the language and culture of listeners again bolstered credibility and thus advanced the effectiveness of U.S. public diplomacy. That talent is invaluable and irreplaceable, and for it to be squandered today for political reasons would be tragic.

Title: Consumer Price Index Falls, but Necessities Continue to Rise in Price

The Bureau of Labor Statistics reported a 0.1% decline in the consumer price index (CPI) in May, driven by decreases in energy, car insurance, clothing, and public transportation prices. The core rate of inflation, which excludes food and energy prices, also fell 0.1%, marking the first three-month decline in a row. However, experts question whether the CPI accurately reflects the experiences of many households, as most people spend a significant portion of their income on necessities like food, shelter, transportation, healthcare, and clothing.

According to researchers at the Brookings Institution, low-income households spend 82% of their income on these necessities, while middle-class families spend 78%, and high-income families spend about two-thirds. While some households may be able to delay buying clothes or reduce transportation spending due to the pandemic, others are still struggling to afford the absolute necessities.

Grocery prices rose 1% in May compared to April, with a 4.1% increase over the past three months, equivalent to an annual rate of 17.5%. Beef prices have risen 11% in just three months. Shelter prices, including rental and ownership costs, are still increasing, up 2.6% in the past year. For low-income families, who spend 41% of their income on housing, even a 0.2% monthly increase can be a significant burden.

While some households may be saving money due to reduced spending on transportation and other non-essential items, others are struggling to make ends meet. The country as a whole may be experiencing deflation, but not everyone is benefiting from falling prices. The only things going up in price are the bare necessities.

Title: Two Centuries of U.S. Immigration: A Visualized Journey

The United States has welcomed 79 million lawful permanent residents since 1820, with the interactive map below visualizing their countries of origin. The brightness of each country corresponds to its total migration to the U.S. during that time period. Users can control the animation to stop, resume, or move back and forth in time.

The map shows a clear pattern of immigration sources over the years. In the 1800s, Western Europe, particularly Ireland, Germany, and the U.K., were the primary sources of immigration. Toward the end of the century, Eastern European countries like Italy, Russia, and Hungary took over. In the early 1900s, most immigrants arrived from the Americas, specifically Canada and Mexico. In recent decades, there has been a significant increase in migration from Asia.

The article also highlights the largest immigration "waves" over time, with each wave often driven by persecution or economic troubles. The author notes that each wave has its own story, such as Jews fleeing Russia after the May Laws were enacted, the Irish Potato Famine, and the Cuban Revolution.

The data used for the map comes from the Department of Homeland Security's Office of Immigration Statistics, which tracks "persons obtaining lawful permanent resident status." This data does not include illegal immigration or forced immigration, such as those brought to the U.S. as slaves.

The article concludes by noting that the U.S. has played a significant role as a sanctuary for people fleeing troubles around the world, and the author is proud to be part of this history.

Title: US Unemployment Rate Drops Below 6% for First Time Since 2008, Job Market Continues to Grow

The United States unemployment rate has dipped below 6% for the first time since July 2008, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS). The nonfarm payrolls added 248,000 new jobs in September, exceeding expectations. The jobless rate fell 0.2 percentage points to 5.9%.

The BLS reports that employment increased in professional and business services, retail trade, and health care. The data were stronger than expected, with employers adding about 69,000 more jobs in July and August than initially reported.

The median forecast among economists surveyed by Bloomberg had called for 215,000 new jobs in September. Jason Furman, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, stated that the report extends the "longest streak of private-sector job growth on record." He attributed the strong economy to the hard work of the American people and the policies pursued by the President.

Many economists consider 5.5% unemployment a "healthy number," and as the unemployment rate moves closer to that figure, it could put pressure on the Federal Reserve to raise its benchmark interest rate. According to NPR, the decline in the unemployment rate has been largely attributed to job growth, rather than people leaving the labor force.

Dean Maki, chief US economist at Barclays PLC in New York, described the latest data as "strong across the board." He stated that the labor market continues to grow fast enough to keep pushing the unemployment rate down.

Despite the new jobs, nearly 100,000 people stopped looking for work. The number of Americans working or looking for work was at 62.7%, the lowest proportion since February 1978.

Title: Trump Vetoes Bipartisan Resolution to Block Border Emergency Declaration

Article:

President Donald Trump has used his first veto of his administration to reject a bipartisan resolution that aimed to block his declaration of a national emergency at the border. The move is likely to kill the measure, as lawmakers are unlikely to muster the two-thirds majority required to override the veto.

The resolution, which passed the Senate 59-41, was a rebuke to Trump's declaration, with 12 Senate Republicans joining Democrats in voting against it. Trump called the resolution "dangerous" and said it would revoke border operations put in place by the declaration. He thanked Republicans who voted against the resolution, calling them "strong Republican senators" who were "on our side and on the side of border security."

Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer, D-N.Y., criticized the veto, saying it was a sign that Trump had "chosen to trample all over the Constitution." House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, D-Calif., announced that the House will vote to override the veto on March 26.

The resolution had been passed by the Democrat-controlled House and aimed to block Trump's declaration, which he made last month after Congress granted only a fraction of the $5.7 billion he requested for a wall on the border. Declaring a national emergency allows Trump to steer an extra $3.6 billion to the wall.

Some Republicans, including Sens. Mitt Romney, R-Utah, and Marco Rubio, R-Fla., expressed concerns about the expansion of presidential power and voted against the declaration. Other Republicans, such as Sens. Susan Collins, R-Maine, and Lisa Murkowski, R-Alaska, opposed the declaration due to concerns about the constitutionality of the move.

The veto is likely the last word on the matter, as lawmakers are unlikely to muster the two-thirds majority required to override it.

Title: Yemeni Protesters Storm US Embassy Compound, Burning American Flag and Demanding Justice

Article:

Protesters in Yemen stormed the US Embassy compound in Sanaa, the capital city, in the latest attack on US diplomatic posts in the Middle East. The protesters, who considered a film they deemed blasphemous to Islam, smashed windows and breached the perimeter, but did not enter the main building housing the offices. They removed the US flag and replaced it with a black banner bearing Islam's declaration of faith, "There is no God but Allah."

Yemeni security forces responded by firing in the air and using tear gas to disperse the demonstrators, driving them out of the compound after about 45 minutes. It was unclear whether anyone was inside the embassy at the time of the attack.

The incident was similar to an attack on the US Embassy in Cairo, Egypt, on Tuesday night, and another in Benghazi, Libya, which resulted in the death of American Ambassador Chris Stevens and three other Americans. The US Embassy in Washington, D.C. condemned the attack, stating that the situation was under control and that the government of Yemen would honor its international obligations to ensure the safety of diplomats.

The movie "Innocence of Muslims" has been cited as the reason for the protests, which have spread to other countries in the region. The film's trailer, which depicts Muhammad as a fraud, womanizer, and madman, was dubbed into Arabic and posted on YouTube. The video-sharing website blocked access to the trailer on Wednesday.

In Iraq, several hundred Shiite hardliners protested in Baghdad's Shiite stronghold of Sadr City, with the leader of an Iranian-backed militia threatening anti-US attacks. In Iran, about 50 protesters shouted "Death to America" outside the Swiss Embassy, which represents US diplomatic interests.

The US Embassy in Baghdad did not respond to a request for comment. Egyptian protesters clashed with police near the US Embassy in Cairo for the third day in a row, with 16 protesters and 13 policemen wounded.

Title: Ted Cruz's Pedigree Adds Element of Disbelief to Liberal Disdain

Article:

Ted Cruz, a freshman senator from Texas, has been a target of liberal disdain over the past year. However, his academic background has added an extra layer of shock and disbelief to the criticism. Cruz attended Princeton and Harvard, where he excelled academically, earning a champion debater title at Princeton and graduating magna cum laude from Harvard. He also clerked for the Supreme Court and served as Texas solicitor general, arguing dozens of cases before the U.S. Supreme Court.

Cruz's intellectual credentials have led some to question his conservative politics, with some Princetonians stating that he is "a man of calcified thinking, dangerously impervious to facts." Democrats and liberal pundits would likely dislike Cruz regardless of his educational background, but his pedigree adds an extra element of shock to the disdain.

Cruz's opponents have criticized him for his aggressive approach to politics, which has led to him being labeled a "traitor to his class" by some. He has been accused of being a "man of calcified thinking, dangerously impervious to facts" and has been described as a "prosecutorial instincts of a Harvard-trained lawyer" by some. Cruz's opponents have also criticized him for his lack of subtlety, with some describing him as a "SWAT team" that "knocks down a drug suspect's front door" when he joins the Senate.

Cruz's opponents have also criticized him for his lack of defensiveness about his positions, which has led to some annoyance among his opponents. Despite these criticisms, Cruz has been a force in the Senate, and his push to defund Obamacare has been a contentious issue. While some have criticized his strategy as a "grass roots-pleasing slogan in search of a realistic path to legislative fruition," Cruz remains a prominent figure in American politics.

It is worth noting that Cruz's presidential aspirations have been a topic of discussion, and even if he does not ascend to the highest office, he will likely continue to be a force in the Senate.

**Mortgage Rates Hit Record Low Amid COVID-19 Concerns**

Mortgage rates in the United States have fallen to their lowest level ever, with the 30-year fixed-rate mortgage dropping to 3.29% during the week ending March 5, according to Freddie Mac. This significant decrease of 16 basis points from the previous week is a major windfall for millions of homeowners across the country, who can now save thousands of dollars in interest by refinancing. Additionally, an estimated 44.7 million homeowners have $6.2 trillion in home equity that they can access through a cash-out refinance, and now they have the chance to access that cash at a lower interest rate.

The decline in rates is largely attributed to concerns related to the economic impact of the COVID-19 outbreak, which has spread globally. "COVID-19 is here, and it will continue to be the main driver of mortgage rate movements in the coming weeks," said Zillow economist Matthew Speakman.

While interest rates on home loans had followed Treasurys downward in recent weeks, the spread between the two had widened to an extent. Lenders have been hesitant to trim rates at such a fast clip for many reasons, including the need to maintain their margins and not cut into their profits too much by reducing rates.

The decline in rates has stoked another refinancing boom, with mortgage applications increasing 10% last week from one year ago and showing no signs of slowing down, according to Freddie Mac. Those who are considering refinancing shouldn't wait on the sidelines, as it's not guaranteed mortgage rates will drop much further than where they are now.

However, there are some concerns that could prevent Americans from taking advantage of low rates. The possibility of government orders to shelter in place amid the coronavirus outbreak could create friction in the system, and the inventory of homes for sale has hit an all-time low, making it difficult for buyers to find a new home. Additionally, the overall health of the economy could also impact the housing market, with some experts predicting a weakening of the job market and a potential decline in the housing market.

Title: Pence and Kaine Face Off in Vice Presidential Debate, Focus on Policy Differences

The vice presidential debate between Governor Mike Pence of Indiana and Senator Tim Kaine of Virginia took place on October 4, with both candidates aiming to advance their party's agenda and challenge their opponents. The debate focused on policy differences, with Pence and Kaine lobbing fresh attacks on each other's bosses and delving into various issues.

Pence, who faced a barrage of incoming from Kaine, chose to deflect and ignore many of the attacks, instead focusing on raising controversies around Clinton's private email server and the family's charitable foundation. This strategy allowed him to avoid defending Trump on several issues, including his taxes, admiration for Russian President Vladimir Putin, and past comments about women and birtherism.

Kaine, on the other hand, came under fire for being overly aggressive and interrupting Pence frequently, particularly at the beginning of the debate. Despite this, he managed to get off some memorable one-liners that may be used in future Clinton campaign ads.

The debate also touched on the topic of faith, with both candidates discussing their personal beliefs. Pence spoke about the importance of the sanctity of life, while Kaine shared his struggles as governor of Virginia with the death penalty. The two candidates also discussed their views on abortion, with Pence criticizing the Clinton-Kaine ticket's support for abortion rights.

Overall, the debate provided a platform for Pence to score some points against Clinton and show Trump how to keep his cool during a debate. For Kaine, the debate was an opportunity to unload a torrent of sound bites against a Trump candidacy loaded with vulnerabilities.

Title: Obama Calls for Action After Sandy Hook Elementary School Shooting

President Barack Obama has vowed to press for meaningful action to prevent more mass shootings like the one that occurred at Sandy Hook Elementary School in Newtown, Connecticut, where 27 people were killed, including 20 children. The President's comments come as the nation mourns the loss of life and grapples with the tragedy.

The shooting, which occurred on Friday, has left many questions unanswered, including the origin of the firearms used in the massacre. Authorities have recovered a Glock, a Sig Sauer, and a.223 Bushmaster rifle near the body of the suspected shooter, Adam Lanza, 20. The guns were registered to Lanza's mother, Nancy Lanza, who was among the victims.

The AR-15, one of the most popular rifles in America, is under scrutiny after police say it was used in the massacre. The Connecticut shooting has sparked a renewed debate on gun control, with some calling for stricter laws and others arguing that restrictions are ineffective.

Connecticut has some of the toughest gun-ownership restrictions in the country, with residents required to undergo an extensive background check to purchase and carry a handgun. Assault weapons are banned in the state. However, gun-rights supporters argue that even in states with strict gun laws, criminals can still obtain firearms illegally.

The shooting has also raised questions about the effectiveness of gun-control measures. Some experts argue that even the most restrictive laws cannot prevent all mass shootings, citing the 2011 shootings at a Norwegian summer camp that killed dozens of people, despite Norway having some of the toughest gun laws in the world.

The Obama administration has taken steps to ease restrictions on gun ownership, including a 2011 rule that allowed gun owners to carry loaded weapons into National Parks and wildlife refuges as long as the relevant state's laws permitted it.

The President's comments on Friday were emotional, as he spoke of the children who were killed, saying, "The majority of those who died today were children—beautiful little kids between the ages of 5 and 10 years old. They had their entire lives ahead of them—birthdays, graduations, weddings, kids of their own."

New York City Mayor Michael Bloomberg, co-chairman of Mayors Against Illegal Guns, called for immediate action, saying, "Calling for'meaningful action' is not enough. We need immediate action. We have heard all the rhetoric before."

Title: 7th Circuit Court Rules Against Trump Administration's Attempt to Withhold Grant Funds from Sanctuary Cities

The 7th Circuit Court of Appeals has ruled that the Trump administration's threat to withhold public safety grants from cities that refuse to cooperate with federal immigration authorities, commonly referred to as "sanctuary cities," is an overreach of its authority. The decision is the latest development in the ongoing court battle between the Trump administration and the city of Chicago.

In 2017, the city of Chicago sued the administration after it attempted to make the funds contingent on adhering to immigration policy. The court found that the executive branch's authority on immigration policy does not include withholding funds from cities that were allocated from the legislative branch. The court ruled that such a concentration of power would allow tyranny to flourish and that the separation of powers is a foundation of the US government.

The court battle dates back to 2017, when the Department of Justice moved to withhold Edward Byrne Memorial Justice Assistance Grants from Chicago, a city that has refused to honor ICE detainer requests, share information, or cooperate with immigration agents. The city's mayor, Lori Lightfoot, celebrated the court's decision, stating that it is a great victory for immigrant and refugee communities everywhere.

The grant money at stake was a small fraction of 1% of Chicago's budget, but the drawn-out court fight indicated that the lawsuit was much more for Chicago leaders than receiving federal funds. The Justice Department has the option to appeal the decision to the Supreme Court, but it is unclear how they will proceed.

The city of Chicago has taken a stance against cooperating with ICE, refusing to honor ICE detainer requests and allowing illegal aliens charged with heinous crimes to walk free without notifying the agency. This stance has led to some gruesome consequences, including the release of an illegal alien who went on to allegedly sexually assault a toddler in a public bathroom.

Title: Trump's Executive Order on Family Separations Causes Confusion and Humanitarian Concerns

The White House is scrambling to address the confusion and humanitarian concerns sparked by President Donald Trump's reversal on the separation of parents and children who cross the southern border as undocumented migrants. The executive order, aimed at defusing a growing political crisis, has instead created new problems, particularly for the 2,300 children already taken from their parents.

The order does not provide procedures for reuniting children now in the care of the federal government with their parents, leaving many questions unanswered. Critics argue that the move has done little to address the crisis, while others see it as a step in the right direction.

Homeland Security Secretary Kirstjen Nielsen emphasized that the administration is working to reunite families, stating, "We have a plan to do that, as you know we do it on the back end. So a combination of DHS, DOJ, HHS, reuniting as quickly as we can." However, the agency has yet to provide a clear plan for reuniting families.

The controversy has sparked a wave of criticism, with many accusing Trump of creating the problem by adopting a "zero-tolerance" policy of prosecuting undocumented migrants, which led to the separations. Democratic House Minority Whip Steny Hoyer stated, "He created a crisis, he said he solved the crisis. He has not."

The political situation remains uncertain, with the House of Representatives set to vote on two Republican immigration bills that could partially alleviate the separations drama. However, even if one of the measures passes, its inclusion of elements of Trump's hardline changes to legal immigration policy seems almost certain to kill it in the Senate.

The legal challenges to the executive order are also complex, with some arguing that it may not be enough to address the crisis. Under the Trump administration's new policy, many people are funneled into the criminal justice system when they cross the border illegally, and US guidelines mandate that children are separated from their parents. The executive order lays down new guidelines, requiring families to be kept together in the custody of the Department of Homeland Security, but this position is almost certain to be challenged in court.

The 1997 consent agreement stipulates that children can be kept in detention only for 20 days, which could lead to families being separated again. Jonathan Turley, a George Washington University professor of law, stated, "It's absolutely a possibility. You reunite the family; a clock is ticking. If it goes beyond 20 days, you either release the entire family, which is similar to the Obama policy that the President wants to change, or you once again separate the family and send the child into some type of custodial care."

Title: Britain's New Prime Minister Boris Johnson Faces Immediate Challenges

Article:

Britain's Conservative Party has chosen Boris Johnson as its new Prime Minister, succeeding Theresa May. Johnson, a former mayor of London and a well-known figure in British politics, has a reputation for his populist style and his strong opinions on various issues. As he takes office, he faces immediate challenges, including the escalating naval crisis with Iran and the looming threat of war.

Johnson has been a vocal supporter of the United States and has defended President Trump on several occasions. In the past, he has criticized Trump's policies, calling him "unfit to hold the office of president of the United States" in 2015. However, in recent times, he has signaled a more conciliatory approach, stating that he would not support US military action against Iran.

As Prime Minister, Johnson has inherited a divided Conservative Party and Parliament, which has made it difficult for his predecessors to make progress on key issues. He has vowed to make Brexit happen by October 31, but this goal is uncertain given the current state of negotiations with the European Union.

Johnson's first challenge will be to navigate the escalating crisis with Iran, which has seized a British-flagged oil tanker in the Strait of Hormuz in response to the British seizure of an Iranian tanker off Gibraltar earlier this month. Johnson has already signaled that he will not support US military action against Iran, and instead will focus on diplomatic efforts to resolve the crisis.

In a recent interview, Johnson emphasized his commitment to upholding British interests, stating that he will continue to be "forthright" in his dealings with the United States on issues such as climate change, disputes with Iran, and the Iran nuclear deal. He also expressed his admiration for President Trump, saying that he believes they will have a "great relationship."

As Johnson begins his tenure as Prime Minister, he will face numerous challenges, including navigating the complexities of international diplomacy and dealing with the divisions within his own party. His ability to navigate these challenges will be closely watched by the international community and the British public.

Title: Five Ways to Cut Spending and Boost Economic Growth

The article discusses the challenges faced by lawmakers in achieving the goals of reducing deficits and promoting economic growth. The author presents five common-sense policies that could help spur economic growth and reduce spending. These policies include:

1. Encouraging competition in the pharmaceutical industry by allowing the importation of drugs from other countries, which would lower prices for American consumers. This could be achieved by reimbursing doctors based on procedures rather than drug costs or tests performed, and by allowing patients to state their end-of-life wishes when renewing their driver's licenses.

2. Ending the war on drugs by legalizing and taxing marijuana. This would generate new revenue, reduce spending on overcrowded jails, and create new job opportunities for the unemployed.

3. Attracting and retaining the best and brightest in the fields of science, technology, engineering, and math (STEM) by offering them Green Cards and encouraging them to stay in the United States. This would help create new ventures, train others, and generate new tax revenue.

4. Encouraging the unemployed to find work by requiring them to volunteer 20 hours a week at a non-profit organization. Research shows that the longer unemployment benefits are given, the longer the jobless stay jobless.

5. Allowing companies to bring back foreign profits at a lower tax rate (10%) if at least half the money is spent on new U.S. jobs or capital investment. This would help jump-start the economy, create jobs, and generate tax revenue.

These policies aim to cut spending and boost economic growth by promoting competition, reducing unnecessary spending, and creating new job opportunities. By adopting these ideas, lawmakers can begin to meet sequestration goals without raising taxes or cutting entitlements, and put the U.S. back on the path to prosperity.

Title: Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid Abandons Filibuster Rules for Presidential Nominees

Article:

Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid has taken the unprecedented step of gutting Senate filibuster rules for presidential nominees, a move that could have significant implications for future presidents and reshape the institution. The decision was made on a straight party-line vote, with 52 senators voting in favor and 48 against. Three Democratic senators broke with Reid on the issue.

Reid enlisted the help of his top lieutenants, Senators Chuck Schumer and Dick Durbin, to gauge support among his fellow Democrats. Despite some initial skepticism, Reid ultimately won the vote after President Barack Obama personally called senators to back the move.

The decision marks a significant shift in Reid's stance on the filibuster, which he once called an "un-American" move that would "ruin our country." However, he believes the timing is right to make the change after Republicans blocked Obama's judicial picks and Democrats were on the defensive over the Affordable Care Act.

The move has been met with criticism from Republicans, who warn that Reid will ultimately regret it. Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell called Reid a "puppet of the president," while Senator Rand Paul described him as a "bully." Senator Mike Johanns (R-Neb.) said Reid has always been about power and has "rammed a rule change through."

The change in filibuster rules allows the Senate to set a new precedent by a simple majority of 51 senators, rather than the typical 67 votes required to change the rules by regular order. This means any majority can fundamentally weaken the filibuster without consensus of the minority party, effectively weakening its ability to block, delay, or shape legislation.

While both sides acknowledge that future majorities will cite Reid's precedent to continue weakening the filibuster, some Democrats see it as a necessary step to break gridlock and allow the Senate to function more efficiently. However, others warn that it could perpetuate gridlock and usher in a conservative agenda the next time the GOP returns to power.

Senator Dianne Feinstein (D-Calif.) described Reid's move as having "guts," while Senator Richard Burr (R-N.C.) called it a "puppet of the president."

Title: Republicans Seek Consensus on Healthcare Replacement Plan Amidst Supreme Court Challenge

The Affordable Care Act, also known as Obamacare, has been a topic of debate for nearly five years, with Republicans vowing to repeal it. However, with the Supreme Court set to hear a case that threatens subsidies to millions of people, Republicans are under pressure to coalesce around a replacement plan. The case, King v. Burwell, is the most significant legal challenge to the healthcare law since its passage in 2012. If the court rules in favor of the plaintiffs, subsidies could be cut off to millions of people in states relying on the federal health exchange.

Senator John Barrasso, chairman of the Senate Republican Policy Committee, believes the King case provides an opportunity for Republicans to come together and present a replacement plan. Various Republican proposals have been put forth over the years, but forging agreement requires bridging deep ideological differences among Republicans about the scope of a plan, the role and responsibility of the federal government in healthcare, and how much to spend.

The Republican moves come as the Affordable Care Act is working fairly well, with the three-month enrollment season for 2015 going smoothly and likely to surpass the administration's modest second-year goals. As of mid-December, more than 6 million people had signed up in the federal exchange, a tally that will rise when state numbers are added in. However, a ruling against the White House would hobble the healthcare law and spill over into the rest of the U.S. health insurance system.

The GOP could face a political backlash if people lose coverage from a lawsuit it supported, reminiscent of the fury Obama faced over last year's plan cancellations. The uncertainty surrounding the court case adds complexity to the Republican attempts to undermine the law through repeal votes and the budget process known as reconciliation. Republicans may wait until the court's ruling to decide how they want to use reconciliation.

Senator Ron Johnson, who is up for reelection in 2016, believes that if the justices rule against the White House, the American public will be asking Congress to act. "We've got to figure that out," he said. Republicans cite a sense that articulating their own alternatives may send a message to the Supreme Court that it doesn't have to fear healthcare chaos if it rules against the White House.

Several House Republicans have replacement plans as well, including a comprehensive plan being tweaked by Senators Richard Burr and Orrin Hatch. Whether a vote on a replacement plan actually takes place is far from certain, as there have been dozens of repeal votes but not a single vote on a replacement plan in either the House or the Senate.

Democrats are preparing for yet another year of defending the five-year-old law, struggling to figure out how to message the law and build coalitions across the country to defend the gains.

Title: Trump's Approval Rating Compared to Obama's at Same Point in Their Presidencies

President Donald Trump took to Twitter on Friday morning to highlight his approval rating, stating that it was almost identical to President Barack Obama's at the end of their first year in office. Trump's tweet came after a discussion on the Fox News program "Fox & Friends" about a new Rasmussen poll showing his approval rating at 46 percent, matching Obama's 47 percent at the same point in his presidency.

The discussion on the program featured Beverly Hallberg, president of the District Media Group and a fellow for the conservative Heritage Foundation, who noted that Trump's approval rating is often portrayed negatively by the media. Hallberg pointed out that Trump ended the year with landmark tax reform legislation being passed, which was a significant achievement for his presidency.

Hallberg also noted that Trump has faced significant media scrutiny, including multiple Russia investigations and staff turnover, which may have impacted his approval rating. However, she emphasized that Trump's numbers are not as low as some in the media would suggest.

According to Hallberg, six out of 10 media stories about Trump were negative, compared to Obama's coverage, which was "far more favorable." Hallberg attributed Trump's relatively high approval rating to his achievements, particularly the passage of tax reform, and the fact that people wanted results.

Rachel Campos-Duffy, a Fox News contributor, also weighed in on the discussion, saying she could imagine what Obama's poll numbers would be if he had faced the same level of media scrutiny as Trump.

Title: President Obama Faces Challenging Agenda in Second Term

Article: President Barack Obama has returned to the White House after a brief vacation on Martha's Vineyard, where he spent eight days with his family and friends. With more than three years remaining in his presidency, Obama faces a daunting array of issues that will shape his legacy. The article highlights several key challenges, including reaching a new spending plan with Congress, addressing the economy, and navigating foreign and domestic policy issues.

In the short term, Obama must prioritize reaching a spending plan with Congress by September 30 to avoid a government shutdown. He will need to keep his cool and work with Republican leaders to find a compromise. In the long term, the economy remains a top priority, with Obama planning a bus tour to promote his ideas for economic growth. He will need to persuade the majority of Americans that his policies will improve their lives.

Abroad, Obama faces challenges in Syria and Egypt, where he will need to demonstrate wisdom and courage to find solutions to complex problems. At home, he must navigate the implementation of the Affordable Care Act and pass immigration reform legislation, requiring determination, flexibility, and open-mindedness.

The article also notes that Obama will have some enjoyable moments, such as entertaining the 1972 Super Bowl champion Miami Dolphins and marking the 50th anniversary of Martin Luther King Jr.'s "I Have a Dream" speech.

Title: Obama and Romney Engage in Tense Foreign Policy Debate, with Both Candidates Scoring Points

The third and final presidential debate between President Obama and Governor Romney focused on foreign policy, with both candidates presenting their views on various international issues. The discussion touched on topics such as Syria, Iran sanctions, and the state of the economy, with both candidates scoring points on different lines.

Romney was seen as calm and poised, effectively challenging Obama's claims and emphasizing his own strengths. He was particularly strong on the economy and debt, as well as his stance on Israel and the so-called "apology tour." Obama, on the other hand, repeatedly emphasized his role as Commander-in-Chief and shared a personal anecdote about meeting a 9/11 orphan.

The debate saw both candidates agreeing on several fronts, leading to smaller skirmishes over who would have done what sooner or more forcefully. Romney's strategy was to pass the "eye test," challenge Obama where necessary, and project strength without appearing bellicose.

Early fact-checks suggest Romney was correct on the disagreement over forces remaining in Iraq, while Obama was incorrect. The debate did not appear to be a game-changer, with Romney executing a clear strategy to project strength and challenge Obama.

Snap polls and instant polls from various news organizations showed mixed results, with some giving an edge to Obama and others to Romney. The debate was seen as a tactical and strategic win for Romney, who successfully passed the "Commander-in-Chief test" according to some experts.

Title: Media Critic Jack Shafer Defends Obama Administration's Treatment of Press

Article:

Media critic Jack Shafer, a columnist for Reuters, has written a piece questioning the notion that the Obama administration has declared war on the press. Shafer's article, published on May 24, argues that the legal actions taken by the administration against journalists do not rise to the level of a "war" on the press.

Shafer's defense relies heavily on a single example, an affidavit for a search warrant for journalist James Rosen's emails, which referred to his actions as a "criminal offense." Shafer cites an explanation from a George Washington University Law School professor, who stated that the language used in the affidavit was not a prelude to prosecution. Shafer also notes that the administration has cracked down on leaks, but claims that this is mostly focused on bureaucrats rather than journalists.

Shafer's article also attempts to deflect criticism by pointing out that the press also lobbies and that Republicans have cheered on leak-chasers in the past. He also notes that the administration's actions are not unique and that other presidents have taken similar measures.

However, Shafer's defense has been criticized for being overly nuanced and lacking in substance. His article has been accused of downplaying the severity of the administration's actions and of using traditional liberal defenses to deflect criticism.

Shafer's own background and affiliations have also been called into question. He has worked at left-leaning publications such as The Washington City Paper and Slate, and has written columns critical of Fox News and its owner, Rupert Murdoch. His own website features a prominent link to a "Hot Topic" on Murdoch, which includes 51 columns criticizing the media mogul.

Overall, Shafer's defense of the Obama administration's treatment of the press has been met with skepticism by many in the media and beyond.

Title: Senate Democrats Prepare to Trigger "Nuclear Option" Against Minority Filibusters

Article:

Senate Democrats are laying the groundwork to trigger the "nuclear option" against minority filibusters, setting up a dramatic showdown on Tuesday. This move would fundamentally alter the balance of power between the White House and the Senate, giving the president more latitude to put his team into place. However, it would also aggravate a contentious atmosphere in the Senate and dim prospects for bipartisan agreements this year.

Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid, a Nevada Democrat, said he would not use the option at the beginning of the year, but changed his mind after Minority Leader Mitch McConnell, a Kentucky Republican, broke his side of an agreement by delaying confirmation of some of President Obama's nominees. "A deal is a deal, a contract is a contract, an arrangement is an arrangement, a bargain is a bargain, as long as each party to such an agreement holds up his end of the bargain," Reid said in a morning floor speech.

Republicans warned that they could retaliate easily if they reclaim the majority by ending other filibusters, which would let them push through their own priorities without fear of minority obstruction. "These are dark days in the history of the Senate," McConnell said. "I hate that we've come to this point. We've witnessed the majority leader break his word."

Reid is only forcing a confrontation on executive branch and independent agencies, not judicial nominations or legislation. Democrats pioneered partisan filibusters of judicial nominees under President George W. Bush, but both parties have long histories of filibustering each other's executive branch appointments.

Each side cites statistics to back up its case. Democrats point to the number of nominees where Reid has forced votes to end filibusters. Republicans say all of Obama's nominees eventually have been approved, including John F. Kerry as secretary of state, who was confirmed in seven days.

Reid has set up filibuster votes for Tuesday for seven nominees: for Labor Department secretary, Environmental Protection Agency administrator, three members of the National Labor Relations Board, the president of the Export-Import Bank, and the director of the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau. Republicans asked for a bipartisan meeting of all senators to air out the issue and try to reach an accord. Reid agreed, though he scheduled the meeting for Monday evening. Republicans said that doesn't leave much time to change minds.

The term "nuclear option" refers to changing the rules by a majority vote, rather than the two-thirds vote the Senate usually requires – a rule that guarantees the minority certain rights that have defined the chamber throughout its history. If Republicans filibuster the nominees, Reid likely will ask for a parliamentarian ruling on whether the filibuster is legal. Based on Senate history, the parliamentarian will rule that it is, and Reid will move to overturn that ruling – which requires a simple majority and sets official precedent.

Republicans have been slow-walking or outright blocking many of Obama's nominees, but they signaled Thursday that they would be willing to relent and allow votes on most of them. McConnell said the only nominees he was reluctant to approve speedily were two NLRB nominees and the consumer bureau nominee – each of whom Obama has installed to temporary appointments using his recess powers. A federal court ruled that the maneuver violated the Constitution.

It takes only a majority vote to approve a nominee on a final vote, but the minority is allowed to filibuster to prevent that final vote, and it takes 60 votes to end the filibuster. The increasing use of filibusters – or even their threat – has shifted power from the president, whom the Constitution gives the right to nominate officers of the United States with the "advice and consent" of the Senate.

Obama tried to regain some of that power by using his recess appointment powers in an unprecedented way. He appointed members to the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau and the National Labor Relations Board even though the Senate didn't consider itself in recess. Two federal appeals courts have ruled that Obama's NLRB appointments violated the Constitution. The Supreme Court said last month that it would hear one of the cases, and the ruling could dramatically circumscribe the president's power.

Reid waited until after he cleared a major immigration bill through his chamber to raise the filibuster issue, knowing it would be so contentious that it could have ruined his chances to win the bipartisan vote on that bill. Republicans contemplated using the nuclear option in 2005 to end Democratic filibusters of judicial nominees, but backed off after a bipartisan "Gang of 14" senators struck a deal that preserved the filibuster in limited circumstances. That deal held for several years but has since dissipated.

"My position has been the same since the Republicans tried to jam judges in 2005 and we stood up against it and said, 'You shouldn't be changing the rules by breaking the rules and almost every Democrat spoke against it,'" said Sen. Carl Levin, a senior Democrat from Michigan. But with 54 Democrats in the chamber, McConnell said he expects Reid to be able to find the 51 votes he needs to force the rules change.

Title: Supreme Court Nominee Brett Kavanaugh Denies Sexual Misconduct Allegations in Fox News Interview

Supreme Court nominee Brett Kavanaugh has denied allegations of sexual misconduct made by two women, Christine Blasey Ford and Deborah Ramirez, in an interview with Fox News' Martha MacCallum. The allegations, which date back to his high school and college years, have sparked a heated debate over his fitness to serve on the nation's highest court.

Kavanaugh flatly refuted the accusations, stating that he was never involved in any sexual misconduct and that he was not present at the parties where the alleged incidents took place. He also emphasized that he was not a virgin until many years after he left Georgetown Prep, the elite all-boys Catholic high school he attended.

Kavanaugh's wife, Ashley Estes Kavanaugh, sat beside him during the interview and defended her husband, describing him as "decent, kind, and good." She acknowledged that the process has been difficult for their children, but emphasized that they know their father and the truth.

The judge's interview with MacCallum was his only public statement on the allegations, and it has sparked criticism from some who argue that he chose a partisan network to air his denials. Shaunna Thomas, executive director of UltraVive Action, a progressive group opposing Kavanaugh's confirmation, called his decision "the move of a political hack, not a nominee to the Supreme Court."

The Senate Judiciary Committee is scheduled to hold another hearing on Kavanaugh's nomination, and the allegations will likely be a central topic of discussion.

Title: Florida State University Shooting Leaves Three Wounded, Gunman Dead

A shooting occurred on the campus of Florida State University (FSU) in the early hours of Thursday morning, leaving three people wounded and hundreds of students scrambling for exits and seeking shelter. The gunman, identified as Myron May, a 2005 FSU alum, was shot and killed by police.

According to Tallahassee Police Chief Michael DeLeo, May had written documents and made videos discussing his belief that he was being targeted by the government. His Facebook page included Bible verses and links to conspiracy theories about government surveillance.

The shooting began at around 12:15 a.m. when May, armed with a semiautomatic.380 caliber handgun, opened fire in the Strozier Library. He reloaded at least once but never made it past the library lobby. More than 300 students were in the library at the time of the shooting.

One victim was hospitalized in critical condition, another in good condition, and a third was grazed by a bullet and treated at the scene. Campus Police Chief David Perry said classes will resume on Friday, and the library will reopen with a strong police presence.

Students were initially kept on lockdown in the library and dorms, with an alert warning issued by FSU police advising students to seek shelter immediately. The campus was eventually cleared, and students were allowed to leave the library around 3 a.m.

Several students shared their experiences on social media, including Jason Derfuss, who was near the gunman when the shooting started but was not injured. Allison Kope, a freshman, described running for her life and not thinking about anything except getting out of the building.

University President John Thrasher described the incident as an isolated event, praising police for their quick and decisive action to prevent further tragedy. Tallahassee Mayor-elect Andrew Gillum expressed relief that the victim count was not higher.

The incident has left the campus community shaken, with many students taking to social media to express their concerns and offer support.

Title: The Truth About Pre-Existing Conditions and Obamacare

The Affordable Care Act, also known as Obamacare, has been a topic of much debate in the United States. A recent AP-NORC poll found that about half of Americans support the law, but many want it repealed. The social media narrative has exaggerated the number of people who would lose insurance without Obamacare, with hashtags like #MakeAmericaSickAgain and #CoverageMatters emerging as rhetorical weapons for defenders of the law.

One of the latest hashtags is #the27percent, which supposedly represents the share of Americans under 65 with pre-existing conditions who are at risk of losing coverage if Obamacare is repealed. However, a closer examination of the data reveals that this figure is greatly exaggerated. According to a report from the Kaiser Family Foundation, the overwhelming majority of those in this category are already covered through employer-based or government programs.

Obamacare's defenders argue that repealing the law will cause millions of people with pre-existing conditions to lose their coverage. The Department of Health and Human Services claims that up to half of non-elderly Americans have pre-existing conditions, and that these nearly 130 million people could be denied affordable coverage without health reform. However, a straightforward reading of the data reveals that this crisis never actually existed.

The Kaiser report estimates that 52 million non-elderly people, or 27% of the population, have uninsurable health conditions. However, even this smaller figure is an exaggeration. According to the report itself, "at any given time, the vast majority of these approximately 52 million people with declinable pre-existing conditions have coverage through an employer or through public programs like Medicaid."

Individuals insured through government programs have long been protected from coverage denials based on pre-existing conditions. Since 1996, the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act has provided the same protection to Americans insured through their employers. So, denials of coverage were only ever possible in the individual market pre-Obamacare. And even within this small segment of Americans, few were likely to face coverage denials before Obamacare. A 2010 congressional investigation found that the nation's four largest insurers denied coverage to only one in seven applicants because of a pre-existing condition.

Assuming the same denial rate in a post-Obamacare world, roughly 1% of the non-elderly population is actually at risk of losing coverage. In other words, Obamacare upended the U.S. healthcare marketplace and drove premiums skyward for millions in order to address a problem that afflicts, at most, 1 in 100 Americans.

The GOP's replacement plan will still protect those with pre-existing conditions. The plan will bar insurers from raising people's premiums significantly, provided they maintain continuous coverage. If they can't find affordable insurance on the open market, they'll be able to turn to state-based high-risk pools supported by $25 billion in federal funding over 10 years for subsidized coverage.

The social media campaigners behind #the27percent are perpetuating precisely the false narrative about pre-existing conditions that gave rise to Obamacare in the first place. Instead of opting for #FakeNews, Obamacare's partisans should stick to the facts.

Title: Movie Theaters Prepare to Reopen Amid Pandemic Challenges

As the country slowly reopens after months of pandemic-related shutdowns, people are getting a taste of life as they once knew it, albeit in small doses. Restaurants, stores, salons, and small gatherings are returning to our routines, but one former hallmark of American life has yet to return: going to the movies. With many theaters preparing to reopen in July, the movie industry is facing significant challenges.

Production of new movies stalled during the pandemic, resulting in fewer films slated for release. Additionally, theaters are capping capacity at 25-50% of usual numbers and implementing strict safety guidelines, including mask-wearing and temperature-taking. These precautions may make theatergoers feel safer, but they may also detract from the experience of escaping reality for 90 minutes.

Hollywood, like the rest of us, has been disoriented by the pandemic. Some upcoming releases, such as "Unhinged" and "Tenet," may not be the best choices for those seeking escapism. However, other films, like "The Little People" and potential reboots of classic franchises, may provide the perfect escape.

Despite the challenges, many are optimistic that Hollywood can deliver the kind of escapism people need. With the right films and precautions in place, moviegoers can once again experience the thrill of the big screen and the joy of sharing that experience with others.

Title: District of Columbia's Unique Political Landscape: A City of Contrasting Trends

The District of Columbia, a city with a unique blend of urban and suburban characteristics, has a distinct political landscape shaped by its demographics and economic trends. As a non-voting delegate in Congress, Eleanor Holmes Norton, Washington's sole representative, provides insight into the city's electoral dynamics.

Washington's voting patterns have remained consistent, with the city consistently supporting Democratic candidates. This is largely due to its large black population, which has been a majority since the 1960 census. However, over the past decade, the city's economy has thrived, attracting young, affluent, and mostly white professionals to neighborhoods like Chinatown and the Penn Quarter. This influx has led to a shift in the city's demographics, with the black population now making up less than 50% of the population, according to the 2010 census.

The changing racial makeup of Washington has led to concerns about gentrification and the displacement of long-time residents, many of whom are black. This has become a key factor in local elections, with voters judging candidates based on their stance on issues affecting both old and new residents. The city faces challenges in education and income inequality, but its voting patterns remain consistent, with a strong Democratic lean.

The city's unique status as a non-voting district has been a long-standing issue, with efforts to grant voting rights to its representative, Delegate Norton, coming close but ultimately failing. On Independence Day, Delegate Norton plans to celebrate by waving a District of Columbia flag, symbolizing the city's struggle for full voting rights. With President Obama expected to win the district's three electoral votes, the city's political landscape remains a fascinating study in contrasts, with its unique demographics and economic trends shaping its electoral dynamics.

Title: North Korea Denies Preparing for Imminent Nuclear Test, but Military Provocation Remains a Concern

The South Korean government and military officials have denied reports that Seoul detected signs of North Korea preparing for an imminent nuclear test, the fourth by the isolated nation. However, analysts in the South believe a mid-range, conventional missile test remains highly likely, possibly within the next week.

According to international relations expert Kim Sung-han, a strategic provocation by North Korea, such as a missile or nuclear test, is more probable than a direct attack against South Korea. This type of provocation does not necessarily invite immediate retaliation, whereas a direct attack would likely prompt massive retaliation from South Korea.

The United States' top military commander in South Korea, Gen. James Thurman, and South Korea's Joint Chiefs of Staff chairman, Gen. Jung Seung-jo, have both canceled their scheduled trips to Washington in the next week. North Korea has announced it will recall 51,000 North Korean workers and suspend operations at a factory complex it jointly runs with South Korea, moving closer to severing its last economic link with its rival.

The statement from Kim Yang Gon, secretary of the Central Committee of the Workers' Party of Korea, did not specify what would happen to the 475 South Korean managers still at the Kaesong industrial complex in North Korea. The move comes amid weeks of North Korean war threats and efforts to punish South Korea and the U.S. over joint military drills and U.N. sanctions imposed over its February nuclear test.

Pyongyang may launch a missile at some point in the next seven days, with Wednesday being the day beyond which Pyongyang warned it cannot guarantee the safety of diplomatic staff for the limited number of countries that maintain diplomatic representation there. Next Monday, April 15, is the anniversary of the birth of Kim Il Sung, a key date in a state whose main religion is the cult of the Kim family.

If North Korea fires missiles or conducts another nuclear test, "I think South Korea and international society will rely on the United Nations Security Council," said Kim. "This type of diplomatic response is more probable." South Korea is concerned about a provocative attack near the border areas or a possible terrorist attack from the North that is difficult to identify quickly, as with the sinking of the South Korean navy ship Cheonan in 2010.

The North's relatively new leadership is a concern, as it is still consolidating its power base. The North began hurling threats and curtailing ties after new economic sanctions were imposed on it by the U.N. to get it to halt its nuclear program. The threats were increased during routine annual training exercises between the U.S. and South Korean militaries.

Analysts predict the current crisis will culminate around April 15, but remain noisy until late April. The North Korean regime is "gradually losing domestic support," said Andrei Lankov, a North Korea specialist at Koomkin University in Seoul. "There is a chance of an outbreak of public discontent," he said. "It's always helpful to remind the people that their country is surrounded by evil and scheming enemies, and only the leader and the army can keep the country secure."

There is a "high possibility" of an imminent provocation from North Korea, but a mid-range missile test is "more likely" than another nuclear test, said Shin Jong Dae, a professor at the University of North Korean Studies in Seoul. "The Park Geun-hye administration are taking the threat from North Korea seriously, but they don't see signs North Korea is preparing to attack South Korea. I think the South Korean government will preserve a cool stance, even if the North conducts a missile test," he said.

The industrial complex that Pyongyang said would be shut down combines cheap North Korean labor and South Korean know-how and technology. It is the last remaining inter-Korean rapprochement project from previous eras of cooperation.

Title: The Power of Television in Presidential Debates: Lessons from the Past

The upcoming presidential debate between Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton has sparked concerns about the importance of television in shaping public opinion. As the two least popular presidential nominees in modern polling history, they face the daunting task of convincing voters to choose them as the next leader of the United States. The debate's outcome may hinge on how well each candidate can overcome their respective public image and perceived flaws.

Historically, television has played a significant role in presidential debates, with some candidates emerging victorious despite factual inaccuracies or policy missteps. The 1980 election between Ronald Reagan and Jimmy Carter, for instance, saw Reagan's calm and reasonable demeanor win over undecided voters, despite Carter's attempts to portray him as a "simpleton" and hard-right war-monger.

In the 1984 election, Reagan's second debate against Walter Mondale was crucial, as he managed to recover from a lackluster first debate by employing a new tactic: having high-ranking presidential insiders fan out across the press room to emphasize his strong performance. This "spin" technique, as it was dubbed within the Reagan White House, helped to create the perception that Reagan had won the debate.

The 2000 election between George W. Bush and Al Gore also saw both candidates fighting against negative stereotypes. Bush aimed to dispel the notion that he was uninformed, while Gore sought to overcome the perception that he was obnoxious and dishonest. While some of Gore's claims were trivial, any hint of untruth reminded voters of the scandals of the Clinton administration.

Research suggests that contemporary press reports overstate the importance of televised debates, which tend to nudge poll ratings by a few percentage points or less. However, when elections are close, every point counts. As the two candidates face off on Monday, they must confront their own public image and perceived flaws.

For Trump, this means reassuring millions of Americans who worry that he is too ignorant, divisive, and hot-headed to lead the country. For Clinton, it means winning over voters who dislike her as a symbol of everything they resent about politics. Ultimately, the test set by the debate is the same for both: can Americans imagine waking up on the morning after election day, feeling happy, comfortable, or safe with either Trump or Clinton in the Oval Office?

As the debate unfolds, television will play a crucial role in shaping public opinion. With 100 million spectators expected in the United States alone, the choice between Trump and Clinton will be a defining moment in American politics.

Title: Supreme Court Nominee Brett Kavanaugh Faces New Allegations Amidst Credibility Concerns

The confirmation hearing for Supreme Court nominee Brett Kavanaugh has been marred by new allegations of misconduct, which have sparked concerns about the credibility of the claims. The latest accusation, published in The New Yorker, alleges that Kavanaugh exposed himself to a woman while they were both students at Yale. However, the accuser, Deborah Ramirez, admits that she hesitated to come forward due to gaps in her memory.

Ramirez initially described the incident as uncertain, stating that she was reluctant to characterize Kavanaugh's role in the alleged incident with certainty. She only decided to speak out after six days of assessing her memories and consulting with her attorney. Even after her newfound certainty, her story contains gaps, as she was drunk and did not directly see the alleged incident.

The only other corroboration comes from an unidentified classmate who claims to have heard about the incident after the fact, which is considered hearsay. The New Yorker has not confirmed with other eyewitnesses that Kavanaugh was present at the party, and two male students identified by Ramirez as being present at the party have no recollection of the incident.

This latest development comes on the heels of another blow to the credibility of Christine Blasey Ford's account, which has been disputed by four other people who were present at the high-school party where Kavanaugh allegedly assaulted her as a teenager. All have denied the allegations, including Leland Keyser, a long-time friend of Ford's and a Democrat.

The opposition to Kavanaugh hopes that the two stories will support each other despite their inherent weakness. However, if Democrats succeed in taking down Kavanaugh based on these unproven and probably unprovable charges, it will be a victory for "garbage-pail politics." Brett Kavanaugh is an excellent jurist who has earned his reputation over decades of public service, and if his career is to be ruined, it should require clear and convincing evidence.

The article concludes that if Republicans surrender on the basis of what is known now, they will face the fury of their own voters – and rightly so.

Title: Environmental Groups and Billionaire Tom Steyer Ask Facebook to Ban CO2 Coalition

Article:

The CO2 Coalition, a research group comprising 55 climate scientists and energy economists, has been targeted by environmental groups and billionaire Tom Steyer, who have asked Facebook to ban the organization. The group's annual budget is half a million dollars, compared to the combined annual budgets of the environmental groups, which total over half a billion dollars. The CO2 Coalition's research focuses on the benefits of carbon dioxide, a non-polluting gas that is an important source of plant and plankton food.

The request to ban the CO2 Coalition is led by Stacey Abrams, who ran for governor of Georgia, and Tom Steyer, who ran for president of the United States. The environmental groups, including 17 large environmental lobbies, claim that the CO2 Coalition's views on carbon dioxide are "false" and "misleading."

However, the CO2 Coalition argues that their research is being suppressed by environmental groups and their allies, who are using their significant financial resources to silence opposing views. The group points to the work of Eric Michelman, a Silicon Valley computer entrepreneur who has devoted his wealth to promoting climate alarmism and silencing opposing views.

The CO2 Coalition's research has been labeled as "false" by Climate Feedback, a group certified by the Poynter Institute for Media Studies, which was founded by the Tampa Bay Times and operates the left-leaning PolitiFact. However, the group's methodology has been criticized for being biased and often incorrect.

The CO2 Coalition's executive director, Dr. Caleb Rossiter, argues that the group's research is being suppressed by environmental groups and their allies, who are using their financial resources to silence opposing views. Dr. Rossiter believes that the truth will ultimately prevail, even against "fact-checkers."

Title: Military Experience in the First Presidential Cabinet: A Historical Perspective

The first presidential cabinet in the history of the United States, established by George Washington, consisted of individuals with significant military experience. In fact, 70% of his cabinet members were military men, with Washington himself having served as the commander-in-chief of the Continental Army during the American Revolution. When including Washington, 80% of the cabinet had military backgrounds.

Washington hand-picked each member of his cabinet, with Alexander Hamilton being chosen as Secretary of the Treasury. Born on the island of Nevis in the Caribbean, Hamilton was illegitimate and had an uncertain father. Despite these challenges, he became an ardent supporter of American independence and joined a militia company at the start of the Revolution. He later became an aide-de-camp to Washington and played a key role in the Battle of Yorktown.

Other notable military figures in Washington's cabinet included Henry Knox, the first Secretary of War, who was a bookbinder by trade but had a natural talent for military tactics. Knox designed an artillery rampart in Roxbury, which Washington admired, and later led the American artillery during the Siege of Boston. He also played a crucial role in the Battle of Yorktown and the crossing of the Delaware.

Even the first Postmaster General, Samuel Osgood, had a military background, having led a company of local militia during the Battle of Lexington and Concord and later serving as a Colonel during the Siege of Boston.

The article concludes by drawing parallels between the military experience of Washington's cabinet and the current concerns about the appointment of generals to national security positions in the Trump administration. The author argues that military men have leadership skills, are unswervingly loyal, and have been defending the American people and Constitution for 227 years without any instances of military coups or junta takeovers.

Title: New Orleans Removes Jefferson Davis Memorial, Second Confederate-Era Monument to Come Down

New Orleans began the removal of the Jefferson Davis Memorial on Thursday morning, the second of four Confederate-era monuments slated for removal. The statue, erected in 1911 to honor Confederate President Jefferson Davis, was taken down by workers wearing masks and helmets, with the area heavily guarded by police officers to prevent potential clashes between pro- and anti-monument groups.

The city voted to remove the monuments in 2015, citing their association with racism and white supremacy. According to a city press release, the statues were built decades after the Civil War to celebrate the "Cult of the Lost Cause," a movement that promoted white supremacy.

New Orleans Mayor Mitch Landrieu stated, "Three weeks ago, we began a challenging but long overdue process of removing four statues that honor the 'Lost Cause of the Confederacy.' Today we continue the mission. These monuments have stood not as historic or educational markers of our legacy of slavery and segregation, but in celebration of it. I believe we must remember all of our history, but we need not revere it."

The city began the removal process late last month, starting with the removal of the monument to the Battle at Liberty Place, which Landrieu said was erected to celebrate the murder of police officers by white supremacists. Workers in the removal crew wore masks, and the area was guarded by officers and snipers.

Proponents and opponents of the removal plan have held demonstrations at monument sites in the past, with multiple protesters arrested and charged with disturbing the peace. The city has not released a timeline for its removal plans, citing "widely known intimidation, threats, and violence, serious safety concerns."

Landrieu previously stated that the monuments of Davis, Confederate generals Robert E. Lee, and P.G.T. Beauregard could come down "anytime, sooner rather than later." He emphasized that the city should not be afraid to confront and reconcile its past, saying, "To literally put the Confederacy on a pedestal in some of our most prominent public places is not only an inaccurate reflection of our past, it is an affront to our present, and a bad prescription for our future."

Title: Former Acting Attorney General Yates Testifies on Efforts to Warn Trump Administration of Flynn's Misinformation

Former Acting Attorney General Sally Yates testified before a Senate subcommittee on Monday, detailing her efforts to warn the Trump administration about misinformation provided by former National Security Advisor Michael Flynn. Yates stated that she spoke with White House counsel Donald McGahn three times, twice in person and once over the phone, and informed him that statements made by Vice President Mike Pence and others about Flynn's discussions with the Russian ambassador to the U.S. were incorrect.

Yates expressed concern that Flynn was vulnerable to blackmail due to his compromised position. She emphasized that she and her team had acquired information that showed Flynn's statements were untrue and informed McGahn of this information, explaining how they had acquired it and why it was inaccurate.

The testimony focused heavily on Yates' conversation with McGahn, with Yates stating, "We told them how we had this information, how we had acquired it, and how we knew it was untrue." President Trump fired Flynn four days after the Washington Post published a story about Flynn's reported misinformation, which was more than two weeks after Yates' warning to the White House.

During the hearing, Yates was asked how classified information ended up in the newspapers, but she was unable to provide an explanation. She did confirm that Flynn had shared untrue information, citing phone calls intercepted by the Obama administration.

The Trump administration has defended Flynn and has received support from Judicial Watch, a conservative watchdog group that has filed a lawsuit about the intercepted phone calls. Judicial Watch President Tom Fitton stated, "President Trump is onto something. The Obama administration was monitoring at least people close to him and certainly the results of that classified intelligence gathering was leaked, which is wildly illegal."

Yates emphasized that her decision to inform the White House was not politically motivated and that she did not call for the Trump administration to fire Flynn. She stated, "We gave them this information so that they could take action."

Title: US Justice Department to Challenge Texas Voting Law in Wake of Supreme Court Ruling

The US Department of Justice has announced its intention to challenge Texas's voting law, citing evidence of intentional racial discrimination and a history of voting-related discrimination against racial minorities. The move comes in response to the Supreme Court's recent decision to strike down a key part of the Voting Rights Act, which had required certain states to obtain federal approval before making changes to their voting laws.

In a speech to the National Urban League conference in Philadelphia, Attorney General Eric Holder stated that the Justice Department will urge a federal judge to subject Texas to the pre-clearance procedure, which was largely struck down by the Supreme Court last month. The procedure would require Texas to obtain approval from the Justice Department before making changes to its voting laws and practices.

The move is part of the Obama administration's efforts to protect voting rights and prevent racial discrimination in the electoral process. Holder emphasized that the evidence of intentional racial discrimination and the history of voting-related discrimination against racial minorities justify the need for the pre-clearance procedure.

Texas Governor Rick Perry and Attorney General Greg Abbott have criticized the move, calling it an "end-run around the Supreme Court" and an attempt to undermine the will of the people of Texas. Abbott has vowed to fight the effort, stating that it is an attempt to control the state's elections.

The Supreme Court's decision to strike down the Voting Rights Act's formula for determining which states must obtain federal approval was seen as a major blow to voting rights advocates. However, the justices left intact a rarely-used mechanism that allows judges to impose the same pre-clearance requirements on states and localities found to have intentionally discriminated illegally in voting practices.

The Justice Department's move is seen as a step towards restoring some of the protections that existed before the Supreme Court's decision. Holder emphasized that while the move is a step in the right direction, it is not a substitute for legislation that must fill the void left by the Supreme Court's decision.

Title: Trump's UN Speech Sparks Controversy, Criticism from Some Nations

Article:

United States President Donald Trump delivered his first major speech at the United Nations General Assembly, which sparked controversy and criticism from some member nations. Trump singled out Iran, North Korea, and Venezuela as "rogue regimes" and threatened to "totally destroy" North Korea if forced to do so.
