Iranian Foreign Minister Javad Zarif denounced Trump's speech as "ignorant hate speech" and compared it to medieval times.

Trump's speech outlined a vision for a world where sovereign states work together for the betterment of their citizens, but he spent most of the address targeting what he called "rogue nations" that are "the scourge of our planet today." He criticized North Korea's leader, Kim Jong-un, calling him "rocket man" and saying that if the US is forced to defend itself or its allies, it will have no choice but to "totally destroy" North Korea.

The speech received a mixed reaction from the audience, with some covering their faces and others appearing shocked. Swedish Foreign Minister Margot Wallstrom called the speech "the wrong speech, at the wrong time, to the wrong audience." Iranian media followed the lead of Foreign Minister Javad Zarif in denouncing Trump's remarks, with commentators on the official TV news channel IRINN comparing his speech to the bizarre performance of Libyan leader Muammar Gaddafi at the same podium in 2009.

Trump also targeted Venezuela, calling its government a "corrupt socialist dictatorship" and warning that the US is prepared to take action against it. Venezuelan Foreign Minister Jorge Arreaza rejected what he called "threats" and said Trump is not the president of the world. Bolivian President Evo Morales, an ally of the Venezuelan government, tweeted that he is not surprised that a "multi-millionaire like Trump attacks socialism."

French President Emmanuel Macron defended the nuclear deal with Iran, saying "renouncing it would be a grave error." Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu backed Trump's stance, saying the deal with Iran should be amended or scrapped altogether and warning against the spread of Iranian influence in the Middle East.

Trump's speech was an eloquent exposition of his "America First" doctrine, but it also contained some fulsome praise for the United Nations as a body that can bring together sovereign states to tackle the world's problems. However, his world view contained many contradictions, leaving questions about the boundary between national sovereignty and collective action and whether America's newfound foreign policy pragmatism extends just to calling for the return of democracy in Iran and Venezuela or actually doing something practical about it.

Title: Romney's Wealth Under Scrutiny as Democrats Intensify Attacks

Article:

The presidential campaign of Mitt Romney, the Republican candidate, is facing increased scrutiny over his personal wealth, with Democrats seizing on reports of his financial holdings in offshore accounts. The Democratic National Committee released a video highlighting the reports, while senior adviser Robert Gibbs accused Romney of not providing voters with the information they need to make an informed decision about his wealth.

Romney's campaign has responded by calling the attacks "unfounded character assaults" and "unseemly and disgusting." Spokeswoman Amanda Henneberg said that Romney's financial information is publicly available and that he has released his 2010 tax returns, which included information about his Swiss bank account.

The controversy comes as the economy continues to struggle, with the latest jobs report showing a disappointing 80,000 jobs added in June. Romney has criticized President Barack Obama's economic policies, saying they have failed to create jobs and stimulate economic growth.

The Obama campaign is trying to make Romney seem out of touch with ordinary Americans by highlighting his wealth and his financial interests in offshore accounts. However, Romney's advisers believe that the effort will backfire and that voters are more concerned with the economy than with the candidate's personal wealth.

A Washington Post/ABC News poll in April found that 71% of those surveyed did not consider Romney's wealth to be a major reason to support or oppose him. Among those who said it was a major factor, his wealth was more likely to be a negative.

Romney's campaign is focusing on Obama's renewed call to let tax cuts for the wealthy expire, saying it would be a massive tax hike and a blow to the economy. The campaign is also highlighting Obama's record on job creation, saying it has been poor.

The controversy over Romney's wealth is likely to continue as the election season heats up, with both sides trying to gain an advantage in the polls.

Title: Supreme Court Nominee Brett Kavanaugh Testifies Before Senate Judiciary Committee

Article:

Supreme Court nominee Brett Kavanaugh testified before the Senate Judiciary Committee on September 27, 2018. The event sparked a flurry of analysis and commentary, with many attributing his behavior to a supposed "White Male Entitlement" (WME). This narrative posits that Kavanaugh's actions are a manifestation of his male privilege and entitlement, stemming from his white, male identity.

However, this explanation is more allegory than argument. It reduces Kavanaugh to a metaphor for an idea, rather than acknowledging him as a real person with his own agency and motivations. Critics have pigeonholed him into their preconceived theories about what's wrong with the world, rather than considering his individual experiences and qualifications.

Kavanaugh's critics, such as Martha Nussbaum and Jonathan Capehart, have argued that his behavior is a manifestation of his fear of women's empowerment and a desire to maintain his own privilege. Maureen Dowd of the New York Times wrote that his actions were a "cri de coeur" custom-made for the age of Trump, with entitled white men feeling aggrieved at losing their power.

However, this narrative oversimplifies the complexities of the situation. While it is possible that Kavanaugh may feel entitled to certain things, it is also possible that his sense of entitlement stems from his qualifications and experience as a judge. He has spent over a decade on the second-highest court in the country, and his nomination was met with strong support before the allegations surfaced.

The article concludes that Kavanaugh is an actual human being, deserving of agency and consideration beyond being reduced to an allegory. Appeals to historical grievances, highbrow theories of the male psyche, and pent-up resentments are not relevant in this case. It is essential to recognize that this is the real world, not an allegory, and that Kavanaugh's actions and motivations are complex and multifaceted.

Title: Trump Reverses Plan to Cut Funding for Special Olympics

The White House has announced that President Donald Trump has decided to reverse a budget request to eliminate funding for the Special Olympics, a global organization that provides sports training and competition for individuals with intellectual disabilities. The decision comes after widespread criticism of Education Secretary Betsy DeVos' defense of the proposed $17.6 million cut to the organization's funding.

The Special Olympics, founded in 1968, provides year-round training, health education, community building, and athletic competition for children and adults with intellectual disabilities, serving over five million athletes across 190 countries. The organization is separate from the Paralympics, which are mostly for elite athletes with physical disabilities.

The budget request, included in the administration's proposed $4.75 trillion federal budget, was met with opposition from many, including the Special Olympics itself. The organization relies heavily on individual and corporate donations, as well as fundraising campaigns, for its support.

The proposed cut would have affected programs in 6,500 schools, according to Andrea Cahn, the Senior Director of Unified Champion Schools for Special Olympics. While the budget cuts would not impact state games, world games, or ongoing competitions, the organization's Unified Champion schools programming would have been affected.

The Special Olympics provides training and competitions in 18 sports, including soccer, swimming, equestrian, and basketball. The organization's World Games, held every two years, took place in Abu Dhabi earlier this month.

In a tweet, Education Secretary Betsy DeVos clarified that she had pushed for funding "behind the scenes" and was pleased and grateful that the President had decided to fund the Special Olympics grant.

Title: Georgia Governor Overrules Local Mask Mandates, Extends State's COVID-19 Restrictions

Georgia Governor Brian Kemp has issued a new order extending the state's COVID-19 restrictions, which encourage the wearing of masks in public, but do not require them. The order rescinds mask orders in key cities such as Atlanta, Savannah, Athens, and Augusta, as well as over a dozen other local jurisdictions.

Kemp's decision comes as Georgia reported its second-highest new coronavirus case count to date, with 3,871 new confirmed cases and 37 COVID-19 deaths. Since the start of the pandemic, nearly 128,000 people in Georgia have tested positive for the coronavirus and over 3,000 have died.

The governor's new order requires people who are most vulnerable to COVID-19, such as the elderly and those with underlying health conditions, to shelter in place. It also requires restaurants and other businesses to follow social distancing precautions and restricts public gatherings to no more than 50 people.

However, some health care workers have expressed concerns that the state is not doing enough to combat the spread of the virus. Earlier this month, over 1,400 health care workers signed a letter to Kemp warning that Georgia is "simply not prepared" for an upsurge in COVID-19 cases. The letter called for stricter measures, including a statewide mask requirement, reinstating the closing of bars and nightclubs, and prohibiting indoor gatherings of more than 25 people.

The governor's new order expires at the end of the month, and it comes on the same day that President Trump visited a UPS hub in Atlanta. Trump praised the carrier's workers and referred to the "battle against the China virus," a term that has been criticized for being racist and anti-Asian.

Title: Geithner Warns of LIBOR Integrity Issues in 2008 Memo

Article:

In a previously undisclosed memo, Treasury Secretary Timothy Geithner expressed concerns about the integrity of the London Interbank Offered Rate (LIBOR) in 2008, when he was the president of the New York Federal Reserve. The memo, obtained by a news organization, highlights Geithner's concerns about the rate-setting process and recommends six key practices to prevent LIBOR manipulation.

In the memo, Geithner warned Bank of England Governor Mervyn King that steps were necessary to "improve the integrity and transparency of the rate-setting process." He suggested practices to prevent "accidental or deliberate misreporting" and eliminate incentives for banks to report inaccurate rates. Geithner expressed a desire to discuss these recommendations with King and requested feedback on potential changes.

The LIBOR manipulation scandal gained widespread attention last month when Barclays Bank was fined hundreds of millions of dollars for its practices, leading to the resignation of its CEO, Bob Diamond. The revelation of Geithner's 2008 memo is likely to raise questions about what he knew about banks' efforts to manipulate LIBOR and what steps he took to address the issue.

The LIBOR rate, published daily in London, is a benchmark interest rate that gauges the cost of borrowing between banks. The rate affects the cost of lending for various products, such as mortgages and credit cards. The rate is calculated based on submissions from a group of banks, with 18 banks contributing to the U.S. dollar rate.

A group of 12 Democratic lawmakers has called for a full investigation into the scandal, questioning the integrity of Wall Street banks and the ability of regulators to effectively monitor them.

Title: Kaiser Poll Reveals Wide Disparities in Perceptions of Obamacare's Impact

The Kaiser Family Foundation has released a new poll that highlights significant differences in how Democrats and Republicans perceive the impact of the Affordable Care Act (ACA), also known as Obamacare. The survey found that Democrats are five times more likely to say they have been helped by the health care law, while Republicans are about half as likely to know someone who has gained coverage through the law.

The poll also showed that Republicans are more likely to say they know someone who lost their health coverage or had their hours cut due to Obamacare. The disparities in perceptions of the law's impact are significant, with over a quarter of Democrats reporting that they have been helped by the ACA, compared to just 5% of Republicans.

The poll's findings suggest that political views may play a significant role in shaping individuals' impressions of the health care law's effectiveness. Democrats are more likely to have access to Medicaid expansion, which may contribute to their perception that more people have benefited from the law. However, this factor alone may not fully explain the significant disparities in perceptions.

The Kaiser poll highlights the complex and multifaceted nature of the Affordable Care Act's impact, with different groups experiencing varying effects. The survey's findings underscore the importance of considering individual perspectives and experiences when evaluating the law's effectiveness.

Title: Facebook Content Moderators Expose Anti-Conservative Bias Within the Company

A recent exposé by James O'Keefe and Project Veritas has revealed the extent of anti-conservative bias within Facebook's content moderation team. The investigative journalism team went undercover at Facebook, along with Accenture and Cognizant, which provide contractors for content moderation. The undercover videos captured employees acknowledging anti-Trump and anti-conservative bias at the company, with some employees stating their intention to ban pro-Trump content on the platform.

In one video, a content moderator, Daniel Will, stated, "I think they're very biased with who they protect. They already shadowban, Facebook is notorious for it. They say they don't, but it's clear that people's content doesn't come up because it's been de-filtered off the queue."

Another video features a Cognizant employee, Lara Kontakos, working as a social media content moderator, saying, "If someone is wearing a MAGA hat, I'm going to delete them for terrorism."

A former Cognizant employee, Zach McElroy, came forward with his findings while working at the content moderation company. McElroy outlined the bias he perceived within the company and across Facebook. He wrote in a post on Medium.com:

During the interview, I found out the platform I'd be working for would be Facebook/Instagram, which I had already suspected given the nature of the job description. I was shown examples of just what "content" I would be "moderating," which included racist memes, people bullying each other, and gore like you'd have seen on /b/ or LiveLeak years ago. But for the most part, my day-to-day content feed was largely incoherent rants and WorldStar fight videos.

McElroy stated that he chose to come forward with his story after seeing the work done by Project Veritas with Pinterest whistleblower Eric Cochran. He claimed that while working at Cognizant, a graphic image of President Trump having his throat cut was allowed on the platform while memes and cartoons about former Democratic presidential hopeful Beto O'Rourke were removed.

Donald Trump Jr. commented on Project Veritas' video, stating, "More truth about Facebook and the social media masters. Enough is enough, we can't let them interfere with elections any longer. Election interference is such a hot topic except when it's done by the left, then everyone is silent."

The revelations have sparked concerns about the potential impact on free speech and the integrity of online discourse.

Title: Senate to Vote on Ending Government Shutdown, Leaders Weigh Political Costs and Rewards

The United States Senate is set to vote on a bill to end the government shutdown, with Democratic and Republican leaders making intricate political calculations ahead of the 12 p.m. ET vote. The shutdown, which began on Friday, has closed down the federal government and affected over 800,000 federal employees.

Both sides are weighing the political costs and rewards of prolonging the shutdown. Democrats must decide whether they have sufficient trust in Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell's assurances that he will hold a key immigration debate if the government reopens and a funding deal is secured. Republicans, on the other hand, must consider whether they are prepared to take new steps to pry open divisions between moderate and liberal Democrats to break down opposition to opening the government.

President Donald Trump must also decide whether he is willing to sit on the sidelines and watch as he is portrayed as an unreliable bit player in the drama. Trump has been watching the shutdown unfold hour-by-hour on cable TV and may need to make a leap of faith to end the shutdown and steel himself to go against hardline advisers and his own political base to make concessions on immigration.

The shutdown has affected government operations, with many federal employees working without pay and essential services disrupted. The Democratic Party's activist grassroots base had been fiercely critical of some of its Washington leaders for failing to do more to force the GOP into a deal to address the fate of 700,000 people brought to the US illegally as children and whether to extend their legal status, which they could lose in March.

The Republican Party has accused Democrats of closing down the government on an unrelated issue to funding federal programs, stoking enthusiasm in their own political base and putting pressure on Democratic senators facing re-election in states in November. The White House has also claimed that Democrats are holding government funding, including funding for troops and national security priorities, hostage to an unrelated immigration debate.

The costs of the shutdown and the political pressures on both sides are expected to rise significantly as government operations remain silent at the start of the work week. The Senate is due to vote on a bill to reopen the government and fund it for three weeks, but it is unclear whether the plan will win over sufficient Democrats to pass.

Title: Ocasio-Cortez and Sanders to Campaign for Left-Wing Candidates, Raising Concerns Among Top Democrats

Article:

Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, the 28-year-old democratic socialist and rising star in the Democratic Party, is hitting the campaign trail this week with Vermont Senator Bernie Sanders to support left-wing candidates. The duo will campaign for two congressional candidates seeking to unseat Republican incumbents in Kansas, James Thompson and Brent Welder, on July 20. Ocasio-Cortez will also visit Michigan to support progressive candidate Abdul El-Sayed, who is running for governor, on July 28 and 29.

Ocasio-Cortez's rising national profile and far-left politics have raised concerns among top Democrats, who worry that her activism could fracture the party ahead of critical midterm elections. She has endorsed several progressive candidates seeking to take down incumbent Democratic lawmakers, including Delaware Senator Tom Carper and Representatives Stephanie Murphy of Florida, Adam Smith of Washington, and Michael Capuano of Massachusetts.

In Kansas' Republican-leaning 4th District, Thompson came close to winning in a special election last year and is taking his second shot at unseating GOP Rep. Ron Estes. Welder, a labor lawyer, is running against GOP Rep. Kevin Yoder, who was endorsed by President Trump. Welder has polled ahead of Yoder and won the 3rd District by a slim margin in 2016.

Primaries in both Kansas and Michigan take place on August 7. Thompson expressed excitement about the Sanders and Ocasio-Cortez visit, saying it's a "huge boost to our campaign" and that the interest and enthusiasm have been "electric."

However, top Democratic leaders have sounded the alarm, with Representative Alcee Hastings, D-Fla., calling Ocasio-Cortez's politics "overly idealistic" and Representative Bill Pascrell, D-N.J., expressing disappointment over her public feud with Representative Joe Crowley, D-N.Y., after she defeated him in a primary contest last month. Representative Lacy Clay, D-Mo., called Ocasio-Cortez's behavior "petty" and a "lack of maturity."

Former Connecticut Senator Joe Lieberman, who was the Democratic Party's candidate for vice president in 2000, expressed concerns about Ocasio-Cortez's policies, saying they will not be supported in many places across America. He wrote a Wall Street Journal op-ed calling for voters to reject Ocasio-Cortez in the November elections.

Title: Hacksaw Ridge: A Sobering Reminder of the Pacific Theater's Brutal History

The article recounts the author's visit to Hacksaw Ridge, a historic site on the Japanese island of Okinawa, where some of the fiercest fighting during World War II took place. The author, Larry Alex Taunton, reflects on the significance of the site and the brutal nature of the Pacific Theater's battles, which saw high casualties on both sides. He notes that the Battle of Okinawa was often overshadowed by other battles, such as Operation Overlord in Europe, but was similar in scale and duration, with many more casualties.

Taunton also highlights the contrast between the peaceful, green landscape of modern-day Okinawa and the brutal fighting that took place there during the war. He notes that the Japanese military fought fanatically, with many soldiers choosing to die rather than surrender, and that the last Japanese soldier did not surrender until 1974.

The article also touches on the author's observations about the current state of American influence in the world, noting that while the US is often seen as a force for good, it can also be a bully, promoting its own cultural agenda in the Third World. The author concludes by reflecting on the importance of remembering the sacrifices of those who fought in World War II and the lessons that can be learned from the brutal fighting that took place in the Pacific Theater.

Title: Illinois Sees Surge in Cannabis-Related Emergency Room Visits Following Recreational Use Legalization

Article:

Illinois has seen a significant increase in emergency room visits related to cannabis use since the state legalized recreational marijuana on January 1, 2020. According to reports from doctors and health officials, the surge in cases is attributed to novice users and those who have not used cannabis in a long time or are trying it for the first time due to its new legal status.

Dr. Trevonne Thompson, an emergency room physician and toxicology director at the University of Illinois at Chicago hospital, has seen a notable increase in cannabis-related incidents since the new year. He notes that the most common symptoms are heart palpitations, anxiety, and restlessness, but in some cases, patients can experience more severe symptoms such as full-on psychosis, agitation, and hallucinations.

Thompson attributes the increase in cases to the potency of newer cannabis strains, which contain higher percentages of THC, the main psychoactive compound in marijuana. He notes that law-abiding baby boomers and others in their middle-aged years who may have tried marijuana decades ago and have not touched it since are in for a rude awakening.

Edibles, such as gummy candies and other sweets, are the primary cause of issues, as they are consumed at a faster rate than smoking and can cause a delay in experiencing the effects of THC. By the time the first dose kicks in, users may have consumed more of the product, leading to adverse symptoms.

Illinois is not alone in experiencing this surge. According to multiple studies, Colorado doctors saw close to triple the number of cannabis-induced emergency room cases after the state legalized recreational use. The situation highlights the importance of responsible cannabis use and the need for education on the potential risks and effects of cannabis consumption.

Title: Attorney General Sessions' Investigation of FISA Abuse Raises Questions Amidst Political Backlash

The recent tweet storm by President Trump targeting Attorney General Jeff Sessions has sparked controversy and raised questions about the investigation into alleged FISA abuse. The president's criticism of Sessions' decision to ask the Department of Justice's inspector general to investigate potential misconduct has been met with skepticism, with many viewing it as an attempt to undermine the investigation and discredit the attorney general.

The investigation in question is focused on allegations of abuse of the government's national-security surveillance powers under the 1978 Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act (FISA). The Nunes memo and the Grassley-Graham memo, which were released earlier this year, alleged that top FBI and Justice Department officials presented suspect evidence and failed in their duty of candor to the tribunal. If true, this would be egregious misconduct, although it is unclear whether it constitutes a prosecutable violation of criminal law.

Attorney General Sessions' decision to ask the inspector general to investigate the conduct of FBI and Justice Department officials in FISA court proceedings was seen as a responsible move, as it complies with federal law and Justice Department protocols. The Office of the Inspector General or the Office of Professional Responsibility is responsible for investigating allegations of wrongdoing by Justice Department or FBI officials.

The president's criticism of Sessions' decision has been met with criticism from both sides of the political aisle. Many have argued that the president's tweet storm was an attempt to undermine the investigation and discredit the attorney general, while others have praised Sessions' decision as a necessary step to ensure accountability and transparency.

The investigation itself is ongoing, with the inspector general's report on the actions taken by former FBI Director James Comey during the Clinton emails investigation expected to be released in the coming weeks. The report is said to be imminent and was always expected to be filed in the March-April time frame.

The controversy surrounding the investigation has also raised questions about the politicization of the Justice Department and the challenges faced by the agency in recruiting and retaining quality appointees. With vital leadership positions unfilled and a razor-thin majority in the Senate, the Department's ability to function effectively is being hampered by the ongoing political turmoil.

Title: Russia Used Multiple Social Media Platforms to Influence 2016 US Election, Report Claims

A recent report released by the US Senate and the University of Oxford's Computational Propaganda Project and Graphika reveals that Russia leveraged every major social media platform to spread propaganda and influence the 2016 US presidential election. The report, which analyzed millions of social media posts provided by Twitter, Google, and Facebook to the Senate Intelligence Committee, found that YouTube, Tumblr, Instagram, and PayPal were also targeted.

The report highlights the scale of Russia's disinformation efforts, which were spearheaded by the Internet Research Agency (IRA), a Russian company described by the US Intelligence Community as a troll farm with ties to the Russian government. The IRA focused on targeting conservatives with posts on immigration, race, and gun rights, as well as undermining the voting power of left-leaning African-American citizens by spreading misinformation about the electoral process.

The report also notes that Russia's IRA had a particular focus on developing Black audiences and recruiting Black Americans as assets, which included encouraging activists to stage rallies. One IRA campaign, Black Matters US, existed across multiple platforms, including Twitter, Facebook, Instagram, YouTube, Google+, Tumblr, and PayPal.

The report criticizes the "belated and uncoordinated response" from tech firms, highlighting details that could have led to earlier detection of interference, such as the use of the Russian rouble to buy advertisements and internet signatures relating to the IRA's base of operations.

The findings of the report are based on data provided by Facebook, Twitter, and Google, and suggest that Russia's disinformation campaign was widespread and sophisticated. The report concludes that social media has become a "computational tool for social control," manipulated by political consultants and available to politicians in democracies and dictatorships alike.

Title: Supreme Court Allows New Wealth Test for Green-Card Applicants to Move Forward

The Supreme Court has ruled in favor of the Trump administration's revised wealth test for green-card applicants, allowing the policy to move forward while litigation continues. The decision, which was made on January 27th, was a 5-4 split, with Justice Neil Gorsuch dissenting.

The new policy, announced last August, would deny permanent legal status to immigrants who are deemed likely to need government assistance, such as food stamps, Medicaid, or housing assistance, over the next 36 months. The test considers factors such as family size, English proficiency, credit score, and income.

The policy was initially blocked by a federal district court in New York, but the Trump administration appealed the decision to the Supreme Court. The court granted the request without comment, allowing the policy to move forward.

Justice Gorsuch, in a four-page statement, expressed frustration with the phenomenon of district judges issuing injunctions that apply universally across the country. He noted that two circuit courts had lifted similar injunctions against the revised wealth test, but Judge Daniels' move involved a single judge enjoining the government from applying the new definition to anyone, anywhere, without regard to participation in this or any other lawsuit.

Gorsuch argued that these injunctions "share the same basic flaw" in that they dictate how the government must treat people who are not parties to the case. He characterized them as "patently unworkable" and sowing chaos, and suggested that they are a sign of "our impatient times."

Other legal experts have weighed in on the issue, with some agreeing with Gorsuch's reasoning and others disagreeing. Howard Wasserman, a law professor at Florida International University, agrees with Gorsuch's reasoning but wonders why he chose this moment to attack universal injunctions. Mila Sohoni, a professor at the University of San Diego law school, speculates that Gorsuch's missive may be designed as a warning to judges to be more cautious in issuing such broad injunctions and an invitation to the Department of Justice to keep up its "aggressive" efforts against injunctive overreach.

Amanda Frost, a law professor at American University, argues that there is a debate to be had regarding when universal injunctions are appropriate, but it is "almost laughable" to argue that they are unconstitutional. She notes that administrative law explicitly allows judges to invalidate regulations "as to everyone, not just the plaintiff."

The Supreme Court's decision allows the revised wealth test to move forward, but the litigation is ongoing, and the issue is likely to be revisited in the future.

Title: US Deploys 1,500 Troops to Middle East to Counter Iranian Forces

The United States is deploying 1,500 troops to the Middle East to counter the ongoing threat posed by Iranian forces, according to Acting Defense Secretary Patrick Shanahan. The move comes after a series of mysterious explosions damaged shipping in the Gulf of Oman, and tensions between the US and Iran have been escalating.

The deployment will include fighter jets, drones, and other weaponry, as well as a team of engineers and additional intelligence, surveillance, and reconnaissance aircraft. The move is intended to safeguard US forces and reduce the possibility of future hostilities, according to Shanahan.

The decision was announced by President Donald Trump, who said the deployment was "relatively small" and that he did not think more troops would be needed. However, Acting Defense Secretary Shanahan said the move was a "prudent defensive measure" to counter the ongoing threat posed by Iranian forces, including the IRGC (Iran's Revolutionary Guard Corps) and its proxies.

The IRGC is the most elite military unit in Iran, and the US designated it as a foreign terrorist organization last month. The deployment is seen as a response to the recent attacks on oil tankers in the Gulf of Oman, which the US has blamed on Iran.

The deployment is significantly smaller than some administration sources had predicted, with around 1,500 service personnel expected to be dispatched. The move will also include the deployment of Patriot missile batteries and surveillance planes, which will allow for a clearer assessment of Iranian activity and troop movements along the coast.

The exact nature of the increased threat from Iran and what should be done about it remains unclear, with President Trump appearing reluctant to become overly entangled in the region. Tensions between the US and Iran began rising this month after Washington ended exemptions from sanctions for countries still buying from Iran, and Iran has now announced it will suspend several commitments under the nuclear deal.

**CNN Rejects Trump Campaign Ad Targeting Whistleblower Complaint and Impeachment Inquiry**

CNN has rejected an advertisement from President Donald Trump's reelection campaign that attacked the whistleblower complaint and the impeachment inquiry. The ad, titled "Coup," claimed that the whistleblower process was a "coup" and featured a clip of Senator Lindsey Graham (R-S.C.) on Fox News stating that the complaint was based on hearsay and was a "set up." However, CNN deemed the ad unacceptable due to its factual inaccuracies.

According to a CNN spokesperson, the ad "contains assertions of fact about the whistleblower complaint that have been refuted by the Intelligence Inspector General. In addition, it is inaccurate to use the word 'coup' to describe a constitutionally prescribed legal process." The ad was also rejected by Turner Sports, which is owned by CNN's parent company.

Meanwhile, the Joe Biden campaign is urging Fox News to reject another Trump campaign ad, "Biden Corruption," which claims that Biden offered Ukraine $1 billion to fire the prosecutor investigating a company affiliated with his son. The Biden campaign argues that the allegation is "completely false" and has been debunked by news stories.

Fox News has accepted the ad, stating that it is not their role to censor ads from either side of the aisle. However, the Biden campaign is urging the network to reconsider, citing the ad's inaccuracies and potential to mislead viewers.

This is not the first time Trump's campaign has faced rejection from networks. CNN previously rejected an ad from Trump's campaign that targeted the whistleblower complaint and the impeachment inquiry, citing its factual inaccuracies. The Trump campaign has slammed CNN's decision, accusing the network of protecting Joe Biden and shielding him from truthful advertising.

Title: Former Mexican President Vicente Fox Blames US for Drug Trafficking and Violence at the Border

Former Mexican President Vicente Fox has attributed the drug trafficking and violence at the US-Mexico border to drug consumption in the United States, rather than Mexico. In an exclusive interview, Fox stated that Mexico does not produce drugs significantly and that the country is caught in the middle of a drug war between drug producers in South America and consumers in the US.

Fox pointed out that the state of California produces more marijuana than all of Mexico together, and that Mexico's drug consumption rate is extremely low, with only about 5% of the population consuming drugs daily. He emphasized that Mexico is not the source of the problem and that the country is paying the price for collaborating with the US to cut drug trafficking and impede drug reaching the US market.

Fox also criticized the US for not addressing the root causes of the problem, stating that the country is more focused on demonizing Mexico rather than finding solutions. He called himself an "activist" for legalizing marijuana, citing the estimated $55 billion generated by the illegal drug trade and the need to address the money laundering that funds the cartels.

Fox also took aim at presumptive Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump, criticizing his rhetoric on crime and violence at the border. He urged the US to "get rid of that language of hate" and instead focus on finding solutions to the problem.

It is worth noting that Fox's statements do not provide a comprehensive solution to the complex issue of drug trafficking and violence at the border, and the root causes of the problem are multifaceted and complex. However, his comments highlight the need for a nuanced understanding of the issue and a more collaborative approach between the US and Mexico to address the problem.

Title: ACLU Files Complaint Against Republican Candidate Peter Meijer Over Refusal to Host Drag Queen Performance

The American Civil Liberties Union (ACLU) has filed a complaint against Republican congressional candidate Peter Meijer, 31, for refusing to host a drag queen performance at a venue he owns, featuring a group of performers with Down syndrome known as "Drag Syndrome." Meijer, who is running for the seat currently occupied by Rep. Justin Amash in Michigan, cited concerns about the potential exploitation of the performers as the reason for his decision.

The ACLU alleges that Meijer's refusal to host the event constitutes discrimination based on disability and sex. According to the organization's Michigan chapter, the complaint was primarily filed due to the drag component of the performance. Meijer, however, maintains that he reached out to numerous individuals, including members of the disability advocacy community, parents of children with Down syndrome, and national groups dedicated to Down syndrome, before making his decision.

Meijer expressed concerns about the performers' ability to give full, informed consent, stating that the involvement of individuals with disabilities whose ability to act of their own volition is unclear raises serious ethical concerns. He believes that individuals with disabilities, like children and other vulnerable populations, should be protected.

DisArt, a production company focused on artists with disabilities, strongly criticized Meijer's decision, calling it discrimination and self-preservation. The organization plans to find an alternative venue for the performance and has announced that Drag Syndrome will perform on September 7th as part of Project 1 by ArtPrize in Grand Rapids, Michigan.

Meijer has denied allegations of ableism and transphobia, stating that he has been unfairly targeted and that his concerns about potential exploitation were taken out of context. If the complaint is deemed valid, Meijer could face fines.

Title: Howard Schultz's Presidential Bid Sparks Debate Amidst Trump's Criticism

Article:

Former Starbucks CEO Howard Schultz's potential presidential bid has sparked a heated debate, with President Donald Trump taking a swipe at the businessman's chances of success. Trump tweeted that Schultz "doesn't have the guts" to run for president and that he agrees with Schultz's self-deprecating assessment that he is not the smartest person in the world. Trump also joked that he hopes Starbucks is still paying his rent in Trump Tower.

Schultz, a longtime Democratic donor, has been critical of both the Democratic and Republican parties, stating that they are failing the American people. He believes that Trump has proved himself to be unqualified to be president. In an interview with CBS's "60 Minutes," Schultz said that he has a long history of recognizing that he is not the smartest person in the room and that he recruits and attracts people who are smarter and more experienced to make great decisions.

Political consultants from both parties have praised Schultz's business background, but many believe that an independent bid would likely split the anti-Trump vote with the Democratic nominee, giving the incumbent a better chance to win re-election. Republican consultant Mike Murphy tweeted that Schultz's campaign slogan should be "Schultz: The Independent Vote-Splitting Leadership Trump Needs Now." Democratic strategist Mark Mellman urged Schultz not to run, stating that it would be a mistake and could potentially hand the general election to Trump.

Schultz has dismissed concerns about splitting the anti-Trump vote, saying that he wants to see the American people win and is open to ideas from all political backgrounds. He also expects to face criticism from Trump and has become "bored" with the president's tweets.

Title: Corroborating Evidence Emerges in Tara Reade's Sexual Misconduct Allegations Against Joe Biden

The recent allegations of sexual misconduct against former Vice President Joe Biden by former Senate staffer Tara Reade have garnered significant attention, with seven people now corroborating details of her story. This level of corroboration is higher than what Christine Blasey Ford had for her claim against Supreme Court Justice Brett Kavanaugh. While Biden and his campaign have denied the allegations, Reade's account has more supporting evidence from third parties relatively close in time to the alleged assault.

Reade's ex-husband, Lynda LaCasse, and brother, Collin Moulton, have corroborated details of her account, with LaCasse stating that Reade told her in the 1990s that her boss in Washington, D.C. had sexually assaulted her. Lorraine Sanchez, who worked alongside Reade in the mid-1990s for a California state senator, also confirmed that Reade had complained to her about her former Washington, D.C. boss's sexual harassment. Two anonymous friends of Reade have also backed up her story.

In contrast, Ford's accusation against Kavanaugh lacked corroboration from third parties, with her primary corroborating witness, Leland Keyser, ultimately stating she didn't have confidence in Ford's account. The only corroboration Ford had was from notes from therapy sessions she and her husband had in 2012 and 2013, which showed she discussed an alleged high school assault, although she didn't name the alleged perpetrator.

The difference between Reade's account and Ford's is that Reade's accusation has more corroboration from third parties relatively close in time to the alleged assault, while Ford's accusation had issues and lacked corroboration. Despite this, some high-profile Democrats have not offered Reade the same level of support they offered Ford, with Democratic California Sen. Dianne Feinstein calling Reade's accusation "ridiculous" and Democratic New York Sen. Kirsten Gillibrand stating she "stands by Vice President Biden."

Title: Declining Upward Mobility in the United States: A Shift from the Post-War Era

A recent study by a team of researchers led by Raj Chetty has shed light on the declining trend of upward mobility in the United States over the decades. The study found that children born in 1940 had a high likelihood of earning more than their parents, whereas those born in 1980 experienced a significant decline in upward mobility. The research suggests that the very wealthy were less likely to out-earn their parents, while those from the bottom of the income distribution were more likely to experience upward mobility.

The study also found that economic growth has less to do with this decline than one might think. In fact, even if GDP growth had remained as rapid as it was during the 1940s and 1950s, upward mobility would still not have been restored. Instead, the study suggests that a more egalitarian income distribution is necessary to achieve the kind of broadly shared increase in living standards seen in the post-war era.

The research highlights the importance of addressing income inequality, which has been a growing concern in the United States. While some argue that faster economic growth is desirable, it is not clear how it can be achieved on a sustained basis. In contrast, making changes to tax and regulatory structures to promote greater equality is a more achievable goal. However, implementing such changes in the current political climate, which is poised to enact a large regressive tax cut, remains a challenge.

Title: Facebook Removes Natural News Page, Citing Violation of Spam Policy

Facebook removed the page of Natural News, a far-right conspiracy outlet, on Sunday, citing a violation of its policy against spam. The page had nearly 3 million followers. According to Facebook, the page violated its policy, but the exact nature of the violation was not disclosed.

Natural News' founder, Mike Adams, claimed on Infowars, another far-right conspiracy site, that his site was "permanently banned" from posting. He told Gateway Pundit, another far-right site, that the apparent ban is evidence of a conspiracy against his website.

Natural News had a history of pushing hoaxes and calling for mass arrests against the left. Prior to the ban, Natural News had more Facebook followers than Infowars at its peak. The page used its platform to promote its trademark combination of natural remedies and far-right conspiracy theories, including misinformation about vaccines.

Facebook has previously banned similar pages, including those for Infowars, which was criticized by the right as "censorship" by Silicon Valley. In May, Facebook issued a new ban against Alex Jones, as well as far-right figures like Paul Joseph Watson, Laura Loomer, and Milo Yiannopoulos, and anti-Semitic and Nation of Islam leader Louis Farrakhan. The bans also applied to Facebook-owned Instagram.

A Facebook spokesperson stated, "We've always banned individuals or organizations that promote or engage in violence and hate, regardless of ideology. The process for evaluating potential violators is extensive, and it is what led us to our decision to remove these accounts today."

Facebook has taken steps to crack down on conspiracy and extremist content over the past year. In August, it banned Infowars and its founder Alex Jones, although Infowars appears to have used similar-sounding pages like "Newswars" to promote its content after the ban. Facebook also began taking stronger actions against anti-vaccination hoaxes this year, banning anti-vax ads in March. Those ads previously targeted women in measles-stricken areas, The [news outlet] revealed.

Title: Facebook Takes Steps to Address Fake News Concerns

Facebook Inc. is taking measures to address its role in spreading false information, including enlisting the help of third-party fact-checkers and posting warnings on dubious stories. The company's Chief Executive Officer, Mark Zuckerberg, responded to criticism that Facebook's news feed rewarded false stories in the run-up to the U.S. presidential election, including a post claiming Donald Trump was endorsed by the Pope.

Zuckerberg outlined several projects Facebook has underway to address the issue. The company is exploring labeling stories that have been reported as false by third parties or the community, so users are warned before they read or share them. Facebook is also working to make it easier for users to report fake news and improve its technical systems to better detect such articles.

In addition, Facebook is seeking outside help to tackle the issue. The company will meet with journalists to understand how they verify information and is exploring partnerships with third-party fact-checking organizations. Zuckerberg noted that fake news has become a big business and said Facebook is looking for ways to disrupt its economics.

Zuckerberg's remarks come after he previously stated that it was "crazy" to think that fake news on Facebook influenced the outcome of the election. He also noted that more than 99 percent of the stories on Facebook are accurate. However, criticism of his handling of the issue mounted, with even President Barack Obama speaking about the negative effect of fake stories on social media.

Title: Reopening Schools Amid Pandemic: A Complex and Ongoing Debate

The debate surrounding the reopening of schools in the United States is a complex and multifaceted issue, with various perspectives and challenges emerging. Despite President Trump's urging to "seriously consider" reopening schools as part of a larger push to revive the economy, most schools in the country will remain closed for at least several months.

Currently, 45 states and Washington, D.C. have ordered or recommended school building closures through the end of the academic year, with a focus on possibly resuming in-person instruction in the fall. The impact of shifting to distance learning has been significant, with students, especially those in vulnerable groups, missing out on important academic and social development. Many parents are also unable to work without a reliable place to send their kids every day.

Experts agree that reopening schools will be one of the most important steps in getting the country back to normal. Optimistic forecasters suggest schools will be able to safely reopen on time in the fall, although day-to-day instruction will likely look very different. A vaccine won't be widely available for another year at the earliest, health experts say, meaning the coronavirus will be a threat through the entirety of the next school year.

Models for a return to instruction call for social distancing measures to protect students, teachers, and parents at home from infection. Suggested changes include limiting class sizes to keep desks far apart, staggered schedules to limit the number of kids on campus, and a blend of online and in-person learning.

The next few months will provide important data on the viability of reopening schools. There is significant evidence that the virus poses less risk to young children than adults, and some epidemiologists say there is reason to believe kids are also less likely to pass it on to others, although there is not enough research to know for sure yet. The U.S. will also learn a lot about the impact of reopening from schools in other countries, some of which are already bringing students back.

However, others point to a long list of logistical hurdles that need to be resolved before schools can open. The biggest challenge will be lack of resources, some argue. Many of the country's 13,000 school districts were struggling to operate before the pandemic, a problem that will only be exacerbated amid the economic downturn caused by the virus. Without proper funding, there won't be enough space or staff available to enact distancing measures, some administrators argue. Any plan to return will also need to be approved by the teachers unions, the biggest unions in the United States having already suggested they would strike if proper safety measures weren't in place when schools return.

Another point of view suggests schools should only reopen when testing is widely available and technology to effectively track outbreaks is in use, even if that takes well beyond the start of the next school year. A number of national education associations have banded together to lobby Congress for $200 billion to prop up state budgets and ensure that schools have the resources to reopen safely. Funding for states is expected to be a major point of debate as lawmakers in Washington consider yet another massive stimulus bill in the coming days and weeks.

As the debate continues, experts warn that whenever students do come back, classes are unlikely to look anything like the school days they remember. There may be staggered half-day classes or one-day-on, one-day-off schedules so desks can be spread out and buses can run half-empty.

Title: Trump's Strike Against Iran: A Calculated Move to Gain Negotiating Position

The recent strike by the United States against Iran has sparked a mix of reactions from lawmakers and experts. According to Senator Jim Inhofe, Trump has achieved his goal of getting into a negotiating position with Iran. Inhofe stated that Trump is now in a good position, having already won, and does not need to go for a "blood and all that."

On the other hand, some Senate Democrats, such as Senator Joe Manchin, have expressed a better understanding of the reasons behind the strike after receiving a classified briefing. However, many Democrats view the strike as an example of Trump's erraticism and a departure from the 2015 deal with Iran.

Senator Martin Heinrich (D-N.M.) expressed concerns that the U.S. is now in a worse position than it was a week ago, with the potential for a nuclear-armed Iran. He emphasized the need for a more predictable and proportional response from the administration.

Two Republican senators, Mike Lee (R-Utah) and Rand Paul (R-Ky.), have expressed their dissatisfaction with the classified briefing, stating that it was insufficient and did not allow for discussion on the appropriateness of further military intervention against Iran.

Experts warn that Iran could retaliate through proxies, cyberattacks, or other means, and the Department of Homeland Security has warned of the possibility of an attack on the homeland with little or no warning. Behnam Ben Taleblu, a senior fellow at the Foundation for Defense of Democracies, stated that the Iranian regime will look for other opportunities to confront Washington and bring an end to the sanctions.

Trump's allies and critics alike have expressed mixed opinions on the strike. Some, like Senator Mitt Romney (R-Utah), praised the action, stating that it sent a clear message to the Iranian regime and dealt with a "bad person." Others, like Senator Martin Heinrich, expressed concerns about the potential consequences and the lack of a clear strategy.

The article provides a balanced view of the reactions and opinions on Trump's strike against Iran, highlighting the differing perspectives within the political spectrum.

Title: Congress Adjourns, Government Shutdown Begins: Federal Services to be Impacted

The United States government has officially shut down, with Congress failing to agree on a funding bill before the midnight deadline. The shutdown will affect many federal services, with around 800,000 non-essential employees being furloughed and hundreds of thousands more required to report to work without paychecks. The White House has issued orders to begin closing operations, and many government agencies will be impacted.

The main point of contention was the Affordable Care Act, also known as Obamacare, which is funded through separate laws and will continue to operate despite the shutdown. Americans without health insurance can still access state-based exchanges to purchase insurance, often with government aid.

The House and Senate had been unable to reach a deal, with House Republicans sending repeated proposals to the Senate, but refusing to consider a funding bill without changes to the health care law. Senate Democrats have passed a bill to fund the government through November 15, but have refused to negotiate further.

The shutdown will affect many government services, including national parks, federal agencies, and benefits processing. However, essential services such as air traffic controllers, Border Patrol agents, the military, and federal law enforcement will continue to operate, although without paychecks in the near term.

House Speaker John A. Boehner said the House had done its best to keep the government open while trying to address concerns about the health care law. Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid, however, stated that there will be no negotiations with the threat of a shutdown still looming.

Title: Aetna's Exit from Obamacare Exchanges Highlights Challenges in Rural Areas

The recent announcement by Aetna that it will be pulling out of the Affordable Care Act (ACA) market exchanges in 11 states has raised concerns about the sustainability of the healthcare law. However, experts argue that the situation is more complex than it seems. While premiums are expected to rise more quickly next year, they are still less expensive than initially forecast. Additionally, about 20 million Americans now have health insurance who did not have it before, and projections for the total cost of healthcare in America have fallen by $2.6 trillion compared to the government forecast in 2010.

The problem lies in the "exchange" markets, where people choose their insurer under Obamacare. Key insurers are losing hundreds of millions of dollars in these exchanges and pulling out of some of them, leaving consumers with only one insurer – no choice. According to Avalere Health, a healthcare consulting company, a third of the country's exchange regions may offer only one insurer in 2017.

Experts suggest several solutions to address the lack of competition in some parts of the country. One option is to expand the pool of healthy enrollees, which could be achieved through a more aggressive outreach effort to attract younger, healthier individuals. Another approach is to offer plans that young people perceive as desirable and affordable, which could be achieved by changing government requirements for the plans.

Others propose increasing federal financial support in troubled markets, such as rural areas, where it can be more expensive to offer healthcare due to the limited number of providers and hospitals. This could be achieved through a "public option" or by allowing people 55 and older to buy Medicare coverage, reducing the pool of older people relying on Obamacare.

The Bipartisan Policy Center suggests letting states take the lead in designing their own healthcare plans, which could include encouraging competition between exchange-market regions within and between states. However, whether Congress and the next administration will work towards these solutions remains uncertain, pending the outcome of the election.

Title: Greece's New Government Raises Concerns About Eurozone's Future

Article:

Greece's far-left Syriza party has won the country's general election, leading to fresh concerns about the future of the eurozone. The party's leader, Alexis Tsipras, has agreed to form a coalition government with the right-wing Independent Greeks party, which is also opposed to the terms of Greece's international bailout. The bailout, worth $270 billion, has allowed Greece to avoid bankruptcy but has come at the cost of severe spending cuts.

The Syriza party did not win the required 151 parliamentary seats to form a government on its own, but the Independent Greeks party's 13 seats will enable the new government to push ahead with its agenda. Tsipras has vowed to negotiate better terms for Greece with its creditors, citing the country's 26% unemployment rate and an anemic growth rate that has seen GDP plunge 30% below pre-financial crisis levels.

The election results have sent shockwaves through financial markets, with the Athens Stock Exchange falling nearly 4% before recovering some of those losses. The euro currency strengthened slightly, but markets across Asia and Europe were weaker. The eurozone's future is now uncertain, with some analysts warning that the Syriza party's victory could lead to a broader shift away from mainstream political parties in Europe and towards economic populism.

European leaders, including German Chancellor Angela Merkel, have warned the Syriza party not to make promises it cannot keep and that the current debt arrangements must be respected. The Syriza party has no plans to meet with the "troika" of the European Commission, European Central Bank, and International Monetary Fund, and instead seeks direct talks with governments.

The election results have also raised concerns about the impact on Greece's economy, with one-third of the population living below the poverty line and many without health insurance or other necessities. The country's 10-year government bond yields increased 40 basis points to 8.81%, according to Bloomberg data, as doubts about the EU bailout program's extension kept Greek bonds and the euro under pressure.

Title: Trump Criticizes Cohen's Testimony, Praises Him for Not Alleging Collusion

Article:

U.S. President Donald Trump has criticized his former attorney Michael Cohen for lying in his testimony to Congress, but also expressed surprise and approval that Cohen did not accuse Trump's 2016 presidential campaign of colluding with Russia. Trump made these comments during a news conference in Vietnam, where he was attending a summit with North Korean leader Kim Jong Un.

Trump described Cohen's testimony as "fake" and stated that it should not have been scheduled during his trip. He also questioned why Cohen did not lie about the alleged collusion, saying, "I wonder why he didn't lie about that too like he did about everything else. I was actually impressed that he didn't say, 'Well, I think there was collusion for this reason or that.' He didn't say that."

Cohen, who testified on Wednesday, called Trump a "conman" and claimed that Trump knew in advance about the release of stolen emails aimed at hurting his Democratic rival in the 2016 election campaign. Trump criticized the timing of the hearing, saying it should not have occurred during his summit with Kim Jong Un. "Having a fake hearing like that and having it in the middle of this very important summit is really a terrible thing," he said.

Cohen, a 52-year-old former close aide to Trump, testified that he had no direct evidence of collusion between Trump's campaign and Moscow during the 2016 election campaign. The possibility of collusion is a key theme of Special Counsel Robert Mueller's Russia investigation, which has been a subject of controversy and debate during Trump's two years in office.

Title: Lawyer for Accuser in Trump Defamation Suit Says Funding Efforts Yield $30,000, Mostly Small Donations

The lawyer representing former Apprentice contestant Summer Zervos in her defamation lawsuit against President Donald Trump has spoken out about the funding efforts for the case. In an interview, lawyer Lisa Bloom said she is not concerned about the motivations of those donating to the cause, stating that she does not have the time or interest to investigate each donor's motivations.

Bloom has personally solicited donations from influential Democrats and has discussed fundraising assistance with David Brock, a former "right-wing hit man" who later became a prominent supporter of Hillary Clinton during her 2016 presidential campaign. According to Bloom, the fundraising efforts have yielded around $30,000, mostly in small donations. The funds are being used to cover expenses such as depositions, with legal fees already reaching $150,000. Neither Bloom nor Zervos will personally accept any of the donated funds.

Despite the financial challenges, Bloom and Zervos remain committed to pursuing the case, citing their belief that truth matters and that Trump should be held accountable for his words and actions. Zervos has accused Trump of sexually assaulting her in 2007, after she appeared as a contestant on his reality TV show "The Apprentice." Trump has denied the allegations, calling them "made-up nonsense" and suggesting they were motivated by fame or orchestrated by Hillary Clinton's campaign. A judge is currently deciding whether to allow the lawsuit to proceed.

Title: Trump's Tweets and Actions Spark Uncertainty in International Relations

The outgoing President Barack Obama and the incoming President-elect Donald Trump have taken contrasting approaches to international relations in recent days. Trump has taken to Twitter to express his views on various global issues, including the need for the United States to strengthen its nuclear capabilities, the seizure of a US Navy underwater drone by China, and the deadly truck rampage in Berlin.

In a series of tweets, Trump accused China of an "unprecedented act" and suggested that the US should "let them keep" the drone. He also condemned the Berlin attack as an "attack on humanity" and linked it to his proposed ban on immigration from countries plagued by Islamic extremism. Trump's tweets have sparked debate about the potential impact of his presidency on international relations.

Meanwhile, the Obama administration has taken a different approach. According to reports, Obama directed his national security adviser, Susan Rice, to tell the US ambassador to the United Nations, Samantha Power, not to block a UN Security Council resolution on the Middle East peace process. The resolution was eventually passed by four other countries, with the US watching from the sidelines.

The role reversal between the outgoing and incoming presidents has deepened concerns about the future of US foreign policy. The Obama administration's decision not to block the resolution has been seen as a sign that the US is no longer willing to take a strong stance on the Middle East peace process. This has led to speculation about the potential consequences of Trump's presidency, including the possibility of increased tensions with Israel and the Middle East.

Trump's aides have said that he has spoken often with Obama, but the president-elect has shown little patience for the traditions of the interregnum between presidents. The contrast between Trump's tweets and Obama's actions has sparked uncertainty about the future of US foreign policy and the potential impact of Trump's presidency on international relations.

Title: National Review Publishes Anti-Trump Editorial, Raises Concerns About His Conservatism

The National Review, a prominent conservative magazine founded by William F. Buckley, has published an editorial expressing concerns about Donald Trump's suitability as a presidential candidate. The editorial, accompanied by submissions from 22 right-leaning thought leaders, argues that Trump's free-flowing populism could change the nature of the right end of the US political spectrum and potentially harm the conservative movement.

The magazine's central problem with Trump is not personal, but ideological. The editors and contributors believe that Trump's lack of philosophical grounding and his willingness to abandon core conservative principles make him an untrustworthy candidate. They argue that Trump's support for big government, his praise for single-payer healthcare, and his past donations to Democrats raise doubts about his commitment to conservative values.

Some contributors, such as David McIntosh, president of the low-tax group Club for Growth, point out that Trump's record on government spending and regulation is inconsistent with conservative principles. Others, like Weekly Standard editor William Kristol, worry that Trump's boasts about his personality being enough to solve chronic problems hint at authoritarian tendencies.

Despite the concerns expressed in the National Review editorial, Trump remains a strong contender in the Republican primary race. His supporters argue that his outsider status and willingness to challenge the status quo are refreshing and necessary changes for the party. Trump's core message of contempt for those who oppose him has resonated with many voters, and it is unclear whether the anti-Trump movement will be able to slow or stop his momentum.

The core problem of the anti-Trump movement is that there is currently no viable alternative candidate to rally around. The Republican establishment has not coalesced around a single candidate, and the party's actors have failed to signal to mainstream conservative voters that one of the remaining candidates, such as Marco Rubio, Jeb Bush, Chris Christie, or John Kasich, is the best choice.

**Congressional Leaders Weigh Options to Prevent Government Funding Showdown**

Congressional leaders are intensifying their planning to prevent a government funding showdown, exploring legislative options to redirect GOP anger at Barack Obama's expected action on immigration and stave off a political disaster. According to sources involved with the sessions, Obama plans to use his executive authority to change the enforcement of immigration laws by the end of the year, a move that top Republicans warn could derail efforts to pass a long-term spending bill by a December 11 deadline.

Speaker John Boehner, Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell, and their top aides and deputies are considering several options to give Capitol Hill Republicans the opportunity to vent their frustration with what they view as an unconstitutional power grab by the White House without jeopardizing the government financing bill. These options include offering a separate piece of immigration legislation on the floor aimed at tightening border security and demanding the president enforce existing laws, promising to renew the effort next year when Republicans have larger numbers in both chambers, and passing two separate funding bills – a short-term bill with tight restrictions on immigration enforcement agencies and another that would fund the rest of the government until the fall.

The leadership has not made any decisions and is likely to weigh additional options. The House does not expect to bounce between options on the floor; they will pick one and stick with it, sources said. The strategies are all designed to prevent another standoff over funding the government. Republicans take control of Capitol Hill in January and have promised to govern responsibly and end crisis-fueled legislating.

GOP leaders have not completely given up on a funding bill that would last until next October, but the political and legislative climate is unpredictable. The White House has not told Republican leaders when it will take unilateral action, but senior aides and lawmakers have made it clear to the Obama administration that acting before Congress funds the government would backfire.

The least desirable option, according to several Republicans directly involved in planning, is a series of short-term spending bills. McConnell and Boehner desperately want to avoid a rolling set of spending fights early in the year, which would undermine their campaign promises to return Congress to regular order. An endless stream of stopgap spending bills would throw Washington back into the crisis-like atmosphere that has defined the post-2010 divided government.

As of now, House conservatives seem unsure of their strategy. "We got ta look at what the president may do on immigration," said Rep. Jim Jordan (R-Ohio), a former chairman of the Republican Study Committee. "There's all kinds of discussions happening right now, so we'll look at a number of things."

Title: Trump Administration's Feud with CNN Continues: Kushner's Remarks Spark Controversy

The Trump administration's animosity towards CNN has not subsided, with Jared Kushner, President Donald Trump's senior adviser and son-in-law, recently meeting with a top executive at Time Warner, CNN's parent company. According to the Wall Street Journal, Kushner told the executive that CNN should fire 20% of its staff due to its coverage of the 2016 presidential election. A White House official downplayed the remark, stating that Kushner was simply trying to make a point.

This is not the first instance of the Trump administration's hostility towards CNN. When Kushner took on a more prominent role in Trump's presidential campaign last summer, he began complaining to CNN executives about its coverage of Trump. The tension escalated after CNN fact-checked a speech Trump gave in June, prompting Trump to threaten to restrict campaign members from appearing on the network.

The feud has only intensified since Trump took office, with him frequently labeling CNN as "fake news" and sharing a doctored video of himself wrestling a CNN avatar. In August, he shared and then deleted a cartoon picture of a "Trump Train" running over a person meant to represent CNN.

The White House's open attacks on CNN and the wider media are already concerning. However, the administration's animosity towards CNN may have significant implications for a pending media merger involving the network. In October 2016, AT&T announced its intention to acquire Time Warner, a deal that would bring together premium TV channel HBO, film studio Warner Bros., and networks like CNN, for $85.4 billion. The government must review the merger for antitrust reasons, but Trump has already expressed opposition to the deal, stating that it would concentrate too much power in the hands of too few.

It is unclear whether the administration's decision to block the merger is driven by its animosity towards CNN or Trump's promise to be a populist president who would enforce antitrust laws. The administration claims that politics are not influencing its review of the merger, but AT&T Chief Executive Randall Stephenson has stated that he does not believe politics are an issue. However, given Trump's track record of disregarding norms and prioritizing his own interests, it is difficult to know for certain.

**Amazon, Berkshire, and JPMorgan Form Healthcare Venture to Cut Costs**

Amazon.com Inc, Berkshire Hathaway Inc, and JPMorgan Chase & Co have announced the formation of a new not-for-profit company aimed at reducing healthcare costs for their employees. The joint venture, which will initially focus on technology for "simplified, high-quality, and transparent healthcare," will target the more than 500,000 employees of the three companies in the United States.

The new entity will seek to negotiate directly with drugmakers, doctors, and hospitals to get a better handle on the costs of healthcare services. This could potentially undercut the industry's "middlemen," including health insurers, pharmacies, and benefits managers.

Healthcare industry experts believe the new venture could eventually use its vast databases to identify areas of inefficiency and negotiate better prices for healthcare services. This could lead to significant cost savings for the companies and potentially the broader healthcare system.

The initiative grew out of conversations between Amazon's Jeff Bezos, Berkshire's Warren Buffett, and JPMorgan's Jamie Dimon, who have expressed concerns about the rising costs of healthcare. The CEOs plan to share their strategies and technology with other companies and the government to reduce healthcare costs across the economy.

The new venture is expected to face challenges, particularly from traditional healthcare players who have tried to reduce costs without sacrificing profit margins. However, the involvement of Amazon, Berkshire, and JPMorgan could bring new opportunities to shake up the industry.

Shares of healthcare companies, including UnitedHealth Group, Cigna, and CVS Health, fell across the board following the announcement, while Amazon's shares rose 1.4%.

Title: Democrats' Shift Away from Judeo-Christian Values: A Shift in Political Landscape

The article discusses the Democratic Party's shift away from Judeo-Christian values and its implications on the party's relationship with religious voters. The article highlights how, in 2004, the Democratic Party attempted to appeal to "values voters" by adopting a more moderate stance on social issues, but this effort was met with criticism from liberal Democrats who felt it was too focused on religion.

The article notes that this attempt at outreach was short-lived, and by 2012, the party had shifted its focus towards secularism and moral relativism. The article quotes Michael Wear, the former "faith-outreach" director for President Barack Obama, who expressed frustration with the party's lack of understanding and appreciation for Judeo-Christian values.

Wear attributes the party's shift to its demographics, stating that younger Democrats are less familiar with religion and are more focused on other issues. He also notes that White House staffers were unfamiliar with biblical references and struggled to understand the concept of "the least of these," highlighting the party's lack of religious literacy.

The article concludes that the Democratic Party has become the party of transgender bathrooms and Ramadan dinners, and that its commitment to secularism and moral relativism has made it difficult for the party to connect with Judeo-Christian voters. The article suggests that the party's shift away from Judeo-Christian values has been a significant factor in the decline of the party's appeal among religious voters.

Title: Election Analysis: Kentucky, Mississippi, and Virginia Provide Insights Ahead of 2020 Elections

The recent elections in Kentucky, Mississippi, and Virginia have provided some key takeaways for the 2020 elections. In Kentucky, Governor Matt Bevin's loss to Democrat Andy Beshear was not an upset, as many had predicted, given the governor's vulnerability. President Donald Trump's last-minute visit and push may have helped Bevin, but it was not enough to overcome his problems.

The results also suggest that impeachment is not a silver bullet for Republicans, as some had hoped. While it may galvanize the GOP base, it is not a guaranteed winner. Bevin's unique problems, including his low approval ratings and controversies, contributed to his loss.

In Virginia, the results are a testament to the state's transformation from a Republican stronghold to a Democratic stronghold. Republicans are now struggling to find a credible challenger against Senator Mark Warner, and Democrats have full control of the state and federal levels.

The suburbs continue to be a problem for Republicans, as seen in Kentucky and Mississippi. The GOP's struggles in the suburbs, which were evident in the 2018 and 2019 elections, are likely to continue in the 2020 elections. This could be particularly concerning for President Trump, who is trying to win key states like Pennsylvania, Michigan, Arizona, Georgia, and Texas.

In Mississippi, Attorney General Jim Hood's loss to Republican incumbent Governor Tate Reeves was not a surprise, given Hood's strong Democratic credentials. The results in Mississippi and Kentucky suggest that the 2020 elections will be highly competitive, with both parties having opportunities to win.

Overall, the recent elections provide some key insights for the 2020 elections, including the importance of suburban voters, the limitations of impeachment as a political strategy, and the ongoing challenges facing Republicans in the South.

Title: June Jobs Report Shifts Focus Back to Economy, Threatening Obama's Re-Election Hopes

The recent June jobs report has brought the presidential campaign back to the forefront, with President Barack Obama's re-election hopes now facing significant challenges. The report showed a dismal 80,000 job growth in June, capping the worst quarter for job creation in two years, with the unemployment rate stuck at 8.2%. This development has put pressure on Obama to bring the jobless rate down before the November election, as no president since World War II has won re-election with a jobless rate above 7.4%.

The report's significance lies in its impact on voter impressions, as voters tend to judge a president on recent economic trends rather than their overall performance over four years.
