Obama's approval rating on the economy, consistently ranked as the top issue for voters, has been stuck in dismal territory. The president's campaign will likely continue to frame Mitt Romney as an unpalatable alternative through attacks on his business record and extensive wealth, including his money in overseas accounts.

However, the Romney campaign and its supporters are expected to unleash a massive advertising campaign, fueled by hundreds of millions of dollars, to criticize Obama's stewardship of the economy and defend Romney's private sector record. The Romney campaign is also preparing to add new communications staff and launch a fresh defense of his record as head of private equity firm Bain Capital.

The weak jobs report plays directly into Romney's argument that Obama has failed to push the economy onto a faster track and that it is time to try a new approach highlighted by lower taxes and less regulation. The report should also help wash away a tough news cycle for Romney and refocus the campaign on friendly terrain for the Republican challenger, who has based his bid for the White House on the argument that he would create faster economic growth and pull the United States out of its current funk.

In response to the report, Obama emphasized the creation of over 4 million jobs during his term and blamed Congress for standing in the way of policies that would create faster growth, such as infrastructure spending and hiring more police officers, teachers, and other public employees.

Title: President Obama Embarks on Three-Day Fundraising Trip to the West Coast

Article:

President Barack Obama will embark on a three-day fundraising trip to the West Coast, starting on Wednesday, to raise millions for Democratic congressional candidates. The president will attend five fundraisers in California, hosted by executives from Disney studios, Yahoo, and the former chairman of Qualcomm. The events are part of over 20 fundraisers the president has committed to attend this year, as Democrats try to keep control of the Senate and pick up seats in the House.

Mr. Obama's job-approval ratings are near the lowest point of his presidency, but he managed to joke about it at the annual White House Correspondents' Dinner, saying that Democrats are avoiding him. He will visit Arkansas, where he will tour tornado damage and meet with the families of victims, accompanied by Senator Mark Pryor, who is running for re-election.

The president will also participate in a joint fundraiser to benefit House and Senate Democratic candidates in Los Angeles and receive an "Ambassador for Humanity" award from Steven Spielberg at a Holocaust memorial event sponsored by the University of Southern California's Shoah Foundation. The event and another "official" energy-related event on Friday in San Jose will ensure that taxpayers cover much of the cost of the president's trip, even though it is mostly devoted to politics.

Tickets for the events range from $1,000 per person to $64,800 per couple, depending on the event and the level of access to Mr. Obama. Irwin Jacobs, the former chairman of Qualcomm, was the second-biggest donor to Mr. Obama's 2012 campaign, contributing over $2 million to the president's re-election effort.

Democrats hold a 55-45 majority in the Senate, but they are defending 21 of the 36 seats contested in November. Many political analysts believe the GOP is within reach of picking up the net six seats needed to regain control of the Senate. In the House, Democrats would need a net gain of 17 seats to take the chamber, a goal that most political strategists believe the party cannot achieve.

Title: Romney and Obama Campaign in Ohio, Focus on Economy and China Policy

Article:

The 2012 presidential campaign has shifted its focus to Ohio, a crucial swing state, as both Mitt Romney and Barack Obama held campaign events in the state. No Republican has won the presidency without carrying Ohio since 1988. Romney's campaign emphasized the national debt, with the candidate standing in front of a ticking debt clock. Obama, on the other hand, accused Romney of "newfound outrage" over China's trade practices, a sensitive topic in Ohio where outsourcing of U.S. jobs is a major concern.

According to a recent Quinnipiac University poll, Romney leads Obama on handling the federal budget deficit, with 49% of Ohio voters preferring Romney's approach. However, Obama's campaign ratings have improved, with 54% of Americans viewing his campaign efforts favorably, compared to 43% unfavorably.

Romney's campaign has faced criticism for its handling of the campaign, with 6 in 10 Americans expressing a negative opinion. Obama's campaign, on the other hand, has seen a significant improvement in its ratings, with 8 points gained since July, according to pollster Gary Langer.

The candidates will continue to campaign in Ohio, with Romney hosting a business roundtable in Bedford Heights and Obama speaking at Bowling Green State University. The president accused Romney of making "disingenuous claims" about holding China accountable, highlighting trade cases his administration has won against China at the World Trade Organization.

The candidates will swap sides of the state, with Romney holding an event at the SeaGate Convention Center in Toledo and Obama stumping in Kent at Kent State University. With over a month left in the campaign, voters in key battleground states are already casting absentee ballots, and the presidential debates are set to take place between now and Election Day.

Title: Americans' Fears of Government Intervention Drive Economic Uncertainty

Article:

The article highlights the growing unease among Americans regarding government intervention in the economy. With the Obama administration's plans to raise taxes and expand government, many individuals are seeking to avoid or benefit from these changes. This has led to a surge in gun show attendance, estate planning, and lobbying for favors. The article notes that the "invisible hand" of free markets is being replaced by the "visible hand" of bureaucrats, with the political class becoming the new master of the universe.

The article also discusses the potential consequences of the fiscal cliff and the impact of Obama's reelection on the economy. It notes that the unemployment rate is falling largely because millions have stopped looking for work, and ordinary wages are stagnant or falling. The article also highlights the growing national debt and the potential for inflation, which could have long-term consequences for the economy.

The article concludes by predicting that millions of Americans who voted for Obama will be disappointed in 2013, but will not blame him for the outcome. Instead, they will agree with him that the solution is to double the dose of Washington power. The article ends by noting that the Obama administration's policies will have real-world consequences for every American, and that the economy is at a crossroads.

Title: Beto O'Rourke Drops Out of Presidential Race, Citing Weak Poll Numbers and Fundraising

Article:

Former Texas Representative Beto O'Rourke has dropped out of the Democratic presidential primary race, citing his weak poll numbers and reduced fundraising efforts. Despite initially showing promise, O'Rourke's campaign struggled to gain traction, with his polling numbers deteriorating over the past few months. He had raised $13 million by the end of the second quarter, a significant drop from his initial $6.1 million haul in the first 24 hours of his campaign.

O'Rourke's exit from the race comes after a series of disappointing debate performances, including his most recent outing, which saw his net favorability among Democratic primary voters decline by about 6 points. His lack of momentum and fundraising woes left him struggling to qualify for future debates, with only two qualifying polls shy of making the November debate and none registered for the December debate.

The former congressman's campaign had initially shown promise, with some polls suggesting he could be a viable contender for the Democratic nomination. However, his inability to attract a broad base of support, particularly among younger and non-white voters, ultimately proved to be a significant obstacle. According to data from the Cooperative Congressional Election Study, only about 12% of 2016 Democratic primary voters fit the profile of young, white, and moderate, a demographic that O'Rourke struggled to connect with.

O'Rourke's pivot to the left on issues, particularly gun control, was seen as an attempt to broaden his appeal, but it failed to generate significant momentum. His exit from the race leaves the Democratic field with one fewer contender, but it also highlights the challenges of building a successful presidential campaign.

Title: Senate Democrats Weigh Options on Supreme Court Nominee Neil Gorsuch

Article:

The Senate is currently deliberating on President Trump's nominee for the Supreme Court, Neil Gorsuch. While some Democratic senators are considering an open vote for Gorsuch, others, including Minority Leader Chuck Schumer, are concerned about appearing obstructionist. However, Senate Democrats must consider the importance of preserving the filibuster, not just for Gorsuch, but for any future nominee.

The most significant fact to consider is that this is a stolen seat, as Senator Jeff Merkley (D-Ore.) has pointed out. Supreme Court justices have retired or died in the final year of a presidential term on numerous occasions, and presidents have still managed to get their nominees through. However, the norm has now been established that a president will not fill a Supreme Court seat unless their party also controls the Senate.

The surrounding political circumstances also strengthen the case for an all-out partisan trench war. President Trump lost the popular vote by the largest margin of any president, and his election was marked by efforts to disenfranchise African-Americans and FBI meddling on his behalf. Instead of trying to govern in a moderate fashion, Trump and his inner circle of white nationalist advisors are pushing through radical, bigoted policies as fast as they can.

The Supreme Court will soon rule on Trump's defiance of federal court orders, and there is every reason to think that Gorsuch will behave as a "partisan stooge." This raises the alarming prospect of Trump's nominee serving to legally launder his illegal actions.

In conclusion, Senate Democrats must consider the importance of preserving the filibuster, not just for Gorsuch, but for any future nominee. They must also consider the surrounding political circumstances and the importance of signaling to their base that they will fight Trump tooth and nail. Filibustering Gorsuch is the loudest way they can do it.

Title: Jeb Bush Supports Confirmation of Loretta Lynch as Attorney General

Article:

Former Florida Governor Jeb Bush has expressed his support for the confirmation of Loretta Lynch as the next Attorney General, a position nominated by President Barack Obama. Bush made his stance clear during a stop at the "Politics and Pie" forum in Concord, New Hampshire, on Thursday night.

Bush emphasized that presidents have the right to choose their team and that Republicans should consider the fact that the longer it takes to confirm Lynch, the longer current Attorney General Eric Holder remains in office. The Senate has been holding up Lynch's nomination for 160 days since Obama announced his choice last November, with a fight over a sex-trafficking bill that includes a controversial abortion provision.

Bush also touched on the importance of showing deference to the executive branch, stating that if someone is supportive of the president's policies, whether one agrees with them or not, there should be some respect for the executive. He did not explicitly endorse Lynch's policies, but rather emphasized the importance of confirming the president's nominee.

In a lighthearted moment, Bush joked about his own family's presidential legacy, saying he is not trying to break a tie between his family and the Adamses, who have produced two presidents. He also poked fun at Hillary Clinton's recent trip to Chipotle, saying he cooks at home and doesn't need to go to the fast-casual chain.

In a departure from his strict paleo diet, Bush indulged in some blueberry pie at the event, saying "to hell with the diet" and asking where the french fries were.

Title: Congressional Democrats Debate Expanding Trump Tax Inquiry to Include Business Returns

Article:

Congressional Democrats are deliberating whether to expand their inquiry into President Donald Trump's taxes to include his business tax returns, a move seen as crucial for effective oversight. The debate has intensified since former Trump personal attorney Michael Cohen's testimony, which alleged that Trump altered his business asset values and slashed employee salaries to lower his taxes.

House Democrats have spent months preparing for an unprecedented request to Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin for Trump's personal tax filings. Adding Trump's business returns could complicate the already legally delicate effort, as Trump owns over 550 companies and business entities, according to his financial disclosure reports.

Representative Richard Neal, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, is working to formulate a request to Mnuchin that can withstand a likely court fight with Trump, who has refused to release his returns, defying decades of presidential practice. Unlike predecessors, Trump has also retained extensive business interests while serving as president, raising questions about conflicts of interest.

At least four other House panels, including Oversight and Judiciary, are also interested in Trump's business returns, according to aides and lawmakers. House Oversight wants to depose long-time Trump tax attorney Sheri Dillon, who likely has a deep understanding of Trump's tax returns.

Cohen's testimony "opened a lot of doors for investigatory bodies," said Democratic Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, a member of the House Oversight Committee. "It's about comparing his financial statements with his tax reports. What Cohen named particularly were the Trump Organization taxes."

Democrats, who won control of the House in the 2018 U.S. elections, say Trump's personal returns would reveal whether he has complied with U.S. tax laws and any IRS audits, as well as his effective tax rate, business and investment income, and charitable contributions.

However, tax experts warn that focusing solely on Trump's personal returns may not be enough to identify conflicts of interest between his sprawling business investments and the policies he advocates from the Oval Office. "Personal returns alone fall short," said Steve Rosenthal, a senior fellow at the nonpartisan Tax Policy Center.

Including business returns would strengthen the House argument because the documents are geared strongly to legitimate oversight questions such as conflicts of interest. However, House Democrats are considering simplifying their request by targeting a limited number of Trump companies tied to investments of interest, rather than the entire business network, and possibly making further requests later.

"It's going to be a combination of both personal and business, because he goes back and forth between both. To get the full picture, I don't think you can just pick one or the other," said Representative Gerry Connolly, an Oversight member.

Title: Ferguson's Shift in Leadership and Perception Amidst Calls for Change

Ferguson, Missouri, has undergone significant changes in recent months, with the city's demographics and leadership shifting towards greater diversity. The city's new interim police chief, Andre Anderson, a black police commander from Glendale, Arizona, emphasized his commitment to community-centered policing during his introduction. He was flanked by Ed Beasley, the city's new interim city manager, and two newly elected African-American members of the City Council, increasing the number of black representatives to three out of seven.

The changes come after the city faced intense scrutiny following the killing of Michael Brown, which sparked widespread protests. Barbara Tipsword, an 85-year-old volunteer at a local store, expressed surprise at the angry protests, having previously thought of Ferguson as a model of integration. Over the last 25 years, the city has shifted from nearly three-quarters white to two-thirds black.

While Tipsword is not sympathetic to the protesters, she has become more aware of the anger black residents feel towards the police. The city is under pressure to present a new image, with city leaders hoping to reach a settlement with the Justice Department over its findings that the city's law enforcement policies were predatory and that city officials stood by as some employees shared racist emails.

The changes in Ferguson's leadership and demographics aim to address the city's past issues and promote a more inclusive and diverse community.

Title: US Government Debates Response to Russian Cyberattacks Amid Election Concerns

The US government is grappling with how to respond to a year-long campaign of cyberattacks attributed to Russia, which has targeted Democratic Party organizations and election registration websites. The FBI and Justice Department believe there is strong evidence to publicly name Russia as responsible for the attacks, but intelligence agencies and the Office of the Director of National Intelligence are cautioning against doing so, citing concerns about Russian retaliation and the potential exposure of US intelligence operations.

The debate comes as the Obama administration is under pressure to address the issue before the US presidential election. Some White House officials are hesitant to publicly attribute the attacks to Russia, fearing it could be seen as political interference and undermine the integrity of the election process.

Intelligence and law enforcement officials believe the goal of the Russian cyberattacks is not to support a particular candidate, but rather to sow dissension and raise doubts about the US political system. The attacks have already affected election registration websites in Illinois and Arizona, and there is increasing confidence that Russian government hackers were behind the breaches.

The hacking activity has also raised concerns about the potential impact on public confidence in the election outcome. While officials believe it would be difficult to alter the vote count, hackers could potentially tamper with registration data, causing voters to show up at their polling places only to find they are not on the voting rolls.

The debate over how to respond to the Russian cyberattacks is ongoing, with some lawmakers calling for a strong response and others urging caution. The Obama administration has not publicly attributed the attacks to Russia, but officials say they are working to gather more evidence and will make a decision based on the results of the investigation.

Title: Senator Al Franken Accused of Groping and Forcibly Kissing Radio Host Leeann Tweeden on USO Tour

Article:

Senator Al Franken, a prominent Democratic lawmaker, has been accused of groping and forcibly kissing radio host Leeann Tweeden on a USO tour in 2006. According to Tweeden, Franken repeatedly told her that actors need to rehearse everything, including kisses, and then proceeded to demonstrate the kiss on her. She described the incident as "disgusting" and "violating," stating that she pushed him away and told him she wouldn't be so nice about it if it happened again.

Franken's response to the allegations was a statement apologizing to Tweeden, saying he doesn't remember the rehearsal the same way, but acknowledging that the photo of the kiss was not funny and shouldn't have been done. However, his apology has been met with skepticism, as he was 55 years old at the time of the alleged incident and cannot claim it was a youthful indiscretion.

The Democratic Party is likely to be divided in its response to the allegations. Senator Claire McCaskill of Missouri tweeted that the behavior described is "completely unacceptable" and called for an ethics investigation. However, Senator Sheldon Whitehouse of Rhode Island responded with a seemingly unrelated comment, saying "You guys need to find something more interesting," before being asked about the Franken allegations. This response has been criticized as tone-deaf and insensitive.

The incident highlights the importance of addressing inappropriate behavior, regardless of political affiliation. As the #MeToo movement continues to bring attention to the prevalence of sexual harassment and assault, it is crucial that those in positions of power take allegations seriously and take responsibility for their actions.

**Irma Brings Widespread Power Outages and Flooding to Southeastern United States**

A powerful storm system, Hurricane Irma, brought strong winds and heavy rainfall to the southeastern United States, causing widespread power outages and flooding in Georgia and South Carolina. The storm made landfall in Florida on Sunday, bringing with it strong winds and heavy rainfall.

In Charleston, South Carolina, the storm surge caused knee-high floodwaters to flow through the streets, prompting a flash flood emergency and the closure of parts of the city's historic core. The city's mayor, John Tecklenburg, described the flooding as worse than last year's Hurricane Matthew, which inundated the city in October.

Farther inland, concerns about serious damage remained high, with strong winds causing trees to fall and power lines to break. The city of Atlanta canceled classes through Tuesday, and Delta Airlines canceled over 900 flights. In Alabama, a tropical storm warning was issued for the eastern half of the state, with concerns about flooding and strong winds.

In Florida, the storm caused extensive flooding in the Florida Keys, with Governor Rick Scott describing the damage as "extensive" and "devastating." The governor also flew over the state's Gulf Coast, reporting less damage than expected.

Rescue efforts were underway on Marco Island, where officials searched for people who stayed behind during the storm. There were no reported deaths or serious injuries, but many homes and condominiums were damaged. The storm surge had receded by daybreak, leaving the island without power and water, but with minimal structural damage.

Overall, Hurricane Irma brought significant disruption and damage to the southeastern United States, with widespread power outages, flooding, and strong winds causing significant damage.

Title: Experts Weigh In on the Relevance of Juvenile Indiscretion in Brett Kavanaugh's Past

The recent allegations against Supreme Court nominee Brett Kavanaugh, accused of attacking a girl at a house party in 1982, have sparked a national conversation about the relevance of youthful indiscretion in assessing a person's character. While some argue that the incident is an isolated mistake, experts in psychology and sexual violence prevention emphasize that sexual assault is a hard line that cannot be attributed to immaturity or experimentation.

According to clinical psychologist Christine Nicholson, many teenagers engage in risky behavior, such as drinking and pranks, but sexual assault is a different matter. "They're going to do things in the kind of experimental fashion," she said. However, experts note that sexual assault is a rare offense in teenage boys and is not a common behavior that can be written off as youthful indiscretion.

Psychology professor Sherry Hamby pointed out that if a boy covers a girl's mouth to drown out her screams, it's clear that he knows he doesn't have consent. "It's pretty clear that you know you don't have consent," she said. Similarly, Katie Edwards, a psychology professor at the University of New Hampshire, emphasized that children begin to read emotions and learn right from wrong as early as age 2 or 3, making it unlikely that a 17-year-old would not understand the harm caused by his actions.

Experts also highlighted the importance of taking responsibility for one's actions. Yale psychiatry professor Joan Cook noted that if Brett Kavanaugh had acknowledged his actions, apologized, and worked through them in therapy, it would be a different story. However, the fact that he has denied the allegations and has not taken responsibility for his actions raises concerns.

The experts' consensus is that sexual assault is a serious offense that cannot be excused by age or youthful indiscretion. As Kristen Houser, chief public affairs officer at the National Sexual Violence Resource Center, said, "Youth who commit sexual assault can be reformed by taking responsibility for their offense and working through it in therapy, but that takes admitting it first."

Title: Senate Democrats Hesitant to Push Obama on Immigration Reform Before Midterm Elections

Article:

Senate Democratic leaders are grappling with the timing of President Barack Obama's potential executive action on immigration reform, amid concerns that it could complicate the reelection bids of vulnerable Democrats in red states. Despite calls from immigration activists for swift action, Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid, Majority Whip Dick Durbin, and Sen. Chuck Schumer have refused to publicly urge the president to take action before the November midterm elections.

The debate reflects the delicate balancing act Democrats face on both ends of Pennsylvania Avenue. While Obama and Democratic congressional leaders are under pressure to stem deportations, they risk going too far and flipping the Senate to the GOP, giving Republicans full control of Congress and an even more powerful platform to block immigration reform.

The Obama administration is reviewing immigration enforcement practices and is expected to take steps within weeks to ease deportations of certain immigrants living in the United States illegally. However, the exact timing is a subject of hot speculation. The president is unlikely to halt deportations for all undocumented immigrants who would have become legalized under the Senate's comprehensive reform bill that passed last year.

House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi has singled out family ties as a key factor, saying parents of U.S. citizens or young undocumented immigrants should be granted the same protections as the so-called "Dreamers" who were shielded under a 2012 Obama administration directive. Pelosi also backs the call from Latino lawmakers to protect the estimated 8 million undocumented immigrants who would have qualified under the Senate bill.

With the potential for the fallout to hurt their incumbents in conservative states, Democratic leaders in the Senate want little ownership of the timing of the president's decision. At the same time, they don't want to anger pro-immigration groups by publicly siding with red-state Democrats.

Title: Supporting Protesters: Consider Donating to Local Bail Funds to Reduce COVID-19 Risk

The ongoing protests across the country have raised concerns about the well-being of those involved, particularly in regards to their exposure to COVID-19. Imprisoning protesters without sufficient funds can be cruel, and getting them out of jail quickly is crucial to reducing their risk of infection. To address this issue, local bail funds have been established to help protesters secure their release.

Several local bail funds, such as the Minneapolis Freedom Fund and the Brooklyn Bail Fund, have seen an outpouring of support and are now asking donors to redirect their funds to other nonprofits. This presents an opportunity to support funds within your own community. A starting point for deciding where to send your donations is a thread compiled by filmmaker Matthew A. Cherry, which lists funds for major cities across the country.

Before making a donation, it is essential to conduct a background check on the organization to ensure your funds are being used effectively. The National Bail Fund Network offers a directory of community bail funds, including dedicated funds for protesters, organized by state. ActBlue's donation portal also allows you to split your donation among 38 different community bail funds.

In the short-term, getting protesters out of jail quickly is critical. In the long-term, police brutality is a systemic issue that requires comprehensive reform. If you have extra funds to spare, consider donating to organizations working towards ending police brutality, such as Campaign Zero. Campaign Zero not only accepts donations but also provides resources on possible solutions and actions you can take to address police violence.

For those looking to advocate for Black lives, a list of resources is available.

Title: Sarah Palin Endorses Donald Trump in 2016 Presidential Race

Former vice-presidential nominee and governor of Alaska Sarah Palin has endorsed Donald Trump for the 2016 presidential election. Palin announced her support in a statement from the Trump campaign, stating, "I am proud to endorse Donald J. Trump for President of the United States of America." She later appeared alongside Trump at a campaign event at Iowa State University in Ames, Iowa.

In her endorsement speech, Palin praised Trump for bringing up controversial issues and creating a "good, heated primary." She also took aim at what she called "establishment candidates" in the race. Trump expressed gratitude for Palin's support, saying he was "greatly honored" to receive her backing.

Palin, a symbol of the Tea Party movement, is the highest-profile backer for a Republican contender so far in the race. Her endorsement comes less than two weeks ahead of the critical lead-off Iowa caucus, where Trump is locked in a dead heat with Texas Sen. Ted Cruz.

In a statement announcing the endorsement, Trump's campaign described Palin as a conservative who "helped launch the careers of several key future leaders of the Republican Party and conservative movement." The statement also quoted Cruz as saying he "would not be in the United States Senate were it not for Gov. Sarah Palin... She can pick winners."

Cruz responded to Palin's endorsement of Trump, saying "regardless of what Sarah intends to do in 2016, I will remain a big, big fan of Sarah Palin." Trump's national political director, Michael Glassner, previously worked with Palin, who was a virtual newcomer to the national political arena when she was named as John McCain's running mate.

Palin is expected to join Trump on Wednesday for campaign events in Norwalk, Iowa, and Tulsa, Okla. The endorsement was met with a response from the Democratic National Committee, which stated, "Even with a record number of candidates and internal calls to become more inclusive as a party, Donald Trump and Sarah Palin remain two of the GOP's most influential leaders. Their divisive rhetoric is now peddled by everyone from Ted Cruz to Marco Rubio. Americans deserve better than what Trump and Palin have to offer, but it seems like the other Republican candidates would rather follow in their footsteps."

Title: The Myth of Technological Unemployment: A Reality Check

The notion that technological advancements are driving jobs away from Youngstown, Ohio, and other American cities, and that this trend is a serious problem, is a common concern. However, a closer examination of the issue reveals that the reality is more nuanced. While it is true that automation and robotics have replaced some jobs, the impact is not as dire as often claimed.

Many experts, including economists Robert Gordon and Tyler Cowen, have expressed concerns about the effects of technological unemployment. However, the data suggests that workers are adapting and moving to better-paying jobs. According to the article, workers are transitioning from low-paying assembly-line jobs to higher-paying positions, such as monitoring robots, thanks to the increased efficiency and productivity brought about by automation.

The article also highlights the historical record, pointing out that previous technological advancements, such as the introduction of mechanical harvesting and hybrid corn, did not lead to widespread unemployment. In fact, the economy has consistently adapted to new technologies, and workers have found new opportunities.

The article also debunks the notion that automation is solely responsible for job losses. It notes that the decline of unionization in private companies has led to a decline in the portion of income going to the middle class, but this is not a direct result of automation.

The article concludes that the key to addressing the issue of job displacement is not to stop innovation or protect existing jobs, but to create a more flexible labor market that allows workers to adapt and retrain. It argues that government programs and subsidies are not the solution, as they can create a culture of dependency and stifle economic growth. Instead, workers themselves know best how to retrain and relocate, as seen in the example of those who moved to North Dakota during the oil boom.

In the end, the article suggests that the key to a prosperous economy is not job protection, but liberty and the ability for workers to adapt to changing circumstances.

Title: Military Court Martial: Bergdahl's Sentence Raises Questions of Justice and Command Influence

The recent sentencing of Bowe Bergdahl, a former US Army private who deserted his post in 2009, has sparked controversy and raised concerns about the role of command influence in the military justice system. Bergdahl, who pleaded guilty to desertion and endangerment, was sentenced to a minor fine and a dishonorable discharge by Judge Col. Jeffery R. Nance of the Army.

The case has been marred by President Trump's public statements, which some argue compromised the fairness of the trial. Trump had previously called Bergdahl a "dirty rotten traitor" and a "no good traitor who should have been executed." Bergdahl's lawyers had sought a pardon or commutation from President Obama, and later, a dismissal or leniency from the court martial authorities.

The presiding judge, Col. Nance, had initially stated that he was not influenced by Trump's public outbursts. However, during the sentencing hearing, Nance said he would consider Trump's comments as mitigation evidence, which has raised concerns about the potential for command influence.

Critics argue that Trump's comments were inappropriate and could have tainted the prosecution. The New York Times reported that the JAG Corps judge was willing to take the bait, stating that he would consider the president's comments as mitigation evidence. The ruling has been met with widespread criticism, with many questioning the fairness of the sentence.

The case has also raised questions about the role of command influence in the military justice system. Military commanders are not supposed to twist subordinate arms about military justice, but the Commander-in-Chief's public statements can have a significant impact on the outcome of a trial. In this case, Trump's comments were seen as a form of command influence, which can compromise the fairness of the trial.

The controversy surrounding Bergdahl's sentence has sparked a larger debate about the role of the military justice system and the impact of command influence on the outcome of trials. The case highlights the importance of maintaining the integrity of the military justice system and ensuring that justice is served fairly and impartially.

Title: Engineer's Actions and Train's Speed in Minutes Leading Up to Crash Investigated

The investigation into the derailment of Northeast Regional Train 188, which occurred on Tuesday night north of Center City Philadelphia, is focusing on the actions and decisions made by the train's engineer, Brandon Bostian, in the moments and days leading up to the crash. The train was traveling at 106 miles per hour, more than twice the speed limit, when it derailed, killing eight people and injuring over 200.

According to investigators, a video shot from the front of the train shows the train's speed increasing from 70 miles per hour to 100 miles per hour in the 16 seconds leading up to the crash. The train eventually reached a speed of 106 miles per hour before the engineer applied the emergency brakes, causing the train to slow down slightly.

The train's engineer, Brandon Bostian, was at the controls of the train when it derailed. The locomotive, an ACS64, had been in use for over a year and had no reported problems prior to the accident. The track and signals in the area had also been checked the day before the accident and showed no issues.

The train's design and infrastructure are also being examined as part of the investigation. The locomotive, a "Cities Sprinter" electric locomotive, was introduced last year and was built by Siemens specifically for Amtrak's Northeast Corridor service. The train's design has roots in Germany and Austria.

Title: Democrats' Opposition to Betsy DeVos: More Than Meets the Eye

The confirmation of Betsy DeVos as the new Secretary of Education has sparked intense debate and opposition from Democrats, with some arguing that her views are "radical" and she lacks experience as a government bureaucrat or school administrator. However, a closer examination of the opposition reveals that it may be motivated by more than just her views or qualifications. Some Democrats and mainstream media outlets have focused on claims that DeVos has "radical" views, but columnist Ross Douthat notes that her views are not significantly different from those of the Obama administration or centrist Democrats like Senator Cory Booker.

Others have criticized DeVos for her lack of experience as a government bureaucrat or school administrator, and her inability to answer certain questions during the confirmation hearings. However, these reasons may not be the primary motivators behind the intense opposition. Some argue that the real reasons for the opposition are the powerful interest groups and upper-middle-class suburbanite constituency within the Democratic Party.

The article suggests that some of these groups may be motivated by the fear that DeVos' charter schools and vouchers will make private schooling more accessible to families with financial disadvantages, ethnic minority heritage, or ideological and religious convictions that differ from the mainstream. This could potentially erode the Democratic Party's near-monopoly on education.

The article also highlights four reasons why DeVos may be a welcome remedy to the nation's educational ills. Firstly, her educational philosophy could liberate American education from federal bureaucracy, allowing families, local communities, and states to have more control over education. Secondly, her views on education emphasize the rights and freedoms of families, communities, and religions, which could lead to a more pluralistic society. Thirdly, her potential system of vouchers and charters would allow financially-disadvantaged children to choose the education that fits their unique needs and abilities. Finally, her critics' argument that she lacks experience as a teacher, principal, or educational policy wonk is not a necessary prerequisite for the office.

In conclusion, while DeVos' confirmation has sparked intense debate, it is essential to consider the motivations behind the opposition and the potential benefits of her educational philosophy. As a philanthropist who has devoted her life to education and has the work ethic and connections to make a difference, DeVos may be a welcome remedy to the nation's educational ills.

Title: President Trump Reiterates "Chinese Virus" Label, Despite Global Health Officials' Warnings

President Donald Trump has again used the term "Chinese virus" to refer to the novel coronavirus, despite warnings from global health officials against associating the disease with a particular nation or ethnic group. The president's comments have drawn backlash and raised concerns about stigmatizing Asian-Americans.

Trump's rhetoric gained attention on Tuesday after he used the phrase in a tweet about supporting the airline industry, which has been heavily impacted by travel restrictions. "The United States will be powerfully supporting those industries, like Airlines and others, that are particularly affected by the Chinese Virus. We will be stronger than ever before!" he wrote.

The World Health Organization has warned against using terms that associate diseases with certain groups of people, and scientists have confirmed that the virus originated in Wuhan, China, late last year. However, Trump defended his terminology, stating, "Because it comes from China, it's not racist at all. It comes from China, that's why. I want to be accurate."

The White House also pointed out that similar names for illnesses have been used in the past, such as "Spanish Flu" and "West Nile Virus." However, many critics have condemned the president's use of the term, with New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio tweeting, "Our Asian-American communities – people YOU serve – are already suffering. They don't need you fueling more bigotry."

Several social media users, including Dr. Eugene Gu and Evangelical pastor Eugene Cho, have also spoken out against the president's language, calling it racist and divisive. Fox News Channel host Tucker Carlson, however, praised the president's remark, saying, "How is it inaccurate to call a virus from China 'Chinese'?"

The president's use of this rhetoric has sparked concerns about the potential consequences of stigmatizing Asian-Americans, with the NYPD investigating several cases of potential hate crime attacks and Asian-Americans reporting increased discrimination, bullying, and harassment.

Title: Trump Clarifies Stance on Russian Election Meddling, Says He Believes Putin's Denials

Article:

President Donald Trump clarified his stance on Russian election meddling on Sunday, stating that he believes the assessment of U.S. intelligence agencies that Russia interfered in the 2016 presidential election. However, he also expressed his belief that Russian President Vladimir Putin is sincere in his denials of interference.

At a news conference in Hanoi with Vietnam's President, Trump said, "I believe that he feels that he and Russia did not meddle in the election. As to whether I believe it, I'm with our agencies. As currently led by fine people, I believe very much in our intelligence agencies."

On Saturday, Trump had questioned the judgment of former heads of the FBI, CIA, and Office of the Director of National Intelligence, calling them "hacks" and suggesting that their opinions on Russian meddling were biased. However, on Sunday, he said he has worked "very strongly" with the new leadership in U.S. intelligence agencies.

The CIA and other U.S. intelligence agencies have concluded that Russia meddled in the 2016 election to help Trump defeat Democrat Hillary Clinton. A special counsel's examination of potential collusion between Moscow and Trump campaign aides has led to indictments against Trump's former campaign chairman and another top aide for crimes unrelated to the campaign, as well as a guilty plea from a Trump foreign policy adviser.

Senator John McCain, an Arizona Republican, criticized Trump's stance, saying it was "naive" to believe Putin's denials over those of the American intelligence community. "There's nothing 'America First' about taking the word of a KGB colonel over that of the American intelligence community," McCain said.

Trump also took to Twitter to defend his efforts to improve relations with Russia, accusing critics of "playing politics" and hurting the U.S. He emphasized the need for cooperation with Russia on issues such as North Korea, Syria, and Ukraine, saying, "We have to get to work to solve Syria, to solve North Korea, to solve Ukraine, to solve terrorism."

The president also pointed to recent U.S. sanctions against Moscow over election meddling, saying, "People don't realize Russia has been very, very heavily sanctioned. They were sanctioned at a very high level, and that took place very recently. It's now time to get back to healing a world that is shattered and broken."

Title: Sanders Faces Uphill Battle in Arizona as Clinton Gains Momentum

The Bernie Sanders campaign's prospects in Arizona, a state where he had devoted significant resources and drawn large crowds, have been dealt a significant blow following a series of losses in recent primaries and caucuses. The Vermont senator's wife, Jane Sanders, visited Sheriff Joe Arpaio's "Tent City" outdoor jail, an event that was widely criticized by immigration advocates. The Clinton campaign quickly seized on the appearance, highlighting Arpaio's reputation as an immigration hardliner.

The Clinton campaign has been aggressive in its own Latino outreach efforts, releasing a series of ads highlighting Clinton's work on immigration reform and contrasting her record with that of Donald Trump and Arpaio. Sanders has also been working to build support among Latino voters, securing endorsements from over a dozen prominent Latino Democrats and releasing a trio of ads featuring Tucson-based Congressman Raul Grijalva.

Demographically, Arizona is a challenging state for Sanders, with a sizable Hispanic population that has historically worked in Clinton's favor. According to Arizona Democratic Party chairwoman Alexis Tameron, the Clintons have a strong reputation in the state, with President Bill Clinton having visited multiple times to campaign on behalf of Democrats.

While Sanders has made stops in the state three times and attracted large crowds, Clinton has yet to campaign in Arizona, with her first stop scheduled for Monday. Early voting numbers have offered some positive signs for Clinton, with a significant number of voters 65 and over and those between 50-64 returning ballots. By contrast, younger voters, who have been a strong demographic for Sanders, have shown less enthusiasm.

Despite the challenges, Sanders' chief strategist, Tad Devine, remains optimistic that the campaign can still pull out a victory in Arizona. However, the numbers suggest that Clinton has a significant advantage, with half of the state's voters having already cast their ballots.

Title: Republican Senators Cruz and Rubio Clash on National Security and Immigration in Final Debate of 2015

In the final Republican presidential debate of 2015, the focus was on the growing feud between Senators Ted Cruz of Texas and Marco Rubio of Florida. Both senators are vying to become the main alternative to front-runner Donald Trump, with Cruz surging in the polls and Rubio polling third nationally. The debate centered on national security and immigration, with the two senators going after each other on these issues.

On national security, Rubio criticized Cruz for his vote on the USA Freedom Act, which imposed new limits on the collection of phone metadata by US intelligence agencies. Rubio argued that the legislation would hinder the government's ability to identify potential threats before they attack. Cruz defended his vote, stating that the legislation expanded the potential universe of records the government has access to, but did not provide information on the process for accessing those records.

The two senators also clashed on defense spending and the approach to Islamic State. Rubio criticized Cruz for voting against legislation that authorizes defense spending, stating that it would hinder efforts to defeat the terrorist group. Cruz defended his "no" votes, citing his opposition to the federal government's authority to detain US citizens without due process.

On immigration, Rubio faced criticism from Cruz for his support of comprehensive immigration reform legislation, which included a path to citizenship for undocumented immigrants. Cruz accused Rubio of favoring "legalization" of undocumented immigrants, while Rubio sought to distance himself from the bill and emphasize his support for increased border security.

Both senators were deemed to have had strong performances in the debate, and their duel is likely to intensify in the weeks ahead. The debate highlighted the differences between the two senators, with Cruz emphasizing his conservative credentials and Rubio presenting himself as a more moderate alternative.

Title: Brazil's President-Elect Jair Bolsonaro: A Shift in Political Landscape

Article:

Brazil's recent presidential election has sparked concerns among the international community, with many labeling President-elect Jair Bolsonaro as the "Trump of the Tropics." However, Brazilians seem unfazed by the comparisons, citing their country's unique struggles and the need for strong leadership.

Bolsonaro's election has been met with criticism from the Western liberal elite, who are concerned about his stance on issues such as climate change, abortion, and environmental activism. His appointment of Ernesto Araujo as foreign minister has been particularly scrutinized, with some labeling him as a "right-wing extremist."

Araujo's views on climate change, which he has described as a "Marxist crock," have been met with disapproval from the international community. The left-leaning Guardian newspaper has criticized Araujo's appointment, stating that it is a "blow to the Amazon rainforest" and a "threat to the planet."

However, many Brazilians see Bolsonaro's election as a much-needed change from the country's previous left-wing government. They are tired of the high levels of gang violence and corruption, and believe that Bolsonaro's military background and tough-on-crime stance will bring much-needed stability to the country.

Bolsonaro's decision to cancel the climate change summit in Rio de Janeiro has also been met with criticism, with some seeing it as a step backward for the country. However, others see it as a pragmatic decision, given the country's economic struggles and the need to prioritize its own interests.

The article notes that Brazil's homicide rate is high enough to meet the UN's criteria for low-intensity civil war, and that the country has been plagued by gang violence and corruption. Many Brazilians see Bolsonaro's election as a chance to break away from the region's left-wing ideology and take a more nationalist approach.

Overall, the article presents a nuanced view of Bolsonaro's election, highlighting both the concerns and the hopes that it brings. While some see his election as a step backward for the country, others believe it is a much-needed change for Brazil.

Title: Esquire Magazine Debuts Cover Story on White Teen's Life Amidst Black History Month

Article:

Esquire magazine has sparked controversy with its latest cover story, featuring a profile on 17-year-old Ryan Morgan, a high school senior from West Bend, Wisconsin. The March issue's cover, titled "An American Boy," explores Morgan's life as a white, middle-class teenager growing up in the era of social media, school shootings, toxic masculinity, #MeToo, and a divided country.

The cover choice has been widely panned on Twitter, with many criticizing the magazine for choosing a white teenager as the focus of its Black History Month issue. The criticism has been fueled by the inclusion of a tease for a story on disgraced movie mogul Harvey Weinstein's defense, which some see as insensitive and tone-deaf.

The Esquire piece chronicles Morgan's daily life, including the adversity he has faced for being a President Trump supporter. Morgan told the magazine, "I couldn't say anything without pissing someone off... Lots of drama over politics, it ruined friendships and changed social groups. People were making friends based on their politics more than anything."

Esquire editor-in-chief Jay Fielden defended the cover story, stating that it is part of a series on growing up now – white, black, LGBTQ, female – that will continue to appear in coming issues. Fielden explained that the magazine asked author Jennifer Percy to look at the country's divisions through the eyes of one kid, Ryan Morgan, who is white, lives in the reddest county in Wisconsin, and is an unusually mature, intelligent, and determined young man.

Title: US Signs Legislation Imposing Sanctions on China Over Uighur Repression, China Threatens Retaliation

The United States has signed legislation aimed at imposing sanctions on China over its treatment of the Uighur Muslim minority. The bill, passed with only one dissenting vote, requires sanctions against those responsible for the oppression of Uighurs and calls on US companies operating in Xinjiang to take steps to ensure they do not use parts made with forced labor.

The United Nations estimates that over a million Muslims have been detained in camps in the Xinjiang region, with the US State Department accusing Chinese officials of subjecting them to torture, abuse, and attempting to erase their culture and religion. China denies mistreatment and claims the camps provide vocational training to combat extremism.

In response to the signing of the law, China's Foreign Ministry expressed anger, calling it a "malicious attack" on China and urging the US to correct its "mistakes" and stop interfering in China's internal affairs. China warned that it will take "countermeasures" if the US does not correct its actions, without providing details.

The signing of the bill comes as China and the US are already at odds over various issues, including China's handling of the coronavirus pandemic and US support for Taiwan. The World Uyghur Congress thanked President Trump for signing the law, saying it "gave hope to the desperate Uighur people."

Trump signed the bill with a signing statement that some of its requirements may limit his constitutional authority to conduct diplomacy, and he will regard them as advisory rather than mandatory. The White House did not immediately respond to a request for comment.

The Uighur law also calls for sanctions on Chen Quanguo, a member of China's powerful Politburo and Xinjiang's Communist Party secretary, who is responsible for "gross human rights violations."

Title: House Republicans and Democrats Unveil Contrasting Budget Plans, Reflecting Deep Divisions

Article:

House Republicans and Democrats have released their respective budget plans, showcasing starkly different visions for the future. The plans, presented by Budget Chairman Paul Ryan, R-Wis., and the House Progressive Caucus, led by Reps. Raul Grijalva, D-Ariz., and Keith Ellison, D-Minn., highlight the deep divisions between the two parties.

The Republican plan, a 91-page document, aims to balance the budget in 10 years by reducing government spending and reforming the tax code. It proposes lowering tax rates on individuals and corporations, including high-income earners, while eliminating deductions and credits. National defense remains fully funded, but Medicare is essentially voucherized for those turning 55 now, with patients expected to opt for fewer procedures to reduce healthcare costs.

The plan also includes block-granted Medicare, giving states more flexibility in managing funds, and the repeal of the Affordable Care Act, allowing individuals to opt out of health insurance. Tort reform and job-training programs are also included.

In contrast, the House Progressive Caucus's 19-page blueprint aims to lower the deficit by raising taxes and investing in infrastructure, education, and public welfare programs. The plan proposes increasing taxes on individuals making over $250,000, while maintaining benefits in Medicare, Medicaid, and Social Security. It also includes a public-option health system, expanded unemployment benefits, and increased funding for infrastructure and education.

The two plans differ significantly, with the Republican plan aiming to balance the budget in 10 years and the Democratic plan projecting a $4.2 trillion deficit over the same period. While neither plan is likely to become law, they represent the extremes of what is possible, reflecting the deep divisions between the two parties.

The House is often seen as the epicenter of the partisan divide, with Republicans and Democrats holding vastly different views on fiscal responsibility and government spending. Over the next 10 years, it is likely that Republicans and Democrats will find common ground in the middle, but the stark differences between these two budget plans highlight the challenges ahead.

Title: Democrats Adopt Republican-Like Campaign Ads in Swing Districts

In a shift from traditional Democratic rhetoric, several Democratic candidates are running campaign ads that echo Republican themes, such as balanced budgets, tax cuts, and limited government spending. This strategy is aimed at appealing to more conservative voters in swing congressional districts, where the political environment is increasingly challenging for Democrats.

In a departure from their party's typical messaging, Democratic candidates are adopting a more moderate tone to appeal to voters in districts that broke sharply for President Barack Obama in 2012. Colorado's Andrew Romanoff, running in a district Obama won in 2012 and 2008, has started airing a commercial that highlights his record as speaker of the state House of Representatives, where he helped balance the state's budget. The ad features a graph of the nation's soaring debt, similar to one used by Wisconsin Rep. Paul Ryan in 2011 to promote his budget plan.

Other Democratic candidates, such as New Hampshire's Ann McLane Kuster and former Iowa state Sen. Staci Appel, are also running ads that tout their support for small-business tax cuts and fighting overspending in government. Democratic Rep. Ron Barber, running in a swing southern Arizona district, uses his first TV spot to highlight his support for increasing border security funds, without mentioning elements of immigration reform popular among Democratic voters.

Even Democrats running in deep-red districts are adopting conservative themes. North Little Rock Mayor Patrick Henry Hays, running in an Arkansas district Mitt Romney won in 2012, uses his first TV ad to discuss the need for a balanced budget, limited government regulations, and less wasteful spending. Like Romanoff, Hays includes a graphic to depict the national debt.

According to Democratic pollster Ben Tulchin, "It's a different kind of electorate. If you're running in a competitive district as a Democrat in a non-presidential year, you want to strike a more moderate tone." The strategy is aimed at appealing to more conservative voters and increasing the chances of Democratic candidates' success in swing districts.

Title: Obama Clarifies Economic Stance, Backtracks on "Private Sector is Doing Fine" Comment

President Barack Obama held a press conference on Friday to address the state of the economy, but his comments sparked controversy and led to a swift backtracking. Obama initially stated that the private sector is "doing fine," which was met with swift criticism from Republican presidential candidate Mitt Romney and congressional Republicans. They argued that the president is out of touch with the economy and that his statement contradicts the consensus among economists that this is the weakest recovery from a recession in modern American history.

However, Obama later clarified his comments, stating that the economy is not doing fine and that private-sector job growth is outpacing austerity-sapped public payrolls. He emphasized that he is aware of the economy's weakness and is working to make it stronger. Obama also used the opportunity to denounce rumors of leaks of key national security information coming from the White House as "offensive."

Romney and other Republicans quickly pounced on Obama's initial comment, with Romney calling it an "extraordinary miscalculation" and "a misunderstanding by a president who's out of touch." House Majority Leader Eric Cantor (R-Va.) and House Speaker John Boehner (R-Ohio) also criticized Obama's statement, with Cantor saying the private sector is not doing well and Boehner calling Obama "completely disconnected from reality."

Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-Ky.) told Fox News that Obama must be "on another planet" and that his statement is a sign of his disconnect from reality. Obama's comments were intended to reassure the public that he is working to address the economy's weaknesses, but instead sparked a political firestorm.

Title: Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.'s Use of Biblical and Literary References in His Speeches

Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., a son, grandson, and great-grandson of Baptist ministers, was well-versed in the black church's oral tradition and knew how to engage his audience through his speeches. He often incorporated jazz-like improvisations and quotes from the Bible, as well as vivid imagery and metaphors, to convey the struggles of African-Americans and provide hope and encouragement to his audience. In his famous "I Have a Dream" speech, King drew parallels between the struggles of African-Americans and those of the Israelites in Exodus, using biblical language to emphasize the importance of perseverance and faith.

The speech is replete with biblical references, including quotes from Galatians and allusions to prophets Isaiah and Amos. King also drew inspiration from other historical and literary texts, such as the Declaration of Independence, Shakespeare, and Woody Guthrie's song "This Land Is Your Land." These references added depth and context to his message, much like T.S. Eliot's allusions in his poem "The Waste Land."

King's ability to synthesize diverse ideas and motifs was shaped by his childhood in his father's church and his later studies of various thinkers, including Reinhold Niebuhr, Gandhi, and Hegel. This gift allowed him to address a wide range of audiences and make complex ideas accessible and familiar. As the leader of the civil rights movement, King was able to balance the concerns of grassroots activists with the need to forge alliances with the federal government.

King's use of historical and literary references also lent authority to his arguments, evoking memories of Langston Hughes' poem "Let America Be the Dream the Dreamers Dream" and W.E.B. Du Bois' description of the "wonderful America" envisioned by the founding fathers. The speech concludes with a Negro spiritual, "Free at Last, Free at Last; Thank God Almighty, We Are Free at Last," emphasizing the importance of perseverance and faith in the face of adversity.

Title: Congressional Negotiators Work to Finalize Spending Bill, Avoid Government Shutdown

Congressional leaders are working to finalize a $1.3 trillion spending bill, with House Speaker Paul Ryan expressing optimism that an agreement can be reached by the end of the day on Tuesday. The bill, which would fund government agencies through the remainder of the fiscal year, requires bipartisan agreement from the White House and all four corners of Congress.

Appropriators have been working around the clock to complete the bill, with some negotiators working past 1 a.m. on Tuesday. The agreement still faces several unresolved issues, with a top Democratic aide stating that there are around 20 riders still in play and at least a dozen major issues still being discussed.

One potential sticking point is the Fix NICS gun purchase background checks bill, which Republicans are considering attaching to the spending bill. House Speaker Ryan signaled that Republicans are discussing the bill with their Democratic counterparts, and believes it is an important issue.

Other lawmakers, such as Rep. Dan Donovan, are hoping to attach the Gateway Tunnel project to the spending bill. Donovan believes that President Trump may be willing to back off his veto threat if the omnibus helps fund the project, which he sees as an economic stimulus.

However, not all lawmakers are on board with the spending bill. Rep. Dave Brat, a Virginia Republican and member of the Freedom Caucus, has stated that he will vote against the bill due to its $1.3 trillion price tag.

With government funding set to lapse at the end of the day on Friday, time is running out for Congress to reach an agreement. Rep. Donovan emphasized the importance of keeping the government open, stating that lawmakers were sent to Washington to make the government work better for the American people.

Title: Former FBI Deputy Director Andrew McCabe Admits to Misleading Investigators About Media Leak

Former FBI Deputy Director Andrew McCabe has admitted to misleading investigators about his role in a media leak, according to transcripts of his interviews with investigators released by the Justice Department's inspector general. The transcripts were released in response to a Freedom of Information Act lawsuit by Citizens for Responsibility and Ethics in Washington.

According to the transcripts, McCabe repeatedly denied being the source of the leak, but later confessed and apologized when confronted by investigators. An unidentified FBI investigator expressed frustration with McCabe, stating that he had spent a significant amount of time investigating the leak, only to discover that it came from the former deputy director himself.

The investigation was conducted by the Justice Department's inspector general, Michael E. Horowitz, who concluded that McCabe "lacked candor" with investigators probing a leak to The Wall Street Journal that revealed the FBI was investigating Hillary Clinton's emails and the Clinton Foundation. As a result, the Justice Department fired McCabe in the spring of 2018, citing Horowitz's conclusions.

McCabe is currently suing the Justice Department for wrongful termination, alleging that President Trump ordered his firing. The Justice Department is considering criminal charges against McCabe based on Horowitz's conclusions, but his attorneys have denied any wrongdoing. McCabe has stated that he would refuse to accept a plea deal.

Title: Supreme Court Sends Oregon Bakery Case Back to Lower Court, Avoiding Decision on Same-Sex Wedding Cake

The Supreme Court has sent a case involving an Oregon bakery back to a lower court, avoiding a decision on whether the bakery's refusal to bake a wedding cake for a same-sex couple violated state antidiscrimination laws. The case, which involves the bakery's owners claiming the state drove them out of business due to fines, was sent back to the Oregon Court of Appeals in light of a previous Supreme Court ruling in a similar case, Masterpiece Cakeshop v. Colorado.

In the Masterpiece Cakeshop case, the Supreme Court ruled 7-2 in favor of a baker who refused to serve a same-sex couple, citing the baker's religious beliefs. The court did not decide on the underlying question of whether a wedding cake qualifies as artistic expression protected by the First Amendment.

The Supreme Court's decision to send the Oregon bakery case back to the lower court is seen as an incremental win for the bakery owners, while avoiding a divisive decision in the midst of the 2020 election campaign. The court's term beginning in October is expected to be significant for LGBT rights, with a decision on whether federal antidiscrimination laws apply to LGBT employees expected by June 2020.

The case highlights the ongoing debate over the balance between religious freedom and anti-discrimination laws, with the Supreme Court having punted on the issue twice in two years. In the Masterpiece Cakeshop case, Justice Anthony Kennedy emphasized the difficulty of deciding the issue, noting that a baker's religious rights "might" be violated by antidiscrimination laws, but also acknowledging the difficulty of pinpointing the moment when a customer's right to not be discriminated against gives way to the business owner's own First Amendment rights.

Title: Shale Gas and Natural Infrastructure: Balancing Energy and Environmental Concerns

The increasing use of shale gas as a source of electricity is a significant development, as it generates less carbon dioxide than traditional coal-based power plants. According to Philip Verleger Jr., oil economist, this shift will lead to lower oil and gas prices, benefiting American consumers, manufacturers, and jobs. However, he notes that the new technologies used to extract shale oil and gas could release vast quantities of methane, a potent contributor to climate change, if not done properly.

Environmentalists are urging the president to take action to mitigate the potential negative impacts of shale gas extraction. A carbon tax, which would discourage the use of carbon-intensive fuels in favor of low-carbon energy, is seen as a key solution. The president could also use his authority under the Clean Air Act to order reductions in CO2 emissions from existing coal power plants and refiners by 25%.

Additionally, the president could focus on reducing energy waste in buildings, as about 30% of energy is currently wasted. This could be achieved through policies that encourage the use of energy-efficient technologies and practices.

Mark Tercek, president and CEO of The Nature Conservancy, suggests that the president should also emphasize the concept of "natural infrastructure," which refers to the natural ecosystems that provide essential services, such as flood control and water supply. Tercek notes that investing in natural infrastructure, such as restoring forests and wetlands, can help communities adapt to climate change and reduce the risk of damage from natural disasters.

The article concludes by highlighting the importance of balancing energy and environmental concerns. While shale gas may provide short-term benefits, it is crucial to consider the long-term implications of its extraction and use. By investing in both traditional infrastructure and natural infrastructure, the president can help mitigate the negative impacts of shale gas and promote a more sustainable future.

Title: Obama Defends Surveillance Programs, Says They Are Necessary to Fight Terrorism

Article:

President Barack Obama defended his administration's collection of private citizens' phone records, email, and Internet activities as "modest encroachments on privacy" necessary to fight the war on terrorism. At a news conference in San Jose, California, Obama emphasized that the National Security Agency (NSA) is not listening to phone calls or looking at content, and that the American people should feel comfortable with the established process and procedure.

The president's comments came after the news broke that the NSA, at the request of the FBI, was collecting the phone records of millions of Verizon customers in the U.S. The government also acknowledged that the NSA is gathering Internet users' personal data, such as email, photos, and online chats, from the computer servers of at least nine large Web service providers under a top-secret program called "Prism."

Obama assured that lawmakers are "fully briefed" on the programs, which have been authorized by broad bipartisan majorities since 2006. He emphasized that the surveillance does not apply to U.S. citizens or those living in the United States.

The president also acknowledged that he himself might be on a list of individuals who could be targeted for surveillance after he leaves office, but emphasized that he has a personal interest in ensuring his privacy is protected.

Obama stated that his administration must balance national security interests with the protections of individual freedom guaranteed in the Constitution. He emphasized that there is a system of checks and balances in place among federal judges, Congress, and the executive branch to ensure the surveillance programs are not abused.

The president also emphasized that government employees involved in national security "take this work very seriously" and "operate like professionals," and that the last thing they would do is take programs like this to listen to someone's phone calls.

Title: US Intelligence Community Majority Believes COVID-19 Originated from Wuhan Lab Leak

The majority of the United States intelligence community agencies believe that COVID-19 originated from a laboratory leak in Wuhan, China, according to a senior intelligence official. The official stated that while not all 17 agencies are fully on board with this idea, most believe that the virus was an accidental leak, rather than an intentional act. The official noted that the unanimous view among the intelligence community is that the virus was not the result of an intentional act.

This account confirms what Fox News White House reporter John Roberts reported, and matches with what President Donald Trump has said publicly. Roberts cited a senior intelligence official, stating that there is agreement among most of the 17 intelligence agencies that COVID-19 originated in the Wuhan lab. The source stressed that the release is believed to be a mistake, and was not intentional.

The Office of the Director of National Intelligence confirmed in a statement that the intelligence community is "rigorously" investigating whether the virus was a result of a lab leak, while making clear that COVID-19 is not believed to be "manmade or genetically modified." Trump stated during a press conference that he has seen information that indicates with a high degree of confidence that the virus originated from the Wuhan Institute of Virology.

It is worth noting that not all 17 intelligence agencies agree on the origin of the virus, with some still open to the possibility that it leaked from a laboratory. However, confidence is high among 70-75% of the agencies, according to Roberts.

Title: Obama Highlights Benefits of Healthcare Law, Criticizes Republican Efforts to Repeal

The White House hosted a gathering of families who have received rebate checks from their insurance companies, as part of the Affordable Care Act (ACA), also known as Obamacare. President Obama used the event to highlight the benefits of the healthcare law and criticize Republican lawmakers who are trying to repeal it. The president emphasized that the law is working as intended, with insurance companies being held accountable for spending a certain percentage of premium dollars on medical care and improving health care quality.

The event featured families who have benefited from the law's provision, which requires insurance companies to spend at least 80% of premium dollars on medical care and improving health care quality. One such family, Morgan Theriot, received a $267 refund check from her insurance company after it failed to meet the requirement. Obama asked rhetorically what opponents of the law think people should do with the money they were reimbursed, suggesting they should send it back to the insurance companies.

However, Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell, a Kentucky Republican, countered that the president is not telling the full story. He pointed out that next year, Obamacare will impose a new sales tax on the purchase of health insurance that will cost Americans about $8 billion. McConnell urged the administration to work with Republicans to repeal the law and start over.

Speaker John A. Boehner, an Ohio Republican, also reiterated the GOP's commitment to repealing the law, citing concerns that it is driving up costs and forcing people to give up their current health plans. The House voted to delay mandates in the federal healthcare law requiring individuals and large employers to have coverage, with some Democrats joining Republicans in supporting the measure.

The president's event came a day after the House voted to delay the individual and employer mandates, with some Democrats joining Republicans in supporting the measure. The president chuckled at Republican lawmakers for repeatedly voting to repeal provisions of the law, saying they have a lot of problems to address in the country.

The article also mentions that the administration announced a one-year delay in the requirement for employers with more than 50 workers to provide health insurance for all full-time employees. Employment law specialist Sharon Stiller noted that many employers are uncertain about the definition of "part-time" employee, which is currently defined as anyone who works less than 30 hours per week.

Title: Heritage Action to "Key Vote" Bill Ditching Obamacare Provisions

Heritage Action, the activist arm of the conservative Heritage Foundation, has announced it will "key vote" a bill that ditches certain provisions of the Affordable Care Act (ACA), also known as Obamacare. The bill, which is set to be taken up by the House, repeals the individual and employer mandates, some taxes, and an independent panel to cut Medicare costs. However, it does not fully repeal the ACA, including its major spending provisions, such as the Medicaid expansion and subsidies for individuals to purchase insurance on the exchanges.

The bill uses the reconciliation process to repeal certain provisions of the ACA, which requires a simple majority of Senate votes. Policy experts agree that using budget reconciliation rules to repeal Obamacare is the best chance for Republicans to put a repeal bill on President Obama's desk, despite the president's likely veto.

Heritage Action's decision to "key vote" the bill puts pressure on conservatives to vote against a bill they had otherwise been enthusiastic about. This move may inadvertently praise Democrats, who plan to vote against the bill because they support the healthcare law.

The bill's proponents argue that it is a net tax cut, a net spending cut, and a net reduction in the deficit and debt. It repeals the most essential parts of Obamacare and cannot be filibustered by Harry Reid. The bill also forces President Obama to double down on the most unpopular parts of his healthcare law.

However, critics argue that the bill does not fully repeal the ACA and does not address the individual mandate tax, which requires all Americans to purchase a government-mandated product. The bill also does not repeal the IPAB rationing board and some of the most harmful taxes built into the law.

Despite the controversy, many conservatives strongly support the bill, which would defund the bulk of Planned Parenthood's taxpayer subsidies and redirect those dollars to women's health centers that are not scandal-tainted abortion factories.

In conclusion, the bill is a complex and controversial issue, with both sides presenting valid arguments. While Heritage Action's decision to "key vote" the bill may put pressure on conservatives, it also highlights the importance of strategic messaging and advancing the proverbial ball in the fight against Obamacare.

Title: Obama and Romney Court Latino Voters with Immigration Policy Stances

The presidential campaigns of President Barack Obama and Republican nominee Mitt Romney are taking their stump speeches to a prominent group of elected Latino officials this week. Obama will address the National Association of Latino Elected and Appointed Officials (NALEO) on Friday, while Romney will speak to the group on Thursday.

The appearances come just a week after Obama announced a new policy allowing some undocumented young people to stay in the U.S. Romney has not publicly denounced the move, and both candidates recognize the importance of garnering Latino votes in the election.

The economy remains the main event of the presidential election, but immigration is a significant side issue with potential electoral consequences.
