Title: Trump Accuses McCabe and Rosenstein of Pursuing "Illegal and Treasonous" Plot Against Him

Article:

President Donald Trump has accused former FBI Deputy Director Andrew McCabe and Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein of pursuing an "illegal and treasonous" plot against him. The allegations stem from McCabe's recent interviews promoting his forthcoming book, in which he detailed private discussions between Rosenstein and other Justice Department officials about secretly recording and potentially ousting Trump.

According to McCabe, Rosenstein suggested recording Trump in the days following James Comey's firing as FBI director, which McCabe described as a "serious" proposal. Trump responded on Twitter, calling McCabe a liar and lashing out at top DOJ and FBI officials, including former Attorney General Jeff Sessions.

Trump's tweet referenced the "insurance policy" mentioned in texts between former FBI officials Peter Strzok and Lisa Page, which was widely suspected of referring to aspects of the Russia collusion probe. McCabe claimed he never considered taking Rosenstein up on the offer and discussed the matter with the FBI's then-general counsel, James A. Baker.

Baker testified to congressional investigators that McCabe and Page came to him and shared details of the meeting where Rosenstein made the comments. Baker took their word seriously and said he had a heart attack when he learned of the plan. Days later, Rosenstein appointed Robert Mueller as special counsel to oversee the investigation into allegations of collusion between the Trump campaign and Russian officials.

Rosenstein has denied pursuing or authorizing the recording of the president and has also denied McCabe's suggestion that he broached the idea of invoking the 25th Amendment. The Justice Department echoed both denials in a statement, saying Rosenstein was not in a position to consider invoking the 25th Amendment.

McCabe claimed that Rosenstein discussed the 25th Amendment with him, stating that he was counting votes or possible votes to remove Trump from office. Fox News reported that Baker provided more details about the alleged 25th Amendment discussions, stating that two Cabinet officials were "ready to support" such an effort.

Title: US Democrats Wear Kente Cloth Scarves Amidst Police Reform Debate

The recent proposal by US Democrats in Congress to reform the police following the death of George Floyd has sparked a unique controversy, with many commenters on social media focusing on the scarves worn by lawmakers. The scarves, made from a colorful Ghanaian cloth called kente, were given out by the Congressional Black Caucus to show solidarity with the African American community.

The kente cloth has a rich history and cultural significance in Ghana, with intricate designs and bold colors. It is often worn to reflect pride in African heritage, particularly during special occasions such as graduation ceremonies for students in historically black fraternities or sororities.

The Congressional Black Caucus has worn kente at other events, including the 400th anniversary of the arrival of enslaved Africans to America and President Donald Trump's State of the Union address in 2018. The cloth is associated with the Ashanti people in central Ghana and is linked with special occasions, as it is expensive to make.

The kente cloth has become a trending topic on Twitter, with some celebrities like Questlove and John Legend sharing their reactions. While some people found it amusing, others saw it as a way to promote African culture and heritage. However, some critics, like Kenyan writer Nanjala Nyabola, viewed the Democrats' use of kente as an insult to Africans, saying "We are not your props."

The controversy surrounding the kente cloth has diverted attention from the proposed reforms aimed at making it easier to prosecute officers for misconduct, banning chokeholds, and addressing racism. The Democrats' Justice in Policing Act of 2020 has yet to receive support from Republicans, who control the US Senate.

Title: Canadian Parliament Unanimously Condemns Trump's Attacks on Prime Minister Trudeau

The Canadian House of Commons has passed a motion condemning the "disparaging ad hominem statements" made by U.S. officials, including President Donald Trump, against Prime Minister Justin Trudeau. The symbolic move comes after a series of verbal sparring matches between the two leaders following the Group of Seven (G-7) summit in Canada last weekend.

The motion, which was approved unanimously, rejected "disparaging ad hominem statements by U.S. officials which do a disservice to bilateral relations." The move was seen as a rebuke to Trump's recent attacks on Trudeau, which included a tweet in which the president called the Canadian leader "very dishonest & weak."

The tensions between the two leaders began after Trudeau criticized Trump's tariffs during a press conference following the G-7 summit. Trump had refused to sign the joint agreement, citing disagreements over trade and tariffs. Trump officials have since accused Trudeau of "double-crossing" the president by criticizing him on television after he left the gathering.

The Canadian parliament also approved a motion supporting the Canadian steel and aluminum industry, which has been affected by Trump's tariffs. The move was seen as a way for the Canadian government to push back against the tariffs and support its domestic industry.

Trudeau was not present in the House of Commons during the vote, but the move was seen as a way for the Canadian government to stand up to Trump's attacks and defend its prime minister.

Title: Trump's Primary Challengers: A Rare Phenomenon with Limited Impact

The recent announcement by former Illinois Rep. Joe Walsh that he is challenging President Trump in the Republican primary has sparked widespread coverage. However, it is essential to examine the likelihood of a successful primary challenge against the incumbent president. Trump's popularity among Republicans remains high, with 88% of the GOP approving of his job performance in the latest Gallup poll. This level of support is rare, with only Dwight Eisenhower in 1956 having been more beloved among members of his own party.

Historically, primary challenges have been rare and often unsuccessful. The last sitting president to be denied renomination was Chester Arthur in 1884. Even Lyndon Johnson, who retired before the primary, faced challenges that likely contributed to his decision. Trump's popularity among Republicans, as measured by polls, suggests that he is not vulnerable to a primary challenge.

Head-to-head polls show Trump with massive leads over potential challengers, including former Massachusetts Gov. Bill Weld, who was the first notable candidate to jump into the race. Trump leads Weld by 60-85 points, and even high-profile hypothetical challengers like Utah Sen. Mitt Romney and former Ambassador to the United Nations Nikki Haley by up to 80 points.

While some may see the primary challenges as a way to spur a conversation about the party's direction, it is unlikely that Trump will be toppled. Challengers like Walsh, Weld, and former South Carolina Rep. Mark Sanford may be more focused on sparking a discussion about the party's direction rather than actually winning the primary.

The success of these challengers will depend on their ability to appeal to specific segments of the Republican base. Weld may be best positioned to appeal to Trump-skeptical Republicans, while Walsh's in-your-face style may be needed to pry away some of Trump's existing support. Sanford may hold the most appeal to business-oriented Republicans and their deep pockets.

However, even if the president doesn't lose renomination, it would still be a bad sign for Trump if one of his challengers gets a respectable share of the primary vote. This could put him in a category with Ford, Carter, and Bush, which would bode poorly for his reelection chances. Ultimately, the most important takeaway from Walsh's and other primary challengers' campaigns may be that they put Trump in a difficult position, making it harder for him to win the primary.

Title: Former President George H.W. Bush's Final Hours: A Gentle and Peaceful Passing

Former President George H.W. Bush, the 41st President of the United States, passed away on Friday at the age of 94, surrounded by his family and friends. In an interview on Fox News Sunday, his longtime friend and former Secretary of State James Baker shared details about Bush's final hours, describing them as "gentle and peaceful."

According to Baker, Bush spent his final hours with his loved ones, including his children, who called in to say goodbye. His last words were "I love you," spoken to his son, former President George W. Bush, who had called in to say "Dad, I love you, I will see you on the other side." Bush's peaceful passing was a testament to the kind of life he lived, with Baker noting that it was "the kind we ought to all hope we have."

The New York Times provided additional details about Bush's final days, stating that he had been fading in the last few days, having not gotten out of bed, stopped eating, and mostly sleeping. His longtime friend and former Secretary of State James A. Baker III arrived at his Houston home on Friday morning to check on him, and Bush suddenly grew alert, asking "Where are we going, Bake?" Baker replied, "We're going to heaven," to which Bush responded, "That's where I want to go."

Bush's death was confirmed by his office, with his son George W. Bush, the former president, saying goodbye to him over the phone. The former president died in his home in a gated community in Houston, surrounded by his family, friends, doctors, and a minister.

As news of his passing spread, tributes poured in from around the world, with many remembering his life and legacy. The late President George H.W. Bush will lie in state in the U.S. Capitol Rotunda from Monday evening to Wednesday morning, with the public invited to pay their respects.

In a poignant tribute, an editorial cartoon depicting Bush reuniting in heaven with his beloved wife and daughter, who passed away at a tragically young age, went viral. The cartoon brought tears to many eyes, as did the handwritten note Bush delivered to his successor, Bill Clinton, on the day of his inauguration.

Title: Republican Leaders Find Success in Pushing Back Against Democratic Attacks

Article:

The confirmation process of Supreme Court nominee Brett Kavanaugh has been a historic and contentious one. Despite Democratic efforts to delay and discredit the nominee, Kavanaugh was ultimately confirmed as the 114th associate justice of the Supreme Court. The Democratic Party's strategy, which included promoting a leaked letter accusing Kavanaugh of sexual assault, ultimately failed to disqualify him.

Kavanaugh's confirmation was a departure from the typical Republican approach, which often involves conceding to Democratic demands. However, Trump's presidency has changed the dynamics, and Republican leaders have learned to push back against Democratic attacks. Trump's willingness to take on the media and Democratic politicians has given Republicans a newfound confidence to stand their ground.

The confirmation process saw Republican leaders, such as Senator Orrin Hatch and Chairman of the Judiciary Committee Chuck Grassley, push back against Democratic attacks and criticism. Grassley even scolded the press for their bias against Kavanaugh, citing an incident where pro-Kavanaugh individuals were denied interviews while anti-Kavanaugh groups were given preferential treatment.

Trump's influence on Republican leaders is undeniable. His willingness to take on the media and Democratic politicians has given Republicans a newfound sense of confidence and willingness to push back. Trump's most significant victory yet is the confirmation of Justice Brett Kavanaugh, a testament to the power of standing up against Democratic attacks.

It remains to be seen whether this newfound confidence will continue to shape Republican leadership in the future. However, one thing is certain: Trump's presidency has changed the dynamics of political discourse, and Republican leaders are no longer afraid to push back against Democratic attacks.

Title: Thousands to March on Washington to Demand Justice and Accountability in Police Conduct

Article:

Thousands of protesters are set to gather in Washington, D.C. on Saturday to demand justice and accountability in police conduct, particularly in cases of racial profiling. The "Justice for All" march, organized by civil rights leader Rev. Al Sharpton, will bring together families of two black men who died at the hands of police: Eric Garner, who died in Staten Island after being arrested for selling loose cigarettes, and Michael Brown, who was shot and killed by a police officer in Ferguson, Missouri. Grand juries in both cases declined to indict the white officers involved.

The march aims to show Congress, the country, and the world that protesters will not stand down until systemic change, accountability, and justice are served. NAACP President and CEO Cornell William Brooks stated, "This march is one of many demonstrations to show that we will not stand down until systemic change, accountability, and justice in cases of police misconduct are served."

The event will feature a rally at Freedom Plaza, just a block from the White House, where Sharpton will speak to the crowd. The march is expected to draw attention to the need for federal action to address racial profiling and police misconduct. According to a Pew Research Center poll, about 57% of Americans believe a grand jury should have indicted police officer Daniel Pantaleo in the death of Eric Garner, who was seen on a cell phone video with his arms around Garner's neck as Garner lay on the ground, gasping "I can't breathe."

The grand jury's decision in Staten Island sparked protests in New York, Philadelphia, San Francisco, and Atlanta, as well as a congressional aide walkout in Washington. The mother of Eric Garner, Gwen Carr, expressed pride and gratitude for the ongoing protests, urging participants to "keep on doing it but just do it in peace." The mother of 12-year-old Tamir Rice, who was shot and killed by police in Cleveland, Ohio, will also attend the event.

Title: Democrats Restore References to God and Jerusalem as Israel's Capital to Party Platform

The Democratic National Convention witnessed a brief but raucous floor fight on Wednesday over the restoration of references to God and Jerusalem as Israel's capital to the official party platform. The controversy arose after the initial platform language omitted these references, sparking criticism from Republicans and some Democrats.

The restoration of the language was met with grumbling from delegates who felt they were "steamrolled" by party leaders. Platform committee head and former Ohio Governor Ted Strickland initially described the move as a "clarification" rather than an "error." However, President Obama's deputy campaign manager, Stephanie Cutter, contradicted this, stating that Obama personally intervened to restore the references, calling them a "mistake" that needed to be fixed.

Rashida Tlaib, a Michigan delegate and state representative, described the process as "irresponsible" and "wrong," stating that delegates were "shammed" because it was clear the party did not have the votes to change back the language. The visual from the floor, featuring delegates shouting down the convention chairman and booing the decision, is likely to be used by Republicans to portray Democrats as hostile to religion and Israel.

The restoration of the language, which was previously included in the 2008 platform, effectively reinstates the statement that "Jerusalem is and will remain the capital of Israel." The change was made after both Mitt Romney and GOP running mate Paul Ryan criticized the omission, with Romney stating that it signaled the party was "veering further and further away from the mainstream of the American people."

The Democratic National Committee Chairwoman, Debbie Wasserman Schultz, stated that the changes were made to maintain consistency with the personal views expressed by President Obama and the 2008 Democratic Party platform.

Title: Trump and Obama Engage in Twitter Spat Over Economic Boom

Article:

In a recent Twitter exchange, President Trump and former President Barack Obama clashed over the current economic boom. On Presidents' Day, Obama tweeted about the Recovery Act he signed in 2009, which he claimed paved the way for over a decade of economic growth and the longest streak of job creation in American history.

Trump responded by accusing Obama of trying to take credit for the economic achievements under his administration. "Did you hear the latest con job?" Trump tweeted. "President Obama is now trying to take credit for the Economic Boom taking place under the Trump Administration." He went on to highlight the economic conditions he inherited from the previous administration, stating that the Obama-Biden economy was the worst in modern history.

The Trump campaign also issued a statement criticizing Obama's tweet, saying Trump "reversed the floundering Obama/Biden economy" and created the hottest economy on record. The statement highlighted the low unemployment rates, particularly for African Americans, Hispanics, the disabled, and veterans, as well as the growth of paychecks for low- and middle-income Americans.

The exchange between Trump and Obama marks the latest in a series of Twitter spats between the two presidents.

Title: Senate Democrats Approve Budget Plan, But Face Defections and Criticism

The Senate Democrats have approved their first budget in four years, but the vote was a narrow 50-49, exposing cracks in Democratic unity. The plan, which was passed after a marathon session, failed to tackle the deficit and was criticized by some moderate Democrats who felt it did not go far enough to address the country's fiscal crisis.

The budget plan, which includes $975 billion in new taxes and $975 billion in spending reductions, primarily from health programs, defense, and reduced interest payments, would not eliminate the deficit. Instead, it would add $7.3 trillion to the national debt over the next decade.

Four Senate Democrats, including Mark Begich, a moderate Democrat from Alaska, voted against the plan, citing its failure to tackle the deficit. Begich stated that Alaskans expect Congress to make the deficit manageable and not pass the problem off to future generations.

The House Republicans, on the other hand, passed their budget plan, which aims to eliminate deficits over the next 10 years. However, their plan was criticized by Senate Democrats, who say it relies on unrealistic projections and would make significant cuts to domestic spending and health care programs.

The budget plans from both parties will now be subject to negotiations, and each side will need to make concessions to reach a final agreement. The White House has expressed displeasure with the House Republican plan, which does not include tax hikes, and has called for a balanced approach to deficit reduction.

The Senate Democrats' plan includes $100 billion for public works projects and other programs aimed at creating jobs, but it has been criticized for not going far enough to address the deficit. The plan also includes novel proposals for cutting spending, such as preventing people making over $1 million from receiving jobless benefits and cracking down on wasteful spending in the farm subsidy program.

The budget debate is expected to continue, with both parties needing to find common ground to reach a final agreement.

Title: Apple Resists FBI's Demand to Create Backdoor for iPhone Encryption

Apple has refused to comply with a federal magistrate's order to help the FBI break into an encrypted iPhone belonging to one of the shooters in the December 2015 San Bernardino terror attack. In a statement, CEO Tim Cook emphasized that the order has implications beyond the legal case at hand and that creating a backdoor to the iPhone would be "too dangerous" and "create a backdoor" that could be exploited by others.

The FBI had requested that Apple create a specialized software to bypass the iPhone's self-destruct feature, which erases data after too many unsuccessful attempts to unlock it. The FBI wants to try different combinations in rapid sequence to access the phone's contents. Apple has provided default encryption on its iPhones since 2014, allowing users to access their devices only with their passcode.

The ruling by U.S. Magistrate Judge Sheri Pym requires Apple to supply the specialized software, which the FBI believes will help investigators access the iPhone and uncover potential clues about the couple's communication and travel patterns. The FBI believes the information on the iPhone could be crucial in understanding the attack and preventing future incidents.

The FBI has argued that encryption is a major problem for law enforcement, as it makes it difficult to access devices even when there is probable cause to do so. FBI Director James Comey has stated that encryption is a major obstacle in investigations, making it difficult for authorities to access devices even when a judge has authorized a search.

The case has sparked a debate about digital privacy and national security, with Apple emphasizing the importance of protecting user data and the FBI pushing for greater access to encrypted devices. The ruling has significant implications for the tech industry, as it sets a precedent for government requests for backdoors in encrypted devices.

Title: Presidential Candidates Respond to Orlando Mass Shooting, Highlighting Different Approaches to Terrorism and Gun Control

The mass shooting in Orlando, Florida, has sparked a stark contrast in responses from presidential candidates Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton. Trump has called for tougher action against terrorism and taken credit for being "right" about the threat, while Clinton has emphasized the need to keep "weapons of war" off American streets.

As the investigation into the shooting continues, Trump has taken to social media to express his condolences and call for increased vigilance. He has also criticized President Barack Obama's response to the attack, saying the president should "step down." Trump's comments have been met with criticism from some, who see his approach as crass and insensitive.

Clinton, on the other hand, has taken a more measured approach, expressing her condolences and emphasizing the need for stricter gun control legislation. She has also avoided making any direct connections to international terrorism, instead focusing on the need to keep guns out of the hands of terrorists or violent criminals.

The differing responses from the two candidates highlight the stark choices facing American voters in the upcoming election. Trump's approach emphasizes a more aggressive and militaristic response to terrorism, while Clinton's approach focuses on addressing the root causes of gun violence and promoting stricter gun control measures.

As the investigation into the shooting continues, it remains to be seen how the tragedy will impact the presidential campaign. However, one thing is clear: the choice between Trump and Clinton will be a stark one, with voters facing a decision that will have significant implications for the future of the country.

Title: Obama Expects Immigration Bill on Senate Floor Next Month, Discusses Guest Workers and Upcoming Trip to Mexico

U.S. President Barack Obama expressed optimism about the progress of immigration reform efforts in interviews with Telemundo and Univision, stating that he expects a bill to be introduced on the Senate floor next month. The president emphasized that a debate over guest workers will not derail reform efforts, as a group of lawmakers are close to working out the details of their proposal.

According to Obama, the senators are confident that they will be ready to unveil the highly anticipated immigration bill early in the week of April 8, when Congress returns to work. The president expressed his confidence that the bill can be passed before the end of the summer.

The president also discussed his upcoming trip to Mexico, where he will visit in early May. He highlighted the importance of strengthening the relationship between the United States and Mexico, going beyond the focus on borders and drug cartels to explore commerce, trade, and energy cooperation.

In his interviews, Obama reiterated his commitment to immigration reform, stating that he is prepared to step in with his own legislation if necessary, but believes that a strong compromise is within reach.

Title: Rep. Eric Swalwell Continues to Defend Debunked Russian Collusion Claim

Article:

Representative Eric Swalwell (D-CA) has continued to defend the claim that President Trump colluded with Russia during the 2016 election, despite the conclusion of Special Counsel Robert Mueller's investigation and the lack of evidence to support this claim. In a recent interview with Fox News host Martha MacCallum, Swalwell stated that he still believes the Trump campaign had ties to Russia and that the Steele dossier, which was largely unverified, is a legitimate piece of evidence.

Swalwell's stance has been met with criticism from both sides of the aisle. Representative Devin Nunes (R-CA), who was chair of the House Intelligence Committee, called Swalwell's claims "abjectly insane" and stated that he should have filled the entire show with his antics. Other Republicans have also weighed in, with Sean Davis calling Swalwell a "Chupacabra hunter" for his continued pursuit of a debunked narrative.

Swalwell's refusal to back down from his claims has also led to a response from the Trump campaign, which has asked TV producers to challenge Swalwell's assertions. In an interview with MSNBC, Swalwell stated that he is willing to be sued by the President and believes he would win in court.

It's worth noting that the Mueller report's summary concluded that there was no collusion between the Trump campaign and Russia, and over 2,500 subpoenas were issued and 500 witnesses were interviewed during the investigation. Despite this, Swalwell remains convinced that the Trump campaign had ties to Russia and continues to defend the debunked dossier.

The controversy surrounding Swalwell's claims has also led to criticism from some in the media, with some calling his antics "insane" and "frankly having a total meltdown."

Title: Trump's Campaign Promise of a Border Wall Fizzles Out

The article discusses the decline of President Donald Trump's promise to build a wall along the US-Mexico border, which was a key campaign promise. The author, who spoke with Ann Coulter, an early supporter of Trump's candidacy, notes that Coulter is no longer confident in the President's commitment to fulfilling this promise. The article highlights the White House's willingness to compromise on the issue, with Press Secretary Sarah Huckabee Sanders indicating that the administration is open to finding alternative funding sources for the wall. Coulter, however, is not convinced, stating that without a wall, she would not vote for Trump's reelection in 2020. The article concludes that the Trump administration's failure to make the wall a priority and its willingness to compromise on the issue may ultimately mean that the promise will not be fulfilled.

Title: Migrant Caravan Stopped at US-Mexico Border, Awaits Processing

A group of around 150 migrants, mostly from Central America, has been stopped at the US-Mexico border near San Diego, with many traveling with children. The migrants, who claim to be fleeing persecution and violence in their home countries, are seeking asylum in the United States. According to US border officials, the San Ysidro port of entry is currently at capacity, and those who are not processed will need to wait in Mexico.

The migrants, who began their journey on March 25, traveled over 2,000 miles by bus, train, and on foot. They are being held outside the US Customs and Border Patrol (CBP) processing center, with some being allowed to cross a long bridge to the US side but being stopped outside the buildings. CBP Commissioner Kevin McAleenan stated that the agency has reached capacity at the San Ysidro port of entry, and those individuals may need to wait in Mexico as CBP officers work to process those already within their facilities.

A lawyer for the group, Nicole Ramos, expressed frustration that inspectors at the border were not prepared to process the migrants. "We can build a base in Iraq in under a week. We can't process 200 refugees. I don't believe it," she told the Associated Press.

Despite the setback, the migrants have decided to camp out overnight near the processing center. "We've been waiting so long that it doesn't really matter whether it's today, tomorrow, or when they let us in," said Irineo Mujica, director of Pueblo Sin Fronteras, the campaign group that organized the caravan.

Under US immigration law, inspectors have the power to quickly deport individuals who do not have the proper travel or visa documents or if they believe the person requesting entry has committed fraud or misrepresented the truth. However, if an individual expresses a fear of return to their home country, they will not be immediately deported but instead be detained until they undergo a "credible fear interview."

Title: Trump's Campaign Advisers Express Frustration Over Debate Performance

The first presidential debate between Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton has sparked internal concerns within Trump's campaign team. According to sources, some of Trump's advisers believe his debate prep was a "disaster," with too many people in the room providing conflicting advice. This led to Trump being overprepared, leaving him without a clear plan to deliver his message or respond to Clinton's jabs.

The debate itself saw Trump's supporters remaining loyal, with Trump not committing a major gaffe. However, his campaign team is concerned that his focus and objectives dissolved during the debate, and they plan to more rigorously prepare him for the next face-off.

Some campaign aides and advisers expressed frustration and discouragement over Trump's performance, citing his failure to attack Clinton on trade and character issues. This internal carping has led to some of Trump's own advisers anonymously criticizing his performance, stating he was "erratic" during the debate.

In contrast, Clinton is widely credited with delivering a strong performance, keeping Trump on the defensive and likely receiving a polling bump. The debate's outcome has sparked concerns within Trump's campaign, with some questioning whether he is open to practicing meticulously for the next debate.

It is worth noting that Trump's supporters are angry at the media coverage portraying him as having lost the debate, and some have pointed out that the press has been repeatedly wrong about Trump. However, the anonymous criticism from his own advisers does not help his cause.

Title: California Golf Course Finds Innovative Ways to Conserve Water Amidst Drought

In the midst of California's severe drought, golf courses are often under scrutiny for their water usage. However, The Resort At Pelican Hill in Newport Coast, California, is taking a unique approach to conserve water while still maintaining its lush greens. The golf course employs a combination of reclaimed water, native bushes, and a sophisticated irrigation system to minimize its water footprint.

The course uses reclaimed water, which is treated wastewater that has been purified to meet drinking water standards, for its irrigation needs. This approach has allowed the course to save 50 million gallons of water annually. Additionally, the course captures and stores rainwater, which is used to supplement its water supply. The rainwater is collected from buildings, pavement, and cart paths and stored in underground cisterns and lake systems.

The course's irrigation system is designed to be highly efficient, allowing course managers to monitor and control watering from their smartphones. This precision irrigation system enables the course to water specific areas as needed, reducing waste and overwatering.

The Resort At Pelican Hill's conservation efforts are not limited to its golf course. The resort's design incorporates native bushes and drought-resistant plants in non-playing areas, further reducing its water consumption.

While some may argue that golf courses are a luxury that can't be justified during a drought, the golf industry employs nearly 130,000 people in California, making it a significant contributor to the state's economy. The Resort At Pelican Hill's innovative approach to water conservation demonstrates that it is possible to balance the needs of the golf industry with environmental responsibility.

The course's vice president, Stephen Friedlander, emphasizes that golf courses should prioritize water quality and management, stating, "If you're in the golf industry and you're not a water quality and a management person, then what are you doing?" This approach is not limited to California, as golf courses around the world are facing similar water conservation challenges.

Title: Supreme Court Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg's Health Concerns Spark Widespread Support and Speculation

Article: Supreme Court Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg, a champion of women's rights and a Brooklyn native, has been the subject of widespread attention and concern after news of her health issues spread on social media. The 86-year-old justice has been a stalwart advocate for women's rights throughout her career, earning her the nickname "Notorious R.B.G." and inspiring a documentary and a forthcoming movie about her life.

In recent years, Ginsburg has gained a significant social media following, with many users expressing their admiration and support for her. In response to her health concerns, some Twitter users even offered to donate their ribs to her, while others called for protective bubble wrap to be sent her way.

Ginsburg was appointed to the Supreme Court by President Bill Clinton in 1993 and has been a key figure in many landmark cases. She has stated that she would not base her retirement plans on who is currently in the Oval Office, saying she would stay on the job as long as she can do it full steam.

In contrast, Justice Anthony M. Kennedy, who retired earlier this year, had announced his retirement, which was seen as a significant blow to the liberal side of the court. His replacement, Justice Brett Kavanaugh, was confirmed in the closest Senate vote since the 19th century.

A hospital spokeswoman directed questions about Ginsburg's condition to the Supreme Court's press office, leaving the public awaiting further updates on her health.

Title: Republican Leaders Fail to Revoke Endorsements Despite Trump's Sexual Assault Boast

Article:

The Republican National Committee Chair, Reince Priebus, House Speaker Paul Ryan, and Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell have expressed outrage over Donald Trump's leaked audio, in which he boasts about sexually assaulting attractive women. While they condemned Trump's comments, they did not withdraw their endorsements. This decision is not surprising, given Trump's long history of making misogynistic and bigoted comments.

Trump's past remarks include characterizing Mexican immigrants as "rapists," calling Senator John McCain a "war hero" because he was captured, and suggesting that Senator Elizabeth Warren is not Native American. He has also proposed banning an entire religious group from entering the US, encouraged physical attacks on protesters, and gotten into public feuds with the parents of a fallen military veteran and a Fox News anchor.

Despite these past incidents, Republican leaders have consistently stood by Trump, and it appears that his latest comments about sexual assault will not change their stance. This decision raises questions about the party's tolerance for Trump's behavior and whether they are willing to accept him as the face of the party and potentially the next President of the United States.

**Coronavirus Resurgence Wipes Out Two Months of Progress in the US**

The United States has seen a significant surge in COVID-19 cases, with the country recording a one-day total of 34,700 new confirmed cases, the highest level since late April. This marks a reversal of the progress made in recent months, with hospital administrators and health experts warning that politicians and the public are letting the situation unfold.

Several states have set single-day records, including Arizona, California, Mississippi, Nevada, Texas, and Oklahoma. Some of these states have also broken hospitalization records, with North Carolina and South Carolina experiencing a surge in intensive care unit admissions.

The virus has been blamed for over 120,000 US deaths and more than 2.3 million confirmed infections nationwide. The University of Washington's computer model projects nearly 180,000 deaths by October 1.

The resurgence of the virus has sent shockwaves through the economy, with stocks sliding on Wall Street as the news dampened hopes for a quick economic turnaround. The Dow Jones Industrial Average lost over 700 points, and the S&P 500 fell 2.6%.

Hospital administrators and health experts are urging the public to take precautions to slow the spread of the virus. Dr. Marc Boom, CEO of the Houston Methodist hospital system, said, "People got complacent, and it's coming back and biting us, quite frankly."

The situation is particularly dire in Texas, where hospitalizations have doubled and new cases have tripled in two weeks. Governor Greg Abbott has warned of a "massive outbreak" and may need to impose new local restrictions to preserve hospital space.

In other parts of the country, states are taking measures to slow the spread of the virus. California has reported over 7,100 new cases, and Governor Gavin Newsom has threatened to withhold pandemic-related funding from local governments that do not comply with state mask and anti-virus measures. Florida has seen a 25% jump in new cases, with hospitalizations surging to 5,500.

The resurgence of the virus has also led to increased hospitalizations in other parts of the country, with Alabama's intensive care units nearly full and two public hospitals running at capacity. In Arizona, emergency rooms are seeing about 1,200 suspected COVID-19 patients a day, compared to around 500 a month ago.

Experts warn that the situation is dire and that the country is running out of time to head off a much larger crisis. Dr. Peter Hotez, an infectious-disease expert at the Baylor College of Medicine in Texas, said, "We're still talking about subtlety, still arguing whether or not we should wear masks, and still not understanding that a vaccine is not going to rescue us."

Title: Trump Denies Collusion Amidst Turmoil, But His Behavior Raises Questions

Article:

In a recent rally, President Donald Trump denied collusion with Russia, a claim that has been at the center of the ongoing investigation led by Special Counsel Robert Mueller. This denial comes amidst a tumultuous week for the President, with his former personal attorney, Michael Cohen, pleading guilty to multiple charges, including tax evasion and campaign finance violations. Additionally, Trump's former campaign manager, Paul Manafort, was found guilty on eight felony charges.

Trump's denial of collusion is not surprising, as it would be challenging to prove that he knew about a specific meeting between Trump surrogates and Russian representatives before the 2016 election. However, Trump's behavior since the investigations began has raised questions about his fitness for office. He has been accused of lying about various matters, including his involvement in his former lawyer's payments to women and his knowledge of campaign finance violations.

Trump's denial of collusion is also notable given his history of making false statements. He has been known to deny or downplay various allegations, including his involvement in the Trump Tower meeting and his knowledge of payments to adult film star Stormy Daniels. His behavior has been criticized by many, including some Republicans, who have expressed concern about the President's honesty and integrity.

The article concludes that while Trump may be telling the truth about not colluding with Russia, his behavior raises questions about his fitness for office. The author notes that Trump's example is not one to be emulated, and that the real scandal is not collusion, but rather Trump himself.

Title: Trump Administration Seeks $850 Billion Emergency Stimulus Package to Mitigate Economic Impact of Coronavirus

The Trump administration is seeking approval from Congress for a roughly $850 billion emergency stimulus package to alleviate the economic impact of the coronavirus. According to a senior administration official, the proposal is a tax proposal, not a spending stimulus, as Senate Minority Leader Charles Schumer has proposed. The package is expected to include a payroll tax cut and approximately $50 billion in aid for the airline industry.

President Trump and Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin discussed the proposal with reporters on Tuesday, stating that the administration wants to send checks to Americans as part of the package. Mnuchin emphasized that the goal is to get cash payments to Americans within the next two weeks, although the exact amount of the one-time payments remains unclear.

The administration is also considering a payroll tax cut as a means of helping those affected by the virus. Trump has expressed support for the airline industry, stating that his administration would "back the airlines 100 percent" and is considering the industry's request for $50 billion in assistance.

Mnuchin is expected to outline the package to Senate Republicans on Tuesday, which is expected to include payments to small businesses and loan guarantees for specific industries, such as airlines and hotels. Schumer is set to unveil a proposal for $750 billion in spending to address the economic fallout of the virus.

This potential stimulus package would be the third such action taken by Congress to address the impact of the virus, which has sickened over 4,000 people in the United States, rattled the stock market, and prompted school, business, and other closures across the country.

Title: Senator Portman's Decision to Block Supreme Court Nomination Raises Concerns Among Educators

Article:

Maria Mueller, an educator in the Mason City Schools District, has expressed concerns about Senator Rob Portman's decision to block a vote on Supreme Court nominee Merrick Garland. As an advocate for civic education, Mueller believes that the confirmation process is a valuable teachable moment for students to understand the checks and balances established by the Founding Fathers.

In an op-ed published in The Enquirer, Senator Portman argued that the confirmation process should wait until after the presidential election, citing the need for a less partisan atmosphere. However, Mueller argues that this decision only perpetuates the hyper-partisan atmosphere and undermines the trust students have in the government.

Mueller is concerned that Senator Portman's actions will have a lasting impact on students' perceptions of politics and the Constitution. She believes that politicians' rhetoric and actions can shape students' views on politics and government, and that Senator Portman's decision will only reinforce the notion that politics is divisive and unproductive.

As an educator, Mueller is worried that students will learn that politicians prioritize their own interests over the needs of the people and are unwilling to engage with those who have different views. She implores Senator Portman to fulfill his duty as a public servant and to be an example for students, rather than perpetuating a culture of obstruction and partisanship.

The article highlights the importance of civic education and the need for students to understand the Constitution and the democratic process. It also underscores the significance of politicians' actions and rhetoric in shaping students' perceptions of politics and government.

**Midterm Elections: Republicans Gain Momentum, Democrats Face Challenges**

The midterm elections are just around the corner, and the latest analysis suggests that Republicans are gaining momentum, particularly in the Senate. According to Charlie Cook, the founder of the Cook Political Report, the GOP is now more likely to gain a seat or two, moving their majority to 52 or 53 seats.

In the House, Democrats remain favored to capture a majority, but their chances of achieving a significant gain of 40-50 seats or more have diminished. The suburban-oriented districts, where most competitive House races are held, remain challenging for Republicans. However, the more rural and small-town districts, which are heavily Republican, are now more engaged and moving some districts back away from the edge of competitiveness.

The most endangered incumbent on the Democratic side is Senator Heidi Heitkamp of North Dakota, who is trailing in the polls and has faced criticism for publicly identifying women as survivors of assault without their consent. Her campaign has apologized for the mistake, which has damaged her reputation.

In other news, Senator Bob Menendez of New Jersey is facing scrutiny over a scandal, and the Democratic super PAC, Senate Majority PAC, has launched a $3 million ad buy in the state. Meanwhile, Senator Kyrsten Sinema of Arizona is facing criticism for her attacks on her own state, and her opponent, Martha McSally, is gaining momentum.

A statistical review shows that McSally is on the rise, but the media is working to run interference for Sinema, including mischaracterizing an accurate line of criticism from McSally.

Title: Jeb Bush Forms Exploratory Committee for 2016 Presidential Run

Jeb Bush, the former governor of Florida, has announced the formation of an exploratory committee to consider a run for the 2016 presidential election. This move is seen as a significant development in the Republican primary, with Bush currently polling near the top of the prospective nominees.

According to recent polls, Bush is tied with Mitt Romney at 19% and ahead of other potential Republican candidates, including Chris Christie, Mike Huckabee, Paul Ryan, and Ted Cruz. While Bush's name recognition and family legacy may give him an initial advantage, his candidacy is not without its challenges.

One of the primary concerns is his support for Common Core education standards, which may not sit well with some Republican voters. Additionally, his backing of comprehensive immigration reform and his past support for tax increases as part of a broader budget reform package may alienate some on the right wing of the party.

Despite these potential drawbacks, Bush's candidacy is likely to be well-funded, thanks to his connections with donors, bundlers, and independent expenditure committees. This could give him an edge over his Republican opponents.

If Bush does decide to run, he will face a tough primary battle, but he may also be well-positioned to take on Hillary Clinton, the likely Democratic nominee, in the general election. Both Bush and Clinton are seen as pragmatic politicians who are serious about the issues and willing to work across the aisle.

The potential for a Bush-Clinton matchup would bring a level of civility and substance to the campaign, with both candidates having a strong understanding of the issues and a willingness to engage in thoughtful debates.

Title: White House Dismisses Anecdotal Evidence of Obamacare's Impact on Job Growth

The White House has dismissed claims that the Affordable Care Act (ACA), also known as Obamacare, is having an adverse impact on job growth and the number of hours employees are working. According to Jason Furman, chairman of the president's Council of Economic Advisors, there is no systematic evidence to support these claims. Since the ACA became law, nearly 90% of the gain in employment has been in full-time positions.

However, some employers are citing the ACA as a reason for not hiring full-time staff. Executives at staffing and payroll firms say that part-time workers offer them flexibility, allowing them to quickly adjust to changes in the market. They also claim that the ACA's requirement for employers with 50 or more full-time workers to provide healthcare coverage or incur penalties is a factor in their hiring decisions.

United Parcel Service (UPS) has announced plans to remove thousands of spouses from its medical plan, citing the ACA as a reason. However, analysts have downplayed the impact of the ACA on companies like UPS, noting that the move reflects a long-term trend of shrinking corporate medical benefits.

A quirk in the ACA could also lead to some workers and their families being financially penalized if they are offered health insurance subsidies through their employer. This could result in some individuals being unable to afford insurance through either the private sector or the government, leaving them uninsured and subject to the Obamacare tax.

The White House has dismissed these claims as anecdotal, but some experts argue that the ACA's impact on job growth and employment hours is still unclear. The debate continues, with some employers citing the ACA as a reason for not hiring full-time staff, while others argue that the law has had a positive impact on the job market.

Title: US Army Begins Trial of Maj. Nidal Hasan for Deadly Fort Hood Attack

The US Army has started the trial of Maj. Nidal Hasan, accused of opening fire at a training center at Fort Hood on November 5, 2009, killing 13 and injuring scores of others. In his opening statement, Hasan acknowledged his role in the attack, stating that "the evidence will clearly show that I am the shooter." Hasan is accused of shooting at a training center, killing 13 and injuring scores of others, and was shot by a responding police officer, leaving him partly paralyzed.

The trial, which could last months, is significant not only for the military justice system but also for the victims and their families, as well as the still-unresolved question of whether the attack was an act of terrorism. The US armed services have not carried out an execution since 1961, and military-justice experts say that the presiding judge, Col. Tara Osborn, has taken steps to ensure that the verdict and sentence in this trial can withstand any appeals.

The trial has been delayed for years, with Hasan pleading with the court to let him acknowledge his guilt, but Col. Osborn denied the request, given the prosecution's pursuit of the death penalty. Hasan is allowed to defend himself, giving him wide legal leeway. Military-justice experts say that the prosecution is determined to secure a conviction and is willing to take the time and resources necessary to do so.

The victims of the attack are expected to take the stand to describe what they saw, and then be cross-examined by Hasan. Some victims have expressed a desire to help convict the man they see as a traitor. Injured Staff Sgt. Alonzo Lunsford said, "I'm not going to dread anything. That's a sign of fear. That man strikes no fear in my heart."

The trial has shed light on the motives behind the attack, with Hasan stating that he was on the "wrong side of America's war" and later switched sides. The Obama administration has defined the attack as an act of workplace violence, while President Obama said that Hasan's act may have been "inspired by larger notions of jihad." The government has said that Hasan sent over a dozen emails to Anwar al-Awlaki, a radical cleric killed in a drone strike in 2011.

The trial has also raised questions about the classification of the attack, with some experts saying that it would be impossible to prove that the targeted soldiers posed a direct risk to Taliban leaders. The issue is significant, as victims are ineligible for some Army benefits because their injuries are not classified as "combat-related." Meanwhile, Hasan is still collecting a pension. If classified as a terrorist attack, the Fort Hood shootings would be the deadliest on US soil since 9/11.

Title: President's Latest Immigration Plan Raises Questions and Concerns

The President has announced a new plan aimed at swaying Latino voters in key states like New Mexico and Colorado, offering work permits to young people under 30 who meet certain criteria. However, critics argue that this move is little more than a token gesture, as only a small percentage of those eligible are actually being pursued and deported.

The plan has been met with skepticism, as unemployment rates among young people remain historically high. Some argue that the move creates more competition in an already struggling labor market, rather than addressing the root issues of immigration reform. The President has been criticized for failing to demonstrate leadership on this issue, despite having had two years of a Democrat majority in Congress.

The plan was reportedly prompted by pleas from Democrat senators, and some see it as a political ploy to win over Latino voters. However, others argue that it hinders the possibility of meaningful, long-term reform, as it creates a false sense of security and distracts from the real issues.

The President's plan has been met with criticism from both sides of the aisle, with some accusing him of using Latino voters as pawns in his re-election bid. The contrast between the President's approach and that of his predecessor, President Reagan, is striking. While Reagan believed that success was not about who gets the credit, the President seems more concerned with claiming credit for any achievements, regardless of their substance.

It remains to be seen whether this latest move will have any significant impact on the Latino community or the broader immigration debate.

Title: Republican Lawmakers Barge into Closed-Door Impeachment Hearing, Delaying Testimony

A group of nearly two dozen Republican lawmakers, led by Rep. Matt Gaetz of Florida, stormed into a closed-door deposition on Thursday, demanding to be allowed to see the proceedings. The move delayed the testimony of Deputy Assistant Defense Secretary Laura Cooper, who was being questioned as part of the impeachment inquiry into President Donald Trump. The lawmakers, who were not authorized to be in the secure room, were eventually escorted out.

The incident marked a new and more confrontational phase in the GOP's attack on House Intelligence Chairman Adam Schiff and the Democratic impeachment investigation. The lawmakers' actions were met with confusion and criticism from some, including Republican Sen. Lindsey Graham of South Carolina, who tweeted that the protest was initially described as a "storming" but was actually a "peaceful protest."

The lawmakers, who had advance knowledge of the plans to attempt entry to the secure room, entered the facility, known as a Sensitive Compartmented Information Facility (SCIF), where cellphones are not allowed. They brought pizza, which is allowed, and left at 2 p.m. for votes.

The most effective Republican gripe about the impeachment process has been about the lack of transparency and due process. However, Republicans who sit on the committees conducting the investigation are present during testimony, and Trump does not have attorneys representing him.

The Constitution does not specify how the impeachment process should play out, and the courts have generally stayed out of it. Democrats have promised that there will be open hearings during the process.

The article also touches on the term "quid pro quo" and how Trump has hijacked the impeachment debate with his claim of "no quid pro quo" regarding Ukraine. The article notes that Trump had been using the term long before the whistleblower complaint was public and before any published reports about his phone call with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky.

The article also mentions the whistleblower's identity and the pressure felt by Ukrainians early on, as well as the Justice Department's policy of not charging sitting presidents with crimes and a recent court decision regarding the release of Ukraine-related records from the State Department.

Title: Trump Threatens to Deploy Military to Restore Order in American Cities

Article:

President Donald Trump has threatened to deploy the U.S. military to restore order in American cities if mayors and governors fail to do so, amid ongoing protests over the death of George Floyd. In a brief speech from the Rose Garden, Trump emphasized the need to act vigorously to stop the chaos and protect the country's most vulnerable communities.

The President has the authority to send in the military under the Insurrection Act, which allows the President to deploy troops to suppress domestic violence and insurrection. The Act does not prohibit the use of federal troops for domestic law enforcement, but rather requires statutory authorization. If the President determines that "unlawful obstructions, combinations, or assemblages" are making it impossible to enforce the laws in a state, he can take action.

While some may view Trump's threat as an attempt to impose a dictatorship or wage war on the American people, it is important to note that this is not a new phenomenon. Previous presidents, including George H.W. Bush, Lyndon Johnson, and Dwight Eisenhower, have invoked the Insurrection Act to restore order in times of crisis.

However, it is unclear how Trump could invoke the Insurrection Act over the objections of state and local officials. Having hostile and competing authorities trying to police the same streets is not a formula for success. The main utility of discussing the Insurrection Act may be in prodding states to be more forceful in their response.

Minnesota has called out the National Guard, and Minneapolis has been relatively calm for three straight nights. New York, on the other hand, has avoided calling the Guard, and New York City was a scene of rioting and looting on Monday night. Cities need to impose early curfews, vigorously enforce them, and call out the National Guard if they have any doubt that the police can't do the job on their own.

While Trump's language about "dominating" the streets is inflammatory, the basic point is correct. However, the President has failed to rise to the moment with his incendiary tweets and insulting commentary on the performance of local officials. His performance was also marred by a photo-op in front of St. John's church, which some critics have deemed a petty and foolish use of government authority.

As the nation grapples with the ongoing crisis, it is crucial that leaders, including the President, act with wisdom and restraint.

Title: UK Forms Task Force to Examine Extremist Groups, Two Arrested on Suspicion of Arson

The United Kingdom has announced the formation of a task force to examine the dynamics behind extremist groups in the country, led by Prime Minister David Cameron. The group will have a general focus on extremist groups, but acknowledge that the greatest threat is from Islamist extremists. The Muslim Council of Britain has called for the task force to examine extremism from all quarters, warning against giving in to the demands of all extremists and making society less free, divided, and suspicious of each other.

The announcement comes in the wake of an alleged terrorist attack on a British soldier, Lee Rigby, who was killed near the Royal Artillery Barracks in southeast London. The attack has sparked widespread shock and outrage across the UK, with a far-right street demonstration held in northern England calling for Muslims to leave the country.

In a separate incident, a mosque caught fire in the city of Grimsby on the country's east coast, and two men were arrested on suspicion of arson. The blaze coincided with inciting messages on social media by a small minority of individuals, according to Humberside County police.

Nine people have been arrested in connection with the Woolwich attack, including three men who were taken into custody and released on bail. The men were being held on suspicion of conspiracy to commit murder, but police have not released their identities or details on how they were allegedly tied to the killing.

The UK's MI5 intelligence agency will report the results of a preliminary investigation into the suspects this week to the Intelligence and Security Committee, government sources said. The report is expected to be confidential.

The incident has also sparked a debate on social media, with some calling for greater vigilance against extremist groups and others warning against Islamophobia and hate speech.

Title: Global Temperatures Expected to Continue Rising, Reach Critical Milestone in 2030s

Global temperatures are projected to continue their upward trend over the next decade, with a critical milestone expected to be reached in the 2030s, according to two leading climate scientists from the United States government. The scientists, Deke Arndt and Gavin Schmidt, predict that the planet will reach a level of 1.5 degrees Celsius above pre-industrial levels by 2035, surpassing the critical threshold set by the Paris climate accord.

The Paris agreement aims to limit global warming to 1.5 degrees Celsius or less to avoid the worst climate catastrophes, such as sea-level rise and more destructive wildfires, floods, and storms. The United Nations Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) estimates that the window to limit warming to 1.5 degrees Celsius will close around 2030.

The scientists' findings are based on a review of temperature records from NASA, NOAA, the Berkeley Earth research group, the Met Office Hadley Centre (UK), and the Cowtan and Way analysis. All five records show rapid warming in the past few decades, with the past decade being the warmest.

Schmidt emphasized that the future of global temperatures depends on what is done with greenhouse gas emissions. "We aren't able to tell you by looking at the past how society will react to the information," he said.

The report by NASA and NOAA reached a similar conclusion to other climate agencies, such as the European Union's Copernicus Climate Change Service, which stated that 2019 was the second-hottest year since record-keeping began in 1880.

Arndt and Schmidt highlighted the consistency of five recent studies on global temperature trends, which support their findings. "These are five independent analyses that make different assumptions. It doesn't really matter which way you cut it, it always looks the same," Schmidt said. "The fact is the planet is warming. The main thing here is not really the ranking [of 2019] but the consistency of the methodology and the long-term trends that we're seeing."

Warming patterns are particularly pronounced in the Arctic, which is heating up three times faster than the rest of the planet, Arndt noted. At the same time, the amount of sea ice in the Arctic is falling, contributing to global warming.

The researchers attributed the recent trends to human-induced climate change caused by rising greenhouse gas emissions. "Climate change in the past had nothing to do with human activity," Schmidt said, referring to warming that occurred thousands and hundreds of thousands of years ago due to Earth's orbit or massive asteroids or volcanic eruptions. "That explanation fails in the 20th century because we know there hasn't been an asteroid and hasn't been a massive volcano."

Title: Chicago Teachers' Union Votes to Strike, Citing Disagreements Over Pay, Benefits, and Class Size

The Chicago Teachers' Union (CTU) has voted to go on strike, with over 25,000 members refusing to return to their classrooms on Thursday. The decision comes after months of negotiations between the union and Chicago Public Schools (CPS) failed to resolve disputes over pay, benefits, class size, and teacher preparation time. The strike is expected to affect over 300,000 students in the nation's third-largest school district.

The CTU is seeking improvements on issues such as class size, staffing, and teacher preparation time, while CPS has offered a 16% pay raise over five years and agreed to put language in the contract addressing "enforceable targets" on class size and increasing staffing levels. However, the union claims the city's proposals do not go far enough to address the issues.

Mayor Lori Lightfoot expressed disappointment over the union's decision to strike, stating that the city had offered a "historic package" on the core issues and that school district negotiators would remain at the bargaining table. The city has canceled classes for Thursday, and parents are scrambling to prepare for the strike.

The strike will also affect 7,000 support staff, whose union has also failed to reach a contract agreement. Community organizations and local businesses are preparing to provide alternative care for students, including camps, libraries, and after-school programs.

The strike is expected to have a significant impact on the city, particularly for low-income and minority families who rely on the schools for childcare and educational services. The city's public libraries, churches, and community centers are also planning programs to provide a safe haven for students during the strike.

The strike is the first major walkout by teachers in Chicago since 2012, and both sides are urging parents to prepare for the strike. The city's CEO, Janice Jackson, encouraged parents to send their children to their usual schools, but noted that they will be welcome in any district schools.

Title: The Affordable Care Act: A Law Born from a Democratic Supermajority

The Affordable Care Act (ACA), also known as Obamacare, was passed in 2009-2010 during a period of Democratic supermajority. The law's passage was a result of a lengthy process that began in April 2009 and concluded with President Obama signing the bill in March 2010. The Supreme Court has recently agreed to take up the case of King v. Burwell, which focuses on the meaning of a certain phrase in the ACA and whether the federal government can subsidize federal health exchanges.

The passage of the ACA was not rushed, but rather a result of a deliberate process that was hindered by Republican obstruction. The law's drafting and passage were marked by a lack of Republican input, as the party strongly opposed the individual mandate, community rating, and guaranteed issue provisions. The Obama Administration's health reform centered on these provisions, which Republicans believed would make the American health care system worse.

The Democratic supermajority allowed the party to pass the law without Republican input, but this also meant that "ordinary fixes" and maintenance were not implemented. The law's passage was not without controversy, with some Democrats breaking their pledge to post the final legislative language 72 hours in advance of the final vote. The legislative language of the bill is at the center of the Halbig v. Burwell case.

The election of Scott Brown in a special election in Massachusetts in 2010 marked the end of the Democratic supermajority, leading to the use of reconciliation and the avoidance of "ordinary fixes" to improve the law. Republicans had no obligation to help Democrats fix the drafting errors in the legislation, as they strongly opposed the underlying provisions. The ACA's passage was a product of a Democratic supermajority, and its current challenges are a result of the party's decision to pass the law without Republican input.

Title: Sri Lanka's Gotabaya Rajapaksa Names Brother Mahinda as Prime Minister

Sri Lanka's newly-elected President Gotabaya Rajapaksa has appointed his brother, Mahinda, as the country's new prime minister. Mahinda, a two-term former president, is set to be sworn in on Thursday, following the resignation of Ranil Wickremesinghe after his party's defeat in the recent presidential polls.

The Rajapaksa brothers are credited with ending Sri Lanka's 26-year-long civil war, but their tenure has been marred by allegations of war crimes and human rights abuses. Mahinda, 74, will be sworn in by his younger brother Gotabaya, 70. Two other brothers, Basil and Chamal, are also active in politics.

According to a spokesman, Gotabaya will have his cabinet appointed shortly after taking his oath of office. The new administration will face challenges in addressing the country's security concerns and allegations of human rights abuses.

The appointment of Mahinda as prime minister marks a significant development in Sri Lanka's political landscape, with the country set to have two brothers at the helm for the first time. During Mahinda's previous presidency, Chamal was the speaker of the Sri Lankan parliament.

Ranil Wickremesinghe, the outgoing prime minister, formally announced his resignation on Wednesday, clearing the way for the Rajapaksas to form a minority government ahead of snap elections expected around April next year. Wickremesinghe's party put forward Sajith Premadasa as their presidential candidate, but was defeated by Gotabaya in a highly divisive election.

The Rajapaksa brothers' previous terms in power have been marked by allegations of human rights abuses and war crimes, with the United Nations alleging that more than 40,000 people were killed by security forces in the final days of the country's civil war. The new president also faces a civil suit in the United States for allegedly ordering the torture of a Tamil man and several others when he was the defence secretary.

The appointment of Mahinda as prime minister has sparked concerns about the Rajapaksa family's continued grip on power and the potential for further human rights abuses. The new administration will face significant challenges in addressing the country's security concerns and allegations of human rights abuses.

Title: Al Qaeda's Core Leadership Severely Weakened, but Regional Affiliates Remain Active

The core leadership of al Qaeda, based in Pakistan, has been severely weakened, according to statements from the Obama administration. However, the terrorist organization's affiliates in Yemen, North Africa, and other regions remain active and pose a significant threat to Western interests and national security.

The Obama administration has taken steps to target al Qaeda's core leadership, including the successful mission that resulted in the death of Osama bin Laden in 2011. The administration has also increased the use of armed unmanned aircraft in Pakistan, resulting in the killing of nearly 300 al Qaeda operatives and other extremists.

While al Qaeda's core leadership has been significantly weakened, its affiliates in Yemen, North Africa, and other regions continue to pose a threat. Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula (AQAP), which operates in Yemen, is of particular concern, as it has been responsible for several high-profile attacks and plots, including the failed attempt to blow up a Northwest Airlines flight on Christmas Day in 2009.

The Arab Spring has resulted in significant changes in the region, but the continued instability and fledgling governments have created an opportunity for terrorists to take advantage of the situation. Al Qaeda is seeking to establish safe havens and recruit extremists in areas where security is diminished.

The threat posed by al Qaeda's affiliates is not limited to Yemen and North Africa. Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb (AQIM) operates in northern Africa, and has been linked to the kidnapping of Westerners and the support of Nigerian-based Boko Haram. Al Qaeda in Iraq (AQI) has also extended its reach into Syria, where it is taking advantage of the ongoing conflict.

While al Qaeda's core leadership has been weakened, its affiliates remain active and pose a significant threat to Western interests and national security. The Obama administration and its predecessor have taken steps to target al Qaeda's core leadership, but the organization's affiliates continue to pose a significant threat.

Title: Obama's Body Language Reflects Stiffened Resolve in Fiscal Cliff Negotiations

President Barack Obama's stance during the ongoing fiscal cliff negotiations has been characterized by a more combative approach, a departure from his previous negotiating style. According to sources, this newfound toughness is rooted in the lessons he learned from his convincing victory in the 2012 presidential election.

After his re-election, Obama's confidence and resolve have deepened, leading him to demand respect from Republicans, who he believes owe him a debt of gratitude for his victory. This shift in attitude is a departure from his previous emphasis on bipartisanship, as he now seeks to squeeze concessions from Republicans.

Obama's top aides and friends have noted that his 2012 win has given him a greater sense of confidence and a deeper resolve not to be rolled by a recalcitrant GOP. His legacy, which was uncertain after his 2008 win, is now seen as secure, and he is determined to make the most of it.

The president's advisors believe that his re-election has made him a resilient and popular figure who can unify the country, but only if Republicans are willing to work with him. However, the White House has been thrust back into a partisan battle, making it unclear whether Obama's tough stance will hold.

So far, Obama has refused to provide specific details on spending and entitlement cuts, and has threatened GOP leaders with the bully pulpit of his inauguration and State of the Union speech. While some Hill Democrats are cautiously optimistic, others are wary of the administration's overtures to the GOP on entitlement reform.

Title: Susan Rice's Changing Story Raises Questions About Allegations of Unmasking

The controversy surrounding former National Security Adviser Susan Rice's alleged involvement in unmasking Donald Trump or his associates on foreign intercepts has taken a new turn. Rice initially claimed she knew nothing about the matter, but after reports emerged suggesting she was involved, she broke her silence, stating that it was a common practice to request the identities of Americans picked up on intercepts and that it was necessary for her job.

Rice's change in story has raised a host of questions about the allegations. While it is possible that what she did was legal, the fact that she initially denied any knowledge of the matter has sparked concerns about her motivations. Did she seek the identities of Trump associates solely for intelligence reasons or did she have political motivations? Did she leak any of the findings or cause them to be leaked?

The media has been divided on the issue, with some outlets like the Washington Post and New York Times downplaying the allegations, while others like Fox News and Bloomberg have reported on the story. Some critics on the right have accused the media of covering for Rice, while others have argued that the story is being blown out of proportion.

The situation is complicated, and it is unclear what exactly happened. The lack of concrete evidence and the reliance on anonymous sources have made it difficult to determine the truth. While some outlets have chosen not to cover the story, others have reported on it, often using unnamed sources.

The controversy highlights the importance of transparency and accountability in the media. It is crucial that journalists strive to provide accurate and unbiased reporting, even in the face of uncertainty. The public deserves to know the truth, and it is up to the media to provide it.

Title: Thousands Protest President Trump's Visit to the United Kingdom

Thousands of protesters have taken to the streets in London to demonstrate against President Donald Trump's four-day working visit to the United Kingdom. According to reports, over 50 to 100,000 people are expected to participate in the protests, with more than 60 demonstrations scheduled throughout the duration of Trump's visit.

Protesters began gathering early Friday morning, holding signs and placards condemning the president's policies and rhetoric. One protester gained attention on social media for dressing up as a "Trump Dalek," a fictional character from the popular British television show "Doctor Who." The Dalek costume was accompanied by a tweet from @signs_trump, which read: "There's a Dalek Trump on Whitehall in London with his own secret service personnel. Great British humour coupled with real anger. #TrumpVisitUK #DrWho."

Additionally, protesters flew a blimp depicting Trump as a baby over Parliament Square. Despite Trump's previous statement that he believes London citizens "like him a lot," he later expressed feeling "unwelcome" in London due to the planned protests.

"I used to love London as a city," Trump told The Sun newspaper. "I haven't been there in a long time. But when they make you feel unwelcome, why would I stay there?"

Trump's schedule will largely avoid the planned protests, with his visit limited to one night in London. In January 2017, over 1 million people in the U.K. signed a petition demanding Trump's visit be canceled following his executive order blocking refugees and people from seven predominantly Muslim countries from entering the United States.

Title: Chicago Mayor Distances Police Department from Racially-Charged Photo from Over a Decade Ago

The Chicago Police Department is facing renewed scrutiny after a photo surfaced showing two former officers, Timothy McDermott and Jerome Finnigan, posing with a black man lying on his stomach with deer antlers on his head. The photo, taken between 1999 and 2003, was published by the Chicago Sun-Times this week after a Cook County judge declined to keep it out of the public eye.

Mayor Rahm Emanuel has distanced the city and the police department from the incident, stating that the photo does not represent the values of the city or the police department. The photo shows the two white officers, armed with rifles, kneeling over an unidentified African-American drug suspect who was allegedly posed to look like a hunter's bounty.

The publication of the photo comes as Chicago, like many other big cities in the USA, is grappling to repair damaged relations in the African-American community. The city council recently approved an unprecedented reparations package to the victims of police torture under the control of former police commander Jon Burge. The package included a $5 million payout to Laquan McDonald, a black teenager fatally shot 16 times by police last fall.

The officers in the antler photo were part of a disgraced special unit accused of robbing drug dealers and other individuals of hundreds of thousands of dollars. Finnigan is serving a 12-year prison sentence for robbery and home invasion after pleading guilty in 2011. McDermott was not charged with any criminal wrongdoing but was fired from the police department last year based on the photo. He has sued to reverse his dismissal.

The Chicago Police Department has launched a listening tour to meet with residents and community leaders to mend strained relations between police and minority communities. The department has also taken disciplinary action against the officers involved, with McDermott being fired and Finnigan serving a prison sentence.
