The photo came to light after federal prosecutors gave it to the police in 2013, and the department sought to keep it out of the public eye, citing the privacy of the suspect. However, a judge refused to hide the picture, and the Sun-Times obtained the image from the court file. The police were unable to identify the suspect, who was never charged.

Title: Colorado Republicans Select Delegates Without Primary Vote, Cruz Wins All 34 Delegates

Colorado Republicans held their presidential delegate selection process over the weekend, with Senator Ted Cruz emerging victorious, capturing all 34 delegates. However, Donald Trump is expressing discontent, calling the results "totally unfair" and claiming that the people of Colorado had their vote taken away from them.

The Colorado Republican Party canceled its traditional primary election in August, opting instead for a caucus process that allowed party insiders and activists to select national delegates. This decision was met with controversy at the time, as it effectively removed the majority of Republican voters from the process. The Cruz campaign, however, worked diligently to build an organization and capitalize on the Trump campaign's failure to adapt to the system.

Trump took to Twitter to express his discontent, stating that the people of Colorado never got to vote in the Republican primary and that the results are "totally unfair." He also claimed that the people of Colorado had their vote taken away from them by "phony politicians."

However, the Trump campaign had chosen not to compete in Colorado, citing the system's favoritism towards party insiders as their reason. The Cruz campaign, on the other hand, had been working in Colorado for months, securing endorsements and winning over delegates.

According to Cruz's state chairman, Rep. Ken Buck, over 100 people had been working since last year to get people to the caucuses to elect delegates to the convention. The campaign is now seeing a return on their investment.

Whether or not one agrees with Colorado's decision to cancel its traditional caucus is a separate issue. Cruz won fair and square by working within the process and rules that were established, according to his campaign spokeswoman.

Title: Speaker Pelosi Expresses Skepticism Over Impeaching President Trump

Article:

Speaker of the House of Representatives Nancy Pelosi (D-CA) has expressed doubts about the feasibility of impeaching President Donald Trump, stating that it "isn't worth it" unless there is "something so compelling and overwhelming and bipartisan" to justify the move. In an interview with the Washington Post, Pelosi emphasized that she does not believe Trump is "ethically, intellectually, or politically fit" to be president.

Pelosi's comments have sparked a mixed reaction from fellow Democrats, with some lawmakers agreeing with her assessment and others continuing to push for impeachment. New York Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez disagrees with Pelosi, stating that her view could change if new evidence emerges from Special Counsel Robert Mueller's investigation into Russian meddling in the 2016 election.

Other Democratic lawmakers, such as Representative Maxine Waters (D-CA) and Representative Rashida Tlaib (D-MI), remain committed to investigating and potentially impeaching Trump. Waters, chairwoman of the House Financial Services Committee, believes that the Constitution gives Congress the authority to decide whether the president is acting in the best interest of the country and that she has enough evidence to impeach Trump. Tlaib has publicly called Trump a "motherf***er" and plans to introduce a resolution to have the Judiciary Committee investigate grounds for impeachment.

The left-wing media is also continuing to push for impeachment, with MSNBC's Chris Matthews stating that the push for impeachment is either ahead or behind schedule.

Title: Federal Judge Rules Government Can Mandate School Attendance, But Not Provide Education

A recent ruling by U.S. District Judge Stephen Murphy III has clarified that the government can require students to attend school, but it is not constitutionally obligated to provide a specific level of education. The decision came in response to a lawsuit filed by Detroit students who claimed that the state's emergency managers deprived them of their right to an education and basic literacy.

The plaintiffs argued that the state's failure to provide access to literacy violated their Due Process and Equal Protection rights under the 14th Amendment. However, Judge Murphy disagreed, citing the 1973 Supreme Court case San Antonio Independent School District v. Rodriguez, which held that the U.S. Constitution does not establish a fundamental right to education.

The judge noted that while literacy is crucial for various aspects of life, such as voting, accessing justice, and applying for jobs, it does not necessarily make access to literacy a fundamental right. The court has previously ruled that other essential services, like water and sewer services, are not constitutionally mandated.

The ruling has sparked outrage among some, with the plaintiffs promising to appeal. However, the decision is not unprecedented, as courts have been hesitant to define what constitutes a fundamental right to education. The judge emphasized that the government can mandate school attendance, but it is up to parents and students to choose alternative educational options.

The ruling highlights the importance of competition and choice in the education system. If the courts cannot force schools to provide a certain level of education, parents and students must be free to choose other schools. Research has shown that the presence of charter schools and other school choice options can lead to improved public schools.

In conclusion, the recent ruling underscores the need for parents to have access to school choice options to decide what is best for their children. While the government can require attendance, it is up to individuals to seek out alternative educational paths to achieve their goals.

Title: Muslims in India and Bangladesh Celebrate Subdued Eid al-Fitr Amid COVID-19 Pandemic

Muslims in India and Bangladesh marked a subdued Eid al-Fitr on Monday, marking the end of the holy month of Ramadan under the shadow of the coronavirus pandemic. The three-day holiday, which typically involves travel, family gatherings, and feasts, was significantly toned down this year due to the ongoing pandemic.

In India, authorities banned religious congregations, and security officers patrolled the streets, with most shops closed except for a sweets shop. In Ahmedabad, a businessman, Shehzad Khan, distributed kheer, a sweet dish, to homeless people, redirecting funds typically spent on new clothes to support those who have lost livelihoods due to the virus.

In Bangladesh, authorities asked people to avoid mass prayers in open fields and instead join prayers at mosques while maintaining safe distances. Devotees wore masks and gloves, and many mosques had limited capacity to ensure social distancing.

Government and religious leaders across both countries appealed to Eid celebrants to follow lockdown norms and maintain a safe physical distance. India has reported over 138,000 cases and 4,000 deaths, while Bangladesh has confirmed 35,585 cases and 501 deaths.

Prime Minister Narendra Modi and Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina of Bangladesh offered Eid greetings, emphasizing the importance of maintaining health guidelines and staying safe.

Title: Trump's Fiscal Priorities: A Recipe for a Growing National Debt

The article discusses the potential consequences of President Donald Trump's fiscal policies, specifically his proposal to cut taxes and increase spending. According to experts, this approach could lead to a significant increase in the national debt, as the government would be giving away more than it takes in.

The article highlights that politicians often pretend to make hard choices, but rarely do. In this case, Trump's proposal to cut taxes and increase spending is seen as an easy way out, as it would not require making difficult decisions. The article quotes Robert Bixby, executive director of The Concord Coalition, saying, "There's a political logic to it: 'You get what you want. We get what we want. And the future will pay for it.'"

The article also notes that Trump's proposal to cut taxes and increase spending is not a new approach, as it has been the default option for decades. The article mentions that Trump's proposed spending cuts, which would reduce the deficit, are unlikely to be approved, as they would affect popular programs such as the Environmental Protection Agency and the National Endowment for the Arts.

The article concludes that the only other place where spending could be cut is in the biggest entitlements, such as Social Security, Medicare, and Medicaid, but Trump has promised not to touch these programs. The article notes that the president's proposal to boost outlays, such as his $1 trillion infrastructure plan, is likely to receive bipartisan support, as it is seen as a way to stimulate economic growth.

Overall, the article presents a neutral and factual analysis of Trump's fiscal priorities, highlighting the potential consequences of his proposals and the likelihood of a growing national debt.

Title: Supreme Court Chief Justice John Roberts' Swing Vote Continues to Shape High-Profile Decisions

Article:

Supreme Court Chief Justice John Roberts has been at the center of several high-profile decisions in recent weeks, with his votes often determining the outcome of 5-4 decisions. While he has sided with the liberal bloc in some cases, he has also voted with the conservative justices in others. This has led to both praise and criticism from politicians and legal experts.

In a recent decision, Roberts sided with the liberal justices to rule against a Louisiana law restricting who can perform abortions, upholding precedent from a similar case in 2016. This decision was seen as a victory for reproductive rights advocates and a blow to anti-abortion groups.

However, Roberts has also sided with the conservative justices in other cases, including a decision that delivered a win for the school choice movement. This decision, which was a 5-4 ruling, held that a clause in Montana's state constitution forbidding aid to schools controlled by a "church, sect, or denomination" violated the U.S. Constitution's Free Exercise Clause.

Roberts' decisions have been closely watched, with some politicians and legal experts expressing concern that he is not a swing vote, but rather a liberal justice. Former Arkansas Governor Mike Huckabee called Roberts an "empty black robe who wants to be loved by liberals who believe in legislating from the bench." Fox News contributor Dan Bongino tweeted that Roberts "didn't'side with' the liberal wing of the Supreme Court, HE IS A LIBERAL."

Despite the criticism, Roberts has a history of separating himself from the conservative contingent in key cases. In 2012, he sided with the liberal wing and reinterpreted an individual mandate as a tax, allowing ObamaCare to be found constitutional. Last year, he joined with liberals again in shutting down the Trump administration's efforts to add a citizenship question to the census.

Roberts' decisions have significant implications for the country, with several cases still pending before the court. These include issues such as whether states can force members of the Electoral College to vote in accordance with the state's popular vote, and whether President Trump's tax returns can be released to House committees or Manhattan prosecutors.

Title: Attacks on Free Speech Intensify Amidst COVID-19 Crisis

The COVID-19 pandemic has brought about unprecedented challenges to liberal democratic institutions and values, with authoritarian power grabs and "corona coups" on the rise worldwide. One of the first victims of these attacks is freedom of speech, which is being targeted not only at "fake news" but also at critiques of hospital inadequacies by healthcare workers.

Repressive measures against "fake news" have been a popular topic in recent years, with many mainstream politicians convinced that the spread of misinformation is a primary reason for their loss of power and votes to populists. Social media platforms and fact-checking organizations have emerged to combat the issue, but too little progress has been made.

The current crisis has given populists in power an opportunity to intensify their fight against "fake news," with some countries passing draconian laws to prevent the spread of misinformation. One example is Hungary, where the parliament has passed "emergency measures" giving Prime Minister Viktor Orbán dictatorial powers to punish anyone deemed to be spreading "fake news" with up to five years in prison.

The attack on free speech is not limited to "fake news." Healthcare workers, who are best informed about the situation and the best potential antidotes to misinformation, are also being targeted. In the UK, British NHS doctors are being gagged over protective equipment shortages, while in the US, private hospitals are threatening staff with termination if they speak out about the lack of protective gear.

Censoring healthcare professionals is dangerous to the broader community, as they are the ones who have day-to-day experience with the virus and risk their lives to help others. Moreover, this type of censorship is reminiscent of China's authoritarian approach, which has worsened the country's response to the pandemic.

Some politicians who support or allow censorship of healthcare professionals in their own country have been outspoken critics of China's approach. To ensure that we are not making the same mistakes as China and to protect the health and lives of heroic healthcare workers, we must resist these dangerous attacks on free speech and other unnecessary authoritarian measures in response to the COVID-19 crisis.

Title: Texas Senator Ted Cruz Enters Presidential Race with Bold Move

Texas Senator Ted Cruz has officially announced his candidacy for the 2016 presidential election, making him the first major contender to do so. This bold move is characteristic of Cruz's go-for-broke style, which has been evident since his 2012 Senate campaign. Despite not being a leading candidate in national polls, Cruz has an undeniable appeal to base voters, particularly in red states.

Cruz's decision to skip the "exploratory committee" phase and declare his candidacy immediately cuts through the usual noise and confusion surrounding nascent presidential bids. This move allows him to raise money quickly and defend his home state of Texas against other candidates vying for donors.

Additionally, Cruz's early declaration bolsters his bid to be the standard-bearer for conservative activists, setting him apart from other potential candidates vying for the same lane. By getting in early, Cruz may discourage some competitors and eclipse others, such as Ben Carson and Carly Fiorina.

While some may view Cruz's candidacy as a long shot, he has 10 months to test the market and maximize his media exposure. Even if he doesn't win the nomination, Cruz can still return as a ticket-balancer at convention time, which has proven to be a successful strategy for some candidates.

Overall, Senator Ted Cruz's bold move to declare his candidacy early sets the stage for an exciting and unpredictable presidential election season.

Title: Navigating the Complexity of Politics and Voters

The article discusses the current state of politics in the United States, specifically the aftermath of the recent presidential election. The author, John Inazu, argues that people and voters are more complex than labels, and that political disagreements should be settled with words rather than violence. He notes that the nature of Donald Trump's campaign has raised the stakes, but also that some of the reaction to Trump has been problematic, including "resistance at every turn" and "equating critiques of identity politics with endorsements of white nationalism."

Inazu emphasizes the importance of maintaining a modest unity and avoiding the zero-sum game of politics, where one side wins and the other loses. He encourages those who are uncomfortable with the current state of the country and the prospects of a Trump administration to look inward and ask concretely and individually how they can become more engaged in their politics.

The author also cautions against blaming others or pledging unqualified resistance, instead suggesting that people should extend a little grace to those who pursue either dissent or partnership for the sake of maintaining unity. He notes that not all political opponents are the face of evil, the belly of racism, or the pit of depravity, and that critics of Trump should also question the elitist rage targeting and demonizing certain groups.

Inazu concludes by emphasizing the importance of speaking, writing, and tweeting with care, depth, and nuance, and avoiding lazy thinking that encourages stereotyping. He encourages people to listen to what others have to say and to recognize that "those people" are also "our people."

Title: Senate Judiciary Committee Chairman Requests Document on Scope of Mueller Investigation

The Senate Judiciary Committee Chairman, Chuck Grassley, has sent a letter to Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein requesting a document that outlines the full scope of special counsel Robert Mueller's Russia investigation. The letter, dated May 18, comes after Mueller's team provided an unredacted copy of a memo written by Rosenstein on August 2, 2017, to a federal judge in Virginia. The memo was previously provided to Paul Manafort, President Donald Trump's former campaign chairman, who is under indictment for bank and tax fraud related to his work in Ukraine.

Grassley, an Iowa Republican, argues that Congress is entitled to see the document, citing its constitutional duties and oversight responsibilities. He noted that the Judiciary Committee is a separate branch of government with its own constitutional duties that require access to Executive Branch information.

Mueller's office provided the memo to Manafort's legal team, which has questioned the timing of the memo and its potential connection to the search warrant executed on Manafort's Virginia residence several days before Rosenstein wrote the memo. Manafort's lawyers have argued that Mueller did not have jurisdiction to investigate areas not related to possible collusion between the Trump campaign and the Russian government.

Grassley has also expressed interest in the timing of the Rosenstein memo, asking why it was not drafted until August 2017, nearly three months after Mueller was appointed special counsel. Grassley has been a supporter of the Mueller investigation and has publicly warned President Trump against taking steps to shut down the investigation or fire Mueller.

In his letter, Grassley emphasized that the investigation should be free to follow the facts wherever they lead without improper outside interference, but noted that it is not immune from oversight or that information about the scope of its authority under existing Department regulations should be withheld from Congress.

Title: Sen. Susan Collins' "Yes" Vote on Brett Kavanaugh Ends Uncertainty, Sparks Controversy

Article:

Sen. Susan Collins' announcement on Friday that she would vote "yes" on Supreme Court nominee Brett Kavanaugh likely ended the uncertainty over his confirmation. However, her decision has sparked controversy, with activists groups raising over $3 million to defeat her in the 2020 election. The groups, Be A Hero Team, Maine People's Alliance, and Mainers for Accountable Leadership, had been criticized by Collins and others over several weeks as a possible attempt to bribe her into voting against Kavanaugh.

The campaign, which started in August, asked people across the nation to donate to Collins' opponent in an attempt to show her the stark opposition to Kavanaugh. The donation page, titled "Either Sen. Collins VOTES NO on Kavanaugh OR we fund her future opponent," went down briefly on crowdfunding website crowdpac.com due to "overwhelming" traffic. The groups are also raising money on the website ActBlue, with the total amount exceeding $3 million.

Collins' decision to vote in favor of Kavanaugh's confirmation came after a nearly 45-minute speech on the Senate floor, where she explained her process and why she would be voting to confirm him. The speech addressed various issues, including Obamacare, same-sex marriage, and abortion rights, and Collins stated that Kavanaugh's record and pledges before Congress were enough to keep her vote.

The activists groups, however, are committed to defeating Collins in the 2020 election and have pledged to "never let her forget" her decision. They argue that Collins has betrayed the people of Maine, especially women and survivors, by voting to confirm Kavanaugh. The groups claim that Collins has ignored the pleas of thousands of Mainers who wrote, called, visited, protested, and begged her to vote against Kavanaugh.

A watchdog group, the Foundation for Accountability and Civic Trust (FACT), has asked the Justice Department to investigate the campaign against Collins, citing concerns that the money donated was an attempt to bribe her vote and is illegal.

Title: US Officials Confirm Ongoing Attacks by Iran-Backed Militias on American Outposts in Iraq

The United States continues to experience targeted strikes by Iran-backed militia groups in Iraq, according to senior US officials. James Jeffrey, the Trump administration's special representative for Syria engagement and special envoy for the global coalition to defeat ISIS, stated that while the attacks have scaled down since the killing of top Iranian general Qassem Soleimani, they still occur regularly.

Jeffrey reported that coalition forces have been subject to a few shellings of bases where coalition forces are located, with the most recent incident being a few days ago at the American embassy compound. He emphasized that these attacks are not as frequent or intense as the 11 incidents that led to the US response last month.

When asked if these attacks are orchestrated by Iran, Jeffrey replied, "We think so." The US is primarily focused on protecting American forces in the region from retaliatory strikes by Iran, rather than actively engaging in the fight against ISIS.

Additionally, US officials remain concerned about the potential resurgence of ISIS, which has suffered major territorial defeats in the past year. Jeffrey emphasized that the risk of ISIS's resurgence is a "very big problem," citing the coordination among ISIS forces and the concern shared among the US, Iraq, and other regional partners.

In summary, while the frequency and intensity of attacks have decreased since the killing of Soleimani, Iran-backed militias continue to target US outposts in Iraq, and the US remains focused on protecting its forces and concerned about the potential resurgence of ISIS.

Title: Dr. Rick Bright Warns of "Darkest Winter" if US Fails to Plan for COVID-19 Pandemic

Dr. Rick Bright, a former director of the US research agency working on a coronavirus vaccine, testified before a House subcommittee that the US needs to take "simple but critical steps" to control the COVID-19 pandemic and head off a disastrous second wave of infections this winter. Bright warned lawmakers that without better planning, 2020 could be the darkest winter in modern history.

In his testimony, Bright emphasized the importance of having the right testing, contact tracing, isolation, and quarantine measures in place to combat the pandemic. He also cautioned that a COVID-19 vaccine is a question of when, not if, but noted that it may take longer than 12 to 18 months to manufacture.

Bright's testimony comes as the US is experiencing a surge in COVID-19 cases, with many experts warning of a potential second wave of infections this fall. Bright's warning is echoed by other experts, who have expressed concerns about the country's preparedness for the coming winter.

Bright's testimony also touched on his removal from his position as director of the Department of Health and Human Services' Biomedical Advanced Research and Development Authority (BARDA) in April. He alleges that his removal was an act of retaliation by Trump administration officials because he resisted a push by the White House to promote unproven coronavirus treatments using hydroxychloroquine.

Bright's written testimony, submitted ahead of the hearing, had an even stronger warning: that without clear planning and quick action, the coming winter will be the darkest in recent history. He modulated that warning slightly on Thursday but still struck a sobering note.

In his written testimony, Bright describes "dismissive" HHS leadership and said that, as early as January, he warned the department to ramp up production of ventilators, personal protective equipment, and testing swabs in anticipation of a pandemic, and that his warnings were ignored.

Bright also said in prepared testimony that he was "cut out of key high-level meetings to combat COVID-19."

The hearing saw Republicans on the committee focus more on defending President Trump's promotion of hydroxychloroquine than on getting to the bottom of the circumstances surrounding Bright's removal.

Title: Trump Ends DACA Program, but Decision Splits Opinion

The Trump administration's decision to end the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) program, also known as the "Dreamers" program, has sparked a heated debate. The program, implemented by former President Barack Obama in 2012, allowed certain individuals who entered the United States as minors to remain in the country without fear of deportation.

The decision to end the program has been met with widespread criticism from the mainstream media, who have been largely aligned against President Trump and in favor of preserving the program. The media have highlighted the stories of individual Dreamers, including those with successful careers, families, and contributions to society.

However, the decision was also seen as a compromise by some, as it allows for a six-month delay before the program is officially rescinded. This delay has been seen as a way for the administration to limit the backlash against the decision.

The decision to end the program was made by Attorney General Jeff Sessions, who cited constitutional grounds for the decision. The administration has also halted new applications for the program, which has been a point of contention.

The debate surrounding the program has been further complicated by the fact that it was implemented by President Obama through executive action, rather than being passed through Congress. This has led to criticism from some that the program was not a permanent solution and was vulnerable to being reversed by a new administration.

The decision has also been seen as a way for President Trump to appease his base, while also leaving the door open for a potential deal with Congress to address the issue. However, many Democrats have criticized the decision, with House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi calling it a "cruel and heartless" move.

The fate of the program remains uncertain, as Congress has been unable to agree on a comprehensive immigration reform bill. The six-month delay has been seen as a way for the administration to punt the decision to Congress, but many are skeptical that a deal will be reached in that timeframe.

**Immigrant Rights Activists Converge on Capitol Hill to Demand Action on Legislation**

Tens of thousands of immigrant rights supporters are expected to gather on Capitol Hill on Wednesday to push for action on legislation that would legalize the estimated 11 million illegal immigrants in the United States. The rally is seen as a key moment in the ongoing debate, with activists arguing that every day that passes means 1,100 more immigrants are deported.

This year's protest is part of a growing movement that has been building momentum over the past decade. Similar protests were held in 2003, 2006, and 2010, with each event highlighting the growing power of the immigrant rights movement in the United States.

Activists will demand that the legalization process be simple and quick, and will argue that there is no need to do more to beef up border security or boost deportations. They will also push for a guest-worker program for future foreign workers.

The rally will serve as a demonstration of the growing political power of the movement, which has been ascending for years but finally forced lawmakers to take notice after the 2012 elections. Activists are hopeful that their presence and voice will lead to the introduction and passage of immigration reform.

The movement has been marked by several key moments, including the Immigrant Worker Freedom Rides in 2003, massive marches in the spring of 2006, and a rally on the Mall in Washington in 2010. These events have served as a test of the emerging coalition and have highlighted the growing power of the movement.

The rally comes as negotiators are struggling to write legislation, and activists are getting antsy. Douglas Rivlin, who worked for the National Immigration Forum at the time, said that the rallies have served as a wake-up call for many Americans, but also hardened some positions on each side.

The issue has been a dividing line in the 2008 election, with then-candidate Barack Obama promising to make immigration a top priority in his first year in the White House. However, he turned instead to health care, angering Hispanic voters who felt betrayed. The anger was boosted by the president's push to step up deportations.

Activists are now pushing for the president to keep his promise and renew his efforts to pass a broad legalization bill. The rally will serve as a reminder of the power the movement can bring and a call to action for lawmakers to take a stand on the issue.

Title: Congressional Leaders Urge President Obama to Provide Lethal Arms to Ukraine

Article:

A bipartisan group of 11 lawmakers, including House Speaker John A. Boehner and ranking Democrats and Republicans on key security committees, has called on President Obama to provide lethal American arms to Ukraine. In a letter, they emphasized that Congress has already given the president permission to do so and that he needs to act quickly to stop Russian aggression.

The lawmakers stated that Ukraine is a major geopolitical test for the U.S. and that the country is in danger of losing. They described Russia's actions as a "grotesque violation of international law" and a challenge to the West and the international order established after World War II.

Congress passed a law last year allowing the transfer of defensive military equipment to Ukraine, and Ukrainian officials have delivered a list of military equipment they could use to the Pentagon and the White House. However, President Obama has not taken advantage of this permission, and his aides say he is still considering it and watching how the cease-fire agreed to last month is being carried out.

The lawmakers expressed concern that Russian-backed separatists have abused the cease-fire to consolidate their positions and push Ukrainian forces out of the territory. They urged President Obama to act quickly on arms and to lead European leaders in challenging Russia's actions.

Some analysts have predicted that providing lethal arms to Ukraine could spur a more emphatic response from Russia, which is backing separatists in eastern Ukraine. However, President Obama's top military advisers have weighed in favor of providing lethal aid, citing the need to help Ukraine defend against Russia's "incredibly lethal" offensive capabilities.

The stakes go beyond Ukraine, with the lawmakers noting that an attack on the Baltic countries, which are part of NATO, would trigger NATO's collective defense pact.

Title: New Dictionary Aims to Bridge Political Divide by Providing Balanced Definitions of Controversial Terms

The AllSides Dictionary, a new online resource, aims to help bridge the political divide by providing balanced definitions of 400 controversial terms. The dictionary, created by AllSides, a news hub that offers guidance on the potential political bias of articles and news providers, features contributions from academics and aims to provide a nuanced understanding of how different political perspectives view these terms.

The dictionary defines terms such as "abortion," "Black Lives Matter," "truth," and "white privilege," among others. Phil Neisser, one of the editors of the dictionary and a professor in the department of politics at the State University of New York at Potsdam, believes that the dictionary represents an opportunity for higher education institutions to help students become more well-rounded in their understanding of controversial topics.

Neisser noted that universities are often places of potential conflict, as people from different backgrounds and perspectives come together. He believes that the dictionary can help build mutual understanding by providing a platform for people to engage in respectful conversations and learn from each other.

Mikhail Lyubansky, a teaching associate professor in the department of psychology at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, also contributed to the project. He sees the dictionary as a means to get students to think differently and understand the positionality of people who hold different views.

The dictionary's definitions are the result of extensive research and analysis by the contributors, who aimed to provide a balanced and nuanced understanding of the terms. Neisser and Lyubansky emphasized the importance of the dictionary's growth and evolution, as it is an ongoing project that will require continuous updates and additions.

The dictionary's definitions are designed to be accessible and engaging, making it a valuable resource for students, educators, and the general public. By providing a platform for respectful dialogue and understanding, the AllSides Dictionary aims to promote a more informed and empathetic society.

Title: QAnon: A Mysterious Online Conspiracy Theory Gaining Popularity Among Trump Supporters

Article:

A growing number of attendees at President Trump's rallies have been spotted wearing apparel celebrating QAnon, a conspiracy theory that has gained traction among a segment of his supporters. But what is QAnon, and why is it gaining attention?

QAnon followers believe that a person posting messages on 4Chan and 8Chan under the name "Q" is a high-ranking government official. According to Q, President Trump is on the verge of exposing a cabal of pedophiles, globalists, and celebrities who secretly control America. The theory is centered around the idea that a "deep state" took over decades ago, and President Trump is working to expose it.

QAnon adherents believe that President Kennedy was set to reveal the existence of the secret government when he was assassinated, and that President Reagan was shot on the deep state's orders. They also believe that all presidents since Reagan, except Trump, have been deep state agents. The military recruited Trump to run for president to overthrow the deep state, but the deep state tried to smear him through "fake news" and unfounded allegations of collusion with Russia.

QAnon followers believe that Trump is secretly working with special counsel Robert Mueller to bring the deep state down, and that the "storm" is a coming series of mass arrests that will end the deep state forever. Q has repeatedly suggested that the storm will hit in the very near future, but when those dates come and go without any arrests, Q says they needed to be delayed for one reason or another.

Q's posts are often vague or incomprehensible, but QAnon fans are eager to decipher them. They spend a lot of time trying to figure out who in the government is a "white hat" Trump supporter and who is a "black hat" in league with the deep state. Their rallying cry is "where we go one, we go all," which is frequently abbreviated to "WWG1WGA."

The QAnon faithful sometimes point to former national security adviser Michael Flynn and White House aide Dan Scavino as possibilities behind the posts, while others believe it's Trump himself or even John F. Kennedy Jr., who faked his death and now posts on 8Chan as QAnon.

Title: Government Shutdown and Health Care Law: Obama Criticizes Republican Demands

The government shutdown has entered its second day, with President Obama criticizing Congressional Republicans for refusing to fund the government unless they agree to alter the Affordable Care Act, also known as Obamacare. In a Rose Garden address, Obama stated that Republicans are "shutting down the government over an ideological crusade to deny affordable health care to many Americans." He emphasized that the shutdown did not have to happen and that Republicans are demanding ransom for doing their job.

The President met with 12 individuals who have benefited from the Affordable Care Act's changes to health insurance coverage or plan to enroll in coverage through the new insurance marketplaces. He urged Republicans to pass a budget and end the government shutdown, stating that he will not give in to reckless demands to deny affordable health insurance to millions.

The Affordable Care Act's health exchanges opened for business on October 1, with over 1 million people visiting healthcare.gov before 7 a.m. Obama acknowledged that the online system is experiencing glitches due to high demand, but compared it to Apple's rollout of a new operating system, stating that no one suggested Apple should stop selling iPhones or iPads.

On Capitol Hill, both Houses of Congress reinforced their original positions, with House Republicans planning to approve smaller spending bills to fund specific government programs, such as veterans' services and national parks. Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid rejected the strategy, stating that it is "just another wacky idea from the Tea Party-driven Republicans."

The government shutdown has resulted in the closure of national parks and war memorials, with over 800,000 federal employees furloughed without pay. The impact of the shutdown is also being felt in other ways, including delays in Federal Housing Administration home loans and court proceedings.

The political consequences of the shutdown could be severe for both parties, with a recent poll showing that 63% of Americans disapprove of Republicans' handling of the budget debate. Experts warn that public pressure on lawmakers could grow, particularly on Republicans, as federal employees and their families face the consequences of the shutdown.

Title: Critique of "American Sniper" Reveals Dark Aspects of GOP Mindset

The film "American Sniper" has been criticized for its inaccurate portrayal of Chris Kyle, the real-life American sniper. However, the real issue with the film goes beyond its depiction of Kyle. The movie suffers from a lack of nuance, context, and subtlety, reflecting a broader problem with the GOP mindset.

Two key moments in Clint Eastwood's public appearances highlight the troubling aspects of his worldview. In 2005, Eastwood confronted filmmaker Michael Moore at the National Board of Review dinner, where he jokingly threatened to kill Moore if he showed up at his door. This reaction demonstrates the GOP's tendency to respond to disagreement with aggression. In 2012, Eastwood delivered a rambling monologue at the Republican National Convention, targeting an empty chair that supposedly had an invisible Barack Obama sitting in it. This bizarre performance was met with confusion and bewilderment.

The film "American Sniper" perpetuates a delusional link between the 9/11 attacks and the war in Iraq, ignoring the fact that the war had no connection to the attacks. This misconception is common among those who rely heavily on Fox News, which has been shown to spread misinformation. The film also perpetuates a culture of violence, dividing the world into categories of wolves, sheep, and sheepdogs, with Iraqis depicted as wolves. The film's logic of war is simplistic and unquestioned, failing to consider the complexities of the conflict.

The film's lack of nuance and subtlety is not surprising, given Eastwood's own views. His reaction to Moore and his 2012 monologue at the RNC demonstrate a tendency towards aggression and a refusal to engage with opposing viewpoints. The film "American Sniper" is not just about a sniper, but also about an attitude that threatens to destroy political compromise and productive debate. This is what makes the film truly disturbing.

Title: Presidential Debate: Romney Edges Obama in Latest Polls, but Race Remains Tight

The third and final presidential debate of the 2012 election season is set to take place tonight, with a focus on foreign policy. As the candidates prepare to face off, recent polls suggest a slight lead for Republican challenger Mitt Romney over incumbent President Barack Obama. According to multiple polls, including Rasmussen, Gallup, and Politico/GWU, Romney has established a modest lead among likely voters, with some polls showing him ahead by as much as 5 points.

The Rasmussen poll, which has been tracking the race daily, shows Romney with a 49-47 edge, while Gallup puts him at 51-45. The Politico/GWU poll, which has been more favorable to Democrats in recent months, still shows Romney with a slight lead, 49-47.

The polls suggest that Romney is building momentum in critical battleground states, with Rasmussen's swing state tracker showing him ahead by a handful of points. The NBC/WSJ poll, which has been less kind to Republicans in recent months, still shows a tie, 47-47.

The polls also highlight some key demographic trends. Romney is winning the gender gap, with a 10-point lead among men and a 2-point edge among women. He is also leading among women without children, 50-46. Romney's strong performance among married women, 42-55, and seniors, 58-38, is a significant factor in his overall lead.

The Monmouth University poll shows Romney with a 48-45 edge, with the president at 45%. The poll suggests that Romney is building his advantage by carrying independents handily on every major question.

Recent state polls also suggest a tightening race, with Romney leading in Colorado, Iowa, and Ohio. The Gravis Marketing poll shows Obama and Romney tied at 47%, with Romney leading among independents, 52-33. The poll also suggests that Obama is underwater in job approval, 44-50, and independents disapprove of him overwhelmingly, 31-58.

The race remains tight, and the trajectory could shift again before Election Day. The final debate tonight may present the president with his best chance to re-shuffle the deck.

Title: Burkina Faso Hotel Attack Leaves at Least 28 Dead, Including American Missionary

An attack on an upscale hotel in Ouagadougou, the capital of Burkina Faso, resulted in the deaths of at least 28 people, including an American missionary, Mike Riddering, 45. The attack began late Friday when terrorists seized the Hotel Splendid, a popular meeting place for foreign tourists and United Nations staff, and the nearby Cappuccino Cafe. The terrorists set fire to several cars and took hostages.

National and French security forces raided the hotel, killing four extremists and freeing 126 hostages. Two of the attackers were women, according to President Roch Marc Christian Kabore. Three of the terrorists, believed to belong to a local al-Qaeda affiliate, were killed in the assault on the hotel, and a fourth was killed nearby at the Hotel Yibi.

The attack is believed to be the work of AQIM, or al-Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb, which claimed responsibility online. The group said fighters had "broken into a restaurant of one of the biggest hotels in the capital of Burkina Faso, and are now entrenched and the clashes are continuing with the enemies of the religion."

The same group is believed responsible for a similar siege at an upscale hotel in Bamako, Mali, in November that left 20 dead. Burkina Faso, a largely Muslim country, has largely been spared the violence wracked by Islamic extremist groups in Mali, but a Romanian national was abducted last April.

The attack follows growing tension in Burkina Faso in the wake of a coup attempt by presidential guards that collapsed in September. The newly installed government of President Kabore recently issued an arrest warrant for Guillaume Soro, the head of the National Assembly in neighboring Ivory Coast, for his alleged involvement in the failed coup attempt.

In a separate development, an Australian doctor and his wife were kidnapped Friday night by extremists in Burkina Faso's north near its border with Mali. The couple was abducted in Djibo, the capital of the northern Soum province, where they had been living since 1972, volunteering in health services.

Title: Congress Members Prioritize TV Appearances Over Governance

Article:

Members of Congress are increasingly prioritizing their television appearances over their duties as lawmakers, leading to a decline in actual governance and a rise in grandstanding and posturing. This phenomenon has been exacerbated by the proliferation of social media and cable news, which has transformed politics into a form of performance art.

According to Yuval Levin, writing in a Commentary essay, the 21st century's technological advancements have had both positive and negative effects on politics. While transparency has increased, it has also led to a focus on image over substance. As a result, politicians are more concerned with appearing on TV and social media than with actually governing.

This trend is evident in the lack of legislative achievements during the current administration. Despite having control of both chambers and a Republican president willing to sign their bills, Congress has accomplished very little. They passed a tax cut, but have failed to address other key issues, such as healthcare reform, immigration reform, and the entitlement crisis.

The chief job of Congress, developing a budget, has also been neglected. For the first time in 40 years, neither chamber has considered a budget resolution. This lack of legislative activity is a result of Congress prioritizing their TV appearances over their duties as lawmakers.

The article also highlights the example of Paul Manafort, who was accused of corruption and financial improprieties. While President Trump defended him, it is unclear why he did not conduct a background check on Manafort before hiring him as his campaign chairman. The article notes that Manafort's lavish spending habits and denial of off-the-books payments were publicly known, but Trump did not investigate further.

The article concludes that Congress is willingly surrendering its intended role for the pleasures of TV appearances, a trend that will likely outlast the current administration.

Title: Republicans' Deficit Reduction Ambitions Face Internal Hurdles

The Republican Party's strong stance on deficit reduction may be more of a unifying theme than a genuine desire to tackle the issue. According to Julian Zelizer, a prominent political analyst, many Republicans are aware that entitlement cuts are unpopular in red states and districts, making it difficult for them to accept a "grand bargain" that would require revenue increases.

At the Conservative Political Action Convention, Republicans spent a significant amount of time criticizing President Obama's budgetary policies and emphasizing the need for dramatic deficit reduction. Congressman Paul Ryan, a key figure in the Republican Party, warned that the country's debt is a threat to its future and emphasized the importance of balancing the budget to promote a healthier economy.

However, despite the rhetoric, many Republicans are hesitant to actually tackle the issue. Deficit reduction has become a defining theme for the party since the 2010 elections, and many Republicans are reluctant to give up this issue as a way to unite their party. Without deficit reduction as a central issue, the divisions within the Republican Party become more apparent, with factions such as neoconservatives, social conservatives, and libertarians having different priorities.

For President Obama, a grand bargain on deficit reduction could be a way to steal away one of the main issues that Republicans have used to attack Democrats for decades. However, such a deal would require Republicans to accept revenue increases, which goes against their anti-tax fundamentalism. Many experts agree that eliminating deficits would require a combination of tax increases and loophole-closing reforms, making it difficult for Republicans to achieve their goal.

Furthermore, Republicans understand that deep cuts in entitlement spending would be painful for their party, particularly in red states and districts where elderly voters would feel the impact of reductions to Medicare, Medicaid, and Social Security. The political backlash from Republican voters against such cuts could be severe, as recent social science research has shown that many conservatives, including Tea Party activists, strongly support federal programs for the elderly.

In conclusion, while Republicans continue to emphasize the need for deficit reduction, their internal divisions and reluctance to accept revenue increases make it difficult for them to achieve their goal. The political implications of a grand bargain on deficit reduction could be significant, with Republicans facing a difficult choice between their desire to unite their party and their commitment to fiscal responsibility.

Title: Political Outfits Associated with Top Prospects Raise at Least $86 Million

The article reports on the financial activities of political outfits associated with top presidential prospects in both the Republican and Democratic parties. According to an analysis of campaign reports and interviews with the prospects' allies, these outfits raised at least $86 million last year for committees that could help launch or support campaigns.

The article highlights the importance of building a strong financial foundation for a presidential campaign, particularly in the post-Citizens United era. Prospective candidates need a stable of rich allies to bolster their efforts well before the campaign starts and fend off attacks from opponents who also have wealthy friends.

The article notes that many of the biggest Democratic donors and top campaign operatives are aligning behind Hillary Clinton, but that doesn't stop prospective rivals from assembling their campaign-style operations and working the circuit. The article also mentions that some prospective candidates, such as Wisconsin Gov. Scott Walker, are already building their campaign infrastructure and reaching out to wealthy donors.

The article provides specific examples of politicians and their allies raising money for their respective campaigns. For instance, Sen. Ted Cruz invited Foster Friess to be his guest at the State of the Union, while Louisiana Gov. Bobby Jindal met with some of the right's most prolific donors at a Koch brothers' retreat. The article also notes that some politicians are using innovative fundraising strategies, such as joint committees that merge their various accounts and increase the maximum size of donations to $10,000.

Overall, the article provides a comprehensive overview of the financial activities of political outfits associated with top presidential prospects, highlighting the importance of building a strong financial foundation for a presidential campaign.

Title: Democratic Debate Highlights: Immigration Takes Center Stage, Candidates' Positions on Deportations Raise Questions

The first hour of the Democratic debate, hosted by Univision and moderated by Latino journalists, focused primarily on immigration, border security, and legalization. The debate saw both Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders expressing sympathy for the plight of illegal aliens and advocating for a pathway to citizenship, potentially bypassing Congress and using executive orders. While the candidates avoided using the term "amnesty," the result of such a pathway would be the legalization of illegal immigrants.

On the issue of deportations, both candidates deviated from standard Democratic National Committee talking points and platitudes about the American dream, instead promising lawlessness. Clinton suggested that deportations would end for all "non-criminal" illegal immigrants if she were to become president, while Sanders appeared to agree. This raises questions about the implications of such a promise, including what would happen to newly arrived illegal immigrants and what precedent it would set for the country if the commander-in-chief felt entitled to ignore a huge body of existing federal law.

The debate highlighted the candidates' efforts to outdo each other as champions of illegal immigrants, who have broken U.S. federal law. The candidates' positions on securing the border without enforcing laws against a vast majority of illegal entrants were seen as a form of open borders.

Title: Trump's Executive Order on Anti-Semitism Raises Concerns and Questions

The recent executive order issued by President Trump, aimed at combating anti-Semitism, has sparked concerns and questions among many. The order directs agencies to consider the International Holocaust Remembrance Alliance's (IHRA) definition of anti-Semitism, which includes examples of speech that some argue should be protected by the First Amendment.

Critics of the order argue that it could be used to stifle criticism of Israel and suppress pro-Palestinian protests on college campuses. The order's language suggests that the Trump administration is willing to expand its efforts to attack the speech rights of Palestinian students, echoing an illiberal trend in organized pro-Israel advocacy.

The order's language also raises concerns about the potential for double standards, as it only applies to cases where anti-Semitism is accompanied by an ethnic component. Some argue that this could lead to the suppression of legitimate criticism of Israel.

The article also touches on the recent killing of Iranian General Qasem Soleimani, with some questioning the strategic implications of the strike and the potential for a wider war with Iran. The article notes that the strike did not decapitate any major organizations and that the war would likely be fought on multiple fronts, with unclear objectives and potential consequences.

In conclusion, the executive order on anti-Semitism has sparked concerns and questions about its potential impact on free speech and the potential for a wider conflict with Iran.

Title: Democratic Presidential Nomination Process: A Reflection on the Media's Preferred Candidates

The Democratic presidential nomination process has finally narrowed down to a binary choice between two well-known candidates, Joe Biden and Bernie Sanders. As the media's preferred candidates, Elizabeth Warren and Amy Klobuchar, failed to gain traction, it is worth examining the performance of the media's favored candidates in the 2020 race.

The New York Times' dual endorsements of Warren and Klobuchar, like the points on a game show, did not matter. Similarly, the media's fawning over Pete Buttigieg, Beto O'Rourke, and Kamala Harris did not resonate with the millions of Americans outside the Acela corridor. Instead, Democratic voters consistently showed interest in Biden and Sanders, with early wins for Sanders and a comeback surge from Biden.

The idea that any other candidate had a likely shot at the nomination was always pundit-driven misdirection, driven by commentators seeking more interesting, intersectional characters. The media stumped for Warren so hard that Vox's Matt Yglesias had to write a post explaining why she was losing, even among Vox's audience. Yglesias noted that Vox's audience is comprised of graduates or students of selective colleges, which also describes the staff and their social peers.

Outside the Vox bubble, there was little interest in the kind of cultural progressivism represented by Warren. At present, Biden and Sanders are locked in a battle for delegates, with both having a good shot at the nomination. However, this was true a year ago as well, as both men were better-known and better-liked than many in the media seemed to grasp. Despite an endless series of magazine covers, fluff pieces, and editorial board endorsements aimed at other candidates, neither Biden nor Sanders' popularity could be swayed.

Title: White House Chief of Staff Denies Russian Connection Allegations, Calls Reports "Complete Garbage"

The White House Chief of Staff, Reince Priebus, has vehemently denied allegations that high-ranking officials in the Trump administration had contact with Russian spies, calling the reports "complete garbage." Priebus made the comments on "Fox News Sunday," stating that top levels of the intelligence community have assured him that the story is not only inaccurate but also grossly overstated and wrong.

Priebus emphasized that accusing an organization of being in constant contact with Russian spies is "outrageous" and that every day, it seems like a new, untrue story emerges. He attributed the allegations to unnamed sources within the intelligence community and claimed that the media is focused on the wrong issues instead of discussing the administration's accomplishments.

The allegations of a Russian connection began shortly after President Trump's upset victory in November, with Democrats questioning the legitimacy of the election results. Since then, the story has become the focus of major news organizations and prompted calls for investigations into Russian email hacking during the campaign.

Top Republican lawmakers, including Representative Devin Nunes, have also spoken out against the allegations, suggesting that Obama-era holdovers within the government are leaking information to damage the Trump administration. Nunes stated that major laws have been broken and that those responsible are illegally leaking information to the press.

The White House has also pushed back against the allegations, with President Trump himself denying any ties to Russia. Trump stated that he owns nothing in Russia, has no loans in Russia, and has no deals in Russia, calling the allegations "fake news."

The controversy surrounding the allegations has led to the resignation of Michael Flynn, Trump's former national security adviser, who was accused of misleading White House officials about his conversations with the Russian ambassador during the transition. The White House has maintained that Flynn's downfall was due to his failure to disclose his conversations with the Russian ambassador, which included recent U.S. sanctions against Russia, rather than any illegal or improper conduct.

In conclusion, the White House Chief of Staff has denied allegations of a Russian connection, calling them "complete garbage" and emphasizing that the media is focused on the wrong issues. The controversy surrounding the allegations has led to the resignation of Michael Flynn and has sparked a heated debate about the role of Obama-era holdovers within the government.

Title: Democrats Face Challenges in Battleground States Ahead of 2020 Election

The Democratic Party is facing concerns about its prospects in the 2020 presidential election, with some polls suggesting that the party may struggle to win over key swing states. However, experts caution that there is still a year to go before the election and that the party can still develop a convincing strategy to win over voters.

According to a recent poll, the Democratic candidate, whoever it may be, needs to develop a plan to win over voters in battleground states that Trump carried in 2018. This may involve paying attention to working-class white voters, who are not necessarily opposed to progressive policy proposals such as raising taxes on the rich, tackling political corruption, and providing universal day care and healthcare.

The poll also suggests that the Democratic Party can still support ambitious progressive ideas without alienating voters. In 2018, the party won by running a populist campaign focused on reducing healthcare costs and helping ordinary families. The candidates avoided supporting unpopular policies like mandatory Medicare and border decriminalization, and still managed to win.

However, some experts warn that the party may be making a mistake by ignoring the lessons of 2018. They argue that the party can still support progressive ideas without running afoul of popular opinion, but they also need to signal that they care about winning over voters who do not consider themselves very liberal.

The article also notes that Senator Elizabeth Warren's popularity has given her a head start with moderate and conservative Democrats, but it is harder for newer moderate Democrats to build a national constituency. The article concludes that the party should be concerned about its position a year before the election, but that new events, such as a recession or another scandal, could still erode Trump's base.

Overall, the article suggests that the Democratic Party faces challenges in the 2020 election, but that there is still time to develop a convincing strategy to win over voters.

Title: Trump's Abuse of Power and Corruption: A Pattern of Behavior

The article highlights several instances of President Trump's alleged abuse of power and corruption, which, if left unchecked, could have significant consequences for the country. The first instance mentioned is Trump's attempt to pressure the Ukrainian government to investigate his political opponents, including the Bidens. This behavior is reminiscent of Richard Nixon's efforts to use government agencies to target his political opponents, as detailed in the second impeachment article against him.

Trump has a history of calling for investigations against his political opponents, both publicly and privately. For example, he pressured then-Attorney General Jeff Sessions to investigate Hillary Clinton, saying he would be a "hero" if he did so. This behavior has violated the constitutional rights of American citizens and undermined the credibility of the judicial system.

The article also highlights Trump's alleged violation of the Constitution's emoluments clause, which prohibits the president from profiting from their office. Trump owns hotels, which have hosted politicians, lobbyists, and foreigners who have enriched him and sought to curry favor with him. For example, Attorney General William Barr paid for a 200-person holiday party at Trump's hotel in downtown Washington.

The Democratic-controlled House has been criticized for not doing a better job of addressing these issues, with some arguing that they have not conducted adequate oversight hearings. The article also notes that Trump's $280,000 in undisclosed hush-money payments during the 2016 campaign may have had a significant impact on the election outcome, which was decided by fewer than 80,000 votes across three swing states.

Finally, the article highlights Trump's encouragement of people to break the law or impede investigations with promises of future pardons. This behavior is a departure from the president's usual authority to issue pardons, which are typically used to correct past injustices or show mercy.

Overall, the article presents a pattern of behavior that raises concerns about Trump's commitment to the rule of law and his willingness to use his office for personal gain.

Title: Gov. Bobby Jindal Urges Republicans to Shift Focus, Compete for Every Vote

Gov. Bobby Jindal, a potential 2016 presidential candidate, addressed the Republican National Committee's Winter Meeting, urging his party to rethink its approach and compete for every vote. Jindal emphasized the need for Republicans to move beyond their focus on government bookkeeping and instead showcase the benefits of free-market policies.

In his remarks, Jindal criticized Republicans for being too focused on government spending and not doing enough to appeal to voters. He also took aim at comments made by former Republican presidential nominee Mitt Romney, saying that Republicans must "stop insulting the intelligence of voters" and "stop looking backward."

Jindal highlighted the need for Republicans to treat all people as individuals, rather than as members of special interest groups, and to reject the notion that demography determines voter behavior. He also criticized the economic stimulus programs of the Obama administration, citing the example of Solyndra.

Jindal's remarks positioned him as a forward-looking voice among Republicans, and his comments on minority outreach align with the goals of the Republican National Committee's "Growth and Opportunity Project." The project aims to identify winning political strategies for the future, particularly in the area of minority outreach.

Jindal's speech was laced with criticism of Democrats, but he also acknowledged the need for Republicans to shift their focus and compete for every vote. He emphasized that Republicans must move beyond a notion of "if we can just put together a spreadsheet and a power point and a TV ad, all will be well" and instead demonstrate that they like and respect voters.

Jindal's remarks come as the Republican Party prepares for its next election cycle, with RNC Chairman Reince Priebus up for re-election on Friday.

Title: Chicago Loses Another Second Amendment Case Over Gun Range Restrictions

The city of Chicago has suffered another defeat in its ongoing battle to restrict Second Amendment rights, this time over its attempts to ban private gun ranges. The Seventh Circuit Court of Appeals ruled that the city's zoning provisions, which restricted gun ranges to manufacturing districts and prohibited them within 100 feet of another range or 500 feet of certain sensitive areas, were overly restrictive and violated the Second Amendment.

The city's efforts to restrict gun ranges date back to the 2010 Supreme Court decision in McDonald v. City of Chicago, which struck down the city's virtual ban on firearms. In response, the city passed a series of ordinances aimed at making it difficult for private gun ranges to operate. However, these efforts have been met with repeated legal challenges, with the city losing several cases in the Seventh Circuit Court of Appeals.

The latest case, Ezell v. City of Chicago, was brought by Rhonda Ezell, a Chicago resident, along with several other residents, the Second Amendment Foundation, and the Illinois Rifle Association. The court found that the city's zoning provisions were overly restrictive and failed to provide any valid reason for restricting gun ranges to manufacturing districts rather than commercial areas.

The court also rejected the city's claims that gun ranges posed a risk to public health and safety, citing a lack of evidence to support these claims. The city's attempts to justify the restrictions were deemed speculative and failed to provide any concrete evidence of harm.

The court's decision affirmed that the city has the right to regulate the construction and operation of firing ranges to address genuine risks to public health and safety, but the city failed to justify any of the "risks" it claimed to be addressing with the gun-range ordinance.

This latest loss may serve as a wake-up call for the city of Chicago to reevaluate its approach to Second Amendment rights. However, given its history of defiance since the original McDonald case, it remains to be seen whether the city will continue to challenge the Second Amendment or finally come into compliance with the law.

Title: Macron's European Ambitions Depend on Washington's Approval

The French President, Emmanuel Macron, is set to visit the United States, sparking a mix of hopes and anxieties. While some see him as a champion of liberal values, others view him as a threat to their worldviews. Macron's trip to Washington comes at a time when the global liberal order is facing challenges, and his meeting with US President Donald Trump is being closely watched.

Macron's European ambitions are centered on revitalizing the European Union and making France strong within it. He believes that his centrist approach can bring stability and unity to the continent. However, his plans face opposition from both the left and right, who see him as a threat to their ideologies.

Macron's visit to Washington is seen as an opportunity for him to raise his profile and gain credibility in Europe. He is aware that his presidency was made possible by the 1958 Gaullist constitution, which allows for the rise of an outsider. He believes that coming under attack from both left and right helps to secure his position in Europe.

The article notes that Macron's European plans are not without controversy, and his idea of pan-EU candidate lists has been rejected. However, he is likely to continue pushing for a European political aggiornamento, or revitalization. The deadline for his plans is the May 2019 European parliament elections.

Macron's trip to Washington is seen as a boon for the French president, as it allows him to navigate the complexities of the US presidency and potentially gain support for his European ambitions. However, the article notes that Macron's European plans depend not only on his domestic reform agenda but also on his ability to raise his profile in Washington and draw credibility from that in Europe.

Title: EPA Administrator Scott Pruitt to Welcome President Trump for Executive Order Rollback

The Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) Administrator Scott Pruitt is set to welcome President Donald Trump to the agency's headquarters on Tuesday. The visit will mark a significant step in Pruitt's efforts to roll back the Obama-era Clean Power Plan and other environmental regulations. The executive order is expected to review the Clean Power Plan and change Obama-era executive orders on climate change and carbon emissions regulations.

Pruitt believes that the EPA has strayed from its original mission and has been overstepping its authority. He plans to restore the agency's focus on tackling big environmental cleanup projects, such as the 1,300 hazardous "superfund sites" designated by the agency as priority areas for cleanup. Pruitt also aims to reduce regulatory uncertainty and boost economic growth by streamlining the permitting process.

The EPA administrator has been a vocal critic of the Obama administration's environmental policies, which he believes have hurt the energy industry and led to job losses. He has sued the agency 13 times as the Attorney General of Oklahoma, challenging many of the Obama-era rules.

Pruitt's philosophy is centered on the idea of "EPA originalism," which involves re-focusing the agency on its original authorities and reducing regulatory overreach. He believes that the agency should prioritize environmental cleanup projects and work with industries to create jobs and stimulate economic growth.

The executive order is expected to have significant implications for the environment and the economy. While some critics have expressed concerns about the potential impact on the environment, Pruitt believes that the agency can be both pro-growth and pro-environment.

Title: Putin Criticizes US Investigations, Sanctions, and Trump's Decision on Iran Deal

Russian President Vladimir Putin expressed frustration with the state of relations between Russia and the United States, citing ongoing investigations and sanctions as major obstacles to improved ties. Speaking at an economic forum in St. Petersburg, Putin stated that Russia is "hostage to this internal strife in the United States" and hopes that the situation will resolve itself, allowing for the development of Russian-American relations.

Putin also announced that he will step down from his post in 2024, adhering to the Russian constitution's ban on serving two consecutive presidential terms. However, this does not necessarily mean he will retire, as he has done so previously and returned to the presidency.

During the forum, Putin criticized the US sanctions against Russia, as well as President Trump's decision to withdraw from the international nuclear agreement with Iran. He questioned the justification for punishing Iran, as an international watchdog agency has confirmed that Tehran was complying with the agreement. Putin also expressed concerns about the lack of stability and trust in international relations, citing the frequent revision of agreements and the use of sanctions as a tool.

The Russian president also took aim at the West's sanctions against Russia over its annexation of Crimea from Ukraine and the US sanctions imposed in response to Russian interference in the 2016 US elections. Putin described the situation as "chaotic" and noted that the "sanctions baton" is being used more often in the world, not just against Russia.

In a conversation with French President Emmanuel Macron, Putin offered to help protect Europe if its dispute with the US over Iran widens. Macron responded that France and its allies can stand on their own, but Putin's offer was seen as a gesture of goodwill.

Title: US Surpasses 3 Million Coronavirus Infections as Virus Continues to Surge Across the Country

The United States has reached a grim milestone, surpassing 3 million coronavirus infections, with data from the John Hopkins University Coronavirus Resource Center showing 3,009,611 cases at midday on Wednesday. This marks a significant increase from the previous day, with the country recording 60,000 new cases on Tuesday, shattering previous records. California and Texas both reported over 10,000 new cases in a single day, while Arizona, Florida, and South Carolina led the world in new cases over the last seven days, according to New York Times data.

Hospitals in Florida have run out of beds in their intensive care units, with Governor Ron DeSantis continuing to downplay the situation and refusing to release critical information about hospitalizations. Experts had previously predicted a summer lull in infections, but that never materialized. Many states, facing pressure from business leaders and the White House, rushed to reopen without fully anticipating the impact on new infections.

The White House coronavirus task force coordinator, Deborah Birx, stated that states ignored guidelines put in place by federal and local public health officials and "stepped on the gas" while reopening, causing this new surge. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention recently released guidance for safely reopening schools, but President Trump expressed his displeasure with the guidelines, saying they were too burdensome and "expensive," and indicated he would be meeting with the agency to change them.

Testing capacity is being strained in states with the largest number of new infections, and supply chain issues that plagued the country early in the pandemic have resurfaced. While Trump and other administration officials have highlighted a declining fatality rate as a sign of progress, Dr. Anthony Fauci, the nation's leading infectious disease expert, warned against focusing on this statistic alone, stating that it is a "false narrative." Deaths are a lagging indicator in an outbreak, and will rise as people generally don't die until weeks after they become sick. Many of the newly infected have been young people, who generally tend to be healthier, but Fauci emphasized that it's crucial not to get complacent and that the virus can still cause serious illness.

Title: Reliance Industries Launches Online Shopping Portal, JioMart, to Take on Amazon in India

Reliance Industries Ltd. has launched its online shopping portal, JioMart, as part of its efforts to establish a digital platform and compete with e-commerce giant Amazon.com Inc. in India. The portal, available to select customers who pre-register, promises over 50,000 grocery products, free home delivery, and a return policy with no questions asked. Currently, the pilot site is only available in three neighborhoods surrounding Mumbai.

JioMart is part of Reliance Industries' pivot towards newer businesses, with the company controlled by Asia's richest man, Mukesh Ambani, aiming to contribute 50% of its earnings from these ventures in a few years. The company has spent billions of dollars on small acquisitions to achieve this goal.

Ambani's previous project, Reliance Jio Infocomm Ltd., the group's wireless carrier, has already shown signs of success, with over 350 million users and India's No. 1 operator. The company entered the market with free calls and cheap data, forcing some incumbents to exit or merge with rivals.

Ambani aims to replicate this success in online retail, seeking to "completely transform" India's unorganized retail market, which accounts for 90% of the nation's industry. The tycoon believes that a tech-enabled partnership will link producers, traders, small merchants, consumer brands, and consumers.

Reliance Industries has unveiled a plan to create a $24 billion digital-services holding firm and has vowed to list its new businesses within five years. The plan has led to a surge in the company's stock price, with investors adding more than $15 billion to Ambani's wealth, taking his net worth to almost $60 billion.

Title: Number of Uninsured Americans Decreases by 25 Percent, According to Recent Estimates

The number of Americans without health insurance has decreased by approximately 25 percent this year, with estimates suggesting around 8-11 million people remaining uninsured. This decline is attributed to the Affordable Care Act (ACA), which aimed to reduce the number of uninsured Americans. According to private sector surveys and a government report, the ACA has made significant progress towards achieving this goal.

The majority of those who have gained insurance coverage have signed up for Medicaid, particularly in states that have expanded the program to low-income residents. The remaining individuals have enrolled in private health plans through the new state insurance marketplaces. Additionally, around 3-4 million people, mostly young adults, became newly insured through provisions of the law that took effect before this year.

The uninsured rate has dropped from 18 percent in mid-2013 to 13.4 percent by the end of May, according to the Gallup-Healthways Well-Being Index. This decline is mirrored by other polls, including a quarterly telephone poll by the Commonwealth Fund and a government survey by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

While the reduction in the uninsured rate is a significant achievement, it is still early to determine the long-term impact of the ACA. The Congressional Budget Office estimates that around 26 million people will gain insurance coverage through the law, with the nation currently at least a third of the way towards this target.

The success of the ACA also depends on the perspective. Some critics argue that the law has not gone far enough in reducing the number of uninsured, while others worry that some people may have signed up for coverage only to cycle out of it quickly due to premium payments or limited provider networks.
