Over the next four years, the law is projected to expand coverage to millions more Americans, but it is unlikely to eliminate the problem of the uninsured entirely.

Title: Journalist Tom Brokaw Faces Backlash for Comments on Assimilation

Article:

Journalist Tom Brokaw, a renowned figure in the television news industry, has faced intense criticism for his recent comments on assimilation during an appearance on Meet the Press. Brokaw, who is known for his work chronicling the "Greatest Generation" of Americans who fought in World War II, suggested that Hispanics should work harder at assimilation and ensure their children learn to speak English.

The comments sparked a swift and furious response from various individuals and organizations, with some labeling them as "racist" and "xenophobic." Aura Bogado, an investigative immigration reporter, described Brokaw's comments as "classic white supremacist talking points" and "a deeply racist rant on national television." Julio Ricardo Varela, founder of LatinoRebels.com, called the comments a "punch in the gut" and "xenophobia in action."

Liberal commentator Maria Cardona also criticized Brokaw, stating that his comments were "a little out of touch" and that "Latinos absolutely assimilate." However, Cardona's statement was met with skepticism, as many argue that assimilation is not a realistic expectation for many Hispanic individuals.

Brokaw later apologized for his remarks, stating that they were "offensive to many" and "never intended to disparage any segment of our rich, diverse society." He also apologized to fellow panelist Yamiche Alcindor, who had expressed disagreement with his views.

The controversy surrounding Brokaw's comments highlights the ongoing debate about assimilation and language in the United States. While some argue that assimilation is essential for social and economic advancement, others believe that it is unrealistic and ignores the cultural diversity of the country.

According to the Census Bureau, the number of households that speak a language other than English at home has risen steadily over the last three decades, reaching 22% in 2017. The majority of these households are concentrated in areas near the southern border and a few large northern cities. However, further studies have shown that many individuals who speak another language at home do not speak English well or at all, with nearly half found to have functional illiteracy.

The debate surrounding Brokaw's comments serves as a reminder of the complex and multifaceted nature of language and assimilation in the United States. While some may view assimilation as a necessary step towards social and economic advancement, others see it as a threat to cultural diversity and individual identity.

Title: Boehner Faces Challenges in Steering Republicans Toward Year-End Tax Deal

Article:

House Speaker John Boehner will need to navigate reluctant Republicans toward a year-end deal on tax reform, but first, he must address two crucial questions: what is the revenue target and what standard of progressivity will govern the revised code? The 1980s tax reform experience serves as a reminder that lowering rates is an understandable goal, but setting rates in advance can put the cart before the horse.

According to David Brockway, former counsel to the Joint Tax Committee, lawmakers must prioritize meeting their revenue target and maintaining an agreed-upon standard of how the tax burden is distributed across different income groups. The same pressures will be present in any reform effort now.

After the recent elections, it is unclear whether Boehner expects President Obama to accept a reform framework that does not improve on the equities of the current code. The speaker's office has not yet committed to a specific aggregate revenue target or agreed to keep current Bush-era rates in place while lawmakers write a reform package.

The White House meeting on Friday offers a fresh start, but Obama will need to show more give on the spending side of the ledger to bring Republicans on board. The president has expressed confidence in his ability to get his way, but the real test of strength lies in his willingness to give up something of his own to bring Republicans toward him.

The White House has a history of patronizing Congress, but two potential options to change the tone could be reforms in the food stamp program and action on a long-discussed change in the inflation index used to adjust government benefits and tax brackets. While these changes may be unpopular with some, they could bring Republicans and Democrats together. The Center on Budget and Policy Priorities has developed a model for a new CPI that eases the impact on the most elderly Social Security recipients and still saves about $150 billion over 10 years.

Title: California Launches $75 Million Program to Provide $500 Cash Payments to Unauthorized Immigrants

California has launched a $75 million program to provide $500 cash payments to unauthorized immigrants who have been shut out of traditional government aid programs due to their immigration status. The program, which will be conducted over the phone to reduce in-person contacts, is expected to benefit 150,000 people, with a maximum award per household of $1,000.

The program is aimed at supporting unauthorized immigrants who are jobless as a result of the pandemic and do not qualify for unemployment programs or stimulus checks. Philanthropic organizations are also donating $50 million to support the effort, which will be distributed by 12 nonprofit organizations.

California Governor Gavin Newsom stated, "California is the most diverse state in the nation. Our diversity makes us stronger and more resilient. Every Californian, including our undocumented neighbors and friends, should know that California is here to support them during this crisis. We are all in this together."

The program is expected to benefit over 2 million unauthorized immigrants who live in California, making up around 9% of the state's labor force. Many of these immigrants work in low-wage jobs in hotels and restaurants that have been severely impacted by the pandemic.

The program is part of a broader effort to provide financial relief to those affected by the pandemic. The House Democrats recently approved a $3 trillion coronavirus spending package, which includes a provision allowing unauthorized immigrants to qualify for a direct federal payment with their Taxpayer Identification Numbers. However, the provision was met with opposition from Republicans, who declared the Heroes Act "dead on arrival" in the Senate.

The program is a significant step towards providing financial support to unauthorized immigrants who have been disproportionately affected by the pandemic. With over 11 million unauthorized immigrants living in the US, the program aims to provide a lifeline to those who need it most.

Title: White House Calls on Republicans to Support Gun Control Measures, Citing Broad Public Support

The Obama administration has urged Republicans to back the president's plan for gun control, emphasizing that 90% of Americans support expanding background checks on citizens who purchase guns. In recent interviews on Sunday morning news programs, Dan Pfeiffer, a senior White House adviser, highlighted the widespread public support for the proposal and pressed Republicans to get on board with what he called "common-sense measures."

Pfeiffer warned that a potential Republican filibuster could block significant and meaningful gun-reform legislation, stating that it would require Republicans not to filibuster for the bill to pass. Senator John McCain, an Arizona Republican, expressed similar sentiments, saying that his party should not filibuster gun-control debates, as the goal is to keep guns out of the hands of criminals and the mentally ill.

In contrast, former Representative Asa Hutchinson, now the director of the National Rifle Association's National School Shield Task Force, believes that armed guards in schools would be an effective way to protect teachers and students. However, Pfeiffer criticized this approach, arguing that it would only exacerbate the situation and that more guns would not make schools safer.

The debate highlights the ongoing discussion around gun control and school safety, with the White House emphasizing the need for "common-sense measures" supported by the majority of Americans, while some Republicans argue that armed guards and other measures are necessary to protect children.

Title: Scotland Votes on Independence: A Historic Decision Looms

Scotland is holding a historic referendum today, with voters deciding whether to end its 300-year union with Great Britain and become an independent country. The outcome is expected to have a lasting impact, regardless of the result. With 4,285,323 people registered to vote, a historically high turnout is anticipated.

The options are simple: "yes" or "no" to the question "Should Scotland be an independent country?" Public opinion polls suggest the vote could be extremely close, with Scotland evenly split on the issue.

British Prime Minister David Cameron made a final emotional appeal to keep the United Kingdom intact, warning that a vote for independence would precipitate a "painful divorce." He acknowledged the unpopularity of his conservative government among more liberal-minded Scots, saying, "If you don't like me – I won't be here forever. But if you leave the U.K., that will be forever."

President Obama also weighed in on the referendum, urging the United Kingdom to remain "strong, robust, and united." Former President Bill Clinton also urged a "no" vote.

Alex Salmond, the leader of the campaign for independence, cast his ballot in his home village of Aberdeenshire, saying, "We're in the hands of the people of Scotland, and there's no safer place to be than in the hands of the Scottish people."

The outcome of the vote is also being closely watched in other independence-minded regions of the world, including Quebec, Catalonia, and Kashmir.

Title: Whistleblower System Under Scrutiny as Experts Hope Justice Department Inquiry Brings Real Change

The whistleblower system in the United States is under scrutiny, with experts calling for wholesale reform to ensure that there are real protections in place for those who come forward with concerns about government wrongdoing. The debate has been reignited by a powerful new insider account from John Crane, a former supervisor of the whistleblower-protection unit of the Pentagon inspector general.

Crane's story, told in Mark Hertsgaard's book "Bravehearts: Whistle-Blowing in the Age of Snowden," suggests that the inspector general's office, meant to aid whistleblowing, can put whistleblowers in danger. He argues that the system failed Thomas Drake, an NSA employee who became concerned about warrantless surveillance after 9/11 and took his concerns to the inspector-general's office. Crane's suspicion is that instead of protecting Drake, his office's identity was passed to the Justice Department.

The stakes for an inquiry at the US Justice Department, set to launch on June 1, are high. Will it follow Snowden's model or Drake's? Many experts believe that the current system is broken and that whistleblowers need to have confidence that they can step forward without facing reprisal.

Crane, who lost his career for defending Drake, wants to make future Snowdens feel protected internally. He hopes that the Justice Department inquiry will ultimately deter future whistleblowers from going outside the system and convince them that they can work within the system.

However, some experts are skeptical that the inquiry will bring about the necessary reforms. Jesselyn Radack, a prominent whistleblower lawyer who represented Crane, believes that the inquiry may only rearrange deck chairs on the Titanic, but the system will remain broken.

On the other hand, Tom Devine, an attorney with the Government Accountability Project, believes that the inquiry is a step necessary to save a broken whistleblower system. The inquiry will be a major step in determining whether non-public whistleblowing will be a viable or robust option.

The article highlights the complexities of the whistleblower system and the need for real protections for those who come forward with concerns about government wrongdoing. The inquiry will be a crucial test of whether the system can be reformed to ensure that whistleblowers are protected and that those who come forward can do so without facing reprisal.

Title: FBI Officials Decline to Comment on Investigation into Trump-Russia Links

The FBI has declined to comment on the investigation into alleged connections between some of Donald Trump's aides and Moscow, which led to the opening of a broad investigation into possible links between the Russian government and the Republican presidential candidate. Intelligence officials have stated that Trump himself has not become a target, and no evidence has emerged linking him or anyone else in his business or political circle directly to Russia's election operations.

The investigation has focused on Paul Manafort, Trump's campaign chairman for much of the year, who has had extensive business ties in Russia and other former Soviet states, particularly Ukraine. The focus has been on Manafort's ties with Ukraine's ousted president, Viktor F. Yanukovych, and whether he had declared the income in the United States, rather than any Russian influence over Trump's campaign.

In classified sessions in August and September, intelligence officials briefed congressional leaders on the possibility of financial ties between Russians and people connected to Trump. They focused on what cyberexperts said appeared to be a mysterious computer back channel between the Trump Organization and Alfa Bank, one of Russia's biggest banks, whose owners have longstanding ties to President Vladimir Putin.

FBI officials spent weeks examining computer data showing an odd stream of activity to a Trump Organization server and Alfa Bank. Computer logs obtained by The New York Times show that two servers at Alfa Bank sent more than 2,700 "look-up" messages to a Trump-connected server beginning in the spring. However, the FBI ultimately concluded that there could be an innocuous explanation, such as a marketing email or spam, for the computer contacts.

The most serious part of the FBI's investigation has focused on the computer hacks that the Obama administration now formally blames on Russia. The investigation also involves numerous officials from intelligence agencies. Investigators have become increasingly confident, based on the evidence they have uncovered, that Russia's direct goal is not to support the election of Trump, as many Democrats have asserted, but rather to disrupt the integrity of the political system and undermine America's standing in the world more broadly.

The hacking, they said, reflected an intensification of spy-versus-spy operations that never entirely abated after the Cold War but have become more aggressive in recent years as relations with Putin's Russia have soured.

Title: Martin McGuinness, Former First Minister of Northern Ireland, Dies

Article:

Martin McGuinness, the former first minister of Northern Ireland and a prominent commander of the Irish Republican Army (IRA), has passed away. Although his death was not unexpected, given his decision to step down as first minister in January due to health reasons, it still marks the end of an era for the country.

McGuinness's life was marked by a complex and tumultuous journey from being a commander of the IRA to becoming a statesman. As a commander, he was involved in the Irish Republican Army's armed struggle against British rule in Northern Ireland. However, he later became a key figure in the peace process, serving as the deputy first minister of Northern Ireland and working alongside unionist leaders to bring about a power-sharing government.

McGuinness's IRA credentials and the violence they entailed allowed him to become a respected statesman in the latter half of his life. He was known for his ability to work with his former enemies, including unionist leader Ian Paisley, with whom he developed a close working relationship. The two were often referred to as the "Chuckle Brothers" due to their apparent bonhomie.

Despite his IRA past, McGuinness was widely respected for his role in the peace process and his ability to bring about a power-sharing government in Northern Ireland. He was also known for his willingness to admit his membership in the IRA, which set him apart from his Sinn Féin leader Gerry Adams, who has never publicly acknowledged his involvement with the organization.

McGuinness's legacy is complex and multifaceted, with some viewing him as a hero who played a key role in bringing about peace in Northern Ireland, while others see him as a former terrorist who was involved in violence and bloodshed. Regardless, his journey from gunman to statesman is a testament to the power of politics and the ability to change one's views and actions over time.

**Senate Approves Loretta Lynch as Attorney General, Defeating Early Filibuster Attempt**

The United States Senate is poised to confirm Loretta Lynch as the new Attorney General, defeating an early filibuster attempt on Thursday morning. Lynch, a federal prosecutor from New York, would become the first black woman to hold the top law enforcement post. She cleared the filibuster on a 66-34 vote, with Republican opposition primarily focused on President Obama's policies rather than Lynch's qualifications.

Lynch's nomination was delayed due to disagreements over abortion-funding provisions in a bill aimed at combating human trafficking. An agreement was reached this week, setting the stage for the final vote. Democrats have criticized the delays as a "black mark" for Republicans, accusing them of thwarting civil rights history.

Lynch's opponents, primarily Republicans, expressed concerns about her defense of President Obama's executive actions, particularly on immigration. Senator John Cornyn, a Texas Republican, stated that Lynch seemed to "embrace the president's illegal executive action without regard to the fact that it is a constitutional overreach."

However, Democrats argued that opposing Lynch because she defended the president was a troubling precedent to set. Senator Claire McCaskill, a Missouri Democrat, said, "This defies common sense. You must vote against a nominee for the Cabinet of the duly elected president of the United States because she agrees with the duly elected president of the United States?"

Lynch's qualifications were not questioned, and she has headed some of the Justice Department's highest-profile cases, including terrorism prosecutions and the case against former Representative Michael Grimm. Her opponents primarily focused on her defense of President Obama's policies and her willingness to defend his executive actions.

In contrast, Sally Yates, a white prosecutor from Georgia, was confirmed as Deputy Attorney General on an 18-2 vote earlier on Thursday. Yates received strong support from Georgia's two Republican senators and defended the president's policies while emphasizing the Justice Department's role as an independent constitutional authority.

The confirmation of Loretta Lynch as Attorney General is seen as a major milestone for civil rights, with Democrats hailing it as a triumph for the American people.

**Senate Republicans Release Revised Healthcare Bill**

Senate Republicans have released a revised version of their plan to replace the Affordable Care Act (ACA), also known as Obamacare. The revised bill aims to address concerns from moderates and conservatives, but it remains unclear whether it will be enough to win over wavering Republican senators.

The revised bill keeps taxes imposed by the ACA on investment income and high earners, and eliminates the limit on how much of an executive's pay an insurance company can write off as a corporate tax deduction. It also repeals other ACA taxes, including those on tanning beds, sectors of the health care industry, and high-cost employer-provided insurance plans.

The bill would still allow people to buy catastrophic plans, including those who qualify for subsidies. However, these plans have low premiums but high deductibles and limited benefits. The bill would also increase funding to states for addiction services, including $45 billion, up from the initial $2 billion.

The revised bill would still sunset cost-sharing subsidies for low- and middle-income people who purchase insurance on an exchange, but it includes an additional $70 billion for states to reduce insurance costs in other ways. States would have to match the funds.

The bill would also eliminate the ACA's requirement that insurers spend a specific amount of premiums on benefits, instead of on profits, administration, and other expenses. It would also increase the amount older customers can be charged for insurance, from three times to five times what younger customers pay.

The revised bill does not change the ACA's rule that dependent children can stay on a parent's plan until age 26. However, it would phase out enhanced federal funding for low-income adults who gained eligibility through the ACA, ending after 2024.

The bill would also scale back federal support for traditional Medicaid, which would require states to find new funding or cut the program through restricting enrollment, curbing benefits, reducing payments to healthcare providers, or finding efficiencies.

The revised bill includes changes to the way hospitals are paid by the federal government to help cover the bills of the uninsured, which are expected to increase. It also increases funding for addiction services and includes an exception for abortions performed to save the life of the mother or to end a pregnancy that resulted from rape or incest.

The bill would also continue to block Planned Parenthood from receiving Medicaid funding for a year, which GOP Sens. Susan Collins of Maine and Lisa Murkowski of Alaska oppose.

Title: Justin Amash's Stance on Trump's Impeachable Conduct Sparks Debate

Article:

Justin Amash, a five-term Michigan congressman, has sparked a heated debate by stating that President Donald Trump is guilty of "impeachable conduct." Amash's assertion has been met with both praise and criticism from his colleagues, with some arguing that the House of Representatives' definition of impeachable conduct is unclear.

The article highlights that the House impeached President Bill Clinton for lying under oath about oral sex, and Amash believes that the conduct described in Special Counsel Robert Mueller's report is more troubling and consequential. The report details Trump's attempts to interfere with the investigation into Russian efforts to influence the 2016 presidential election, including his attempts to stop the FBI investigation, repeatedly demanding Mueller's removal, and discouraging witnesses from cooperating.

The article notes that Mueller's report makes a strong case that Trump's actions meet the three elements of obstruction: an obstructive act, a nexus to an official proceeding, and a corrupt intent. Trump's attempts to stop the FBI investigation, repeatedly demand Mueller's removal, and discourage witnesses from cooperating arguably meet these criteria.

The article also mentions that Trump's defenders and some critics seem determined to obscure the definition of impeachable conduct, with some arguing that the president's actions do not rise to the level of obstruction of justice. However, the article argues that even if Trump's actions do not meet the legal definition of obstruction, they still constitute an abuse of power that betrays the public trust.

The article concludes that while the political calculation may be against impeachment, members of both parties may come to regret the signal they are sending about the sort of presidential behavior Congress is willing to tolerate.

Title: Senate Votes to Overcome Filibuster, Paving the Way for Brett Kavanaugh's Confirmation Vote

The United States Senate voted 51-49 to overcome a Democratic-led filibuster, bringing Supreme Court nominee Brett Kavanaugh one step closer to confirmation. The vote, which was marked by deep divisions and historic partisan rancor, saw one defection from each party, canceling each other out and giving the judge enough votes to clear the procedural hurdle.

The confirmation process has been marred by controversy, with Democrats citing concerns over Judge Kavanaugh's conservative leanings and the recent sexual misconduct allegations against him. Judge Kavanaugh has denied the allegations, which relate to decades-old high school and college parties.

Despite the opposition, Republicans hailed the vote as a chance to send a message to the public at a time of deep divisions. "We know the Senate is better than this. We know the nation deserves better than this," said Majority Leader Mitch McConnell.

The vote was unclear until the end, with four members publicly undecided: GOP Sens. Susan Collins, Jeff Flake, Lisa Murkowski, and Democratic Sen. Joe Manchin. Ms. Murkowski joined Democrats in their filibuster, but the other three voted to end debate and advance to a final vote.

A final confirmation vote is now looming, with some potential hiccups still to come. One Republican senator plans to attend his daughter's wedding Saturday, which could complicate the timing of the vote. Sen. Jeff Merkley is also pursuing a long-shot lawsuit to ask a judge to intervene and order the release of more documents from Judge Kavanaugh's past, which could spur a new delay in confirmation.

The confirmation process has been marked by intense political drama, with Democrats accusing Republicans of trying to push Judge Kavanaugh through too quickly and Republicans accusing Democrats of trying to delay the process. The outcome of the vote remains uncertain, with a final confirmation vote still pending.

Title: US Loses Leverage in Syria Chemical Weapons Negotiations, Says Rep. Mike Rogers

The United States has lost all its leverage in negotiations over chemical weapons in Syria, according to Republican Rep. Mike Rogers, chairman of the House Intelligence Committee. Rogers made the statement on CNN's "State of the Union" on Sunday, arguing that if Congress had moved more quickly to authorize a strike against Syria, the situation would be more favorable for the US.

Rogers faulted President Barack Obama for not adequately explaining why an attack against Syria would be in the US' security interests, which allowed Russian President Vladimir Putin to fill the void and gain the upper hand. He also warned that the deal reached on Saturday, which allows Syria to hand over control of its chemical weapons, does not include a threat of military force if Syria fails to comply.

On the other hand, Democratic Rep. Adam Schiff of California was more optimistic about the diplomatic deal, calling it a "very positive step." Schiff acknowledged that it has been an "ugly" process and will be "tough" to ensure Syria follows through, but believes it is the "best pathway" seen in the last couple of years.

President Obama also weighed in on the situation, saying he is not concerned with criticism of his handling of the Syria situation, as Washington tends to judge based on style rather than substance. He emphasized the importance of getting the policy right, rather than focusing on style points.

The deal reached between the US and Russia allows Syria to hand over control of its chemical weapons, but does not include a threat of military force if Syria fails to comply.

Title: Obama's Economic Legacy: A Strong Foundation for Future Growth

The article highlights the significant progress made in the US economy under President Barack Obama's administration, which has led to a strong job market and wage growth. The author emphasizes that this success is a testament to the effectiveness of Obama's policies, including the stimulus package, progressive taxation, consumer and environmental protection, and increased access to healthcare. The article also notes that the economy has recovered quickly and strongly from the 2008 financial crisis, outperforming many other developed countries.

The author argues that it is essential to recognize the role of Obama's policies in achieving this success and not attribute it to Republican policies or Donald Trump's presidency. They also point out that Hillary Clinton's proposals for increased infrastructure spending, which Trump has since adopted as his own, were blocked by Congressional Republicans, highlighting the partisan divide.

The article also touches on the 2016 presidential election, where Clinton lost the electoral college vote despite receiving more popular votes. The author suggests that Clinton's campaign focused too much on Trump's bigotry and not enough on the economy and her plans to help those left behind, which may have cost her the election. They also note that research shows that reminding white voters of their whiteness can increase their support for Republican candidates.

The article concludes by emphasizing the importance of the economy in future elections and the need for Democrats to focus on the economy and highlight their record of creating a strong job market and wage growth. The author warns that if Trump can take credit for Obama's accomplishments, he may win a second term.

Title: Obama and Romney Spar Over Troops in Iraq

The 2012 presidential debate between President Barack Obama and his Republican challenger, Mitt Romney, saw the two candidates engage in a heated discussion over the US military presence in Iraq. The topic remains a contentious issue, with both sides presenting their views on the matter.

Obama, who opposed the 2003 invasion of Iraq, emphasized that his administration's efforts to extend a US training mission in the country were unsuccessful due to the Iraqi government's refusal to grant legal immunity to US troops. He pointed out that his administration had attempted to negotiate a Status of Forces Agreement, which would have allowed for a smaller US presence in Iraq, but ultimately failed to secure an agreement.

Romney, who supported the 2003 invasion, criticized the Obama administration's handling of the situation, stating that they should have kept a larger number of troops in Iraq to help train and advise the Iraqi military. He claimed that the abrupt withdrawal of US troops has led to the erosion of the gains made in the country.

The debate highlights the differing views on the US military presence in Iraq, with Obama emphasizing the need for a responsible and gradual drawdown, while Romney believes that a larger force should have been maintained. The debate also underscores the complexities of the situation, with both sides presenting valid points and criticisms.

It is worth noting that the Status of Forces Agreement signed between the US and Iraq in 2008 called for US troops to withdraw from Iraqi cities by 2009 and be out of the country entirely by the end of 2011. The Obama administration's efforts to extend the US training mission in Iraq were unsuccessful due to the Iraqi government's refusal to grant legal immunity to US troops.

Title: Sioux Tribes in South Dakota Refuse to Remove Coronavirus Checkpoints, Defying Governor's Demands

The Oglala Sioux and Cheyenne River Sioux tribes in South Dakota are refusing to remove coronavirus checkpoints they set up on roads passing through their land, despite a letter from Governor Kristi Noem demanding their removal. The governor claims the checkpoints are illegal, but the tribes argue they are necessary to prevent the virus from entering their reservations and overwhelming their limited healthcare facilities.

The tribes have implemented strict measures to control the spread of the virus, including requiring travelers to complete a health questionnaire and only allowing entry for essential business if they have not traveled from a Covid-19 hotspot. The Cheyenne River Sioux Tribe's chairman, Harold Frazier, stated that the tribe will not apologize for being an "island of safety in a sea of uncertainty and death."

The tribes argue that their limited healthcare facilities would be unable to cope with an outbreak, with the nearest critical care facilities three hours away. The Cheyenne River Sioux Tribe operates an eight-bed facility on the reservation, with no intensive care unit for the 12,000 people who live there.

Governor Noem has threatened to take the tribes to federal court if they do not comply with her demands. However, the tribes are standing firm, citing the need to protect their people and communities. The Oglala Sioux President, Julian Bear Runner, stated that the governor's decision "threatened the sovereign interest of the Oglala people."

The situation highlights the challenges faced by Native American communities in the US, who have been disproportionately affected by the pandemic. As of Sunday, there were 198 cases of Covid-19 among Native Americans in South Dakota, with the state having more than 3,500 confirmed cases and at least 34 deaths.

Title: Supreme Court to Review Constitutionality of Independent Payment Advisory Board in Obamacare

The Independent Payment Advisory Board (IPAB), established by the Affordable Care Act (Obamacare), has been criticized for its broad authority to control Medicare costs and its lack of accountability. A new petition will be filed with the Supreme Court on Wednesday, seeking a review of the IPAB's constitutionality. The petition argues that the IPAB's powers are an unprecedented consolidation of government authority and violate the Constitution's separation of powers.

The IPAB is responsible for controlling Medicare costs, but its methods are not clearly defined. The law gives the IPAB broad authority to implement price controls, levy taxes, and take any action deemed "related to the Medicare program." The IPAB is also immune from control by the president, Congress, and the courts, making it an unaccountable bureaucracy.

Proponents of the IPAB argue that it is necessary to insulate lawmakers from political pressure and allow for Medicare policy decisions to be made without fear of voter backlash. However, critics argue that this is a flawed approach, as it creates an unaccountable agency that can make decisions without transparency or oversight.

The Constitution's authors intended for public pressure to be a key feature of the government, serving as a check on power. However, the IPAB's lack of accountability and immunity from review by the courts raises concerns about the erosion of the Constitution's separation of powers.

The 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals has already dismissed a challenge to the IPAB's constitutionality, citing the lack of appointments to the board. However, the petition argues that the law's provision allowing the secretary of health and human services to exercise IPAB's powers alone, if the president fails to appoint anyone, only exacerbates the problem.

The petition urges the Supreme Court to take up the case and review the IPAB's constitutionality, citing the importance of maintaining the Constitution's separation of powers and ensuring accountability in government decision-making.

Title: Russian National Charged with Conspiring to Interfere in 2018 Midterm Elections

The FBI and Justice Department have charged a Russian national, Elena Alekseevna Khusyaynova, with conspiring to interfere in the 2018 midterm elections. According to the indictment, Khusyaynova, 44, was the chief accountant of "Project Lakhta," an effort funded by Russian oligarch Yevgeniy Viktorovich Prigozhin and two companies he controls, Concord Management and Consulting LLC, and Concord Catering.

The conspiracy allegedly involved a $35 million budget from 2014 to 2018, which covered spending on activists, social media advertising, and promoting news postings on social networks. The proposed operating budget for 2018 alone was over $10 million.

The indictment states that the conspiracy aimed to "sow discord in the U.S. political system and undermine faith in our democratic institutions." The conspiracy allegedly involved creating fake social media accounts and messaging groups, as well as promoting divisive issues and propaganda on social media.

The indictment also reveals that the conspiracy advised social media writers on how to write for U.S. audiences, suggesting that people of color who are LGBT are "less sophisticated" than those who are white. The guidance also recommended using infographics to target specific groups, such as LGBT and liberal allies.

The conspiracy also aimed to brand certain politicians as "old geezers" or "complete and absolute nobodies," as seen in messages about articles about John McCain and Paul Ryan.

President Trump has denied any involvement in the conspiracy, stating that it had nothing to do with his campaign. The nation's top law enforcement and intelligence agencies have issued a warning against ongoing campaigns by Russia, China, and other foreign actors to undermine confidence in democratic institutions and influence public sentiment and government policies.

The FBI and Justice Department have not found any evidence of a compromise or disruption of election infrastructure, but the indictment highlights the ongoing efforts to interfere in U.S. politics.

Title: Senate Democrats Urge Government Reopening, Criticize Trump's Immigration Remarks

Article:

Senator Bernie Sanders, an independent from Vermont, used a live-streamed YouTube response to criticize President Trump's recent remarks on immigration and the border wall, calling him a liar. Sanders listed several instances of what he deemed misstatements made by the president during his address. The senator emphasized that the country has more pressing issues to address, such as the lack of health insurance for millions of Americans, elderly people without retirement savings, and the specter of global climate change.

Sanders stated, "We don't need to create artificial crises. We have enough real crises." He also expressed his opposition to the government shutdown, which has affected various government agencies, including the Internal Revenue Service and the Agriculture Department.

Meanwhile, President Trump is planning a trip to the border in McAllen, Texas, on Thursday. Democrats plan to introduce a series of bills to reopen shuttered government agencies, including the IRS and the Agriculture Department, to allow for tax refunds and farmer support payments. The Treasury Department and the IRS will be the first to reopen on Thursday, followed by Agriculture and Interior Department programs, including national parks, on the same day. Transportation and housing programs will reopen on Friday.

Representative Steny H. Hoyer of Maryland, the majority leader, emphasized that the government shutdown is exacerbating problems rather than solving them. A group of Senate Democrats spent Tuesday evening taking turns on the Senate floor urging Majority Leader Mitch McConnell of Kentucky to bring up House-passed legislation to reopen the government. The group, led by Senators Tim Kaine of Virginia and Jeanne Shaheen of New Hampshire, aimed to highlight the harm caused by the shutdown on federal workers and those who rely on government programs.

Title: Bill Maher Apologizes for Using Racial Slur on HBO's Real Time

Bill Maher, the host of HBO's Real Time, offered an on-air apology on Friday for using a racial slur during an interview with Senator Ben Sasse, R-Neb. Maher acknowledged that the word he used has caused pain and apologized for his actions. He also invited Georgetown professor and political activist Michael E. Dyson to join him on the show to discuss the issue.

During the conversation, Maher expressed his regret and acknowledged that the word he used is offensive. He also stated that he is not excused from his actions simply because he did not intend to cause harm. Dyson agreed that the word is a "very bad thing" and that it has caused pain.

Later in the episode, hip-hop artist and actor Ice Cube joined the show and shared his thoughts on the matter. He noted that when he hears his peers use the word, it does not feel as harmful, but when a white person uses it, it is like a knife.

The controversy surrounding Maher's use of the racial slur did not stop there. Senator Al Franken, D-Minn., canceled his appearance on the show, citing that he did not want to be attacked for appearing on the show before it aired. Franken, who considers Maher a friend, expressed disappointment in his actions, stating that he should have known better.

HBO also issued a statement condemning Maher's use of the slur, calling it "inexcusable and tasteless." The network announced that it would edit the segment out of future airings of the episode.

Title: Research Suggests News Consumption Contributes to Racial and Political Polarization

Article:

A recent study published in the journal Cognition has shed light on the psychological mechanisms that drive people to categorize themselves into groups based on political views, race, gender, and age. The research suggests that these categorizations can lead to a deep-seated bias, making it difficult for people to consider alternative perspectives. This bias is perpetuated by the news media, which often reinforces existing stereotypes and divisions.

The study, conducted by David Pietraszewski and his team, found that people tend to categorize themselves into groups based on political views and race, with gender and age playing no significant role. The researchers also discovered that people are more likely to form groups based on political views than race, and that these groups are mutually exclusive.

John Tooby, a professor of anthropology at the University of California, Santa Barbara, notes that this phenomenon is not unique to race, but rather a natural human tendency to form coalitions. "Coalition is the real coin of the evolved mind, not race," he said.

However, the news media can exacerbate this tendency by perpetuating stereotypes and reinforcing existing biases. Temple Northup, an assistant professor at the University of New Hampshire's Jack J. Valenti School of Communication, conducted a study using the Implicit Association Test (IAT) to investigate the extent to which news media can influence people's implicit racial bias. The results showed that reading a newspaper about poor race relations or watching a newscast about foreign tension increased people's implicit bias on the IAT.

Pietraszewski suggests that consumers of news have a simple and effective way to avoid the traps of ugly selection biases: cooperation. By exercising empathy and looking beyond the surface-level differences, people can reduce racial discrimination and political polarization. "What is required is cooperation that cross-cuts the previous boundary, and the more the better," he said. "Reducing racial discrimination or political polarization will be no easier or harder than changing patterns of cooperation."

The study's findings highlight the importance of media literacy and the need for news organizations to prioritize neutrality and accuracy in their reporting. As Pietraszewski noted, "The quality of our thoughts is only as good as the information it's fed."

Title: Washington State Legalizes Marijuana Use, But Driving While Impaired Remains a Concern

Washington state has legalized the use of marijuana, but driving while impaired by the drug remains a complex issue. Unlike alcohol, there is no national legal limit for THC, the psychoactive ingredient in marijuana, and different states have varying policies on how to handle impaired driving. In Washington, possessing pot is now legal, but driving while high is not.

Studies have shown that marijuana can cause dizziness, slowed reaction time, and impaired coordination and judgment, making it a concern for road safety. Research in the Netherlands found that drivers who use marijuana are more likely to drift and swerve while driving. California Highway Patrol drug recognition expert Sgt. Tyler Eccles noted that marijuana users may have reduced attention span and difficulty perceiving time and distance.

However, proponents of legalization argue that marijuana is less debilitating than alcohol and that users are more aware of their impairment. In Colorado, a proposed standard of five nanograms per milliliter of blood was considered, but ultimately rejected due to concerns that innocent people could be found guilty based on prior use, even if they showed no signs of impairment.

In Washington state, advocates for the ballot measure that legalized marijuana included the five-nanogram standard, but it is unclear if this will become the standard for impaired driving. The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration notes that THC concentrations peak during the act of smoking and generally fall to less than 5 nanograms within three hours. However, THC can remain detectable in body fat for weeks after use, making it difficult to determine impairment.

Police and prosecutors are working to educate the public on the effects of marijuana and how it can impair driving. In Washington state, drivers will still need to demonstrate signs of impairment before being pulled over, and if they are impaired, they may face a DUI conviction and penalties. The debate over marijuana and driving will continue as research and laws evolve.

Title: Baker's Right to Refuse Service: A Matter of Religious Freedom

Article:

In a recent development, a Colorado baker, Jack Phillips, has faced multiple legal attacks for declining to bake a wedding cake for a homosexual couple. The controversy has sparked a heated debate about the intersection of religious freedom and public accommodations. Phillips, a Christian, operates Masterpiece Cakeshop in Lakewood, Colorado, and has consistently maintained that his business is guided by his religious beliefs.

The U.S. Supreme Court ultimately ruled that the Colorado Civil Rights Commission had acted with "religious hostility" when it targeted Phillips, leading to a second lawsuit being dropped. However, a third lawsuit has been filed by Autumn Scardina, the complainant in the second action, seeking a birthday cake to celebrate a gender transition.

This is not the first time Phillips has faced legal action for his refusal to bake a cake. The legal doctrine of "public accommodations" was initially established to address racial segregation, which severely limited the lives and opportunities of African Americans. While there is still discrimination against the LGBTQ+ community, the situation is vastly different from the 1940s. In the 21st century, it is relatively easy to find a gay-friendly caterer in Colorado.

The current legal actions against Phillips are not about providing equal opportunities for the LGBTQ+ community or enabling them to organize their own affairs. Instead, they aim to coerce and bully individuals with traditional views on marriage into obedience and conformity. The "dissident baker" is a genuine political category that highlights the absurdity of our times.

This is a matter of religious freedom and persecution, and it is unjust. It is essential to address this issue with legal and political means to bring it to a stop.

Title: US Announces Nationwide Ban on Certain E-Cigarette Flavors Amid Concerns Over Teen Vaping

The United States has announced a nationwide ban on certain e-cigarette flavors, specifically mint and fruit flavors offered in cartridge-based e-cigarettes, such as those sold by Juul. The ban aims to address concerns over the growing use of e-cigarettes among teenagers. The US will continue to allow menthol and tobacco flavors, as well as fruit flavors delivered in other ways.

The decision has been under consideration for over a year, with several states already implementing similar rules. The ban is part of a broader effort to balance public health concerns with the need to offer adults an alternative to traditional cigarettes.

According to the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), 55 people have died and over 2,500 people have been hospitalized with injuries linked to vaping. Investigators believe vitamin E acetate, sometimes added to marijuana vaping products, is playing a role in the crisis.

The Trump administration had initially considered banning all e-cigarette flavors except tobacco, but later softened its stance after industry pushback. The ban will force competitors to Juul to remove their flavored pods from the market within 30 days.

Advocates for stricter rules have expressed concerns that teens will switch to menthol flavors if other options are eliminated. However, officials have stated that they will take steps against menthol and tobacco flavors if they see their use among teens rising.

The US has also recently raised the age for purchasing tobacco products to 21, and e-cigarettes are governed by those rules. The ban is part of a broader effort to address the growing use of e-cigarettes among teenagers and to protect public health.

Title: Social Security's Projected Shortfall: A Growing Concern for Future Generations

The Social Security Administration has issued a warning that by 2034, payroll taxes collected will be enough to pay only about 77 percent of scheduled benefits. This alarming forecast has been a recurring theme, with the government acknowledging that the ratio of workers paying taxes to support each Social Security beneficiary will decline significantly from 3:1 to 2:1 by 2034. The total number of beneficiaries is projected to reach 87 million by 2034, a 41% increase from 2017.

The aging Baby Boomer population, born between 1946 and 1964, is a significant factor in this issue. Pew Research reports that in 2019, there will be 72 million Boomers. The "bulge years" will begin in 2026, when all Boomers will be eligible to collect retirement benefits. By 2034, when the oldest Boomers turn 88, the "bulge" is projected to burst, and only 77% of benefits can be paid.

The cost of Social Security is staggering, with the program being the government's second-largest annual budget expense at $967.5 billion. By 2022, the cost is projected to be $1.166 trillion, surpassing Medicare/Medicaid at $1.138 trillion. The Social Security Trust Fund's liability is currently $17 trillion, but will grow to $24 trillion by 2022.

The U.S. government's total unfunded liabilities, including Social Security, Medicare/Medicaid, federal-employee and veterans benefits, and debt held by the public, stand at $113 trillion, increasing to $140 trillion by 2022. In contrast, the U.S. Gross Domestic Product (GDP) is projected to increase from $20 trillion to $22 trillion by 2022, while federal tax revenue will rise from $3.33 trillion to $3.4 trillion.

The Social Security Trustees warn that without legislative action, approximately 11 million disabled people and their families could face across-the-board benefit cuts of 7% in 2028. The question remains when and how elected leaders will break the news to the American people, as Congress refuses to take any action to reform Social Security.

Title: Russian Warplanes Enter Ukrainian Airspace, Pentagon Calls for De-escalation

The Pentagon has confirmed that Russian warplanes have entered Ukrainian airspace multiple times within the past 24 hours, describing the incursions as "small probes." According to Pentagon spokesman Army Col. Steve Warren, the Russian military has made "a handful of incursions" into Ukrainian airspace. The Pentagon is urging Russia to take immediate steps to reduce tensions along the Ukraine border and to help de-escalate the situation.

The recent uptick in tensions between the two countries has been attributed to a series of military exercises conducted by Russia near the Ukraine border. Russian Defense Minister Sergei Shoigu announced the exercises on Thursday, citing the ongoing NATO training exercises in Poland and the death of at least two pro-Russia insurgents in eastern Ukraine.

The Pentagon has attempted to contact Russian Defense Minister Sergei Shoigu regarding the increased tensions, but to no avail. Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel has also tried to reach out to Shoigu, but the communication has been unsuccessful.

Ukraine's acting Defense Minister Mikhail Koval has denied that Russian troops or aircraft have crossed into Ukraine during the military exercises. However, a Defense Department official declined to comment on Koval's statement.

The relationship between the United States and Russia has been strained in recent months, with high-level contact between the two countries coming to an abrupt halt. The last time President Barack Obama and Russian President Vladimir Putin spoke was on April 14. However, Pentagon officials have emphasized that the relationship has not yet "frozen over," with Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff Gen. Martin Dempsey speaking with his Russian counterpart, Chief of the General Staff of the Armed Forces of Russia Gen. Valery Gerasimov, just yesterday.

Title: Commerce Department Rolls Back Tariffs on Newsprint from Canada, But Publishers Still Seek Complete Repeal

The United States Commerce Department has announced a reduction in tariffs on newsprint imported from Canada, with the new rates ranging from 8 to 20 percent. The original tariffs, imposed in May, had added up to 30 percent extra to the price of newsprint from Canada. The move is seen as a step in the right direction by some, but publishers are still pushing for the complete repeal of the tariffs.

The tariffs have already led to job losses in the printing and publishing sectors and decreased news coverage in local communities, according to David Chavern, president and CEO of the News Media Alliance, an umbrella industry group. Paul Boyle, head of Stop Tariffs on Printers & Publishers (STOPP), echoed this sentiment, stating that the tariffs are still causing damage and need to be repealed to protect newspapers.

Newsprint, the second-biggest cost to publishers after workers, has increased significantly, with prices now close to $800 per metric ton. The Pittsburgh Post-Gazette is set to reduce its print edition to five days a week, making it one of the largest big-city dailies to take such a drastic step in response to the paper hike. Other papers are reducing the number of pages, trimming the trim size, and in some cases, dropping Sunday comics.

The tariff is also affecting advertisers, who are printing fewer circulars to insert into papers, according to Boyle. He noted that the financial harm to US paper mills is coming from a decade-long shift to digital advertising, not from Canadian paper. North American newsprint demand has declined by 75 percent from 2000 to 2018, and the tariffs will further erode demand, ultimately hurting the very paper producers they are intended to protect.

The International Trade Commission is expected to hand down a ruling on the tariffs on August 28, and Boyle is hoping for a complete repeal.

Title: Obama Nominates Anthony Foxx as Transportation Secretary, First African-American Pick for Second Term Cabinet

The White House announced on Monday that President Barack Obama will nominate Anthony Foxx as the new transportation secretary, a position that comes with significant oversight responsibilities over the nation's roads, airports, railroads, and seaways. If confirmed by the Senate, Foxx would become the second African-American to head a Cabinet agency under Obama, joining Attorney General Eric Holder.

Foxx, the current mayor of Charlotte, North Carolina, has a background in urban development and transportation. He has been credited with opening a new runway at Charlotte/Douglas International Airport and championing a new streetcar system in the city. He also played a key role in last summer's Democratic National Convention, which drew tens of thousands of attendees without any major logistical issues.

The nomination comes as Obama faces criticism for the lack of diversity in his second-term Cabinet picks. Earlier this year, the first Cabinet picks of Obama's second term – Secretary of State John Kerry, Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel, and Treasury Secretary Jack Lew – were all white men. The criticism led to the appointment of several women to prominent roles, including Sylvia Mathews Burwell as director of the White House budget office and Mary Schapiro as the chief of the Securities and Exchange Commission.

However, groups like the Congressional Black Caucus (CBC) have expressed disappointment with the lack of African-American nominees, saying it amounts to a snub for Obama's most ardent supporters. Rep. Bennie Thompson, D-Mississippi, said in a weekly address for the CBC that Obama "has once again overlooked his most loyal constituency." The CBC's chairwoman, Rep. Marcia Fudge, wrote a letter to Obama expressing concern that the people he has chosen to appoint in his second term have not been reflective of the country's diversity.

Obama himself has disputed the notion that his inner circle is lacking diversity, urging patience and pointing out that his first four years saw a diverse White House and Cabinet. He emphasized that he intends to continue this trend, stating, "I think until you've seen what my overall team looks like, it's premature to assume that somehow we're going backwards, we're going forward."

Title: China Daily Spends Millions on Advertising and Printing Expenses in US Newspapers

China Daily, an English-language newspaper controlled by the Chinese Communist Party, has spent nearly $19 million on advertising and printing expenses in American newspapers over the past four years, according to documents filed with the Justice Department. The newspaper has paid more than $4.6 million to The Washington Post and nearly $6 million to The Wall Street Journal since November 2016, the records show.

China Daily produces paid supplements called "China Watch" that are designed to look like real news articles but often contain a pro-Beijing spin on contemporary news events. One insert from September 2018 touted an initiative pushed by Chinese President Xi Jinping with the headline "Belt and Road aligns with African nations." The same insert ran a story titled "Tariffs to take toll on U.S. homebuyers" that asserted that U.S. tariffs on Chinese lumber would raise the cost of building homes in the United States.

China Daily also paid for advertising in several other newspapers, including The New York Times, Foreign Policy, The Des Moines Register, and CQ-Roll Call. The newspaper spent a total of $11,002,628 on advertising in U.S. newspapers and another $265,822 on advertising with Twitter.

China Daily has also paid out more than $7.6 million to newspapers and printing companies for its newspaper for U.S.-based readers, the Justice Department's filings show. The Los Angeles Times, The Seattle Times, The Atlanta Journal-Constitution, The Chicago Tribune, The Houston Chronicle, and The Boston Globe are all listed as clients of China Daily. The Chinese outlet paid the Los Angeles Times $657,523 for printing services, according to the FARA filings.

The Justice Department has required China Daily to disclose its activities semi-annually under the Foreign Agents Registration Act (FARA) for years. The most recent filing, which China Daily submitted on June 1, is the first to include detailed breakdowns of payments to American news outlets. The outlet disclosed those expenditures for the period between November 2016 and April 2020.

It is unclear if China Daily submitted the more detailed filings under pressure from the Justice Department or on its own. Pro-democracy groups have long warned about the Chinese government's attempts to push propaganda through American news outlets. Freedom House and the Hoover Institution have both drawn attention to China Daily's paid inserts in reports on the Chinese government's efforts to influence the media.

China Daily and other Beijing-controlled propaganda mills have come under intense scrutiny amid the coronavirus pandemic. Chinese government officials have tried to divert blame for the spread of the virus to the United States and other Western nations. Many of the regime-controlled outlets, including China Daily, have echoed the communist leaders' talking points.

China Daily has slowed its advertising expenditures in recent months, the filings show. China Daily last paid The Washington Post for advertising in December 2019. Its payments to The Wall Street Journal have been less than half their average amount since February 2020, the documents show.

Title: U.S. Senators Introduce Temporary Funding Bill to End Government Shutdown, Trump Demands "Down Payment" for Border Wall

Article:

U.S. senators attempted to end the partial government shutdown with a temporary funding bill on Thursday, but President Donald Trump demanded a "down payment" for a border wall that Democrats reject. The Republican-led Senate failed to advance two measures to reopen shuttered agencies, prompting Democratic and Republican lawmakers to urge quick passage of a three-week stopgap funding bill to create time for talks on border security.

White House spokeswoman Sarah Sanders stated that such a measure would only work if there is a large down payment on the wall. However, a spokesman for Senate Democratic leader Chuck Schumer said Senate Democrats had made clear to Republicans that they will not support funding for the wall.

Trump, who sparked the shutdown with his demand for $5.7 billion in funding for the U.S.-Mexico border wall, told reporters that "we have no choice but to have a wall or a barrier, and if we don't have that, it's just not going to work" in terms of border security. He also stated that if Senate Democratic leader Chuck Schumer and Republican Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell come to a "reasonable" agreement to end the shutdown, "I would support it, yes."

McConnell said late on Thursday that talks were ongoing, stating, "At least we're talking. I think that's better than it was before." Democratic House of Representatives Speaker Nancy Pelosi said Trump's demand for a large down payment on a border wall "is not a reasonable agreement."

The shutdown has left 800,000 federal workers without pay and struggling to make ends meet, as the effects on government services and the economy reverberate nationwide. Republican Senator Lindsey Graham said he had spoken to Trump about a short-term funding bill, stating, "All of us believe if we have three weeks with the government open that we could find a way forward to produce a bill that he would sign, that would be good for everybody in the country. To my Democratic friends, money for a barrier is required to get this deal done."

Earlier, a bill backed by Trump to end the shutdown by funding the wall and a separate bill supported by Democrats to reopen shuttered agencies without such funding did not get the votes required to advance in the 100-member chamber. Trump has touted Republican unity during the longest shutdown in U.S. history, but in a sign of cracks in that resolve, or just a desire for compromise, six Republican senators voted with Democrats on their measure to reopen government agencies temporarily without money for a wall.

Pelosi told reporters earlier she was willing to meet with Trump to discuss the shutdown. Her comments came one day after she essentially withdrew an invitation for Trump to give his State of the Union in the House chamber next Tuesday, saying that would not happen until the shutdown ended. Trump, who had planned to come despite the shutdown and considered giving the speech at another venue, conceded late on Wednesday and said he would deliver the speech in the House in the "near future."

U.S. Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross urged furloughed federal workers to seek loans to pay their bills while adding in a CNBC interview that he could not understand why they were having trouble getting by. "Is this the 'Let them eat cake' kind of attitude or 'Call your father for money' or 'This is character building for you'?" Pelosi asked at a news conference. She said she did not understand why Ross would make the comment "as hundreds of thousands of men and women are about to miss a second paycheck tomorrow."

A recent Ipsos poll found more than half of Americans blamed Trump for the shutdown even as he has sought to shift blame to Democrats after saying last month he would be "proud" to close the government for border security.

Title: The Intersection of Food Production and Climate Change: A Complex Web of Economic and Environmental Interests

The article discusses the relationship between food production and climate change, highlighting the significant role that the Farm Bill plays in shaping the agricultural industry. The author notes that the current system is dominated by large, industrially oriented operations, which can be less environmentally friendly. However, changing practices in cropping, fertilizing, irrigation, and waste management can reduce carbon emissions and benefit small-scale farming.

The article also touches on the idea that environmental policy is often linked to broader economic and social issues, citing the example of Senator Edmund Muskie's Clean Air Act and Clean Water Act, which aimed to address environmental concerns while also promoting social justice. The author notes that the Green New Deal is a recent example of this approach, with its broad ambitions marking the ground for future climate fights.

The article concludes by highlighting the complexity of the issue, noting that there will be competing visions about who deserves to benefit and what kind of economy should be built. The author suggests that centrist proposals will focus on promoting investment in new technologies, while more radical approaches may advocate for nationalizing fossil fuels or implementing a carbon tax.

Overall, the article provides a nuanced exploration of the intersection of food production and climate change, highlighting the need for a multifaceted approach that considers both environmental and economic factors.

Title: Malian Troops, Backed by US and French Forces, Retake Radisson Hotel After Hostage Siege

Malian troops, supported by US and French special forces, stormed the Radisson Blu hotel in Bamako, the capital of Mali, to retake the building and free hostages after a more than seven-hour siege. The operation resulted in the deaths of at least 20 people, including one American, and two gunmen.

According to the Malian military, the heavily armed Islamic extremists seized the hotel, taking 170 people hostage, including 30 hotel staff and 140 guests. The hostages were made to recite Koranic verses before being released, with some 20 others still held captive. The hotel, operated by the Rezidor Hotel Group, is popular among foreigners and is located near government ministries and diplomatic offices.

The Malian military, with the help of United Nations peacekeeping troops, surrounded the hotel, and a Malian military official confirmed three deaths, including two Malians and one French national. Turkish Airlines reported that six of its crew members were among the hostages.

There was no immediate claim of responsibility for the attack, but it comes amid an uptick in jihadist violence across Mali. The country has seen a history of Islamist militant activity, particularly in the north, which fell under the control of Islamic extremists in 2012. France and other Western nations have been working with the Malian government to prevent the Islamist militants from regaining a foothold in the north.

The Radisson Blu hotel was hosting a large delegation of UN workers involved in the ongoing peace process, making the attack a significant incident. The UN spokesman stated that the hotel was a popular gathering place for international officials and diplomats.

In August, nine people, including four UN mission members, were killed in a hotel attack in the central town of Sevare, which was seen as a significant escalation of violence. The attack was a reminder of the ongoing threat posed by Islamist militants in Mali, which has been a concern for the international community.

Title: Texas Seeks to Exclude Planned Parenthood from Federal Family Planning Funding

Texas is on the verge of setting a new national precedent for states looking to defund Planned Parenthood. The state has requested permission from the Trump administration to exclude the organization and other abortion providers from receiving some federal family planning dollars. If approved, this would likely clear the way for other states to do the same.

The push in Texas is the latest salvo against Planned Parenthood, which stands to lose federal funding for one year under the Republican healthcare bill being considered in the Senate. Republicans have long tried to block Planned Parenthood from being reimbursed by the government for medical services, citing its provision of abortions. The Hyde Amendment prohibits the use of federal funds for the procedure.

Texas is seeking federal Medicaid funding it lost four years ago when it excluded Planned Parenthood and other abortion providers from participating in a family planning program for low-income women who are not otherwise eligible for Medicaid. The state created its own state-funded program, called "Healthy Texas Women," and is now asking the Trump administration for the federal money back, while still exempting abortion providers.

If approved, the program would take effect for five years beginning September 1. The federal comment period is open until August 4, after which the Centers for Medicaid and Medicare Services (CMS) would make a decision.

Experts warn that excluding Planned Parenthood from the program could have negative consequences, including a drop in women receiving services and a diminished access to care for low-income women. Community health centers in Texas are already facing limited resources and facilities, making it difficult to replace the services provided by Planned Parenthood and other centers.

The issue could end up in court, as federal law says Medicaid beneficiaries may go to any provider who is "qualified to perform the service," and there are questions about whether Texas's proposal would violate that. Courts have previously sided with Planned Parenthood in cases where states have tried to block the organization from receiving Medicaid funding.

Planned Parenthood has called the proposal an "underhanded attempt to cut off care at Planned Parenthood with devastating consequences for our patients." The organization's spokeswoman, Danielle Wells, warned that the proposal paints a grim picture of what healthcare access could look like nationwide if the Trump administration approves the waiver.

Title: Taylor University Defends Decision to Invite Vice President Mike Pence as Commencement Speaker Amidst Controversy

Taylor University, a small evangelical Christian school, has faced backlash from students and alumni after announcing that former Indiana Governor and Vice President Mike Pence will be this year's commencement speaker. Over 3,300 people have signed a petition on Change.org calling for the invitation to be rescinded, citing Pence's policies as being "not consistent with the Christian ethic of love." However, not all alumni agree, with some defending the decision and others expressing disappointment.

One Taylor graduate expressed strong opposition, stating that the school "should be ashamed" and feeling "personally attacked." However, not all alumni share this sentiment. Kevin Holtsberry, a Taylor alumnus, believes that the outraged students and alumni are mistaking disagreement on political issues with personal attacks. He praised the school for "standing firm" and not pulling Pence's invitation.

The university has defended its decision, with President Paul Lowell Haines describing Pence as a "good friend to the University over many years" and "a Christian brother whose life and values have exemplified what we strive to instill in our graduates." Taylor University spokesman James Garringer stated that the university is an "intentional Christian community that strives to encourage positive, respectful, and meaningful dialogue" and looks forward to hosting Pence next month.

The controversy has also drawn attention from South Bend Mayor Pete Buttigieg, a Democratic presidential hopeful, who criticized Pence's stance on LGBTQ issues during an event hosted by the LGBTQ Victory Fund.

Title: The Divided States of America: A Conflict Over the Meaning of American Identity

The United States is facing a deep-seated division, often described as a "cold civil war" by Angelo Codevilla of the Claremont Institute. This polarization is rooted in a fundamental disagreement between two camps: those who unconditionally love America, its history, culture, and principles, and those who believe the country is flawed and in need of "fundamental transformation," as famously put by Barack Obama.

The former group emphasizes the positive aspects of American history and culture, acknowledging past mistakes, while the latter group qualifies any affirmation of America's past and present with endless criticism of its perceived flaws. They insist on supporting American "ideals," which they equate with the goals of a new "social justice" regime prioritizing ethnic, racial, and gender groups.

The conflict is not just about policy disagreements over how to achieve shared goals like liberty, equality, and justice but fundamentally about the meaning of those principles. The argument over "first principles" has been brewing for decades, with historians and civic educators revising the traditional story of America to emphasize a multicultural society and the concept of a "mosaic" or "salad bowl" replacing the traditional "melting pot."

The revised narrative portrays America as the result of the "convergence" of three civilizations: Amerindian, European, and Islamic West Africa. This narrative has spread to education, with the AP curriculum referring to the "three worlds meet" narrative as the "Atlantic World." The promotion of "diversity" and the trinity of race, ethnicity, and gender has become dominant, prioritizing group identity over American citizenship.

The conflict has intensified, with Americanist forces pushing back against the multicultural Left. The Claremont Institute has launched a project explaining the regime struggle between Americanism and multiculturalism, and people are beginning to recognize the multicultural Left's loud megaphone but limited popular support.

Title: CNN Panel on Ferguson Unrest Turns Heated, Focus Shifts from Mental Health to Racism

A recent CNN panel discussion on the recent shooting in Ferguson, Missouri, turned into a heated debate between University of Pennsylvania professor and CNN contributor Marc Lamont Hill and conservative radio host Larry Elder. The conversation, moderated by Brooke Baldwin, initially focused on the mental health of young men of color, but quickly shifted to the topic of racism.

Hill argued that the stigma surrounding mental illness and societal assumptions about black men's behavior contribute to the lack of discussion around mental health. Elder countered by claiming that the media exaggerates the problem of racism in America and that the left uses it as a tool to gain votes and power.

The discussion became increasingly tense, with Elder becoming defensive and Hill accusing him of not taking the topic of mental health seriously. The conversation ended with Elder asking why Hill had to "insult" him and Hill expressing frustration that the topic had been derailed.

The rest of the interview is worth watching, as Elder makes some valid points when not being defensive.

Title: The Wrong Problem: Focusing on Taxes Instead of Overspending

The recent passage of the fiscal cliff deal in the House, which raised taxes on the top 1-2% of income earners, has sparked a renewed debate about the effectiveness of this approach in addressing the nation's fiscal woes. However, many argue that the focus on taxes has been misguided, and that the real problem lies in overspending.

The article contends that the president, the House speaker, and Senate leaders have done the nation a disservice by focusing almost exclusively on taxes for the past six months. The author argues that overspending is the root of the problem, not insufficient revenue from taxes. The article defines overspending as spending more than one takes in, and notes that it is not hard to grasp or define.

The article also highlights the failure of the "Cut, Cap, and Balance" bill, which would have addressed the deficit and fiscal sanity, but was not passed. The author suggests that the House should have stood firm and forced the Senate's hand, leading to a more comprehensive solution.

The article also examines the Congressional Budget Office's estimate that the deficit for fiscal 2013 will exceed $1 trillion, and notes that the tax increases implemented by President Obama will only produce about $60 billion in revenue, a mere 6% of the annual deficit. The author argues that this is not a solution, and that a 65% tax increase on all taxpayers would be needed to close the gap, which is unrealistic.

The article concludes that the focus on taxes is misguided and that the only practical route to reducing the deficit is through rapid economic growth and real, substantive expenditure cuts. The author notes that the looming debt-ceiling debate may be an opportunity to refocus on the real problem of overspending and stimulate growth.

Title: Obama and Kaine Team Up to Boost Clinton's Presidential Bid

The Democratic National Convention saw a powerful duo take the stage on Wednesday, as President Barack Obama and Senator Tim Kaine delivered a strong warm-up for Hillary Clinton's nomination acceptance speech. Obama endorsed Clinton as a tough and tenacious leader, emphasizing her qualifications and readiness to be the next commander-in-chief. He also launched a scathing attack on Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump, accusing him of offering only "slogans" and "fear."

Kaine, who was officially nominated as Clinton's running mate, also took aim at Trump, delivering a passionate speech that mocked the billionaire's claims and emphasized Clinton's commitment to issues like gun control and national security. The senator's speech was punctuated by his impressions of Trump's New York accent and his tendency to say "believe me."

The evening's speakers, including Obama, Kaine, and others, focused on the importance of electing a qualified leader like Clinton, who has the experience and expertise to tackle the country's challenges. They also highlighted the dangers of electing Trump, who they portrayed as a divisive and inexperienced candidate.

The convention's third night saw a range of speakers, including Senate Democratic Leader Harry Reid, former Maryland Governor Martin O'Malley, and former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton herself. The evening's speeches were marked by a focus on issues like gun control, global warming, and national security, and featured a number of barbed insults aimed at Trump.

The Obama-Kaine duo's speeches set the stage for Clinton's nomination acceptance speech, which is expected to be delivered on Thursday night.
