The president's speech marked the beginning of his role as a chief surrogate for Clinton, with aides indicating that he will be on the campaign trail regularly until the election.

Title: Sanders Responds to Allegations of Sexism and Harassment in 2016 Campaign

Sen. Bernie Sanders (I-Vt.) has responded to a New York Times report detailing allegations of sexism and harassment against his 2016 presidential campaign. The report claims that nearly a dozen female staffers experienced harassment and that their concerns were not properly addressed by their superiors.

In an interview with CNN's Anderson Cooper, Sanders acknowledged that he was unaware of the allegations at the time, stating, "I was a little bit busy running around the country, trying to make the case." He also expressed regret and promised to do better if he were to run for president again in the future.

Sanders noted that he was proud of his 2016 campaign, but acknowledged that it did not do enough to address the concerns of female staffers. He highlighted the importance of having proper training programs and reporting procedures in place, which he implemented in his recent successful re-election campaign for Senate.

The Times report included detailed accounts from several staffers, including one instance where a supervisor ran his hands through a staffer's hair in a "sexual way" and her reports of the incident were laughed off. The report comes just days after more than two dozen alumni of Sanders' 2016 campaign sent him a letter requesting a meeting to discuss "sexual violence and harassment" that took place while working on the campaign.

Sanders' response to the allegations is a significant development in the ongoing conversation about workplace harassment and the need for better practices and procedures to prevent and address such incidents.

Title: Virginia Governor's Assault Weapon Ban Proposal Fails to Pass

Article:

Virginia Governor Ralph Northam's proposal to ban the sale of assault weapons has failed to pass, with members of his own party rejecting the legislation. The bill, which would have prohibited the sale of certain semiautomatic firearms, including popular AR-15 style rifles, and banned the possession of magazines that hold more than 12 rounds, was shelved by senators and sent to the state crime commission for further study.

The decision was met with cheers from a committee room packed with gun advocates, who had been vocal in their opposition to the bill. Four moderate Democrats joined Republicans in voting against the legislation, citing concerns about the constitutionality and effectiveness of the ban.

Governor Northam had campaigned heavily for the bill, which was part of a broader package of gun control measures. He argued that banning new sales of assault weapons and high-capacity magazines would help prevent mass murders, but opponents claimed the proposal would infringe on the rights of law-abiding gun owners.

The debate over gun control and mass shootings has been intense in Virginia, with tens of thousands of gun-rights activists from across the country flooding the state Capitol and surrounding area in protest. The state has seen significant pushback from gun owners and gun-right advocates, who have accused the governor and others of wanting to confiscate commonly owned guns and accessories from law-abiding gun owners.

While Governor Northam has been able to get some of his gun control agenda passed this year, the proposed assault weapon ban proved to be a sticking point. Earlier proposals to ban possession of AR-15-style rifles or require owners to register them with state police have been scrapped.

The debate is expected to continue, with lawmakers in both the House and Senate having already advanced several other gun-control measures. These bills include limiting handgun purchases to once a month, universal background checks on gun purchases, allowing localities to ban guns in public buildings, parks, and other areas, and a red flag bill that would allow authorities to temporarily take guns away from anyone deemed to be dangerous to themselves or others.

Title: Former FBI Director James Comey Urges Democrats to Vote in Midterms, Criticizes Republican Congress

Former FBI Director James Comey has taken to Twitter to express his opinions on the upcoming midterm elections and the current state of American politics. In a tweet on Tuesday, Comey stated that the current Republican Congress has proven "incapable" of fulfilling the Founders' design and urged those who believe in the country's values to vote for Democrats this fall. According to Comey, policy differences do not matter at this point, and history is watching.

Comey, a former registered Republican, has also been critical of President Donald Trump's handling of the Helsinki summit with Russian President Vladimir Putin. In a tweet on Monday, Comey described Trump's actions as "standing on foreign soil next to a murderous lying thug and refusing to back his own country." He urged patriots to stand up and reject the behavior of the current president.

It is worth noting that Comey has faced criticism himself, including being deemed "insubordinate" and defying authority while he was director of the FBI, according to a Department of Justice Inspector General report in June 2018. He is also under investigation for his handling of classified reports about his meetings with Trump. Additionally, Comey faced criticism for his handling of the investigation into Hillary Clinton's email server.

It is important to note that Comey's statements are his personal opinions and do not reflect the views of the FBI or any other organization.

Title: Analysis Suggests Extremism's Electoral Cost is Negligible in Presidential Elections

A recent analysis of ideological extremism in presidential elections over the past several decades has concluded that the electoral cost of extremism is "negligible" compared to the effects of other economic and political factors. The study examined the performances of presidential candidates Barry Goldwater, George McGovern, Ronald Reagan, and Barack Obama, as well as the current presidential candidates, Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump.

The analysis found that Goldwater and McGovern, who were considered "extreme" in their political views, likely lost their elections due to factors other than their ideology. In 1964, Goldwater lost to Lyndon B. Johnson, who was presiding over an economic boom, and in 1972, McGovern lost to Richard Nixon, who was also riding a strong economy.

In contrast, Reagan and Obama benefited from running in election years when economic recessions undermined the appeal of their opponents. Reagan won in 1980, and Obama won in 2008.

The current presidential candidates, Clinton and Trump, are taking different approaches. Clinton is leading in the polls despite her "hard-core liberal" campaign stands and a voting record to the left of most Senate Democrats. Trump, on the other hand, is trailing despite having moderated some of his party's conservative stands on issues like social spending and gay rights. However, his policy positions are closer to the center of the electorate than those of previous Republican presidential candidates.

The analysis also highlights the issue of racial policy as the single largest difference in positions between presidential candidates and swing voters over the past three decades. Republican candidates have been seen as six points to the right of the political center on government assistance to African-Americans, while Democratic candidates have been 26 points to the left.

The study suggests that voters who are quick to condemn the extremism of their opponents often see virtue in their own party's deviations from centrist opinion. However, it is worth asking whether policy "extremism" is such a bad thing, anyway.

Title: Author's Stance on Trump and Clinton: A Critique of Both Candidates

The article discusses the author's views on the 2016 presidential election, specifically their stance on Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton. The author identifies themselves as a #NeverTrump and #NeverHillary, citing their dissatisfaction with both candidates. They express concerns about the potential consequences of a Trump presidency, including the potential for reckless decision-making and the erosion of religious liberties.

The author also criticizes Trump's lack of foreign policy experience and his tendency to make rash decisions, citing his support for wars and his nationalist views on immigration and trade. They argue that Trump's presidency would be a departure from the norm, and that his lack of restraint and working knowledge of government make him a dangerous choice for the presidency.

On the other hand, the author acknowledges that a Clinton presidency would likely result in the consolidation of liberal gains in the judiciary and the potential for more pitched battles over religious liberty. They express relief that a Clinton presidency would mean the end of a divided era on the Supreme Court, but also note that her presidency would likely lead to more liberal policies and the potential for increased government intervention in various areas.

The author concludes that they will not be voting in the election, citing their dissatisfaction with both candidates. They express concern about the potential consequences of a Trump presidency, but also acknowledge that a Clinton presidency would have its own set of problems. Ultimately, the author's stance is one of skepticism and frustration with the political process, rather than a clear endorsement of either candidate.

Title: Supreme Court Justice Anthony Kennedy Announces Retirement, Setting Stage for Political Battle Over Replacement

The retirement of Supreme Court Justice Anthony Kennedy, announced on Wednesday, has set the stage for a political battle over his replacement. Kennedy, 81, will retire on July 31, giving President Donald Trump the opportunity to cement a conservative majority on the high court for decades to come.

Democrats are urging the Republican-controlled Congress to wait until after the November midterm elections to confirm a successor, citing the precedent set by the Republican-led Senate's refusal to consider President Barack Obama's nominee, Merrick Garland, in 2016. Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell, however, has stated that a vote will take place by the autumn.

The Senate, currently controlled by Republicans with a slim 51-seat majority, could change after the midterm elections. Trump has promised to draw names from the same list of 25 conservative candidates from which he picked Justice Neil Gorsuch last year. When asked if he would wait until after the midterms to nominate a successor, Trump replied, "I think you want to go as quickly as possible."

The Supreme Court plays a crucial role in American life, often serving as the final word on highly contentious laws, disputes between states and the federal government, and final appeals to stay executions. The justices serve for life unless they decide to retire, making their appointments particularly significant.

Kennedy's retirement has raised concerns among pro-choice groups that access to legal abortions in several states could be under threat. Trump, during his presidential campaign, vowed to attempt to overturn Roe v. Wade, the 1973 decision legalizing abortion throughout the US.

Kennedy, who was raised in California, was nominated by President Ronald Reagan and began his term in 1988. He voted conservative on issues of campaign finance, voting rights, and gun rights. However, he also authored the Supreme Court's first major gay-rights decision in 1996, protecting LGBT Americans from discrimination, and gave LGBT citizens the right to marry in 2015.

The White House has released a statement thanking Kennedy for his 30 years of service as a "tireless voice for individual rights." Several front-runners have emerged from the list of 25 judges Trump has said he would draw from, including Brett Kavanaugh, Amul Thapar, and Amy Comey Barrett.

Title: Trump Administration to Re-Lift Ban on Military Equipment Transfer to Local Police Departments

The Trump administration has announced plans to reinstate a program allowing the transfer of surplus military equipment to state and local police departments, which was previously blocked by former President Barack Obama in 2015. Attorney General Jeff Sessions made the announcement on Monday, stating that the ban "went too far" and that the program will "make it easier to protect yourselves and your communities."

The 1033 program, established in 1997, allows the Department of Defense to transfer excess military equipment to local law enforcement agencies for use in counterterrorism and drug investigations. Since its inception, over $5 billion worth of equipment has been transferred to police departments across the country.

The ban was put in place by Obama in 2015 after images of heavily armed police responding to protests in Ferguson, Missouri, sparked concerns about the militarization of law enforcement. The ban prohibited the transfer of armored vehicles, grenade launchers, armed aircraft, bayonets, and guns and ammunition of.50 caliber or higher.

Sessions argued that the ban was too restrictive and that it prioritized "superficial concerns" over public safety. He cited the recent violence in Houston as an example of why the program is necessary.

The decision to lift the ban has been met with mixed reactions. Some law enforcement groups, such as the Fraternal Order of Police, have been pushing for the rollback of the Obama-era ban, citing the benefits of having access to military-grade equipment. However, critics argue that the program allows police departments to stockpile military-grade equipment and increases the instances of violent encounters.

The debate surrounding the program is ongoing, with some arguing that it is necessary for public safety and others believing it perpetuates a culture of fear and aggression. The decision to lift the ban is likely to continue to spark controversy and debate in the coming weeks and months.

Title: Facebook Addresses Concerns Over Viral Video of Nancy Pelosi, Reduces Distribution and Adds Disclaimer

Facebook has released a statement regarding its decision not to remove a viral video that appears to show House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, D-Calif., slurring her words. The video, which was altered to make it seem like Pelosi was having trouble speaking, has sparked controversy and criticism towards the social media giant.

In response to the backlash, Facebook reduced the video's distribution and added a disclaimer notifying users that the video is false. The company stated that it does not have a policy requiring the accuracy of information posted on its platform, but instead focuses on removing content that violates its Community Standards.

Facebook emphasized that it is working to strike a balance between encouraging free expression and promoting a safe and authentic community. The company explained that while it allows users to post content, it does not necessarily mean it will be displayed prominently on the platform.

"We remove things from Facebook that violate our Community standards, and we don't have a policy that stipulates that the information you post on Facebook must be true," a Facebook spokesperson said.

The company also outlined its efforts to combat misinformation, including removing content that violates its Community Standards, reducing the distribution of content that undermines the authenticity of the platform, and empowering users to make informed decisions by providing more context and promoting news literacy.

Facebook's vice president for product policy and counterterrorism, Monika Bickert, stated that the company "dramatically" reduced the video's distribution and alerted users that it is false. Bickert emphasized the importance of allowing users to make their own informed choices about what to believe, and that Facebook's role is to provide accurate information.

The controversy comes amid growing scrutiny of social media companies and their handling of content on their platforms. Facebook and Twitter have faced criticism for perceived bias against conservatives and allowing content promoted by Russians during the 2016 election.

Title: Millennials Overwhelmingly Support School Choice, Surveys Show

Article:

Two recent national surveys conducted by different pollsters have found strong support for school choice among Millennials. The surveys, conducted by Beck Research and GenForward, respectively, found that 75% of Millennials support school choice. The results are consistent across racial and ethnic lines, with 79% of African Americans, 76% of Asian Americans, 77% of Latinos, and 66% of whites supporting the concept.

The surveys also found that charter schools enjoy support from 65% of African Americans, 61% of Asian Americans, 58% of Latinos, and 55% of whites. The results suggest that school choice is a winning issue for both Republicans and Democrats willing to seize the moment and push bold reforms.

Legislative momentum has grown in recent years, with several states enacting or expanding educational choice for K-12 students. Twenty-six states have private-school-choice programs, and 44 states have charter schools, demonstrating nationwide support for educational choice. Research also shows that school choice works, with 11 of 17 empirical studies using the random-assignment method showing that students using private-school-choice programs do better academically.

The Millennial generation grew up with abundant options across most aspects of their lives, and they are naturally inclined to think expansively when it comes to what's possible in education. Many Millennials graduated high school or college during the 2008 financial crisis and struggled to find work after earning degrees they were promised would lead to good jobs. This experience has led to distrust of institutions and a desire for more educational options.

The future of education in America could be bright and dynamic, with better outcomes for students. All that is required is for leaders to choose that future.

Title: Study Reveals Liberals More Likely to Strain Friendships Over Political Differences

A recent Pew study has shed light on the growing divide in American politics, highlighting that liberals are more likely to strain friendships over political differences. The study found that nearly half of liberal Democrats (47%) believe that if a friend supported Trump, it would put a strain on their friendship, compared to 13% of Republicans who feel the same about those who voted for Hillary Clinton.

The research also showed that white and more-educated Democrats are more likely to find it difficult to be friends with a Trump supporter. This is partly due to the fact that liberals tend to live in more homogeneous areas and do not often associate with conservatives. The study noted that 47% of people who planned to vote for Clinton did not have any close friends who supported Trump, compared to 31% of Trump supporters who did not have any friends who backed Clinton.

The Pew study also found that 68% of Democrats and Democratic-leaning voters find it "stressful and frustrating" to talk to people who have a different opinion on Trump, compared to 52% of Republican and GOP-leaning voters.

The article goes on to suggest that individuals who are targeted by liberal friends for their political beliefs may want to consider finding new friends. The author questions the strength of those who find it intolerable to be around Trump supporters, citing Hillary Clinton's infamous "deplorables" comment and the widespread anger and frustration displayed by liberals since the 2016 election.

The article concludes by stating that individuals can be who they want to be and know where they stand, acknowledging the trend towards tribalism in American politics.

Title: White House Press Secretary Corrects and Apologizes for False Information on Job Creation Under Obama and Trump

The White House Press Secretary, Sarah Sanders, issued a rare correction and apology on Tuesday after providing incorrect information during a press briefing about job creation under the presidencies of Barack Obama and Donald Trump. Sanders had claimed that President Trump had created three times as many jobs for African-Americans as President Obama had during his entire eight years in office. However, media outlets quickly fact-checked the claim using data from the Bureau of Labor Statistics, revealing that President Obama created nearly 3 million jobs for blacks during his presidency, about 15 times what Sanders claimed.

In a tweet, Sanders acknowledged the mistake, stating, "Correction from today's briefing: Jobs numbers for Pres Trump and Pres Obama were correct, but the time frame for Pres Obama wasn't. I'm sorry for the mistake, but no apologies for the 700,000 jobs for African Americans created under President Trump." The White House Council of Economic Advisers also posted an apology on Twitter, attributing the mistake to a miscommunication.

Sanders had initially made the claim during a defense of President Trump's record on race, following accusations of using the N-word on tape and calling former White House aide Omarosa Manigault Newman a "dog" on Twitter. The claim was made in an attempt to show that President Trump's record with the African-American population was not only great but even better than Obama's, stating that Trump had created 700,000 new jobs for African-Americans during his presidency, compared to Obama's 195,000 jobs. However, the data provided by the Bureau of Labor Statistics revealed that Obama created nearly 3 million jobs for blacks during his presidency, about 15 times what Sanders claimed.

Title: Senator Robert Menendez's Support for Natural Gas Bill Raises Questions About Ties to Major Donor

Senator Robert Menendez (D-NJ) has faced scrutiny over his relationship with his biggest donor, Dr. Salomon Melgen, a Florida eye doctor who has been involved in a Senate ethics investigation. The latest development is Menendez's sponsorship of a bill that would have provided tax credits and grants to truck and heavy vehicle fleets that converted to natural gas. The bill could have benefited Melgen's company, Gaseous Fuel Systems Corp., which designs and manufactures products to convert diesel- and gas-fuel vehicles to natural gas.

The bill, which did not pass, has raised questions about the close relationship between Menendez and Melgen. However, political analysts argue that Menendez's support for the bill is part of a larger clean-energy agenda, and that it is unlikely to be a conflict of interest.

Menendez has denied any allegations of impropriety, including those related to this latest report. His office did not respond to requests for comment. The senator has a history of supporting environmental causes, including legislation aimed at jump-starting offshore wind energy, extending solar energy tax credits, and creating block grants to spur green-energy projects.

The natural gas industry spends hundreds of thousands of dollars lobbying members of Congress, including Menendez and his staff. While Menendez's ethics controversy has had an impact on his poll numbers, analysts believe that the latest development may further damage his image.

A Quinnipiac University poll found Menendez's approval ratings plummeted 15 percentage points between January and February, as news reports emerged about his relationship with Melgen. His approval rating dropped from 51 percent in mid-January to 36 percent in mid-February. The same poll found only 28 percent of New Jersey voters said the senator was "honest and trustworthy."

Title: Obama Administration to Implement New Procedures for Verifying Income of Americans Seeking Government Subsidies

The Obama administration is set to introduce new procedures to verify the income of Americans who apply for government subsidies under the federal health care law. According to Gary Cohen, deputy director of the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services, the government will verify the income of everyone who applies for subsidies on state-based exchanges, where individuals without employer-based insurance can shop for private health coverage with the help of premium tax credits.

The new procedures aim to address concerns raised by Chairman Dave Camp, Michigan Republican, that enrollees in state health exchanges will self-certify their income, which would require the government to cross-check that information later when enrollees file their tax returns. The administration will deliver tax credits through the health exchanges, not directly to individual enrollees, as stated by Daniel Werfel, acting director of the IRS.

The new procedures are part of the administration's efforts to implement the Affordable Care Act, which is set to begin enrollment for coverage that takes effect in January. The law aims to provide health insurance options for individuals without employer-based insurance. The administration has faced criticism for delays in setting up exchanges in over half the states and the decision to delay the employer mandate requiring firms with 50 or more full-time workers to offer health insurance or pay fines.

The House is scheduled to vote on a bill that would prevent the IRS from implementing and enforcing the health care law, a reaction to mounting distrust of the agency in the wake of a political targeting scandal in its tax-exempt organizations branch. The administration has assured that tax data will not be displayed to anyone outside of the marketplace itself.

The new procedures aim to increase transparency and accuracy in the verification process, addressing concerns about the potential for errors and fraud. The administration's efforts to implement the Affordable Care Act have been met with criticism and skepticism from some lawmakers, who argue that the law is flawed and should be repealed.

Title: Democrats Express Concerns Over Obamacare Implementation and Rising Premiums

Article:

In a recent meeting with White House officials, Democratic senators expressed concerns about the implementation of the Affordable Care Act (ACA), also known as Obamacare. The senators, including Jeanne Shaheen of New Hampshire and Tom Harkin of Iowa, raised concerns about the complexity of the law and its impact on small businesses and individuals.

Senator Shaheen noted that small businesses in New Hampshire are struggling to comply with the law, with some considering reducing employee hours to avoid offering health coverage. Harkin, chairman of the appropriations subcommittee on health care, expressed frustration with the administration's decision to redirect funds from public health prevention programs to promote the new law.

Additionally, Senator Benjamin Cardin of Maryland expressed concerns about rate increases sought by the largest health insurer in his state, CareFirst BlueCross BlueShield. The company is seeking average increases of 25% for individual insurance policies and 15% for small businesses, citing the costs of complying with the new law.

The concerns come as the Obama administration faces criticism over the rollout of the ACA. The law's implementation has been plagued by technical issues, and some Democrats are worried that the law's unpopularity could lead to a political backlash in the 2014 elections.

The article highlights the challenges faced by small businesses and individuals in complying with the law, as well as the concerns of some Democrats about the law's impact on premiums and the overall cost of healthcare.

Title: US Economy Matches Best Performance Since Great Recession, But Growth Prospects Uncertain

The United States economy ended 2018 with a solid performance, matching its best growth rate since the Great Recession of 2007-2009. The nation's gross domestic product (GDP) grew at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 2.6% in the fourth quarter, following an average 3.7% advance in the previous two quarters. For the year, the economy grew 2.9%, matching its performance since 2015.

The strong growth was driven by healthy consumer spending and business investment. Consumer spending grew 2.8%, down from 3.5% in the third quarter, while business investment increased 6.2%, largely due to a big jump in software and research and development. The solid performance defied the drop in stock prices late last year and the global economic slowdown.

However, economists predict that the economy will slow down in 2019, with growth expected to be around 2% to 2.5%. The Federal Reserve has also adopted a wait-and-see approach, indicating a rate cut to stimulate growth may be just as likely as a hike. The labor market is also expected to lose some steam as the 4% unemployment rate makes it harder for businesses to find qualified workers.

The economy's growth was boosted by federal tax cuts and spending increases, which are expected to fade later this year. The trade tensions with China and a sluggish global economy are also expected to slow down the economy. The nation's trade deficit widened as exports increased 1.6% while imports grew 2.7%, making trade a slight drag on economic growth.

Residential investment fell for the fourth straight month, slipping 3.5%, due to low housing supplies, worker shortages, and higher material costs. Existing home sales slowed noticeably late last year amid higher mortgage rates and home prices, leading many builders to pull back. However, prices and rates have moderated recently, possibly heralding a recovery in housing starts.

Overall, while the economy had a strong finish to 2018, the outlook for 2020 is uncertain, with many analysts predicting a recession.

Title: Trump Attacks Democratic Senate Candidate, Predicts Government Shutdown Over Border Wall Funding

Article:

President Donald Trump recently attacked Tennessee Democratic Senate candidate Phil Bredesen, labeling him a "tool" of "MS-13 lover" Nancy Pelosi. The comments came during a rally in Nashville, where Trump reiterated his stance on border control and claimed that Mexico will pay for the border wall.

Meanwhile, ousted White House strategist Steve Bannon predicts that the government may shut down before the midterm elections over Trump's insistence on funding his long-promised border wall. In an interview with CNN's Fareed Zakaria, Bannon stated, "I believe the government will actually shut down in the run-up to the election." He emphasized that the wall is "absolutely central" to Trump's program.

The Trump administration has requested $33 billion to secure the border, with $18 billion allocated for the wall, according to Customs and Border Protection documents obtained by CNN. However, Congress has declined to allocate funds for the wall, and only existing fences have been repaired. Prototypes of a possible wall have been built, but no concrete plans have been implemented.

Bannon believes that Trump will take drastic measures if lawmakers refuse to allocate funds for the wall. "I believe that what he's going to do is, as we come up on September 30, if that appropriations bill does not include spending to fully build his wall – not some $1.6 billion for prototypes, I mean to build the southern wall – I believe he will shut down the government," Bannon said.

Trump's demand for a wall was a central campaign promise during his 2016 presidential bid. He claimed that Mexico would pay for the wall, but Mexican President Enrique Pena Nieto has repeatedly denied this, stating "NO. Mexico will NEVER pay for a wall. Not now, not ever."

Title: US Deploys Patriot Missile-Defence System and Warship to Middle East Amid Escalating Tensions with Iran

The United States has deployed a Patriot missile-defence system and a warship, USS Arlington, to the Middle East, amid escalating tensions with Iran. The USS Abraham Lincoln strike group has also joined the USS Arlington in the Gulf, with US B-52 bombers arriving at a base in Qatar. The Pentagon stated that the moves are a response to a possible threat to US forces in the region, without providing specific details.

Iran has dismissed the claim as "nonsense" and described the deployments as "psychological warfare" aimed at intimidating the country. Tehran has also suggested it may resume uranium enrichment nuclear activities. The US has not specified what specific threats it is responding to, but stated that it is "ready to defend US forces and interests in the region" and does not seek conflict with Iran.

The Patriot system can counter ballistic missiles, cruise missiles, and advanced aircraft. The USS Arlington had been scheduled to visit the region, but its deployment was brought forward to provide enhanced command and control capabilities. The USS Abraham Lincoln passed through the Suez Canal on Thursday.

Iran's semi-official Isna news agency quoted a senior Iranian cleric, Yousef Tabatabai-Nejad, as saying that the US military fleet could be "destroyed with one missile." The US has previously blacklisted Iran's elite Revolutionary Guard Corps, designating it as a foreign terrorist group, and has reimposed sanctions on the country, leading to a sharp downturn in its economy.

The Trump administration hopes to compel Iran to negotiate a "new deal" that would cover not only its nuclear activities but also its ballistic missile program and what officials call its "malign behavior" across the Middle East. Iran has threatened to retaliate to the US measures by blocking the Strait of Hormuz, through which about a fifth of all oil consumed globally passes.

The real battle for the fate of the Iran nuclear deal has begun. In the year since the Trump administration unilaterally withdrew from the deal, Iran and all the other parties have continued to implement the agreement. However, the US has been ratcheting up the pressure on Tehran, and the pressure on Iran's economy has been severe. The Iranian government has now decided to act, saying it will no longer respect restrictions on storing enriched uranium and heavy water, and setting deadlines for the other parties to implement their commitments. A difficult couple of months of diplomacy lie ahead, with no guarantee of success.

Title: Former Security Advisers Weigh in on Tensions Between Obama and Netanyahu

The relationship between former US President Barack Obama and Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has been marked by significant differences in their approaches and personalities, according to Yaakov Amidror, a former national security adviser to Netanyahu. While acknowledging that personal issues may have played a role, Amidror emphasized that the main issue lies in their differing views on the situation.

The two leaders' vastly different political backgrounds and ideologies made it inevitable that they would have disagreements. However, these differences were exacerbated by choices made along the way. Critics of Obama have said that he was not adequately attuned to the sensitivities of the alliance, and did not prepare Netanyahu for his decisions. Netanyahu, on the other hand, chose to focus on the most incendiary interpretations of Obama's policies, rather than emphasizing common ground.

When they do communicate, their conversations are described as robust and pointed. Netanyahu is known to make his points bluntly, while Obama is more reserved but can come across as condescending. According to Benjamin J. Rhodes, Obama's deputy national security adviser, their phone calls can last up to 90 minutes and are characterized by a desire to debate each other.

The two leaders first met in 2007, when their aides hastily arranged a meeting at Ronald Reagan Washington National Airport. At the time, Netanyahu was heading home, while Obama was returning from the campaign trail. Despite their differences, they reportedly had a good chemistry.

Title: Democratic Presidential Candidates Address LGBTQ Issues at Forum

Article:

Former US Vice President Joe Biden and eight other Democratic presidential candidates gathered at a forum in Los Angeles to discuss LGBTQ issues, with a focus on promoting equality and acceptance. The event, the second major presidential forum dedicated to LGBTQ issues, aimed to highlight the candidates' positions on issues affecting the LGBTQ community.

Biden, the front-runner in the Democratic race, defended his record on LGBTQ rights, stating that he would withhold foreign aid from countries that persecute lesbian, gay, bisexual, and transgender people. He also announced plans to establish an office in the State Department to promote LGBTQ rights worldwide.

South Bend, Indiana, Mayor Pete Buttigieg, who is vying to become the first openly gay US president, shared his personal experience as a gay man, recounting his time serving in the military while still closeted. He emphasized the need to change public health rules that bar gay men from donating blood, citing the HIV epidemic of the 1980s and 1990s.

Other candidates, including Senators Cory Booker, Bernie Sanders, Elizabeth Warren, and Kamala Harris, also participated in the forum. They discussed their plans to promote LGBTQ equality, including supporting the Equality Act, which would add LGBTQ protections to federal anti-discrimination law. They also emphasized the importance of making pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) accessible and affordable to all who want it.

The candidates' remarks highlighted the ongoing struggle for LGBTQ rights in the US, with many criticizing the Trump administration's record on LGBTQ issues. The event aimed to showcase the candidates' commitment to promoting equality and acceptance, with each candidate emphasizing the importance of elevating LGBTQ concerns as president.

**Supreme Court Faces Pressure to Unseal Documents in Death Penalty Case**

The recent execution of Christopher Price in Alabama has raised concerns about transparency and secrecy in the justice system. The case is unusual in that half of the briefs filed in the case were blacked out, and virtually all of the record was sealed. The Reporters Committee for Freedom of the Press and NPR have filed a motion with the Supreme Court requesting that the sealed material be unsealed.

The sealed information does not relate to Price's guilt or innocence, but rather concerns the drugs and protocol used in executions. Price had requested to be executed by nitrogen gas, which he believed would be less painful than death by lethal injection using the drug midazolam, which Alabama ultimately used.

The Supreme Court has allowed the deletions at the insistence of Alabama, citing a need for secrecy. However, the Reporters Committee argues that the state has not provided a legitimate reason for the secrecy and that the information is not related to the defendant's guilt or innocence.

The case has sparked concerns about the transparency of the justice system, with some arguing that the secrecy surrounding the execution protocol and expert evidence undermines the public's ability to understand the legal issues at play. The Reporters Committee points to the availability of appellate records and the importance of transparency in the judicial process.

The case has also raised questions about the balance between the need for secrecy and the public's right to know. The Supreme Court has historically been committed to transparency, with Chief Justice John Roberts stating that the judiciary is the most transparent branch of government. The court has also upheld the right of access to a wide range of judicial proceedings and records.

The case is ongoing, with the Reporters Committee seeking to unseal the sealed documents and the state of Alabama seeking to keep the information confidential. The outcome will have implications for the transparency of the justice system and the public's ability to understand the legal issues at play.

Title: Trump Administration's Abortion Restrictions Spark Debate Ahead of Midterm Elections

The Trump administration's recent actions to restrict abortion access have sparked a heated debate ahead of the midterm elections, with both sides claiming to have the upper hand. The restrictions, which include a proposal to ban recipients of federal family planning money from referring patients for abortions or sharing locations with abortion providers, have been hailed by anti-abortion groups as a major victory.

However, Democrats argue that these restrictions will ultimately hurt Republican candidates on the ballot in November. They point to the recent surge in women running for office and the high attendance at women's marches as proof that the Trump administration's actions will backfire.

Anti-abortion groups, on the other hand, believe that the restrictions will energize their base and help galvanize Republican voters. They argue that the restrictions are a necessary step to protect the lives of the unborn and that the public is increasingly supportive of their cause.

The stakes are high for both sides, with anti-abortion advocates seeking to elect more Republicans to the Senate who can pass a ban on abortions after 20 weeks, defund Planned Parenthood, and approve future Supreme Court nominees. Democrats, meanwhile, hope to gain control of both chambers and block such bills and fight back against policy changes from the administration.

The debate has already led to a surge in campaign spending, with both sides pouring millions into the midterms. Planned Parenthood has announced a $20 million campaign targeting eight states, while the anti-abortion Susan B. Anthony List aims to raise and spend $25 million. NARAL has also announced its largest-ever midterm investment of $5 million in 19 states.

The debate is expected to continue to shape the messaging of both parties heading into the 2020 presidential election.

Title: Trump Open to Meeting with North Korean Leader, Criticizes Putin and Putin's Actions in Ukraine

Article:

In a recent interview with Reuters, Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump expressed his willingness to engage in talks with North Korean leader Kim Jong Un to address the country's nuclear program. Trump stated that he would "speak to him" and "have no problem speaking to him," marking a potential shift in US policy towards the isolated nation.

Trump also shared his views on various other topics, including his disapproval of Russian President Vladimir Putin's actions in eastern Ukraine and his desire to renegotiate the Paris climate accord. He believes the US is treated unfairly in the agreement, which aims to reduce carbon emissions by over 170 countries.

Regarding the economy, Trump plans to release a detailed policy platform in two weeks, which he claims will dismantle nearly all of the Dodd-Frank financial regulations. He views Dodd-Frank as a "very negative force" that has developed a "bad name."

Trump also expressed concerns about the tech startup industry, stating that companies are attaining high valuations without generating profits. He believes a Republican should head the US Federal Reserve, but does not consider current chair Janet Yellen to be an enemy. He noted that he is a "low-interest rate person" unless inflation becomes a concern.

It is worth noting that Trump did not provide specific details on his plans to address North Korea's nuclear program, but a meeting with Kim would represent a significant shift in US policy towards the country.

Title: Amazon's CEO Jeff Bezos' Shift from Hero to Opportunist

Amazon's founder and CEO, Jeff Bezos, has gone from being a celebrated entrepreneur to a criticized figure in the eyes of some. The change in perception stems from his company's decision to lobby for a higher minimum wage, which some see as a move to stifle competition and benefit his own business.

Bezos' company has been praised for creating jobs and providing low prices, with the Federal Reserve Chairman attributing a decrease in the US inflation rate to Amazon's business model. However, some critics argue that the company's low prices come at the expense of its employees, with some workers eligible for government assistance programs like food stamps.

Amazon initially responded to the criticism by calling the claims "inaccurate" and "misleading." The company pointed out that it has created jobs and given workers better choices, and that more people would collect government assistance if Amazon did not hire. However, the company has since announced that it will pay all its workers at least $15 per hour, a move that some see as a way to curry favor with progressive politicians.

The move has been met with criticism from some who argue that a higher minimum wage will price out entry-level workers and make it harder for them to gain experience and work their way up the career ladder. A California restaurant manager, Merv Crist, explained that higher minimum wages can cut people out of the job market completely, making it harder for beginners, kids, and the disabled to find employment.

Amazon's decision to lobby for a higher minimum wage has also been seen as a way for Bezos to use government to stifle competition and protect his company's lead in automation. The company has already replaced some workers with robots, and a higher minimum wage could make it harder for competitors to attract workers and invest in automation.

The controversy surrounding Amazon's decision highlights the complex issues surrounding the minimum wage and the balance between business and government. While some see a higher minimum wage as a way to help workers, others argue that it can have unintended consequences and hurt certain groups of people.

Title: Romney's Convention Strategy: A Focus on Humanizing the Candidate and Addressing Concerns

The 40th Republican National Convention has come to a close, and political strategists are analyzing the poll numbers to gauge the post-convention bounce for Mitt Romney and Paul Ryan. The convention aimed to humanize Romney and address concerns that have been raised in focus groups. Romney's convention managers made some deliberate decisions, including not relitigating the 2008 election and acknowledging the hopes for change that motivated Barack Obama voters.

The convention featured a special call-out to young voters, who went 66 to 32 percent for Obama in the last election. Ryan addressed this demographic by talking about twenty-somethings in their childhood bedrooms, "staring up at fading Obama posters and wondering when they can move out and get going with life." The convention also reached out to the unquantifiable but undoubtedly large number of voters who feel that it would be a bad thing for Americans to be seen rejecting the first black president.

The convention included a unique moment with Clint Eastwood, who spoke without a teleprompter and effectively delivered a message about accountability. The event was not as tightly scripted as previous conventions, with speakers like Condoleezza Rice and Ann Romney delivering unscripted remarks. The convention floor was also home to testimonials from fellow church members about the Romneys' service and caring, which were genuinely moving and will likely be featured in TV ads.

The convention addressed concerns that have surfaced in focus groups, including the candidate's openness to women taking a lead role and his experience in creating businesses that employ tens of thousands of people. Romney's speech was praised by rank-and-file delegates and received limited praise from those with more experience. While not spectacular, it was considered good enough by many. Overall, the convention aimed to humanize Romney and demonstrate that he is a sufficient tool to do the job, which seems to have been achieved.

Title: White House Aide Resigns Amid Domestic Abuse Allegations, Second Official to Leave in a Week

The White House has announced the resignation of David Sorensen, a speechwriter, amid allegations of domestic abuse made by his former wife, Jessica Corbett. Sorensen denies the allegations, claiming he was the victim of physical abuse himself. This development comes just days after another Trump official, Rob Porter, resigned over similar allegations.

According to Corbett, Sorensen was physically abusive to her during their marriage, including running a car over her foot, throwing her against a wall, and extinguishing a cigarette on her hand. Sorensen has denied these allegations, stating he has "never committed violence of any kind against any woman in my entire life."

The White House learned of the allegations against Sorensen on Thursday and immediately confronted him, leading to his resignation. Deputy Press Secretary Raj Shah stated that Sorensen denied the allegations and resigned the same day.

This is the second high-profile resignation in a week, following Rob Porter's departure over allegations of domestic abuse from two ex-wives. Porter denies the allegations, but his ex-wives have spoken out about the abuse they suffered at his hands.

The controversy has raised questions about how long it took the White House to act on the accusations against Porter, with some critics suggesting that the administration was slow to respond. The White House has faced criticism for its handling of the situation, with some accusing it of downplaying the allegations.

In a statement, President Trump expressed surprise and sadness over the allegations against Porter, but did not refer to the accusers. The controversy has also put pressure on Chief of Staff John Kelly, who has denied reports that he offered to resign over his handling of the accusations.

The case has also raised questions about the White House's handling of security clearance applications, with reports suggesting that officials were aware of the allegations against Porter for several months but did not take action.

Title: Critique of Media and Government: A Call for Nuance and Accuracy

The article discusses the author's perception that the media and government have become increasingly biased and inaccurate in their reporting and decision-making. The author argues that the media often focuses on sensationalized headlines and government-centric thinking, rather than providing a balanced view of the issues. They also criticize the media for not acknowledging the existence of a "deep state" or "administrative state," which they believe is responsible for stifling innovation and freedom through excessive regulations.

The author specifically takes issue with The New York Times' article claiming that there is no "deep state" in the United States, arguing that this is a misconception. They point out that the government employs over 20 million people, many of whom are partisan and resistant to change. The author also criticizes the media for not acknowledging the partisan leanings of government employees, such as those working at the EPA.

The article also touches on the topic of climate change, with the author arguing that the media often presents a simplistic view of the issue, claiming that Scott Pruitt's views on climate change are "at odds with the established scientific consensus." However, the author notes that Pruitt's views are not necessarily anti-science, and that there is uncertainty surrounding the causes of climate change.

Finally, the author critiques comedian John Oliver's reporting on Venezuela, arguing that he failed to mention the country's socialist policies and instead attributed its economic woes to oil prices. The author believes that this is a common mistake made by many on the left, who are unable to see the flaws of socialism even when they are right in front of them.

Overall, the article presents a critique of the media and government, arguing that they often prioritize sensationalism and partisanship over accuracy and nuance.

Title: Republicans Divided on Healthcare Repeal, Democrats Plan to Play Offense

Article:

The debate over the Affordable Care Act (ACA), also known as Obamacare, is heating up as Republicans in the US House of Representatives prepare to vote on repealing the law. However, divisions are emerging within the Republican party, with some members suggesting that certain provisions should remain intact.

Representative Nan Hayworth, an ophthalmologist and a freshman Republican from New York, outlined a framework for alternative healthcare measures, including bolstered health savings accounts, the option to purchase insurance across state lines, medical malpractice limits, and a government-subsidized insurance pool for sick individuals who cannot afford insurance. However, these alternatives have not been widely discussed.

Some Republicans, facing re-election in swing districts, are advocating for a more measured approach, while others are pushing for a full repeal. Representative Pete Sessions of Texas, chairman of the National Republican Congressional Committee, stated that the healthcare law was passed with "deception at its core" and that the penalty for those who fail to purchase insurance has been unmasked as a tax on the middle class.

On the other hand, Democrats are planning to play offense, launching an advertising campaign portraying Republicans as controlled by insurance companies and intent on taking away popular consumer protections in the law. A series of news conferences are planned, featuring real-life families who would be harmed by repeal.

The Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee has started an advertising campaign, while a video will be released Monday using Speaker John A. Boehner's phrase "Mr. President, where are the jobs?" to mock the repeal exercise. Former Governor Tim Kaine of Virginia, a Democrat running for the Senate, stated that there is a strong sense that the country does not want to continue fighting over the healthcare law.

For Republicans in solidly conservative districts, the repeal vote is a way to energize their base and prove to constituents that the fight has not ended. However, Republican campaign consultants are more cautious, noting that voters are already energized by the prospect of voting against President Obama in November. The impact on independent voters is unclear.

Democrats are driving the narrative that voters are ready to move on, with some pushing for improvements to the healthcare law rather than debating its repeal. Dan Maffei, a former House Democrat from upstate New York, is using the Supreme Court's decision to push the debate toward improving the healthcare law, rather than whether it should stay or go.

Title: Union City: The Embroidery Capital of the World's Resilience in the Face of Globalization

Article:

Union City, New Jersey, is a city that defies expectations. Nestled in the heart of North Hudson, it is often overlooked by tourists and commuters alike, who are more focused on the nearby Lincoln Tunnel and Manhattan. However, this city has a rich history and a unique story to tell. Union City is known as the "embroidery capital of the world," a title that may seem surprising in today's globalized economy.

The city's embroidery industry thrived in the early 20th century, thanks to its unique geology and proximity to New York's shipping harbors. The city welcomed immigrants from various countries, including Switzerland, Germany, Italy, and Ireland, who brought their skills and traditions to the industry. Over time, the city became a hub of factory culture, with a strong union presence and a reputation for being a place where workers could walk down the street and see their colleagues running errands or heading to church.

However, the industry began to decline in the mid-20th century, as companies moved to the American South and globalization took hold. The North Jersey factory ecosystem, which once included breweries, industrial material manufacturers, and a giant soap factory, began to dwindle. Union City's embroidery industry collapsed, but the city itself did not. Small businesses, New York jobs, and an aggressive push by the municipal government to fill the embroidery void kept the city going.

Today, a few embroidery businesses still operate in the city, producing silk and lace. The city's story is one of resilience and adaptation, as it has learned to thrive in the face of economic challenges. It serves as a warning to those who wish to keep their governments contained, as big government decisions can have far-reaching consequences for local communities.

Title: Federal Reserve Expected to Raise Interest Rates, But Impact on Economy Uncertain

The Federal Reserve is likely to raise the federal funds rate at its two-day meeting on Wednesday, marking a significant shift in monetary policy since the depths of the financial crisis in 2008. The move is expected to push up the cost of mortgages, slow jobs creation, and curb stock prices, but the effects will depend on whether the 10-year Treasury rate increases.

The Federal Reserve's decision to raise the federal funds rate has the potential to impact various aspects of the economy. If the 10-year Treasury rate rises, rates on mortgages, corporate, and municipal bonds will likely follow, potentially slowing down the economy. However, the current state of household balance sheets and lower gasoline prices are expected to offset the effects of the rate increase, leading to economic growth of 2.5 to 3 percent in the New Year.

The banking industry is also expected to feel the impact of the rate increase. Banks' costs for providing retail services have increased due to tighter regulations, and higher short-term borrowing rates will make things even more challenging. As a result, banks may increase fees on checking accounts and other services, as well as charge higher rates for short-term credit, such as credit cards, car loans, and home improvements.

On the other hand, the stronger dollar and lower oil prices are pinching corporate profits, and hiring has slowed this year to about 210,000 new jobs per month, less than the 260,000 monthly average in 2014. Small businesses, which are a crucial source of new jobs in an economic recovery, may not be significantly impacted by the rate increase, as they have already faced challenges in accessing credit due to tighter regulations.

The article also notes that finding a job remains a significant challenge for the long-term unemployed, whose skills may have atrophied during the Great Recession and slow recovery. Government benefits, such as expanded Medicaid and food stamps for healthy men, have often overwhelmed incentives to reskill.

Overall, the article concludes that if Beijing can mount an adequate stimulus program to stabilize its economy, the global economy will not sink America's boat, and job gains will continue. Once gasoline prices have bottomed, overall inflation is expected to rise to about 2 percent. The market is likely to react positively to the rate increase, as uncertainty about timing has been removed.

Title: Supreme Court Blocks Trump Administration's Asylum Policy, Denying Immediate Enforcement

The Supreme Court has blocked the Trump administration's asylum policy, denying its request to immediately enforce a ban on asylum claims from immigrants who enter the US illegally. The 5-4 decision marks the second legal setback this week for the administration's efforts to tighten immigration rules.

In a brief written order, the court denied the administration's bid to enforce an asylum ban for immigrants who cross the US-Mexico border illegally. The decision leaves in place lower-court rulings that blocked the administration from automatically denying asylum to individuals who do not go through official border crossings.

The current legal challenge originated in California, where the 9th US Circuit Court of Appeals recently ruled against the administration, stating that the policy was likely "inconsistent" with existing law. The Supreme Court's decision was led by Chief Justice John Roberts, who sided with the four liberal justices. Newly confirmed Justice Brett Kavanaugh and three other conservative justices sided with the administration.

The decision comes after a federal judge in a separate case ordered that asylum seekers who were deported be returned to the US to have their claims heard anew. The White House responded to the ruling, stating that it will "further overwhelm our immigration courts with meritless cases, making the existing massive backlog even worse."

Despite the setbacks in the courts, the administration is moving forward with other changes. Department of Homeland Security Secretary Kirstjen Nielsen announced that the US has secured an agreement with Mexico to return immigrants claiming asylum to Mexico as their cases are processed, aiming to end the practice known as "catch-and-release."

Title: Sen. Chris Van Hollen Proposes Motion for Supreme Court Chief Justice to Decide on Witnesses in Trump Impeachment Trial

Sen. Chris Van Hollen (D-MD) plans to introduce a motion on Friday that would require Supreme Court Chief Justice John Roberts to determine whether the Senate will hear from witnesses in President Donald Trump's impeachment trial. The motion aims to ensure a fair trial by allowing the Chief Justice to subpoena witnesses and documents if deemed relevant to the articles of impeachment.

According to Sen. Van Hollen, this approach is consistent with Senate rules and could pass with a majority vote. The motion would also allow the Senate to overrule the Chief Justice if the majority disagrees. The senator emphasized that the Chief Justice, nominated by a Republican President, should not be feared, and his authority to rule on questions of privilege would not lead to a drawn-out process.

The motion is part of the Democratic argument that hearing from witnesses will clarify the president's alleged wrongdoing. The two main individuals Democrats want to hear from are former National Security Adviser John Bolton and Acting White House Chief of Staff Mick Mulvaney. Republicans, however, argue that any witnesses should have been called during the House investigation, and the White House's invocation of executive privilege has prevented this.

The motion comes after Speaker Nancy Pelosi pushed forward with the impeachment inquiry, despite the White House's claims that the courts could take a long time to determine whether the testimony was a matter of national security. The outcome of Sen. Van Hollen's motion remains to be seen, as it will be up to the Senate to decide whether to adopt it.

Title: Obama's College Ranking Plan Faces Criticism: Focus Shifts to Measuring Work-Ready Skills

Article:

President Obama recently proposed a plan to rank colleges based on metrics such as graduation rates and graduate earnings, with the goal of improving the quality of higher education. However, the plan has not been well-received by lawmakers, who argue that it does not address the root issue of employers' skepticism about the value of college credentials.

Critics point out that the modern workplace demands more than just subject-area knowledge, which can be easily accessed through online resources. Instead, employers are looking for graduates with cognitive skills such as critical thinking, problem-solving, and quantitative reasoning. These skills, known as competency-based learning, are essential for success in a rapidly changing global economy.

A 2011 study found that at least 45% of college students showed little or no improvement in critical-thinking skills after their first two years in college. This may explain why 57% of Americans believe that colleges fail to provide good value for the money. A 2010 survey found that only 1 in 4 employers believe that colleges prepare students for the global economy.

To address these concerns, lawmakers are exploring alternative scorecards that measure a graduate's work-ready skills. One such test is the Collegiate Learning Assessment (CLA+), which measures a person's ability to "access, structure, and use information." The test costs $35 and takes about 90 minutes. Several states have tied government aid to such tests and other measures of "learning outcomes." A few hundred colleges plan to administer the CLA+ test this year.

The test also offers a way for students who take free or for-profit online courses to gain a credible credential for employment. Advanced economies that rely on innovation need advanced thinkers, or those adept at higher-order skills such as perception and creativity. President Obama and Congress need to rethink the meaning and purpose of the college degree to ensure that it prepares students for the demands of the modern workforce.

Title: Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell's Plan to End Filibuster on Supreme Court Nominees

Article:

Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell has announced his intention to end the use of the filibuster on nominees to the Supreme Court, a move that has sparked controversy and debate. In an interview with NBC's "Meet the Press," McConnell stated that he had already made up his mind to end the filibuster, and that the Democrats would be responsible for making him do so.

When asked if he had any regrets over the matter, McConnell referenced the nomination of Neil Gorsuch to the Supreme Court, saying that if the shoe had been on the other foot, the Democrats would not have filled a Republican president's vacancy. In a separate interview with "Fox News Sunday," McConnell declined to comment on whether Republicans would unilaterally change the Senate rules via the "nuclear option" to confirm Gorsuch.

Adam Jentleson, a former deputy chief of staff to Senator Harry Reid, pointed out in a New York Times op-ed that McConnell's relentless opposition to President Obama's agenda led to Reid's decision to end the filibuster on lower court nominees. McConnell's actions, Jentleson argued, were part of a broader pattern of obstructionism and refusal to work with Democrats, regardless of the substance of the issue.

McConnell's actions have been criticized by some as a further erosion of the Senate's institutional norms and a move that prioritizes party politics over the country's best interests. His decision to end the filibuster on Supreme Court nominees has been seen as a significant departure from the traditional norms of the Senate, and has sparked concerns about the long-term implications for the institution.

Title: Clinton Emphasizes Shared Goals with Sanders on Income Inequality, Refuses to Release Wall Street Speech Transcripts

Article:

Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton emphasized her shared goals with Senator Bernie Sanders on addressing income inequality during a "Good Morning America" town hall meeting on Thursday. Clinton, who won the New York primary with a significant margin, used rhetoric reminiscent of Sanders' campaign to drive home her point. She stated that both she and Sanders want to tackle inequality, raise the minimum wage, and regulate industries that pose risks to the economy.

Clinton's comments came as she faced criticism from her left-leaning opponents, who question her authenticity on the topic of income inequality. The criticism stems from her highly-paid speeches to security firms and banks, such as Goldman Sachs, after her tenure as Secretary of State. Sanders has called on Clinton to release the transcripts of those speeches, which she has refused to do.

Clinton responded to the request by saying that she will release the transcripts when others do the same. She noted that she, like her predecessors Colin Powell and Condoleezza Rice, has given speeches to various groups after leaving office, sharing her unique perspective on global events. Clinton emphasized that her speeches were primarily focused on what's happening in the world, rather than promoting any specific agenda.

**House Republicans Delay August Recess Amid Border Security Bill Uncertainty**

House Republicans are poised to delay their August recess by one day as they struggle to pass a border security bill. The bill, which aimed to provide $659 million in funding for border security measures, was pulled from the House floor on Thursday after failing to garner sufficient support.

The decision is embarrassing for new GOP Whip Steve Scalise, who had been tasked with rallying support for the bill. The legislation was rewritten twice to attract more votes, but ultimately fell short. The bill's failure means lawmakers will not be heading home for their five-week recess as planned.

The bill aimed to address the influx of migrants across the U.S.-Mexico border, providing funding for border security measures and revising a 2008 anti-trafficking law. However, hard-right conservatives opposed the bill, demanding tougher border-security and immigration provisions, including the repeal of the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) program.

The White House criticized the House's plan, stating that it would restrict a law enforcement tool used to focus resources on key enforcement priorities like public safety and border security, while providing temporary relief from deportation for people who are low priorities for removal.

The episode is a setback for House Republicans, who had hoped to pass the bill and demonstrate their commitment to addressing the border crisis. The delay will allow lawmakers to continue working on the bill, but it also means they will not be heading home to their districts to hear from voters on the issue.

Title: Bernie Sanders' California Push Narrows Gap with Hillary Clinton Ahead of Primary Election

Bernie Sanders' campaign is gaining momentum in California, with the Vermont senator closing in on Hillary Clinton in the state's primary election, which takes place on Tuesday. According to Real Clear Politics, Clinton holds a narrow lead over Sanders, with an average margin of 4.7 points. In recent polls, Sanders has pulled ahead of Clinton by as little as two points, with one poll even showing him winning by a single point.

The Sanders campaign is banking on a victory in California, the most populous state, to encourage superdelegates who currently support Clinton to switch their allegiances. Sanders' campaign manager, Jeff Weaver, stated that many of Clinton's superdelegates announced their support for her before the race began and before recent polls showed a tightening race. "We have the establishment very nervous, and that's a good thing," Sanders said at a rally at the University of California-Davis, which drew around 9,000 people.

Donald Trump's campaign is also taking notice of the tightening race, with his national co-chairman and chief policy adviser, Sam Clovis, saying that Sanders is "right over her shoulder" and making a drastic pivot to the left as a result.

However, even with a decisive win in California, it's unlikely that Sanders will be able to catch Clinton, as the state's 475 delegates are awarded proportionally, not winner-take-all. Clinton only needs 256 pledged delegates to clinch the nomination, and with 763 pledged delegates still available between now and the Tuesday primaries in California and five other states, she can secure the nomination even before California's polls close.

If Sanders does defeat Clinton, Republicans could use her loss to depict her as a flawed general election candidate, while Sanders could use the victory to stay in the race through the July convention, forcing Clinton to fight a two-front battle for longer than expected. Sanders has been campaigning hard in California since May 17, and Clinton has also been spending time in the state, including a headline-making speech in San Diego where she slammed Trump over foreign policy.

Title: Supreme Court Blocks Indiana Law Prohibiting Abortions Based on Fetal Characteristics, Allows Fetal Remains Disposal Requirement

The Supreme Court has ruled that a provision in an Indiana law prohibiting abortions motivated solely by the race, sex, or disability of the fetus will remain blocked. However, the court did allow a separate provision requiring clinics to bury or cremate fetal remains to take effect. The decision suggests that the court is not currently inclined to challenge its core abortion precedents, such as Roe v. Wade and Casey v. Planned Parenthood.

The Indiana law, signed in 2016 by then-Gov. Mike Pence, was blocked by the 7th US Circuit Court of Appeals last year. The law's supporters, including Pence, have defended the measure as a victory for life. However, opponents argue that the provision violates well-established Supreme Court precedent and is unconstitutional.

In his dissenting opinion, Justice Clarence Thomas wrote that the court should soon address the issue, stating that "although the Court declines to wade into these issues today, we can't avoid them forever." Thomas also spent 15 pages discussing the history of eugenics and its connection to the abortion debate.

While Thomas's opinion does not necessarily indicate that the court will immediately take up the issue, Supreme Court analyst Steve Vladeck notes that none of the other conservative justices joined his separate opinion. This suggests that the court may not be eager to jump into the sensitive political thicket.

The court did allow the provision requiring fetal remains to be buried or cremated to take effect, with Justice Thomas writing that it is "easy to understand why the District Court and the Seventh Circuit looked to Casey to resolve a question it did not address." The law requires that fetal remains be disposed of in the same way as other human remains, and a separate provision prohibits abortion solely motivated by the race, sex, or disability of the fetus.

The decision is a significant development in the ongoing debate over abortion rights and the role of the Supreme Court in shaping those rights.

Title: Bipartisan Disapproval of Iran Nuclear Deal Won't Stop Obama's Implementation

The Iranian nuclear deal is facing strong bipartisan disapproval in the US Congress, but President Barack Obama is expected to implement the agreement despite the opposition. The vote on the deal is shaping up as a warning to Europe against resuming business with Tehran before the next US president is elected.

Senate Minority Leader Harry Reid has become the highest-profile Democrat to endorse the deal, stating that it is the best path to stop Iran from obtaining a nuclear weapon. However, clear bipartisan majorities in the House and Senate are lining up against the deal.

Despite this opposition, President Obama has broad executive authority to ease many sanctions on Iran by himself. Analysts say he has a plan to circumvent Congress and can delist Iranian banks, commercial entities, and individuals targeted for sanctions. He can also order the Treasury Department to give out licenses allowing financial and commercial transactions with Iranian businesses.

The president can also provide sanctions relief for Iranian oil exports by treating legislation passed by Congress in 2012 as unconstitutional. Section 1245 of the National Defense Authorization Act required the president to freeze assets of Iranian banks, including the Central Bank of Iran, and aimed to reduce Iranian oil revenue by imposing sanctions on foreign banks that carry out "significant financial transactions" with the central bank. However, President Obama issued a "signing statement" on Section 1245 when he approved the overall legislation, stating that he could treat that section as nonbinding because it "would interfere with my constitutional authority to conduct foreign relations."

The White House has gained support from Rep. Jerrold Nadler, New York Democrat, who said the deal offers "the best chance of stopping Iran from developing a nuclear weapon." Rep. Donald Norcross, New Jersey Democrat, has also announced he will vote against the agreement, stating that a better deal can be achieved.

The opposition to the deal is not limited to Republicans, with 29 senators, including two Democrats, voting against it. In the House, 225 lawmakers, including 16 Democrats, have announced they will vote against the deal. Despite the opposition, lawmakers would need to muster a two-thirds majority vote in the House and the Senate to override President Obama's expected veto of the Iran resolution.

The ultimate size of the vote against the agreement will influence European governments and industries about the prospects of US policymakers seeking a tougher deal after President Obama leaves office.

Title: Journalists' Definition of "Fake News" Remains Elusive, Raises Concerns of Censorship

Article:

In the aftermath of Donald Trump's unexpected presidential victory, liberal journalists have launched a campaign against "fake news," blaming it for the perceived disconnect between political journalists and everyday Americans. However, the definition of "fake news" remains unclear, with many liberal journalists lumping in legitimate news organizations alongside objectively false sources.

A recent list compiled by a liberal college professor, which was widely distributed by some liberal journalists, included top right-of-center sites like Independent Journal Review (IJR) and The Blaze alongside objectively fake sites. The Washington Post labeled one website as "fake news" without providing evidence, prompting a threatened lawsuit. Meanwhile, liberal media organizations like the Los Angeles Times and New York magazine distributed the list to their readers.

The controversy has raised concerns that the crackdown on "fake news" sites will be used by liberals to censor their conservative competitors. Forbes contributor Frank Miniter argued that some liberals are using the "fake news" controversy to invite government control over First Amendment-protected speech or ask social media platforms to become bigger censors of certain views.

Media Research Center director of media analysis Tim Graham warned that the danger lies in defining "fake news" as "fake angles," or topics that should not be explored, such as the funding of protests. Conservative website The Daily Wire was listed as "fake news" without justification, prompting contributor John Nolte to warn that the "fake news" label is being used by frustrated liberal journalists to censor conservative viewpoints.

The controversy highlights the challenges in defining "fake news" and the potential risks of censorship. As the debate continues, it remains unclear what constitutes "fake news" and whether the term will be used to silence competing ideas or promote a more nuanced understanding of the media landscape.

**Fake University in Metro Detroit: Over 90 Foreign Students Arrested for Immigration Violations**

A total of approximately 250 foreign students at a fake university in metro Detroit, created by the Department of Homeland Security, have been arrested in recent months for immigration violations. The students, mostly from India, had arrived legally in the U.S. on student visas but lost their immigration status after the university was shut down in January.

The University of Farmington, which marketed itself as offering graduate programs in technology and computer studies, was staffed with undercover agents posing as university officials. The students had enrolled through a program known as Curricular Practical Training, which allows students to work in the U.S. through a F-1 visa program for foreign students.

According to ICE officials, nearly 80% of the arrested students have been granted voluntary departure and departed the United States, while about half of the remaining 20% have received a final order of removal.
