The remaining 10% are contesting their removals with the Executive Office for Immigration Review.

Seven of the eight recruiters who were criminally charged with trying to recruit students have pleaded guilty and been sentenced in Detroit. The remaining defendant is scheduled to be sentenced in January.

Attorneys for the students arrested argue that they were unfairly trapped by the U.S. government, as the Department of Homeland Security had listed the university as legitimate on its website, and an accreditation agency had also listed it as a legitimate institution. The students had paid an average of $12,000 in tuition and fees per year.

The fake university is believed to have collected millions of dollars from unsuspecting students. No one has filed a lawsuit or claim against the U.S. government for collecting the money or for allegedly entrapping the students.

ICE and the Department of Justice maintain that the students should have known it was not a legitimate university because it did not have classes in a physical location. However, some students who transferred from the university after realizing it did not have classes on-site were still arrested.

Title: Clinton's Email Server: A Threat to National Security

The newly confirmed secretary of State, Hillary Clinton, has been criticized for her decision in 2009 to use a personal email server for official business, rather than an official State Department account. A recent report by the State Department's inspector general has revealed that this decision had far-reaching consequences, putting national security at risk.

The report highlights four specific warnings that Clinton and her top aides ignored, despite being aware of the potential threats. In January 2011, hackers attacked Clinton's private server, prompting her staffer to shut it off to protect sensitive data. Two months later, the assistant secretary for diplomatic security sent a memo warning of a significant increase in attempts to compromise private home email accounts, potentially gaining access to policy documents and personal information.

In May 2011, Clinton herself suspected a hacking incident when she received an email with a suspicious link. Hours later, she received another email with a suspect link from the under secretary of State for political affairs. A month later, the State Department sent a cable to all diplomatic and consular posts, warning of the dangers of unsecured personal email accounts.

Despite these warnings, Clinton and her top aides continued to use personal email for sensitive State Department business thousands of times. The report raises questions about Clinton's judgment and her ability to prioritize national security over personal convenience.

Clinton has yet to fully explain her decision to use a personal email server, and her refusal to answer questions from the Obama administration-appointed inspector general has sparked concerns about her transparency. As a presidential candidate, she will need to convince voters that she can put the national security of the United States above her own self-interest.

The investigation into Clinton's email practices is ongoing, and it remains to be seen whether she broke the rules or the law.

Title: Homeland Security Reports 1.17% of Visa Holders Overstayed Their Visas in 2015, Raising Concerns Over National Security

The U.S. Department of Homeland Security has released a report revealing that nearly 1.17% of the 45 million temporary visas issued to business and tourist travelers between October 2014 and September 2015 were not honored, with over 527,000 individuals overstaying their visas. According to the report, this means that more than 400,000 of these individuals were still likely in the U.S. three months later.

The report highlights a significant loophole in immigration enforcement and national security, as those who overstayed their visas are not prioritized for removal unless they pose a national security threat or are serious criminals. This means that thousands of individuals from countries connected to terrorism, including Afghanistan, Iraq, Iran, Libya, Pakistan, Syria, and Yemen, may have remained in the country.

Senator Jeff Sessions, chairman of the immigration subcommittee, expressed concern over the issue, stating that it erodes public confidence and sends a message that individuals can get away with overstaying their visas. Senator Chuck Grassley, Iowa Republican, noted that the numbers are likely in the millions when combined with previous years' overstays.

The report also highlights the difficulty in tracking overstays, as the government relies on passenger information from airlines to complete its checks, leaving the system susceptible to errors or fraud. Lawmakers on both sides of the aisle have called for a biometric exit system to address this issue.

The report does not cover major visa categories for students or guest workers, which analysts believe are likely to be even worse than tourism and business visas. Homeland Security officials have promised to release those figures next year.

The issue of visa overstays has been a long-standing concern, with at least five of the 9/11 hijackers having arrived in the U.S. on legal visas but overstayed their welcome. The report's release is more than a decade overdue, and the government is still struggling to implement a biometric exit system.

In the meantime, lawmakers are urging the administration to find a solution to the problem, particularly after Congress dedicated $1 billion from visa fees to address the issue. The report highlights the need for a more effective system to track and remove individuals who overstay their visas, ensuring national security and public confidence.

Title: Thousands Download 3D-Printed Gun Blueprints Amid Controversy and Legal Action

The blueprints for 3D-printed guns, designed by Defense Distributed, were made available online four days earlier than expected, sparking controversy and legal action. The designs, which include nine types of guns, were uploaded to the Defense Distributed website on Friday, despite a US Justice Department ruling that Americans could access and reproduce the technical data.

The controversy surrounding 3D-printed guns began in 2013 when Cody Wilson, a self-styled crypto-anarchist, showcased the world's first 3D-printed gun. The files showing how to replicate the process were initially made available on the Defense Distributed website, leading the US State Department to order their removal. A four-year legal battle ensued, with Defense Distributed joining forces with the Second Amendment Foundation to sue the State Department. Last month, the US Justice Department ruled that Americans may access, discuss, use, and reproduce the technical data, leading to a backlash from lawmakers.

Washington State Attorney General Bob Ferguson announced on Monday that his state would be suing the State Department to stop the illegal distribution of 3D-printed guns on behalf of eight US states. Ferguson expressed concerns that the downloadable guns are unregistered and difficult to detect, even with metal detectors, and will be available to anyone regardless of age, mental health, or criminal history.

Twenty-one attorneys general from states including California, Massachusetts, Virginia, and Pennsylvania also sent a letter to the State Department, urging it to reinstate its ban on 3D-printed guns. They argued that the settlement terms and proposed rules are "deeply dangerous" and could have an unprecedented impact on public safety, providing another path to gun ownership for those prohibited by federal and state law from possessing firearms.

Cody Wilson has hailed his victory as the beginning of "the age of the downloadable gun," while critics are concerned that it will lead to a massive rise in so-called ghost guns, unregistered weapons the government is unaware of and unable to trace. Since the legal action began, Defense Distributed has been working on new gun designs and has created a milling device called Ghost Gunner, which can turn parts purchased online into a fully working weapon.

Title: House Speaker Pelosi Announces Impeachment Proceedings Against President Trump, Citing Concerns Over Ukraine Aid

Article:

House Speaker Nancy Pelosi announced on December 6, 2019, that the House of Representatives will draft articles of impeachment against President Donald Trump. Pelosi warned that if the president is allowed to be above the law, it would be a threat to the republic. However, Democrats have struggled to identify any specific laws that Trump has broken.

One of the Democrats' star witnesses, Army Lieutenant Colonel Alexander Vindman, testified that the National Security Council found the 55-day pause in U.S. military aid to Ukraine to be lawful. The White House should dispatch Marine One to fly over Capitol Hill and hurl hundreds of copies of this legal opinion through the windows and into the curious hands below.

Trump's request to Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky to investigate alleged Ukrainian interference in the 2016 election and corruption accusations against the Bidens conformed to the Treaty with Ukraine on Mutual Legal Assistance in Criminal Matters, signed by President Clinton in 1998 and ratified by the Senate in 2000. The treaty allows for mutual assistance in investigating, prosecuting, and preventing offenses.

The aid pause was within Trump's responsibility to ensure that $391 million did not vanish down a black hole of graft. OMB official Mark Sandy attributed the hold to Trump's concern about other countries not contributing money to Ukraine. Trump also stated that he gave the money because Republican Senator Rob Portman and others called him and asked, but he doesn't like to be the sucker.

Delays in foreign aid are nothing new. The hold on security assistance to Ukraine was not significant, and Trump withheld $300 million in aid to Pakistan last year for neglecting its anti-terrorism commitments. Obama chopped aid to Uganda in 2014 after it adopted cruel anti-gay statutes. Human-rights worries prompted President Carter to slice aid to Argentina, Ethiopia, and Uruguay.

Despite the controversy, Ukraine received its lethal military aid on September 11. If the funds were unallocated on October 1, that would have been illegal. However, the funds beat the September 30 Fiscal Year-end deadline by 19 days.

There is no way to know President Trump's state of mind on September 11. Trump opponents presume that he released the aid as a panicked reaction to the whistleblower's emergence. However, this claim goes beyond the facts and delves into conjecture and clairvoyance.

Title: Dave Chappelle's Latest Stand-up Special "Sticks & Stones" Sparks Controversy

Dave Chappelle's latest Netflix stand-up special, "Sticks & Stones," has generated significant attention and debate among audiences and critics. The special features a secret epilogue, "The Punchline," where Chappelle answers questions from audience members who attended his separate "Dave Chappelle on Broadway" show last July. The special takes his anti-wokeness schtick to a new level, with some critics finding it repetitive and exhausting.

Chappelle's latest special builds upon his previous Netflix specials, "The Age of Spin: Dave Chappelle Live at the Hollywood Palladium" and "Equanimity and the Bird Revelation," which honed his voice as a comedian wary of progressive criticism. In his latest routine, he makes controversial statements, including his disbelief in Michael Jackson's alleged molestation of young children and his continued jokes about transgender people.

Chappelle also defends fellow comedians Kevin Hart and Louis C.K., portraying them as victims of an overzealous callout culture. The special includes jokes about a Chinese person being stuck in a Black man's body, which some have criticized as racist.

The Q&A segment at the end of the special showcases Chappelle's unapologetic approach to courting controversy. He shares a story about a white woman who left one of his practice sets at The Punchline comedy club in San Francisco, telling him she was raped. Chappelle responds with a joke, saying "It's not your fault you were raped. But it's not my fault either. Ta-ta, bitch," which some have criticized as insensitive.

Chappelle also shares a story about befriending a trans woman who laughed the hardest at his trans jokes, which some have accused him of using as a way to appear inclusive without making any significant changes to his comedy style. Chappelle's approach has been met with criticism, with some accusing him of ignoring historic criticism against his style of comedy and refusing to adapt to changing societal norms.

As Chappelle continues down this path, some worry that his legacy may be tarnished by his refusal to acknowledge and address the concerns of marginalized communities.

Title: Foxconn Shifts Focus of Wisconsin Plant from Manufacturing to Research Hub

Foxconn Technology Group has announced that its planned $10 billion Wisconsin campus, initially touted as a hub for blue-collar manufacturing jobs, will instead focus on research and development. The company claims it remains committed to creating 13,000 jobs as promised, but the shift has been met with criticism and skepticism.

The project, which was announced in 2017, was touted as a major investment in American manufacturing, with President Donald Trump and Wisconsin Governor Scott Walker participating in a groundbreaking ceremony. The deal included a $4 billion incentive package from the state and local governments, with Foxconn agreeing to invest $10 billion and create 13,000 jobs.

However, Foxconn has already fallen short on its job creation promises, hiring only 178 full-time employees instead of the targeted 260. The company has also failed to earn a state tax credit worth up to $9.5 million.

Foxconn's decision to shift its focus from manufacturing to research and development has been met with criticism from some quarters, with Wisconsin Assembly Minority Leader Gordon Hintz calling it a "bait-and-switch." The company's special assistant, Louis Woo, stated that the decision was made due to changes in the global market environment, but critics argue that Foxconn's true intentions were always to create a research hub.

Economic development officials and supporters of the project are urging patience, citing the company's plans to invest what it promised. However, critics argue that the incentives promised to Foxconn were too rich and that the company may never fulfill its promises.

The shift in focus has also sparked debate about the effectiveness of the state's economic development strategies and the role of government incentives in attracting businesses. The Wisconsin Technology Council's president, Tom Still, believes that Foxconn can still succeed if the plant becomes more research-oriented, citing the company's areas of interest aligning with Wisconsin's strengths in robotics, medical imaging, and industrial imaging.

The White House had no immediate comment on the matter.

Title: The Minimum Wage Debate: A Complex Issue with Unintended Consequences

The minimum wage, set to rise to $15 per hour, has sparked a heated debate among politicians and economists. Some argue that it is a necessary step to ensure fair compensation for employees, while others claim it is an overreach by the government into the employer-employee relationship. The debate raises questions about the role of government in the economy and the unintended consequences of such a move.

The minimum wage, a political compromise rather than a market-driven decision, may have profound economic consequences. Some argue that it will lead to higher prices for goods and services, making certain products unaffordable for some individuals. Others claim that it will result in higher unemployment, as employers may choose not to employ certain individuals due to the increased labor costs.

The debate also touches on the fundamental principles of the Constitution, which protects the right of individuals to enter into contracts freely. Some argue that the government's interference in the employer-employee relationship is a violation of this principle. Others claim that the government has a role in ensuring fair compensation for employees.

The article highlights the potential unintended consequences of the minimum wage increase, including the transfer of wealth from consumers to employees, rather than from employers. It also raises questions about the government's understanding of the way businesses earn money, create wealth, and pay salaries, suggesting that the government's mindset is stuck on a governmental economic model that has no competition, guaranteed revenue, and no creation of wealth.

The article concludes by asking what the consequences of this move will be and whether the politicians who implemented it truly understand the effects of their actions. It also questions whether the minimum wage increase is a genuine attempt to help the poor or simply a means to win votes.

Title: Senate Delays Vote on Military Airstrikes in Syria Amid Growing Opposition

The Senate has delayed a vote on a resolution authorizing military airstrikes in Syria, as opposition builds among senators in both parties. Six senators, including five Republicans and one Democrat, have announced they will vote against the resolution, making it increasingly unlikely that the administration will garner the necessary support.

Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid announced the delay, stating that the president needs more time to make his case to senators and the public. The delay comes as reports emerge that Russia is seeking a deal with Syria to dismantle its chemical weapons program, which could potentially circumvent the need for US military intervention.

Some senators have expressed skepticism about the Russian proposal, with Senator Lindsey Graham stating that he is "very dubious and skeptical" about its success. Secretary of State John Kerry's comments describing the military effort as "unbelievably small" have also raised concerns among lawmakers.

Five Republican senators and one Democrat have announced their opposition to the resolution, citing concerns about the potential consequences of military action. Senator Lamar Alexander stated that he sees too much risk that the strike will do more harm than good, while Senator Heidi Heitkamp is working on an alternative resolution that would give the Assad government 45 days to sign an international chemical weapons ban and begin turning over its chemical weapons.

Despite the growing opposition, some senators still support the resolution, with Senator Lindsey Graham stating that it could still pass the Senate if the president does a good job making his case. The president will visit separately with Senate Democrats and Republicans on Tuesday before his prime-time television address.

**Korean Leaders' Delegation Holds "Frank and Candid" Talks Amid Skepticism**

SEOUL (Yonhap News Agency) - A high-ranking North Korean delegation, led by Kim Yo Jong, the younger sister of North Korean leader Kim Jong Un, concluded its visit to South Korea on Sunday, holding "frank and candid" talks with South Korean President Moon Jae-in. The delegation's three-day visit aimed to improve inter-Korean relations, but still faces deep skepticism over Pyongyang's sincerity.

During the visit, Moon met Kim Yo Jong four times, and the two sides discussed the possibility of a summit between the two leaders. According to the Blue House, Kim Jong Un invited Moon to visit Pyongyang "at his earliest convenience" and expressed his desire to meet him "in the near future."

The North Korean delegation also handed over a personal letter from Kim Jong Un to Moon, stating his "intention," although the contents of the letter were not disclosed. The delegation's visit concluded with a farewell dinner and a performance by a North Korean orchestra.

South Korean officials have expressed skepticism over Pyongyang's intentions, citing the lack of concrete steps towards denuclearization. The main opposition party, Liberty Korea Party, warned that any talks without a precondition of denuclearization would only benefit the North Korean regime.

The United States, South Korea, and Japan remain united in their stance against North Korea's nuclear and missile programs, with U.S. Vice President Mike Pence stating that the three countries are in complete agreement on isolating North Korea until it abandons its nuclear and ballistic missile program.

The North Korean delegation's visit has sparked a mix of emotions, with some South Koreans expressing hope for improved relations, while others remain skeptical. The delegation's return to Pyongyang on Sunday marked the end of their visit, with the North Korean orchestra set to return home on Monday.

**USCIS Admits Gang Member, Illegal Alien with Murder Charges, Was Approved for DACA**

The U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services (USCIS) has acknowledged that a gang member and illegal alien, Jesus Rangel-Hernandez, was approved for the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) program despite being in removal proceedings. Rangel-Hernandez has been charged with four counts of first-degree murder in North Carolina.

According to USCIS records, Rangel-Hernandez requested deferred action in January 2013, while he was in removal proceedings as an alien present in the United States without being admitted or paroled. At the time of his request, he was arrested for possession of marijuana, but the charges were subsequently dismissed. There was no indication that U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) was aware of his gang affiliation at the time of the arrest.

Rangel-Hernandez's request for deferred action was approved on August 26, 2013, despite a TECS record indicating that he was a known gang member. His application for employment authorization was also approved. After his deferred action request was approved, immigration proceedings were administratively closed on December 18, 2013.

In February 2015, Rangel-Hernandez allegedly murdered four people in North Carolina. He was scheduled for deportation but was able to stay in the country due to his DACA status.

The incident has sparked concerns about the effectiveness of the DACA program in keeping criminals out of the country. North Carolina Senators Richard Burr and Thom Tillis have called for improved criminal background checks to prevent similar tragedies from occurring in the future.

The Senate Judiciary Committee will hold a hearing today to examine the Obama administration's Central American Minors Refugee and Parole Program, which was used by MS-13 gang members to gain entry into the United States during the unaccompanied minor crisis last summer.

Title: Senate Tax Overhaul: New Data Reveals Shift in Resource Allocation

The Congressional Budget Office (CBO) has released a report analyzing the Senate's tax overhaul, providing a detailed look at its impact on taxpayers across various income groups. The report highlights a significant shift in resource allocation, with the wealthy benefiting more than lower-income Americans.

According to the CBO data, the Senate bill would move resources away from lower-income individuals and towards upper and upper-middle-class Americans. The report shows that lower-income groups would face overall losses, while upper-income groups would experience significant gains.

The analysis reveals that the wealthy would gain the most in dollar amounts, with benefits reaching up to $59,000 per tax filer. When factoring in the higher and lower incomes involved, the wealthy would gain the most relative to their income. For instance, Americans making $10,000 to $20,000 would see a loss worth just 0.14% of their income, while those making $500,000 to $1 million would see a net benefit worth nearly 3% of their income.

The article also examines the population size of each group, with lower-income groups having larger amounts of taxpayers but benefiting far less from the tax overhaul. Higher-income groups, on the other hand, have fewer taxpayers but would gain many times more from the GOP bill.

The report's findings contradict the common notion that the wealthy would benefit more due to their larger incomes. Instead, the data shows that the GOP tax plan would shift resources away from the poor and towards the rich, reversing the current progressive tax system.

Title: Women Candidates Play Key Role in Senate Elections

The 2014 midterm elections are shaping up to be a crucial test for both parties, with Republicans seeking to flip six Democratic-held seats to gain control of the Senate. Amidst the intense political drama, women candidates are taking center stage, with several high-profile contenders vying for seats in key states.

In Kentucky, Democratic nominee Alison Lundergan Grimes is running a fierce challenge to Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell, using her gender to appeal to female voters who make up more than half the Kentucky electorate. Grimes has been playing up the fact that McConnell is especially unpopular with women, with polls showing a significant gender gap.

In Georgia, Michelle Nunn, daughter of veteran Sen. Sam Nunn, is the Democrats' other big hope for picking up a GOP Senate seat. Nunn has been emphasizing her qualifications and experience, saying, "I believe that change is possible."

On the Republican side, Monica Wehby, a pediatric neurosurgeon, is running as a political outsider in Oregon, vying to unseat Democrat Jeff Merkley. Wehby has been touting her own qualifications, saying, "I'm not a career politician."

In West Virginia, Republicans are favored to pick up a Democratic seat with Shelley Moore Capito, who would be the state's first female senator. Even if she loses to Democrat Natalie Tennant, the state would still elect its first female senator.

Currently, there are 20 women senators, a record but still far from representative of the country, which is more than 50% female. The 2014 elections could mark another historic number, with women playing a crucial role in shaping the balance of power in the Senate.

Title: Trump Signs Executive Orders to Revive Keystone XL and Dakota Access Pipelines

The President of the United States, Donald Trump, signed executive orders on Tuesday to revive the controversial Keystone XL and Dakota Access pipelines, which had been stalled by the previous administration under pressure from environmental and other groups. The orders aim to renegotiate the terms of the projects and expedite reviews and approvals for the remaining parts of the Dakota project.

According to the White House Press Secretary, Sean Spicer, Trump directed agencies to approve the Keystone XL pipeline without delay and to expedite reviews and approvals for the remaining parts of the Dakota project. The President also signed three other orders related to pipeline construction, including one expediting the environmental permitting process for infrastructure projects and one directing the Commerce Department to maximize the use of U.S. steel.

The Keystone XL pipeline, which would run from Canada to Nebraska, had been rejected by the Obama administration in 2015, citing concerns over its potential impact on the environment and global climate change. The Dakota Access pipeline, which would carry North Dakota oil through South Dakota and Iowa to a shipping point in Illinois, had been the subject of fierce protests and was blocked by the Army Corps of Engineers in 2016.

The pipeline projects are expected to create thousands of jobs and generate tens of millions of dollars in annual property taxes, according to TransCanada, the builder of the Keystone XL pipeline. However, environmental groups, such as the Sierra Club, have expressed concerns over the potential environmental and social impacts of the projects.

The moves are likely to spark a new fight with environmentalists, who have long opposed the pipeline projects. The Sierra Club's Executive Director, Michael Brune, called the decision "dangerous" and stated that the pipelines were a "bad idea then and they're a bad idea now."

The pipeline orders come as Trump makes the economy and jobs the centerpiece of his administration's first week in office. The President met with representatives from the auto industry and business leaders, and has announced plans to nominate a justice for the Supreme Court next week.

Title: House Speaker Boehner Offers Olive Branch in Post-Election Deal-Making to Avoid Fiscal Cliff

House Speaker John A. Boehner has extended an olive branch to President Obama, offering to let the government collect more tax revenue in exchange for dropping his plan to raise tax rates on the wealthy. This move sets the stage for the lame-duck session of Congress, which begins next week, and the full 113th Congress, which opens in January.

Boehner's proposal relies on cutting out tax loopholes, which would bring in more revenue, and then using that money to lower income tax rates for everyone. He argues that the resulting tax code would be better for economic growth, which he says would produce more money for the federal government in the long run.

Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid, a Nevada Democrat, said he approached negotiations with an open mind and wouldn't draw any lines in the sand. He believes the election results gave a mandate for raising taxes on the wealthy, something President Obama ran on as a centerpiece of his campaign.

The two sides have different approaches to addressing the looming fiscal cliff, with Boehner's plan focusing on cutting loopholes and Reid's plan relying on raising tax rates. The fiscal cliff refers to the expiration of the George W. Bush-era tax cuts and automatic spending cuts, which would plunge the U.S. into a short but deep double-dip recession if not addressed.

The article also mentions that President Obama placed private calls to Reid, Boehner, Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell, and House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi, urging for a "balanced" approach to cutting the deficit. Vice President Joe Biden spoke to reporters, stating that there was a clear mandate for people to come closer to their view on tax policy and that he expects "some real soul searching" from Republicans to decide where they are willing to cooperate.

Grover Norquist, head of Americans for Tax Reform, said the revenue deal offered by Boehner passes muster, citing that raising economic growth to 4% a year would mean an additional $5 trillion in tax revenue over 10 years without raising tax rates.

Title: US Job Market Shows Resilience, But Economic Fears Remain Amid Global Uncertainty

The latest job market figures have been hailed as "extraordinary" and "blowout" by economists, with 312,000 new jobs added in the past month. This news has been welcomed by President Trump, who described the pickup in wage growth as "beautiful to watch." However, the report comes amidst flashing yellow lights elsewhere, with unresolved trade tensions with China and a slump in the housing sector in the United States.

The unresolved trade war with China has already led to an economic downturn in the country, which could dampen global demand. In the US, the housing sector is experiencing a slump, and there are hints that the auto industry could be next. Apple has cut its revenue forecast for the first time in 16 years, citing flagging iPhone sales in China. Kevin Hassett, chairman of the White House Council of Economic Advisers, warned that many US companies with sales in China could see their earnings downgraded until a deal is reached with Beijing.

The Institute for Supply Management released a survey showing the biggest drop in manufacturing activity since 2008, with many manufacturers blaming rising costs related to tariffs. While the index reading of 54.1 still indicates an economy in expansion, measures of consumer confidence have weakened recently. The stock market has been experiencing its worst decline since the financial crisis.

Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell acknowledged the mixed signals, saying that investors are "way ahead of the data." Despite the uncertainty, the latest job market figures suggest that the economy is still resilient, with economists saying that fears of a recession have been overstated.

Title: Trump's Potential Presidential Bid Sparks Mixed Reactions and Concerns

Article:

Comedians and political writers are abuzz with excitement as Donald Trump is likely to announce his candidacy for the 2016 Republican Party presidential nomination. According to The Washington Post, Trump plans to publish a two-page financial document summarizing his $9 billion net worth following his speech at Trump Tower in Manhattan. This move has sparked a mix of reactions and concerns among political analysts and the general public.

Trump's entry into the race has led some to speculate that the Republican Party is more interested in entertainment value than serious governance. The party's presidential nomination process has been criticized for being more focused on spectacle and ratings than substance. Trump's presence in the race only adds to this concern, as he is known for his reality TV background and bombastic rhetoric.

Trump's polling numbers are currently around 3.6%, placing him in the middle of the pack. However, his presence in the race has raised eyebrows, with some questioning the seriousness of his candidacy. Critics argue that Trump lacks the qualifications and experience to be taken seriously as a presidential candidate.

The article also notes that Trump's lack of a concrete plan to address pressing issues, such as defeating ISIS, has raised concerns. His promise to reveal a "secret plan" after being elected has been met with skepticism, with many questioning the legitimacy of his claims.

Overall, Trump's potential presidential bid has sparked a lively debate about the state of American politics and the Republican Party's priorities. While some see him as a breath of fresh air, others view him as a sideshow attraction who is more interested in fame and fortune than serious governance.

Title: Saudi Arabia Arrests 11 Princes and Ministers in Crackdown on Corruption

Saudi Arabia's King Salman has ordered the arrest of 11 princes and several current and former government ministers, a move seen as a bid to consolidate power around his son, Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman. The arrests were announced on Al Arabiya, the Saudi state satellite TV network, and among those detained was Prince Al-Waleed bin Talal, a prominent member of the royal family and a major investor in Apple and Twitter.

The arrests came just hours after King Salman established a new anti-corruption committee, headed by the 32-year-old Crown Prince Mohammed. The committee is authorized to investigate, arrest, and freeze the assets of anyone suspected of corruption.

The unexpected arrests also saw the removal of Prince Miteb bin Abdullah, the Saudi minister of the National Guard, who was once considered a contender for the Saudi throne before the rise of Prince Mohammed two years ago. His removal gives the crown prince tighter control over the kingdom's security services.

It is unclear whether the arrests are connected to the new anti-corruption committee, which was established due to the "propensity of some people for abuse, putting their personal interest above public interest, and stealing public funds," according to The Wall Street Journal.

King Salman has been moving to stamp out dissent in the kingdom ahead of his expected abdication in favor of Crown Prince Mohammed. Prince Miteb, who was one of the few powerful princes from outside King Salman's branch of the royal family, had been critical of the king's decision to appoint Prince Mohammed as his successor.

Title: President Trump Pledges Support for Law Enforcement, Criticizes FBI Leadership

President Donald Trump addressed a graduating class of law enforcement officers at the FBI Academy on Friday, reaffirming his administration's commitment to supporting law enforcement. In a 17-minute speech, Trump emphasized that his administration has the backs of law enforcement officers, stating, "The president of the United States has your back 100 percent."

Trump's comments came as tensions between the White House and the FBI have reached an all-time high. The president has publicly criticized the bureau's senior leadership and its reputation, calling it "in tatters" and "the worst in history." However, during his speech, Trump praised agents who keep the country safe and did not blame them for the investigations that have dogged his administration.

The president also took aim at growing violence in Baltimore and Chicago, asking, "What the hell is going on in Chicago? What the hell is happening there?" The comment was met with an awkward silence and mild applause.

The White House has recently revealed FBI records showing an "extreme bias" against Trump among senior leadership at the FBI. Deputy Press Secretary Hogan Gidley told Fox News that edits to former FBI Director James Comey's statement on Hillary Clinton's private email server and text messages from a top agent critical of Trump are "deeply troubling." Gidley also pointed to the disclosure of politically charged text messages sent by Peter Strzok, an agent who was involved in the Clinton case and later worked on special counsel Robert Mueller's investigation into potential Trump campaign ties to Russia.

The FBI National Academy program, which Trump attended, is a weeks-long training course aimed at raising law enforcement standards and cooperation. The coursework included intelligence theory, terrorism and terrorist mindsets, law, behavioral science, law enforcement communication, and forensic science. About 200 leaders in law enforcement from around the country attended the program.

Title: Texas Hospital Apologizes for Ebola Mistakes as Officials Consider Restricting Travel for Healthcare Workers

The Texas hospital where an Ebola patient died and two nurses became infected has apologized for mistakes made in treating the patient, Thomas Eric Duncan. The hospital's chief clinical officer, Dr. Daniel Varga, acknowledged that the hospital did not correctly diagnose Duncan's symptoms as those of Ebola and expressed regret for the mistakes. The hospital has since made several policy changes, including updating the emergency department screening process to include a patient's travel history and increasing training for staff.

The hospital is also considering restricting travel for 76 healthcare workers who treated Duncan, as officials weigh the risk of potential exposure to the virus. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) is considering lowering the fever threshold that would be considered a possible sign of Ebola, from 100.4 degrees Fahrenheit to a lower temperature.

A second nurse, Amber Vinson, who tested positive for Ebola, flew on a plane a day before it was known that she might be suffering from the virus. Vinson reported a fever to the CDC, but was told she could continue her travel. As a result, 132 passengers on her flight are now being contacted as a precaution.

The CDC is also investigating the case of Vinson, who is now being treated at Emory University Hospital in Atlanta. The hospital has successfully treated two other Ebola patients and has not had any employees infected.

The hospital is offering a room to any concerned employee who wants to stay and avoid potential exposure to family, friends, and the broader public. The hospital is also providing a room for employees who treated Duncan to stay in during their monitoring period.

The news of Vinson's travel has led to school closures in two states, with schools in Texas and Ohio closing due to concerns about potential exposure. Frontier Airlines has placed six crew members on paid leave for 21 days as a precaution and removed the plane's seat covers and carpet near where the infected passenger sat.

The hospital has denied some allegations made by a nurses' union, including claims that Duncan was left in an area where other patients were present without being in isolation and that hazardous waste was not properly contained.

Title: The Dark Side of Black Friday: A Day of Excess and Humiliation

The day after Thanksgiving, commonly known as Black Friday, has become a symbol of American excess and humiliation. It's a day when people flock to stores, often at dawn, to snag discounted merchandise, driven by a desire to keep up with consumerist culture. This phenomenon is not unique to the United States, but it's particularly pronounced in the country where conspicuous consumption is deeply ingrained.

According to analytics, some of the states with the highest rates of in-store fights over discounted merchandise are among the poorest, including Mississippi, West Virginia, Arkansas, Alabama, Tennessee, and Louisiana. This suggests that middle- and working-class individuals are more likely to engage in Black Friday shopping due to financial pressures and the need to keep up with societal expectations.

The article highlights the darker side of Black Friday, where people are willing to compromise their dignity and engage in physical altercations to get their hands on discounted goods. The phenomenon is not limited to individual actions, as it has also led to a vicious cycle of cutting costs, reducing quality, and exploiting workers.

The article also notes that many of the deals offered on Black Friday are not as good as they seem, as similar products can be found at better prices throughout the year. Additionally, the article quotes Bayard Winthrop, a clothing manufacturer, who argues that discounts often mask inflated prices and can lead to a cycle of cutting costs, reducing quality, and exploiting workers.

The article concludes by questioning the value of Black Friday, a holiday that has become a symbol of American excess and humiliation. It suggests that people should reassess their priorities and consider the long-term consequences of their actions, as well as the impact on workers and the environment.

Title: Christie's "Straight Talk" Under Scrutiny: Review of Governor's Statements Raises Questions

Article:

Republican presidential candidate Chris Christie launched his campaign with the motto "telling it like it is," but a closer examination of his statements during the Fox Business debate reveals that he may not always be telling the truth. During the debate, Christie responded to Marco Rubio's attack by denying allegations that he supported liberal views, including Common Core, gun control, and the appointment of Sonia Sotomayor. However, a review of Christie's past statements suggests that he may have supported Sotomayor after initially opposing her.

According to Politifact, Christie initially stated in 2009 that Sotomayor would not have been his choice for the Supreme Court. However, he later issued a statement supporting her appointment that same year. Christie's camp claims that his 2009 statements did not constitute support, but rather a call for an up-or-down vote.

Christie also disputed Rubio's claim that he made a donation to Planned Parenthood. However, a 1994 Newark Star-Ledger story quotes Christie as saying he supports Planned Parenthood privately with his personal contribution. While Planned Parenthood does not disclose private donors' information, Christie's camp now claims he never made the donation.

The debate exchange between Christie and Rubio highlighted the candidates' differing views on judicial appointments and political attacks. Christie accused Rubio of attacking him to boost his own poll numbers, while Rubio accused Christie of holding liberal views. The exchange was marked by testy exchanges and personal attacks.

In the end, Christie's "straight talk" was put under scrutiny, and his past statements were reviewed to determine the accuracy of his claims. While Christie's camp maintains that his statements were taken out of context, the review suggests that he may not always be telling the truth.

Title: Trump Holds Rally in Michigan as House Votes on Impeachment

The U.S. House of Representatives voted to impeach President Donald Trump on Wednesday night, with Trump holding a rally in Battle Creek, Michigan, shortly after the vote. Trump took the stage, boasting about the military spending and the creation of Space Force, a sixth branch of the armed forces. He also mocked Senator Elizabeth Warren, using the nickname "Pocahontas."

The impeachment was sparked by a whistleblower complaint over Trump's attempt to pressure Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky to investigate Joe Biden and his son Hunter, as well as a Republican theory that Ukraine had interfered in the 2016 U.S. presidential election.

Vice President Mike Pence warmed up the crowd, saying Trump would wait to speak until after the House vote. Trump started his speech by discussing the restoration of the practice of wishing each other "Merry Christmas" and praised the USMCA trade deal. He also touted the strong economy, without providing evidence, and boasted about the size of his rally crowds.

Trump also mentioned a new poll showing him ahead of Democratic candidates seeking the nomination and called the impeachment process a "political suicide march" for Democrats. He claimed that House Speaker Nancy Pelosi and the Democrats had branded themselves with an "eternal mark of shame" for impeaching him. Trump also brought up Hillary Clinton, who is considering another presidential run, and mocked Michigan Rep. Debbie Dingell, who voted for impeachment.

The rally was marked by a heckler interrupting Trump's speech, and he told security to "get tougher" with protesters.

Title: Voter ID Laws: A Limited Experiment in the United States

The debate surrounding voter ID laws in the United States has been ongoing, with some arguing that they are necessary to prevent fraud and others claiming they are an unnecessary barrier to voting. The limited experiment with voter ID laws in the country may come to an end after this election, as Democratic-appointed judges have struck down voter ID laws in various states.

However, voter fraud has been a problem in American elections throughout history. In 1948, Lyndon B. Johnson won his U.S. Senate seat by manufacturing fake votes, turning a 20,000-vote deficit into an 87-vote win. Similarly, voter fraud was reported in the 1960 presidential election, with some questioning whether John F. Kennedy actually won. In 1982, it was discovered that at least 100,000 fraudulent votes were cast in the U.S. Senate election in Illinois, and in 1994, Democrats obtained control of the Pennsylvania state Senate through large-scale voter fraud using absentee ballots.

Recent cases of voter fraud have also been reported, including instances in California, Pennsylvania, Indiana, Chicago, and Virginia. In some cases, voters have been registered to vote after their death, with 119 dead people voting 229 times in Chicago alone. In another case, 1,046 illegal aliens were found to have illegally registered to vote in Virginia.

Many countries around the world require voters to register in-person using a valid photo ID, which is seen as a simple and effective way to prevent fraud. In Mexico, voters must present a voter ID card, which includes a photo, thumbprint, and other security features to prevent multiple voting. The country's voter ID requirements are more stringent than those in the United States, with voters required to register in-person and pick up their voter ID card from a registration office.

Despite these restrictions, voter participation rates in Mexico have actually increased since the introduction of the voter ID system. In the United States, there is evidence that voter ID laws are associated with increased voting rates, and there is no evidence that they disproportionately harm minorities, the poor, or the elderly.

The fate of voter ID laws in the United States will be determined by this election, as Democratic-appointed judges have struck down voter ID laws in various states. If Hillary Clinton wins and gets to appoint a new Supreme Court justice, it is likely that voter ID laws will be struck down permanently. However, there is a real cost to voter fraud, as it undermines the legitimacy of the government and discourages lawful voting.

Title: Secretary of State Kerry Requests Broad War Powers to Combat Islamic State

Article:

Secretary of State John Kerry told Congress on Tuesday that President Obama wants to have expansive war powers to pursue the Islamic State (IS) terrorists wherever and however he deems necessary. This request would allow the Pentagon to commit American combat troops to the fight, although Mr. Obama himself does not want to deploy ground troops. Kerry emphasized that the administration does not want to tie the president's hands in case the war evolves or expands to other countries.

Kerry's appearance before the Senate Committee on Foreign Relations aimed to quell growing concerns over the administration's approach, but it did not seem to help. Lawmakers from both parties criticized the White House for delaying Congress's involvement while doing little to increase its own efforts.

Senator Bob Corker, the ranking Republican on the committee, stated that the president's failure to lead on this issue is the reason for the current situation. Senator Robert Menendez, the committee's chairman, has drafted an authorization for the use of military force (AUMF) that would impose a three-year limit on the authority and prohibit ground combat troops in most situations, with exceptions for intelligence gathering, acting as spotters, or for rescue missions.

The debate is ongoing, with the Senate Committee on Foreign Relations set to vote on Menendez's draft on Thursday. The House of Representatives is expected to take up the issue next year, with Speaker John A. Boehner stating that it is the president's responsibility to propose a resolution to Congress and make the case for it to the American people.

The rise of the Islamic State, which has captured large swaths of Syria and Iraq, has embarrassed the president, who had previously declared al-Qaeda on the run. Kerry emphasized that the administration considers the Islamic State to be a branch of al-Qaeda operating under a different name, meaning Mr. Obama already has powers to pursue the group under the 2001 and 2002 AUMFs.

Title: The Origins of Sequestration: A Look Back at the Budget Control Act of 2011

The impending sequestration, set to take effect on March 1, has sparked a heated debate over deficit reduction and automatic spending cuts. To understand the current situation, it is essential to revisit the Budget Control Act of 2011, a bill aimed at reducing the deficit and avoiding default.

The act created a supercommittee on deficit control, with the provision that if the committee failed to reach an agreement, automatic spending cuts, known as sequestration, would be imposed on all discretionary spending, including the military. The expiration of various tax cuts would also result in tax increases for millions of Americans.

The bill passed the House with an overwhelming majority of Republicans voting in favor, while House Democrats split down the middle. The bill then passed the Senate with 45 Democratic senators supporting it, joined by 28 Republicans and one Independent. President Obama signed the bill into law, a product of bipartisan cooperation.

In the October 2012 presidential debate, President Obama denied any involvement in the sequestration process, stating that it was a product of Congress, not the White House. He also poked fun at Mitt Romney, suggesting he was behind the times in his assessment of U.S. military readiness.

However, according to the Congressional Budget Office, the idea of draconian cuts to the Defense budget originated from the White House. Bob Woodward's book "The Price of Politics" traced the sequestration idea as a negotiating strategy that moved from the executive office to the Democratic leader of the Senate to Republican leaders.

As a member of the 112th Congress, one representative voted against the Budget Control Act of 2011, citing waste in government and the need to cut spending on wars, interventions, and foreign aid. The representative also expressed concerns about the $600 billion trade deficit and the need to start taking care of domestic issues.

The White House promoted sequestration as a way to cut spending on important domestic programs, even going so far as to falsely inject Social Security into the debt debate. The American Taxpayer Relief Act of 2013 passed on January 1, recovering a substantial amount of money that would have been lost due to the expiration of tax cuts.

With automatic spending cuts looming, the president will continue to distance himself from the sequestration process, while Republicans will try to bring him back to where he started – as the initiator. The White House may shift to a "share the pain" approach to deficit reduction, but it may not be enough to avoid sequestration.

Title: Trump Leads Republican Field in Latest National Poll

Article:

Businessman Donald Trump has taken the lead in the latest national poll on the 2016 Republican presidential field, with 24% of Republicans and GOP-leaning independents naming him as their first choice. The Washington Post-ABC poll, released on Monday, shows Trump's closest rival, Wisconsin Governor Scott Walker, at 13%, followed by former Florida Governor Jeb Bush at 12%.

The poll also shows former Arkansas Governor Mike Huckabee at 8%, Senator Marco Rubio of Florida at 7%, and retired neurosurgeon Ben Carson and Senator Rand Paul of Kentucky at 6% each. Rounding out the top 10 are Senator Ted Cruz of Texas and former Texas Governor Rick Perry, both at 4%, and New Jersey Governor Chris Christie at 3%.

Trump's campaign released a statement in response to the survey, in which he emphasized his commitment to addressing the country's problems, including its debt, porous borders, and lack of care for veterans. He also did not back down from recent criticism over his comments about Mexico and illegal immigrants, as well as his remarks about Senator John McCain's military service.

Trump's campaign manager, Corey Lewandowski, downplayed a reported drop in support for Trump following his comments about McCain, attributing it to a "statistical error" and noting that only 8% of the poll was conducted on Sunday. The overall survey of 1,002 adults had a margin of error of plus or minus 3.5 percentage points and was conducted from July 16-19.

Title: House Democrats to Vote on Sending Impeachment Articles to Senate, Despite Low Chances of Conviction

The House of Representatives is set to vote on Wednesday on a resolution to transmit the two articles of impeachment against President Trump to the Senate, marking the end of a nearly four-week delay. The move comes as House Speaker Nancy Pelosi prepares to send the articles to the upper chamber, where President Trump is all but guaranteed an acquittal.

The House impeachment managers are expected to be named on Wednesday, with two lawmakers at the top of the list being House Intelligence Chairman Adam Schiff and Judiciary Chairman Jerry Nadler. The House impeached President Trump in a party-line vote on December 18, charging him with abuse of power and obstruction of Congress.

The two articles of impeachment stem from a July 25 phone call with the Ukrainian president in which President Trump requested a probe of a political rival, former Vice President Joseph R. Biden. Mrs. Pelosi held on to the articles for about a month, demanding the Republican-controlled chamber hold a fair trial and echoing Senate Minority Leader Charles E. Schumer's calls for more witnesses.

However, the prevailing wisdom on Capitol Hill is that impeachment as an election issue will backfire on Mrs. Pelosi, whose Democrats won the majority in 2018 by picking up seats in Trump strongholds. Battleground polling last month in Pennsylvania, Michigan, and Wisconsin showed a boost in support for the president as impeachment proceedings heated up in the House. And there's been a slight decline in public support for the Senate to convict and remove Mr. Trump from office, according to a Real Clear Politics average of national polls.

Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell blasted Senate Minority Leader Charles E. Schumer for demanding a decision on witnesses in pretrial negotiations, saying it's a "win-win" for Democrats to hurt Republicans' reelection chances. Mr. McConnell pointed to a "revealing admission" from Mr. Schumer that the debate over witness testimony was a play to pick up seats in November.

House Majority Leader Steny H. Hoyer bristled when reporters asked if his party was turning impeachment into a plank of its 2020 campaign platform, saying "asking for fairness is not a campaign tactic." Senate Democrats need at least four Republicans to vote with them to get the 51 votes needed to call a witness, and they are eyeing four witnesses close to the president, including acting chief of staff Mick Mulvaney and former National Security Adviser John Bolton.

Recent polling suggests an overwhelming number of Americans would like to hear from Mr. Bolton during the trial. A Quinnipiac poll released this week showed 66% of respondents were eager to hear from the former national security adviser. Mr. McConnell has said he has enough votes to agree to the same rules and procedures that were used for President Bill Clinton's impeachment trial in 1999.

Title: The Campus Culture's Influence on Congressional Hearings: A Shift in the Way We Approach Truth and Due Process

The recent Supreme Court confirmation hearings for Judge Brett Kavanaugh have brought to the forefront the influence of campus culture on the way we approach truth and due process. The hearings have shown that the norms of the university have become the norms of the Senate, with a focus on empathy and perceived believability rather than evidence and facts.

The concept of "narrative truth" has become prevalent, where all stories are considered equal, regardless of their veracity. This approach has led to a lack of interest in discovering the truth, as evidenced by the lack of inquiry into the memories of teenage behavior nearly four decades prior. Instead, feelings and emotions have taken center stage, with little regard for the constitutional norms of due process.

The article highlights how the Senate has adopted the modern university's doctrine of self-censorship, no-go zones, and safe spaces. This has led to a lack of tough questioning and a focus on empathy and perceived believability. The article also notes how the race and gender of individuals have become determinants of their credibility, with some individuals being dismissed based on their age and gender.

The article concludes by noting how the campus culture's influence is now spreading to Congress, with swarming and shouting down those who hold different views becoming a common occurrence. The article warns that this trend is "frightening" and highlights the need for a return to the traditional norms of due process and the pursuit of truth.

**House Speaker Paul Ryan Announces Retirement, Setting Off Leadership Battle**

House Speaker Paul D. Ryan has announced his retirement from the House of Representatives at the end of this year, bringing an end to his two-decade-long career in Congress. The news has sparked a scramble among Republicans to fill the leadership vacuum, with Majority Leader Kevin McCarthy and Majority Whip Steve Scalise seen as the most likely successors.

Ryan cited his family as the reason for his decision, stating that he wants to spend more time with his children, who are now teenagers. He will serve out his term as speaker, pushing for spending controls and the rest of the Republican agenda.

The news has sparked a mix of reactions from lawmakers and conservative groups. Some have praised Ryan's accomplishments, including his role in securing a large tax cut and last month's omnibus spending bill. Others have criticized his failure to repeal Obamacare and lock down a deal on immigration.

Ryan's decision has also sparked a debate about the future of the Republican Party. Some lawmakers and conservative groups have urged a go-slow approach on choosing the next leader, while others have called for a more aggressive approach to fill the void.

Ryan's legacy is complex, with some praising his work on tax cuts and entitlement reform, while others have criticized his failure to deliver on promises to reduce federal spending and reform entitlement programs. His relationship with conservatives has been uneasy at times, with some members of the House Freedom Caucus criticizing his approach as too top-down.

The search for a new speaker is expected to be intense, with many lawmakers and conservative groups weighing in on the issue.

Title: Romney's Business Ties Under Scrutiny as Obama Campaign Raises Questions

The Obama campaign has accused Mitt Romney of either lying to voters or federal regulators about his time at private equity firm Bain Capital, while the Romney team has dismissed the claims as "reckless and unsubstantiated." The controversy stems from a report in the Boston Globe that suggests Romney may have led Bain until 2002, three years longer than he claims.

According to the Obama campaign, Romney's involvement with Bain between 1999 and 2002 led to jobs being shipped off to China and India, and he shares responsibility for the consequences of those investments. "Either Mitt Romney, through his own words and his own signature, was misrepresenting his position at Bain to the SEC, which is a felony, or he was misrepresenting his position at Bain to the American people to avoid responsibility for some of the consequences of his investments," said Stephanie Cutter, deputy campaign manager for the Obama campaign.

The Romney campaign has denied the allegations, citing the findings of independent fact-checkers that agree with them. Romney's aides also pointed to a story by Fortune that suggests internal Bain documents show Romney stopped managing the firm's clients when he went to oversee the Salt Lake City Olympics.

Bain Capital has released a statement supporting Romney's claim that he left the firm in 1999 and had no involvement with the management or investment activities of the firm or its portfolio companies since his departure.

The controversy is likely to continue to dog Romney throughout the campaign, with Democrats demanding he release more tax returns to give voters a better look at his finances. David Yepsen, director of the Paul Simon Public Policy Institute at Southern Illinois, said Romney's complex finances make it a hard story for him to control.

Title: Virginia Poll Shows Tight Presidential Race, Obama and Romney Tied

A recent poll conducted by Quinnipiac University shows a tight presidential race in the swing state of Virginia, with President Barack Obama and Mitt Romney tied at 44 percent. The poll, which surveyed 1,673 registered voters, has a margin of error of 2.4 percentage points.

The poll also found that Obama's favorability ratings have declined, with 46 percent of voters holding a favorable opinion of him and 48 percent having an unfavorable opinion. Romney's favorability ratings are also underwater, with 39-42 favorable-unfavorable split.

The poll results are in line with other recent polls, which have shown a close race nationally. A CBS/New York Times poll has Romney leading Obama 47-46, while a Fox poll has Obama leading 45-41.

The Quinnipiac University Polling Institute's assistant director, Peter A. Brown, noted that while Obama has a slight edge among independent voters, Romney has made gains among women, narrowing Obama's advantage from 16 points to 5 points.

The poll also found that voters are not enthusiastic about either candidate, with Brown stating, "One of them is going to win the White House, but neither would get elected Prom King."

The electoral map is expected to look different this year compared to 2008, when Obama expanded Democratic territory and flipped historically red states such as Virginia and North Carolina. This year, the map could more closely mirror the 2004 election, when an under-fire incumbent was fending off a challenger about whom the electorate was not terribly enthusiastic.

The Obama campaign has launched a voter outreach program in Virginia, with first lady Michelle Obama scheduled to visit the state on Friday. The Romney campaign has also released a new ad, "These Hands," which features Jack Gilchrist, the owner of Gilchrist Metal Fabricating Company in Hudson, N.H., arguing that Obama does not understand the free enterprise system. The Obama campaign has countered with its own ad, "Mitt Romney: Saying Anything to Get Elected," which splices recent remarks from Romney with Obama's comments to argue that the challenger was essentially agreeing with the president's larger point.

Title: Republicans Punish Trump Critics, Female Candidates Dominate in Primaries

In a series of primary elections across the United States, voters sent a clear message: fealty to President Donald Trump matters more than purity on the issues in the Republican Party. The most stunning outcome was the loss of Republican Rep. Mark Sanford, who was criticized for his lack of support for the President.

Sanford's loss was part of a broader trend in which female candidates are winning at unprecedented rates and often by large margins. In Virginia, three key House races saw women emerge victorious, with Elaine Luria, Abigail Spanberger, and Jennifer Wexton winning Democratic primaries. This trend is part of a larger phenomenon in which a record number of Democratic women have filed to run for Congress since Trump took office.

In other races, Trump's influence was evident. Alabama Rep. Martha Roby was forced into a runoff after criticizing the President, and Corey Stewart, a conservative who has appeared with white nationalists, won the Republican nomination for Senate in Virginia. However, national Republicans admit there is virtually no chance Stewart will defeat Democratic Sen. Tim Kaine in the fall.

In other news, Democrats notched another win in a state legislative special election in Wisconsin, with Democrat Caleb Frostman claiming victory in a traditionally Republican district. This marks the party's 43rd red-to-blue flip since Trump took office.

In other races, North Dakota Republicans chose Rep. Kevin Cramer to challenge vulnerable Democratic Sen. Heidi Heitkamp, and Nevada Democrats picked Rep. Jacky Rosen as their nominee against Republican Sen. Dean Heller.

Title: Romney Addresses NAACP Convention, Highlights Economic Concerns in African-American Community

Mitt Romney, the Republican presidential candidate, spoke at the NAACP annual convention in Houston, addressing the nation's oldest civil rights group. Despite not receiving a warm welcome, Romney delivered a speech that touched on economic and educational issues affecting the African-American community. He emphasized the need to rethink the approach to addressing these problems, citing decades of failed promises from the Democratic Party.

Romney highlighted his support for charter schools and vouchers, which align with some of the Obama administration's policies. He also attempted to distance himself from the notion that his campaign is focused on helping the rich, instead emphasizing his commitment to helping the middle class.

The former Massachusetts governor did not address the issue of voter ID laws, which opponents see as a conservative effort to suppress the non-white vote. Romney acknowledged President Obama's historic election, but suggested that the nation's first black president had failed to improve the economic situation for African-Americans.

Romney wrapped up his speech by quoting Martin Luther King Jr. and emphasizing the importance of faith. He also touched on his party-consistent opposition to same-sex marriage, which remains a divisive issue in the black community.

The NAACP's President Benjamin Todd Jealous responded to Romney's speech, stating that while the candidate recognized the power of the black electorate, his agenda was "antithetical to many of our interests." NAACP Chairman Roslyn M. Brock praised Romney for being "courageous" and taking the opportunity to speak directly to the group.

**Blizzard Brings Heavy Snowfall to Nation's Capital and Surrounding Areas**

A powerful blizzard is expected to impact more than 70 million people, with the nation's capital and surrounding areas experiencing heavy snowfall. The storm began dumping snow on Friday, with officials urging government workers to head home by the early afternoon, warning of "life and death implications."

The Washington Metro subway system will shut down entirely late Friday night and remain closed through Sunday for safety reasons. Tens of thousands of people crowded into airports, with over 2,900 flights canceled for Friday and thousands more delayed. All major airlines have issued travel waivers for the weekend.

The storm is expected to hit the Mid-Atlantic region the hardest, with over 2 feet of snow expected in the nation's capital, 12-18 inches in Philadelphia, and 8-10 inches in New York. National Weather Service forecaster Daniel Peterson said, "This is probably going to be one of the top three snowfalls of all-time for Washington."

Train service may be disrupted due to frozen switches, loss of third-rail electric power, or trees falling on wires. Track workers, power company employees, road crew members, firefighters, and other first-responders were mobilized for the long weekend.

The storm has already caused treacherous conditions, with Arkansas and Tennessee receiving 8 inches of snow, Kentucky over a foot, and the Deep South experiencing icy roads and power outages. At least eight people died in traffic fatalities in the dangerous weather.

The National Weather Service issued blizzard warnings stretching from northern Virginia to parts of New York's Long Island, with the U.S. Coast Guard warning of seas swelling up to 18 feet. The blizzard warnings are scheduled to last until early Sunday.

Forecasters also warned of "thundersnow," a dangerous type of thunderstorm that drops snow instead of rain. The most intense part of the storm is expected to hit Saturday morning, with heavy snow and blizzard conditions.

The storm system dropped 6 inches of snow in the Little Rock area overnight, breaking a snowfall record set over 20 years ago. Schools and state government offices in central Arkansas shut down on Friday, and the state's largest utility, Entergy Arkansas, reported about 12,500 homes and businesses lost power.

The Mid-Atlantic region is notorious for struggling with winter weather, and a light dusting on Wednesday night served as an ominous prelude to the massive blizzard.

Title: Trump's Shift on Syria Sparks Conflicting Reactions from Far-Right Fringe

The sudden decision by President Donald Trump to launch a missile strike against Syrian dictator Bashar al-Assad has sparked a mix of reactions from the far-right fringe, with some expressing disappointment and others praising the move. The alt-right, which had initially supported Trump's promise to keep the country out of unnecessary wars, is now divided on the issue.

Some far-right figures, such as Steve Bannon, who was a key advisor to Trump during his presidential campaign, had expressed support for the idea that Trump would keep the country out of war. However, Trump's recent statements, including those made by Secretary of State Rex Tillerson and U.N. Ambassador Nikki Haley, have indicated a shift in the administration's stance.

The alt-right, which had initially been reassured by Trump's campaign rhetoric and the presence of Bannon in the West Wing, is now divided on the issue. Some, such as blogger Mike Cernovich, have suggested that the chemical weapons attack on Syrian civilians was a "false flag" operation, while others, like Infowars, have blamed the attack on Democrat billionaire George Soros.

Breitbart, a news outlet closely tied to the alt-right, has been critical of Trump's decision, with its front page noting the praise from "Republican Hawks" and suggesting that Trump had abandoned his campaign principles. Ann Coulter, a prominent figure in the alt-right, has also criticized Trump's decision, suggesting that he had only acted because he saw upsetting images on TV.

The removal of Bannon from the National Security Council Principals Committee has also sparked conspiracy theories among the far-right fringe, with some blaming Jared Kushner, Trump's son-in-law and a key advisor, for Bannon's diminished influence in the West Wing.

Title: Housing and Urban Development Secretary Ben Carson Proposes Changes to Public Housing Rent Payments

The United States Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD) Secretary Ben Carson has unveiled a proposal to increase rent payments for millions of families living in federally subsidized public housing. The plan, dubbed the Make Affordable Housing Work Act, would raise the rent paid by public housing residents to 35% from 30% of their household income and eliminate deductions that could lower that number. The proposal would also require annual evaluations of rent payments, up from the current three-year cycle.

According to Carson, the changes are necessary to revamp an outdated system and bring more money into the program. "The way we calculate the level of assistance to our families is archaic and has perverse consequences, like discouraging these residents from earning more income," Carson said in an interview. "It's clear from a budget perspective and from a human standpoint that this is not sustainable."

However, tenant rights advocates are already expressing concerns about the proposal. Jack Cooper, executive director of the Massachusetts Union of Public Housing Tenants, called the plan "a war on low-income people." Cooper argued that the increased rent payments would force families into homelessness, as many residents already struggle to make ends meet. The nationwide average annual income for public housing residents is $12,000, making it difficult for families to absorb the additional expenses.

The proposal is still in the early stages and would require approval from Congress before taking effect. It is unclear how lawmakers will respond to the plan, with some Republicans potentially hesitant to support it ahead of midterm elections in the fall.

Title: Republican Senator Chambliss Questions Anti-Tax Pledge, Prioritizes Country Over Grover Norquist

Article:

A prominent Republican senator has broken ranks with his party by expressing skepticism about the anti-tax pledge pushed by activist Grover Norquist. Senator Saxby Chambliss of Georgia told a local television station, WMAZ, that he prioritizes his country's well-being over the 20-year-old pledge, which has been widely adopted by GOP lawmakers.

Chambliss's comments come as Congress faces a year-end deadline to address the country's budget deficit and avoid the so-called fiscal cliff of tax increases and spending cuts. The senator believes that the current approach of relying on the pledge is hindering efforts to reduce the national debt. "If we do it his way, then we'll continue in debt, and I just have a disagreement with him about that," Chambliss said.

The pledge, led by Norquist's Americans for Tax Reform, has been a cornerstone of Republican fiscal policy for years. However, a small number of freshman lawmakers have begun to question its relevance, and Chambliss is now joining their ranks. The senator is not the only one who has criticized Norquist's influence; he has previously spoken out against the activist's stronghold on anti-tax sentiments.

Chambliss's comments have sparked concerns that Norquist may use his resources to target the senator in his 2014 re-election bid. However, the senator remains unfazed, stating, "I care too much about my country, and I care a lot more about it than I do Grover Norquist." He added that he is willing to do what is right and let the political consequences take care of themselves.

The senator's stance highlights the growing divide within the Republican Party over the anti-tax pledge and its role in shaping fiscal policy. As Congress continues to grapple with the budget deficit and the fiscal cliff, Chambliss's comments may signal a shift in the party's stance on taxation and debt reduction.

**Trump-Backed Republicans Face Uncertainty in Ohio and Kansas Elections**

In the closely watched races in Ohio and Kansas, Republican candidates backed by President Donald Trump clung to small leads, sparking concerns about their ability to continue extending millions of dollars in aid to candidates in November's Congressional elections. In Ohio, Republican Troy Balderson may have eked out a victory in a special election for a U.S. House of Representatives seat in a reliably conservative district, but was leading the Democrat Danny O'Connor by only about 1,700 votes or less than 1.0 percent. The final result could be days away as state officials count more than 8,000 provisional and absentee ballots.

In the Kansas primary to select a Republican candidate for November's mid-term U.S. elections, Kris Kobach was unable to convert an endorsement by Trump into a resounding victory, clinging to a 191-vote lead over his Republican primary opponent, current Governor Jeff Colyer, with potentially thousands more provisional and absentee ballots outstanding.

The infusion of cash into the Ohio district, which has been represented by Republicans for 30 years, further triggered alarm bells for the party. The kind of cash from the national party or its allies may not be available for every at-risk Republican on the ballot in November, with Democrats already raising more money in many seats.

"Moving forward, we can't expect to win tough races when our candidate is being outraised," said Corry Bliss, executive director of the Congressional Leadership Fund, a Republican Super PAC that supported Balderson in Ohio. "Any Republican running for Congress getting vastly outraised by an opponent needs to start raising more money."

The Ohio race mirrored other special federal elections over the past 12 months, including upsets by Democrat Conor Lamb in a Pennsylvania congressional race in March and by Democrat Doug Jones over Roy Moore for an Alabama Senate seat in December of last year. Trump stumped for both candidates in losing efforts.

In those races, rural voters favored Trump-supported candidates, but turnout in those regions lagged heavy suburban turnout, where Democrats expanded on margins won by Hillary Clinton in 2016.

Title: White House Spokesman Clarifies President Trump's Stance on Extremist Groups

The White House has clarified President Donald Trump's stance on extremist groups, including white supremacists and neo-Nazis. According to a White House spokesman, Trump explicitly condemned all forms of violence, bigotry, and hatred, including those perpetrated by white supremacist and neo-Nazi groups. The statement was made in response to Trump's comments on Saturday, which were criticized for not specifically condemning white supremacist groups.

In his statement, Trump called for national unity and urged Americans to come together.
