However, some critics, including former White House communications director Anthony Scaramucci, felt that Trump's statement was not strong enough. Scaramucci told ABC News that Trump should have been more forceful in his condemnation of white supremacist groups.

Other Republicans, including Senators Orrin Hatch and Cory Gardner, also weighed in on Trump's statement. Hatch tweeted that "we should call evil by its name" and that "my brother didn't give his life fighting Hitler for Nazi ideas to go unchallenged here at home." Gardner urged Trump to declare the incident an act of terror and called the perpetrators "white supremacists."

The White House spokesman's statement emphasized that Trump condemned all forms of violence, bigotry, and hatred, including those perpetrated by white supremacist and neo-Nazi groups. The statement did not provide further details on Trump's stance on the specific incident in Charlottesville, Virginia, which involved a car attack on a group of anti-fascist protesters.

Title: Mueller's Statement Sparks Concerns About Media Perception

The recent announcement by special counsel Robert Mueller has sparked concerns among some media professionals about the potential impact on the public's perception of the news industry. Mueller's statement, which disputed reported allegations related to the Trump-Russia investigation, has led some to worry that it will reinforce the notion that the media is biased and inaccurate.

Jeffery Toobin, a senior CNN analyst and writer for The New Yorker, expressed his concerns on-air, stating that the larger message people will take from this story is that the news media are "a bunch of leftist liars who are dying to get the president and they're willing to lie to do it." Toobin also lamented that this development is a "bad day for us."

CNN anchor Chris Cuomo similarly observed that Mueller's statement "didn't do the media any favors." Cuomo noted that it allows President Trump and his allies to further discredit the media, saying, "You can't believe what you read, you can't believe what you hear, you can only believe us."

President Trump himself responded on social media, characterizing the development as "a very sad day for journalism, but a great day for our country!" He also denounced "fake news" as the "enemy of the people."

Title: US Admits 12,587 Syrian Refugees in FY 2016, Exceeding Target

The United States admitted a total of 12,587 Syrian refugees during the fiscal year 2016, exceeding the target set by President Obama by 2,587 (20.5%). The majority of these refugees, 12,363 (98.2%), are Sunni Muslims, with 103 identified as Muslims and 20 as Shia Muslims. A smaller number of refugees are Christians, with 68 admitted, comprising 16 Catholics, eight Orthodox, five Protestants, four Jehovah's Witnesses, one Greek Orthodox, and 34 self-identified as Christians.

The remaining Syrian refugees resettled in the US in FY 2016 are 24 Yazidis, eight with religion given as "other," and one with "no religion." The final month of the fiscal year saw 1,847 Syrian refugees admitted, with 1,812 being Sunnis, 13 being other Muslims, 12 being Christians, seven being Yazidis, and three being "other" religion.

The numbers of Christians and other religious minorities among the Syrian refugees admitted to the US are dwarfed by those of Sunni Muslims. While the majority of Syrians are Sunnis, the number of Sunnis among the refugees is still disproportionately high, and the number of Christians is disproportionately low, compared to the overall population makeup.

The conflict in Syria, which began in 2011, has seen atrocities committed by various groups, including Sunni jihadists, Shi'a, and Alawite sects. The United Nations reports that 4,806,702 million Syrians are registered as "persons of concern" in Turkey, Jordan, Lebanon, Iraq, and North Africa, without providing a denominational breakdown.

The US government has determined that atrocities committed by the Islamic State of Iraq and Syria (ISIS/ISIL) against religious minorities in areas under its control amount to genocide. However, administration officials say that the refugee program does not prioritize any particular religious group when considering Syrian applications.

The US has resettled a total of 14,460 Syrian refugees since the conflict began, with 87% of them admitted during FY 2016. Of those, 14,082 (97.3%) are Sunnis, 196 (1.3%) are Shia and other Muslims, and 124 (0.8%) are Christians. The rest are 25 Yazidis, six Zoroastrians, three atheists, two Baha'i, 14 with "other" religion, and eight with "no religion."

Title: Preliminary Autopsy Report Suggests Michael Brown Was Shot Multiple Times, Including Twice in the Head

A preliminary autopsy report has been released, providing new details about the death of Michael Brown, the 18-year-old man who was shot and killed by a Ferguson police officer on August 9. The report, conducted by pathologist Michael Baden, suggests that Brown was shot at least six times, including twice in the head, and that he did not suffer before he died.

According to the report, Brown was shot from at least one foot away, but the distance could have been as far as 30 feet. The autopsy also found that two bullets ricocheted and traveled back through Brown's body. The report suggests that Brown could have survived all of his wounds except for the shot to the top of his head, which was probably sustained last and exited through his right eye.

The report's findings have led to renewed calls for the police officer involved in the shooting, Darren Wilson, to be arrested. Brown's mother, Lesley McSpadden, asked the questions that lawyers could not answer, "What else do we need to get them to arrest the killer of my child?" The report's findings confirm the worst that the family thinks happened, that Brown was executed, according to Benjamin Crump, the family's lawyer.

The report's findings are consistent with police and witness accounts of how Brown died. The shooting and police response drew racially charged protests that have sometimes turned violent. The U.S. Attorney General Eric Holder has ordered a separate federal autopsy, which is being performed by a U.S. military medical examiner. Holder has asked for the public to be patient as the facts are gathered and has emphasized the importance of preserving the integrity of the investigation.

The St. Louis County Medical Examiner's autopsy concluded that Brown died of gunshot wounds, but other details have not been released. The Washington Post, citing a person familiar with the autopsy, reported that the county autopsy indicates Brown was shot six to eight times and that he had marijuana in his system. However, the St. Louis County Medical Examiner's office has not confirmed the marijuana report.

The investigation is ongoing, and the FBI is assisting in a federal civil rights inquiry into Brown's shooting. The Justice Department is committed to preserving the integrity of the investigation and has asked for the public to be patient as the facts are gathered.

Title: The Evolution of Journalism: A Shift from Objectivity to Partisanship

The recent layoffs at BuzzFeed, the Huffington Post, and Vice have left many journalists without jobs, sparking concerns about the future of journalism and its impact on democracy. The finger of blame has pointed to Facebook and Google, with some arguing that the decline of traditional journalism is a threat to democracy. However, a closer examination of the history of journalism reveals that the concept of objectivity is a relatively recent development.

In the past, journalists like Ben Franklin and Samuel Adams were not concerned with objectivity, but rather with promoting their own political agendas. Franklin, for example, wrote under multiple pseudonyms and pioneered the placement of advertising next to content. Adams, on the other hand, was editor of the Boston Gazette and helped organize the Boston Tea Party.

If the Founding Fathers were alive today, they would recognize the modern concept of journalism, including Twitter, blogs, and partisan outlets like Daily Kos and National Review. They would likely have an anonymous Twitter account, a partisan vehicle built around themselves, or a columnist gig at a less partisan outlet.

The idea of objective journalism is a relatively short-lived artifact of 20th-century America. In the past, most newspapers were overtly political, and a name like The Press Democrat meant Democrat with a big D. Advertising was a minor concern, as party leaders encouraged members to subscribe to their local party organ, obviating the need for anything more than classifieds.

The shift towards objectivity occurred as a national market for consumer goods opened after the Civil War, when purveyors like department stores wanted to reach large urban audiences. Newspapers responded by increasing the number of ads relative to content, and switched to models that went light on the political partisanship in the interest of expanding circulation. This move was driven not exclusively by lofty ideals but also by mercenary greed.

Jill Abramson, former executive editor of The New York Times, offers a peek into this collision between the legacy grandeur and profitability of journalism and the current zeitgeist in her memoir Merchants of Truth. In one scene, the Times' CEO asks Abramson to come up with new revenue ideas, to which she indignantly responds, "If that's what you expect, you have the wrong executive editor." Our reborn Founding Father journalist would find this disconnect between editorial and business absolutely inconceivable. Franklin knew very well on what side his journalistic toast was buttered, and would have leapt at any new monetization ideas.

Title: Congress Debates Fate of Obama-Era DACA Program and Its Recipients

The Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) program, implemented by former President Barack Obama, has been a topic of debate in Congress, with concerns surrounding its constitutionality and the fate of its 800,000 recipients. The program, which shielded illegal aliens from deportation, required applicants to meet specific criteria, including having no criminal record and paying a $495 application fee. Recipients had to reapply every two years and, if accepted, gained access to work permits.

The program applied to individuals who entered the United States as minors, and applicants were required to provide sensitive information about themselves and their whereabouts. This raised concerns among immigration activists, as the information provided could potentially be used to identify and deport individuals.

In a memo, the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) clarified that while it would not proactively provide DACA recipients' personal information to Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) for the purpose of immigration enforcement proceedings, it would provide the information if requested. This has sparked concerns among Democrats and immigration activists, who argue that the program's constitutionality is questionable, particularly regarding the separation of powers.

The Trump administration has signaled that it will not defend the program, citing legal concerns. Republican state attorneys general have threatened to sue the administration if it does not end the program. As a result, the program has been ended with a six-month enforcement delay to allow Congress to pass DACA-like legislation. This move has been seen as an opportunity for Senate Republicans, such as Tom Cotton from Arkansas, to push for the RAISE Act, which overhauls the green card process to prioritize immigrants with high skills and adds a language provision.

Meanwhile, the Border Patrol has reported apprehending two DACA recipients who were smuggling illegal immigrants across the border. The debate surrounding DACA highlights the complexities of immigration policy and the ongoing challenges faced by Congress in addressing this issue.

Title: Columnist Reflects on Zimmerman Case, Urges Caution in Opining on Complex Legal Matters

The George Zimmerman case has sparked intense debate and discussion, with many individuals sharing their opinions on the verdict. As a practicing attorney and columnist, the author of this article has a unique perspective on the case. Having tried a murder case in their early days as a lawyer, they understand the complexity of the legal system and the challenges that come with making decisions in the courtroom.

The author notes that while they have no expertise in the Zimmerman case, they do have experience in the legal system and believe that armchair second-guessing of the prosecution or defense strategy is too complicated for those without experience in the courtroom. They also express skepticism about politicians and pundits passing judgment on the jury's decision, as they lack the legal expertise to truly understand the case.

The article also touches on the debate surrounding "stand your ground" laws in Florida and other states, noting that the defense in the Zimmerman case did not rely on this law as a means of arguing their case. The author questions the effectiveness of such laws and how they might be applied in different situations.

Regarding potential new laws related to racial profiling, the author is cautious, wondering how Congress would determine if an individual is "racially profiling" another and whether new laws would apply to all races and how they are treated by others.

The article concludes by acknowledging that Trayvon Martin's death is a tragedy, regardless of the outcome of the case, and that Zimmerman's life will likely be forever affected by the verdict. The author emphasizes the importance of respecting the legal system and the decisions made within it, and encourages those without legal expertise to exercise caution when opining on complex legal matters.

Title: Attorney General William Barr Testifies Before Senate Judiciary Committee, Defending Handling of Mueller Report

Attorney General William Barr testified before the Senate Judiciary Committee on May 1, 2019, amid controversy surrounding his handling of the Mueller report. The report, released in March 2019, concluded that there was no evidence of collusion between the Trump campaign and Russia, but did not exonerate President Trump on obstruction of justice.

Barr's summary of the report's findings, released shortly after receiving it, sparked outrage among Democrats and the media, who accused him of downplaying the report's conclusions. However, Barr has maintained that his summary was a reasonable attempt to provide the public with a brief overview of the report's findings, while also ensuring that the full report was released with minimal redactions.

According to Barr, Mueller himself wrote a letter to him expressing concerns about the public's perception of the report's findings, which led to Democratic calls for Barr to resign or be impeached. However, Barr has maintained that his actions were reasonable and in line with department regulations.

Barr has also faced accusations of perjury, with some claiming he misled Congress about his handling of the report. However, his testimony has been described as "terse and precise," and he has explained that he did not know what specific complaints Mueller's staff had about his handling of the summary.

What is perhaps most notable about this episode is that Mueller himself expressed concerns about the media coverage and political discussion surrounding the report, specifically that it was not damning enough of the president. This has been met with silence from critics, who have instead focused on Barr's handling of the report.

The controversy surrounding Barr's handling of the Mueller report has highlighted the ongoing debate about the role of the Attorney General and the media in shaping public perception of the report's findings.

Title: Dakota Access Pipeline: Separating Fact from Fiction

The Dakota Access Pipeline (DAPL) has been the subject of intense controversy, with many misconceptions and misinformation surrounding the project. As the debate continues, it is essential to separate fact from fiction and provide a balanced view of the situation.

The Standing Rock Sioux tribe has been vocal in their opposition to the pipeline, citing concerns about the potential destruction of tribal lands and ancient artifacts. However, the Army Corps of Engineers had attempted to consult with the tribe on multiple occasions between 2014 and 2016, but the tribe failed to respond or delayed the process.

The pipeline's route was rerouted and modified to avoid 91 of the 149 eligible sites containing stone features considered sacred by American Indian tribes. The U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia denied a motion for a preliminary injunction by the Standing Rock Sioux Tribe, citing the inability of the tribe to show how the pipeline would damage the group's sacred ground.

The pipeline does not cut through the Standing Rock reservation, and the area is privately owned, meaning the route is located several miles north of the tribe's ancestral land. The tribe has attempted to argue that the land is theirs under the Fort Laramie Treaty of 1851, but this claim has been disputed.

Energy Transfer Partners moved the project south near the Standing Rock reservation because it was 11 miles shorter and considered less damaging to the environment. The U.S. Army Corps of Engineers evaluated the Bismarck route, eventually concluding it was not a viable option because of the project's close proximity to the capital's municipal water supply wells.

The southern route near Standing Rock's reservation is mostly rural, making it easier for the pipeline to be constructed with minimal environmental impact. The Army Corps of Engineers deemed the new pipeline route crossing Lake Oahe safe in an environmental assessment, arguing that the ETP has developed response and action plans, and will include several monitoring systems, shut-off valves, and other safety features to minimize the risk of spills and reduce potential damages.

Eminent domain was never used on the North Dakota route, as Energy Transfer Partners relied on voluntary easements to construct the pipeline's southern route near Standing Rock Sioux's reservation. Much of the land that protesters are occupying during their demonstrations is private property owned by farmers. Federal officials are refusing to evict the protesters, citing concerns about free speech rights.

Investments in pipelines like DAPL have increased since 2010 by some 60 percent, according to an American Petroleum Institute study, and have nearly doubled from $56.3 billion in 2010 to $89.6 billion in 2013. The increase has likely raised concerns among environmentalists about the use of eminent domain.

Title: Trump Disputes Official Death Toll in Puerto Rico After Hurricane Maria

Article:

US President Donald Trump has disputed the official death toll in Puerto Rico after Hurricane Maria, claiming that nearly 3,000 people did not die as a result of the 2017 storms. Trump made the statement on Twitter, without providing any evidence to support his claim. The official death toll was released last month after an independent study by George Washington University, which found that 2,975 people died in Puerto Rico as a result of Hurricane Maria.

The study concluded that the initial death toll of 64 only included those killed directly by hurricanes Maria and Irma, either by drowning, flying debris, or building collapse. The study also counted those who died in the six months following the storm as a result of poor healthcare provision and a lack of electricity and clean water. Repeated power cuts also led to an increased number of deaths from diabetes and sepsis.

Trump's tweets came as Hurricane Florence, a category two storm projected to bring catastrophic flooding, bore down on the US East Coast. The president accused Democrats of inflating the death toll to "make me look as bad as possible." He also suggested that the hurricane death toll was artificially boosted by adding those who had passed away from natural causes such as old age.

The governor of Puerto Rico, who commissioned the research, accepted the estimate as official. The study was conducted by George Washington University and published in July. Harvard University public health researchers also published a study in May, estimating that about 4,600 people died in Puerto Rico in the aftermath of the hurricane from delayed medical care.

The controversy surrounding the death toll has sparked a political debate, with some Republicans speaking out against Trump's claims. Florida Republican Congresswoman Ileana Ros-Lehtinen called the president's tweets "mind-boggling" and said it was a "warped-mind that would turn this statistic into 'fake news.'" Florida Governor Rick Scott, who is currently running for the US Senate, tweeted that "I've been to Puerto Rico 7 times & saw devastation firsthand. The loss of any life is tragic."

The US Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) is investigating whether it placed 20,000 pallets of bottled water meant for victims on a runway in Ceiba, Puerto Rico, a year after the storm. Puerto Rican officials have previously blamed mismanagement on FEMA, while President Trump has said authorities on the island are incompetent.

Title: Stock Market Enters Bear Territory as Dow Jones Industrial Average Plunges

The Dow Jones Industrial Average has entered bear market territory for the first time in over a decade, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also poised to follow suit. The decline comes as the World Health Organization declared COVID-19 a pandemic, causing widespread market anxiety.

The Dow Jones Industrial Average, composed of 30 blue-chip companies, has fallen 29% from its February 12 record, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq are 27% from their February 19 peaks. The decline has been driven by a sharp drop in shares of Boeing Co., which has pulled the price-weighted index into bear market territory.

The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index narrowly missed entering bear market territory on Wednesday, but are expected to do so by the end of Thursday's trading. The Dow Jones Industrial Average plunged 1,464.94 points, or 5.9%, to settle at 23,553.22, while the S&P 500 fell 4.9% to 2,741.38.

Historically, bear markets can be lengthy, with the average duration for the Dow being 206 trading days and 146 days for the S&P 500. The current decline is the fastest move from a record high to a bear market since 1931, with the Dow taking 19 days to drop 20% or more.

The market decline has been fueled by concerns over the economic impact of the COVID-19 pandemic, which has infected over 127,000 people and claimed nearly 4,700 lives worldwide. The World Health Organization's declaration of a pandemic has sparked fears of global supply chain disruptions and a potential recession.

While there is some hope that the bear market will be short-lived if the viral outbreak is effectively mitigated, the current decline is a stark reminder of the market's volatility and the potential for significant losses.

Title: African-American Trump Supporter Faces Backlash and Rejection for His Political Views

Article:

In an exclusive interview, 24-year-old Devinn Smart, a vocal supporter of President Donald Trump, shared his journey of being an African-American Trump supporter. Smart's views on Trump have not always been this way; he grew up in a family of die-hard Democrats and attended a historically black university in Hampton, Virginia. However, during his college years, he began researching Trump and was drawn to his policies and the way he appealed to black voters. The phrase "What do you have to lose?" resonated with him, and he started to see Trump as a viable option.

Smart did not vote in the 2016 election, but after Trump became president, he publicly declared his support on Twitter, donning a "Make America Great Again" hat. This decision led to a torrent of insults and criticism, with Smart being called a "coon," "bootlicker," and "Uncle Tom." He has also been disinvited to preach at two spiritual revival conferences in Virginia, with one pastor citing concerns about Smart's support for Trump.

Despite the backlash, Smart remains committed to his beliefs and has not been disappointed by Trump's achievements, including a historically low unemployment rate for African-Americans, a groundbreaking prison reform law, and increased funding for historically black colleges. A recent poll shows Trump's approval rating among African-Americans has almost doubled, from 8% in 2016 to 15% now.

Smart's journey has not been easy, but he remains steadfast in his support for the president. He believes there are many others like him who secretly support Trump but are too afraid to publicly declare their allegiance. The Trump campaign is likely hoping Smart's prediction is correct, as it could be a significant boost for the president's re-election efforts.

Title: Disney Cartoon "The Owl House" Sparks Concerns about Witchcraft's Influence on Children

Article:

A new Disney cartoon, "The Owl House," has recently premiered on the Disney Channel, sparking concerns about the potential influence of witchcraft on children. The show portrays witchcraft as a positive tool to fight evil, which has raised concerns among some parents and experts. While some argue that it's just a fictional show and not a cause for concern, others, like Jenny Weaver, a former witch and lesbian, believe parents should be cautious about what their children watch.

Weaver, who grew up in a dysfunctional home and battled depression, credits a popular movie about witches with influencing her decision to explore witchcraft. She began cutting herself as a teenager and eventually became a practicing witch, believing it was a way to escape her problems. However, she later realized that her involvement with witchcraft was a demonic hold on her life, leading her to explore spells, incantations, and the Wiccan religion.

Weaver emphasizes the importance of parents being aware of the potential risks associated with exposing children to witchcraft. She notes that it's not just a matter of it being a fictional show, as the themes and ideas presented can have real-life consequences. She shares her personal story of struggling with addiction and depression, and how her involvement with witchcraft only exacerbated her problems.

Weaver's story serves as a cautionary tale about the potential dangers of exploring witchcraft and the importance of parents being vigilant about what their children watch. While "The Owl House" may be just a cartoon, it's essential for parents to be aware of the themes and messages it conveys and to have open and honest conversations with their children about the risks and consequences of exploring witchcraft.

Title: U.S. Power Grid Vulnerable to Cyber Attacks, Investigation Reveals

The United States' power grid, which supplies electricity to the military, mass transit, businesses, and millions of Americans, has been repeatedly hacked by foreign adversaries, according to a recent Associated Press investigation. The investigation found that sophisticated hackers have gained remote access to networks that control the grid, posing a significant threat to the nation's energy infrastructure.

The power grid is protected 24/7 against physical and cyber attacks, but experts warn that it was never designed with network security in mind. The grid is old and outdated, making it vulnerable to hacking. In the past decade, nearly a dozen instances of foreign hackers gaining remote access to the grid's networks have been detected.

The attacks are believed to have been carried out by hacking teams from Russia, China, and Iran, with even ISIS attempting to hack American power companies. While no catastrophic blackouts have resulted from these intrusions, experts fear that many cyber attackers already have the information they need to cause widespread disruptions.

The Department of Homeland Security is working to strengthen grid cybersecurity nationwide and raise awareness about evolving threats. Public and private cooperation is seen as key to fighting cyber attacks. As the investigation highlights, the U.S. power grid's vulnerability to cyber attacks is a pressing concern that requires immediate attention and action.

Title: Ashton Carter Assures Senators of Independence as Next Defense Secretary

Ashton Carter, President Obama's nominee for the next defense secretary, testified before the Senate Armed Services Committee on Wednesday, emphasizing his commitment to being an independent voice within the administration. Carter's testimony sparked an immediate response from the White House, with Chief Presidential Spokesman Joshua Earnest clarifying that President Obama, not Carter, sets policy.

Carter's nomination is expected to be confirmed, with two of his predecessors, Robert Gates and Chuck Hagel, having previously criticized White House micromanagement of the Pentagon. Republican senators on the committee used the confirmation hearing as an opportunity to question Carter on his plans to remain independent, particularly on issues such as arming Ukraine against Russian aggression.

Carter expressed his support for sending arms to Ukraine, stating, "I very much incline in that direction... We need to support the Ukrainians in defending themselves." He did not specify the type of weapons to be considered, but indicated that he favors providing lethal aid.

The White House responded by highlighting Carter's commitment to the chain of command and his willingness to express his opinions publicly. Carter also assured lawmakers that he would not allow the White House to pressure him into rapidly closing the U.S. military detention center at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba. He believes that President Obama's goal of closing the facility is unrealistic, but supports the effort.

Senators John McCain and Kelly Ayotte expressed concerns about White House micromanagement of the Defense Department and the potential for pressure to increase transfers from Guantanamo Bay. Carter assured the committee that he would not succumb to such pressure and would prioritize transparency and accountability in his decision-making.

Title: U.S. Adds 151,000 New Jobs in August, Unemployment Rate Remains Steady

The United States added 151,000 new jobs in August, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics' (BLS) monthly jobs report. The unemployment rate remained steady at 4.9 percent, falling short of economists' expectations of 180,000 new jobs and a slight dip in the unemployment rate to 4.8 percent.

The economy has still recorded 78 consecutive months of job growth, with job growth for the past few months revised downward. June's numbers were revised down to 271,000 from 292,000, while July's numbers were revised up to 275,000 from 255,000. The net change resulted in about 1,000 fewer jobs added in the past two months than initially believed.

Average hourly earnings rose by 3 cents to $25.73, while the percentage of involuntary part-time workers, labor force participation rate, and number of long-term unemployed remained relatively unchanged. Service-providing sectors, such as food services, social assistance, professional and technical services, and financial activities, saw growth in August. Healthcare jobs continued to increase, albeit at a slower pace than recent months, while mining employment continued its decline.

The jobs report has been closely watched in recent months as the Federal Reserve considers raising interest rates for only the second time since the global financial crisis. The August jobs report is expected to weigh in the Fed's decision on the timing of a possible rate increase. However, many analysts now expect the Federal Reserve to keep rates unchanged during its September meeting.

Title: Re-Opening Local Economies: A Call to Action

The discussion around re-opening local economies across the nation has become too focused on worst-case scenarios and fear. It's time to shift the conversation towards a more comprehensive approach that balances individual responsibility with business innovation. The COVID-19 pandemic has presented a unique challenge, but it's essential to recognize that the American spirit of resourcefulness and adaptability has always been a key factor in overcoming adversity.

From an economic standpoint, many experts have argued for re-opening America, citing the flattening of the curve and the ability of hospitals to manage the number of cases. Even epidemiologists have criticized the inconsistent models used to project fatalities, with some calling for an end to the "COVID-19 hysteria." It's time to re-open our society and bolster our consumer-driven economy, leveraging the ingenuity of the American people.

Small business owners, like those in the retail and manufacturing sectors, have shown they can adapt to new circumstances. For example, big-box stores like Target, Publix, and Walmart have remained open during shelter-in-place orders and kept customers safe. Similarly, distilleries have pivoted to produce hand sanitizers, demonstrating their ability to adjust to changing circumstances.

Throughout American history, businesses have adjusted to changing circumstances, such as the obesity epidemic and the Tylenol tampering cases. This adaptability has allowed companies like McDonald's and Coca-Cola to remain competitive. Similarly, car manufacturers have innovated to improve safety features, such as seat belts and airbags.

As the country re-opens, it's essential to recognize that personal responsibility, consumer-driven decision-making, and business innovation can coexist with safety measures. By empowering individuals to make informed choices and businesses to adapt to new circumstances, we can overcome the medical, social, economic, and emotional impacts of COVID-19.

Lenny McAllister, Director of Western Pennsylvania for the Commonwealth Foundation, emphasizes the importance of balancing individual responsibility with business innovation in the re-opening process. With more people making good decisions and businesses adapting to new circumstances, we can have more assurances that we can overcome the aftermath of the virus safely.

Title: Trump's Campaign Lags Behind Clinton's in Fundraising Efforts

The Trump campaign's fundraising efforts are off to a slow start, with a significant gap between his war chest and Hillary Clinton's. According to the Federal Election Commission, Trump's campaign had $1.3 million in the bank at the start of June, compared to Clinton's $42.5 million. Several donors backing Trump have expressed concerns about the candidate's rhetoric and policy pronouncements, which they believe are sending mixed signals and hurting the campaign's ability to raise funds.

Trump's campaign has been criticized for its lack of clarity on how much financial help it wants from outside groups, such as Super PACs. Some donors have expressed frustration with Trump's bombastic rhetoric and lack of a clear message, which they believe is turning off potential donors. "He's got to learn not to put his foot in his mouth," said Stan Hubbard, a billionaire broadcaster who has donated $100,000 to the pro-Trump Great America PAC.

Despite the challenges, four key pro-Trump Super PACs have been formally launched, with a combined total of about $5 million in ads. However, this is a far cry from the $130 million ad blitz launched by the leading pro-Clinton Super PAC, Priorities USA Action, in mid-May.

The Trump campaign's top fundraiser has signaled that a new Super PAC, Make America Number One, backed by hedge fund billionaire Robert Mercer, is the "official" one. However, this PAC will seek big checks from GOP donors who are not ready to back Trump but want to stop Clinton. The PAC has raised $2 million, with plans to raise and spend close to $20 million through the GOP convention next month and another $80 million for the rest of the campaign season.

Meanwhile, billionaire Sheldon Adelson, who has pledged $100 million to help Trump, is considering setting up his own Super PAC and talking to key Republican operatives about cobbling one together to help Trump. However, Adelson has been cautious and slow in opening his checkbook, and it is unclear if he will ultimately put up his funds.

Overall, the Trump campaign's fundraising efforts are lagging behind those of Clinton's, and it will need to find a way to turn things around if it hopes to catch up.

Title: Congress Faces Pileup of Issues Amid Scandals and Budget Talks

Article:

The United States Congress is facing a multitude of pressing issues, including the debt ceiling, budget, immigration, jobs, and the Keystone pipeline, among others. The debt ceiling was hit over the weekend, and Treasury Secretary Jack Lew has taken "extraordinary measures" to ensure the government can continue paying its bills. Lew warned Congress that it should act soon to protect the country's good credit and avoid potential catastrophic consequences.

Congressional Republicans are expected to seek cost-cutting concessions to partially offset the increase in the debt ceiling, but have not specified what those concessions will be. House Speaker John Boehner's spokesman, Michael Steel, stated that Congress has "just begun the process of talking with members" and the American people on how to address the debt ceiling and "Washington's out-of-control spending." Steel emphasized that the House will continue to work on legislation, including the Keystone pipeline and student loan measures, while also addressing scandals.

The House is focused on investigating the administration's handling of the Benghazi terror attack, the IRS's targeting of conservative groups, and the Justice Department's seizure of phone records from Associated Press journalists. The scandals have taken up a significant amount of time and resources, leaving less room for other priorities. President Obama has vowed not to let "every fleeting issue" distract him from his focus on the middle class.

The Senate and House have each passed their own budget, but an agreement has not been reached on ironing out the differences between the two versions. Some work on Capitol Hill will likely continue unaffected by the scandals, such as the Senate committee's work on an immigration bill and bipartisan House negotiators crafting their own bill.

Title: Consumers' Online Data Collection Expectations: A Disconnect Between Practices and Preferences

The California Consumer Privacy Act (CCPA) has prompted digital media companies to reevaluate their online data collection policies and procedures to ensure compliance. The law is considered the most comprehensive consumer privacy law and a benchmark for other states to follow. To better understand consumer expectations around online privacy and tracking, Digital Content Next, a trade association of major digital publishers, conducted a survey of a nationally representative sample of U.S. adults.

The survey found that consumers generally expect websites and apps to collect data about them to personalize, protect, and improve their experience. However, there is a significant disconnect between consumer expectations and current online data collection practices. When asked about outside vendors collecting data about them, only 38% of consumers expect their data to be reused, and 24% expect it to be sold.

The survey also revealed that consumers are not aware of their ability to opt out of data collection. Only 52% of U.S. adults are aware of ways to choose not to participate in online data collection. Furthermore, fewer consumers have opted out of online data collection or plan to do so in the next 30 days (40% combined) than those who do not know how to opt out or do not understand what it means to do so (44% combined).

For those who have opted out, the most common actions taken are deleting browser cookies, turning off cookies, and installing ad blockers. However, deleting cookies can have unintended consequences, such as logging out of subscription sites and depersonalizing experiences. Turning on "Do Not Track" does not completely remove consumers from online data collection, as most industry players ignore this setting.

The survey highlights the need for data collection practices to align with consumer expectations. While consumers understand the need for some data collection, there is a significant disconnect with third-party data reuse and sale. Offering seamless and simplified controls is crucial for preserving and growing trust with publishers' audiences.

Title: Buttigieg Leads in New Hampshire Primary Poll, Surging in Presidential Campaign

Article:

A recent poll conducted by the Saint Anselm College Survey Center in Manchester, New Hampshire, has shown Mayor Pete Buttigieg of South Bend, Indiana, leading the pack in the state's primary election. The poll, released on Tuesday, indicates that Buttigieg has gained a significant advantage over his top-tier contenders, with 25% of likely Democratic primary voters in New Hampshire supporting him.

Former Vice President Joe Biden and Senator Elizabeth Warren of Massachusetts are tied for second place, with each receiving 15% of the vote. Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont follows closely behind, with 9% support. The poll also shows Senator Amy Klobuchar of Minnesota at 6%, billionaire environmental and progressive advocate Tom Steyer at 5%, and Representatives Cory Booker of New Jersey and Tulsi Gabbard of Hawaii at 3% each. Tech entrepreneur Andrew Yang received 2% support, while everyone else tested in the survey stood at 1% or less.

The poll's results mark a significant surge for Buttigieg, who has gone from being considered a long shot to reaching the top tier of contenders. His favorable impression among voters has also increased, with 76% having a positive view of him and only 11% unfavorable. In contrast, Warren's support has dropped 10 points since the previous poll, while Biden's has plummeted 9 points.

The poll's findings are consistent with other recent surveys, including a Quinnipiac University poll that showed Buttigieg at 15%, Warren at 16%, Biden at 15%, and Sanders at 14%. A University of New Hampshire-CNN poll conducted late last month also showed similar results.

The poll's release comes with less than three months until the Iowa caucuses, which will kick off the presidential nominating calendar, followed by the New Hampshire primary eight days later. The results highlight the fluid nature of the race, with voters still undecided and open to changing their minds.

Title: Federal Reserve Chairman Leaves Door Open for Additional Stimulus Measures

The Federal Reserve Chairman, Ben Bernanke, has left the door open for additional stimulus measures, stating that the central bank is prepared to take action to protect the U.S. economy and financial system if the economy takes a turn for the worse. This comment has led many to speculate that the Fed may consider a third round of asset purchases, known as quantitative easing (QE).

Bernanke's press conference emphasized the importance of the job market, with the unemployment rate still at 8.2% and the latest jobs report showing a weak 69,000 jobs added in May. The Fed has extended its existing policy, Operation Twist, and lowered its expectations for the job market and the broader U.S. economy this year.

The central bank predicts the unemployment rate will end the year between 8% and 8.2%, which is less optimistic than its previous forecast of 7.8%. The Fed also sees broader weakness ahead, predicting the economy will grow between 1.9% and 2.4% this year, which is lower than its previous forecast of 2.9%.

The Fed's decision to extend Operation Twist by $267 billion aims to push interest rates lower on mortgages and business loans, hoping to boost consumer and business spending. However, the effect on Main Street has been questionable, with mortgage rates at record lows but new home sales remaining choppy and small business owners struggling to get loans.

Title: MSNBC's Chris Matthews Links Senator Ted Cruz to Murder of Prosecutors, Ignoring Criminal Element

Article:

In a recent episode of MSNBC's Hardball, host Chris Matthews made a controversial connection between Texas Senator Ted Cruz and the murders of prosecutors in Kaufman, Texas, and a prison guard in Colorado. Matthews claimed that the individuals responsible for the murders are using their Second Amendment rights to settle disputes with public officials. However, he failed to provide any evidence or context about the actual cases, instead using the opportunity to push his own agenda.

The article from the Media Research Center highlights the lack of information provided by Matthews about the Kaufman and Colorado cases. In reality, the murders of Kaufman County District Attorney Mike McLelland and his wife Cynthia were the result of an apparent assassination, with shell casings found at the scene. A law enforcement official described the scene as "awful," with "shell casings everywhere." The investigation is ongoing, and no motive has been officially confirmed.

A national security expert who has spent years working on intelligence gathering operations in the Mexican drug cartels' criminal insurgency into the continental United States believes that the assassination was meant to send a message: "no one is safe, no one is beyond our reach. We will kill you and your loved ones. We are in control here."

In contrast to Matthews' claims, the criminal element of the case is clear: violent prison gangs working with cartels to show their power. The FBI has declassified 156 pages of internal documents showing the Aryan Brotherhood's history of brutal, high-profile killings to impress upon foreign narcotics cartels and other organized crime groups that they are the best organization to handle a domestic US ground game.

In the wake of the tragic murders, county courthouses across Texas are promising beefed-up security, including armed guards. The District Attorney in Dallas County is advising prosecutors to take their own steps for personal protection, including obtaining a security handgun license.

Matthews' failure to discuss the criminal elements of the case and his tendency to lump all gun owners into the Second Amendment category are a clear example of his bias. The article concludes by challenging Matthews to discuss the actual criminal element of the problem in the United States, rather than using the opportunity to push his own agenda.

Title: New Jersey Middle School Teacher Reassigned After Kneeling During Pledge of Allegiance Recitation

A middle school teacher in New Jersey has been reassigned to a different role after she habitually kneeled during the morning recitation of the Pledge of Allegiance in homeroom. The incidents occurred at Sgt. Dominick Pilla Middle School, named after a U.S. Army Ranger who died during a 1993 mission in Somalia.

The teacher's actions sparked a heated debate among parents, with some believing her silent protest was inappropriate for the middle school setting and others defending her First Amendment rights. The Vineland Public Schools district prohibits partisan political behavior on school premises and during school hours.

During an early October school board meeting, residents expressed their concerns about the teacher's behavior, with one resident, Ron Maccri, stating, "Teachers are paid to educate our students, they're not paid to indoctrinate our students." Another resident, Randy London, a U.S. Coast Guard veteran, voiced his displeasure, saying, "That type of behavior offends me."

The Vineland Education Association's president, Lou Russo, acknowledged that the teacher's actions may have been a misstep but emphasized that students cannot be forced to stand for the Pledge of Allegiance. The district determined the teacher's fate on Tuesday, reassigning her away from conducting homeroom.

The district's executive director, Joseph Rossi, stated that the principal, Ismael Bermudez, has the authority to utilize his building staff as appropriate, and the district and the teacher agree that this is a reasonable solution for all parties. The teacher's union representative, Lou Russo, said that the school deployed a reasonable accommodation for the teacher, balancing her free exercise of religion with parents' concerns about its influence on their children. The union is awaiting a legal opinion from their state affiliate on the matter.

Title: World Health Officials Express Concern Over COVID-19 Outbreak in Iran

World health officials have expressed growing concern over the rapid spread of the COVID-19 coronavirus in Iran, where 18 new cases and four deaths have been confirmed in just two days. The outbreak has been linked to cases in Canada and Lebanon, where patients had traveled to the Middle East nation.

According to World Health Organization (WHO) Director-General Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus, the situation is "very worrisome." He emphasized that while the numbers are still small, the cases are concerning and the window of opportunity to contain the virus is narrowing. "We need to act quickly before it closes completely," he warned.

Iran's health-care system has the basic capacity to detect and contain the coronavirus, according to Dr. Jaouad Mahjour, assistant director of emergency preparedness at WHO. However, world health officials remain concerned about the potential spread of the virus to countries with weaker health systems.

As of Friday, there were 1,152 cases across 26 countries, including eight deaths, outside of China. The WHO has warned that the respiratory disease is capable of spreading through human-to-human contact, droplets carried through sneezing and coughing, and germs left on inanimate objects.

**Federal Execution of Wesley Ira Purkey Halted Amid Competency Concerns**

A federal judge has halted the execution of Wesley Ira Purkey, who was scheduled to be executed on Wednesday evening at the U.S. Penitentiary in Terre Haute, Indiana. Purkey, convicted of a gruesome 1998 kidnapping and killing, was set to be executed by lethal injection, but U.S. District Judge Tanya Chutkan imposed two injunctions prohibiting the federal Bureau of Prisons from moving forward with the execution.

The injunctions were issued due to concerns over Purkey's mental competency, with his lawyers arguing that he suffers from advancing Alzheimer's disease and is no longer mentally fit to be executed. The Justice Department immediately appealed the injunctions, and an appeals court panel kept them in place.

Purkey's execution was one of four scheduled for July and August, despite the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic. The execution of Daniel Lee, who was put to death on Tuesday, was the first of the four, and it went forward after an eleventh-hour legal bid failed.

The issue of Purkey's mental health has been raised in the past, with his lawyers arguing that he was subject to sexual and mental abuse as a child and was diagnosed with schizophrenia, bipolar disorder, major depression, and psychosis. Last week, three mental health organizations urged U.S. Attorney General William Barr to commute Purkey's sentence to life in prison without possibility of parole.

The legal battle over Purkey's execution is ongoing, with appeals to the Supreme Court still pending. The case highlights the complexities and controversies surrounding capital punishment, with some arguing that executing mentally ill individuals is a violation of human rights and others believing that justice must be served.

Title: Massachusetts Senator-Elect Elizabeth Warren Reports Campaign Debt Despite Raising Record Amount

Article: Massachusetts Senator-elect Elizabeth Warren, a Harvard Law professor and renowned scholar of American debt, has revealed that her campaign does not have enough funds to pay its bills, despite raising a record-breaking $42 million for her Senate race. Warren's campaign has not disclosed the exact amount of debt, but attributed the shortfall to the thousands of volunteers who supported her campaign, resulting in increased expenses for "last-minute coffee and pizza."

Warren's campaign, which was one of the most expensive Senate races in the country, has sent multiple requests for donations to supporters, asking for help to pay off the remaining bills. In an email, Warren acknowledged that the campaign's "embarrassment of riches" led to a debt, stating, "Everyone, we need a little more money to pay off our final bills. Can you help one more time?"

It is not uncommon for campaigns to end in debt, even those that are well-funded. However, Warren's situation is notable given her expertise on debt and its impact on American families and businesses. Despite her campaign's success, Warren is seeking additional support to wrap up the 2012 election cycle.

Title: Ohio Polls Show Tightening Race, Romney's Chances Remain Strong

The race for Ohio is intensifying, with Mitt Romney closing the gap with President Barack Obama in recent polls. According to the Real Clear Politics average, Romney has trimmed four-tenths of a point off his deficit, now trailing Obama by 2.1 points. However, Romney's chances of winning Ohio remain strong, despite the polls suggesting otherwise.

One reason for Romney's optimism is his growing strength among independents. In the past week, Romney has increased his lead among independents to 12.3 points, up from 8.7 points last week. This is a significant advantage, as Obama won Ohio in 2008 by just eight points among independents.

Another factor working in Romney's favor is the polls' tendency to overstate early voting. According to estimates, 15% of voters have already cast their ballots, but poll respondents claim 23% have voted. This discrepancy could be due to voters overstating their participation or reporting absentee ballots that have not yet been counted.

Obama's early-voting advantage, which gives him a 20-point lead, may be illusory. Romney's Election Day voter lead is helping him chip away at Obama's overall lead, and the Republican candidate is well-positioned to win Ohio without ever showing a consistent lead in the polls.

Historically, late deciders tend to break against the incumbent, which could benefit Romney. In 2004, late deciders broke against George W. Bush heavily, and a similar trend could occur this year.

Additionally, Republicans tend to outperform their share of the national vote in Ohio, and Romney is currently running ahead of Obama nationally. If Romney wins over more Democrat votes than he loses Republican ones, as he has in the past two elections, Obama's lead in Ohio may be difficult to overcome.

With less than two weeks until Election Day, the outcome is still uncertain. However, Romney's rallies and enthusiasm among Republicans suggest that the picture for the Republican candidate is better than many pundits would have us believe.

Title: House Republicans Confident of Passing Funding Bill Before Government Shutdown

Article:

House Republicans are confident that they will pass their $1.1 trillion, nine-month government funding bill before the government shuts down on Thursday. According to top aides and lawmakers on the GOP whip team, between 150 and 175 Republicans are expected to support the bill. Senior House Democrats predict that some of their members will help make up for Republican defections to get the bill across the finish line.

The bill, which extends government funding through September 2015, has been negotiated by top aides to Speaker John Boehner and Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid. The deal includes provisions that loosen Wall Street regulations and campaign finance laws, which have raised concerns among some Democrats.

Despite these concerns, House Majority Leader Kevin McCarthy and Minority Whip Steny Hoyer have been in close contact throughout the process, with Hoyer expressing skepticism about the bill's provisions. However, senior House Democrats predict that some of their members will support the bill, making up for Republican defections.

The bill's passage is seen as a key test for House Republicans, who have promised to avoid a government shutdown. If the bill fails, Boehner has threatened to put a three-month stop-gap spending bill on the floor, setting up a fiscal fight next year when Republicans have control of both chambers.

White House officials have signaled a preference for the larger funding package, which locks in many Democratic and Republican funding priorities deep into 2015. As of late Wednesday evening, Republicans were not making fallback plans if the bill failed, and House Democrats were not formally whipping against the measure.

The government will begin to shut down by Friday morning if nothing passes, but almost no one expects a shutdown. The session of Congress that started with a failed coup attempt against Boehner will likely end with a bipartisan vote to fund the government, including Obamacare and the president's changes to immigration law that conservatives hate.

Lawmakers are angry that they only had one full day to read a 1,600-page spending bill, which extends government funding through September 2015 and Homeland Security funding through February. The bill includes provisions that help big banks trade derivatives in units backed by a government guarantee and allow national party committees to collect $777,000 each year from individuals, up from $32,400 annually under current law.

High-profile lawmakers like Rep. Chris Van Hollen and Sen. Elizabeth Warren have vowed to vote against the bill, backed by progressive groups on the outside who are seizing on Pelosi's skepticism. Republicans are also worried that the legislation doesn't pick a strong enough fight with Obama over his unilateral changes to immigration law.

Boehner has faced criticism for breaking one of his central 2010 campaign promises: that he would advance legislative issues one at a time. However, he has defended the bill, saying that many provisions were negotiated in a bipartisan, bicameral fashion and that some legislation gets "built up" and never gets to the floor.

The mood was tense in the Capitol on Wednesday when GOP leaders started whipping the bill, but Pelosi and Boehner have been in close contact. If the bill fails, Scalise could catch blame, but if the GOP posts better-than-expected numbers, he'll start off the 114th Congress with a stronger hand.

Title: Pence Outshines Kaine in Debate, Exposing Hillary Campaign's Demagogic Cheapness

Article:

The vice presidential debate between Mike Pence and Tim Kaine took place on October 4, with Pence emerging as the clear winner. Pence's calm and authoritative demeanor stood in stark contrast to Kaine's aggressive and interruptive style. Kaine, who repeatedly interrupted Pence, struggled to articulate his points and seemed more focused on rattling off opposition research than engaging in a substantive discussion.

Pence, on the other hand, effectively redirected the debate to focus on Hillary Clinton's failed record and the clear themes of the Trump campaign. He calmly and authoritatively reiterated basic points about Clinton's tax-and-spend policies and feckless foreign policy, which proved more effective than any point-by-point rebuttal could have. Pence also wisely chose not to take the bait and engage in a back-and-forth with Kaine, instead focusing on the issues.

The debate highlighted Kaine's lack of preparation and his tendency to rely on memorized talking points. He struggled to answer questions and often seemed frustrated when corrected by the moderator. Pence, meanwhile, remained calm and composed, using his steady presence to command the debate and redirect the conversation to serious issues.

The article also touched on Kaine's questionable character, citing his willingness to sell off his scruples for a seat at Hillary's table. Pence effectively pointed out Kaine's inconsistencies, including his claim that his Catholic faith would have no relevance to his public life, despite touting it as proof of his character. Kaine's stance on abortion and his willingness to enforce laws he disagrees with as governor of Virginia were also criticized.

Overall, the debate showed that less is often more, as Pence's calm and authoritative approach proved more effective than Kaine's aggressive and interruptive style.

Title: Bipartisanship in Action: A Cadre of Republicans and Democrats Work Together to Get the Job Done

Article:

In the midst of political polarization, a group of individuals from both sides of the aisle are quietly working together to tackle the nation's most pressing issues. This group, comprising individuals who have served in multiple administrations, hail from industries outside of Washington, and hold different points of view, has found ways to collaborate and achieve success.

One such individual is a registered Republican who has served four presidents, including one Democrat. This individual has partnered with Michelle Obama's office on the "Let's Move" anti-obesity campaign and has built complex public-private partnerships to help solve big problems. By modifying Ronald Reagan's 80/20 rule, this individual created their own 60/40 rule: if they agree with someone on 60 percent of the issues, they can agree to disagree on the 40 percent and focus on areas of commonality.

This approach is not unique among a strata of people who line up on one side of the aisle but find ways to work with the other side. As Mark Twain noted, "Patriotism is supporting your country all the time, and your government when it deserves it." This sentiment is shared by many across the political spectrum with whom this individual has worked.

In 2009, 16 CEOs from consumer goods companies joined this individual as members of the Healthy Weight Commitment Foundation. Working collaboratively with public health agencies and the Obama administration, conservatives and liberals alike joined forces to implement the largest voluntary food and beverage industry marketplace initiative, ultimately removing 6.4 trillion calories from the American diet by reducing the sugar and fat content of hundreds of products. In 2005, as U.S. Commissioner General, this individual worked alongside governors from both parties and the private sector to launch the US Pavilion at the Aichi World EXPO, formerly known as the World's Fair.

Similar approaches are on display in various bipartisan commissions and blue ribbon panels that have tackled issues such as Social Security, biodefenses, tax reform, and the September 11, 2001, terrorist attacks. Many of these efforts are ongoing, both at the state and federal levels, even amid the rancor that permeates current politics. These efforts succeed because the end goal is what matters, not party ideology.

The principles of bipartisanship employed in these efforts are common in many areas beyond politics, such as in the office, at the doctor's office, at the playground, at church, and at home. They focus on personal consideration, listening, and respect, knowing that if they want to succeed, they can't expect others to approach the problem in the identical way, so it becomes imperative to do things differently. They turn the idea on its head, think of new paths, and be bold.

In conclusion, bipartisanship is not dead, but it is alive and in need of further nurturing. As Ronald Reagan won the nation over with his sunny optimism, we must remember that the graciousness he epitomized in political discourse is just as important.

Title: Michelle Obama Surprises at Oscars Ceremony, Introduces Best Picture Winner

Article:

Michelle Obama made a surprise appearance at the 85th Academy Awards ceremony on Sunday, introducing the Best Picture winner, "Argo," via satellite from the Governors' Ball in Washington, D.C. The First Lady's introduction was preceded by a brief awkward moment with Jack Nicholson, who was introducing the nominees. Obama's appearance was met with a mix of excitement and criticism from social media users.

In her introduction, Obama praised the nine nominated films, saying they "took us back in time and all around the world," and taught us that "love can endure against all odds and transform our lives in the most surprising ways." She also emphasized the importance of perseverance and believing in oneself.

The surprise appearance sparked a range of reactions on social media, with some users praising Obama's involvement and others criticizing her for doing too many celebrity appearances. Some users also joked about the potential for her to appear in future movie theater previews, telling viewers to turn off their cellphones and put away their popcorn.

The White House Twitter account, @FLOTUS, congratulated the "Argo" team on their win, with Michelle Obama herself tweeting "It was a thrill to announce the #Oscars2013 best picture winner from the @whitehouse! Congratulations Argo!"

Title: Easter Amidst Turmoil: A Call to Reflection and Transformation

In a world beset by division and turmoil, Easter offers a respite from the chaos. The holiday's themes of sacrifice, redemption, and rebirth provide a much-needed respite from the constant barrage of negative news and divisive rhetoric. As the world grapples with the consequences of its own fault lines – race, gender, class, immigration status, religion, sexual orientation, and more – Easter serves as a reminder of the importance of forgiveness, compassion, and unity.

The article highlights the stark contrast between the Easter message of love and redemption and the current state of the world. The author notes that the fault lines of society are more pronounced than ever, with individuals preparing for the "quake" that brings it all down. The article also touches on the impact of the current political climate, where individuals are either cheering or crying out in response to the actions of those in power.

The author reflects on the Easter story, noting that it is a tale of a faultless man who absorbs the faults of others, sacrifices himself for the greater good, and brings life to others through his defeat of death. The article juxtaposes this story with the values of our current times, where individuals are often more focused on their own interests and less concerned with the well-being of others.

The author concludes by musing about what it will take for individuals to experience a collective transformation and return to a state of wholeness. They suggest that it may require a major event, such as an election or disaster, or a personal transformation that leads to a newfound sense of empathy and compassion. The article concludes by noting that Easter offers a glimmer of hope for a brighter future, and that once individuals catch a glimpse of it, they may take a step towards redemption.

Title: Trump's Egotistical Nature May Seal His Defeat

Article: Donald Trump's refusal to commit to accepting the outcome of the election has dominated post-debate coverage, and for good reason. It is a shocking statement, except for the fact that it is consistent with his behavior throughout the campaign. Trump's inability to accept the possibility of defeat stems from his unstable and disordered personality, which has been a major weakness throughout his campaign.

Trump's obsession with polls and his awareness of the overwhelming odds against him have led him to manufacture an excuse for his impending defeat. He has repeatedly claimed that the election is rigged, a claim that not only undermines the democratic process but will also likely increase his margin of defeat.

The more Americans are exposed to Trump, the more unsettled and unnerved they become. He does not come across as an agent of change, but rather a radical and destabilizing force that hurts his chances. Trump's narcissism was on full display during the debate, as he prioritized his own vanity and self-obsession over the best interests of the nation.

Trump's character flaw has led to several poor moments during the campaign, including his inability to cite his favorite Bible passage. A passage that could have taught him a valuable lesson: "Pride goes before destruction, a haughty spirit before a fall." Peter Wehner, a contributing opinion writer and former staffer in the last three Republican administrations, notes that Trump's egotistical nature has been a major factor in his campaign's failures.

Title: US May Not See a Second Wave of Covid-19 Cases, Says Dr. Anthony Fauci

The United States has recorded over 2 million cases of Covid-19 and nearly 115,000 deaths, according to researchers at Johns Hopkins University in Maryland. Despite concerns about a potential second wave of cases, Dr. Anthony Fauci, a leading public health expert and member of the White House coronavirus taskforce, has stated that the country may not experience a second surge in infections.

Fauci, the director of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases, told CNN that increases in cases in several states are not necessarily indicative of a second wave. He emphasized the importance of maintaining social distancing and wearing masks in public to prevent the spread of the virus.

According to the federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), nearly 80% of Americans have self-isolated in the last month, and 74% have worn face coverings in public either always or often. Residents of New York and Los Angeles have taken these precautions seriously, with around 90% of them self-isolating and wearing masks.

In recent days, 19 states have reported seven-day rolling average highs for new Covid-19 infections. Arkansas, for example, has seen a record number of cases in the past 24 hours, while Oregon has placed a seven-day hold on lifting social restrictions. Maryland has also delayed its reopening plans.

The CDC has not confirmed reports of striking increases in coronavirus hospitalizations but will continue to monitor the numbers closely. The news has sent stock markets into a tailspin, but some experts are becoming more optimistic about the development of a vaccine.

Former CDC director Julie Gerberding told CNN that the science is on the side of a vaccine, but cautioned that it is too early to say whether it will be safe, durable, and effective.

In New York City, mass protests have sparked fears of a resurgence of the virus, but new infections are now at the lowest level in the entire US. New York Governor Andrew Cuomo credited the state's residents for their discipline and responsibility in preventing the spread of the virus.

Title: Ted Cruz Raises Nearly $20 Million in Latest Quarter, Largest Fundraising Haul Yet

Ted Cruz, a Republican presidential hopeful, has raised nearly $20 million in the past three months, according to an internal memo obtained by NBC News. This significant haul brings Cruz's total fundraising figure for the year to $45 million, surpassing his previous quarterly total of $12.2 million.

Cruz's campaign has not publicly disclosed its current cash reserves, but at the beginning of October, it had $13.8 million on hand. The senator's fundraising total is matched by the efforts of several super PACs supporting his candidacy, which have raised $38 million through September. The super PACs have spent little of that money, leaving a significant amount available for future use.

The extra funds will give Cruz's campaign expanded resources to potentially purchase advertising in the upcoming early states. However, the campaign has thus far resisted spending on traditional television and radio advertising, spending less than $1 million in total. Instead, it plans to buy television airtime on a week-to-week basis.

Cruz's campaign has emphasized its ability to go the distance, with a campaign aide stating, "We're showing we have the strength going into the Iowa caucus. If people want to get behind a candidate who can go the distance, we're showing we've got that."

**New York Surpasses 11,600 Coronavirus Cases, Governor Orders Statewide Lockdown**

New York has seen a significant surge in coronavirus cases, with over 4,500 new cases reported on Saturday, bringing the statewide total to over 11,600. The state's epicenter, New York City, accounted for the majority of the increase, with over 2,400 new cases reported. The city's death toll has risen to 60, with at least 15 more fatalities reported on Saturday.

The statewide death toll has exceeded 70, with a total of 25,000 cases reported nationwide, according to data from Johns Hopkins University. In response to the mounting crisis, Governor Andrew Cuomo has promised to purchase 6,000 new ventilators and two million virus-blocking N95 masks.

The governor has directed hospitals statewide to end elective surgeries and alter their space and staffing to accommodate the flood of infected patients. New York is also reviewing four possible locations for temporary "field hospitals" to be set up by the Army Corps of Engineers and operated with FEMA assistance.

The state is working to increase its hospital bed capacity from 50,000 to 70,000, with some 15% of infected patients requiring hospitalization. The governor has urged all but essential workers to stay home or stay apart, and a lockdown will take effect on Sunday night, limiting non-essential businesses and activities.

In related news, New Jersey has also joined the list of states imposing restrictions on movement, with Governor Phil Murphy directing most residents to stay home. The state's sick tally has risen to 1,327, with 16 deaths reported.

The lockdown will force the shutdown of most businesses, with the exception of grocery stores, bodegas, liquor stores, gas stations, laundromats, and restaurant delivery services. The city has appointed a "Food Czar" to ensure no one goes hungry, and exercising outdoors is limited to solitary activities like walking, biking, and running.

Title: Obama Leads Romney by 13 Points in Latest Bloomberg Poll

Article:

According to a recent Bloomberg poll conducted from June 15-18, President Barack Obama leads Republican challenger Mitt Romney by 13 percentage points among likely voters, with Obama receiving 53% of the vote and Romney receiving 40%. The survey also found that while Obama receives low marks on handling the economy and the deficit, six in 10 Americans believe the nation is headed in the wrong direction.

The poll also highlights that Romney has yet to recover from the damage done to his image during the Republican primary, with 39% of Americans viewing him favorably and 48% viewing him unfavorably, a 17-percentage point increase since his presidential candidacy announcement last June. Additionally, a majority of likely voters (55%) view Romney as more out of touch with average Americans compared to 36% who say the same about Obama.

The survey's findings have sparked questions about the accuracy of the poll and the current state of the presidential race. Some have noted that the poll's sample is skewed, while others have questioned the significance of Obama's 13-point lead, given the recent polls from Rasmussen and Gallup showing Romney ahead by identical 47-45 margins. Others have pointed out that Obama's lead is not as commanding as it seems, given his ties or slight leads in recent polls from Michigan and Iowa, both states he won by double digits in the previous election.

The article also raises questions about the accuracy of the poll and the current state of the presidential race, noting that Obama's lead may be due to a combination of factors, including his opponents' failed attacks, party defections, and economic news.

Title: Senator John McCain Criticizes President Obama's Handling of Foreign Policy

Article: Senator John McCain (R-AZ) appeared on CNN's "State of the Union" and expressed his concerns about President Barack Obama's leadership on foreign policy over the past eight years. McCain stated that the president's response to Russian hacking has been inadequate, with no clear strategy or policy to address the issue.

According to McCain, the president's response to Russian hacking has been an "acknowledgement and endorsement" of the attacks, which have potentially disrupted an American election. He emphasized the need for a select committee to investigate the hacking and determine the extent of the damage. McCain also expressed concern about the ongoing cyber attacks on the US military and other areas of American life, stating that Russia is hacking every day and that the US has no strategy or policy to address this issue.

McCain also discussed the broader implications of the president's leadership on foreign policy, stating that the seizure of ships, cyber attacks, and dismemberment of Syria are signs of the unraveling of the world order established after World War II. He attributed this unraveling to the failure of American leadership, noting that when the US does not lead, "bad people" fill the vacuum. McCain specifically mentioned the tragic situation in Aleppo, stating that it is heartbreaking and a result of the lack of American leadership.

Title: Alabama Senator Doug Jones Criticizes "Gaps in Testimony" in Impeachment Case

Senator Doug Jones, a Democrat from Alabama, has expressed concerns about the impeachment case against President Trump, stating that there are "gaps in testimony" and that he is still trying to determine whether the evidence warrants Trump's removal from office. Jones made these comments in an interview with ABC's The Week.

Jones emphasized the importance of interviewing witnesses and obtaining documents to ensure a "full, fair, and complete trial." He criticized President Trump for ordering his top officials who were in the room during the events in question not to testify and for refusing to turn over documents. The senator believes that this lack of transparency is hindering the investigation and making it difficult to determine the truth.

However, Jones also acknowledged that he would need to see a clear connection between the evidence and Trump's removal from office before he would support impeachment. "If those dots aren't connected and there are other explanations that I think are consistent with innocence, I will go that way too," he said.

The senator's comments come as he faces a tough reelection battle in 2020, with a new poll showing him trailing several Republican challengers, including former Attorney General Jeff Sessions, former Auburn head football coach Tommy Tuberville, and Representative Bradley Byrne. Despite this, Jones denied that his reelection concerns were influencing his decision-making, stating that his vote was based on the future of the presidency and how presidents should conduct themselves.

Title: Rubio Questions Effectiveness of Tax Overhaul in Boosting American Workers

The Republican U.S. Senator Marco Rubio has expressed doubts about the effectiveness of the recent tax overhaul in benefiting American workers. In an interview with the Economist magazine, Rubio stated that there is "no evidence whatsoever" that the law has led to significant investments in American workers. Instead, he noted that corporations have primarily used their tax savings to buy back shares and give out bonuses.

The tax overhaul, passed by the Republican-controlled Congress in December, permanently reduced the corporate tax rate from 35% to 21%.
