Several Christian leaders responded to Lemon's claim, with Dr. Derwin L. Gray, a pastor based in North Carolina, tweeting, "Good sir, Jesus was perfect. He had no sin. He is the unblemished Lamb of God who takes away the sins of the world." Gray offered to provide theological advice to Lemon, who grew up learning Christian doctrine and should have known better than to make a claim about Jesus' imperfection.

The article does not take a stance on the matter, instead presenting the differing views and biblical passages that support the idea that Jesus was perfect and sinless.

Title: Columnists' Blind Spot: Criticizing Hillary Clinton's Email Practices While Ignoring Her Other Controversies

Article:

Dana Milbank and Ruth Marcus, two columnists at The Washington Post, have written columns criticizing Hillary Clinton's decision to use a private email server while serving as Secretary of State. While they acknowledge that her actions may have been a "self-inflicted wound" on her campaign, they fail to address other controversies surrounding the Clinton family's activities. Specifically, they do not consider the Clinton Foundation's acceptance of donations from foreign countries while Hillary Clinton was Secretary of State, nor do they investigate the foundation's potential conflicts of interest.

Milbank and Marcus argue that Clinton's decision to use a private email server was a "massive failure of staff" and that she was motivated by a desire for privacy. However, they do not consider the potential security risks associated with using a private server for official business. They also do not explore the potential consequences of Clinton's actions, such as the potential for foreign governments to influence her decisions as Secretary of State.

In contrast, the article suggests that the media has been too focused on Clinton's email practices and has not adequately investigated other controversies surrounding the Clinton family. The article notes that the media has given relatively little attention to the Clinton Foundation's acceptance of donations from foreign countries while Hillary Clinton was Secretary of State, and that the networks have offered only limited coverage of the foundation's potential conflicts of interest.

Overall, the article argues that Milbank and Marcus have a blind spot when it comes to criticizing Hillary Clinton's email practices, and that they fail to consider the broader context of her actions as Secretary of State.

Title: CNN and MSNBC Spend Hours Promoting Debunked Study on Hydroxychloroquine, Ignore Retraction

Article:

CNN and MSNBC dedicated a significant amount of airtime to promoting a study on hydroxychloroquine and its potential dangers, despite the study being retracted due to numerous issues. The study, published in The Lancet, claimed that taking hydroxychloroquine while battling COVID-19 could be fatal. CNN spent 90 minutes and 54 seconds covering the study, while MSNBC devoted 19 minutes and 19 seconds to it.

The study was initially hailed as a major development by CNN's weekday morning co-hosts Poppy Harlow and Jim Sciutto, who described it as "big news" and a "major development" that spelled "real danger" for patients taking hydroxychloroquine. Inside Politics host John King also weighed in, calling it "another violent collision between what the President thinks and says, and the more disciplined world of science and data."

MSNBC's Rachel Maddow also covered the study, stating that it signaled Trump's promotion of hydroxychloroquine had "moved on from absurd and sort of insane to a potentially deadly threat." Morning Joe hosts Joe Scarborough and Mika Brzezinski paused a segment to share the breaking news, with Scarborough describing it as "the death of" the drug.

However, the study has since been retracted due to numerous issues, including concerns about the accuracy of the data and ethical concerns surrounding the company involved, Surgisphere Corporation. The Lancet stated that it "takes issues of scientific integrity extremely seriously" and that there are "many outstanding questions about Surgisphere and the data that were allegedly included in this study."

Despite the retraction, CNN has only given the news one minute and 45 seconds of coverage, while MSNBC has ignored it entirely. This lack of coverage stands in contrast to the extensive coverage given to the original study, which was touted as a major development in the fight against COVID-19.

Title: Tea Party Patriots Citizens Fund SuperPAC Launches to Empower Grassroots Activists in Key Senate Races

The Tea Party Patriots Citizens Fund SuperPAC, launched on Monday, aims to mobilize grassroots activists in key Senate races ahead of the 2014 midterm elections. The organization, led by Jenny Beth Martin, president and co-founder, seeks to empower local tea party groups and individuals to make a difference in targeted districts and states.

The SuperPAC is currently focusing on key Senate races in South Carolina, Kentucky, Mississippi, Nebraska, Louisiana, and North Carolina, with plans to expand its efforts further. Martin emphasizes that the Citizens Fund is "community organizing for conservatives," with a unique approach of providing resources and support to tens of thousands of grassroots activists across the country.

The organization has also launched an early-bird presidential straw poll, featuring candidates who align with the membership's values, including Republican Sens. Ted Cruz, Rand Paul, Marco Rubio, Rep. Paul Ryan, Wisconsin Gov. Scott Walker, and Sarah Palin.

In Kentucky, an interesting dynamic is emerging, with Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell running neck-and-neck with Democratic challenger Alison Lundergan Grimes in a recent poll. However, McConnell's GOP primary rival, Matt Bevin, leads Grimes by six points, according to a survey conducted by pollster Scott Rasmussen.

The results suggest that Bevin may have a stronger chance of defeating Grimes in the general election, prompting Matt Kibbe, president of FreedomWorks for America, to declare that "anybody interested in protecting this Republican Senate seat needs to revisit the premise that a do-nothing incumbent is a safe bet."

Title: Analysis of the Proposed Amnesty Bill's Tax Provisions

The proposed amnesty bill has been met with controversy, with some arguing that it does not require illegal immigrants to pay back taxes for the years they have worked off the books. According to Jon Feere, legal policy analyst at the Center for Immigration Studies, this is true. The bill does not require illegal immigrants to pay back taxes, but rather only requires them to resolve any existing issues with the IRS.

Feere notes that the 45% of illegal immigrants estimated to be working off the books are unlikely to have ever been audited by the IRS, as they are not on the agency's radar. Of those who have been audited, the number is likely small, as the IRS historically audits only about 1% of tax filers.

The current tax provision in the bill will not have any significant impact on the overwhelming majority of illegal immigrants who apply for amnesty. In fact, an amendment has been proposed that would require payment of back taxes for the period amnesty applicants have worked illegally in the United States.

The bill also does not require employers of illegal immigrants to pay FICA taxes for the years they paid illegal immigrants under the table. This is not a new development, as a similar provision was included in the 1986 amnesty bill, which barred amnesty adjudicators from sharing tax information with the IRS. Senator Charles Schumer (D-NY) argued that this was necessary to ensure a successful legalization program, as submitting an application should not make an alien vulnerable to an enforcement action by the IRS. The Bush administration also requested that a back-taxes provision be removed from the failed 2007 amnesty bill.

Title: Gun Rights Activists Criticize Katie Couric's Documentary for Deceptive Editing

Gun rights activists featured in the documentary "Under the Gun" have accused host Katie Couric of using deceptive editing to misrepresent their responses to a question about gun ownership. The film, which premiered on Epix on May 15, features a roundtable discussion with members of the Virginia Citizens Defense League. In a clip from the documentary, Couric asks the group, "If there are no background checks for gun purchasers, how do you prevent felons or terrorists from purchasing a gun?" The clip appears to show nine seconds of silence before the activists respond.

However, audio released to the Washington Free Beacon reveals that the activists did answer the question immediately after it was posed. Director Stephanie Soechtig told The Washington Post that the pause was intended to give viewers time to consider the question. Couric has defended the film and expressed pride in its production.

The controversy has sparked outrage among some, with the Independent Women's Forum calling for Couric to be fired. Culture of Alarmism Director Julie Gunlock stated, "Katie Couric should be ashamed of herself for her dishonest and distorted reporting on this issue." The National Rifle Association (NRA) also criticized the editing, calling it "outrageous" and "unbelievable," and urged Couric to explain the editing.

The backlash against Couric has been swift, with some social media users calling for her to apologize and questioning her credibility. The controversy has also sparked a wider discussion about the ethics of documentary filmmaking and the potential for deceptive editing to influence public opinion.

Title: Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau Wins Second Term, Falls Short of Majority

Article:

Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau has won a second term in office, but fell short of securing a majority government. The Liberal Party, led by Trudeau, took the most seats in Parliament, giving it the best chance to form a government. However, the party will need to rely on opposition parties to pass legislation.

Trudeau's campaign was marred by a series of scandals, including the surfacing of old photos of him in blackface and brownface. Despite this, he still managed to deliver unexpectedly strong results, with the Liberal Party winning 156 seats in the 338-seat House of Commons.

The election was seen as a choice between Trudeau and Conservative leader Andrew Scheer, who was seen as a more low-key alternative to Trudeau's flashy style. Scheer had promised to cut government spending and end a national carbon tax, but his campaign was criticized for being negative and divisive.

Trudeau's campaign focused on his progressive agenda, including climate change and immigration. He had promised to take bold action on climate change and had implemented a carbon tax to fight it. He had also legalized cannabis nationwide and had negotiated a new free trade deal with the U.S. and Mexico.

The results of the election were seen as a victory for Trudeau, despite the challenges he faced. He will now have to work with opposition parties to pass legislation and implement his policies.

Title: Christians Embrace Story of Jesus' Birth at Christmas, Highlighting Refugee Crisis

As Christmas approaches, Christians around the world are reflecting on the true meaning of the holiday. For many, it's a time of joy, gift-giving, and festive traditions. However, for those who take their faith seriously, the story of Jesus' birth is at the forefront. The narrative of a young family fleeing violence and seeking a safe haven resonates deeply with many.

According to Jay Parini, a poet and novelist, and author of "Jesus: The Human Face of God," the story of Jesus' birth is a powerful reminder of the importance of welcoming refugees. Parini, who teaches at Middlebury College in Vermont, emphasizes that Jesus' message is one of love and compassion, urging people to fight hate with love, whether it's from Herod or ISIS leader Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi.

The biblical account tells the story of a young family from Galilee, including a pregnant mother, who arrive in a small town as strangers. The inn is full, and they are forced to take shelter in a manger. The magi, or wise men, later arrive from the East, seeking to worship the newborn Jesus, but their visit inadvertently alerts the wicked King Herod to the child's existence. Fearing Jesus may be a future rival, Herod orders the execution of all young boys in Bethlehem, prompting an angel to instruct Joseph to flee to Egypt with his family, making Jesus a refugee on the run for his life.

As the world grapples with the ongoing refugee crisis, the story of Jesus' birth serves as a poignant reminder of the importance of compassion, empathy, and understanding. For those who take their faith seriously, the message of Jesus' birth is a powerful call to action, urging people to use love to combat hate and to welcome those fleeing violence and persecution.

Title: Obama Emphasizes Importance of Grounding Children in Reality

Article:

Former President Barack Obama has spoken about the importance of keeping his daughters, Sasha and Malia, grounded in reality despite their privileged upbringing in the White House. In an interview with Amazon editor David Blum, Obama emphasized that he and his wife, Michelle, make it a point to remind their daughters that their situation is not the norm.

According to Obama, having relatives who do not live in a similar environment has helped keep his children grounded. He noted that they have cousins who struggle to make ends meet, which has given them a different perspective on life. "Malia and Sasha have cousins who know what it's like to struggle and know what it's like to have to scrape by," Obama said. "They know that those kids are just as worthy as they are, they just haven't had as much luck."

Obama also attributed the changing perception of what constitutes a "normal" life to the constant bombardment of information about the wealthy and famous. He noted that children today are exposed to a constant stream of information about the lifestyles of the rich and famous, which can create unrealistic expectations. "There was not that window into the lifestyles of the rich and famous," he said. "Kids weren't monitoring every day what Kim Kardashian was wearing, or where Kanye West was going on vacation, and thinking that somehow that was the mark of success."

In contrast, Obama said that when he was growing up, children did not have the same level of exposure to celebrity lifestyles. "If you look back on your childhood, or if I talk to my friends, all of us have that same impression when we go back home and we realize that the place where we were living was pretty small," he said. "These days people would say, 'How did you live in a place that small?' Well, it didn't feel that small at the time. It was secure. It was stable."

Overall, Obama's comments highlight the importance of providing children with a realistic understanding of the world and the challenges that many people face, in order to help them develop a sense of empathy and perspective.

**North Korea Conducts Underwater Test-Firing of Submarine Ballistic Missile**

North Korea has conducted an underwater test-firing of a submarine ballistic missile, according to the Korean Central News Agency (KCNA). The test, which took place on Friday near the Sinpo South Shipyard on the east coast, was described as a "world-level strategic weapon" and an "eye-opening success" by North Korean leader Kim Jong Un.

The KCNA report stated that the missile "soared into the sky from underwater," and Kim was seen smiling from a distance at what appeared to be a floating submarine. The test was reportedly designed to demonstrate the North's military capabilities and its ability to strike at enemy forces in any waters.

Experts in Seoul believe that the North's military demonstrations and hostile rhetoric are attempts to secure concessions from the United States and South Korea, which have recently discussed the possibility of holding preliminary talks with the North to test its commitment to denuclearization of the Korean Peninsula.

The test comes as the North has been pressing to resume talks to denuclearize the Korean Peninsula. The last public U.S. attempt to restart the six-party process, involving China, Japan, Russia, South Korea, North Korea, and the U.S., collapsed in 2012 after the North launched a long-range rocket.

The North has also threatened to fire without warning at South Korean naval vessels that it claims have been violating its territorial waters off the western coast of the Korean Peninsula. South Korea's presidential Blue House held an emergency national security council meeting to review the threat and discuss possible countermeasures.

Intelligence sources from Seoul and Washington claim that Pyongyang has been developing a submarine-launched ballistic missile (SLBM) and has succeeded in installing a missile launcher onto a submarine after conducting a series of experiments on shore and underwater. The development of this capability is seen as part of efforts by North Korea to equip its missiles with miniaturized nuclear bombs.

The move is also seen as a potential new threat to South Korea, Japan, and U.S. bases in East Asia, although North Korea's submarines are believed to be old and vulnerable to attack. The South Korean navy has laid out a plan to build six 3,000-ton submarines equipped with vertical missile launchers between 2027 and 2030.

Title: Biden Discusses Unwanted Touching, Plans to Change Campaign Style

Former Vice President Joe Biden addressed recent allegations of unwanted physical contact during a speech to the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, joking that he had permission to touch those he hugged or touched. Biden's comments come after several women accused him of making them uncomfortable with his hugs, shoulder grasps, and other close physical contact.

In response to questions from reporters, Biden expressed regret that he did not understand the impact of his actions, stating, "I'm sorry that I didn't understand more." However, he emphasized that his intentions were not the issue, saying, "I'm not sorry for my intentions. I'm not sorry for anything I've ever done." Biden acknowledged that his actions will need to change, stating, "I think it's going to have to change how I campaign."

Biden also hinted at a potential 2020 presidential bid, saying he is "very close" to making an announcement. He noted that he has been advised by lawyers to be cautious with his words to avoid triggering the start of the campaign clock.

When asked about his chances in the Democratic primary, Biden dismissed the label of being a moderate, stating that the majority of Democratic voters are still liberal-to-moderate. He emphasized his alignment with the Obama-Biden administration and expressed pride in his political views.

In related news, President Trump defended a parody video showing Biden being approached from behind and rubbed by a second Biden, saying people "got a kick out of it." Trump also stated that he does not view Biden as a threat and believes Biden is only a threat to himself. After Biden's speech, Trump tweeted that the union workers will be voting for him instead.

Title: Senate Republicans Join Democrats to Terminate National Emergency Declaration

A rare bipartisan rebuke of President Trump's national emergency declaration was passed by the Senate on Thursday, with 12 Republican senators joining Democrats to terminate the move. The 59-41 vote was a significant blow to the president, who will now issue the first veto of his presidency to preserve the emergency declaration.

The 12 Republican senators who voted to terminate the national emergency declaration came from a range of ideological backgrounds, from conservative to moderate. Most argued that the president was operating outside the rule of law, while some simply believed the emergency declaration was an executive overreach that Congress had a duty to stop.

Senator Lamar Alexander, who is set to retire after three terms, stated that the problem with the emergency declaration was that it allowed the president to unilaterally appropriate funds without congressional approval. Senator Susan Collins, a moderate from Maine, argued that the declaration failed to meet the longstanding five-part test of a genuine emergency: necessary, sudden, urgent, unforeseen, and not permanent.

Senator Mitt Romney, who took a hard-line stance against illegal immigration during his 2012 presidential campaign, stated that the emergency declaration was not a vote against border security, but rather a vote for the Constitution and the balance of powers. He noted that the administration already had $4.5 billion available within existing authority to fund a border barrier.

Two Republican senators who voted against terminating the national emergency declaration were Thom Tillis of North Carolina and Ben Sasse of Nebraska, both of whom face reelection in 2020. Senator Sasse stated that the National Emergencies Act is "overly broad" and needs to be narrowed, but he voted against the resolution because it was "politically motivated" and did not address his concerns.

Senator Tom Cotton of Arkansas, who voted to uphold the emergency declaration, argued that there is a genuine emergency on the Southern border and that President Trump's declaration was both legal and proper. He noted that more than half of the $8.1 billion the president is using to build the wall and secure the border comes from non-emergency statutes passed by Congress.

The debate surrounding the national emergency declaration highlights the ongoing tensions between the executive and legislative branches of government, with some lawmakers arguing that the president's actions are an overreach of power and others believing that the declaration is necessary to address a genuine crisis.

Title: Sen. Bernie Sanders Defends His Record, Highlights Differences with Hillary Clinton

Sen. Bernie Sanders, a presidential candidate, defended his record on Wednesday, emphasizing his opposition to free trade agreements and his efforts to take on big banks. He stated that it will be up to voters to compare his resume with that of former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton, the current frontrunner for the Democratic presidential nomination.

Sanders expressed respect for Clinton and emphasized that he is running for working families and the middle class, not against her. He highlighted his record of voting against every free trade agreement and his leadership in the effort against the Trans-Pacific Partnership, which he believes will lead to the outsourcing of good-paying jobs to low-wage countries.

The senator also discussed his plans to break up large financial institutions on Wall Street, which he believes have too much power. He emphasized his push for free college tuition at public colleges and universities, as well as his efforts on climate change and legislation to make the wealthiest individuals and corporations pay their "fair share" of taxes.

Sanders encouraged voters to examine his record and compare it to Clinton's. He believes that his record shows a strong commitment to standing up for those who are voiceless and have given up on the political process.

**Belgium Bombings: Authorities Search for Suspects, ISIS Claims Responsibility**

At least 30 people were killed and 230 others wounded in two explosions at Brussels Airport and a busy subway station in the Belgian capital on Tuesday. The attacks, which occurred just days after the capture of Paris attacks suspect Salah Abdeslam, have left the city reeling.

Authorities are searching for three men, including one who is believed to have planted a bomb at the airport and then left. The men, who were seen wearing black in surveillance footage, are believed to be suicide bombers who died in the explosions in the airport's departure lounge. The third man, wearing light-colored clothing, is considered a wanted individual.

The Belgian Interior Minister, Jan Jambon, has appealed to the public for help in tracking down the man in light-colored clothing, who is believed to have planted a bomb that did not explode.

The investigation is ongoing, with authorities reviewing surveillance footage and conducting raids in the area. A taxi driver who picked up the suspects has come forward, providing crucial information to investigators.

The blasts sent wounded people fleeing into the streets, prompting evacuations of nuclear plants and transit hubs, and leading to raids in some areas as authorities searched for suspects and evidence.

The attacks have left the city in shock, with many residents expressing fear and uncertainty. "You can not believe it; you can not believe it," said Jef Versele, who was in the airport's departure hall when the bombs exploded. "It was so insane. Not in my backyard."

The Belgian Prime Minister, Charles Michel, has vowed to defend the country's freedoms and liberties, saying, "We are determined to protect our liberties." The attacks have also led to a renewed call for unity against terrorism, with leaders from around the world condemning the attacks and offering support to the people of Belgium.

Title: ACLU's National Legal Director Urges Support for First Amendment, Despite Criticisms

The American Civil Liberties Union's national legal director, David Cole, has written an op-ed piece in The New York Times, emphasizing the importance of defending the First Amendment, despite criticisms that the organization has lost its commitment to free speech. Cole's article is directed primarily at liberals and progressives, but can also be seen as a response to libertarians and conservatives who have expressed concerns about the ACLU's stance on the First Amendment.

The debate about the ACLU's support for freedom of speech is not new. In 1990, a cover story in The New Yorker argued that the organization's commitment to freedom of speech had been compromised by its pursuit of progressive causes. Critics, including longtime ACLU members such as Nat Hentoff and Alan Dershowitz, claimed that the organization had diluted its message, compromised its mission, and abandoned its commitment to the First Amendment.

Recently, a staff memo revealed by Wendy Kaminer, a former member of the ACLU's national board, suggested that the organization's lawyers should consider the impact of speech on "other values advanced by the ACLU," such as equality and racial justice. The memo sparked concerns that the organization's goals conflict with each other and that freedom of speech may be compromised.

David Cole's response to Kaminer's memo reaffirmed the ACLU's commitment to defending speech with which it disagrees, but also acknowledged that First Amendment cases can pose conflicts between the organization's values. Cole argues that the ACLU takes a viewpoint-neutral approach to First Amendment cases, defending a principle that is useful to both the left and the right.

Cole cites several examples of the ACLU's defense of free speech, including cases involving high school students disciplined for walking out of school to call for gun control, students penalized for posting pictures of guns on social media, and fans of a hip-hop band labeled gang members. He also notes that the organization has defended flag desecrators, union organizers, and citizens blocked from their representatives' Facebook sites for their criticism.

Cole emphasizes that the First Amendment favors those without power and influence, and that it is a principle that is essential to a democracy. He argues that the ACLU's defense of free speech is not just about protecting the rights of those who are already powerful, but about defending the rights of those who are marginalized and oppressed.

While Cole's defense of the First Amendment is encouraging, the need for it is depressing. The debate about the ACLU's stance on free speech highlights the ongoing challenges faced by the organization in balancing its commitment to social justice with its commitment to defending the rights of all individuals, regardless of their beliefs or opinions.

Title: Brexit Vote: Immigration a Key Factor in UK's Decision to Leave the European Union

The recent Brexit referendum has sparked widespread discussion about the motivations behind the United Kingdom's decision to leave the European Union. One of the primary concerns driving the vote was immigration. Many Britons felt that the country's inability to govern itself as a sovereign nation was a major factor in their decision to leave.

According to Stephen Booth, co-director of Open Europe, a nonpartisan think tank based in London and Brussels, over three-quarters of the roughly 5 million net immigrants to the United Kingdom between 1990 and 2014 came from outside Europe. However, immigration from the European Union now makes up nearly half of the country's net inflow. The combination of European Union expansion in 2004 and 2007, which brought in poorer countries like Bulgaria, Romania, and Poland, and the Eurozone economic crisis, has led to a significant influx of internal immigration to Britain and its relatively strong economy.

Proponents of immigration argue that it has grown the British economy, increased tax revenue, and attracted skilled workers. However, critics argue that immigration has overwhelmed Britain's public resources and changed the country's culture and values.

In a letter to the UK-based Guardian, Richard Mountford of Tonbridge, Kent, stated that the Brexit vote was a protest against mass immigration and the linked issues of stagnant wages and rising rents. He suggested that the European Union should offer the UK an opt-out from the free movement of people, which would address the main reason for the vote to leave and make it legitimate for the UK government to offer a second referendum.

The article also highlights the significant impact of immigration on the UK's population growth. According to recent statistics, the UK's population grew by half a million last year, with a record 335,000 people migrating to the country. This influx has put pressure on public resources and contributed to concerns about the country's ability to govern itself.

The Brexit vote resulted in a narrow victory for the "Leave" camp, with 52% of voters choosing to leave the EU and 48% choosing to remain. UK Prime Minister David Cameron, who backed the "Remain" camp, announced his resignation the morning after the vote, and a new prime minister is expected to be installed in October.

Title: Sen. Mitt Romney Expresses Concerns Over Trump's Behavior in Mueller Report

Article:

Sen. Mitt Romney, a Utah Republican, has expressed his concerns over President Trump's behavior as detailed in the recently released special counsel Robert Mueller's report. In a social media post, Romney stated that while he is relieved that there was insufficient evidence to charge the President with conspiring with a foreign adversary or obstructing justice, he is "sickened" by the extent and pervasiveness of dishonesty and misdirection by individuals in the highest office of the land, including the President.

Romney specifically mentioned that he is appalled that individuals working in a campaign for president welcomed help from Russia, including information that had been illegally obtained, and that none of them acted to inform American law enforcement. He also expressed concern over the campaign chairman's active promotion of Russian interests in Ukraine.

In response, President Trump shared a video on Twitter mocking Romney's loss in the 2012 election to former President Barack Obama. Trump tweeted, "If @MittRomney spent the same energy fighting Barack Obama as he does fighting Donald Trump, he could have won the race (maybe)."

The Mueller report, released on Thursday, summarized the special counsel's findings nearly two years since Mueller was appointed by the Department of Justice to lead an investigation into the 2016 presidential election. The report concluded that Russia interfered in the election in a "sweeping and systematic fashion" and identified numerous links between individuals with ties to the Russian government and individuals associated with the Trump campaign. However, investigators did not find evidence of Trump's associates illegally coordinating with Moscow, and Mueller concluded the probe without making a determination with respect to the obstruction question.

The report stated that the evidence obtained about the President's actions and intent presents difficult issues that prevent conclusively determining that no criminal conduct occurred. While the report does not conclude that the President committed a crime, it also does not exonerate him.

Trump has celebrated the report's release, declaring on Twitter that "The Russia Hoax is dead!" Romney, who was elected to the Senate in 2018, has been a vocal critic of Trump since prior to his presidency, calling him a "phony, a fraud" and a "failed candidate" in early 2016.

Title: Former Democratic Party Boss Donna Brazile Paints Picture of Hillary Clinton Campaign as "Impermeable" and "Cult-Like"

Article:

Former Democratic Party chair Donna Brazile has sparked controversy with her new book and subsequent media interviews, painting a picture of the Hillary Clinton presidential campaign as "impermeable" and "cult-like". In her book, Brazile suggests that the campaign was overly reliant on data and analytics, and that this approach hindered efforts to address concerns about potential missteps that ultimately gave Donald Trump a path to the White House.

In an interview with Fox News, Brazile described the campaign's attitude as "dismissive" and "condescending", stating that she and others who warned about potential problems were not taken seriously. She also claimed that the campaign was too focused on data and analytics, and not enough on traditional, grassroots campaigning.

Brazile's book has sparked a heated response from Clinton campaign team members, who have disputed her portrayal of the campaign. In an open letter, dozens of campaign team members defended the campaign, stating that Brazile was a "longtime friend and colleague" who was "grateful" for her help during her tenure as Democratic National Committee (DNC) chair.

One of the most explosive claims made by Brazile is that the DNC struck a deal with the Clinton campaign giving the campaign partial control over party decisions and resources in exchange for financial help. This claim has sparked concerns from Bernie Sanders supporters that the Clinton campaign had an unfair advantage in the primary election.

Despite the controversy, Brazile maintains that her goal is to help the Democratic Party heal and become stronger. She emphasized the importance of learning from past mistakes and moving forward, stating, "We had a very competitive primary. I don't know when the Republicans will sit down and heal their wounds, but we are healing our wounds, and we are going to learn how to become a stronger, more effective party."

Title: East Coast Bracing for More Turbulent Weather as Storm Continues to Impact Travel

The East Coast is experiencing a prolonged and intense storm that has already caused significant disruptions to travel and daily life. The system, which started on the West Coast, has brought snow, sleet, and heavy rain to a vast swath of the country, from Florida to New England. The storm is expected to continue causing problems, with winds picking up and potentially causing even more delays and cancellations.

As of Tuesday night, over 100 wrecks have been reported, and three people have died in an icy pileup in northwest Texas. The storm has also been blamed for four deaths in Oklahoma since late last week. In Pennsylvania, a 52-year-old man died when a tree fell on his vehicle.

The storm has already caused significant disruptions to air travel, with over 158 flights canceled nationwide and another 84 expected to be canceled on Wednesday. The highest number of cancellations is at Newark Liberty International Airport, with 28 flights already scrapped. The storm's impact on air travel is expected to worsen, with CNN's meteorology unit estimating average delays of two to three hours for New York metro area airports and potentially even worse for Boston's Logan airport.

For those traveling by car, the combination of strong winds and slick surfaces could lead to problems. The National Weather Service forecasts temperatures to rise into the 50s in Philadelphia and Boston, but the wind speed will remain a concern. Sustained winds in New York are expected to reach 19-24 mph, with gusts blowing as strong as 55 mph.

The storm's impact on the Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade is also a concern, with giant balloons potentially not being flown due to wind speeds exceeding 23 mph. The New York Police Department has assigned sergeants to each balloon to ensure they can be lowered to the ground if necessary.

As the storm continues to affect the East Coast, travelers are advised to plan ahead, pack snacks and patience, and drive safely.

Title: Paul Ryan's Evolution: From TARP Supporter to Limited Government Advocate

Paul Ryan, a representative from Wisconsin, has undergone a significant transformation in his views on government intervention in the economy. Before becoming a national figure, Ryan had lunch with a journalist and discussed his concerns about the country's debt crisis and the unfairness of entitlements. He even referenced Friedrich Hayek's "The Road to Serfdom," expressing his desire for a more limited government.

However, Ryan's stance on government intervention changed when the housing bubble burst and he voted for the Troubled Asset Relief Program (TARP) and the auto bailout. He explained his decisions, stating that he believed the economy was on the verge of a deflationary spiral and that the auto bill aimed to prevent companies from receiving TARP funds.

In a later interview, Ryan acknowledged that he wished he had voted against the bills, but he was part of a panicked political class. He emphasized that the government's role should not be to equalize outcomes but to provide equal opportunities. He warned that excessive government intervention leads to a loss of individual freedom and a "road to serfdom."

Ryan proposed a "Roadmap for the Future" in 2008, a budget plan aimed at slowing government growth. Although it was seen as timid by some, it helped shift the national conversation towards limited government. The plan's influence can be seen in the Republican Study Committee's proposed cuts and the increased discussion around entitlement reform.

In a recent interview, Ryan reflected on his journey, stating that he feels good about the progress made and the shift in the national conversation. He believes that Americans are ready to be treated like adults and understand the debt crisis. Ryan's evolution serves as a reminder that even politicians can change their views and work towards a more limited government.

Title: Iran Nuclear Deal Whispers Emerge as Deadline Looms

As the self-imposed deadline approached on Monday, whispers of a potential deal between Iran and world powers began to circulate. According to unnamed diplomats, the agreement would limit Iran's nuclear program in exchange for the lifting of sanctions. The Associated Press reported that the deal would be announced on Monday, citing unnamed sources.

Iranian TV has added to the expectation of a deal, with state-run media predicting an agreement and Iranian officials describing the document as running to almost 100 pages, including several technical annexes. However, most reports of an imminent deal include the caveat that a few issues need to be worked out and the various capitals must sign off on any agreement.

High-level officials provided comments on the negotiations on Sunday. US Secretary of State John Kerry stated that "a few tough things" needed to be resolved but added, "We're getting to some real decisions." French Foreign Minister Laurent Fabius, who cancelled a trip to Africa to stay at the talks, said, "I hope we are finally entering the final phase of these marathon negotiations. I believe it." Iranian President Hassan Rouhani expressed optimism, saying the sides had "come a long way" and that "we need to reach a peak and we're very close."

If a deal is reached, it would mark the culmination of decades of diplomacy. However, the agreement would require approval from several capitals, including the US Congress.

Title: VA Facilities Under Investigation After Complaints of Falsified Records and Treatment Delays

The Office of Inspector General at the Veterans Affairs Department has expanded its investigation into allegations of falsified records and treatment delays at VA facilities across the country. The investigation now involves 26 facilities nationwide, up from 10 just a week ago. The allegations of manipulated waiting times and other problems have surfaced since reports of issues at the Phoenix VA hospital came to light last month.

Acting Inspector General Richard Griffin told a Senate committee that at least 10 new allegations have emerged since then. The expanded investigation comes as President Barack Obama's choice to help reform the VA, White House Deputy Chief of Staff Rob Nabors, is set to visit the Phoenix VA hospital to meet with staff.

The allegations of delayed care and a cover-up by top administrators in Phoenix have sparked a firestorm on Capitol Hill, with some calling for VA Secretary Eric Shinseki's resignation. The VA's undersecretary for healthcare, Robert Petzel, has stepped down, but Republicans have criticized the move as a hollow gesture.

Several lawmakers are proposing legislation to address the VA's problems, including a bill to ensure that internal probes by the VA's Office of Medical Inspector are released to Congress and the public. The bill would also prohibit payment of bonuses to employees at the Veterans Health Administration through next year.

The VA's Office of Inspector General is investigating allegations of falsified records and treatment delays at 26 facilities nationwide, up from 10 just a week ago. The allegations have sparked a firestorm on Capitol Hill, with some calling for VA Secretary Eric Shinseki's resignation.

Title: Poll Workers Prepare for Election Day Amid Concerns of Violence and Confrontations

Poll workers across the United States are taking extra precautions ahead of the upcoming election, citing concerns about potential violence and confrontations at polling stations. The concerns come after a recent firebombing of a Republican Party headquarters in North Carolina and reports of armed individuals lingering outside a Democratic campaign office in Virginia.

Louisiana Secretary of State Tom Schedler has expressed worry about violence at the polls, stating that it is a more significant threat than hacking of voting machines. Schedler emphasized the importance of balancing voter safety with welcoming voters to the polls.

To prepare for any scenario, poll workers in Denver have added active shooter training to their election judge training. They also have a central hotline to report any problems and can quickly mobilize the police department or emergency response team if needed.

The U.S. Election Assistance Commission's Matt Masterson noted that almost every jurisdiction has a detailed plan for voting place emergencies. Many of these plans were enhanced after the September 11 terrorist attacks, which occurred on a primary election day in New York City. Masterson believes that election officials are re-examining their plans and training poll workers to handle any escalation of conversations in polling places.

To avoid confrontations, Masterson suggests that everyone involved – poll workers, candidates, and outside monitors – should know the rules in advance. For example, some places prohibit voters from carrying guns into polling stations, while others allow open carry.

Schedler emphasized that most times, confrontations can be easily handled by polite but firm poll workers. As election officials strive to balance voter safety with welcoming voters, poll workers are preparing for the worst while hoping for a calm Election Day.

Title: Congressional Divide Emerges Over Marijuana Legalization

Article:

A growing divide has emerged within the Republican Party over marijuana legalization, with some members of Congress calling for the Obama administration to crack down on states that have legalized the drug, while others are pushing for legislation to protect marijuana users and business owners from federal prosecution.

During an appropriations hearing, Representatives Andrew Harris, Frank Wolf, and Jo Bonner (all Republicans) expressed their concerns about the Justice Department not taking action against Colorado and Washington, which have legalized marijuana, citing federal law. However, DEA Administrator Michele Leonhart responded that the agency is still enforcing federal law and that the real problem is the lack of cooperation from local law enforcement groups.

Meanwhile, three more Republicans, including Representative Dana Rohrabacher, are preparing to introduce a bill that would protect marijuana users and business owners from federal prosecution, as long as they are in compliance with state laws. The bill, known as the Respect State Marijuana Laws Act, has five co-sponsors from both parties.

The bill aims to amend the Controlled Substances Act, which makes the sale and use of marijuana illegal under federal law. Rohrabacher called the bill "common sense" and said it "keeps the federal government out of the business of criminalizing marijuana activities."

Recent poll results from Gallup and Pew show that there is no partisan split when it comes to enforcement of federal drug laws against pro-pot states. The results suggest that the GOP's federalists may win this battle in Congress, as being anti-pot but pro-states' rights could be a way to balance older voters who need to be held and younger voters who need to be won. However, it remains to be seen whether the pro-pot faction will run away from the issue.

Title: Trump Leads Clinton in Battleground States of Nevada, North Carolina, and Ohio

A recent statewide likely voter poll conducted by Anderson Robbins Research and Shaw & Company Research has found that Donald Trump is narrowly leading Hillary Clinton in the battleground states of Nevada, North Carolina, and Ohio. The poll, conducted from September 18-20, 2016, surveyed 704 likely voters in Nevada, 734 in North Carolina, and 737 in Ohio.

In Nevada, Trump has a three-point advantage over Clinton among likely voters, with 43% supporting Trump and 40% supporting Clinton. Libertarian Gary Johnson received 8% of the vote, while "none of these" received 4%. In North Carolina, Trump leads Clinton by five points, with 45% supporting Trump and 40% supporting Clinton. In Ohio, Trump also leads Clinton by five points, with 42% supporting Trump and 37% supporting Clinton.

The poll found that Trump's edge in each state comes mainly from his strong support among working-class whites and independents. Clinton, on the other hand, is struggling to win over younger voters and women, with her support among these groups lagging behind Trump's.

The poll also found that both Clinton and Trump supporters are highly certain of their vote choice, with 93% of each group saying they are certain they will back their candidate.

The poll's findings are consistent with other recent polls showing a tight race in these key states. The results suggest that Trump's campaign is gaining momentum, particularly among independents and working-class whites, while Clinton's campaign is struggling to win over younger voters and women.

The poll also asked about the Senate races in these key states, finding the races within the margin of error in Nevada and North Carolina, while Republican Rob Portman holds a double-digit lead in Ohio.

Title: Biden Secures Strong Victory in Illinois Primary, Edges Out Sanders

Article:

Former Vice President Joe Biden secured a significant victory in the Illinois primary, defeating Vermont Senator Bernie Sanders with 59.5% of the vote to 35.8% with 96% of precincts reporting. Biden's strong performance was driven by his support among African-American voters, women, and voters over 45 years old. According to CNN polls, Biden took 70% of the African-American vote, compared to Sanders' 27%, and 65% of the women's vote, compared to Sanders' 30%.

Biden's campaign performed well across the state, with the former vice president winning a majority of the vote in both urban and suburban areas. In Chicago, Biden led Sanders 50.43% to 45.52% with 77% of precincts reporting. In suburban Cook County, Biden led Sanders 62.76% to 32.81% with 95% of precincts reporting.

The Illinois primary was marked by low turnout, with many voters opting to cast their ballots by mail or early voting due to concerns about the COVID-19 pandemic. Despite the challenges, Biden's campaign was able to mobilize a strong ground game, with a record number of early voters and mail-in ballots.

The victory in Illinois gives Biden a significant boost in his bid for the Democratic presidential nomination, as the state's 155 pledged delegates are up for grabs. The win also cements Biden's position as the front-runner in the race, as he continues to rack up delegates and momentum.

Sanders, meanwhile, performed well among younger voters, with 63% of voters aged 17-44 supporting him, compared to Biden's 17%. However, Biden's strong performance among older voters and African-Americans helped him secure the win.

The Illinois primary was one of three states to hold elections on Tuesday, along with Florida and Arizona. Biden won all three states, further solidifying his position as the front-runner in the Democratic primary.

Title: Opioid Crisis Declared a National Emergency: A Call to Action

The opioid crisis in the United States has claimed the lives of over 70,000 Americans annually, with the majority of the drugs coming from Mexico. In 2017, the President declared the opioid crisis a national health emergency, acknowledging the devastating impact it has had on the country. However, despite the severity of the issue, the crisis remains unaddressed, with the majority of the drugs entering the country undeterred.

The situation is dire, with the CDC reporting 70,237 drug overdose deaths in 2017, and the numbers remaining high in 2018. The crisis has resulted in a staggering number of deaths, exceeding the entire death toll of the 12-year Vietnam War. The President has called for a national emergency to be declared, citing the need for a comprehensive approach to address the issue.

Declaring a national emergency would allow the government to mobilize resources and take decisive action to address the root causes of the crisis. It would also provide a framework for the government to work with international partners to disrupt the flow of drugs from Mexico.

The article highlights the need for a secure border to prevent drug traffickers from entering the country and delivering death to Americans. The author argues that declaring a national emergency would be a necessary step to address the crisis and prevent further loss of life.

The article also references the 32 other national emergencies declared by the President, including those related to Sudan, the Democratic Republic of the Congo, and Venezuela. The author questions why the government is not taking similar action to address the opioid crisis, which has resulted in the loss of over 100 American lives daily.

In conclusion, the opioid crisis is a national emergency that requires immediate attention and action. Declaring a national emergency would provide the necessary resources and framework to address the root causes of the crisis and prevent further loss of life.

Title: Election Results: Houston Rejects Transgender "Bathroom Bill", Ohio Votes Down Legal Marijuana, and Republicans Win Gubernatorial Contests

The recent election saw several notable results across the United States. In Houston, voters rejected a transgender "bathroom bill" with 62% voting against the measure and 38% in favor. The bill, which would have allowed individuals to use public facilities based on their gender identity, was championed by Mayor Annise Parker, the first openly lesbian mayor of a major city.

In Kentucky, Republican businessman Matt Bevin defeated Democratic Attorney General Jack Conway by a margin of 53% to 44%, with independent Drew Curtis taking 4% of the vote. Bevin's victory marked a significant shift in the state's political landscape, as Kentucky has traditionally been a Democratic stronghold.

Ohio voters also rejected Issue 3, which would have legalized recreational marijuana for adults 21 and over. The proposal would have also created a monopoly on cultivation for 10 investors, prompting opponents to denounce the measure as an example of "weed greed." The defeat marked the first loss for the pro-pot movement since Colorado and Washington approved legalization measures in 2012.

In Mississippi, Governor Phil Bryant easily won a second term over Robert Gray, a Democrat who spent just $3,000 in a token campaign. Bryant's victory marked a significant win for the Republican Party, as Mississippi is considered a heavily Republican state.

In other election results, Republican businessman Matt Bevin won the gubernatorial contest in Kentucky, defeating Democratic Attorney General Jack Conway. Bevin's victory marked a significant shift in the state's political landscape, as Kentucky has traditionally been a Democratic stronghold.

In Philadelphia, former city council member Jim Kenney easily defeated a Republican businessman to succeed term-limited Mayor Michael Nutter.

Title: Clinton's Private Emails Contained Sensitive Information from Spy Satellites and Signal Intelligence, Security Experts Say

Article:

The revelation that Hillary Rodham Clinton's private emails contained sensitive information derived from spy satellites and signal intelligence has raised questions about her defense that she had no reason to believe she was dealing with classified information. Security experts say that if she is unaware of the classification of the information, it calls into question her overall competence.

As details emerge about the extent of Mrs. Clinton's use of personal email to conduct business as secretary of state, her defense has shifted. Initially, she stated that her private emails did not contain classified information. Later, she claimed that none of the information she sent by private email was classified at the time she sent it. Now, her defenders have evolved her story further, suggesting that she didn't know information she was handling was classified because it wasn't marked as such.

Pete Hoekstra, former chairman of the House Permanent Select Committee on Intelligence, wrote an op-ed published in The New York Post, calling the latest explanation from the Clinton camp a "sham." He stated that the process of handling government secrets requires officials to keep their correspondence on the appropriate government server, so the material can be vetted and classified before being sent to an unclassified recipient.

The inspectors general for the State Department and the intelligence community flatly contradicted Mrs. Clinton's claim that her emails did not contain national secrets. They wrote in a public joint statement that the information among thousands of emails on her private server was definitely classified at the time.

This week, I. Charles McCullough III, the intelligence community's inspector general, revealed that not only did a small sampling of Mrs. Clinton's 30,000 emails contain classified information, but two held data that were top-secret – the highest classification. The top-secret information was labeled "SI," which is intelligence community parlance for "special intelligence." Special intelligence is intercepted communications from foreign targets.

The intercept came from code word "talent keyhole," which stands for the nation's military satellites and their production of classified imagery and intercepted communications. An intelligence spokeswoman said the TK compartmental function "protects information and activities related to space-based collection of imagery, signals, measurement and signature intelligence, certain products, processing and exploitation techniques, and the design, acquisition, and operation of reconnaissance satellites."

The "TOP SECRET/SI/TK" designation means that Mrs. Clinton's server held some of the nation's most sensitive information. The information could have come from the National Security Agency and most certainly the National Geospatial-Intelligence Agency, experts said.

Larry Johnson, a former CIA analyst, said that revelations about the highly sensitive nature of information in certain emails call into question the entirety of Mrs. Clinton's story about the private email server she operated out of her home in Chappaqua, New York. "She's admitting she lacks the knowledge and intelligence to recognize classified information. That's her defense? That she's stupid?" he said. "I think she knew it was classified and used it. They were passing information back and forth."

The SI and TK designations mean that if Mrs. Clinton's server was hacked, "there is the possibility of compromising multiple intelligence sources," Mr. Johnson said. Because Mrs. Clinton conducted all State Department business on one server at her home, it is assumed that her aides also passed classified information on unsecure systems. This is because a commercial system such as Mrs. Clinton's can not communicate with a secure government network set up to handle and protect secrets. Mrs. Clinton did not use a State.gov account, as is expected of all State Department employees.

Intelligence experts said Mrs. Clinton's server, which she turned over under pressure to the Justice Department this week after having vowed never to part with it, was susceptible to hacks from adversaries such as China and Russia.

Title: South Dakota's Concealed Carry Legislation May See Revival with New Governor Kristi Noem

Article:

Supporters of legislation allowing people to carry concealed handguns without a permit in South Dakota are optimistic about the prospects of the bill's passage now that Republican Governor-elect Kristi Noem is set to take office in January. Noem, who won the election on November 6, had expressed support for a so-called constitutional carry law during her campaign.

State Senator-elect Lynne DiSanto, who sponsored a permitless concealed carry bill that was vetoed by outgoing Governor Dennis Daugaard in 2017, believes the legislation is likely to pass in the upcoming session. "There are a lot of Republicans that are very excited to have a conservative governor," DiSanto said. "I think under a new governor, it's very likely to pass."

The current law in South Dakota requires individuals to obtain a permit to carry a concealed pistol or have one concealed in a vehicle. As of the end of October, there were nearly 108,000 pistol permits in the state, according to the secretary of state's office.

Daugaard vetoed DiSanto's proposal in 2017 and again in 2012, and constitutional carry legislation failed to pass during the 2018 session after he issued a veto threat. Supporters of the bill argue that obtaining a concealed pistol permit can be burdensome.

Governor-elect Noem's campaign did not endorse a specific plan, but said she supported the policy "in principle." Her transition team spokeswoman, Kristin Wileman, stated that the governor-elect will review the legislation's text before committing to it, but emphasized her strong support for the Second Amendment and believes provisions like constitutional carry can "protect and even strengthen this right for South Dakotans."

The South Dakota Sheriffs' Association has not discussed the 2019 legislation yet, but supported a bill in the 2018 session that allowed permitless carry for state residents with a South Dakota driver's license or identification card. The 2019 session is scheduled to run from January 8 to March 29, with Republicans controlling both houses of the Legislature and the governorship.

Title: Pelosi Secures Another Term as House Democratic Leader

Article:

Nancy Pelosi has successfully overcome her toughest challenge yet to her leadership of the House of Representatives, defeating Ohio Rep. Tim Ryan to secure another term as House minority leader. The California Democrat received 134 votes to Ryan's 63 in a secret ballot vote on Wednesday. Pelosi had boasted going into the vote that she had support from two-thirds of the caucus, and she received just over that amount.

Pelosi, 76, has held the top slot in House Democratic leadership since 2003. She became the first female speaker of the House in history when Democrats won control of Congress in 2006. However, since Democrats suffered devastating losses in 2010, Pelosi has faced questions about whether she is the best one to lead the minority party in the House.

Ryan, 43, argued that the party needed someone who understands blue-collar voters as well as new, younger blood in leadership. He came from the manufacturing hub of Youngstown, Ohio, and his home county had even flipped to Trump by six points after previously voting for President Obama by 22 points just four years ago. Pelosi mocked Ryan's loss in an interview with the Huffington Post, saying he "didn't even carry his district for Hillary Clinton." However, others saw it as a sign that Ryan was the type of Democrat who could win over working-class voters better than someone from ultra-liberal San Francisco.

The debate over who was best to lead the House Democrats was emblematic of the larger debate over the direction of the party after Hillary Clinton suffered a surprising and stinging loss in the presidential race to Donald Trump. House Democrats had hoped to pick up as many as 15 or 20 seats to cut into Republicans' 30-seat edge. Instead, they flipped only six seats, a disappointing showing to many Democrats.

Title: Attorney General William Barr Under Fire: A Critical Examination of the Criticisms

Article:

Attorney General William Barr has been the subject of intense scrutiny and criticism from the left, with some calling for his resignation. However, a closer examination of his actions and decisions reveals that the criticism may be misplaced. Barr has been accused of being too close to President Trump and of undermining the rule of law. However, a review of his record shows that he has taken steps to address concerns about the 2016 election and its aftermath, including the abuse of FISA surveillance.

Barr's critics have pointed to his decision to change the sentencing recommendation for Roger Stone, which they see as a sign of his willingness to do Trump's bidding. However, it is unclear why a sentence of less than seven years in prison would be seen as a threat to democracy. The judge has complete discretion to impose whatever sentence she sees fit, and Barr has maintained that he was surprised by the initial sentencing recommendation and intended to amend it before Trump's comments.

Furthermore, Barr has allowed the Mueller probe to reach its conclusion unmolested and has declined to prosecute former Department of Justice official Andrew McCabe for lying to investigators. If he were truly Trump's henchman, he would have squashed the Stone case or declined to investigate Trump's campaign. Instead, he has taken steps to address concerns about the 2016 election and its aftermath, including the abuse of FISA surveillance.

The criticism of Barr's actions is often based on speculation and a lack of understanding of the complexities of the situation. The supposed institutionalists and civil libertarians who are piling on Barr are more outraged that he wants to get to the bottom of the abuse of FISA surveillance and related 2016 investigatory overreach than by the abuse itself. It is no wonder that Barr has a poorly disguised contempt for his critics, many of whom are so inflamed by their opposition to Trump that they have lost any sense of standards.

In conclusion, a closer examination of Attorney General William Barr's actions and decisions reveals that the criticism of him may be misplaced. He has taken steps to address concerns about the 2016 election and its aftermath, including the abuse of FISA surveillance, and has allowed the Mueller probe to reach its conclusion unmolested. If he were truly Trump's henchman, he would have taken steps to undermine the rule of law, but instead, he has worked to uphold it.

Title: Obama Calls for Higher Minimum Wage, Potential Ripple Effect on Economy

President Obama has called on Congress to increase the federal minimum wage to $9 an hour by 2015, up from the current $7.25. The proposed hike would be implemented in steps, with the maximum reached in two years, and would thereafter be indexed to inflation. The move is seen as a significant shift in the president's economic policy, as he has previously not prioritized a minimum wage increase.

The White House estimates that 15 million workers would directly benefit from a higher minimum wage, but many economists believe that millions more would gain as the wage scale adjusts upward. The president emphasized that a full-time worker making the current minimum wage earns only $14,500 a year, which is not enough to keep a family above the poverty line.

The proposal has sparked debate among lawmakers and economists. While some argue that a higher minimum wage would reduce job opportunities and increase costs for businesses, others believe it would reduce income inequality and put more money in the hands of consumers, boosting the economy.

The minimum wage has been a contentious issue since its introduction in 1938, with business groups arguing that it is inflationary and represents an unnecessary government intervention in the labor market. However, supporters argue that inflation is low, while income inequality is growing, and that working people lack the spending power to drive economic growth.

The proposal is expected to face opposition from business groups, particularly the National Restaurant Association, which has historically fought against minimum wage increases. However, some states have already implemented higher minimum wages, with Washington state having the highest minimum wage at $9.19 an hour. If the federal level were to rise, many of these states would likely pass new legislation to exceed it.

The debate surrounding the minimum wage highlights the ongoing discussion about the role of government in the economy and the balance between economic growth and social welfare.

Title: Relatives of Aunt Jemima Portrayals Express Concerns Over Rebranding Efforts

The relatives of the women who portrayed Aunt Jemima in the 1920s and 1930s have expressed concerns over Quaker Oats' decision to rebrand the iconic character, citing concerns that it will erase their family's history. Larnell Evans, a great-grandson of Anna Short Harrington, who portrayed Aunt Jemima, stated that the news of the rebranding "comes as a slap in the face" and that his family's legacy is being erased. Evans' great-grandmother, Harrington, was discovered at the New York State Fair in 1935 and went on to work for the company for 25 years.

Similarly, the family of Lillian Richard, who became an ambassador for the brand after being discovered by the company in Dallas, is concerned that the rebranding will erase their aunt's legacy. Vera Harris, Richard's great-niece, stated that her family is proud of her aunt's hard work and wants to honor her legacy. Harris understands why Quaker Oats made the decision, but believes that their aunt's story should not be erased from history.

Both Evans and Harris emphasized the importance of preserving their family's history and legacy, with Evans stating that "if we wipe out our history, we have nothing to strive for in the future." Harris added that "our history will help us prosper in the future." The relatives also expressed frustration that the rebranding effort is seen as a way to erase the history of slavery and racism, rather than acknowledging the contributions of the women who portrayed Aunt Jemima.

Quaker Oats announced the rebranding effort in June, stating that it was part of an effort to make progress toward racial equality. The company has not commented on the concerns expressed by the relatives of the women who portrayed Aunt Jemima.

Title: Conservative Group Launches Radio Ad Challenging Mitch McConnell to Oppose Obamacare Funding

A conservative group, the Senate Conservatives Fund, is spending nearly $50,000 on a 60-second radio ad challenging Senate Republican Leader Mitch McConnell to oppose any funding for President Barack Obama's health care law, even if it means triggering a government shutdown. The ad will begin airing on Tuesday in Kentucky, where McConnell is locked in a tough race for a sixth term.

The ad claims that Republicans in Congress can stop Obamacare by refusing to fund it, but McConnell refuses to lead the fight. It also references a recent campaign embarrassment for McConnell, in which his campaign manager, Jesse Benton, was recorded saying he was "holding my nose" while working for the candidate. Benton later clarified that he believes in McConnell and is 100% committed to his re-election.

The Senate Conservatives Fund, founded by former South Carolina Republican Sen. Jim DeMint, is spending close to $200,000 on radio ads in six other states, calling on GOP senators to refuse to fund the health care law. The group's targets are North Carolina's Richard Burr, South Carolina's Lindsey Graham, Lamar Alexander of Tennessee, Johnny Isakson of Georgia, Mississippi's Thad Cochran, and Arizona's Jeff Flake.

The issue has divided Republicans, with House and Senate GOP leaders wary of the political impact of any government shutdown, but tea party conservatives determined to undermine the health care law. The federal 2013 fiscal year ends on September 30, and new money must be appropriated by then to avoid a shutdown of countless government offices and agencies.

The radio ad comes as another conservative group, the Madison Project, launched a radio spot on Monday critical of McConnell, labeling him a "career Washington politician" who claims to be a conservative. The Madison Project is supporting McConnell's primary challenger, businessman Matt Bevin. The Senate Conservatives Fund has not endorsed in the Kentucky GOP primary, but its executive director, Matt Hoskins, said the group is open to backing Bevin and warned that McConnell could lose the Senate race and cost the GOP its shot at the Senate majority.

Title: Tillerson Urges Russia to Cooperate on Syria Ahead of Trump-Putin Meeting

The United States Secretary of State, Rex Tillerson, has called on Russia to do more to bring peace to Syria, emphasizing that the future of the Syrian regime must be decided through a political settlement. In a statement, Tillerson also suggested that Moscow and Washington could cooperate on establishing no-fly zones in the war-torn Arab country.

Tillerson's statement came just days before President Donald Trump is set to meet with Russian President Vladimir Putin on the sidelines of the G-20 gathering in Germany. The Secretary of State appeared to be trying to influence those talks ahead of time, despite deeply troubled U.S.-Russian relations.

The United States is prepared to explore the possibility of establishing joint mechanisms for ensuring stability in Syria, including no-fly zones, on-the-ground cease-fire observers, and coordinated delivery of humanitarian assistance, Tillerson said. He emphasized that if the two countries work together to establish stability on the ground, it will lay a foundation for progress on the settlement of Syria's political future.

Tillerson warned the Syrian regime, backed by Iran and Russia, against taking advantage of America's limited focus by moving into areas freed from the Islamic State, also known as ISIS. He called on all parties involved in the conflict to avoid conflict with one another and adhere to agreed geographical boundaries for military de-confliction and protocols for de-escalation.

The Secretary of State also emphasized that the United States believes Russia, as a guarantor of the Assad regime and an early entrant into the Syrian conflict, has a responsibility to ensure that the needs of the Syrian people are met and that no faction in Syria illegitimately retakes or occupies areas liberated from ISIS or other terrorist groups' control.

The Trump administration has grappled with a strategy on how to deal with Syria once the Islamic State is pushed out of its territory. America's successful military campaign against the terrorist group has given new space to Assad's forces and those of Iran and Russia to operate, leading to clashes with the United States.

Title: Trump and Clinton React to First Presidential Debate

The first presidential debate between Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton has concluded, with both candidates taking different approaches to assess their performance. While Clinton and her team seemed pleased with the outcome, Trump expressed frustration and disappointment.

Clinton boarded her plane to a round of applause from her staff, describing the debate as a "great, great" evening. She quipped about Trump's complaint about the microphone, saying, "Anybody who complains about the microphone is not having a good night." Clinton is looking forward to the next debate and is confident about her performance.

In contrast, Trump appeared to be unhappy with the debate, calling into Fox News' "Fox & Friends" to express his dissatisfaction. He criticized moderator Lester Holt, saying he did not ask Clinton about her emails, scandals, and Benghazi. Trump also reiterated his complaint about the microphone, suggesting it may have been set up that way on purpose.

Trump also made headlines for his comments about former Miss Universe Alicia Machado, who has accused him of bullying her. Trump described Machado as "the worst" and made personal attacks on her physical appearance. Machado responded with a video and a press conference, calling Trump's comments "stupid" and "misogynistic."

The debate has sparked reactions from voters, with some expressing concern about Trump's behavior and others praising his performance. Marguerite Scott, a retired 68-year-old woman from Cary, North Carolina, attended a Clinton campaign event and criticized Trump for his comments about Machado, saying men should not objectify women and that Trump's behavior is "misogynistic."

**Coronavirus Cases Surpass 18,600 in the United States as Easter Weekend Approaches**

The United States has surpassed 18,600 confirmed cases of COVID-19, with the death toll reaching 18,600. As the Easter weekend approaches, health experts and political leaders are urging Americans to avoid church gatherings and observe the holiday at home. Dr. Anthony Fauci, the government's top infectious disease expert, emphasized that social distancing measures are crucial in slowing the spread of the virus.

Fauci noted that declining rates of coronavirus hospitalizations and intensive care unit admissions, particularly in hard-hit New York state, are a positive sign that social distancing measures are working. However, he warned that it is too early to relax these measures, stating, "The virus will decide" when the country can begin to reopen from state-at-home orders.

The Trump administration has renewed talk of quickly reopening the economy, with some economists forecasting job losses of up to 20 million by month's end. The U.S. death toll could reach 200,000 if stay-at-home orders are lifted after 30 days, according to separate forecasts from the U.S. departments of Homeland Security and Health and Human Services.

The United States accounts for most of the world's confirmed cases of COVID-19, with at least 500,000 known infections. Prisons and jails, along with nursing homes and other institutions with large populations confined in close quarters, have proven especially vulnerable to outbreaks.

As Easter Sunday approaches, many churches have turned to livestreaming services, while some have cancelled in-person gatherings. In some areas, drive-in services have been held, with worshipers watching from their cars. A handful of holdout churches have planned to hold in-person services, citing their right to worship.

The economic impact of the pandemic continues to be felt, with millions of Americans missing paychecks and businesses shuttered across the nation. Food banks and distribution centers are working to meet the increased demand for food and other essentials.

Title: Trump Urges FDA to Approve Gilead's Antiviral Drug Remdesivir as COVID-19 Treatment

The White House has expressed its desire for the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) to expedite the approval process for Gilead Sciences' antiviral drug remdesivir as a treatment for the coronavirus. President Donald Trump stated that he wants the FDA to move "as quickly as they can" to approve the drug, emphasizing the importance of speed in the fight against the virus.

The FDA has been in ongoing discussions with Gilead to make remdesivir available to COVID-19 patients as quickly as possible, as appropriate. White House health advisor Dr. Anthony Fauci described the data from a coronavirus drug trial testing Gilead's drug as "quite good news" and set a new standard of care for COVID-19 patients. According to Fauci, the data showed a "clear-cut positive effect in diminishing time to recover" and a median time of recovery of 11 days for patients taking the drug, compared to 15 days in the placebo group.

While the results suggested a survival benefit, with a mortality rate of 8% for the group receiving remdesivir versus 11.6% for the placebo group, Fauci noted that the mortality benefit has not yet reached statistical significance. The National Institutes of Health released a statement confirming the results, stating that the median time to recovery was 11 days for patients taking the drug, compared to 15 days in the placebo group.

Fauci emphasized that the results demonstrate that a drug can block the virus, and when a drug is proven to work, it should be made available to patients. The FDA has been working closely with Gilead to make remdesivir available to patients as quickly as possible, and the agency has been in sustained and ongoing discussions with the company to achieve this goal.

Title: Editorial Boards Unleash Criticism Against Trump Ahead of First Presidential Debate

The editorial boards of The New York Times and The Washington Post have published scathing critiques of Donald Trump, the Republican presidential nominee, ahead of the first formal debate with Hillary Clinton. The editorials aim to make the case against Trump's candidacy, citing concerns about his leadership qualities and behavior.

The New York Times' 1,400-word essay, titled "Why He Should Not Be President," systematically challenges Trump's claims about his leadership abilities, describing him as a "man far more consumed with himself than with the nation's well-being." The editorial highlights Trump's "bluster, savage mockery of those who challenge him, degrading comments about women, mendacity, and crude generalizations about nations and religions."
