The move comes after China revoked the press credentials of three Wall Street Journal reporters based in Beijing, sparking outrage from White House officials. The cap is seen as a response to China's actions, with Pompeo urging Beijing to respect freedom of expression and reciprocity.

The Chinese Foreign Ministry has expressed discontent with the move, questioning the validity of the White House's goal of reciprocity. A spokesperson tweeted, "Now the US kicked off the game, let's play," suggesting that the US has started the game, and it's time for China to respond.

The cap is the first time since the era of Mao Zedong that China has expelled multiple journalists from one international news organization simultaneously. The move may escalate already-existing tensions between the US and China, which come as the deadly coronavirus outbreak continues to spread globally.

Title: Facebook Reinstates Senator Elizabeth Warren's Ads After Initial Removal

Article:

Senator Elizabeth Warren, a Democratic presidential candidate, recently announced her plan to break up big tech companies, including Amazon, Google, and Facebook. As part of her campaign, she placed ads on Facebook touting her plan, but the social network initially removed four of the ads, citing a violation of its policy against the misuse of its logo. The ads used the letter "f" to represent Facebook.

Facebook reinstated the ads shortly after, stating that it was done "in the interest of allowing robust debate." The majority of Warren's ads, nine others, were not affected by the initial removal.

Warren took to Twitter to comment on the situation, saying that Facebook's actions confirmed her point about the company having too much power. She expressed her desire for a social media marketplace that is not dominated by a single censor.

In her plan, "Here's How We Can Break Up Big Tech," Warren proposes supporting regulators breaking up "anti-competitive" mergers, such as Facebook's acquisitions of WhatsApp and Instagram, Amazon's deals for Whole Foods and Zappos, and Google's acquisitions of Waze, Nest, and DoubleClick.

Title: Al Qaeda Affiliate Takes Responsibility for Charlie Hebdo Attack in Paris

Article:

A commander of Al Qaeda in Yemen, Nasr al-Ansi, has officially taken responsibility for the January 7th attack on the offices of Charlie Hebdo in Paris. In an 11-minute video posted on the internet, al-Ansi claimed that the massacre was carried out in "vengeance for the prophet" and warned of more "tragedies and terror." He stated that Al Qaeda's affiliate in Yemen chose the target, laid out the plan, and financed the operation, although he did not provide any evidence to support the claim.

The video also included a statement from al-Ansi, who referred to France as the "party of Satan" and warned of further attacks. The commander's comments come as the White House continues to emphasize its efforts to combat terrorism and extremism.

The attack on Charlie Hebdo was carried out by two gunmen, including Saïd Kouachi, who had received training in Yemen. The incident has sparked widespread outrage and condemnation, with many governments and organizations condemning the violence.

The White House has previously stated that Al Qaeda is "on the run" and that its core leaders have been "decimated." However, the recent video and statements from Al Qaeda affiliates suggest that the organization remains a significant threat.

The incident highlights the ongoing challenges faced by Western governments in combating terrorism and extremism. The White House has emphasized its commitment to addressing these threats, but the recent events in Paris demonstrate that more work remains to be done.

Title: The First Amendment: A Shield for All Speech, Not Just What We Agree With

The article discusses the controversy surrounding flag burning and the potential implications of criminalizing it. The author argues that while many politicians and citizens may despise flag burning, it is a protected form of free speech under the First Amendment. The Supreme Court has consistently held that flag burning is constitutionally protected, and attempts to criminalize it would be a violation of basic liberties.

The author notes that President-elect Trump has expressed support for criminalizing flag burning, but argues that this would be a mistake. The Constitution prohibits denying citizenship to individuals based on their political beliefs or actions, and attempting to do so would be unconstitutional.

The article also touches on the potential consequences of altering the First Amendment to allow for the criminalization of certain forms of speech. The author suggests that this could lead to a slippery slope, where other forms of expression are also targeted and restricted.

The author concludes by urging President-elect Trump to respect the First Amendment and not attempt to restrict freedom of expression. Instead, they suggest that Trump should develop a thicker skin for criticism and recognize that the flag he is burning is what protects his right to burn it.

Title: Twitter Stands Ground Against Government Demand to Unmask Critic, Raising Free Speech Concerns

Article:

The Department of Homeland Security's Customs and Border Protection division recently demanded that Twitter reveal the identity of an account criticizing the Trump administration. However, the agency quickly retracted the demand, sparking concerns about the government's intentions and the implications for free speech. Twitter's primary objection was that allowing the government to unmask critics violates the Constitution's First Amendment right to free speech, particularly when discussing political speech.

The case highlights the importance of anonymity in online discourse, with the American Civil Liberties Union (ACLU) stating that speaking anonymously about issues of the day is a longstanding American tradition. The ACLU emphasized that this right is often most essential when people criticize the government, and it is as important today as ever.

The incident has also raised questions about the concept of "dark money" in political campaigns. Dark money refers to donations to groups that can use funds for independent expenditures, often without disclosing their donors. While dark-money expenditures have increased in recent years, they still represent a small fraction of total campaign spending.

Legislation has been introduced in Congress and some states to require incorporated nonprofits to disclose their donors and internal communications. However, the ACLU has criticized such laws as overly broad and potentially chilling constitutionally protected speech.

The debate surrounding dark money and disclosure has sparked concerns about the intersection of money and politics. Campaign-finance reformers argue that the focus should be on limiting corporate money in politics, not political speech. However, it is difficult to separate the two, as money can enable political speech and vice versa.

The Supreme Court's Citizens United ruling, which allowed corporations to spend money on political speech, has been widely criticized. The ruling raised questions about the government's ability to limit corporate spending and the potential for corruption. In this context, Twitter's stance against unmasking critics is seen as a crucial defense of free speech and a reminder that the government should not be able to silence dissenting voices.

Title: Former US President George H.W. Bush Emphasized the Importance of Faith in Leadership

Article:

Former President George H.W. Bush, the 41st president of the United States, rarely discussed his faith publicly, but he understood its significance, especially in the Oval Office. In a 1992 interview with Pat Robertson, Bush stated that faith is crucial for anyone leading the country. He believed that an atheist could not be president, as anyone without a higher power guiding them would lack the necessary strength and guidance.

Bush shared his personal experiences with prayer, noting that he and his wife, Barbara, would pray together at meals and before bed. He also agreed with Robertson that prayer was essential in the Oval Office. When discussing Abraham Lincoln's statement that he couldn't handle the presidency without prayer, Bush responded, "Yes, you have to." He explained that as he spent more time in office, he understood the importance of having a higher power to guide him.

Bush also spoke about turning to prayer before making a crucial decision, such as ordering the start of Operation Desert Shield in response to Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. He noted that the decision to commit troops to combat was a heavy burden, and he sought guidance through prayer.

In 2007, Bush discussed his spirituality during a dedication ceremony for the Billy Graham Library in Charlotte, North Carolina. He described his faith as a personal matter, but one that was not self-conscious, and credited Billy Graham with helping him understand the importance of his relationship with Jesus Christ.

Bush's casket will lie in repose in the Capitol rotunda on Tuesday, allowing the public to pay their respects. His casket will then be flown to Washington, D.C. for an invitation-only state funeral at the National Cathedral, followed by a private ceremony and burial at the Bush presidential library in College Station, Texas. He will be buried alongside his wife Barbara and their daughter Robin, who passed away in 1953.

Title: Obama Administration Announces New Immigration Policy, Romney Refuses to Comment

The Obama administration has announced a new immigration policy, which will stop deporting young adult illegal immigrants who meet certain criteria. The policy, which was announced on Friday, will allow individuals who were brought to the country as children and have been here for at least five years, have completed high school, or have joined the U.S. military to apply for a special program that will end their risk of being deported and grant them legal work rights.

The policy is similar to the Dream Act, which was introduced in Congress but failed to pass. The administration says it is exercising its prosecutorial discretion to prioritize deportation cases and focus on removing individuals who are a threat to national security or public safety.

Some Republicans in Congress have vowed to sue the administration over the policy, saying it is an overreach of executive authority. Mitt Romney, the presumed Republican presidential nominee, refused to comment on the policy, saying it was a political move by the administration.

The administration has defended the policy, saying it is based on a review of the law and a determination that it is in the best interest of the country. Homeland Security Secretary Janet Napolitano said that the policy is an exercise of prosecutorial discretion and is designed to ensure that immigration laws are enforced in a strong and sensible manner.

The policy has been met with mixed reactions, with some immigrant rights groups welcoming the move and others expressing concerns about the potential for fraud and abuse. The administration has said that it will work with Congress to pass comprehensive immigration reform legislation, but that it is taking this step to address the immediate needs of young people who are already in the country.

In related news, Senator Marco Rubio, a Florida Republican, is working on a version of the Dream Act that would grant a path to citizenship to students who have graduated high school and are attending a four-year college.

Title: Rubio's Immigration Plan Gains Momentum Among Conservative Voters

Article: Senator Marco Rubio, a Republican from Florida, has been making significant strides in winning over grassroots Republican voters with his immigration reform plan. Since joining the bipartisan group late last year, Rubio has been actively engaging with conservative news media outlets, explaining his guiding principles and receiving praise from prominent figures such as Rush Limbaugh and Sean Hannity.

According to Republican consultant Phil Musser, Rubio's approach has helped to "decalfify a process that's been stuck for a long time" by addressing conservative concerns and emphasizing the importance of strict border security measures before considering a path to citizenship for illegal immigrants. Rubio's plan also focuses on refining the current system, including increased enforcement and a workable plan for future legal immigrants.

Former Republican Senator Mel Martinez, who was part of the failed 2007 attempt at an immigration overhaul, credits Rubio's strong leadership and communication skills for the growing momentum behind his plan. Martinez notes that Rubio's emphasis on strong border security and enforcement is a significant factor in gaining support from both Republicans and Democrats.

Rubio has also been actively engaging with conservative news media outlets, House Republicans, and grassroots supporters through one-on-one phone calls and meetings. He has also brought on Enrique Gonzalez, a well-known immigration lawyer, to his staff and assigned a legislative assistant to work exclusively on immigration issues.

In January, Rubio called for a full committee review of his plan, aiming to prevent the same mistakes that led to the failure of the 2007 bill, such as the perception that the proposal was written in secret and rushed to the Senate floor. Rubio's efforts have been met with enthusiasm from some conservative media personalities, with Rush Limbaugh stating that Rubio is "insistent this thing not be ramrodded through, that there be hearings."

Title: FBI Completes Supplemental Background Check on Brett Kavanaugh, Report to be Released to Senate

The Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) has concluded its supplemental background check on Supreme Court nominee Brett Kavanaugh, according to Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell. The report will be transmitted to the Senate on Wednesday evening, allowing senators to review it before a procedural vote on Friday and a final confirmation vote as early as Saturday.

The FBI's investigation focused on allegations of sexual misconduct by Kavanaugh when he was young, specifically those made by Christine Blasey Ford, who alleged that he sexually assaulted her when they were teenagers. Ford's lawyers have expressed disappointment that she was not contacted or interviewed during the investigation.

The report is expected to center around Ford's allegations, which Kavanaugh has vehemently denied. The FBI had contacted at least a handful of key witnesses during its investigation, but some have questioned why others were not interviewed.

Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer has called for a slowdown in the process, suggesting senators should have a day to study the FBI report before deciding on Kavanaugh's fate. Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell has stated that the report will be finished quickly enough to allow a Senate vote this week.

The FBI's investigation was conducted over a week, during which time the bureau interviewed at least five key witnesses. The report will be kept secret, but its contents are expected to be a deciding factor for three Republican senators who hold swing votes on Kavanaugh's appointment.

The White House has not commented on the scope of the investigation or any restrictions placed on the FBI, leading Senate Democrats to express concerns about the transparency of the process. The report's release is expected to be a crucial factor in the confirmation process, with some senators calling for a delay to allow for further review.

Title: Republicans Consider Preserving Parts of ObamaCare in Potential Replacement

Article:

Despite Republican pledges to repeal ObamaCare, some conservatives are indicating that certain aspects of the Affordable Care Act (ACA) could be preserved if the party were to succeed in its goal. This idea is not new, as some Republicans have long argued that certain provisions, such as subsidies to help individuals buy insurance and consumer protections for the sickest, have bipartisan support.

Michael Gerson, a former speechwriter for President George W. Bush, recently urged Republicans to focus on creating their own health care policy rather than simply tearing down the existing one. In a theoretical post-ObamaCare period, Gerson suggested that a Republican plan could offer a universal credit to those not covered by a large employer and protections for those without insurance from "catastrophic expenses." These ideas would be scaled-back versions of the subsidies and consumer protections currently offered in ObamaCare.

Some Republicans have already proposed similar ideas. For example, the American Health Care Reform Act, proposed by Republican Study Committee Chairman Rep. Steve Scalise, would use some long-standing conservative ideas for health care, such as allowing people to buy insurance across state lines, but also provide tax deductions to help purchase insurance. The bill would not include the mandate on almost everyone to obtain insurance, which is perhaps the least popular element of ObamaCare.

According to a May 2012 Kaiser Health poll, popular provisions of ObamaCare favored by both parties include letting children stay on their parents' plans until they turn 26 and providing subsidies on a sliding scale to those who cannot afford insurance. David Kendall, a senior fellow for health and fiscal policy at Third Way, noted that there is a history of Republicans supporting ideologies parallel to what is seen in the Affordable Care Act, including a universal plan proposed by President Richard Nixon at the end of his term.

The law is not so dissimilar, Kendall said, to versions Republicans have pushed in the past, including a universal plan proposed by President Richard Nixon at the end of his term. The exchanges, which are a centerpiece of the health reform plan, have been plagued by problems since their launch on October 1. The experience would likely leave Republicans hesitant to recreate them if they were in a position to try their own plan. For now, though, the latest budget fight proved Republicans do not have the numbers or the leverage to repeal or replace ObamaCare at this point, and may have to wait until 2016 for their next shot at changing the balance of power.

Title: Trump's Decision on DACA Leaves Congress with a New Opportunity

Article:

President Donald Trump's decision to end the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) program, which protected around 800,000 immigrants who came to the United States as children, has been met with criticism and concern. The decision was seen as both cruel and thoughtless, with Trump sending Attorney General Jeff Sessions to announce the end of the program. However, the president quickly undercut his own policy by tweeting that if Congress does not act to fix the problem, he will revisit his decision.

The ball is now in Congress' court, where it has always been. The Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals program was implemented by President Barack Obama as a temporary fix to ensure that those who had violated U.S. law through no fault of their own could remain in the country without fear of deportation. However, it was never a permanent solution and required congressional action to provide real security to these young immigrants.

The votes are there to pass a bill to protect childhood arrivals, but it will require bipartisanship. Democrats are ready to vote for a bill to put dreamers on the path to citizenship, and despite the rhetoric on the right and anti-immigrant fanaticism in the GOP base, there are enough Republicans who favor helping dreamers to get legislation through both houses. The trick will be getting a bill to the floor.

In an Oval Office meeting with congressional leaders, President Trump decided to back the Democrats' proposal to keep the government funded and raise the debt ceiling for three months instead of seeking a longer-term debt and funding solution favored by his own party. This decision took Republicans by surprise, but it also gives House Speaker Paul Ryan and Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell an opportunity to move forward on legislation that requires Democratic votes to pass.

The biggest impediment to passing legislation to give childhood arrivals permanent resident status has been the reluctance of GOP leaders to bring a bill to the floor that the majority of their members do not support. However, Speaker Ryan could ignore the Hastert rule and allow one of the fixes to move forward.

President Trump has done his best to humiliate Republican leaders in Congress, so why do they owe him any degree of loyalty? If Congress hopes to accomplish anything in the next year and a half, McConnell and Ryan will have to carve out a path of their own. It can begin with recognizing that dreamers are Americans in every way that matters. Half of dreamers came when they were 6 years old or younger, they have attended American schools, graduated, and gone on to be employed at rates higher than their American-born peers. They can and should be asked to give back to the country by paying taxes and serving in the U.S. military – but they won't be able to do those things without permanent resident status. The alternative would be to deport hundreds of thousands of young, productive workers. Why would anyone want to see that happen?

Title: New Polls Show President Obama Leading in Three Swing States

A recent batch of polls in Ohio, Florida, and Pennsylvania suggests that President Barack Obama is leading Republican nominee Mitt Romney among likely voters in these crucial swing states. The polls, conducted by Quinnipiac University/CBS News/New York Times and Franklin and Marshall College, indicate that Obama is ahead by 9-12 points in each state.

The polls come as Romney's campaign has faced criticism for its handling of the economy, an issue that has been a key focus of his campaign. According to the polls, voters in these states see Obama as better equipped to handle the economy, health care, Medicare, national security, international crises, and immigration.

The Quinnipiac University Polling Institute's assistant director, Peter A. Brown, noted that the wide difference between the two candidates is not just a result of Romney's recent controversies, but rather a reflection of Obama's strength on the economy. "The president's strength results from the fact that for the first time in the entire campaign, he is seen as better able to fix the economy than is Romney, the issue that has been the Republican's calling card since the general election campaign began," Brown said.

The economy remains the top issue for Americans when it comes to their vote for president. Romney has been trying to capitalize on this issue, but the polls suggest that his efforts have not been successful. In an interview with CNN, Romney said, "Polls go up and down, but frankly, you're going to see the support that I need to become president on Election Day."

The polls in Ohio, Florida, and Pennsylvania are significant because they account for 67 electoral votes. Ohio, in particular, is crucial to winning the White House, as no Republican has won the presidency without carrying the state in modern times. Florida and Pennsylvania are also key battlegrounds, with Obama having won both states in the 2008 election.

The polls come as both Romney and Obama are campaigning in Ohio, with the first presidential debate in Denver just a week away. Early voting is already underway in some states, and Iowa becomes the first battleground state to begin early voting on Thursday.

Title: Obama's Budget Plan to Include Changes to Social Security and Medicare, Sparking Criticism from Liberal Groups

The White House has announced that President Barack Obama's upcoming budget plan will include proposed changes to Social Security and Medicare, as well as new tax increases, in an effort to reach a deal with Republicans on deficit reduction. The plan, which will be presented on Wednesday, is expected to include $400 billion in savings to Medicare over 10 years.

The proposed changes to Social Security include a switch to a key Republican request called "chained CPI," an inflation formula that proponents say is a more accurate way to measure inflation. However, some critics argue that chained CPI is not a better way to measure inflation for Social Security recipients, who spend a significant amount on healthcare, which rises faster than inflation.

The budget plan also includes funding for initiatives outlined in Obama's State of the Union address, such as universal access to prekindergarten education, which would be paid for by increases to cigarette taxes. Additionally, the plan would close a current loophole that allows people to collect disability and unemployment benefits at the same time, a move that could create savings for the government.

The plan is an offer Obama made to House Speaker John Boehner in December, which included $400 billion in savings to Medicare over 10 years. However, Boehner stated that the two were never able to reach an agreement because Obama's "offers never lived up to his rhetoric," a reality that still exists.

Liberal groups, such as MoveOn.org and Democracy for America, have criticized the proposed changes to Social Security as "unconscionable" and "profoundly disturbing." The groups argue that the changes would hurt vulnerable populations, such as seniors and people with disabilities.

The budget plan is expected to include $1.8 trillion in savings over 10 years and would replace the forced budget cuts that took effect on March 1, also known as the sequester. The plan would also include funding for other initiatives, such as infrastructure projects and education programs.

Title: G-7 Leaders Discuss Russia and ISIS at Summit, Sanctions Against Russia to Remain

The leaders of the world's top industrialized democracies gathered in Germany for the G-7 summit, with Russia and ISIS topping the agenda. Russia was absent from the meeting for the second consecutive year, as a result of its annexation of Crimea from Ukraine and its support for pro-Russian rebels in the region. The G-7 nations imposed sanctions on Russia last year in response to these actions.

During the summit, US President Barack Obama met with German Chancellor Angela Merkel and emphasized the importance of standing up to Russian aggression in Ukraine. Both leaders agreed that sanctions against Russia should not be lifted until President Vladimir Putin fully implements the terms of the peace accord reached in Minsk last February.

Putin, however, maintained that Russia's actions in Crimea, Ukraine, and elsewhere are defensive in nature and pose no threat to the West. Some European officials share this view and may consider weakening the sanctions against Russia, either with or without the support of the US and Germany.

The G-7 leaders also discussed the war against the Islamic State (ISIS) in Iraq and Syria. The general in charge of the effort to recapture Ramadi and other areas in Anbar province reported that the Iraqi military has secured the defense lines leading to Baghdad. However, some European leaders are questioning the effectiveness of Obama's strategy against ISIS, as the group continues to make gains in both Iraq and Syria.

The summit highlighted the ongoing tensions between Russia and the West, as well as the challenges posed by ISIS. The G-7 leaders will continue to monitor the situation and work together to address these pressing global issues.

Title: FBI Reports Surge in Background Checks Amid Renewed Calls for Gun Control

The FBI has seen a significant increase in background checks this year, with some of the biggest spikes coming in August and September following mass shootings in El Paso and Odessa, Texas, and Dayton, Ohio, which left 38 people dead. The surge in checks is a rough barometer of gun sales, and the FBI's National Instant Criminal Background Check System (NICS) is a way to gauge market demand.

According to FBI records, the number of monthly checks has not fallen below 2 million this year, and with the holiday shopping season approaching, the number of background checks for 2019 could break the one-year record of 27.5 million. The FBI has requested additional money and personnel to deal with the workload, citing increasing background checks in its request for 40 new positions and $4.2 million.

The surge in gun sales has been driven by fears that lawmakers may tighten gun laws, said Larry Keane, general counsel for the firearms industry trade group National Shooting Sports Foundation. "People respond to what they perceive as threats to their Second Amendment rights, and this has been going on since August," Keane said.

The FBI has been criticized for problems with its background check system, including a recent incident in which the Air Force failed to provide the FBI with the criminal record of a man who went on to massacre 26 people at a Texas church. The Justice Department has reported that the military and other federal agencies have increased their submissions of criminal and mental health records to the background check system by more than 6% in the past year.

The surge in gun sales has also been driven by political rhetoric, particularly from Democratic presidential candidates who have called for stricter gun control measures. Former Texas congressman Beto O'Rourke's call for mandatory buybacks of popular semi-automatic rifles used in some recent attacks, including the El Paso assault, drew both plaudits and rebukes. The comment drove record gun sales at a store in Tempe, Arizona, with the owner selling over 400 firearms during a week-long "Beto Special."

While some gun owners are responding to perceived threats to their Second Amendment rights, others are simply taking advantage of the holiday shopping season to purchase firearms. Matt Boggs, co-owner of Alpha Dog Firearms, said his store sold more than 400 firearms during the "Beto Special," typically selling about 100 guns in a month. "We did it because someone had the audacity to come after a U.S. citizen's rights," Boggs said.

The surge in gun sales is likely to continue, with the FBI reporting that the number of background checks has only remained steady for the rest of the year to break the record. The political calendar and unrelenting gun violence are likely to keep up demand for firearms.

Title: Political Ads Suspended in Colorado Following Aurora Shooting

In the wake of the tragic shooting in Aurora, Colorado, which claimed at least 12 lives and injured dozens more, both presidential campaigns and major super PACs have suspended their negative advertising in the state. President Obama and Mitt Romney announced that they would cease their advertising efforts in Colorado, acknowledging that it would be distasteful to continue pointed political attacks at this time.

Andrea Saul, a spokeswoman for Romney's campaign, confirmed that all ads in Colorado would be pulled until further notice. Jen Psaki, an Obama campaign spokeswoman, stated that the president's ads were also being taken down, with efforts being made to remove them from stations as quickly as possible.

American Crossroads and its sister organization, Crossroads GPS, which have spent millions of dollars attacking Obama in Colorado, also confirmed that their ads would be suspended. Steven Law, the group's president, said, "In moments of tragedy like the Aurora shooting, we all stand together as Americans."

Priorities Action USA, a super PAC supporting the president, also suspended its ads. Colorado is one of the battleground states where a fierce advertising war has been playing out, with most ads being attack ads. The Obama campaign had been airing three ads attacking Romney, while Romney's campaign had been running two ads accusing Obama of showering his friends and campaign contributors with federal stimulus dollars and lying about his business record.

The suspension of ads in Colorado marks a rare moment of bipartisan cooperation in an otherwise intense election season.

Title: Obama Downplays Diplomatic Snub Claims as G-20 Summit Kicks Off in Hangzhou

The G-20 summit in Hangzhou, China, has gotten off to a rocky start, with tensions between the United States and China evident in the days leading up to the meeting. However, President Barack Obama sought to downplay the significance of the diplomatic snub, attributing it to minor misunderstandings and protocol issues.

Speaking to the press, Obama acknowledged that the seams may be showing in the negotiations and jostling that takes place behind the scenes, but emphasized that it was not a reflection of the broader scope of the relationship between the two nations. He noted that similar issues have arisen during his visits to close allies, citing the need for adjustments to accommodate the United States' larger footprint.

The tensions began to emerge as soon as Air Force One landed in Hangzhou, with Chinese officials blocking U.S. traveling media from watching the president disembark and shouting "this is our country" at a U.S. diplomat. National Security Advisor Susan E. Rice and her deputy, Benjamin J. Rhode, were also blocked from approaching President Obama on the tarmac.

The issues continued to escalate, with Chinese officials reportedly cutting American press access to bilateral events and reducing the press pack to just one person when Obama and Chinese President Xi Jinping took a walk along Hangzhou's famous West Lake.

Despite the tensions, Obama defended media norms in the U.S. and other Western nations, emphasizing the importance of press access and the ability to answer questions. He also highlighted the progress made in the bilateral talks, including the announcement that the two countries will formally join the Paris Climate Change Agreement.

The meeting between Obama and Chinese President Xi Jinping touched on a range of topics, including the environment, the South China Sea, protectionism, and human rights. While there were points of disagreement, the two leaders also found common ground, with Obama stating that "where countries like China and the United States are prepared to show leadership and to lead by example, it is possible for us to create a world that is more secure, more prosperous, and more free than the one that was left for us."

Title: Chief Justice Roberts Admonishes House Managers and President's Counsel Over Lively Debate

Chief Justice John Roberts intervened in the impeachment trial of President Donald Trump, urging both sides to maintain a higher level of civility and decorum. The chief justice's rebuke came during a heated debate over whether former national security adviser John Bolton should be subpoenaed to testify before the Senate. Roberts emphasized the importance of maintaining a respectful tone, citing an example from the 1905 impeachment trial of Florida District Judge Charles Swayne, where a senator objected to the use of the term "pettifogging."

In the current trial, House Judiciary Chairman Jerry Nadler accused senators who might vote against calling Bolton to testify of being part of a "cover-up." White House counsel Pat Cipollone responded by calling for Nadler to apologize to the Senate, the president, and the American people. Cipollone accused Nadler of making false allegations against the Senate and the president's team.

Roberts' admonishment marked his first major intervention in the trial, as he strives to maintain the Supreme Court's reputation for impartiality. According to Jeffrey Rosen, president of the National Constitution Center, Roberts prioritizes the nonpartisan, institutional legitimacy of the courts above all else.

Title: Vox Media Implements Cost-Cutting Measures Amid Pandemic-Induced Economic Fallout

Vox Media, a digital publishing company behind brands such as Eater, SB Nation, New York Magazine, and The Strategist, has announced a series of cost-cutting measures to navigate the economic challenges posed by the coronavirus pandemic. According to a source familiar with the moves, the company will furlough 9% of its staff from May 1 to July 31, with health insurance premiums remaining fully covered.

In addition to layoffs, Vox Media will implement temporary measures to reduce costs. About 1% of staff will move to reduced hours from May 1 to July 31, with health insurance premiums still fully covered. Employees with an annual salary of $130,000 or more will face a temporary tiered pay reduction during the same period. The company will also suspend 401(k) matches until the end of 2020 and freeze merit-based increases and promotions.

In a memo to staff, CEO Jim Bankoff acknowledged the unprecedented circumstances, stating, "The expectations that we had just a few weeks ago for our business and our lives no longer apply." He emphasized the company's goal to limit the impact on employees.

Vox Media is not alone in taking drastic measures to survive the pandemic. Other major media companies, such as Group Nine Media, Bustle Digital Group, and Cheddar, have also laid off staff and implemented pay cuts. The digital news industry has been facing a tough economic outlook for some time, with Vox Media having laid off around 50 staff members in 2018 and hundreds of freelancers last year due to a California law reclassifying freelance journalists as contract workers.

Title: May Jobs Report: 138,000 Jobs Added, Unemployment Rate Dips Slightly

The United States added 138,000 jobs in May, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics' (BLS) monthly jobs report released on Friday. The national unemployment rate decreased to 4.3%, a 16-year low, down from 4.4% the previous month. This marks a slight dip in the unemployment rate, which had been at 4.4% since 2007, before the recession.

The jobs report showed that the economy added 138,000 jobs in May, falling short of economists' expectations of 185,000 job gains. The previous month's report initially showed a stronger job market, with 211,000 jobs added, but this figure was revised downward to 174,000. The March report was also revised, with job gains decreasing from 79,000 to 50,000.

The numbers suggest that job growth is slowing slightly, with an average gain of 121,000 jobs over the past three months, compared to 181,000 over the past 12 months. The number of unemployed Americans remained essentially unchanged, at 6.9 million.

The BLS report also provided more specific data on job markets in different U.S. cities. According to the agency, Ames, Iowa, and Boulder, Colorado, had the lowest unemployment rates, at 1.7% and 1.8%, respectively. The highest unemployment rate was in El Centro, California, at 19.2%. For large cities with a population over 1 million in the 2010 Census, the Denver area had the lowest unemployment rate, at 2.1%, while the Cleveland area had the highest rate, at 5.4%.

Title: Republican Establishment Returns to Trump's Fold as Election Nears

Article:

As the presidential election campaign enters its final days, prominent Republicans are re-endorsing Donald Trump, hoping to avoid being blamed for his potential failure. The most notable re-endorser is Jason Chaffetz, the House Oversight Committee chair, who likely secretly hopes Hillary Clinton will win, allowing him to continue his witch hunts in front of the cameras. Chaffetz may also throw his hat into the ring for speaker if there's a rebellion against Paul Ryan, which is a real possibility.

Other notable Republicans, including Sen. Deb Fischer of Nebraska, Rep. Scott Garrett of New Jersey, Rep. Bradley Byrne of Alabama, and Sen. John Thune of South Dakota, have also returned to Trump's fold after initially dropping their endorsements following the "grab 'em by the pussy" tape. Even Trump skeptic and Beltway conservative Hugh Hewitt has now decided to back Trump.

The Republican establishment has been struggling to come to terms with the fact that their voters have a different interpretation of conservatism than they thought. The elites define Reagan's "three-legged stool" of conservatism as economic, social, and defense conservatism, which they describe as a belief in small government, family values, and patriotism. However, Trump has shown that the base of the party also believes in these pillars, but without the intellectual veneer that made them socially acceptable.

The Pew Research Center poll released this week suggests that the hope of the GOP elders to return to the previous status quo, where everyone pretends the party's base cares about tort reform and the capital gains tax, is not going to happen. The poll found that about two-thirds of Republican and Republican-leaning voters think Trump represents the core principles and positions the Republican Party should stand for, while 31% think he does not.

The divide manifests itself in many different ways, with those who did not vote for Trump in the primaries showing a stronger dislike for the Republican Party as a whole. Trump voters seem to like the party just fine now that Trump has defined what it stands for.

The article also highlights how Trump's beliefs were shaped by his early advisers, including Roger Stone and Sam Nunberg, who were steeped in wing-nut-ism and right-wing media. Trump's platform, from birtherism to the border wall and from torture to terrorism, was largely shaped by conservative media.

**Title:** President Obama's Asia-Pacific Trade Deal: Strengthening Security and Promoting Economic Growth

**Article:**

President Barack Obama has recently concluded a trip to the Philippines and Malaysia, focusing on strengthening alliances in Asia and building multilateral organizations that shape the rules in this dynamic region. While the American public is currently focused on national security and the Middle East, the President's attention to trade across the Pacific is crucial for guaranteeing security. The Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP), a comprehensive trade and investment pact among 12 countries representing 40% of the global GDP and 30% of global trade, is a key component of this effort.

The TPP aims to develop into a Free Trade Area of the Pacific, eventually including all 21 Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) countries, and potentially expanding to non-APEC countries like India and Colombia. Congressional approval is required, and debate on the agreement is underway, with a vote likely to come next year. The economic benefits of the TPP are well-documented, including economic growth and American jobs. However, another less-discussed aspect of the pact is its impact on security.

The provisions in the TPP and the deeper engagement with trading partners are crucial for protecting the United States from a wide range of non-traditional security risks. These risks include the possible re-emergence of pandemic diseases, such as SARS, which could have devastating economic consequences. The World Bank estimates SARS cost the global economy $54 billion, and a future pandemic could cost up to $3 trillion. The TPP would enhance the capacity of trading partners to manage these risks, as well as address other non-traditional challenges like food security and nutrition, which have a significant impact on the productivity of some signatory countries.

The trade deal also addresses some non-traditional risks more explicitly, such as illegal fishing, deforestation, and illegal animal trafficking, which contribute to climate change and the incidence of zoonotic diseases. Other benefits include improving transparency and non-discrimination provisions with regard to state-linked companies and government procurement.

The TPP is more than just a trade agreement; it is a capacity-builder promoting a more peaceful and prosperous world. The United States will increasingly need to ally with its political and economic partners to address the full range of security issues. The failure of these partners to do so will contribute to the United States' own security challenges.

Title: Supreme Court to Hear Lawsuit Challenging Obama's Immigration Executive Actions

The Supreme Court has agreed to hear a lawsuit filed by 26 states against President Obama's executive actions aimed at protecting millions of undocumented immigrants from deportation. The justices are expected to render a decision by the end of June. The lawsuit, which challenges the constitutionality of the president's actions, was filed in 2016.

The Obama administration's executive actions, announced in 2014, aimed to provide work permits and a three-year reprieve from deportation to as many as five million undocumented parents of American citizens or permanent residents who had no criminal record and had lived in the country for at least five years. The actions were seen as a step towards addressing the issue of undocumented immigration, with over 11 million people living in the United States without legal status.

The program, which was implemented in 2012, allowed young immigrants who were brought to the country as children to be given work permits and exempted from deportation. The Obama administration's 2014 plan aimed to build upon this program by providing similar relief to undocumented parents.

The lawsuit, filed by 26 states, argues that the president's actions overstepped his constitutional authority. However, many experts and politicians believe that a more practical solution would be to focus on removing those who pose a threat to public safety while deferring action on most of the rest and helping them "come out of the shadows."

The issue of undocumented immigration has been a topic of debate for decades, with politicians on both sides of the aisle acknowledging the need for a comprehensive solution. In a 1980 presidential debate, George H.W. Bush criticized the harsh treatment of undocumented immigrants, stating, "We're creating a whole society of really honorable, decent, family-loving people that are in violation of the law."

Title: Gun Control Advocates Shift Focus to Local Efforts, Building Political Infrastructure

Gun control advocates are shifting their focus from Capitol Hill to Main Street, recognizing that immediate legislative action is unlikely in the current political climate. Instead, they are building a political infrastructure and organizing local events across the country to keep the issue top of mind.

The anniversary of the Sandy Hook Elementary School massacre, which sparked a national conversation on gun control, was marked with a series of local events and a private moment of silence at the White House. Gun control advocates have learned from the experience, acknowledging that the political momentum was lost after the Senate failed to pass background check legislation.

The fight has moved from a public push for immediate legislation to a grassroots effort, with organizations like Moms Demand Action for Gun Sense in America and the Brady Campaign to Prevent Gun Violence building a political infrastructure to compete with the National Rifle Association. The groups are planning local events, including vigils and town halls, to keep the issue in the public eye.

Shannon Watts, the founder of Moms Demand Action, is leading the charge, using social media to mobilize supporters and organize local events. The group is also planning to target specific companies, such as McDonald's, to pressure them into taking a stance on gun control.

Gun control advocates are also preparing for the midterm elections, recognizing that the issue will remain a key point of contention. They are working to build a coalition of supporters and lawmakers who will push for change.

"We've learned the lessons from Newtown," said Lanae Erickson Hatalsky, director of social policy and politics at Third Way, a centrist think tank. "We won't need to take so much time to figure out what to do. If there is a tragedy that specifically involves one of the policies we're talking about, we'll see more swift action."

The shift in strategy is a recognition that gun control is a complex issue that requires a sustained effort and a broad coalition of supporters. While immediate legislative action may not be possible, gun control advocates are determined to keep the issue on the national agenda and push for change.

Title: Author Reflects on Election Predictions and Trump's Presidency

The author of this article has been told by many that they got everything wrong since Election Day, with some even predicting the end of their career and life. Despite feeling that they have nothing to apologize for, the author acknowledges that they did get some things wrong, including their electoral predictions. However, they argue that the claim that they got everything wrong reveals more about their detractors than about themselves.

The author notes that they were a committed "Never Trump" conservative during the primaries and general election, which earned them the disappointment and wrath of many on the right. While they did get the election wrong, they believe that the claim that they got everything wrong is an exaggeration. They argue that the only sense in which one could plausibly claim they got everything wrong is if Donald Trump is one's everything.

The author also reflects on their predictions about Trump's presidency, admitting that they got some things wrong. They note that many on the left and in the media see Trump's cabinet appointments and policy proposals as cause for existential panic, but as a conservative, they find most of them reassuring. They also acknowledge that Trump's appointments at the departments of Education, Health and Human Services, and Labor and at the Environmental Protection Agency suggest a level of commitment to paring back the administrative state that heartens and surprises them.

The author also expresses surprise by the benefits of having a political novice take over the executive branch, citing Trump's phone call with Taiwan and his ad hoc bargaining with defense contractors as examples. They also believe that Trump's character is a major concern, citing his unrestrained ego, impoverished impulse control, and contempt for policy due diligence as reasons for their concerns. They firmly believe that character is destiny and are troubled by Trump's reported refusal to accept daily intelligence briefings and his freelancing every issue under the sun on Twitter.

Overall, the author does not feel repentant, but acknowledges that Trump has surrounded himself with serious and sober-minded people who will try to constrain and contain the truly dangerous aspects of his character.

Title: Congress on Brink of Government Shutdown as Border Wall Funding Talks Stall

The United States Congress is on the verge of a partial government shutdown, with lawmakers failing to reach an agreement on funding for the government before the holidays. The House and Senate left town on Thursday without a strategy to prevent a shutdown, which could result in the furloughing of hundreds of thousands of workers and cost taxpayers millions.

The impasse is largely due to President Donald Trump's insistence on securing funding for his border wall, which has led to a stalemate between the two parties. The House and Senate have made little progress since Trump's surprise announcement on Tuesday, stating that he would take responsibility for a government shutdown if he doesn't get the funding he wants.

Lawmakers from both parties are frustrated with the lack of progress, with some expressing concern that there is no clear plan to prevent a shutdown. Senate Republican John Cornyn stated that there is "no discernable plan" and that everyone is waiting for a signal from Trump.

The House is not expected to return until the night of December 19, leaving only about 72 hours to reach an agreement. Democrats are waiting for Republicans to make a move, while Republicans are waiting for Trump to provide guidance. The Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell and Minority Leader Chuck Schumer have not been discussing the issue, and senators from both parties are unaware of any ongoing talks.

The House had planned to pass a bill providing $5 billion for Trump's border wall, but it was met with resistance from Democrats. Republicans are now considering delaying the decision until January 3, when House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi takes over leadership, or pushing the deadline to December 26 to give them time with their families over the holidays.

Some Republicans are preparing backup options to temporarily extend funding, while others are pushing for a long-term funding bill that freezes funding through October 2019. The Senate Appropriations Committee Chairman Richard Shelby stated that the situation is at an impasse, and something will happen or there will be a shutdown.

The Democratic leader, Nancy Pelosi, has criticized Trump for his vow to shut down the government over the holidays, delaying paychecks for hundreds of thousands of federal workers. The Senate has been focused on other issues, such as criminal justice reform and the Yemeni civil war, and does not feel like the 2013 shutdown, when government funding lapsed for nearly three weeks.

The situation remains uncertain, with no clear plan in place to prevent a shutdown.

Title: Trump Defends Puerto Rico Relief Efforts, Accuses Critics of "Fake News" and "Politically Motivated Ingratitude"

Article:

President Donald Trump has defended his administration's response to the humanitarian crisis in Puerto Rico, dismissing any criticism as "fake news" and "politically motivated ingratitude." Trump made the comments during a series of tweets on Saturday, in which he targeted San Juan Mayor Carmen Yulin Cruz, who had questioned the pace of relief efforts on the island.

Trump claimed that his administration has done a "great job" in responding to the crisis, citing the work of the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) and the military. He also thanked Puerto Rico Governor Ricardo Rossello and "all of those who are working so closely with our First Responders" for their efforts.

However, Rossello acknowledged that there are still areas of the island that have not been inspected for safety, and that the focus remains on delivering essential supplies to those in need. FEMA Administrator Brock Long also acknowledged that there are still major challenges to overcome, but emphasized the progress that has been made in establishing a joint field office in San Juan and working with local leaders to create unified objectives.

Trump's comments come as he prepares to visit the island on Tuesday to review rescue efforts. The visit has not affected aid deliveries or relief operations, according to Puerto Rico National Guard Maj. Paul Dahlen.

The president's tweets drew criticism from political opponents, who contrasted his response to Puerto Rico with his handling of hurricanes Harvey and Irma in Texas and Florida. Sen. Bernie Sanders, I-Vt., suggested that Trump's response may be influenced by the island's location and the fact that it is not a mainland state. Ohio Republican Gov. John Kasich also criticized Trump's criticism of public officials in the middle of a disaster.

Cruz, meanwhile, dismissed Trump's tweets as "unproductive" and emphasized the need for a collaborative effort to address the crisis. She also expressed willingness to meet with Trump if he requests a meeting.

Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin defended Trump's response, calling the San Juan mayor's complaints "unfair" given the efforts that have been made. However, FEMA Administrator Long dismissed criticism of the federal relief efforts, saying that what matters is what is being done, not what is being said.

Title: Study Suggests Media Policy Changes Contributed to Rising Political Polarization in the United States

The Telecommunications Act of 1996, passed by the US Congress, aimed to overhaul the country's media policy for the first time since 1934. The act relaxed ownership regulations, allowing for increased competition between cable and telephone telecommunications systems. This deregulation led to the inception of partisan news outlets like Fox News and MSNBC, providing viewers with a wider range of options.

Research has shown that partisan news outlets draw distinct audiences, with conservatives consuming Fox News and liberals consuming MSNBC. The availability of this content is significant, as studies have demonstrated that watching content on these outlets contributes to political polarization. Furthermore, the increased availability of niche programming allows non-partisans who are not interested in politics to tune out altogether.

The Telecommunications Act of 1996 created favorable conditions for a dramatic expansion in the number of media channels available to viewers, resulting in a rise in partisan television news channels among others. In turn, partisan television channels have been proven to contribute to political polarization. A recent study published in the International Journal of Public Opinion Research suggests that structural changes to media systems, such as the Telecommunications Act of 1996, can change the nature of media effects.

The study found that the relationship between media and polarization changed after 1996, with TV news contributing more to polarization following the enactment of the Telecommunications Act of 1996 than it did before. Frequent consumers of TV news showed greater increases in polarization on a year-to-year basis than individuals who spent less time watching TV news.

The policy changes may have encouraged the introduction of partisan media outlets and contributed to the increase in horse race coverage that focuses on the positive and negative traits of candidates instead of digging into policy debates. Many people claim that the Telecommunications Act of 1996 helped perpetuate increasing levels of media consolidation, with companies like the Disney Corporation purchasing major TV networks like ABC. Critics argue that decreased competition among cable companies following the law led to hikes in cable prices, which incentivized media companies like Fox to create their own cable networks.

The addition of partisan news sources to the media system provides viewers with an opportunity to seek out information that supports their extant view of the world. Scholars have also noted that when these media conglomerates took control of networks like ABC, news coverage suffered. News is now seen as an additional source of profit instead of a public service for viewers. This is important because the decreased funding of news departments may have contributed to increasing levels of cheap, conflict-oriented programming, which has the potential to increase people's level of polarization. As a result, watching TV news has become more polarizing for those who choose to watch.

Title: Trump Faces Pressure to Show Presidential Side in Upcoming Debate

Article:

With the South Carolina Republican primary just a week away, Donald Trump is set to face pressure to demonstrate a more presidential demeanor in the upcoming debate on Saturday night. Trump, who won the New Hampshire primary handily, has a significant lead in the polls, and his opponents are eager to slow him down. Texas Senator Ted Cruz, Florida Senator Marco Rubio, and former Florida Governor Jeb Bush are among those vying to emerge as the top alternative to Trump for mainstream Republicans.

The debate, hosted by CBS, comes at a time of high anxiety for Trump's opponents, who are struggling to gain traction in the polls. Trump's rivals are looking to raise questions about his behavior, particularly his use of vulgar language during the New Hampshire primary campaign. At a candidates' forum at evangelical Bob Jones University, Bush questioned Trump's behavior, saying, "Is anybody worried about the front-running candidate shouting out obscenities at children?"

Trump's opponents have something to prove at the debate, particularly Rubio, who needs to rebound from a disappointing performance in New Hampshire. Kasich must generate more momentum after a second-place finish, Cruz must solidify his position with evangelical voters, and Bush needs to show upward movement. Retired neurosurgeon Ben Carson, whose campaign has stalled, must show he is still in the race.

Each of Trump's opponents has an image issue they need to address, according to David Yepsen, director of the Paul Simon Public Policy Institute at Southern Illinois University. "Can Trump start acting more presidential without losing what makes him so appealing? Can Jeb continue the flicker of momentum he has coming out of New Hampshire? Have Rubio's bruises healed? Can Carson show something that puts a spark back into his campaign? Has Kasich got more than his New Hampshire game?" Yepsen asked.

Heading into the debate, Trump is taking swipes at Cruz and Bush, who finished third and fourth in the New Hampshire primary. Trump responded to an attack ad run by the Cruz campaign against him, tweeting that he might sue Cruz to settle questions about his eligibility to run for president. The Cruz campaign dismissed the blast, calling it a "Trumper-tantrum."

Title: Trump's Election Rigging Claims: A Familiar Pattern of Pre-emptive Excuses

Article:

Donald Trump has started claiming that the November election might be "stolen" from him, a charge he repeated at a rally in Columbus, Ohio, and to Sean Hannity. This is not a new tactic for Trump, who has made similar claims about "rigged" elections during the GOP primaries. By doing so, he lays the groundwork for explaining his potential loss in November, as he cannot admit to losing fair and square.

Trump's claims are reminiscent of those made by supporters of past Republican presidential losers, who often blame "shady Democrats" and the "biased mainstream media" for their losses. This includes conservative activist Dean Chambers, who re-weighted polls to show Mitt Romney winning in 2012, only to blame voter fraud when Obama won.

Democratic-leaning voters have also cried foul over "stolen" and "rigged" elections, but generally, those cries have stayed on the fringes of the party. In contrast, Trump's claims are more mainstream, with Fox commentators already making the case for voter fraud swinging the election to Clinton.

What is new is Trump's willingness to indulge in claims of stolen elections almost three months before voting starts. This legitimates the fears of the GOP base and indicates that Trump will not go quietly into the night if he loses. The right-wing media will also happily stoke these fires, making it likely that the election will last well past November 8.

Title: President Obama's State of the Union Address: A Review of His Claims and Actions

The President's State of the Union address has sparked controversy and skepticism among many Americans. While President Obama emphasized that his proposals will not increase the national debt, critics argue that his track record suggests otherwise. In his address, the President outlined his plans to tackle various issues, including gun control, global warming, immigration, and raising the minimum wage. However, his promises to cut the deficit in half during his first term were not fulfilled, with the national debt growing by more than half instead.

The President emphasized the need for a "smarter government" that sets priorities and invests in broad-based growth. However, critics point out that his plans often come with a hefty price tag, which may not be sustainable in the long run. The President's promise to create jobs and stimulate the economy has also been met with skepticism, given the country's current economic situation.

The address was met with mixed reactions from lawmakers, with some expressing optimism and others expressing concern. The President's Vice President, Joe Biden, was seen wiping away tears during the speech, while House Speaker John Boehner appeared stoic. The President's use of rhetorical devices, such as the "North Star" metaphor, was also met with skepticism.

Overall, the President's State of the Union address highlighted his plans and priorities for his second term, but also sparked controversy and debate among Americans.

Title: The Iconic Painting of the Declaration of Independence: A Closer Look

The Declaration of Independence, painted by John Trumbull in 1819, is an instantly recognizable image of American history. For nearly two centuries, it has hung in the Rotunda of the Capitol in Washington, D.C., an icon of the American founding. However, the painting captures a scene that never occurred. The famous picture depicts the five men appointed to prepare a declaration of independence from Great Britain presenting their draft to the Continental Congress in Philadelphia. However, the actual events unfolded differently.

According to historical records, the committee's original draft was reported to the Congress on June 28, and only Thomas Jefferson, who chaired the drafting committee, would have submitted the document to the presiding officer. The vote in favor of independence came on July 2, after which Congress spent the better part of three days debating and amending the declaration's words. The delegates agreed to a final text on the morning of July 4, and it was sent off to be printed. The document was not engrossed on parchment until two weeks later, and the signing of the document did not begin until August 2.

Trumbull also took creative liberties with the physical details of the setting. Delegates did not sit in upholstered mahogany armchairs, and the window treatments were simple blinds, not velvet drapes. There were no battle flags adorning the rear wall. However, Trumbull's painting is accurate in two crucial aspects. Of the 48 members of the Continental Congress visible in the painting, nearly all were painted from life. Trumbull was a talented miniature portraitist who made it his mission to preserve the faces of the patriots of 1776 as true-to-life facsimiles. He journeyed extensively to sketch or paint in person as many of the surviving signers as he could find.

As an artist, Trumbull took liberties with chairs and drapes, but when it came to the likenesses of men he revered as heroes, authenticity was paramount. Trumbull knew only too well what the founders had risked for independence. He himself had fought in the Revolutionary War and was imprisoned by the British on a charge of treason. He was passionate about recording for succeeding generations of Americans "the personal resemblance of those who have been the great actors" in what he never doubted was "the noblest series of actions which have ever presented themselves in the history of man."

Title: K-pop Fans' Actions Spark Debate on Cultural Appropriation and Industry Dynamics

K-pop fans gained attention this weekend after claiming to have registered thousands of tickets for President Trump's rally in Tulsa, Oklahoma, with the intention of not showing up. The stunt, which was seen as a demonstration of allyship with Black Lives Matter-supporting protesters and Juneteenth celebrants, led to the arena appearing more than half empty during the rally. While some K-pop fans celebrated their perceived victory, others raised concerns about the cultural appropriation and racism within the K-pop industry.

K-pop fans have been involved in several online activism campaigns, including sabotaging a surveillance app used by the Dallas Police Department and flooding a "White Lives Matter" hashtag with pictures and videos of their favorite idols. While these actions have been celebrated by many on the left, including politicians and protesters, some music fans believe it's essential to acknowledge the industry's history of cultural misappropriation and racism.

K-pop idols have been criticized for perpetuating stereotypes about black Americans and misappropriating black culture by wearing hairstyles such as cornrows and dreadlocks. Artists have also faced backlash for stating they are skilled at "talking Black" and for racist acts like wearing blackface.

Miranda Ruth Larsen, a K-pop fan and cultural studies researcher at the University of Tokyo, emphasized that cultural misappropriation within K-pop shouldn't be solely blamed on the artists. She noted that the decision-making process within the industry is often complex, involving multiple stakeholders, including companies, managers, and other industry professionals.

Larsen stressed the importance of understanding the industry's dynamics and the history of cultural misappropriation within K-pop to gain a full understanding of recent online activism campaigns. Without this context, it's impossible to accurately assess the significance of these actions.

Title: White House Won't Rule Out More Help for Rebels, Hasn't Verified Latest Claim on Chemical Weapons

The White House has not ruled out providing additional support to Syrian rebels, but has yet to verify the latest claims of chemical weapons use by the Assad regime. The administration has sought an urgent U.N. investigation and demanded accountability, but has not taken decisive action.

The latest allegations, which claim over 1,000 people were killed, have sparked concerns about the Obama administration's response to the crisis. The U.S. has provided humanitarian, logistical, and limited weaponry and hardware to the rebels, but has rebuffed calls for a stronger military aid response.

A major obstacle to U.S. involvement is the lack of trust between the administration and the Syrian opposition groups. The opposition has little faith in the U.S., citing the administration's failure to enforce its "red line" on chemical weapons use and its inability to provide decisive support.

The Joint Chiefs Chairman, Gen. Martin Dempsey, has pointed to the lack of trust as a major issue in military involvement in Syria. In a letter to Rep. Eliot Engel, Dempsey wrote that the side the U.S. chooses to support must be ready to promote its interests and those of the U.S. when the balance shifts in their favor.

Experts on the region say that the administration's lack of contact with opposition groups has contributed to the lack of trust. David Lesch, a Middle East history professor at Trinity University, said that the opposition groups have "little faith" in the U.S. and feel like they are on their own.

The administration has faced questions about chemical weapons use in Syria before, with President Barack Obama saying that using them would cross a "red line" and provoke a U.S. military response. However, the administration's failure to take action has damaged its credibility in the region, according to Andrew Tabler, author of "In the Lion's Den: An Eyewitness Account of Washington's Battle with Syria."

The U.N. chemical weapons inspectors have landed in Syria to begin probing the latest allegations, and the U.N. Security Council is set to meet on Wednesday to address the issue.

Title: The Decline of Journalistic Objectivity: A Historical Perspective

The concept of journalistic objectivity and accuracy is facing a significant challenge, with both sides of the media spectrum embracing a more partisan approach to reporting. This phenomenon is not new, as the history of American journalism reveals a complex and often partisan landscape. Prior to the mid-20th century, newspapers were often tied to specific political parties and factions, and reporting was often slanted and sensationalized.

The post-World War II era saw a shift towards more professionalized and objective journalism, with the goal of serving as an arbiter of extra-partisan truth. While this ideal was not always achieved, it imposed rigor on reporting and provided guidelines for journalists to strive for. This period also saw the rise of three television networks, two weekly news magazines, and a handful of print newspapers, which set the tone and standards for the dissemination of information to the American public.

However, in recent years, the standards of fairness and accuracy have been declining, driven by economic pressure to generate online traffic and ad revenue. The increasing partisanship and hostility towards President Trump and the Republican Party have also contributed to this decline. The result is a reversion to the flagrant partisan norms that prevailed before the mid-20th century.

The consequences of this trend are uncertain, but it is likely to exacerbate political polarization and erode social trust. The breakdown of trans-partisan journalistic norms can create a feedback loop that breeds cynicism and contributes to the collapse of social trust and the erosion of the authority of institutions that claim to speak for the common good.

In the coming years, it is unclear whether the country can maintain its power and prestige with a citizenry that treats every item of news with maximal suspicion and public debate takes the form of acrimonious partisan vituperation.

Title: US Health Secretary Calls for Focus on Concrete Health Issues at UN General Assembly

Article:

United States Health and Human Services Secretary Alex Azar addressed the United Nations General Assembly today, emphasizing the importance of expanding access to healthcare worldwide. In his remarks, Azar emphasized the need for a focus on concrete health issues, rather than referencing ambiguous terms such as "reproductive health and rights." Azar stated that the US does not support the inclusion of these terms in UN documents, as they can be misinterpreted and undermine the critical role of the family.

Azar also emphasized the importance of sex education that appreciates the protective role of the family and does not condone harmful sexual risks for young people. He noted that there is no international right to abortion and that these terms should not be used to promote pro-abortion policies and measures.

The statement was delivered during a high-level meeting on universal health coverage, which aims to accelerate progress toward universal health coverage for everyone around the world. The meeting is part of the UN's 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development, under which all countries have committed to achieving universal health coverage by 2030.

Azar and other health officials from 15 countries, including Bahrain, Belarus, Brazil, the Democratic Republic of the Congo, Egypt, Guatemala, Haiti, Hungary, Iraq, Libya, Mali, Nigeria, Poland, Russia, Saudi Arabia, Sudan, United Arab Emirates, and Yemen, spoke on behalf of their countries during the meeting. They emphasized the importance of equal access to healthcare, including reproductive concerns, maternal health, voluntary and informed family planning, HIV, elimination of violence against women and girls, and empowerment to reach the highest standard of health.

The officials urged the UN to focus on concrete issues and challenges to accelerate access to healthcare for all, and emphasized the importance of international solidarity in building broad consensus among member states.

Title: New Poll Reveals Shift in Congressional Control Battle Ahead of 2014 Midterm Elections

A recent CNN/ORC International poll has shown a significant turnaround in the battle for control of Congress in the 2014 midterm elections. The survey indicates that the Democratic Party's 50-42% advantage among registered voters in a generic ballot, which asks respondents to choose between a Democrat or Republican in their congressional district without identifying the candidates, has disappeared. The new poll shows the GOP now holding a 49-47% edge.

The 10-point swing follows a tumultuous period in American politics, marked by the government shutdown and debt ceiling debate, as well as the botched rollout of the Affordable Care Act (ACA) and controversy over insurance policy cancellations. The shift in the poll mirrors similar trends in recent national surveys from Quinnipiac University and Fox News.

According to CNN Polling Director Keating Holland, the biggest shifts towards the Republicans came among white voters, higher-income Americans, and people who live in rural areas, while Democrats have gained strength among non-white voters and lower-income Americans. If these patterns persist, it may indicate that the ACA is popular among those who it was designed to help the most, but unpopular among the larger group of voters who are personally less concerned about health insurance and health care.

The poll results are a long way from predicting the actual outcome of the 2014 midterm elections, with just under a year to go before voters cast their ballots. The survey's overall sampling error is plus or minus 3.5 percentage points.

Title: Pope Francis Criticizes Vatican Clergy for Prioritizing Power Over Spiritual Life

Pope Francis delivered his annual Christmas greeting to the cardinals, bishops, and priests of the Vatican on Monday, using the occasion to address what he called the "ailments" of the Curia, the central administration of the Holy See. In his speech, Francis criticized the clergy for prioritizing power and prestige over their spiritual lives, describing this phenomenon as "spiritual Alzheimer's."

The Pope also spoke about the "terrorism of gossip," which he said can "kill the reputation of our colleagues and brothers in cold blood." He warned that cliques can "enslave their members and become a cancer that threatens the harmony of the body," and that those who prioritize power and prestige over their spiritual lives live "typical of mediocre and progressive spiritual emptiness that no academic degree can fill."

Francis listed 15 "Ailments of the Curia," which he said can affect both individuals and the organization as a whole. The speech was met with tepid applause and few smiles from the cardinals, who may have felt that the Pope was criticizing their own practices.

The annual Christmas greeting comes at a tense time for the Curia, as Francis and his nine key cardinal advisers are working to revamp the bureaucratic structure to make it more efficient and responsive. The Pope emphasized the importance of the Curia's mission and called on it to "always improve itself and grow in communion, holiness, and knowledge."

Some cardinals may have felt that Francis was criticizing their own practices, as he has never worked in the Italian Curia before becoming Pope. Additionally, Francis has faced pushback from conservative and traditionalist bishops and cardinals who disagree with his progressive social views, such as his efforts to give remarried and divorced people the possibility of receiving communion and his views on homosexual unions.

Title: Trump's Pattern of Distortions and Falsehoods: A Persistent Phenomenon

Article:

Fred Trump, the father of the current US President, was born in New York City, with his grandfather born in Germany. This easily verifiable fact has been disputed by Trump at least three times, with him claiming his father was born in Germany when, in fact, he was not. This is just one example of Trump's tendency to bend facts to fit his narrative about himself.

Throughout his life, Trump has demonstrated a willingness to distort and manipulate facts to suit his purposes. He has a tendency to create his own reality, telling himself a story of being the hero and winner, and repeating it repeatedly. This lack of concern for objective facts is troubling, but not entirely surprising.

What is more difficult to understand is why Trump's record of distortions and falsehoods seems to have little impact on his willingness to continue lying or how people perceive him. This phenomenon can be attributed to several factors.
