Firstly, Trump's behavior is not new. He has been exaggerating, distorting, and lying throughout his 2016 presidential campaign and as President. In the 2016 election, only 33% of voters considered him "honest and trustworthy," according to exit polling. However, many voters did not seem to care about his dishonesty, with almost two-thirds of voters saying he was neither honest nor trustworthy, yet still voting for him.

Secondly, some voters may believe that all politicians lie, and Trump's over-the-top lies make him seem more genuine. They may see him as a refreshing change from the typical politician who tries to deceive them. This perception is fueled by Trump's willingness to say anything and do anything to win, making him seem more authentic.

Lastly, many people do not trust the media, and Trump has capitalized on this distrust. The rise of Fox News and its dominance in the conservative media landscape have created a political and economic model that convinces people the media is not only unfair but also intentionally dishonest. This has led to the widespread use of the term "fake news" and a refusal to engage with facts presented by the mainstream media.

In conclusion, Trump's pattern of distortions and falsehoods is a persistent phenomenon that has been evident throughout his life and presidency. Understanding the reasons behind this phenomenon, including the factors mentioned above, can help us better comprehend the complexities of Trump's behavior and its impact on American politics.

Title: DC Republicans to Vote in Non-Binding Primary, Rubio and Kasich Lead in Early Returns

Article:

The District of Columbia Republican convention, often referred to as a "primary," is underway, with Marco Rubio and John Kasich leading in early returns. The non-binding vote is not expected to award any delegates, but it will give insight into the preferences of DC Republicans. Rubio received 37.3% of the vote, followed closely by Kasich with 35.5%. Donald Trump and Ted Cruz trailed behind with 13.8% and 12.4%, respectively.

According to announced results, Rubio secured 10 delegates, while Kasich took 9. Cruz did not receive any delegates. The remaining 29 delegates will be awarded at the state convention next month.

The DC convention is a unique event, as it is not a traditional primary or caucus. The event allows registered Republicans to vote for their preferred candidate, with the goal of selecting 19 delegates to the national convention. The rules are complex, with delegates awarded proportionally to candidates meeting a 15% threshold, and a trigger that allows the winner to sweep all 19 delegates if they reach 50% plus one.

The voting process took place from 10 am to 4 pm, with voters with religious restrictions able to cast their ballots after dark. Results are expected to be announced after 9 pm.

In addition to the DC convention, there are two other races taking place today. Guam will hold a non-binding primary to select 12 delegates, but they are not bound to any candidate. Wyoming will hold county conventions to select 12 delegates, but will have another primary next month to choose the remaining 17 delegates.

Title: Biden Responds Defensively to Questions About Son's Ukraine Business Dealings

Article:

Former Vice President Joe Biden's recent response to a question about his son Hunter Biden's business dealings in Ukraine has sparked controversy and raised questions about potential conflicts of interest. At a press conference in Los Angeles, Biden was asked by CBS News reporter Bo Erickson whether his son's job with an oil company owned by an oligarch accused of corruption posed a conflict of interest for him. Biden responded defensively, stating that there was no indication of any conflict of interest and that he was not going to respond to the question.

This is not the first time Biden has been questioned about his son's Ukraine entanglements. In a previous press gaggle, he berated a journalist for asking about the matter, saying "You should be looking at Trump, ask the right question." The Trump campaign has seized on the issue, with Deputy Communications Director Matt Wolking stating that "Biden bullies the press" and that he has no good explanation for what many independent observers consider an obvious conflict of interest.

The controversy has come as House Democrats are investigating President Trump's dealings with Ukraine, which have raised concerns about corruption and potential conflicts of interest. Biden's role in the Obama administration's Ukraine policy has also been scrutinized, with allegations that he threatened to rescind Ukraine's $1 billion in loan guarantees if the government didn't oust Viktor Shokin, the country's top prosecutor, who had targeted Burisma, the oil company where Hunter Biden worked.

A recent poll found that 43% of Americans believe the allegations against Biden, which has had an impact on his primary campaign. Biden was once the clear front-runner in the Democratic primary, but he now trails Senator Elizabeth Warren in the latest polls. His fundraising has also slowed, with third-quarter figures showing he raised $15.2 million, far behind other candidates like Sanders, Warren, and Buttigieg.

Title: The United States Remains the World's Most Powerful and Indispensable Country

The article highlights the importance of the United States' continued leadership on the global stage, despite facing various challenges such as financial collapse, recession, and polarized politics. The author emphasizes that the country's economic strength is crucial to its ability to promote global peace and prosperity. The article endorses Mitt Romney for president, citing his experience, strategy, and temperament to lead a robust economic recovery and address the mounting federal debt.

The author notes that the world remains a dangerous place, with threats from international terrorism and the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction. They emphasize the importance of maintaining military strength, expanding free trade and investment, and upholding democratic principles. The article concludes that Mitt Romney's vision for American leadership is based on a consistent theme that peace abroad depends on American vitality.

Notable individuals mentioned in the article include Condoleezza Rice, James A. Baker, George P. Shultz, and Henry A. Kissinger, all of whom served as secretaries of state under various U.S. presidents.

Title: Classified Cable Warned of Benghazi Security Risks Months Before Deadly Attack

The U.S. Mission in Benghazi convened an emergency meeting less than a month before the September 11, 2012, attack that killed Ambassador Chris Stevens and three other Americans. According to a classified cable reviewed by sources, the meeting was prompted by concerns about Al Qaeda training camps in Benghazi and the consulate's inability to defend against a coordinated attack.

The August 16 cable, marked "SECRET," stated that the State Department's senior security officer, the Regional Security Officer (RSO), expressed concerns about the consulate's vulnerability to attack due to limited manpower, security measures, weapons capabilities, host nation support, and the overall size of the compound.

The cable also warned of the presence of approximately ten Islamist militias and AQ training camps within Benghazi, including groups such as the QRF Brigade and Ansar al-Sharia, which ran the spectrum from Islamist militias to "Takfirist thugs." The Emergency Action Committee, responsible for security measures and emergency planning, was briefed on these groups.

The details in the cable seemed to foreshadow the deadly September 11 attack, which was a coordinated, commando-style assault using direct and indirect fire. Al Qaeda in North Africa and Ansar al-Sharia, both mentioned in the cable, have since been implicated in the consulate attack.

The cable also warned that the intelligence was unclear on specific threats against the U.S. and cautioned that the militias in Benghazi were not concerned with any significant retaliation from the Libyan government, which had apparently lost control in Benghazi. The RSO noted that the Benghazi militias had become more brazen in their actions and had little fear of reprisal from the Libyan government.

The administration's public statements have suggested that the attack came without warning, but the August 16 cable seems to undercut those claims. It was a direct warning to the State Department that the Benghazi consulate was vulnerable to attack, that it could not be defended, and that the presence of anti-U.S. militias and Al Qaeda was well-known to the U.S. intelligence community.

In a three-page cable on September 11, Ambassador Stevens wrote about "growing problems with security" in Benghazi and "growing frustration" with the security forces and Libyan police. The ambassador saw both as "too weak to keep the country secure."

The State Department declined to comment on specific questions about the August 16 cable, citing its classified nature. An independent board is conducting a review of the assault on the U.S. post in Benghazi, and the State Department will address the matter once the board's findings and recommendations are available.

Title: Police in Nova Scotia Foil Mass Murder Plot, Raising Questions About Obama Administration's Approach to Terrorism

The recent foiled plot by two men to carry out mass murder at a shopping mall and then commit suicide has raised concerns about the Obama administration's approach to terrorism. The Associated Press reported that the plot was not related to Islamic terrorism, but the article's second paragraph sparked controversy among readers.

The article goes on to criticize the Obama administration's reluctance to acknowledge the link between terrorism and Islam, citing examples such as the beheading of 21 Coptic Christians in Libya and the slaughter of four Jews in a Paris kosher deli. The article argues that the administration's refusal to acknowledge the religious motivations behind these attacks hinders efforts to combat terrorism and understand the root causes of extremism.

The article also touches on the topic of corruption in Albany, New York, and the governor's reluctance to take action against corrupt politicians. It also mentions the recent controversy surrounding the mayor of New York City and the council speaker's defense of President Obama's immigration orders.

Overall, the article presents a critical view of the Obama administration's approach to terrorism and corruption, and highlights the need for a more nuanced understanding of the complex issues at play.

**Trump's Criticism of Congress Sparks Concern Among Senate Republicans**

Senate Republicans are urging President Donald Trump to focus on touting the accomplishments of his administration and Congress, rather than criticizing their inability to get things done. Trump has been vocal about the slow pace of legislative progress, particularly on issues like spending bills and judicial nominations.

In recent weeks, Trump has taken to Twitter to express his frustration with Congress, citing the failure to pass regular appropriations bills and the slow pace of judicial nominations. He has also criticized Congress for not making progress on immigration reform and has warned Republicans to be more critical of special counsel Robert Mueller's investigation.

Some Republicans are concerned that Trump's criticism of Congress could dampen enthusiasm among the GOP base, potentially hurting turnout in the midterm elections. Sen. Mike Rounds (R-S.D.) said that Trump's message was well-received during a meeting on Capitol Hill, but others are urging the president to focus on highlighting the accomplishments of his administration and Congress.

Sen. Lamar Alexander (R-Tenn.) has been handing out cards to constituents listing the accomplishments of the 115th Congress, including passing a $1.5 trillion tax cut and confirming 21 circuit court judges. Sen. John Hoeven (R-N.D.) gave Trump one of these cards during a meeting with the GOP conference, emphasizing the importance of rallying the base and touting accomplishments.

GOP strategists believe that Trump's criticism of Congress undermines the party's central argument in the midterm election, which is that the president needs more Republican reinforcements. They argue that Trump's approval ratings are crucial to turning out Republican voters in November.

A Gallup poll found that Trump's job approval rating reached an 11-month high at the end of April, with 42% of respondents nationwide saying they liked the job he was doing. While more people disapprove than approve of Trump's job performance, he is doing significantly better in the public's opinion than Congress, which has a 17% job approval rating.

Title: Controversy Surrounds Use of Private Jets by Government Officials

The recent revelation that Health and Human Services Secretary Tom Price used private jets for official business has sparked a heated debate about the use of private aircraft by government officials. While some have criticized Price's decision, others have pointed out that other senior officials, including Education Secretary Betsy DeVos and Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) Administrator Scott Pruitt, have also used private jets for work-related travel.

DeVos, who is independently wealthy, pays for her travel out of her own pocket, which has been deemed ethical and acceptable. Pruitt, on the other hand, has been criticized for taking four non-commercial flights, including one charter flight from Denver to D.C. However, according to a source, the charter flight was booked after a commercial flight was delayed, and Pruitt would have missed an event if he had not taken the charter flight. The other flights were government flights, including a military flight from Cincinnati to JFK, which was cleared by the EPA's office of ethics.

Fox News' John Roberts explained the relevant details and distinctions between Pruitt's flights and Price's, highlighting that the EPA administrator's actions were not comparable to Price's. Roberts noted that public officials hopping on government or military planes is a commonplace and bipartisan practice, and that the only private charter flight was a last-minute booking resulting from a lengthy commercial airline delay.

A Republican Senator was quoted as saying, "No excuses here. Can't put lipstick on a pig. It's a pig." This statement was likely referring to Price's use of private jets, which has been widely criticized. However, it is important to note that the use of private jets by government officials is not a new phenomenon, and it is not unique to the Trump administration.

In conclusion, while the use of private jets by government officials is a topic of ongoing debate, it is essential to consider the specific circumstances and context of each instance. The public's perception of these actions will likely depend on the individual circumstances and the motivations behind them.

Title: Trump Blames Washington D.C. Government for Canceling Military Parade, Officials Deny Claim

The White House announced that President Donald Trump has canceled a proposed military parade, citing the high cost and logistical concerns. However, Trump blamed the Washington D.C. government for the decision, claiming that local officials wanted a "ridiculously high" price tag. The city's mayor, Muriel Bowser, denied this claim, stating that the estimated cost was $21.6 million, closer to the administration's initial projection of $12 million.

Pentagon officials revealed that the actual cost of the parade would be $92 million, $80 million more than the original estimate. Trump took to Twitter to express his frustration, stating that the local politicians who run Washington D.C. "know a windfall when they see it" and that he was forced to cancel the parade due to the high cost.

The city's mayor and chief of staff, Muriel Bowser and John J. Falcicchio, respectively, responded to Trump's claims, with Bowser calling the proposed parade a "significant concern for taxpayers" and Falcicchio labeling Trump's claim that the city is "poorly run" as "fake news." The city's bond rating has recently been upgraded to AAA.

The Pentagon stated that the Department of Defense and White House had been planning a parade to honor America's military veterans and commemorate the centennial of World War I, but have now agreed to explore opportunities in 2019. The American Legion also weighed in, suggesting that the parade money would be better spent fully funding the Department of Veterans Affairs and giving troops and their families the best care possible.

Trump has announced that he will attend a smaller parade already scheduled for Joint Base Andrews and a November 11 parade in Paris to mark the 100th anniversary of the end of World War I.

Title: Missouri Senate Race Remains Toss-Up as McCaskill's Vote Against Kavanaugh Has Little Impact

Article: A recent opinion poll conducted by Ipsos/UVA Center for Politics found that the Missouri Senate race between Democratic Senator Claire McCaskill and Republican challenger Josh Hawley remains a toss-up, with McCaskill trailing by just one percentage point. The poll surveyed likely voters in Missouri and found that 44% would support McCaskill, while 45% would back Hawley.

The poll also showed that McCaskill's vote against Supreme Court Justice Brett Kavanaugh's confirmation may not have had a significant impact on her re-election chances. While 44% of likely voters said they were more likely to support her because of her opposition to Kavanaugh, 46% said they were less likely. Political analyst Kyle Kondik noted that "Kavanaugh may not have changed any minds" in the state, as those who were already inclined to support McCaskill were likely to do so regardless.

The poll also found that the Supreme Court was not a top priority for likely voters in Missouri, with healthcare, the economy, and immigration being more important issues. Sixty-nine percent of respondents said they were "very motivated" to support a candidate who would "defend laws that protect healthcare for people with pre-existing conditions," which could be a challenge for Hawley, who has said he wants to protect people with pre-existing conditions despite joining a multi-state effort to repeal the Affordable Care Act.

In a separate poll, Illinois Democratic gubernatorial candidate J.B. Pritzker was found to be holding a 20-percentage-point lead over Republican incumbent Bruce Rauner. The race is on track to be the most expensive governor's election in U.S. history, with nearly $249.7 million raised so far.

The Missouri and Illinois polls were conducted online in English from September 27 to October 7 and surveyed between 968 and 1,111 likely voters. The results measured how voters felt at the time of the survey, and those feelings may change before Election Day.

Title: Language Divide: A Growing Chasm in American Politics

The article discusses the increasing polarization of language in American politics, citing examples from recent events and opinions expressed by columnists. The author, Ben Shapiro, argues that the deliberate misuse of language is a key factor in tearing the country apart.

According to Shapiro, the story of the Tower of Babel in the Bible illustrates the importance of shared language in unity. However, in the United States, language is becoming a source of division. The article highlights the controversy surrounding President Donald Trump's use of the word "lynching" to describe the impeachment process, which was met with denunciations from politicians like former Vice President Joe Biden.

Shapiro notes that Biden himself used the same language in 1998 to describe the Clinton impeachment, but later condemned himself for it. The author argues that Trump's use of the word "lynching" was deliberate and intended to liken himself to black victims of white supremacist violence.

The article also touches on the debate surrounding gender pronouns, stating that the deliberate confusion fostered by some individuals is a sign of a "delusional culture." Shapiro believes that refusing to define terms is a method of impugning others and that the refusal to define terms is a key factor in the growing divide.

The article concludes by stating that the deliberate misuse of language is a key factor in tearing the country apart and that the refusal to define terms is a method of impugning others.

Title: Whistleblower Complaint Alleges Trump's Communications with Foreign Officials Moved to Separate Network

A whistleblower complaint has revealed that White House officials moved records of some of President Donald Trump's communications with foreign officials onto a separate computer network, according to reports by the Washington Post. The complaint, which was publicly released, alleges that Trump's transcript with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky was placed on a computer system managed by the National Security Council Directorate for Intelligence Programs.

The whistleblower also claimed that this was not the first time a presidential transcript was placed into the system "solely for the purpose of protecting politically sensitive – rather than national security sensitive – information." The complaint further alleges that Trump is using the power of his office to solicit foreign interference in the U.S. election.

In response to the allegations, Trump defended his July phone call with Ukraine's president, stating that there was "no pressure" on him as a summary showed Trump urging his counterpart to open a probe related to former Vice President Joe Biden. House Speaker Nancy Pelosi announced the opening of an impeachment inquiry on Tuesday.

The White House press secretary, Stephanie Grisham, responded to the allegations, stating that the complaint is "nothing more than a collection of third-hand accounts of events and cobbled-together press clippings – all of which show nothing improper." The White House has released the full, unredacted, and declassified transcript of Trump's call with Zelensky, which forms the heart of the complaint, and has denied any wrongdoing.

Title: "Finding Common Ground: A Journey Across the Political Divide"

The article by Arlie Russell Hochschild, author of "Strangers in Their Own Land: Anger and Mourning on the American Right," explores the growing divide between Republicans and Democrats in the United States. Hochschild, a liberal living in Berkeley, California, spent years venturing into conservative areas, including Lake Charles, Louisiana, to understand the perspectives of those who voted for Donald Trump. She returned to Louisiana three times after her book's publication and invited some of her contacts to her home to discuss their feelings about Trump's presidency.

The article highlights the significant differences between Democrats and Republicans on various issues, citing a Pew survey that shows a growing gap between the two parties. However, Hochschild also notes that despite these differences, there are signs of a grassroots movement seeking to remove the bitter edge from the political divide.

The author shares her own experiences with "Living-room Conversations," a project that brings together people from different political backgrounds to discuss common goals and find common ground. She recounts a conversation with a Trump supporter who expressed embarrassment over Trump's comments on African nations, but also defended him against criticism on Facebook. Hochschild notes that even among the most extreme individuals she met, she found specific issues on which there was potential for coalition-building.

The article concludes by highlighting the importance of reaching out to those with whom we disagree and finding ways to restore a culture of respect. Hochschild notes that while the act of crossing the partisan divide alone will not resolve the crisis, it could help rebuild a nation where people feel connected to one another again.

Title: FDA Approves New Treatments for Sickle Cell Disease and Cancer, Investors Eye Experimental Therapies

The Food and Drug Administration (FDA) has approved two new treatments for sickle cell disease, reinvigorating interest in the therapeutic area. The approvals have led to a surge in clinical data presentations at the American Society of Hematology's annual meeting in Orlando, Florida. The meeting focused on companies developing products that aim to address the needs of patients with sickle cell disease and cancer.

Novartis' Adakveo and Oxbryta, developed by Global Blood Therapeutics, have been approved for treating sickle cell disease. The wholesale list prices for both drugs are around $10,000 per month. Analysts are paying close attention to data for Bluebird Bio's investigational gene therapy for sickle cell disease, which showed a reduction in vaso-occlusive crises and acute chest syndrome in some patients.

The CAR-T therapy field is also gaining attention, with several companies developing products. Bluebird Bio plans to initiate a Phase 3 trial next year after releasing positive data for LentiGlobin in a Phase 1/2 study. The therapy showed a reduction in vaso-occlusive crises and acute chest syndrome in some patients. Shares of Bluebird Bio were up 10% in afternoon trading on Tuesday.

Other companies, such as Bristol-Myers Squibb and Johnson & Johnson, are also developing CAR-T therapies. The currently available CAR-T therapies are expensive, with prices ranging from $373,000 to $475,000. Some experimental therapies are hoping to capitalize on the costs associated with CAR-T treatment.

The headlining deal in hematology is Merck's $2.7 billion buyout of ArQule, a biopharmaceutical company developing treatments for cancer and rare diseases. The deal will add ArQule's mid-stage therapeutic candidate, ARG 531, a Bruton's tyrosine kinase (BTK) inhibitor, to Merck's high-performing oncology portfolio.

Title: Clinton Leads in Unseen Battle for Superdelegates in Democratic Primary

The Democratic primary race between Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders is heating up, with the two candidates vying for the support of party insiders known as superdelegates. According to the latest Associated Press survey, Clinton has an overwhelming lead among these party insiders, with 449 superdelegates, or about 63 percent, currently supporting her. In contrast, only 19 superdelegates back Sanders.

The superdelegate advantage is not only a significant lead for Clinton but also a notable gain, as her total has jumped 90 delegates since the AP's November survey. Sanders, on the other hand, has risen 11 delegates, from eight to 19.

The superdelegate system, which was created in 1982 to give party insiders more influence and reduce the power of "activists," has been a point of contention among Sanders supporters. Some have taken to contacting superdelegates, urging them to "back the will of the voters" and not support Clinton. A petition on MoveOn.org, which has garnered over 161,000 signatures, argues that the race should be decided by who gets the most votes, not who has the most support from party insiders.

However, the superdelegate system was designed to promote a sense of unity and give party insiders a say in the nomination process. Brookings Institution's Thomas Mann and AEI's Norman Ornstein wrote in 2008 that the system is a "sort of peer review" to choose the most electable candidate and promotes stronger ties between the party and its elected officials.

While some superdelegates may have to be re-elected themselves at some point, they remain unbound, even if they've chosen a candidate already. This means that if the race swings heavily in Sanders' favor, some superdelegates who are currently backing Clinton could always switch their support.

Title: Trump Gives McMaster Vote of Confidence Amid NSC Shakeup

President Donald Trump has expressed his support for National Security Adviser H.R. McMaster, despite recent controversies surrounding McMaster's actions. The controversy centers around a letter McMaster sent to his predecessor, Susan Rice, granting her continued access to classified information. McMaster's supporters have described the letter as routine, while others have seized on it to imply that the Army lieutenant general is helping Trump's enemies.

In a statement, Trump praised McMaster, stating, "General McMaster and I are working very well together. He is a good man and very pro-Israel. I am grateful for the work he continues to do serving our country." The statement comes amid a series of firings by McMaster on the National Security Council, including the ousting of Ezra Cohen-Watnick, the senior director for intelligence.

The controversy surrounding McMaster's letter to Rice has sparked tensions within the White House, with some administration officials viewing the move as a betrayal. However, National Security Council sources have clarified that the letter was a standard document, similar to those sent to every living former national security adviser and former president, and that it does not grant Rice access to classified information. Instead, it allows her to be called back in to discuss classified information if necessary.

The recent firings on the National Security Council have been well-documented, with Rich Higgins, director for strategic planning, and Derek Harvey, top Middle East adviser, being relieved of their duties. The changes come as the White House has seen a number of other high-profile staff changes, including the resignation of chief of staff Reince Priebus and the departure of press secretary Sean Spicer.

Title: Pelosi's Opposition to Trump's Shutdown Proposals Boosts Her Popularity

Article:

House Speaker Nancy Pelosi has been a vocal opponent of President Donald Trump's proposals to reopen the government, citing his insistence on allocating $5.7 billion for a border wall as an "immorality." According to recent polling, her stance has boosted her popularity among Democrats, with her favorability rating jumping 13 points to 72% among her party members.

The shutdown, now the longest in U.S. history, has also seen Pelosi emerge as a strong leader, with a CBS News poll showing that more Americans want Trump to give up on wall funding than prefer congressional Democrats agreeing to it. Additionally, a majority of Americans believe Pelosi is handling negotiations better than the president.

Pelosi's opposition to Trump's proposals has been unwavering, with her refusing to compromise on the issue. This stance has earned her the loyalty of her entire caucus, with Democrats unified in their opposition to the president's demands.

While some may question Pelosi's willingness to work with progressive Democrats, her recent performance against Trump has solidified her position as a resolute obstructionist. Her ability to withstand pressure and maintain her stance has impressed many, including those who may have been skeptical of her leadership in the past.

As the shutdown continues, Pelosi's determination to stand firm against Trump's proposals has become a defining moment in her career. Her refusal to compromise has shown that she is willing to take a stand, even in the face of intense pressure. This has earned her the respect of many, including those who may have been critical of her leadership in the past.

For now, Pelosi's opposition to Trump's shutdown proposals has become a key factor in her rising popularity. As the shutdown continues, it remains to be seen how her leadership will be perceived in the long term.

**Political Violence and Confrontations Escalate Against Media and Politicians**

A recent incident in which a mob of left-wing antifa activists descended on Fox News personality Tucker Carlson's home in Washington D.C. has highlighted the growing trend of political violence and confrontations targeting the news media and politicians. This escalation in political tensions has been ongoing since 2012, according to the Global Terrorism Database, with activists increasingly pushing political confrontation to the limit.

The antifa group, which stands for anti-fascist, has anarchist leanings and targets anyone perceived as not in line with a far-left agenda. The group's chant outside Carlson's home, "Tucker Carlson, we will fight. We know where you sleep at night!" highlights the level of aggression and intimidation tactics used by these activists.

This incident is not an isolated event, as political violence has been on the rise in the United States. Capitol police have seen a surge in protective details assigned to lawmakers, particularly since the confirmation of Supreme Court Justice Brett M. Kavanaugh. Senators have been receiving death threats and have been forced to take extra security measures to ensure their safety.

The threats have extended beyond politicians, with journalists and others entering the political arena also receiving threats. Christine Blasey Ford, a California psychology professor who testified against Justice Kavanaugh during his confirmation hearings, is still receiving death threats and has been unable to return to work. Former IRS official Lois G. Lerner is also still receiving threats stemming from her role in the tea party targeting scandal.

Experts attribute the rise in political violence to a perceived threat to democratic norms and a lack of dialogue or compromise. Some extremists on both the left and right are using violence as a means to achieve their goals, citing perceived threats to their values or beliefs.

The incident at Carlson's home is not the first time the antifa group has targeted a journalist. They have previously attacked reporters covering demonstrations, such as during the "Unite the Right 2" rally in August. Fox News executives have condemned the incident, calling it "reprehensible" and "unacceptable."

The incident highlights the need for a more civil and respectful national conversation, with those in the media and politics bearing a special obligation to find common ground and promote inclusivity.

Title: Democrats in North Carolina Seek to Mitigate Damage from Party Scandal

The Obama campaign and top national and North Carolina Democrats are taking steps to protect their candidates and the president's reelection bid from the fallout of a sexual harassment scandal that has rocked the North Carolina Democratic Party. The controversy surrounds the resignation of the party's former executive director, Jay Parmley, who was accused of misconduct by a young male employee.

Despite the challenges, Democrats believe they can work around the current chairman, David Parker, who has managed to keep his position despite calls for his ouster. Parker's focus is reportedly on shoring up his own political position and reaching out to local activists, leaving room for other national and state Democrats to take charge of the situation.

Discussions are underway to set up a coordinated campaign apparatus between national and state Democrats for high-profile state campaigns, including the governor's race and congressional races. While the state party will be involved, campaigns say they expect to be able to work with competent staff members to navigate around the controversy.

One knowledgeable North Carolina Democratic operative characterized Parker's involvement as limited, stating that he is focused on internal party politics and the upcoming state convention on June 16. The operative noted that Parker's participation in the day-to-day workings of coordinated campaigns is diminished.

Gary Pearce, a veteran North Carolina Democratic strategist, said the Obama campaign appears to be committed to working in North Carolina and believes they can work around Parker. However, he noted that it may be difficult to trust Parker with large sums of money due to the scandal.

Title: House Intelligence Committee Chairman Prepared to Sue Trump Administration Over Mueller Report

The House Intelligence Committee chairman, Adam Schiff, stated on Sunday that he is "absolutely" prepared to sue the Trump administration and subpoena Special Counsel Robert Mueller if the Mueller report is not made public. Schiff, a California Democrat, emphasized that the committee will "obviously" subpoena the report and bring Mueller in to testify before Congress. He also expressed willingness to take the matter to court if necessary.

Schiff believes that the Justice Department understands that they will have to make the report public in the end. He emphasized that the report should be shared with the public and that if President Trump is serious about his claims of exoneration, he should welcome the publication of the report.

The Mueller report, which is expected to be released soon, is an investigation into possible Russia interference in the 2016 presidential campaign. The Justice Department is not required to release the document to the public, but Schiff is determined to make the findings public.

Schiff stated that Mueller has a responsibility to report the findings and that if the president cannot be indicted, the only remedy for improper or illegal conduct is impeachment. He also noted that Attorney General William Barr would be under immense pressure to publish the report, as withholding or burying any part of it would tarnish his legacy.

In summary, Schiff is prepared to take all necessary steps to ensure the public has access to the Mueller report, including suing the Trump administration and subpoenaing Mueller.

Title: House Freedom Caucus Calls for Economy to be Reopened, Citing Economic Woes and Job Losses

The House Freedom Caucus has sent a letter to President Donald Trump, urging the reopening of the economy as businesses across the country continue to struggle. The letter was signed by 12 Republican representatives, including Andy Biggs, Jody Hice, Ron Wright, and others.

The letter states that the American people have suffered greatly under the weight of the closed economy, with measures enacted by Congress providing limited relief. The representatives argue that more government intervention is not the solution, and instead, reopening the economy is the key to its recovery. They note that tens of millions of Americans have lost their jobs and many businesses have had to close due to the measures implemented to combat the virus.

The letter also acknowledges that all levels of government have imposed measures to slow the spread of the outbreak, and that the American people have responded to the guidelines. However, the representatives argue that these measures have had a devastating impact on the economy, causing widespread job losses and business closures.

The letter comes as Democrats in the Senate blocked a request by Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell for an additional $250 billion in aid for small businesses. The bill was met with opposition from Democratic Senators Ben Cardin and Chris Van Hollen, who argued that it did not address the immediate needs of small businesses.

Members of Congress are working on legislation to fund small businesses, but the full House and Senate are not expected to return to Washington, D.C. until May 4, making it challenging to pass legislation quickly.

Title: Market Forces May Solve California's Housing Shortage through Office Space Conversion

The concept of a market-based solution to California's housing shortage is gaining traction, with new evidence emerging almost daily. This approach does not involve politicians, but rather the natural market forces of supply and demand. The idea is to convert office space into housing, specifically high-rise apartments and condominiums, but not in new buildings. Instead, existing office towers will be repurposed to accommodate the changing needs of the workforce.

As the COVID-19 pandemic has shown, many white-collar businesses are no longer requiring large office spaces. With the option to work from home, companies like Facebook and Twitter have told their employees to continue working remotely. Others are allowing employees to come into the office one or two days a week. This shift has led to a surplus of office space, with "for lease" signs proliferating in urban areas.

Lease holders who once clamored for more space are now looking for ways to escape their commitments. With state emergency rules allowing tenants to delay payments during the pandemic, some are refusing to pay rent, and others are working out deferred payment deals with their landlords. If they don't pay up or come to an agreement, they will be evicted.

As the pandemic has shown, many workers will opt to stay home most of the time, not just because it's a preference, but because it's necessary. State guidelines for reopening public schools, for example, have created a need for continued virtual commuting. This reality is reflected in recent home pricing figures from San Francisco and its suburbs, where demand is up in areas like Marin, Napa, Santa Cruz, and Monterey counties, but down in San Francisco itself.

As a result, realtors in suburban areas are seeing steady demand, with many would-be buyers being the same people who once worked in office towers but now operate from home. As their bosses tell them they can keep working remotely, some are seeking more spacious quarters and a less urban environment.

The market-based solution is already taking shape, with entire floors of high-rise buildings expected to go vacant and remain empty for significant periods. Once building owners realize that new lessees won't be forthcoming, they'll opt for other ways to monetize their buildings, converting much of the empty floor space to condos and apartments. These will likely come in all sizes and price levels, from large ocean-and mountain-view units to small apartments on the lower floors. Some buildings will have mixed use, with stores on the ground floor and other levels shared by offices and dwelling units. Zoning changes will be inevitable.

In the next five years, market forces will solve the housing shortage, creating vast numbers of units, many of them very affordable.

Title: Human Rights Watch Reports Evidence of Ukrainian Government Forces Using Cluster Munitions in Eastern Ukraine

Human Rights Watch, a New York-based watchdog group, has released a report detailing the suspected use of cluster munitions by Ukrainian government forces fighting pro-Russian separatists in eastern Ukraine. The report, released on Monday, claims that the weapon, banned in much of the world, was used in over 12 locations in the region, killing at least six people and wounding dozens.

According to the report, the attacks may amount to war crimes, and Ukrainian authorities have been urged to make an immediate commitment to not use cluster munitions and join the treaty to ban them. The watchdog group found signs of cluster munitions attacks in more than 12 locations in eastern Ukraine, where over 3,700 people have been killed in fighting since April.

A New York Times investigation also found physical evidence of cluster munitions fired by Ukrainian forces into Donetsk, supported by interviews with witnesses and victims. The allegations could undermine the fragile cease-fire signed by Ukrainian President Petro Poroshenko and pro-Russian rebels in September and jeopardize long-term peace negotiations in the area.

Ukrainian military officials have denied the accusations, while rebels have not commented. The use of cluster munitions by the Ukrainian government could add credibility to Moscow's version of the conflict, which claims that the Ukrainian national government is engaged in a punitive war against its own citizens.

The Convention on Cluster Munitions, an international treaty that bans the stockpile or use of the weapons, has been signed by 114 countries. Ukraine, along with Russia and the US, has not joined the treaty.

Title: Electoral College Scheme to Block Trump's Presidency Faces Skepticism

The article discusses the idea that some Democrats are attempting to persuade Republican electors to deny Donald Trump the presidency, citing concerns about his fitness for office. The scheme, which involves trying to convince 37 Republican electors to flip their votes, is seen as a desperate attempt to overturn the results of the election. The article quotes E.J. Dionne, a liberal columnist, who argues that Trump's presidency would be a threat to the country and that conscientious electors might decide he is unfit for the role. Kathleen Parker, a moderate conservative columnist, adds that the Founding Fathers created the Electoral College as a "braking system" to prevent a president like Trump from taking office.

The article notes that the Electoral College vote is a technicality, with electors expected to support the candidate who won their state. While some electors may cast protest votes, the idea of persuading a large number of electors to switch their votes is seen as a long shot. The article concludes that the debate surrounding the Electoral College is revealing, highlighting the differing opinions on the role of the institution and the qualifications of the president.

Title: Former US Ambassador Nikki Haley Praises Trump's Decision to Kill Iran's Top General, Claims Democrats Are Mourning Soleimani

Article:

Former US Ambassador to the United Nations Nikki Haley praised President Donald Trump's decision to order the drone strike that killed Iran's top general, Qasem Soleimani, last week. During an appearance on Fox News, Haley stated that the president showed "great decisiveness" and "great resolve" in taking out Soleimani, who was responsible for the deaths of hundreds of American service members.

Haley also claimed that the only ones mourning Soleimani's death are Trump's domestic political opponents, stating that "you don't see anyone standing up for Iran. You're not hearing any of the Gulf members. You're not hearing China. You're not hearing Russia." Her comments were met with criticism from several commentators, who called her statement "ridiculous," "inflammatory," and "dangerous."

Democrats have questioned the wisdom of killing Soleimani and whether the Trump administration fully considered the potential consequences before taking action. Many have stressed that Soleimani was responsible for thousands of deaths and that they were not sad to see him go. Former Vice President Joe Biden, for example, stated that Soleimani "deserved to be brought to justice for his crimes against American troops and thousands of innocents throughout the region."

Several Democratic presidential candidates have also weighed in on the issue. Senator Elizabeth Warren called Soleimani a "murderer" responsible for the deaths of thousands, including hundreds of Americans, but stated that the decision to kill him was a "reckless move" that escalates the situation with Iran. Senator Tim Kaine introduced a resolution requiring congressional approval for further military action against Iran, and House Speaker Nancy Pelosi said the House would vote on a similar resolution this week.

The article also notes that the US estimates Soleimani and the Iran Revolutionary Guard were responsible for killing more than 600 American service members in Iraq following the 2003 invasion.

Title: Media Blame Game: Assessing Responsibility for Trump's Rise

The media's role in the rise of Donald Trump's presidential campaign has been a topic of debate, with some attributing his success to the press's coverage and others pointing to his own efforts. A recent issue of Politico Magazine features a collection of essays exploring this topic, with some writers arguing that the media has given Trump too much attention and others claiming that he has exploited the media's desire for ratings.

One of the most notable pieces is written by Campbell Brown, a former CNN and NBC anchor, who argues that TV news has given Trump too much control over the narrative. She claims that TV networks have prioritized ratings over real reporting, allowing Trump to dictate the terms of his coverage. Brown notes that Trump's rallies received extensive live coverage, giving him an unfair advantage over his competitors.

However, others argue that Trump's success is not solely the result of media coverage. Trump's detractors point out that he has seized much of the "free" airtime by doing many more interviews than his rivals and driving the campaign dialogue. Many reporters have dug deep into Trump's businesses, rhetoric, and promises, but these stories have done little to dent his lead.

The article also highlights the fact that Trump's supporters do not trust the press, which has led him to punch back hard, especially on Twitter. Additionally, many conservative and liberal commentators have criticized Trump, which has only fueled his supporters' distrust of the media.

In conclusion, while there is much to criticize in the media's coverage of Trump, it is unfair to say that the media were the engine that powered his candidacy. Trump's success is the result of his own efforts to connect with millions of Republican voters, as well as his ability to exploit the media's desire for ratings.

Title: US to Open Jerusalem Embassy in May, Coinciding with Israel's 70th Anniversary

The United States Department of State has announced that a new American embassy in Jerusalem will open in May, coinciding with Israel's 70th anniversary. The move marks a significant development in the long-standing Israeli-Palestinian conflict, with the US recognizing Jerusalem as Israel's capital and moving its embassy from Tel Aviv.

The decision was announced by the US Department of State, stating that the embassy will initially be located at existing consular facilities in the Arnona district of the city. The move is seen as a significant departure from the US's previous stance on the issue, with the country's neutrality on the status of Jerusalem.

The decision has been met with mixed reactions, with a senior Palestinian official, Saeb Erekat, calling it a "blatant provocation." Erekat stated that the move "reflects their total insensitivities to what goes on in this region" and "reaffirms our position that the US can no longer be part of the peace process." He added that the US administration has become "part of the problem and not part of the solution."

On the other hand, Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu hailed the decision as a "great day for the people of Israel," thanking President Trump for his leadership and friendship. The move is seen as a significant victory for Netanyahu's government, which has long advocated for the recognition of Jerusalem as Israel's capital.

The status of Jerusalem is a highly contested issue, with Israel regarding it as its "eternal and undivided" capital, while the Palestinians claim East Jerusalem as the capital of a future state. The city is also home to sites sacred to the three major monotheistic faiths - Judaism, Islam, and Christianity - and Israeli sovereignty over the city has never been recognized internationally.

The UN passed a resolution in 2017 declaring any decisions regarding the status of the city "null and void" and insisting on its cancellation. The resolution was backed by 128 states, with 35 abstaining and nine voting against.

The sudden change in the timeline for the embassy's opening has been seen by some as a deliberate snub to Palestinians, with the US Vice-President Mike Pence stating that the move would occur sometime before the end of 2019. The exact date of the opening has now been confirmed as May, coinciding with Israel's 70th anniversary.

Title: Trump Allies and Democrats Clash Over Russia Investigation as Mueller Report Looms

Article:

A contentious congressional hearing on Thursday saw Republican allies of President Donald Trump clash with one of his most prominent Democratic critics, Adam Schiff, over the Russia investigation. The hearing was marked by heated exchanges and accusations, as the U.S. attorney general revealed that Special Counsel Robert Mueller's Russia inquiry report is over 300 pages long.

The report's summary, released by Attorney General William Barr, concluded that Mueller did not establish that Trump's campaign conspired with Russia in the 2016 election. However, the full report remains under wraps, with Barr agreeing to testify before the House Judiciary Committee, although no date has been set.

The dispute between Trump and Schiff escalated after the president called for Schiff to resign from Congress, citing Schiff's comments about the Trump campaign's interactions with Russia. Schiff fired back, calling the actions of Trump's associates "unpatriotic and corrupt."

House Speaker Nancy Pelosi defended Schiff, calling the actions of Trump and committee Republicans "shameful" and "irresponsible." The House has passed a resolution calling for the Mueller report to be made public, while Senate Republicans thwarted a similar effort.

The Justice Department official said Barr would issue a public version of the report within "weeks, not months." However, top Senate Democrat Chuck Schumer criticized the delay, saying it had "too much of the odor of political expediency to help the man who appointed him, President Trump."

Pelosi also demanded the report's release, saying, "No, thank you, Mr. Attorney General. We do not need your interpretation. Show us the report and we'll come to our own conclusions."

The hearing was marked by a tense exchange between Schiff and Republican committee members, who accused him of spreading "false information" and called for him to resign. Schiff responded by citing a list of Trump campaign contacts with Russians, including Donald Trump Jr.'s welcome of a Russian offer of "dirt" on Democratic rival Hillary Clinton.

The investigation, led by Mueller, brought charges against 34 people, including Russian agents and former Trump aides. The report left unresolved the question of whether Trump committed obstruction of justice by impeding the Russia investigation and did not exonerate the president. Barr concluded there was insufficient evidence to establish that Trump had committed obstruction of justice.

The House Intelligence Committee has been bitterly divided along party lines for years on the Russia investigation, with Republicans wrapping up their investigation a year ago, finding no collusion between Trump and Moscow. The committee's Democrats, led by Schiff, blasted the announcement as premature.

Title: US Diplomat Testifies Trump Linked Military Aid to Ukraine to Investigation of Political Rival

A top US diplomat, Ambassador Bill Taylor, has testified before an impeachment inquiry that President Trump made the release of military aid to Ukraine conditional on a pledge that a political rival would be investigated. According to Taylor, Trump wanted Ukraine to probe ex-Vice President Joe Biden's dealings. Taylor stated that relations with Ukraine had been "fundamentally undermined" due to an "irregular, informal channel of US policy-making" and the withholding of vital security assistance for domestic political reasons.

Taylor's testimony corroborates other reported accounts of White House efforts to get Ukraine to open investigations that could be damaging to Democrats, and Vice President Joe Biden in particular. The acting ambassador to Ukraine fleshed out the picture, adding new perspective to the ongoing impeachment inquiry.

Taylor's remarks appear to contradict earlier statements by White House officials, including Energy Secretary Rick Perry and Ambassador to the EU Gordon Sondland, who denied any knowledge of a quid pro quo. However, Taylor's testimony provides a detailed account of the events, including a conversation he had with Sondland, where he was told that everything, including military aid and a White House visit, was dependent on the Ukrainian president making a public statement that he would order investigations.

The impeachment inquiry is ongoing, with three committees in the Democratic-controlled House of Representatives investigating allegations of wrongdoing by the president. Democrats accuse Trump of illegally pressuring Ukraine to dig up dirt on a political rival, while Trump denies any wrongdoing. If the House finds sufficient evidence, articles of impeachment will be put to a vote, and if approved, proceedings will move to trial in the Senate.

Title: California and New York Leasing Hotel Rooms for Homeless People, Including Those Released from Jail, to Combat COVID-19 Spread

California and New York have become the first states to experiment with leasing hotel rooms for homeless people, including those released from jail, in an effort to limit the spread of COVID-19. The initiative aims to provide a safe and isolated environment for individuals who are vulnerable to the virus, particularly those living in crowded homeless encampments.

The Alameda County Sheriff's Office in Oakland, California, has leased 393 rooms in two hotels near the airport, with hundreds of people already being housed. The hotels, a Comfort Inn and Suites and the Radisson Hotel at the Oakland Airport, began taking in guests on March 25. The county officials did not release a count of how many people are currently in the hotels or how many among them were released from jail.

The initiative is part of an emergency response to the pandemic, which has prompted law enforcement officials to make difficult decisions to prevent outbreaks in crowded jails. Some agencies have released thousands of people early, but when they leave, where do they go? Cities are trying to find answers, and some metropolitan areas are leasing hotel rooms to provide a safe haven for homeless people, including those released from jail.

California is particularly affected by the homelessness crisis, with an estimated 150,000 homeless individuals, driven by soaring home prices, a housing shortage, and lack of access to mental health care. The state has secured 7,000 hotel rooms so far, with local governments allowed to house particularly vulnerable people, like homeless prisoners.

Advocates for the homeless are hopeful about the initiative, saying it will save lives by providing a safe and isolated environment. "Being placed in a motel room means having your own living space, your own shower, your own bed, and it allows you to self-isolate," said Eve Garrow, a homelessness policy analyst and advocate for the ACLU of Southern California.

The experiment is being closely watched, with other counties throughout the state, including San Diego and San Francisco, starting lease negotiations. San Francisco's public defender, Mano Raju, estimates 20 to 30 percent of the local jail population does not have anywhere to live, emphasizing the need for housing solutions.

The Alameda County Sheriff's Office hopes its plan can serve as a blueprint for other jurisdictions struggling to safely release people from jails. "People should be looking to California," said Sgt. Ray Kelly, the sheriff's spokesman. "We have a week ahead of a lot of other jurisdictions. They don't need to reinvent the wheel on this."

Title: Administration Proposes Charging "Event Management" Costs for Protests and Closing 80% of White House Sidewalks

The Trump administration has introduced a proposal to charge "event management" costs for demonstrations and close 80% of the sidewalks surrounding the White House. The plan, introduced by Interior Secretary Ryan Zinke in August, aims to recoup costs for special events, including erecting barriers, cleaning fees, repairs to grass, permit fees, and salaries of official personnel monitoring demonstrations. These costs would be tallied at the discretion of the police.

The proposal has raised concerns among civil liberties groups, who argue that it is an affront to the rights guaranteed under the First Amendment. The American Civil Liberties Union (ACLU) notes that such fees could make mass protests like the 1963 March on Washington and its "I Have a Dream" speech too expensive to happen.

During the Vietnam War, the federal government attempted to impose similar barriers to citizens freely assembling in protest and were sued by the ACLU. The courts ruled that the use of parks for public assembly and airing of opinions is historic in our democratic society and one of its cardinal values. The White House sidewalk, Lafayette Park, and the Ellipse were deemed unique sites for the exercise of those rights, and therefore, the government could not "accord deference to an executive approach to use of the White House sidewalk that is rooted in a bias against expressive conduct."

The National Park Service has justified the proposal by pointing out that large protests, like the Women's March, overtax their abilities and place a heavy cost on the government. However, some argue that when it comes to preserving our right to protest, no cost is too high.

The public has until October 15 to comment on the plans.

Title: The True Cost of Filling Up: A Surprising Look at Gas Prices Across the US

The conventional wisdom is that the Southeast is the cheapest region for gasoline, while the Northeast is among the most expensive. However, a new study by GasBuddy reveals that the true cost of filling up is more complex than that. The study analyzed average gasoline consumption, local wages, and gas prices to determine the number of hours of work required to fill up for a year.

According to the study, several states in the Southeast, which are usually considered cheap, are surprisingly expensive. Mississippi, for example, has the second-lowest average price per gallon, but requires an average of 100.3 hours of work to pay for a year's worth of gas, making it the fifth most expensive state. On the other hand, Hawaii, which has the highest average price per gallon, is actually the 11th cheapest state, requiring an average of 80.4 hours of work to pay for a year's worth of gas.

The study found that people living in most Northeast states need the fewest number of hours worked to pay for their gas. Massachusetts is the cheapest state, requiring only 66.8 hours, followed by Connecticut, Maryland, New York, Rhode Island, and Delaware.

One reason for the disparity is that people in the Northeast tend to drive less, with more mass transit options available. Some states that have a high cost per gallon also rank as the most expensive when measured by the number of hours worked to pay for a year's worth of gas. Nevada, for example, requires the most hours worked at 107.7, meaning Nevadans are spending over a full 40-hour workweek more on gas than Massachusetts motorists.

Here is the full list of states, ranked by the number of hours the average person needs to work to afford a year of gas, according to GasBuddy:

1. Nevada - 107.7
2. Montana - 107.4
3. Idaho - 107.1
4. South Dakota - 101.4
5. Mississippi - 100.3
6. Oregon - 100.1
7. West Virginia - 98.8
8. Arkansas - 98.2
9. Utah - 97.0
10. California - 95.5
11. Kentucky - 94.8
12. Indiana - 94.4
13. Nebraska - 93.2
14. Oklahoma - 92.9
15. Wyoming - 92.7
16. Michigan - 92.4
17. New Mexico - 92.4
18. Alaska - 92.1
19. Louisiana - 91.4
20. Arizona - 91.1
21. Alabama - 91.0
22. South Carolina - 91.0
23. North Dakota - 90.8
24. Maine - 90.6
25. Kansas - 90.5
26. Tennessee - 90.4
27. Iowa - 89.7
28. Missouri - 89.1
29. Wisconsin - 89.0
30. Pennsylvania - 86.6
31. Ohio - 88.1
32. North Carolina - 88.1
33. Florida - 88.1
34. Georgia - 88.1
35. Illinois - 87.9
36. Texas - 86.5
37. Washington - 84.9
38. Vermont - 82.9
39. New Hampshire - 82.7
40. Hawaii - 80.4

The study highlights the importance of considering local wages and driving habits when evaluating the true cost of filling up.

Title: Former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton Warns Against Unrestricted Gun Ownership

Article: Former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton recently addressed the National Council for Behavioral Health conference in Maryland, expressing concerns about the idea that "anybody can have a gun anywhere, anytime." Clinton believes this mindset is not in the best interest of the majority of citizens, stating, "I think again we're way out of balance. I think that we've got to rein in what has become an almost article of faith that anybody can have a gun anywhere, anytime."

Clinton's comments sparked debate, as the right to own a gun is a long-standing aspect of American law, dating back to the Second Amendment's ratification in 1791. Clinton, however, seems to view this right as a recent and irresponsible shift in society.

During her speech, Clinton expressed concerns about the proliferation of guns in public places, such as movie theaters, where shootings have occurred due to seemingly trivial reasons like loud gum chewing or cellphone use. She cited examples from countries she has visited where there is no rule of law and no self-control, stating, "That's what happens in the countries I've visited where there is no rule of law and no self-control, and that's something that we can't just let go without paying attention."

It is unclear which specific countries Clinton is referring to, but it is worth noting that crime rates have risen in areas where guns were banned in England, and a 2013 Harvard study found an association between high gun ownership and low crime rates globally. The study also highlighted that many developed nations with high rates of gun ownership, such as Norway, Finland, Germany, France, and Denmark, have murder rates as low or lower than those with lower gun ownership rates.

Clinton's political future remains uncertain, with her stating she is still unsure about running in the 2016 election. She encouraged Americans to "stay tuned" for her decision.

Title: Wisconsin Governor Scott Walker's Immigration Stance Under Scrutiny

Article: Wisconsin Governor Scott Walker has faced criticism over his stance on immigration, with a communications aide being forced off his staff after old tweets surfaced disparaging Representative Steve King (R-IA), a well-known opponent of amnesty. The aide, Liz Mair, had tweeted about King's January 24th Iowa Freedom Summit, where Walker, Senator Ted Cruz (R-TX), and other possible Republican presidential candidates spoke.

Walker's immigration stance has been a topic of controversy since January, when opponents began circulating prior statements showing that he had endorsed a "path to citizenship" and the Senate's Gang of 8 bill specifically. Since then, Walker has attempted to walk back those positions, stating, "My view has changed, I'm flat-out saying it. Candidates can say that, sometimes they don't."

Walker's views on immigration have evolved over time. In July 2013, he stated, "You hear some people talk about border security and a wall and all that. To me, I don't know that you need any of that if you had a better, saner way to let people into the country in the first place." In March 2015, he emphasized the need to secure the border and implement a legal immigration system.

Regarding illegal immigrants already in the United States, Walker believes that they should be given a path to citizenship, but only after securing the border. This stance is not uncommon among Republicans. Walker's position is similar to that of Jeb Bush, who also advocates for securing the border before granting legal status to illegal immigrants.

In a March 1st interview with Fox News Sunday's Chris Wallace, Walker stated, "I believe there's a way that you can do that. First and foremost, you've got to secure that border or none of these plans make any sense." He also emphasized the need for employers to use E-Verify and other tools to ensure a legal immigration system.

In conclusion, while Walker's views on immigration have shifted over time, his current stance is similar to that of Jeb Bush, emphasizing the need to secure the border before granting legal status to illegal immigrants already in the United States.

Title: Conservative Media Criticized for Divisiveness, But Is the Problem Really the Other Side?

Article:

Robert F. Kennedy Jr. recently expressed concerns about the "right-wing control of the American media," specifically citing Fox News and conservative talk radio. He argued that these outlets have divided the country and empowered conservative politicians. While many conservatives may indeed criticize liberal media for perceived bias, Kennedy's criticism of conservative media is not entirely accurate.

Conservative radio hosts do not claim to be unbiased journalists, but rather commentators, and they have the right to express their opinions. Fox News, in particular, presents itself as "fair and balanced," with a mix of conservative and liberal hosts and guests. In contrast, liberal networks often do not provide a similar platform for conservative perspectives.

Kennedy's criticism of conservative media is not his only mistake. He scapegoats conservative media for the country's divisions, ignoring the fact that the nation is naturally divided between those with different worldviews. The emergence of alternative media has given conservatives a voice, which is healthy for the republic.

Many liberals are blind to liberal media bias and intolerant of opposing viewpoints. They often view conservative opinions as aberrational and believe that their own views are the only reasonable ones. This can lead to a lack of understanding and respect for opposing perspectives.

The problem is not divided opinion or rigorous debate, which are essential to the American system. Rather, it is journalists who have abandoned their role as watchdogs against abuse of power and now function as co-conspirators with liberal politicians. Conservatives, on the other hand, are more honest about their beliefs and biases, which makes them less of a threat to the republic.

What is needed is not fewer conservative media outlets, but more. And liberal journalists and politicians should be more forthcoming about their biases.

Title: The Role of the Federal Government in Maintaining Safety: A Constitutional Perspective

The recent discussions about gun control and safety have sparked a heated debate, with President Obama and Vice President Biden emphasizing the federal government's role in maintaining safety. However, a closer examination of the Constitution and its history reveals that the states, not the federal government, are responsible for ensuring the safety and well-being of their citizens.

The Constitution was created by the states, which delegated only 16 specific powers to the federal government, primarily related to national defense, foreign affairs, and commerce. The states retained powers related to health, safety, welfare, and morality, as evident from the Constitution's language and the records of the ratifying conventions.

The concept of subsidiarity, as articulated by St. Thomas Aquinas, suggests that problems closest to the people should be addressed by the government closest to those people. This principle is consistent with the Supreme Court's consistent rulings that the "police power" to regulate health, safety, welfare, and morality remains with the states, not the federal government.

The current debate over guns is a prime example of the federal government overstepping its constitutional bounds. The Constitution explicitly prohibits the government from infringing upon the right to keep and bear arms, which is essential for self-defense and as a deterrent against tyranny.

As the country continues to discuss public policy, it is crucial to remember that the Constitution was designed to protect individual freedoms from the lust for power of those in government and the passions of the people who elected them. The federal government's role is limited to the powers delegated to it by the states, and any attempts to expand its authority must be carefully considered and justified within the framework of the Constitution.

Title: Senate Leaders Engage in Bipartisan Discussions on Spending Bill, but Republicans Differ on Immigration

Article:

Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid, a Democrat from Nevada, expressed optimism on Monday about the prospects of passing a spending bill, citing "productive, bipartisan conversations" with Speaker John A. Boehner, a Republican from Ohio, and Senator Barbara A. Mikulski, a Democrat from Maryland, chairwoman of the Appropriations Committee. Reid emphasized the importance of working together to keep the government funded, urging Republicans to reject what he called "brinkmanship" and instead work with Democrats to complete the business of funding the government.

However, some Republicans, including Boehner and Representative Steve King, a Republican from Iowa, have left the possibility of a government shutdown on the table. King is preparing legislation to undo any action taken by the president regarding immigration, including the protected status granted to young immigrants brought to the country illegally as children. King stated that he wants to keep as much of the government operating as possible but cannot support any appropriations that would fund departments that would execute the president's plan to circumvent the law or the Constitution.

Senator John Cornyn, a Republican from Texas, echoed concerns among his colleagues that a presidential executive order on immigration would torpedo their chances of passing their own immigration legislation in the next Congress. Cornyn urged the president to reconsider and work with Republicans in a bipartisan, bicameral way to fix the broken immigration system.

Not all Republicans are opposed to the president's executive action, however. Senator John McCain, a Republican from Arizona, expressed his opposition to a government shutdown, stating that there are other ways to respond to the president's actions, including going to court, appropriations bills, and the Budget Act. McCain emphasized that shutting down the government should not be an option.

The article highlights the ongoing debate between Senate leaders on the spending bill and the potential implications of the president's executive action on immigration. While some Republicans are willing to consider a government shutdown, others are urging a more collaborative approach to address the nation's immigration issues.

Title: Brazilian-American Activist Julia Song's Journey from Protests to Politics

Article:

Julia Song, a Brazilian-American political activist and commentator, has been featured on various platforms, including OANN and Rebel Media. Her views are her own, and she can be found on Twitter @realjuliasong.

Song's activism began in her home country of Brazil, where she helped organize peaceful protests against government corruption and abuses of power in 2013. At the time, Brazil was plagued by scandal, with many politicians prioritizing their own interests over those of the majority of the population. The country's politicians continued to push agendas that benefited themselves and a select few, while the majority of the population struggled to make ends meet.

However, Song's activism led to a government investigation into corruption, resulting in many politicians being sent to prison and the country's president, Dilma Rousseff, being impeached. Following the protests, Song moved to the United States on a family visa, where she was granted temporary residency and began a four-year process to gain full citizenship.

Initially, Song thought her activism days were behind her, but she soon noticed a growing political divide between the political elite and working-class Americans. She began using social media to raise awareness of the issue, initially on Instagram and later on Twitter. Song advocates for a smaller government that guarantees more individual freedoms and allows everyday Americans a chance at success. As a Republican, she supports President Donald Trump's emphasis on fighting for ordinary Americans.

Title: Senate Democrats Warn Republicans Against Repealing Obamacare Without a Replacement Plan

Article:

Senate Democrats are warning Republicans against repealing the Affordable Care Act (ACA), also known as Obamacare, without a replacement plan in place. The warning comes as top Republicans plan to move forward with a budget plan in January to repeal much of the health care law, which would allow them to circumvent a Democratic filibuster in the Senate.

According to Senator Patty Murray, the third-ranking Senate Democrat, "they have failed to come up with any plausible way to provide care and health care insurance for so many people. If they take it away, they better tell us how to fix it because they broke it." Murray emphasized that the GOP will need to provide a replacement plan to avoid chaos in the health care system.

Senator Chuck Schumer, the incoming Senate Democratic leader, warned that repealing Obamacare without a replacement will be "far more disastrous and less clever than they think." Schumer's chief deputy, Senator Dick Durbin, echoed the sentiment, stating that Republicans have a "responsibility to come up with a replacement."

However, some Republicans are confident that Democrats will buckle and support their efforts to repeal the law. Oklahoma GOP Rep. Tom Cole noted that moving ahead with repeal will put the burden on Republicans to lay out the next steps, but acknowledged that it's a complex issue.

The issue has been discussed at length between House Speaker Paul Ryan, Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell, and senior Trump officials, with some health policy experts warning that the health care system could collapse immediately if insurers pull out of the expiring system. The issue is expected to be a major challenge for the GOP in the new Congress.

In related news, House Republicans have selected Rep. Greg Walden of Oregon to chair the powerful Energy and Commerce Committee, giving him a key role in drafting a replacement to the health care law.

Title: California Legislature Passes Bill Requiring Presidential Candidates to Release Tax Returns

The California State Legislature has passed a bill that would require presidential candidates to make their tax returns public before appearing on the state's ballot. The legislation, which was passed by a Democratic-controlled Legislature, is the latest development in California's ongoing feud with President Donald Trump.

The bill, authored by Democratic state Sen. Mike McGuire, would require presidential candidates to file copies of their five most recent tax returns with state officials as a condition for appearing on the primary ballot. The state would then make the returns public.

The enforceability of the bill is uncertain, as the U.S. Supreme Court has held that states cannot add to the qualifications for U.S. Senate or House members. However, other legal experts have said that such a requirement could pass constitutional muster.

It is also unclear if Governor Jerry Brown will sign the measure. While Trump is the first president in years to ascend to the White House without releasing his tax returns, Brown has resisted similar disclosures. In a break with longstanding tradition, he did not release his tax returns during his 2010 or 2014 campaigns.

The bill passed the state Senate on the final day of this year's legislative session, after gaining approval in California's lower house the previous day.

Title: Canada Legalizes Recreational Cannabis: A Watershed Moment for the Country

Canada has become the second country in the world to legalize recreational cannabis, marking a significant shift in the country's drug policy. The change went into effect on Wednesday, allowing adults to purchase and consume cannabis legally.
