The first person to buy marijuana legally was Ian Power, who was first in line in the easternmost province of Newfoundland and Labrador when the clock struck midnight.

Across the country, many people celebrated the occasion, with some hosting parties and others simply enjoying the freedom to purchase cannabis legally. However, not everyone is celebrating. Some worry that legalization will increase cannabis use, especially among youth, and create new safety problems.

The shift in policy was a long time coming, with Prime Minister Justin Trudeau promising to make marijuana legal during his 2014 election campaign. The government has introduced strict regulations to control the sale and consumption of cannabis, including limits on the amount of cannabis individuals can possess and grow.

Despite the new laws, some concerns remain. The Canadian Medical Association Journal published an editorial calling legalization "a national, uncontrolled experiment" and warning of potential health risks. The Canadian Psychiatric Society cautioned that early and regular cannabis use can affect memory, attention, and mental health.

The government has also introduced new drug-impaired driving legislation, which includes stiff fines and possible jail time for those caught driving under the influence of cannabis. However, the reliability of saliva tests used to detect THC, the psychoactive compound in cannabis, has raised concerns and may face legal challenges.

The legalization of cannabis has also sparked a debate over what to call the day. While some suggest "Hash Wednesday" or "Green Day," others have dubbed it "1017," the date it became legal. The Royal Ontario Museum even tweeted pictures of ancient pottery to commemorate the occasion.

Overall, the legalization of recreational cannabis in Canada marks a significant shift in the country's drug policy and has sparked a range of reactions. While some celebrate the freedom to enjoy cannabis legally, others worry about the potential risks and consequences.

Title: Obama Asks Voters to Trust in His Ideas for the Future

President Barack Obama asked the nation to choose a "harder" path to long-term economic prosperity, outlining grand economic promises for a second term in office and describing the 2012 election as a vote on the nature of American citizenship. In his acceptance speech at the Democratic National Convention, Obama emphasized the need for a more optimistic vision for the country's future, acknowledging that the economy is still struggling and that voters are suffering.

Obama's speech marked a departure from his last presidential campaign and the 2004 convention speech that made him a national political phenomenon. He argued that Republican Mitt Romney is an out-of-touch plutocrat who lacks simple patriotism, using strong language to emphasize the differences between the two parties.

The president outlined specific benchmarks for success, including creating a million new manufacturing jobs by the end of 2016, reducing oil imports, creating 600,000 jobs in the natural gas industry, and increasing the number of math and science teachers. He also emphasized the need to extract sacrifices from the wealthiest citizens and special interests to bring about widely shared economic gains.

Throughout the speech, Obama emphasized the importance of American nationalism, highlighting the benefits of trade agreements that help American companies sell goods to new customers and create jobs in the United States. He also took time to mock his challengers, questioning their readiness for the job of president and vice president.

The speech concluded three days of speeches from Democratic leaders, who argued that their party is the only one that can be trusted to look out for the interests of the suffering middle class. The speech was seen as a crucial moment in the 2012 election, with Obama attempting to deliver a forward-looking economic vision and break away from a debate focused on the country's economic struggles.

Title: Trump Signs $1.3 Trillion Spending Plan, Criticizes Lack of Action on DACA and Border Wall

Article:

President Donald Trump has signed a $1.3 trillion spending plan to fund the government through September, despite initially indicating he might veto it due to the lack of action on the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) debate and his border wall. The bill had passed the House and Senate with bipartisan support, but conservatives criticized the lengthy 2,232-page document, which they had only seven hours to review.

Trump stated that he signed the bill on "national security" grounds, citing the rebuilding of America's military and improvements to homeland security. However, he expressed disappointment with the bill, saying he would not sign a similar bill again. Senator Rand Paul had urged Trump to veto the bill, citing the high price tag and inclusion of items like funding for Planned Parenthood.

The bill does include the Taylor Force Act, which suspends US aid to the Palestinian Authority until they change their laws incentivizing terrorism. The act is named after Taylor Force, an American combat veteran who was brutally murdered by a Palestinian terrorist while visiting Israel.

Meanwhile, there is a shakeup in the president's inner circle, as he is replacing his national security adviser, H.R. McMaster, with John Bolton, a former US ambassador to the UN and outspoken hawk on foreign affairs. Bolton's appointment increases the likelihood of the US pulling out of the Iran nuclear deal and taking a tougher stance on North Korea.

The president has also announced plans to impose tariffs on up to $60 billion in Chinese imports to the US, citing a $800 billion trade deficit with China. China has responded by announcing a list of American goods that may be hit with higher imports, which could affect the middle class and Trump supporters heading into the midterm elections and his re-election bid in 2020.

Title: Hillary Clinton Reflects on Patriotism and Foreign Policy in CNN Interview

Former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton recently appeared on CNN's "Fareed Zakaria GPS" show, where she shared her thoughts on patriotism and foreign policy. During the interview, Clinton expressed her pride in her American roots, crediting former President George W. Bush for bringing out her patriotism. She also discussed the importance of the United States' role in the world, stating that the country needs to "sell itself" and define its values and goals.

Clinton highlighted the trend lines of President Bush's foreign policy, specifically his emergency program for AIDS relief in Sub-Saharan Africa. She noted that this program has had a positive impact, with many people in the region expressing gratitude to the United States for its efforts. In contrast, Clinton seemed to imply that President Obama's foreign policy has not been as effective, stating that the country spends a lot of money and time trying to exert influence around the world without being clear about its values and goals.

Clinton's comments have sparked analysis from Fox News analysts, who suggest that she may be trying to distance herself from Obama's foreign policy and potentially positioning herself for a presidential run in 2024. However, Clinton's statements remain focused on the importance of American leadership and the need for the country to define its values and goals.

Title: Romney's Criticism of Obama Administration's Response to Libya and Egypt Attacks Raises Questions

A timeline of events suggests that Mitt Romney's criticism of the Obama administration's response to the attacks on U.S. missions in Libya and Egypt may be misplaced. The U.S. Embassy in Cairo released a statement condemning the violence and breach of its grounds on Tuesday, hours before the attacks occurred. The statement did not specifically mention the online video deemed offensive by Muslims, but condemned the actions of those who abuse the universal right of free speech to hurt the religious beliefs of others.

Romney's campaign released a statement on Tuesday evening, accusing the Obama administration of sympathizing with those who waged the attacks, rather than condemning them. However, the embassy's statement was issued before the breach and protests, and the embassy reiterated its condemnation on Twitter after the breach.

The Romney campaign's criticism of the Obama administration's response has been met with criticism from the Obama campaign, which accused Romney of taking a political swipe during a crisis. Romney's comments also raised questions about his stance on the offensive video, which he did not specifically address during his press conference.

The incident highlights the complexities of navigating international diplomacy and the challenges of balancing freedom of speech with respect for religious beliefs. The Romney campaign's talking points, obtained by CNN, suggest that Republicans should be prepared to answer questions about the embassy's statement and the role of free speech in the crisis.

In conclusion, the events surrounding the attacks on U.S. missions in Libya and Egypt have raised questions about the Obama administration's response and Mitt Romney's criticism of it. The incident serves as a reminder of the complexities of international diplomacy and the importance of balancing freedom of speech with respect for religious beliefs.

Title: Trump Predicts Boost to US Economy as Republican Tax Bill Heads to Congress

The Republican-led Congress is poised to pass a $1.5 trillion tax bill, which President Trump has hailed as a "giant tax cut for Christmas." The bill, which has been in the works for months, is expected to bring significant changes to the US tax code, including a reduction in corporate tax rates and increased standard deductions for individuals.

According to Trump, the bill will have a "big impact" on the economy, with immediate expensing and the creation of many jobs. White House Press Secretary Sarah Sanders echoed this sentiment, stating that middle-class Americans will see the benefits of the tax package.

The bill has garnered support from both the House and Senate, with Senate Republicans flipping two key votes to "yes" on Monday. However, not all Republicans are on board, with Senator Jeff Flake of Arizona still reviewing the bill and Senator John McCain absent due to health reasons.

Democrats have criticized the bill, citing concerns that it favors big corporations and wealthy Americans at the expense of the middle class. Despite this, the bill is expected to pass, with Republicans holding a simple majority in both the House and Senate.

The bill's passage would mark the first major legislative win for Trump's presidency. The bill cuts the corporate tax rate from 35% to 21%, doubles the standard deduction for married couples, and increases the per-child tax credit. It also repeals the individual mandate of the Affordable Care Act, also known as Obamacare.

While some critics have raised concerns about the bill's impact on the economy, Republican leaders have brushed aside negative projections, citing excitement among Americans about a stronger economy and bigger paychecks. The bill is expected to hit the House floor on Tuesday, with a vote expected later in the day.

Title: Obama's Camp David Summit with Gulf Leaders to Address Regional Concerns Amidst Iran Nuclear Deal

The upcoming Camp David summit between President Obama and Gulf leaders aims to reassure Arab partners that the emerging nuclear deal with Iran does not signal a shift in the United States' commitment to the region. However, the meeting is unlikely to bridge the significant gaps between the US and Gulf states on key issues, including Iran's nuclear program and regional security.

The Gulf states are concerned not only about Iran's nuclear program being legitimized by the international community but also about the potential financial windfall and increased influence in the region if sanctions are lifted. They worry that Iran will use this newfound influence to spread its influence in Iraq, Lebanon, Syria, and Yemen, and that the US is not doing enough to counter this.

The summit is also expected to address the disconnect between the US and Gulf states on regional security issues, particularly in Yemen and Libya. The Gulf states have been criticized for their role in these conflicts, with some analysts arguing that their actions are not always in line with US interests.

The meeting may include discussions on arms sales, joint military exercises, and missile defense initiatives, but experts warn that these measures may not address the deeper issues facing the region. The Gulf states are concerned about internal challenges, such as providing jobs to a large youth population, undertaking political reform, and countering extremist ideologies, which the summit may only touch on superficially.

The summit is seen as a test of the Obama administration's "leading from behind" policy, which aims to delegate greater security responsibilities to regional partners. However, experts warn that this approach may not be effective if the Gulf states are not held accountable for their actions and if the US does not provide sufficient guidance and oversight.

Ultimately, the Camp David summit is unlikely to resolve the deep-seated concerns and disconnects between the US and Gulf states, but it may provide some short-term reassurances and symbolic gestures.

Title: White House Aides Quit Amid Domestic Abuse Allegations, President Trump Weighs in on Allegations

The White House has seen the departure of two aides, David Sorensen and Rob Porter, amid allegations of domestic abuse. President Donald Trump took to Twitter to express his thoughts on the matter, stating that lives are being "destroyed by mere allegation" and that there is "no recovery for someone falsely accused." He did not specifically mention the two aides in his tweet.

The White House has faced criticism for its handling of the allegations, and Trump's comments have drawn scorn from some. Democratic Senator Patty Murray responded by saying that women's lives are affected every day by sexual violence and harassment, and that she will continue to stand with and trust survivors, even if the president does not. Democratic Congresswoman Jackie Speier called Trump's comments "offensive."

Sorensen has been accused by his former wife of being violent and emotionally abusive, while Porter faces allegations of domestic abuse involving two ex-wives. Trump has been accused of sexual misconduct himself, which he has denied. The president has also supported others who have faced abuse allegations, including Alabama Republican Roy Moore, who ran unsuccessfully for the US Senate.

The allegations of sexual misconduct have hit a growing list of influential men around the world, following a flurry of allegations against Hollywood producer Harvey Weinstein. The #MeToo hashtag went viral last year as more and more women shared their harassment experiences online.

Title: Republican Congressman Devin Nunes Files Lawsuit Against Twitter and Others for Defamation and Other Claims

Article:

Republican Congressman Devin Nunes, representing California's 22nd District, has filed a lawsuit against Twitter, a GOP operative, and unnamed defendants behind parody accounts on the social network, alleging defamation and other claims. According to Nunes, the parody accounts, including one using the handle @DevinNunesMom, insulted him on the platform, and Twitter played a willing party to the abuse he faced. He also claims that Twitter shadowbanned his account @devinnunes, a process by which a social network can quietly curb the distribution or reach of a user's content without outright banning them.

Nunes alleges that the shadowbanning was intentional and calculated to interfere with and influence the federal election and interfere with his ongoing investigation as a member of the House Permanent Select Committee on Intelligence. Twitter has denied allegations of shadowbanning, stating that it does not make a user's content undiscoverable to everyone but that user, and that it does not shadow ban based on political viewpoints or ideology.

The lawsuit is the first of many lawsuits Nunes plans to file against technology companies for their alleged bias against conservatives. Republicans have alleged that technology platforms, including Google, Facebook, and Twitter, have an unfair bias against conservative viewpoints, an argument that these companies have repeatedly denied and disputed.

The lawsuit was filed in Virginia state court, but it is unclear how Fox News obtained the complaint or why it stated that the suit had been filed on Monday. A Fox News spokesperson did not return a request for comment. Neither Nunes' attorney nor his press representative answered requests for comment. Twitter declined comment.

Title: The Debate Over Cancel Culture: A Complex Issue with No Clear Solution

The concept of "cancel culture" has gained significant attention in recent years, with some arguing it is a powerful tool for holding the powerful accountable, while others see it as a threat to free speech and open debate. The phenomenon, which originated on social media, has led to firings, resignations, and boycotts, with some notable examples including TV shows being pulled from the air and writers losing their jobs due to controversial views.

The debate centers around whether mass public criticism furthers the cause of justice or represents a misinformed online witchhunt that poses a threat to free speech. Critics of cancel culture argue that it threatens freedom of speech and open debate, as people may be hesitant to express their opinions due to fear of personal or professional repercussions. They also argue that cancel culture rarely results in real systemic change and can even let companies off the hook by making small moves, such as disciplining or firing a single employee, instead of addressing larger organizational issues.

On the other hand, proponents of cancel culture believe it serves to reverse deeply entrenched power structures by providing a platform for those whose voices have been historically silenced to hold large companies and public figures accountable. They argue that those who are upset by cancel culture are the elite who are, for the first time, being held to account.

Some argue that there is no such thing as cancel culture and that the phrase has been invented to make worthwhile criticism seem new or exotic. They point out that one bad news cycle is rarely enough to end the career or threaten the financial stability of influential figures, and that it is important to hold people accountable for their actions.

The debate is complex and multifaceted, with no clear solution in sight. As the Washington Examiner editorial board noted, "There is no way we can evolve into a more tolerant society if all people are deemed irremediably racist for things they wrote as teenagers and if major publications target non-public figures. Beyond that, however, the spirit of open speech and debate, in which there is an exchange of a wide array of ideas, is crucial to the survival of the republic."

**Kenya University Attack: 147 Dead, Dozens Wounded in 15-Hour Siege**

A devastating attack on a university in northern Kenya has left 147 people dead and dozens wounded, with most of the victims being students. The assault, which lasted for 15 hours, was carried out by armed terrorists who stormed the Garissa University campus, about 90 miles from the Somali border.

The Somali-based Islamic terrorist group al-Shabab claimed responsibility for the attack, which is the organization's deadliest in Kenya. The group, linked to al-Qaeda, targeted Christians and converts to Islam, with students saying the gunmen separated them and held hostages in a dormitory.

Kenyan Interior Cabinet Secretary Joseph Nkaissery said some students were killed during morning prayers at the mosque, while others were killed or injured as they tried to escape. The attack also resulted in the deaths of two security guards, one policeman, and one soldier.

The Kenyan government has launched an investigation into the attack, with a $220,000 bounty offered for Mohammed Mohamud, also known as Dulyadin and Gamadhere, who is suspected of planning the attack.

The White House strongly condemned the attack, offering condolences to the families of the victims and providing assistance to the Kenyan government. The U.S. ambassador to Kenya, Robert Godec, also condemned the attack, saying it "strongly reinforces the need for all countries and communities to unite in the effort to combat violent extremism."

The attack comes amid concerns over the government's ability to protect its citizens, with a Nairobi-based security analyst, Abdiwahab Sheikh, saying the incident highlights the government's failure to shore up security in the country.

Title: Federal Government on Pace to Break Record for Tax Receipts

The United States federal government is expected to bring in a record $2.7 trillion in tax receipts this fiscal year, according to estimates from the Congressional Budget Office (CBO). This increase reflects a steady post-recession rise in revenues, with a 6% increase in 2012 and an expected 11% jump in 2013. The CBO attributes this growth to the recent agreement between Congress and the White House, which allowed for an increase in tax rates for top earners and the expiration of a 2-point payroll tax cut.

The expected tax boost comes as President Obama pushes for a "balanced approach" of spending cuts, revenues, and entitlement reform. However, House Speaker John Boehner has expressed skepticism, stating that the president has already increased taxes by $650 billion and questioning what more he wants. The CBO notes that the last tax revenue record was set in 2007, when the government brought in nearly $2.6 trillion.

In terms of spending, the CBO estimates that the government is on pace to hit $3.55 trillion in 2013, roughly the same as in 2012. While Republicans argue that spending is the problem, both sides agree that cutting discretionary spending alone will not solve the debt and deficit crisis. The sequester will continue to cut deeper into discretionary spending, but costly entitlements will continue to grow, driving up the U.S. debt and annual interest taxpayers pay on that debt.

Title: North Korea Accuses US President Trump of Declaring War, Threatens to Shoot Down US Bombers

Article:

North Korea's Foreign Minister, Ri Yong-ho, has accused US President Donald Trump of declaring war on the country and stated that Pyongyang has the right to shoot down US bombers, even if they are not within North Korean airspace. The White House dismissed the statement as "absurd," while the Pentagon warned North Korea to stop its provocations.

Ri's comments were a response to Trump's tweet that the North Korean leadership would not "be around much longer" if they continued their rhetoric. The North Korean minister said that since the US declared war on their country, they have the right to take counter-measures, including the right to shoot down US strategic bombers even when they are not inside North Korean airspace.

The exchange is the latest in an increasingly heated war of words between the two countries. The US flew its B-1B Lancer bombers and F-15 fighter escorts over waters to the east of North Korea, the furthest north US warplanes have flown in several months. The US believes it has the right to do this, but if Pyongyang judges that these aircraft are on an offensive mission, what then?

The UN Secretary-General's spokesman, Stéphane Dujarric, warned that "fiery talk can lead to fatal misunderstandings" and called for a political solution. China's ambassador to the UN, Liu Jieyi, expressed concern that the situation is getting too dangerous and urged calm.

Despite the escalating rhetoric, experts have played down the risk of direct conflict between the two countries. North Korea has continued to carry out nuclear and ballistic missile tests in defiance of UN sanctions, while the US has maintained its military presence in the region. The real question is what practical consequences might ensue from the war of words between Washington and Pyongyang.

Title: Obama Pushes for Vote on Immigration Plan, Daring Congress to Say "No"

Article:

President Barack Obama has taken a different approach to leading on the issue of immigration, opting to prod Republican legislators to the middle by demanding a vote on his own plan. On Tuesday, Obama emphasized the importance of bipartisan action, referencing a Senate bill offered by the so-called Gang of Eight senators, which is more palatable to Republicans than his own plan. He stated that if Congress is unable to move forward in a timely fashion, he will send up a bill based on his proposal and insist that they vote on it right away.

In doing so, Obama has dared Congress to say "no" to something specific, a strategy he also employed during the fiscal-cliff talks. With a year-end deadline approaching, he pushed Congress to vote on his own plan, allowing higher income tax hikes to go into effect if lawmakers couldn't cut a deal themselves. Obama asked Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid to call an up-or-down vote on that plan, as he did in a December 28 appearance before cameras at the White House.

Republicans have expressed concerns about Obama's negotiation tactics, feeling that the president and congressional Democrats have sought political gain while refusing to negotiate in good faith. On immigration, it's the same. The Obama plan includes a faster path to citizenship and nothing to trigger border-security enforcement, as well as clearing an easier path for same-sex couples.

Before Obama rolled out his immigration plan in Nevada, Senator Marco Rubio of Florida raised concerns that the president would launch a "bidding war." In a radio interview with Rush Limbaugh, Rubio dismissed the notion of an up-or-down vote, stating that the plan would need to go through committees and have public hearings. A Senate Republican aide jabbed, "The president's been gone from the Senate a long time and perhaps he has forgotten that it's a lot easier to pass legislation if he works with Congress."

Obama has presented Republicans with a plan they will like much less than what's been crafted by the bipartisan Senate group. The group plan includes triggers to enforce border-security measures, more unmanned drones, and no provisions making it easier for same-sex couples seeking to immigrate or naturalize. Unless other Republicans come up with a plan of their own, the president has given Republicans a choice between the left and the middle – it's not hard to tell which they'd prefer.

Title: Bari Weiss Resigns from The New York Times Amid Allegations of Hostile Work Environment

The New York Times has lost another prominent figure, as Bari Weiss, a conservative opinion editor, resigned from the publication. Weiss's departure comes amidst allegations of a hostile work environment and harassment from her colleagues. In her resignation letter, Weiss described the situation as "unlawful discrimination, hostile work environment, and constructive discharge."

Weiss joined The New York Times in 2017, brought in by editorial page editor James Bennet to offer a conservative perspective. However, her views have been met with intense criticism and harassment from her colleagues. According to Weiss, she has been subjected to bullying, with colleagues calling her a Nazi and a racist, and her work and character being openly demeaned on company-wide Slack channels.

The situation escalated when Bennet was forced to resign after publishing an op-ed by Senator Tom Cotton, R-Ark., calling for the use of the military against rioters. The Times' management was criticized for not taking action against the harassment and bullying faced by Weiss and other colleagues.

Weiss's resignation letter highlights the toxic work environment at The New York Times, where employees are encouraged to engage in bullying and harassment. The situation is reminiscent of high school, with junior staffers running the show and the administration cowering in their offices.

The problem, according to Weiss, starts at the top, with Chairman Arthur Ochs Sulzberger Jr. and his son, A.G. Sulzberger, failing to provide adult supervision. The Times' management has allowed the inmates to run the asylum, and it's had a devastating impact on the publication's reputation.

Weiss's resignation is a significant blow to The New York Times, which has struggled to maintain its reputation as a bastion of journalism. The paper's decline is a result of its failure to provide a platform for diverse perspectives and its willingness to censor and silence those who disagree with its views.

In conclusion, Bari Weiss's resignation from The New York Times highlights the toxic work environment and the need for adult supervision at the publication. The Times' management must take responsibility for creating a hostile work environment and take steps to address the issue.

Title: Congressional Leaders Deadlocked Over Fiscal Negotiations, Vowing to Stay in Washington Over Holiday Break

Article:

The negotiations on Capitol Hill over the fiscal cliff have stalled, with House Republicans and Democratic leaders at odds over the holiday season. House Republicans have vowed to stay in Washington until Christmas Eve to reach a deal and avoid a looming economic crisis, while Democratic leaders argue that lawmakers should be home for the holidays.

House Majority Leader Eric Cantor stated that Republicans will work through the holidays to reach a deal, which would avert a mix of automatic tax increases and federal spending cuts worth around $500 billion starting January 1. House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi, on the other hand, expressed hope for a deal before Christmas and emphasized the importance of lawmakers being home with their families.

The debate in Washington has been ongoing, with House Speaker John Boehner describing the conversation with President Obama as "deliberate" and focused on the divide between the two sides. Boehner also criticized the White House's most recent proposal, stating that it lacks a balanced approach of tax cuts and spending reductions. He claimed that the president's offer has "too many taxes" and would not pass in either the House or the Senate.

Pelosi, however, blamed Boehner for the impasse, urging him to allow a vote on the president's proposal and accusing him of stalling. Some House Republicans appear willing to accept a compromise to avert the fiscal crisis and extend tax cuts to 98% of income earners.

The negotiations have been ongoing, with a flurry of exchanges between Boehner and Obama earlier this week, including a meeting, an Obama offer, and a Boehner counter-offer. Despite the optimism, the debate remains ongoing, with no clear resolution in sight.

Title: Two More People Corroborate Some of Tara Reade's Claims Against Joe Biden

A recent report has revealed that two more individuals have corroborated some of Tara Reade's claims that she was sexually assaulted by former Vice President Joe Biden 27 years ago when she was a staffer in his Senate office. The two individuals, who wish to remain anonymous to protect their families' privacy, confirmed having conversations with Reade in 1993 and 2007-2008, respectively, in which she discussed experiencing sexual harassment while working in Biden's office.

This brings the total number of people who have corroborated some details of Reade's claims to four. Lynda LaCasse, a former neighbor of Reade's in California, and Lorraine Sanchez, a former colleague, have also spoken out about Reade sharing details about the alleged assault in the 1990s and complaining about being sexually harassed by her former boss in Washington, respectively.

Reade herself has spoken publicly about the incident, stating that she filed a limited report with a congressional personnel office but did not explicitly accuse Biden of sexual assault or harassment. She recalled feeling uncomfortable and scared, and did not report the incident to supervisors or senior staffers at the time.

In response to the allegations, Biden has denied the incident ever happening, stating "it is not true. I'm saying it unequivocally – it never happened. It didn't. It never happened." He also emphasized that news organizations have spoken with dozens of former staffers who have not corroborated Reade's allegations and that many of them spoke about the office culture being one that would not have tolerated harassment.

Title: Obama Says U.S. Is 'Less Racially Divided' Despite Perceptions

Article:

In a recent NPR interview, President Obama shared his thoughts on the current state of race relations in the United States. The President believes that Americans feel worse about race relations not because the situation has worsened, but because people are talking about it more. He emphasized that the country is making progress, citing the growth of the economy and the increased attention on police-community relations.

The President also discussed the recent police killings of black men in Ferguson, Missouri, and New York City, which sparked widespread debate and protests. He believes that better data for the public and better training for police can improve their interactions. Obama has assembled a task force to examine police and community relations, and he is optimistic that progress will be made in the coming year.

However, the President acknowledged that the Democratic Party faces a challenge in terms of voter demographics. While the share of minorities in the electorate is growing, the party has struggled to win over white voters in recent elections. In the 2010 and 2014 midterm elections, the Democratic Party failed to win over enough white voters, leading to Republican dominance in Congress and state legislatures.

Despite these challenges, Obama's larger sentiment is that it would be beneficial for both major parties to compete seriously for the votes of all major racial and ethnic groups. This ideal is shared by politicians from both parties, but it remains to be seen if it will become a reality in the future.

Title: Trump Administration Officials Discuss COVID-19 Projections and Economic Reopening

The Trump administration held a briefing on Friday, during which President Trump discussed the latest COVID-19 death toll projections. According to the president, the 60,000 estimated death toll is evidence of progress, and he believes the actual number will be "substantially under" the initial 100,000 forecast. However, public health advisers took a more cautious approach, noting that the latest figures may not reflect the full extent of the pandemic.

Dr. Deborah L. Birx, the White House pandemic coordinator, emphasized that the administration has not yet reached the peak of the pandemic and that experts are only seeing the most severe cases due to limited testing. She questioned whether the current numbers represent the tip of the iceberg or half to three-quarters of the total cases.

Administration officials have indicated that it is unlikely President Trump will extend the current guidelines beyond April 30. Instead, he may announce some lifting of quarantine measures, potentially paving the way for a gradual reopening of the economy.

The president has been engaging in discussions with business leaders, including Michael Corbat, CEO of Citigroup, and Brian Moynihan, CEO of Bank of America, about supporting the economy and when it might reopen. Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin has facilitated these conversations, which have also involved executives like Stephen A. Schwarzman, CEO of Blackstone, and Steven Roth, a real estate investor close to the president.

Other business executives have approached Jared Kushner, the president's son-in-law and senior adviser, with concerns about the economy. Paul Tudor Jones made a passionate plea to reopen the economy during a conference call organized by Kushner several weeks ago, while Nelson Peltz was reportedly influential in the president's since-aborted plan to begin reopening by Easter.

Title: Senate Committee Votes Down Amendment to Strengthen Border Security Provisions in Immigration Bill

The Senate Judiciary Committee voted 12-6 to reject an amendment to the immigration bill, which would have required the U.S.-Mexico border to be under control for six months before anyone could seek legal status. The amendment, proposed by Senator Chuck Grassley of Iowa, was seen as a way to ensure the border is secured before moving forward with immigration reform. However, supporters of the legislation, including Democratic Senator Chuck Schumer of New York, argued that the real effect of the measure would be to indefinitely delay citizenship for the estimated 11 million people living in the country without authorization.

The Judiciary Committee's vote was the first of several expected votes on amendments that could potentially alter the bill's core provisions. The 844-page legislation, backed by President Barack Obama, aims to toughen border security, remake legal immigration, and create a 13-year path to citizenship for those already in the country.

Senator Grassley expressed concerns that the bill does not adequately address border security, stating that it "falls short of what I want to see in a strong immigration reform bill." In contrast, Senator Schumer argued that the legislation represents the country's best hope for immigration reform and a chance to break through partisanship.

The bill's authors, including Senators Jeff Flake, Lindsey Graham, Chuck Schumer, and Dick Durbin, are working to show they are open to alterations that could attract additional support. They accepted several uncontroversial amendments from the Republican side to boost enforcement provisions, including an amendment by Grassley to require annual audits of a new immigration reform trust fund.

Senator Marco Rubio, one of the bill's authors, acknowledged that some amendments may be seen as attempts to thwart the legislation, but emphasized that most are intended to refine and improve it. He stated that the public wants legislation that ensures "this illegal immigration wave doesn't happen again."

Title: Colleges Test Critical Thinking Skills of Graduates, Results Show Worrying Trends

The Association of American Colleges & Universities (AACU) and the State Higher Education Executive Officers have released the results of a nationwide experiment aimed at assessing the critical thinking skills of college graduates. The project involved over 125 professors evaluating 7,000 samples of students' coursework from 59 institutions in nine states. The goal was to determine whether professors can use standardized metrics to measure students' performance in critical thinking, written communication, and quantitative literacy.

The results show that fewer than a third of students who completed most of their coursework earned high scores for critical thinking skills, such as using evidence to investigate a point of view or reach a conclusion. Less than half of their coursework demonstrated the ability to draw appropriate conclusions based on quantitative analysis of data. The project's organizers concluded that far fewer students achieved high levels of critical thinking compared to written communication or quantitative literacy.

The experiment's findings are concerning, as they confirm earlier studies that raised concerns about the lack of critical thinking skills among college graduates. The results also highlight the need for colleges to improve their teaching methods and assessments to better prepare students for the demands of the modern workforce.

The project's success in showing that professors can design assessments to measure critical thinking skills is a step in the right direction. However, the actual results are a wake-up call for colleges to re-evaluate their approaches to teaching and learning. The experiment's findings suggest that more work is needed to ensure that students develop the critical thinking skills required to succeed in the rapidly changing job market.

Title: The Elusive Pursuit of Humanitarian Intervention: A Review of America's Military Involvement

The article discusses the United States' track record of humanitarian intervention, highlighting the mixed results and unintended consequences of military action. The piece begins by noting that Americans are often eager to help those in need, but their efforts have not always yielded the desired outcomes. The article cites several examples, including Operation Restore Hope in Somalia, the bombing of Yugoslavia, and the invasion of Iraq, which have all had devastating consequences.

The article argues that the latest example of humanitarian intervention, President Donald Trump's air raid in Syria, is part of a larger pattern of using military force to address humanitarian crises. However, the piece notes that this approach has often been ineffective and has sometimes exacerbated the very problems it aimed to solve.

The article also highlights the importance of public health efforts in addressing humanitarian crises, citing the success of programs like the President's Emergency Plan for AIDS Relief (PEPFAR), which has saved millions of lives through prevention and treatment. In contrast, the article notes that President Trump's proposed cuts to foreign aid and his focus on military solutions are misguided and short-sighted.

The article concludes by emphasizing the need for a more nuanced approach to humanitarian intervention, one that recognizes the limitations of military action and the importance of public health efforts. It notes that while military intervention may be necessary in some cases, it is not a panacea and can often do more harm than good.

Title: Attorney Represents Second Whistleblower with First-Hand Knowledge of Trump's Ukraine dealings

The attorney representing the whistleblower who sparked the impeachment inquiry into President Donald Trump's dealings with Ukraine has revealed that a second whistleblower has come forward, with first-hand knowledge of some of the allegations outlined in the original complaint. Mark Zaid, the attorney, told ABC News that the second whistleblower, an intelligence official, has been interviewed by the head of the intelligence community's internal watchdog office, Michael Atkinson.

The existence of a second whistleblower could undermine Trump's repeated claims that the original complaint was "totally inaccurate." The original complaint, filed on August 12, alleged that Trump pushed a foreign power to investigate his political rival, Joe Biden, and his son, Hunter, and that unnamed senior White House officials then tried to "lock down" all records of the phone call.

The second whistleblower's involvement could also expand the scope of the investigation, as they have first-hand knowledge of some of the allegations outlined in the original complaint. Zaid stated that both whistleblowers have full protection under the law intended to protect whistleblowers from being fired in retaliation.

The news comes as the House Intelligence Committee is conducting an investigation into Trump's dealings with Ukraine. The committee has received a transcript of Trump's July 25 call with Ukraine President Volodymyr Zelenskiy, which showed Trump asking for a "favor" and pushing for an investigation into the Biden family.

The investigation is ongoing, and it is unclear whether Trump or other U.S. officials broke the law in their handling of Ukraine. However, the Constitution allows Congress to decide what constitutes an impeachable offense.

Title: Proposal to Simplify Tax Filing Process Gains Momentum

Article:

The Internal Revenue Service (IRS) has spent a cumulative 2.6 billion hours processing income tax returns, with Americans dedicating an average of 16 hours to preparing their taxes. However, a proposal to simplify the process by having the government prepare tax returns for citizens has been met with resistance from the tax preparation industry. Senator Elizabeth Warren has reintroduced the Tax Filing Simplification Act, which would allow taxpayers to download the necessary information from the IRS and fill out their forms online.

In many countries, including Japan, Chile, Denmark, Estonia, Finland, Iceland, Norway, Sweden, and Spain, the government prepares tax returns for citizens, providing a pre-populated form that citizens can review and dispute if necessary. This system has been shown to save citizens a collective 225 million hours and $2 billion in costs.

The idea of pre-populated tax returns has been around for decades, with even President Ronald Reagan advocating for it in 1985. However, the tax preparation industry has consistently lobbied against such measures, citing concerns that it would threaten their business. Intuit, the maker of TurboTax, has spent over $2 million lobbying against legislation that would allow pre-prepared tax returns, and has made it clear that any government filing option would be a competitive threat.

Major tax preparers have spent nearly $28 million on lobbying since 1998, making it clear that the industry has a significant stake in maintaining the current system. The average American spends around $200 on tax preparation services each year, which accounts for nearly 10% of the typical tax return. With the majority of taxpayers relying on preparers or software to file their taxes, the industry has a lucrative business model that would be disrupted by a simplified filing process.

Senator Warren's proposal has gained support from several Democratic senators, including Jeanne Shaheen, Tammy Baldwin, Al Franken, Tom Udall, Sheldon Whitehouse, Edward Markey, Tammy Duckworth, Maggie Hassan, and Bernie Sanders. However, the proposal has yet to gain traction, and it remains to be seen whether the tax preparation industry's influence will continue to stifle efforts to simplify the tax filing process.

Title: ObamaCare Exchanges to Re-Open with Improved Technology and More Insurance Plans, but Critics Raise Concerns about Consumer Costs and Choices

The ObamaCare exchanges, which opened for business last fall, are expected to be largely improved with better technology and more insurance plans when they re-open next month. According to a preliminary report released by the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS), the number of insurers has increased by 25%, which officials argue should lower premium costs through competition, in addition to offering customers more choices.

The report shows that Americans will be able to choose from 248 qualified health plans, compared to 191 last year, with 67 new insurers joining the exchanges. Sixty-seven new insurers joined the exchanges, while 10 withdrew, resulting in a net increase of 57. States with the biggest increases were Indiana, Georgia, Michigan, Missouri, New Hampshire, Ohio, and Texas, with four new insurers each.

However, critics, such as Georgia GOP Rep. Tom Price, a doctor and member of the Congressional Health Care Caucus, argue that while ObamaCare has made progress in reducing federal spending on millions of uninsured Americans, consumer costs remain too high. Price stated that while the plans are providing more choices, they are not providing the coverage Americans want and need.

The report also included information on eight of the 14 state-run sites, showing 67 companies now offering insurance policies, compared to 61 in 2014. Ten new companies entered the competition, but four withdrew. Washington gained the most, with two new insurers, and California was the only state to have fewer options, minus two.

The massive problems faced by online ObamaCare shoppers when the exchanges debuted in 2013, including system crashes, error messages, incorrect information, and lost applications, appear to have been largely fixed in the past 12 months. President Obama hired industry experts to write better computer code and fix software bugs, ensuring the software problems were essentially fixed after the first several weeks.

Despite the improvements, critics argue that the technology is still not up to par, particularly the "back end" of the computer system that connects patients' insurance information to health-care providers. The report did not include an update on the federal site, HealthCare.gov, but a source said federal officials are scheduled to release such information in the coming days.

The Affordable Care Act, also known as ObamaCare, was passed in 2010 to help an estimated 30 million uninsured Americans get coverage. The law offers financial assistance to Americans buying insurance through exchanges and made insurance available to people previously denied coverage due to a pre-existing condition. The administration reached its goal of enrolling 6 million people by its self-imposed March 31 deadline, and currently, 7.3 million people have enrolled in marketplace plans, paid their premiums, and have access to insurance.

Some states continue to struggle with their sites, with Oregon and Maryland experiencing software bugs and technical problems. Oregon's site was unable to fully enroll a single customer online, and the state is estimated to have spent at least $85 million to manually enroll thousands of customers and salvage the faulty technology. Maryland's site crashed soon after going online last year, and officials have decided to replace the technology instead of fixing the system or joining the federal exchange system.

Title: White House Releases Detailed Breakdown of Tax Dollars Spent

The White House has released the annual "taxpayer receipt" for 2012, providing a detailed breakdown of how federal income tax revenues are spent. The receipt is available on the White House website, allowing taxpayers to see where their money went last year.

According to the report, military operations, such as the U.S. presence in Afghanistan, account for the largest sum of defense spending, taking up over 10% of taxpayer dollars. Health care programs, including Medicare and Medicaid, account for nearly 22.45% of expenditures.

A married couple with one child making $50,000 a year, roughly the median household income in America, paid an average of $995 in federal income taxes in 2012, or 1.99% of their income. Nearly a quarter of their income taxes, $245.17, went to the "National Defense" category, while $223.38, or 22.45%, was spent on "health care".

The report also highlights the significant contributions to Social Security, with workers paying $2,100 for a family of three earning a median income of $50,000 per year, or 4.2% of their gross income.

The federal government spends relatively little on education and the promotion of science and technology, with these areas receiving less than 5% of expenditures. NASA's budget is included in this category.

The report comes amid a debate over the 2014 budget proposals, with President Obama's proposal facing criticism from both Democratic and Republican legislators. The proposal aims to cut deficits by $1.8 trillion over the next decade, with spending on social programs and defense taking up the bulk of federal income tax revenues.

The report provides a detailed breakdown of where taxpayer dollars are being spent, with the largest categories being military operations, health care, and Social Security.

Title: Ayotte Caught in the Middle of Gun Control Debate

Ayotte, a first-term Republican senator from New Hampshire, has found herself at the center of the ongoing debate over gun control. The controversy began after her vote against expanded background checks for commercial gun sales, which sparked a strong reaction from both pro-gun control activists and the National Rifle Association (NRA).

The senator's town hall meeting in Tilton, New Hampshire, ended with little discussion of the issue, but security had to intervene when two women approached Ayotte and demanded to speak with her about her vote. The incident underscored the ongoing controversy that continues to surround Ayotte.

Powerful outside groups, led by former Rep. Gabrielle Giffords and New York Mayor Michael Bloomberg, are pouring resources into the state to pressure Ayotte to reverse her opposition to the bill or face political consequences. The National Rifle Association, on the other hand, is running radio ads thanking Ayotte for her support.

The intense debate has transformed Ayotte into a polarizing figure in her home state, where she is now seen as a representative of gun rights. However, polls show strong support for expanded background checks among New Hampshire residents, which could hurt her political standing.

Ayotte is seeking a lower profile on the issue, but it seems unlikely that the controversy will subside anytime soon. The senator's office has not commented on the matter, but Ayotte herself acknowledged that the issue is a "mixed reaction" that both sides feel strongly about.

Title: Trump Unveils Economic Plan, Clinton Responds with Criticism

Article:

Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump unveiled his economic plan on Monday, promising to make America grow again and create jobs. Speaking at the Detroit Economic Club, Trump outlined his proposals, which include cutting taxes, simplifying the tax code, reducing corporate taxes, and allowing parents to fully deduct child care costs from their taxable income.

Trump's plan has been met with criticism from his Democratic opponent, Hillary Clinton, who called his proposals a re-packaging of old Republican ideas. Clinton accused Trump of relying on his economic advisors, including hedge fund managers and billionaires, to write his speech and make his ideas sound new.

Clinton, who has been touting her own economic plan, emphasized her commitment to creating jobs and supporting small businesses. She warned that Trump's proposals would actually reduce jobs, estimating that they would cost around 3.5 million jobs.

The latest national polls show Clinton leading Trump by double digits, but Trump's hour-long speech on the economy could be a sign that he is working to get his campaign back on track.

**Trump's Aide Hope Hicks Returns to White House as President Surrounds Himself with Loyalists**

Washington (AP) - Hope Hicks, one of President Donald Trump's most trusted and longest-serving aides, is returning to the White House as the president works to surround himself with loyalists ahead of his reelection campaign.

Hicks, a former White House communications director, will serve as counselor to the president, working with presidential son-in-law and senior adviser Jared Kushner. She left the White House in 2018 to work as a top executive at the Fox Corporation, but remained in touch with Trump.

The move comes just one week after Trump's acquittal by the Senate on impeachment charges. Since then, he has been working to clear his administration of those he sees as insufficiently loyal, including ousting staffers at the national security council and state department.

Hicks' return is part of Trump's effort to surround himself with longtime aides he believes he can trust as he heads into what is expected to be a bruising general election campaign to remain in the White House.

In addition to Hicks, Trump recently brought back John McEntee, another longtime staffer who began on the 2016 campaign as an intern and rose to become one of Trump's closest staffers. McEntee had served as Trump's personal aide until he was forced out of the White House in 2018 over issues with his security clearance.

Hicks' new role will not be part of the White House communications department, but she will work closely with Kushner and White House political director Brian Jack in various strategic areas. She is expected to start early next month, although details are still being worked out.

Hicks was part of the small inner circle that traveled the country with Trump aboard his private jet as he waged his unlikely campaign for the Republican nomination and then the presidency in 2015 and 2016. She was known for her loyalty and low public profile, often described as someone who was especially deft at reading the president's moods and helping others navigate his instincts.

The news of her decision was praised publicly by top administration officials, including Stephanie Grisham, the White House press secretary who also serves as the current White House communications director. "I have worked with Hope for almost six years and can say without hesitation she is one of the most talented and savvy individuals I have come across," Grisham said in a statement.

Title: President Trump Embarks on First Overseas Trip as Commander-in-Chief

President Donald Trump departed the United States on Friday, commencing his first overseas trip as commander-in-chief. The trip will take him to the Middle East and Europe, with a packed itinerary of meetings and events.

The president's first stop is Saudi Arabia, where he will participate in an arrival ceremony, meet with King Salman, and attend a royal banquet. He will also sign agreements solidifying U.S.-Saudi security and economic cooperation. Trump and First Lady Melania will join the Saudi royal family for an official dinner.

The next day, Trump will meet with leaders of the Gulf Cooperation Council and deliver a speech on the need to confront radical ideology. He will also participate in the inauguration of a center aimed at fighting radicalism and promoting moderation.

In Israel, Trump will meet with President Reuven Rivlin, lay a wreath at Yad Vashem, and deliver remarks at the Israeli Museum. He will also meet with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and attend a private dinner with the prime minister and his wife.

Trump will then visit the Vatican, where he will meet with Pope Francis and discuss issues of mutual concern. He will also tour St. Peter's and meet with Italian President Sergio Mattarella.

The president will also attend the 28th NATO summit in Brussels, Belgium, and the 43rd G7 summit in Taormina, Italy. During these meetings, he will press America's economic agenda and call for greater security cooperation.

Throughout his trip, Trump will also meet with various world leaders, including King Philippe and Queen Mathilde of Belgium, Prime Minister Charles Michel, and French President Emmanuel Macron. He will also deliver remarks at the unveiling of a NATO memorial and reaffirm the United States' commitment to NATO.

Title: House Republican Leaders Urge Senate to Act First on Fiscal Cliff Legislation

Article:

House Republican leaders, including Speaker John Boehner, Majority Leader Eric Cantor, Majority Whip Kevin McCarthy, and Conference Chairman Cathy McMorris Rodgers, have called on the Senate to take the lead on legislation to avert the fiscal cliff. In a statement, they emphasized that the Senate must act first, hinting that the House will not bring itself back into session until the Senate passes a bill.

The statement read: "If the Senate will not approve and send them to the president to be signed into law in their current form, they must be amended and returned to the House. Once this has occurred, the House will then consider whether to accept the bills as amended, or to send them back to the Senate with additional amendments." The House will consider the Senate's actions and decide whether to accept or reject the bills, but the Senate must act first.

Senate Democrats responded by saying that House Republicans should pass a bill extending tax rates for income below $250,000. "The Senate bill could pass tomorrow if House Republicans would simply let it come to the floor," said Adam Jentleson, a spokesman for Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid.

The stalemate over the fiscal cliff continues, with the House Republican leadership holding a conference call on Wednesday and all House Republican lawmakers set to have a conference call with leadership on Thursday. The call was limited to top GOP leaders, not the full House Republican conference, and no decisions were made.

The GOP position on the fiscal cliff is that Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid needs to move a bill to avert the fiscal cliff or else he's abdicating his duties. This stance will be repeated this week, according to aides. The fiscal cliff deadline is approaching, with tax rates set to jump on all income levels and federal spending cuts taking effect in a few days. Treasury Secretary Timothy Geithner has warned Congressional leadership that the nation's statutory borrowing cap will be hit on December 31, and "extraordinary measures" will allow the federal government to continue borrowing money for two months. However, the fiscal cliff standoff throws even this calculation into flux.

It remains to be seen whether the House will return to session before January 1, with sources saying it's still possible.

Title: California's Dominance in Tobacco Cessation Efforts Declines as Proposition 29 Faces Vote

California, once a leader in tobacco cessation efforts, is facing a decline in its dominance as 23 other states have passed tougher antismoking laws since 1998. The American Cancer Society has contributed over $7 million to get Proposition 29 passed, which would raise an estimated $735 million and increase the cigarette tax by 87 cents. The tax would not go towards closing the state's $16 billion deficit, as organizers argue that it would have less chance of passing if voters thought it would go into the state coffers.

The proposition is backed by the American Cancer Society, American Heart Association, and American Lung Association, among other groups, while Philip Morris USA and the R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Company are the leading contributors behind the effort to defeat it. The tax increase would aim to discourage smoking, particularly among teenagers, as raising the cost of tobacco has proved to be the most effective way to do so.

California's cigarette tax is currently about half the national average, ranking 33rd in the nation, and has not been increased since 1998. About 12% of Californians now smoke. Opponents of the proposition argue that the money raised would go out of state and have no legislative oversight, while supporters believe it would be a crucial step in reducing smoking rates.

The proposition's passage requires a simple majority from voters, and its outcome remains uncertain. Despite the challenges, organizers remain optimistic, citing the significant contributions from big tobacco companies as a sign of the importance of the issue.

Title: Obama Criticizes Trump's Fitness to Serve as President

Article:

Former President Barack Obama publicly criticized Donald Trump's ability to serve as president, calling him "unfit" to hold the office. Obama made the comments during a press conference at the White House, where he was joined by Singapore's Prime Minister. He expressed concern over Trump's repeated criticism of Muslim parents of a U.S. Army officer who was killed in the Iraq War, saying it was "unacceptable" and "not an episodic gaffe."

Obama also questioned why Republican leaders continue to support Trump, despite his divisive rhetoric and actions. "If you are repeatedly having to say in very strong terms that what he has said is unacceptable, why are you still endorsing him?" he asked. "There has to come a point at which you say, 'enough.'"

Trump responded to Obama's comments with a statement, criticizing the former president and Democratic nominee Hillary Clinton for their handling of the economy and foreign policy. He accused them of destabilizing the Middle East, allowing ISIS to gain a foothold, and failing to protect American personnel.

The exchange between Obama and Trump is the latest in a series of heated exchanges between the two politicians. Trump has been under fire for his comments about the parents of a fallen U.S. Army officer, who criticized Trump's proposal to temporarily ban Muslims from entering the U.S. Trump has also faced criticism for his response to the parents' comments, including his suggestion that the bereaved mother's initial silence was due to her religion.

While no Republican leaders have publicly dropped their endorsement of Trump, one congressman, Rep. Richard Hanna, announced he would vote for Clinton, citing Trump's comments on the Khan family.

Title: Former Intelligence Community Inspector General Details Intense Backlash from Clinton Allies During Email Investigation

The former Intelligence Community Inspector General, Charles McCullough III, has spoken publicly for the first time about his role in the Hillary Clinton email investigation during the Obama administration. In an exclusive interview with Fox News, McCullough revealed the intense backlash he and his team faced from Clinton allies, including threats to fire him if she won the 2016 election.

McCullough, who was appointed by the Obama administration with over two decades of experience at the FBI, Treasury, and intelligence community, discussed how quickly the probe was politicized and his office was marginalized by Democrats. He recalled receiving personal blowback, with some members of Congress warning him to be careful and suggesting he was losing credibility.

The former inspector general also shared that then-Director of National Intelligence James Clapper expressed concerns about the Clinton email findings, stating that it was "extremely reckless" and mentioning that the campaign would have "heartburn" about it. Clapper made these comments during an in-person meeting about a year before the presidential election.

McCullough's team was subsequently marginalized, and he was told to keep Clapper out of the loop. As one of the few people who viewed the 22 top-secret Clinton emails deemed too classified to release, McCullough emphasized that there was a "very good reason" to withhold those emails, citing potential harm to national security.

The article also mentions WikiLeaks documents showing the Clinton campaign formulating talking points as the review of 30,000 Clinton emails was ongoing. McCullough was critical of the campaign's response, stating that there was an effort to "mislead people into thinking that there was nothing to see here."

In March 2016, seven senior Democrats sent a letter to McCullough and his State Department counterpart, questioning the impartiality of the Clinton email review. However, McCullough was not making the decisions on what material in Clinton's emails was classified – he was passing along the findings of the individual agencies who got the intelligence and had final say on classification.

McCullough described a confrontation with Democratic Sen. Dianne Feinstein's office just six weeks before the election, amid pressure to respond to the letter. He also recalled being told by a source directly from the Clinton campaign that he and another senior government investigator would be the first two to be fired if Clinton won the election.

The article concludes with McCullough stating that he was just trying to do his job, which requires independence, and that he was a whistleblower in this context, explaining to Congress what he was doing during his confirmation hearing.

Title: Wisconsin and Minnesota Voters Choose Nominees for November's Congressional Elections

In the key battleground states of Wisconsin and Minnesota, voters chose nominees on Tuesday, setting the stage for what are expected to be tight races in November's congressional elections. In Wisconsin, state senator Leah Vukmir was tapped by Republicans to challenge incumbent Democratic U.S. Senator Tammy Baldwin, according to an Associated Press projection. Vukmir emerged victorious after a bruising primary fight with Kevin Nicholson, a U.S. Marine Corps veteran backed by conservatives such as Senator Ted Cruz of Texas and Steve Bannon, the former Trump political adviser.

In Minnesota, state senator Karen Housley was chosen by Republicans to take on Democratic incumbent U.S. Senator Tina Smith, appointed after former Senator Al Franken resigned last year amid sexual harassment accusations. The primaries in both states have set up what are expected to be competitive races, with Wisconsin helping drive Republican Donald Trump's surprising presidential win two years ago and Minnesota being a key battleground state.

All 435 U.S. House members and one-third of the Senate are running for re-election in November. Democrats need to add two Senate seats to seize control of that chamber, while in the House, they need to win 23 seats to take control, which would derail or stall much of Trump's policy agenda and increase congressional oversight and investigation of the administration.

In other news, Wisconsin Republicans also chose Bryan Steil, a former aide to Speaker Paul Ryan, to replace him in his seat in southeast Wisconsin. Steil will face Randy Bryce, an ironworker known on Twitter as "Iron Stache," in November. Wisconsin Democrats tapped Tony Evers, the state schools chief, to battle incumbent Republican Governor Scott Walker, who is seeking a third term. Whether Walker can survive the challenge will be closely watched, as another measure of Democratic intensity.

In Minnesota, Republicans picked state senator Jim Hagedorn to take on Democratic incumbent U.S. Representative Tim Walz, who is running for governor. The primaries in two House districts representing regions affected by Trump's trade policies could play a key role in determining control of Congress.

Title: Republican Party Faces Identity Crisis as Trump's Strong Performance on Super Tuesday Sets Him on Path to Nomination

The Republican Party is on the edge of a precipice, struggling to define its identity and future as Donald Trump's strong performance on Super Tuesday sets him on a firm path toward the Republican presidential nomination. Trump's victories on Tuesday, coupled with Hillary Clinton's strong performance on the Democratic side, have all but locked in their respective nominations.

The Trump juggernaut has effectively taken over the Republican Party, with many longtime Republicans and newcomers to politics jumping on board his message. However, this shift has raised concerns among Republican leaders, who have spent years trying to craft an image of a more welcoming and inclusive party. Trump's call for mass deportations of illegal immigrants and other incendiary rhetoric have been met with criticism, with some seeing his message as tinged with nativism and intolerance.

The party's conservative message on social issues, particularly its hostility to same-sex marriage, is falling out of favor, and views on healthcare are all over the map. Trump's rejection of free trade agreements and praise for Planned Parenthood are also at odds with traditional Republican orthodoxy.

Republican leaders have been hesitant to pass judgment on Trump, with many avoiding comment on his controversial statements and actions. House Speaker Paul Ryan spoke out against Trump's latest controversy, stating that the party does not prey on people's prejudices and appeals to their highest ideals. However, most Republican elected officials have declined to publicly criticize Trump, and some have even endorsed him.

The party's internal divisions are evident, with some Republicans, such as Senator Ben Sasse of Nebraska, rejecting Trump as the potential nominee. Senator Ted Cruz of Texas has won three contests, positioning him as Trump's main opponent going forward. However, even Cruz's victories have raised concerns among mainstream Republican leaders, who see him as a hard-line, no-compromise candidate.

The Republican Party's best hope may be for no candidate to reach the Republican National Convention with the majority of delegates required to secure the nomination, allowing party leaders to win over enough delegates for a more electable candidate. However, Trump has the momentum, and if he's the nominee, Republicans face ominous signs that he could have a hard time getting the turnout he needs to win.

Title: Markets Plummet Amid Fears of Escalating Trade War Between US and China

Markets experienced a significant downturn on Friday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling over 700 points, as concerns about a growing trade war between the United States and China intensified. The Dow recovered slightly before the end of trading, falling 572 points. The White House press secretary, Sarah Huckabee Sanders, attributed the tariffs imposed by the two economies to China's policies, while White House chief economic advisor Larry Kudlow claimed that the US is not in a trade war, but rather attempting to correct past wrongs.

The sense of escalating tensions mounted when President Trump announced a possible expansion of US tariffs on Chinese goods by $100 billion. This move would add to the $50 billion in tariffs already imposed in response to intellectual property concerns in China. The Auto Care Association's senior vice president, Aaron Low, expressed concern about the potential impact on the auto repair industry.

The American Chemistry Council's president and CEO, Cal Dooley, criticized the tariffs as misguided economic policy, stating that they target less competitive industries and harm the most competitive ones. Republicans have struggled to find a middle ground between Trump's aggressive trade stance and their own free trade orthodoxy.

The expanding list of potential tariffs has raised concerns about China's potential retaliation. China has already announced retaliation for the initial $53 billion in US tariffs and could respond to the new $100 billion if implemented. This would nearly equal total US exports to China. The potential for China to sell off its US debt holdings or make its currency artificially cheap could have negative growth implications.

The article also highlights the potential for China to target US financial, travel, and other services industries, as well as the US having a $38 billion trade surplus in services. The European Union has criticized Trump's tariffs and sought to close ranks with China, emphasizing the importance of preserving the rules-based multilateral trade order.

Title: Debbie Wasserman Schultz Supports Iran Nuclear Deal, Citing Intelligence and Security Concerns

Debbie Wasserman Schultz, the chairwoman of the Democratic National Committee, has announced her support for the Iran nuclear deal, stating that she believes it is the best option to prevent Iran from becoming a threshold nuclear state. In an interview with CNN's "State of the Union," Wasserman Schultz emphasized that she still has some concerns, but believes that the deal's opponents have not provided sufficient evidence to support an alternative plan.

The Florida representative, who is Jewish and represents a largely Jewish constituency, emphasized the importance of ensuring Israel's security and existence. She stated that she has been assured by intelligence officials that Iran will not be allowed to use its own inspectors to certify compliance with the deal.

Wasserman Schultz's decision to support the deal is seen as influential among other Democrats, as she is a leading Jewish lawmaker and head of the DNC. She has also spoken with President Barack Obama, who assured her that she will be part of a group of members in Congress working with the administration to develop an enhanced security package for Israel and to tighten enforcement of the deal.

The decision to support the deal has been a difficult one for many Jewish lawmakers, with some struggling to balance their concerns about Iran's nuclear program with their commitment to Israel's security. Vice President Joe Biden met with Jewish leaders in South Florida last week to urge them to support the deal, which he believes will put the U.S. in a stronger position to address concerns from Israel and Arab states about Iran's behavior in the region.

Not everyone agrees with Wasserman Schultz's decision, however. Former Vice President Dick Cheney has attacked the deal as a "major, major defeat" and compared it to the appeasement of Nazi Germany in the lead-up to World War II. He believes that the deal will shift the balance of power in the region and allow Iran to dominate its neighbors.

Former Secretary of State Colin Powell, on the other hand, has called the deal "a pretty good deal," stating that it has stopped Iran's nuclear program from moving forward and is a significant step towards preventing a nuclear-armed Iran.

Title: Kavanaugh's Confirmation to the Supreme Court Appears Inevitable, Vulnerable Democratic Senators Shouldn't Sacrifice Their Seats

Article:

The confirmation of Brett Kavanaugh to the Supreme Court is nearing its conclusion, with a few Republicans' thumbs-down votes appearing increasingly unlikely. Democratic activists are urging Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer to persuade vulnerable Democratic senators, such as Joe Manchin, Heidi Heitkamp, and Joe Donnelly, to vote against Kavanaugh. However, such a move would be a self-sacrificial act, as it would likely lead to the loss of their seats and diminish the Democratic Party's influence.

Given the significant margins by which Trump won the states represented by these senators, it is likely that voters will heed the president's urging to defeat those who oppose his Supreme Court nominee. Even if the senators were to vote against Kavanaugh, Trump would likely campaign against them, making their re-election prospects even more challenging.

The concerns about Kavanaugh's potential impact on issues like Roe v. Wade and the Affordable Care Act are legitimate, but the Supreme Court's dynamics are difficult to predict. While some speculate that a sharp turn to the right could lead to dysfunction, others believe Chief Justice Roberts may adjust his behavior to mitigate this.

In reality, the more likely outcome is the defeat of these vulnerable Democratic senators. If the Democrats were able to hold down their losses in the worst midterm environment in decades, it would serve as a constraint on the Republican majority and be especially significant if the Democrats become the majority in the House. However, this would require a significant shift in the political landscape.

It is unrealistic to demand politicians sacrifice their seats for the sake of political ideology. While Democratic activists may view votes for confirmation as a betrayal, it is crucial to recognize that politicians must prioritize their own survival and the well-being of their constituents. Senate leaders like Schumer must balance the demands of party loyalists with the harsh realities of political reality.

Title: Trump's Latest Claims Under Scrutiny: Fact-Checking the Republican Nominee's Statements

Donald Trump's latest speeches and statements have been met with scrutiny, as fact-checkers and journalists have been busy debunking his claims on various topics. From trade policies to his own campaign, Trump's words have been put to the test, and the results are not flattering.

In his speeches, Trump has made several claims that have been found to be exaggerated, contradicted, or simply untrue. For instance, he stated that subsidized foreign steel is "dumped" into the US market, threatening American factories. However, in 2015, the Obama administration imposed a 522% tariff on Chinese steel producers, and the US International Trade Commission launched an investigation into aluminum imports.

Trump also claimed that the US imports nearly $800 billion more in goods than it exports.
