While this is true, the US is largely a service-based economy, and its trade deficit has decreased significantly since 2015. Additionally, Trump's own company outsources manufacturing to China and Bangladesh, making suits and ties there and importing them to the US.

In his speech, Trump also invoked the founding fathers, stating that they understood trade better than current politicians. However, the founders had differing opinions on trade, with some, like Alexander Hamilton, supporting tariffs to protect American manufacturing, while others, like Thomas Jefferson, opposed them.

Trump also made claims about Hillary Clinton's role in the US-Korea Free Trade Agreement, stating that she "shoved" the deal through Congress. However, the agreement was signed by President George W. Bush in 2007, and Clinton opposed it as a candidate but supported it as Secretary of State.

Furthermore, Trump's proposal to suspend immigration from regions linked with terrorism has been met with criticism. He has repeatedly changed his stance on the issue, from a "total and complete shutdown" of Muslims entering the US to a more nuanced approach. The US already has a rigorous refugee acceptance process, involving vetting by the UN and multiple US security agencies.

In another instance, Trump claimed to know nothing about Hank Paulson, the former Treasury Secretary who endorsed Hillary Clinton. However, Trump praised Paulson by name in an interview with CNN in 2008.

Finally, Trump's claim that he has forgiven a large loan to his campaign has been disputed, with the Federal Election Commission confirming that it has no record of Trump converting loans to donations.

These examples illustrate the importance of fact-checking and scrutiny in politics. As the election season heats up, it is crucial that voters remain informed and critical of the claims made by candidates.

Title: Anti-Trump Groups Focus on Indiana as Crucial State in Presidential Election

The Club for Growth Action (CGFA), a major anti-Trump super-PAC, has spent at least $1.7 million on statewide TV advertising in Indiana, opposing Trump's candidacy. The group believes that Ted Cruz must win and will win Indiana, citing the state's importance in stopping Trump's momentum. Indiana is seen as a crucial state for Trump's presidential campaign, as it is one of the few remaining contests where he can accumulate delegates to secure the nomination.

Our Principles PAC, another anti-Trump group, is also targeting Indiana, spending at least $1 million on opposing Trump. The group's chairwoman, Katie Packer, stated that they have a "full-court press" in place, including a comprehensive TV buy, mail program, and digital efforts. Packer believes that if Trump wins Indiana, it will make their job much harder, as it would leave him needing fewer than 50 percent of the remaining delegates to secure the nomination.

Indiana holds a winner-take-most contest, with the statewide winner receiving 30 delegates and 27 more awarded through winner-take-all contests in each congressional district. Trump currently sits at 987 delegates, according to the Associated Press delegate tracker, and needs fewer than 50 percent of the remaining delegates to lock up the nomination. Both Cruz and Kasich are mathematically unable to reach that mark without a contested convention.

The anti-Trump movement is hoping to slow Trump's delegate accumulation in Indiana and ultimately stop him short in the June 7 California primary. If Cruz and the anti-Trump forces can keep Trump from reaching the 1,237 mark and convince unbound delegates not to push him over that threshold on the convention's first ballot, it would reset the contest.

Title: Federal Government Launches Campaign to Prevent Gun Violence, but Critics Question Enforcement Efforts

The federal government has launched a campaign to prevent gun violence, urging potential buyers to "don't lie for the other guy." The message aims to stop individuals with clean criminal records from buying firearms for felons who are legally prohibited from purchasing guns on their own. This initiative is part of a broader effort to adopt new gun control laws, including universal background checks and a ban on military-style rifles and large ammunition magazines.

However, recent studies have shown that the Obama administration has not enforced many gun laws already on the books. According to a Syracuse University study, gun crime prosecutions hit a decade low in 2011, down 40% from their peak under President George W. Bush in 2004. The study prompted 23 House Republicans to call on President Obama and Attorney General Eric Holder to prosecute more people for gun-related crimes.

The study found that the number of federal weapons prosecutions fell from around 11,000 in 2004 to around 6,000 under the Obama administration in 2011, and ticked up to 7,770 in 2012. The GOP letter also cited data from the National Criminal Justice Reference Service (NCJRS), which found that in 2010, less than 2% of the 6 million Americans who applied to buy a gun were denied. Of those denied, the ATF referred 4,732 cases for prosecution, but only 44 were prosecuted, and only 13 were punished for lying or buying a gun illegally.

Critics argue that the Obama administration has not prioritized enforcing existing gun laws, and that the focus should be on prosecuting individuals who lie on forms or buy guns illegally, rather than those who are simply denied. Justice Department sources argue that the attorney general has finite resources and prefers to prosecute prohibited persons who obtain guns illegally, rather than those who simply lie on forms.

A source also noted that "lie and try" cases have little jury appeal, as they are essentially about lying on a form where the individual was ultimately denied the ability to purchase the gun. Prosecutions for making a false statement when buying a gun are down 29% from five years ago, while prosecutions for illegal possession are down 14%, according to federal data. Penalties are also light, with data compiled by the U.S. attorney's office showing that a third of those charged with gun crimes serve no jail time, and those who do typically serve one to four years of a possible 10-year sentence for lying or illegally possessing a firearm.

Some lawmakers, including Republican Rep. Scott Rigell of Virginia, are proposing a bill to make straw purchases a federal crime and increase the penalty from 10 to 20 years. Rigell argues that when four out of 10 straw buyers suffer no meaningful consequences for their actions, there is a problem.

Title: Gitmo Detainees to be Transferred to Undisclosed African Country, Pentagon Announces

The United States Department of Defense has announced that a new round of Guantanamo Bay detainee transfers will begin this weekend, with two detainees being sent to an undisclosed country in Africa. This comes after the Pentagon conducted a bulk transfer of 10 detainees in January, the largest transfer to date.

According to a U.S. official, the transfers are being carried out in compliance with a 30-day notification period required by law. The first notification was sent to Congress in early March, and the second notification was sent in the middle of this month. The transfers are expected to continue in the middle of next month, with a total of about a dozen detainees being transferred.

There are currently 91 detainees remaining at Guantanamo Bay, with 35 having been cleared to transfer to other countries. The Pentagon has not confirmed the transfer of any detainees beginning this weekend, but a defense department spokesman stated that the administration is committed to reducing the detainee population and closing the detention facility responsibly.

In the past, the Pentagon has only confirmed detainee transfers once they are completed, with detainees flying in US military aircraft to their third-party nation. However, in a recent revelation, the Pentagon's point man for Gitmo stated that some of the transferred detainees have re-joined the fight and worse.

Congressman Dana Rohrabacher, R-Calif., asked Paul Lewis, the defense department's envoy for the prison, how many lives have been lost after detainees had been transferred. Lewis replied that unfortunately, there have been Americans who have died because of Gitmo detainees.

The Pentagon has released new statistics showing that the number of former Gitmo detainees suspected of re-engaging in terrorism has doubled from six to 12. Senator John McCain refuted the administration's statistics, stating that he believes more released Gitmo detainees return to the battlefield, putting more American lives at risk.

The Pentagon has also submitted a plan to transfer those detainees not eligible for transfer overseas to American prisons in Colorado, Kansas, or South Carolina. However, the plan was immediately rejected by Congress, who passed a law forbidding the transfer of any Gitmo detainees to the United States.

In a recent statement, President Obama vowed to close the prison, stating that it is viewed as a stain on our broader record of upholding the highest standards of rule of law. However, critics in Congress point out that in addition to keeping terrorists from returning to the fight, they also demand a plan for handling ISIS detainees, now that a 200-man special operations task force fighting ISIS has recently killed the group's second-in-command.

The U.S. military has no plans to hold captured Islamic State operatives for more than a month before turning them over to the Iraqi government, according to a U.S.-led coalition spokesman based in Baghdad. The lack of a well-defined policy for handling captured ISIS terrorists is raising concerns on Capitol Hill, with a congressional aide stating that the law requires a comprehensive detainee policy.

Title: FBI Director Mueller Testifies on IRS Investigation and Surveillance Programs

Article:

FBI Director Robert Mueller testified before the House Judiciary Committee on Thursday, facing questions from lawmakers on various topics, including the IRS investigation into the targeting of Tea Party and conservative groups, and the government's surveillance programs. Rep. Jim Jordan, R-Ohio, pressed Mueller for details on the IRS probe, citing the lack of transparency and accountability. Mueller declined to provide specific information, citing the ongoing nature of the investigation.

Mueller also defended the government's collection of millions of U.S. phone records, emails, and other information, stating that it is vital to national security. He argued that law enforcement must stay ahead of criminals and terrorists while respecting the civil liberties of Americans. However, Judiciary Committee Chairman John Conyers Jr. expressed skepticism, stating that the argument does not justify collecting information on every call and that it would lead to an "anything and everything goes" situation.

The FBI chief also testified on the government's controversial surveillance programs, which were recently revealed to have gathered emails of Fox News correspondent James Rosen and phone records of The Associated Press. Mueller maintained that the programs complied with U.S. law and the Constitution. The Justice Department had previously acknowledged that Attorney General Eric Holder was involved in a search warrant for Rosen's personal emails, obtained after federal officials accused him of being a likely criminal "co-conspirator" under the Espionage Act.

The committee also discussed the investigation into the Boston Marathon bombings, with lawmakers seeking to know whether there was a breakdown in information-sharing between federal agencies, preventing the FBI from thwarting the explosions that killed three people and injured over 260.

Title: Supreme Court Blocks Voting Law Changes in Several States Ahead of Election Day

The Supreme Court has intervened in several voting law disputes in the days leading up to the November elections, blocking changes in Arkansas, Ohio, Wisconsin, and North Carolina. In Texas, a civil rights group has asked the court to block the state's voter ID law, while a case involving Arizona and Kansas's proof of citizenship requirement is pending.

In Arkansas, the state's Supreme Court struck down the voter ID law, which had been stayed pending appeal. The court found that requiring voters to show a photo ID imposed a new qualification for voting, violating the state's constitution.

In Ohio, the U.S. Supreme Court voted 5-4 to block a lower court ruling that would have prevented the state from cutting back its early-voting period. The decision means that Ohio voters will have to wait a week before early voting begins, and early voting will no longer be available during evening hours and on Sundays. Opponents argued that the cuts would disproportionately affect minority voters.

In North Carolina, the U.S. Supreme Court stayed a federal appeals court decision to block part of the state's new voting law, which eliminates same-day voter registration and prohibits counting ballots cast in the wrong precinct. Two justices, Ruth Bader Ginsburg and Sonia Sotomayor, dissented, with Ginsburg noting that the appeals court found the law "risked significantly reducing opportunities for black voters."

In Wisconsin, the U.S. Supreme Court blocked a federal appeals court ruling that had allowed the state's voter ID law to go into effect this year. The law had been on hold, and the court's decision means that Wisconsin voters will not have to show a photo ID at the polls.

In Texas, civil rights groups have asked the U.S. Supreme Court to block the state's new voter ID law, which one of the strictest in the nation. A decision is expected soon. The law was found unconstitutional by a federal judge, who said it placed a disproportionate burden on black and Hispanic voters.

In Arizona and Kansas, a case is pending involving a requirement that voters show proof of citizenship when registering to vote. The states are suing to get the federal government to change its registration form to reflect the requirement. If the case is not resolved before Election Day, voters in those states who used the federal registration form and have not shown proof of citizenship may not be allowed to vote in state and local elections.

The Supreme Court has shown a reluctance to allow major voting changes to be put in place right before an election. However, it has not ruled on whether these laws are constitutional, and a decision is expected after the election, possibly next year.

Title: Car Firms Pivot Production to Manufacture Ventilators and Face Masks Amidst Coronavirus Pandemic

Car manufacturers around the world are answering calls from governments to help increase production of ventilators and face masks to combat the spread of the coronavirus pandemic. Fiat, General Motors, Ford, Tesla, Nissan, and Formula 1 teams in the UK are among the companies pledging their support to produce vital medical equipment.

Fiat has already begun converting one of its car plants in China to produce approximately one million masks per month, with production expected to start in the coming weeks. Ford is working with GE Healthcare and 3M to design modified respirators and ventilators, using parts typically used in its cars. The company has also started producing transparent face shields, with the first 1,000 units set to be delivered to Detroit-area hospitals this week.

In the United States, President Donald Trump has given the green light for Ford, General Motors, and Tesla to produce ventilators and other medical products, with a tweet stating, "Ford, General Motors and Tesla are being given the go ahead to make ventilators and other metal products, FAST! Go for it auto execs, let's see how good you are?"

The US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) has reduced barriers in the medical device approval process to speed up the production of ventilators. Medical device makers can now make changes to existing products or repurpose production lines to increase supply.

However, some experts have warned that carmakers may not find it easy to switch production. Jens Hallek, head of ventilator manufacturer Hamilton Medical, noted that the materials and components needed to build a ventilator are "highly specific" and require "specialized know-how." Former US Defense Department officials told the Washington Post that it could take more than a year for carmakers or aerospace factories to start making ventilators.

Meanwhile, Tesla CEO Elon Musk announced that he had purchased 1,255 ventilators from China and had them shipped to Los Angeles. Formula 1 teams in the UK are also working with the government and health authorities to increase the supply of medical equipment, while Nissan is part of a consortium developing a new medical ventilator.

The Mahindra Group, an Indian conglomerate, has also pledged to explore how its factories can produce ventilators. With the world's largest tractor maker and India's biggest electric vehicle manufacturer, the company is well-positioned to make a significant contribution to the global effort.

Title: Interest Rates on Federally Subsidized Student Loans Double, Potentially Costing Students $2,600

The interest rates on federally subsidized Stafford student loans have increased from 3.4% to 6.8% after Congress failed to reach a deal. The Joint Economic Committee estimates that this change will cost the average college student an additional $2,600 unless a bill is passed to reverse the decision. The hike has sparked debate among lawmakers, with Democrats seeking to keep interest rates low to help poor and middle-class students access higher education, while Republicans propose linking student loans to financial markets.

The Senate Joint Economic Committee estimates that the interest rate increase will cost students an average of $2,600. Democrats have pushed to keep interest rates low, citing the need for affordable education for low-income and middle-class students. Republicans, on the other hand, have proposed tying student loan rates to the 10-year Treasury note yield, which President Obama included in his budget proposal earlier this year.

Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell's spokesman, Don Stewart, expressed optimism that Democrats will join a bipartisan effort to assist students. However, Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid's spokesman, Adam Jentleson, stated that a proposal to tie loan rates to the 10-year Treasury note yield would not pass the Senate without stronger protections for students and parents.

The Senate is expected to consider voting on a one-year extension of the current interest rates on July 10, after a recess for the 4th of July holiday. However, Senator Elizabeth Warren has expressed a preference for including a comprehensive student loan measure in a long-range law governing colleges and universities. She emphasized the need for a one-year patch to keep interest rates from doubling on student loans, which would buy time for a more comprehensive solution.

Title: House Speaker John Boehner Expresses Uncertainty Over Sequester's Impact

House Speaker John Boehner has expressed uncertainty over the potential impact of the $85 billion in spending cuts, also known as the sequester, which took effect on Friday. In an interview on NBC's "Meet the Press," Boehner stated that he does not know whether the cuts will have a negative impact on the economy, although he had previously warned that the sequester would threaten U.S. national security and thousands of jobs.

Boehner blamed Democrats and President Barack Obama for not acting to avoid the cuts, which were the result of a 2011 agreement between the two parties. He expressed concern about the impact on the economy and the military, stating that the problem has been known for 16 months.

In contrast, President Obama's tone during a press conference at the White House on Friday was more measured. He acknowledged that not everyone will feel the immediate effects of the cuts, but emphasized that the pain will be real, particularly for middle-class families. The president's administration had previously warned of dire consequences if the sequester took effect.

Boehner questioned the accuracy of some claims made by the administration, including Education Secretary Arne Duncan's statement that teachers in West Virginia were being laid off due to the spending cuts. The claim has since been debunked. The House Speaker also expressed skepticism about the White House's communication strategy on the sequester.

The sequester, which is expected to continue for the remainder of the fiscal year, has sparked intense debate and rhetoric from both sides of the aisle.

Title: Study Reveals Importance of Blood Sugar Control for People with Type 2 Diabetes in COVID-19 Patients

A recent study published in the journal Cell Metabolism has found that people with Type 2 diabetes who maintain control over their blood sugar levels fare much better if they become infected with the novel coronavirus. The study, which examined a cohort of 7,336 COVID-19 patients with or without Type 2 diabetes from 19 hospitals in Hubei Province, China, found that those with well-controlled blood sugar levels had a significantly lower mortality rate and fewer health complications compared to those with poorly controlled blood sugar.

The study's senior author, Hongliang Li, noted that the findings were "surprising" and highlighted the importance of controlling blood sugar levels for people with Type 2 diabetes during the pandemic. The research showed that people with Type 2 diabetes who had COVID-19 required more medical interventions and had a higher incidence of multiple organ injury, but those with well-controlled blood sugar levels had fewer medical interventions and fewer health complications.

Experts emphasize that risk factors for dying from COVID-19 include the prevalence of diabetes, obesity, and hypertension. The virus has disproportionately affected African-American and Hispanic communities in several states, with experts attributing this to issues with health access and resources. The American Diabetes Association's president and CEO, Tracey Brown, noted that "those with the fewest resources are the least likely to have access to quality health care, and COVID-19 testing is no exception."

The study's findings offer a few key messages for people with Type 2 diabetes: they should take extra precautions to avoid becoming infected with COVID-19 due to the higher risk of severe complications or dying after being infected, and those with diabetes should take extra care to keep their blood sugar under good control during the pandemic.

Title: Florida's COVID-19 Cases Surge, Governor DeSantis Faces Criticism for Handling of Pandemic

Florida has become the new epicenter of COVID-19 infections, with over 200,000 cases and over 3,731 deaths reported as of July 6. The state's hospitals are struggling to cope with the surge, with three acute-care hospitals in Southwest Florida having no available intensive-care unit beds for adults. In Miami-Dade County, authorities are debating whether to allow lap dances at strip clubs, while hospitals are cutting back on elective surgeries.

Governor Ron DeSantis has faced criticism for his handling of the pandemic, with some accusing him of being incompetent and mediocre. DeSantis has signed several bills into law, including SB 664: Verification of Employment Eligibility, which requires businesses to use the E-Verify program to discriminate against immigrants. This bill was passed despite warnings from immigrant rights organizations that it would intimidate undocumented immigrants and cause them to avoid contact with government institutions.

DeSantis has also been accused of prioritizing his deportation agenda, which has been criticized by immigrant rights organizations. In the previous legislative session, he passed a "show me your papers" bill that enhanced cooperation between immigration enforcement and local police. This bill was seen as a way to further Trump's deportation agenda.

The governor's handling of the pandemic has been criticized for being inadequate, with some accusing him of improvising, falsifying data, and blaming others for his failures. DeSantis has refused to take steps to mitigate the spread of the virus, such as closing down non-essential businesses, which has helped bring the virus under control in other states.

In a recent press conference, DeSantis said that the state is not going back to lockdowns and that people going to businesses is not driving the spread of the virus. He also refused to commit to encouraging people to stay home or wear masks.

The situation in Florida is dire, with hospitals overwhelmed and thousands of new cases reported every week. The state's residents are struggling to access unemployment benefits and are frustrated with the governor's handling of the pandemic. The November elections cannot come soon enough for many Floridians who are desperate for change.

Title: US Economy Sees Strongest Quarter of Growth Since 2003

The United States economy has experienced its strongest quarter of growth since 2003, with the gross domestic product (GDP) soaring 5% on an annual basis in the third quarter, according to the government's latest data. This marks an upgrade from the Commerce Department's initial estimate of 3.9% growth.

The strong growth was driven by across-the-board increases in business investment, consumer spending, housing, exports, and government spending. Consumer spending, in particular, showed a healthy pace of 3.2%, up from previous estimates of 2.2%. With gas prices remaining low, many expect this trend to continue through the holiday season.

Defense spending was also a significant contributor to the third quarter's growth, surging 16%. The strong growth marks an acceleration from the 4.6% growth during the second quarter and the -2.1% contraction in the first quarter, which was affected by harsh winter weather.

The solid growth has led to increased hiring, with employers adding 321,000 jobs in November, making 2014 the strongest year for job growth since 1999. The strong economy could clear the path for the Federal Reserve to increase interest rates in 2015, a move that would signal the economy is strong enough to withstand the change.

The American public appears to be taking notice of the positive economic headlines, with a new CNN/ORC poll showing that for the first time in seven years, more than half of Americans believe the economy is in good shape. However, it's worth noting that new data released on Tuesday showed that orders for big-ticket items unexpectedly declined in November, suggesting businesses may be hitting the brakes on investment.

Title: Gun-Rights Activists File Lawsuit to Block Maryland's New Gun Law

Maryland gun-rights activists have filed a federal lawsuit to block the state's new gun law, which is set to take effect on October 1. The lawsuit, filed in the U.S. District Court in Maryland, argues that the Second Amendment and case law protect the right to own assault rifles and magazines that hold more than 10 rounds. The plaintiffs include the Maryland Licensed Firearms Dealers Association, the Maryland State Rifle and Pistol Association, the National Shooting Sports Foundation, Associated Gun Clubs of Baltimore, and several other organizations, individuals, and gun shops.

The new law, passed by Maryland lawmakers earlier this year, bans 45 types of assault weapons, but allows current owners to keep them. The law also limits handgun magazines to 10 rounds and requires people to submit fingerprints to the state police to get a license to buy a handgun. The plaintiffs are seeking an injunction to prevent the law from taking effect.

A spokeswoman for the National Rifle Association told The Baltimore Sun that lawyers for the plaintiffs plan to ask a judge for an injunction on Friday. A spokeswoman for Governor Martin O'Malley, a Democrat, said she expects the law to withstand the legal challenge. "The vast majority of Marylanders support these common-sense efforts to reduce gun violence," she said. "The new law will take effect on Tuesday, and it will make families safer."

John Josselyn, legislative vice president of the Associated Gun Clubs of Baltimore, said in a statement that the restrictions are "an unconstitutional violation" of the Second Amendment rights of "law-abiding, responsible citizens." "Together we are drawing a line in the sand where Maryland's gun control agenda tramples the fundamental individual right to defend oneself and family in the home," he said.

The pending new law has prompted a huge increase in applications for firearm purchases, resulting in a backlog. In the last two weeks, state troopers said applications are coming in at a rate of 1,000 per day. Maryland State Police said residents who have submitted handgun purchase applications before the new requirements go into effect next week will not have to obtain a handgun qualification license. The agency said troopers will not enforce the new requirements, which also include background checks and fingerprinting, on applications submitted by September 30.

As of Friday, slightly more than half of the more than 100,000 purchase applications received had been processed. The agency began 24/7 operations in December to process the applications, but the backlog continued to grow. Earlier this month, state police said 20 law enforcement officers from other agencies began helping with background investigations. State law requires that the investigations be conducted by police officers. Troopers also said that beginning last week, 24 data entry employees from the Maryland Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services have been inputting information from applications. State police said several security measures were being taken to limit the access of DPSCS employees to the State Police database.

**Las Vegas Shooting Investigation Continues: Girlfriend Questioned, No Motive Established**

The investigation into the deadliest mass shooting in modern US history continues, with authorities questioning the girlfriend of the gunman, Stephen Paddock, and searching for any potential accomplices. Marilou Danley, 62, returned to the US from the Philippines on Tuesday night and was questioned by the FBI on Wednesday. In a written statement, Danley said she had no idea Paddock was planning violence against anyone.

Danley, an Australian citizen of Filipino heritage, said she flew back to the US voluntarily to cooperate with the investigation. She stated that Paddock never gave her any indication that he was planning something like this and that she knew him as a "kind, caring, quiet man."

The FBI is investigating whether Paddock had any accomplices, with Sheriff Joseph Lombardo saying it's difficult to believe that he assembled the arsenal of weapons and explosives on his own. Lombardo stated that the attack was the obvious outcome of meticulous planning.

The investigation has recovered nearly 50 firearms from three locations, including 12 rifles fitted with bump stocks, which allowed them to be fired almost as though they were automatic weapons. The FBI is also examining the possibility that Paddock's purchase of over 30 guns in October 2016 may have been precipitated by some triggering event in his life.

Paddock's girlfriend, Marilou Danley, was questioned about his weapons purchases, a $100,000 wire transfer to a Philippine bank, and whether she saw any changes in his behavior before she left the US. Danley said Paddock had bought her an airline ticket to visit her family and wired her money to purchase property there, leading her to worry he might be planning to break up with her.

The investigation is ongoing, with no motive established yet. The FBI is working to determine whether Paddock acted alone or had any accomplices.

Title: Trump and Biden Campaigns Announce Massive Fundraising Totals Ahead of Election Day

The campaigns of President Trump and challenger Joe Biden have announced their fundraising totals for the three months ending June 30, with Biden's campaign surpassing Trump's in both overall and monthly totals. Trump's campaign and the Republican National Committee raised $266 million, including $131 million in June, while Biden's campaign and the Democratic National Committee brought in $282 million during the same period, with $141 million in June alone.

This marks the second consecutive month that Biden's campaign has outraised Trump's. It is unusual for a challenger's campaign to raise more money than an incumbent president's, but Biden's campaign has been gaining momentum, with a strong focus on small donors and online fundraising. The average online donation in June was $34, with the campaign touting its growth in small donors.

Trump's campaign, on the other hand, has a significant cash-on-hand war chest of $295 million, thanks to its early start and fundraising efforts. The campaign is focused on defending states won by Trump in 2016, reserving nearly $100 million worth of ad time in Arizona, Florida, North Carolina, Ohio, Pennsylvania, and Wisconsin. The campaign is also buying ads in Georgia, Michigan, and Iowa.

While neither candidate appears to have the 270 electoral votes needed to win the presidency, Biden is closer to reaching that threshold, with at least one state Trump previously won, Michigan, leaning his way. The president has failed to make progress in states won by Democrat Hillary Clinton in 2016.

Title: House Speaker Pelosi Announces No Vote on Impeachment Proceedings Against President Trump

House Speaker Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.) announced on Tuesday evening that the lower chamber will not hold a vote on whether to launch formal impeachment proceedings against President Donald Trump. Pelosi stated that there is no requirement for a vote and that the House will not be holding one at this time. She emphasized that the goal is to find the truth and uphold the Constitution, rather than engaging in a "game" or "bluffing."

The decision comes after the White House informed the House last week that it would not cooperate with the ongoing probe, citing the lack of a floor vote to authorize the proceedings. In an 8-page letter to Pelosi and other top Democrats, Counsel to the President Pat Cipollone argued that the House has never launched an impeachment inquiry without a majority vote to authorize it.

Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-Ky.) criticized the House Democrats for abandoning due process, stating that they are "indulging in their three-year-old impeachment obsession" and "lowering the bar" in their pursuit of the president. McConnell reminded his colleagues that some Democrats had declared their plans to impeach Trump before he was even inaugurated, and that the House Democrats have no intention of letting norms, precedents, or due process stand in the way of their efforts to "cancel out" the presidency.

**China's November Exports and Imports Show Slower Global and Domestic Demand**

China's exports and imports in November showed a weaker-than-expected performance, indicating a slowdown in global and domestic demand. According to Chinese customs data, exports rose 5.4% from a year earlier, the weakest performance since March, and fell short of the 10% forecast in a Reuters poll.

The export data showed that the "front-loading" impact, where firms rushed to ship goods before planned U.S. tariff hikes, has faded, and export growth is likely to slow further as demand cools. China's major trading partners, including the United States, the European Union, and South Korea, saw significant slowdowns in export growth.

Imports grew 3%, the slowest since October 2016, and a fraction of the 14.5% seen in the poll. Iron ore imports fell for the second time, reflecting waning restocking demand at steel mills as profit margins narrow.

Analysts say the sluggish imports show a significant pullback in domestic demand. The soft imports and exports indicate a deterioration in China's economic outlook, which may prompt policymakers to take more measures to keep the country's growth rate from slipping too much.

The November trade numbers came out less than a week after Presidents Donald Trump and Xi Jinping agreed to a 90-day truce delaying a planned U.S. tariff hike on Chinese goods. The arrest of Huawei Technologies' top executive, Meng Wanzhou, in Canada has raised concerns about a potential reignition of trade tensions.

Despite the concerns, U.S. President Donald Trump sounded an optimistic note about trade negotiations with China, saying "China talks are going very well." Analysts at Haitong Securities in Shanghai noted that growth in shipments of Chinese goods on the U.S. tariff list has started to pull back, indicating that front-loading effects may be starting to recede.

China's trade surplus with the United States was a record $35.55 billion in November, while its imports from the U.S. fell 25% from a year earlier. The yuan's weakening against the dollar has helped make Chinese products more competitive abroad, which may boost industrial exports in the coming months.

Economists have penciled in a deterioration in China's export outlook in 2019, factoring in higher U.S. tariffs on a wider range of Chinese goods. Chinese policymakers are expected to offer more policy support and deliver more support measures if domestic and external conditions continue to deteriorate.

Title: Constitutional Moments: The Erosion of the Independence of Law Enforcement and the Rise of the Administrative State

The concept of "constitutional moments" was proposed by Yale Law School professor Bruce Ackerman, who suggests that constitutions can change not only through the formal amendment process but also when prominent political actors act contrary to the existing constitution, with the people accepting and validating their actions. This idea is not appealing to originalists, who believe that the only legitimate way to change the Constitution is through the Article V process.

The current political climate is characterized as a "constitutional moment" by Harvard Law School professor Noah Feldman, who argues that the firing of FBI Director James Comey by President Trump is a crisis of American rule of law. Feldman notes that while Trump was technically within his constitutional rights, the real law is not the written words on parchment but the law in action that has developed under our living constitution.

The article highlights the development of an unwritten norm that certain aspects of government are too important to be monkeyed with by democratically elected politicians. This norm has led to the rise of the "administrative state," where career bureaucrats see themselves as above politics and believe they are running the country. Temporary occupants of political office offend the careerists at their peril, as seen in the case of Scott Pruitt, who was forced from office due to ethical lapses.

The current constitutional moment is about who is running the country: the elected president or the "swamp" that he promised to drain. The game plan for the new constitutional order was laid out by James Comey, who argued that while the president may fire him for any reason or for no reason at all, if he does so for what a majority of the House considers an inappropriate reason, that's an impeachable offense.

The article concludes that if we start removing presidents from office for the thought crime of taking actions that are well within their official powers under the Constitution but with motives that the opposition considers inappropriate, it will be a constitutional moment of fundamental significance. The rise of the administrative state and the erosion of the independence of law enforcement are significant issues that will shape the future of American governance.

Title: San Bernardino Considers Legalizing Medical Marijuana to Crack Down on Illegal Dealers

San Bernardino, a city in California, is exploring the idea of legalizing medical marijuana to raise revenue and crack down on illegal dealers. The city's decision was sparked by concerns about the proliferation of illegal medical marijuana dispensaries, which have been a thorn in the side of local authorities. By legalizing and regulating the industry, the city hopes to generate millions of dollars in revenue and have a say in who operates these businesses.

The city's plan is still in its exploratory phase, with a legislative review panel collecting data and examining laws in other jurisdictions before bringing a proposal to the full City Council. The panel plans to hold at least two more public meetings on the subject through August.

City Attorney Gary Saenz emphasized that the goal is to close down illegal shops, not to promote the use of marijuana. He noted that police have reported as many as 20 illegal storefronts in the city at any given time, and that legalizing and regulating the industry is one of the tools available to the city to take control.

City Council member James Mulvihill supports the idea, citing the financial benefits and the difficulty of shutting down illegal dealers. He believes that permitting a limited number of dispensaries, with fees and taxes, could generate significant revenue for the city. Mulvihill noted that the city has not received much negative feedback since the idea was made public.

The city's mayor, R. Carey Davis, prefers not to see marijuana dispensaries in the city, but is open to exploring options to combat the current problems. The city's chief of staff, Michael McKinney, emphasized that any funds generated from the regulation and tax of marijuana dispensaries would be used exclusively for enforcement.

San Bernardino is one of 200 California municipalities that have maintained an outright ban on pot shops since medical marijuana was made legal in 1996. However, the city's financial struggles, including its bankruptcy in 2012, have led officials to reconsider their stance.

Title: Cuba Enters Uncharted Territory After the Death of Fidel Castro

Cuba has entered a period of official mourning following the death of Fidel Castro, the longtime dictator who ruled the island nation from 1959 until his retirement in 2008. Castro's death has left a power vacuum, with his brother Raul Castro, who has been in power since then, taking the reins. The country is experiencing a subdued atmosphere, with bars and discotheques closed, and a general sense of uncertainty about what the future holds.

Fidel Castro's role in Cuban life had diminished significantly in recent years, with him making only a few public appearances, including two notable instances in 2016. In March, he condemned the historic visit of President Obama to Cuba, stating that it was not in accordance with the warming of relations between the two countries. A month later, he appeared on national television, praising communism and stating that Cuba did not need the United States.

Despite his reduced public presence, Castro remained a significant figure in Cuban life, with many Cubans holding him in high esteem. However, opinions about his legacy are divided, with some viewing him as a revolutionary leader who brought about significant social and economic changes, while others see him as a dictator who ruled through oppression.

The death of Fidel Castro has sparked a range of emotions among Cubans, with some expressing sadness and loss, while others are relieved that he is no longer in power. The country is now facing an uncertain future, with many wondering what changes will come about without Castro's influence. While Raul Castro has been in power for over a decade, there is a sense of uncertainty about what the future holds, particularly in terms of economic reforms and human rights.

As Cuba enters this uncharted territory, it remains to be seen what the future holds for the island nation.

Title: French President Emmanuel Macron Addresses Congress, Urges Global Cooperation and Caution Against Isolationism

Article:

French President Emmanuel Macron addressed the United States Congress on Wednesday, praising the country's global leadership against various threats while urging it to remain vigilant and avoid isolationism. Macron's speech was a rare address to lawmakers from both the House and Senate, and it highlighted the strong relationship between the two leaders.

Macron emphasized the importance of global cooperation and warned against the dangers of isolationism and nationalism, which he believes are only temporary solutions that would "not douse, only inflame, the fears of our citizens." He urged the U.S. not to "close the door to the world" and instead work together to address global challenges.

The French president also touched on several pressing global issues, including Russian aggression, the Syrian civil war, climate change, North Korea, and the Iran nuclear deal. Macron has been a strong advocate for the deal, which imposed restrictions on Iran's nuclear programs in exchange for lifting international economic sanctions. However, he seemed to move closer to President Trump's critique of the agreement, stating that it should not be abandoned until a more substantial alternative is developed.

Macron also addressed the Paris climate agreement, which President Trump canceled in 2017, saying he was confident the U.S. will rejoin the accord. He made a direct reference to Trump's "Make America Great Again" campaign pledge, saying "Let us work together to make our planet great again and create new jobs and new opportunities while safeguarding our earth."

The French president also discussed terrorism, lamenting the multiple attacks in the U.S. and Europe over the past five years and emphasizing the need for shared efforts to combat extremism. He warned against the spread of "fake news" and the corruption of information, saying "without reason, without truth, there is no real democracy."

Macron's speech was met with a standing ovation and applause from lawmakers, with some Republicans and Democrats expressing differing opinions on certain issues. The French president's visit to the U.S. has been marked by a strong relationship with President Trump, with the two leaders sharing a tour of monuments and a review of U.S. troops.

Title: Iran's Leaders Fear a Revival of the Green Movement, and the US Response

The Iranian government's primary concern is the potential revival of the Green Movement, which nearly toppled the regime after the 2009 presidential election. According to Omid Memarian of the Center for Human Rights in Iran, the authorities' ferocity in persecuting human rights lawyers reflects their fear of exposure and desire to evade accountability. The task of reviving the Green Movement has been made more challenging due to the Trump administration's indifference to human rights issues and its rhetoric and policy towards migrants.

The article also suggests that the US may be witnessing the beginning of the end of the American era in the Middle East. The Trump administration's willingness to support the House of Saud, despite its human rights abuses, and its reluctance to re-establish deterrence with Tehran through a limited military reprisal, may be seen as a sign of a shift in US foreign policy. This could be music to the ears of America's quasi-isolationists, but it may also frighten traditional Middle Eastern allies.

The article highlights the importance of the US response to an unprovoked attack on Saudi Arabia, a central pillar of the global economy. The consequences of failure will be felt for years to come.

Title: Obama and Republicans Diverge on Lessons from Fiscal Cliff Deal

The recent agreement to avert the "fiscal cliff" has left President Obama and congressional Republicans with sharply different lessons to take into the next round of budget negotiations. The deal, which raised taxes on the wealthy and extended unemployment benefits, has set a precedent for deficit reduction and federal spending, according to the President. However, many Republicans see the agreement as a victory for the President and are now focused on achieving spending cuts.

The deal, which was passed by the House on Tuesday, postpones steep automatic spending cuts until March 1, giving the White House and Congress less than two months to agree on an alternative solution to reduce deficits. The agreement also sets a precedent for future deals, with the President stating that "everyone pays their fair share" and that the deficit needs to be reduced in a way that is balanced.

However, Republicans argue that the agreement gave the President all the tax increases he will get and that future deals must emphasize spending cuts. Some Republicans are willing to force a government shutdown to make their point in negotiations over raising the nation's borrowing limit, which the President said he will no longer debate.

The next fiscal deadline is March 31, when temporary legislation to keep the government running is set to expire. Looming over both deadlines is the question of raising the nation's debt ceiling, which the Treasury Department is taking steps to postpone until late February or early March. The government technically has already reached its borrowing limit, but the Treasury Department is taking steps to postpone the day of reckoning until late February or early March. After that, the government would start defaulting on its debts, a scenario the President said is reckless.

The President has warned that a government default would have catastrophic consequences for the global economy, while Republicans argue that the agreement has created a precedent for future deals and that spending cuts are necessary to address the nation's debt.

The agreement has also sparked debate over the impact of the deal on the deficit. While the President has hailed it as a deficit-reduction measure, the agreement would boost the deficit by $4 trillion over the next 10 years, compared to a scenario in which Congress did nothing. The nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office said the bill will increase spending over the next decade by about $330 billion.

The agreement includes an extension of lower tax rates for families earning up to $450,000, and a patch to the alternative minimum tax that adds roughly $3.6 trillion to the deficit over the next decade. Other business and energy tax extenders would add a further $76 billion. The extension of unemployment benefits for about 2 million people will cost roughly $30 billion, and the so-called "doc fix" on Medicare reimbursements will cost an additional $25 billion.

Title: Florida Resident's Decision on President a Personal and Emotional One

Article:

As the presidential election approaches, Morning Edition has embarked on a series of reports from an iconic American corner: First and Main. The series aims to explore the lives of ordinary Americans and their thoughts on the upcoming election. In Hillsborough County, Florida, one resident, Wanda Kos, shared her story and her thoughts on the election.

Kos, a stay-at-home mom of three, lives in the suburban area of New Tampa, where she and her husband, a chef, have seen the real estate market fluctuate. She expressed concerns about the area's transformation, citing the rise of rentals and the uncertainty surrounding the value of their home.

Kos, who voted for President Obama in the last election, is still undecided this time around. She and her husband discuss their pros and cons, weighing the candidates' strengths and weaknesses. While she is not a fan of Obamacare, she is open to understanding its implications. On social issues, she aligns with the president's views, but is undecided on the Republican alternative, Mitt Romney.

Kos's decision will be an emotional one, as her 20-year-old son has just joined the Army and will be heading to basic training on September 11. As a single mom, she worked hard to support her son's decision to join the military, and she is now facing the reality of her son's deployment.

Kos's story is a testament to the personal and emotional stakes involved in the upcoming election. As she navigates her decision, she is not alone in her uncertainty. Many Americans are grappling with the complexities of the election, weighing their own pros and cons, and making decisions that will impact their lives and their families.

Title: USWNT Lawsuit: A Look at Both Sides of the Argument

The United States Women's National Soccer Team (USWNT) filed a gender-discrimination lawsuit against the U.S. Soccer Federation (USSF) in March 2019, claiming institutionalized gender discrimination. The lawsuit gained international attention after the team's dominant victory in the 2019 Women's World Cup. The dispute centers around the pay disparity between the USWNT and the U.S. Men's National Team.

In 1999, the USSF took a financial risk to increase the scale of the Women's World Cup, despite a lack of action from FIFA. However, the relationship between the two parties has remained strained. The USWNT alleges that the USSF engages in "institutionalized gender discrimination."

The lawsuit was filed in U.S. District Court for the Central District of California under the Equal Pay Act and Title VII of the Civil Rights Act. The USWNT claims that the USSF pays its female players less than their male counterparts, citing a pay gap of $34.1 million to $26.4 million from 2010 to 2018.

In response, the USSF released an open letter citing extensive analysis of 10 years of financial data, showing that the women's players were paid $34.1 million in salary and game bonuses, compared to $26.4 million given to the men during the same period. The men's and women's teams operate with separate collective bargaining agreements and pay structures.

In November 2019, a federal judge granted the USWNT's motion to give its lawsuit class certification, allowing the lawsuit to include players who appeared for the national team dating back to February 4, 2015. The USSF had opposed the motion for certification.

In February 2020, the two sides filed different motions in district court. The USWNT filed for partial summary judgment seeking back pay of at least $66.7 million in addition to punitive damages. The USSF asked the court to dismiss the lawsuit "based on the actual facts in the record and the governing law."

In March 2020, the USSF reversed course on its most contentious argument, with Cordeiro resigning amid backlash from fans and sponsors over language in court filings attempting to show women's players did not perform work of equal skill, effort, and responsibility. Both Cordeiro and new USSF president Cindy Parlow Cone apologized for the language widely viewed as demeaning women's players and women's sports generally.

The trial was originally slated to begin on May 5 but was pushed back to June 16 after both sides sought guidance from the court in light of the coronavirus outbreak. California Governor Gavin Newsom has issued a stay-at-home order in his state due to the global pandemic. The USSF publicly apologized for and legally walked back its most hard-line arguments, earning a fairly resounding win on the motion for summary judgment by focusing on the idea that the differences in CBAs did not constitute discrimination but fair trade-offs willingly negotiated.

The debate surrounding the lawsuit has sparked a wider discussion about gender equality and pay disparities in sports. Supporters of the lawsuit argue that the women's team has been paid more than the men's team in the last decade, citing total compensation and tournament payouts dictated by viewership and popularity. Opponents argue that the women's team has been paid more than the men's team in the last decade, citing the same metrics.

The outcome of the lawsuit remains uncertain, with the trial delayed due to the pandemic. The debate highlights the ongoing struggle for gender equality in sports and the need for continued discussion and action to address the pay disparities faced by women athletes.

Title: North Carolina Orders New Election in House District After Fraud Allegations

The North Carolina State Board of Elections has ordered a new election in the 9th Congressional District after a monthslong investigation and four days of dramatic testimony revealed an absentee ballot scheme linked to the campaign of Republican Mark Harris. The November 6 results, which showed Harris leading Democrat Dan McCready by 905 votes, have been in limbo due to fraud allegations, leaving the district's congressional seat empty in the new Congress.

The board's unanimous vote for a redo came after reviewing evidence and deciding whether to certify the November 6 results or order a new election in the district, which spans the area between Charlotte and Fayetteville. Chairman Bob Cordle said the "illegal activity" uncovered undoubtedly had "tainted the results of the entire election."

Harris initially fought to have his November 6 win certified, but he abruptly reversed course at the hearing, stating that a new election was warranted due to the public's confidence in the election being undermined. The reversal came after inconsistencies in his testimony and revelations that his campaign attorney withheld documents relevant to the investigation.

The investigation revealed that Harris's campaign had contracted with political operative Leslie McCrae Dowless, who allegedly orchestrated a scheme to "harvest" absentee ballots, which is illegal in North Carolina. Dowless refused to testify, and his attorney denied any wrongdoing.

The North Carolina Republican Party Chairman Robin Hayes expressed respect for Harris's decision, while the North Carolina Democratic Party Chairman Wayne Goodwin blamed the wrongdoing on Harris and the Republican Party. The Lawyers' Committee for Civil Rights Under Law cheered the decision for a new election, stating that the outcome of the election was illegitimate due to rampant absentee ballot fraud.

The board will set the date of the election at a future meeting.

Title: Menendez Lawyers Accuse Government of "Fixation on Sex" and "Salacious Headlines"

The lawyers for Senator Robert Menendez and his wealthy donor, Salomon Melgen, have filed a motion to dismiss the bribery and fraud charges against them, accusing the Justice Department of having a "fixation on sex" and "salacious headlines." The defense teams argue that the government's investigation has been mischaracterized and that no witness or document has ever accused Menendez of being in the presence of a prostitute, much less engaging in relations with one.

The defense lawyers point to a black notebook found at Melgen's office, which they claim was mischaracterized as a "prostitution ledger" by the FBI. They argue that the notebook contains innocent material, including jottings about "Dixi," which is actually the name of a sanitation company in the Dominican Republic, not a prostitute.

The defense teams have also accused the government of "serious misconduct," including media leaks and misstating facts to the grand jury that indicted the men. They claim that the government has a "preoccupation with the defendants' sex lives" and is trying to sensationalize the case with "salacious headlines."

The government, on the other hand, has maintained that it conducted an "exhaustive, focused, and disciplined investigation" that produced a 22-count criminal indictment against Menendez and Melgen. The indictment alleges that Melgen paid for travel and housing for Menendez in exchange for a series of favors from the lawmaker.

The case is scheduled to go to trial in November, but either side may seek to appeal, potentially delaying the trial into an election year. The judge has already refused to move the trial out of New Jersey, and the next hearing is set for September 17, when both sides will argue over critical pieces of evidence and the way authorities gathered information and presented it to grand jurors.

Title: Trump Calls for $2 Trillion Infrastructure Bill as Part of "Phase 4" of Coronavirus Response Efforts

Article:

President Donald Trump has called for a $2 trillion infrastructure bill to be passed as part of the federal government's coronavirus response efforts, just days after Congress approved a massive stimulus package worth over $2 trillion. In a tweet, Trump stated that with interest rates in the United States being at zero, it is the time to pass a "decades-long-awaited infrastructure bill" that should be "very big and bold" and focused solely on jobs and rebuilding the country's infrastructure.

The president's tweet comes as lawmakers in both the House and Senate are already eyeing a fourth coronavirus response bill, although some have expressed caution about appropriating such massive sums of money. Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer and House Speaker Nancy Pelosi have both expressed the need for further legislation, with Democrats seeking additional funding for the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP) and emissions restrictions on airlines.

Republicans, on the other hand, have expressed a desire to see the impact of the first three phases of coronavirus response legislation before considering another bill. Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell and House Minority Leader Kevin McCarthy have both stated that they will wait and see the effects of the current legislation before considering further action.

The $2.2 trillion stimulus package passed last week included massive amounts of aid for individuals, large corporations, and small businesses, as well as provisions to help replace the salaries of furloughed workers for four months. The package also gave $1,200 per adult and $500 per child directly to the public. Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin has stated that he would be willing to ask Congress for more money for small businesses and those in the private workforce if necessary.

The latest unemployment numbers, released last Thursday, revealed that Americans filing for unemployment benefits surged to 3.28 million as the coronavirus pandemic forced businesses around the country to close. It remains unclear what provisions the White House would like to see as part of any proposed infrastructure legislation.

Title: Trump Officially Enters 2020 Presidential Race, Trails Biden in Polls

President Donald Trump officially launched his re-election campaign in Orlando, Florida, but recent polling suggests he has a significant gap to close. According to a new CBS battleground poll, former Vice President Joe Biden leads the Democratic field, with a 10-point advantage over Trump.

Biden expressed confidence in his chances, stating, "I believe we can win Texas and Florida if you look at the polling data now." He also emphasized his plan to campaign in the South, targeting states like Georgia, North Carolina, and South Carolina.

The same poll showed Trump trailing Biden by double digits in Wisconsin and Pennsylvania, and by seven points in Florida, where Trump is announcing his re-election campaign. Trump's campaign manager, Brad Parscale, dismissed the polls as "ancient," citing "huge swings in the president's favor" since March. However, a Fox News poll on Sunday showed Trump trailing behind five Democrat candidates in hypothetical matchups.

Trump maintained that he has a plan to win swing voters, citing issues like safety, security, and a strong economy. He also emphasized his administration's record-low unemployment rates among African Americans, Asians, and Hispanics.

Meanwhile, Democratic contenders like Buttigieg emphasized the need to engage with voters across the party, particularly black voters. "We have a moment on our hands where we can do the exact opposite of what the president has done," Buttigieg said. "The president has used identity as a wedge, he's used race as a wedge to divide people who have common interests."

As the 2020 presidential election heats up, the Democratic contenders appear united in their efforts to take down Trump, but it remains to be seen how the campaign will unfold.

Title: Germanwings Co-Pilot's Intention to Destroy Plane Confirmed by French Prosecutor

The co-pilot of the Germanwings plane that crashed in the French Alps on Tuesday appeared to have intentionally destroyed the aircraft, according to French prosecutor Brice Robin. The prosecutor stated that the intention was to destroy the plane, and that death was instantaneous.

The investigation revealed that the pilot, Andreas Lubitz, a 27-year-old German citizen, took control of the plane after the captain asked him to do so. The plane then began a rapid descent, which was made manually by Lubitz. The co-pilot had 630 hours of flying experience and had undergone extensive psychological and aviation reviews since beginning his training in 2008.

Lufthansa CEO Carsten Spohr initially expressed shock at the prosecutor's comments, tweeting that the airline was "shocked by the statements from French authorities that the co-pilot deliberately crashed the aircraft." However, Spohr later acknowledged that the plane was crashed on purpose, stating that it seemed to be true that the co-pilot denied the pilot access to the cockpit.

Spohr emphasized that the motivation behind the co-pilot's actions could be of various nature and asked people not to rush to judgment. He also noted that the co-pilot had undergone extensive reviews and training, but his training was interrupted six years ago for an unspecified reason.

The investigation found that all seemed normal during the first 20 minutes of the flight, with the pilots communicating in a "jovial" way. However, later, the captain can be heard knocking on the door and asking to re-enter the cockpit, but there was no response from the co-pilot. The co-pilot was heard breathing until the moment of impact, suggesting he was alive until the crash.

Air traffic control also attempted to contact the cockpit, but received no response. The investigation is ongoing, and the German Interior Ministry has stated that there is no evidence of a connection to terrorism.

Title: Supreme Court to Issue Rulings on Trump's Travel Ban, Union Fees, and Abortion Regulations

The United States Supreme Court is nearing the end of its nine-month term, with several high-profile cases still pending. The justices are expected to issue rulings on a range of issues, including President Donald Trump's travel ban targeting five Muslim-majority countries, the legality of union fees for non-union workers, and California's regulations on crisis pregnancy centers.

The travel ban, which was argued on April 25, has been a contentious issue since its introduction. The conservative majority on the court signaled support for Trump's policy, which was allowed to go into effect in December. The challengers, led by the state of Hawaii, argue that the ban is motivated by Trump's animosity towards Muslims and violates federal immigration law and the Constitution's prohibition on favoring one religion over another.

The court is also set to decide on the legality of agency fees for non-union workers in the public sector. During arguments in February, conservative justices expressed skepticism towards the fees, which provide millions of dollars annually to unions representing state and local employees. The fees are required in 24 states for workers who choose not to join unions, but want to still benefit from the collective bargaining process.

Additionally, the court will issue a ruling on California's regulations requiring crisis pregnancy centers to post notices about the availability of state-subsidized abortions and birth control. The justices seemed skeptical during arguments in March towards the regulations, indicating that they may strike down at least part of the law.

The Supreme Court's decisions on these cases are expected to have significant implications for the country's immigration policy, labor laws, and reproductive rights. With the court's term winding down, the justices are due to issue their rulings on these and six other cases by the end of June.

Title: Romney Addresses NAACP Amid High Expectations and Political Tensions

Article:

Mitt Romney, the presumptive Republican presidential nominee, faced a challenging task on Wednesday when he delivered a speech to the NAACP, the nation's oldest and most prominent civil rights organization. The timing of his address was particularly sensitive, coming just a day after Attorney General Eric Holder delivered a strongly worded critique of the proposed Texas voter ID law, which he framed as harmful to minority voters. Holder's remarks highlighted the racial undertones of the 2012 presidential election, with many expecting Romney to face skepticism and criticism from the NAACP.

Romney's speech aimed to take his economic message to the NAACP, despite the likelihood that President Barack Obama will again win a significant majority of black votes in November. Tara Wall, a senior communications adviser to Romney, emphasized the need to manage expectations and be realistic about the current economic situation, while also speaking to voters where they are. "You have to manage expectations, and you have to be realistic with where people are, but also speak to people where they're at," she said.

The challenge for Romney was to balance his economic message with the political reality of trying to take down the nation's first African-American president. While Romney has avoided discussing race in-depth, his speech to the NAACP provided a highly charged backdrop for his appearance. The stakes are high, with many expecting Romney to face a skeptical reception and criticism from the NAACP and other civil rights organizations.

Title: US to Send Additional Troops to Iraq, Ramping Up Military Efforts Against Islamic State

The Pentagon has announced plans to deploy an additional 500 US troops to Iraq, bringing the total number of troops sent this summer to over 1,500. The new troops will be stationed in Baghdad and Irbil, the capital of the Kurdish north, with some assessing the skills of Iraqi soldiers and others helping to operate armed drones targeting the Islamic State (IS), also known as ISIL or ISIS.

In his address to the American people, President Obama emphasized the need to "go on offense" against IS, which has been the focus of about 150 US airstrikes in Iraq to date. The US military is also preparing to conduct direct action against IS targets in Syria, although no specific timeline has been given for when this will occur.

The US plan also involves increasing support to the Syrian opposition, with the President calling on Congress to provide additional authorities and resources to train and equip these fighters. However, identifying the "moderate opposition" in Syria remains a challenge, with experts noting that the less-extreme center of the Syrian opposition is small and has shrunk over time.

Additionally, there are concerns about the "end state" in Iraq and Syria once the US military completes its mission. If IS is destroyed in Syria, it could strengthen the standing of Syrian President Bashar al-Assad and his regime, while pushing IS out of Iraq could lead to Sunni resentment against the Shiite-led government. Former Iraqi Prime Minister Nouri al-Maliki is set to become vice president, which could perpetuate existing grievances and resentments.

The US military's strategy is designed to envision an "end state" condition, but the complexities of the situation raise questions about what will happen once IS is defeated.

Title: Michael Cohen's Relationship with President Trump: From Loyalty to Betrayal

Michael Cohen, former personal lawyer and fixer for President Donald Trump, has gone from being a devoted defender of the President to a vocal critic. In a dramatic shift, Cohen has turned against Trump, calling him "a weak person" and cooperating with investigators in the special counsel's investigation.

For over a decade, Cohen was Trump's go-to lawyer, handling various legal matters and defending the President against allegations. In April, the FBI raided Cohen's office, and he became a target in the investigation. Trump initially came to Cohen's defense, but as the investigation zeroed in on Cohen, his loyalty began to wane.

In July, Cohen released audio recordings of a conversation with Trump, discussing payments to a former Playboy model who claimed to have had an affair with Trump. The conversation took place two months before the 2016 election. Cohen's release of the recordings marked a turning point in his relationship with Trump.

Trump publicly distanced himself from Cohen, calling him a "liar" and stating that he had expected such behavior from Cohen. "I mean, for two years, he's been lying for years," Trump said. "There's nobody that I know that knows him that hasn't warned me that if his back is up against the wall, he will lie like crazy, because he's lied all his life."

On August 21, Cohen pleaded guilty to violating federal campaign finance laws, and on November 29, he made a surprise appearance in a Manhattan courtroom, confessing to lying to Congress. He admitted to negotiating a Trump Tower project in Moscow during the 2016 presidential campaign. Prosecutors have interviewed Cohen repeatedly over the past several months, and he has cooperated with the investigation.

Trump has downplayed Cohen's admissions, stating that Cohen is trying to get a reduced sentence and that the project was well-known. However, Cohen's cooperation with investigators has led to significant revelations about Trump's business dealings and potential campaign finance violations.

Title: Romney Embarks on "Every Town Counts" Bus Tour, Focusing on Rural America

Article:

Republican presidential candidate Mitt Romney kicked off his "Every Town Counts" bus tour in New Hampshire, revisiting the farm where he launched his campaign a year ago. The five-day tour will take him to small towns in six swing states that voted for President Obama in 2008. Romney's campaign aims to win over voters in these traditionally Republican strongholds.

Both Romney and President Obama are trying to appeal to rural America, a shift from past presidential candidates who often had a more rustic image. The Obama administration has established the Rural Council, a group of Cabinet members focused on policies benefiting rural America. The council's latest report highlights improvements in the agricultural economy, including increased exports and record profits for farmers.

The administration's plan includes increasing exports, producing biofuels, and providing low-interest loans to small businesses in rural America. Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack attributes the growth in exports to the Obama administration's efforts, while Jim Talent, a former senator and Romney advisor, disputes this claim, citing the weak dollar as a contributing factor.

Romney's bus tour will focus on rural areas in six swing states, where he will outline his plans to help rural America, including increased oil and natural gas drilling, lower taxes, and deficit reduction. According to Dee Davis, president of the Center for Rural Strategies, Obama lost rural counties by a smaller margin in 2008 than past Democratic presidential candidates, and rural areas are now trending Republican.

The Republican candidate has some work to do in rural America, as he underperformed in small towns during the primary season. However, Romney's campaign believes that by focusing on these areas, he can tip the whole state into the red column this time around.

Title: California's Marijuana Laws: A Review of the Current Situation

The debate surrounding marijuana laws in California has been ongoing for some time, with proponents and opponents presenting their arguments. The article highlights the reasons why marijuana laws do not work, citing the lack of a compelling public safety interest in banning adult recreational use. The author argues that marijuana is not a dangerous drug, with few ill effects when used in moderation and fewer and less severe side effects than alcohol. The article also notes that there has been no known lethal human overdose of marijuana.

The article goes on to discuss the California Medical Association's support for Proposition 64, which would legalize, tax, and regulate marijuana for recreational adult use. The author argues that the criminalization of marijuana has led to the growth of drug gangs and that legalizing marijuana would move the trade out of the shadows and allow the state to regulate and tax it.

The article also touches on the issue of public contempt towards the political system, citing the fact that former Presidents Obama, Bush, and Clinton used marijuana as young men and got away with it. The author notes that this has led to a lack of political will to address the issue, with many statewide officeholders in California refusing to endorse Proposition 19 in 2010.

The article concludes by highlighting the current state of marijuana laws in California, noting that possession of less than an ounce of marijuana is no longer a criminal offense, but rather an infraction punishable by a $100 fine. The author argues that state laws against marijuana were wrong when they led to jail time, but are now a waste of resources and ineffective.

Overall, the article presents a balanced view of the issue, highlighting the pros and cons of legalizing marijuana and the current state of marijuana laws in California.

Title: 11 Candidates Qualify for Fourth Democratic Debate, Tulsi Gabbard Remains Two Polls Shy

The fourth Democratic primary debate is now within reach for 11 candidates, including billionaire activist Tom Steyer, who secured his fourth qualifying poll from a Nevada survey. The qualification thresholds for the debate, set by the Democratic National Committee (DNC), require candidates to receive at least 2% support in four qualifying national or early-state polls and collect contributions from 130,000 unique donors, including at least 400 individual donors in at least 20 states.

The 10 candidates who qualified for the third debate automatically qualified for the fourth debate, and Steyer's latest poll brings the total number of qualified candidates to 11. The CBS News/YouGov poll was the last survey Steyer needed to qualify.

The qualification thresholds for the fourth debate are the same as those for the third debate: candidates must attract 2% support in four qualifying national or early-state polls released between June 28 and October 1, and collect contributions from 130,000 unique donors, including at least 400 individual donors in at least 20 states.

The candidates who have qualified for the fourth debate are:

* Joe Biden
* Pete Buttigieg
* Kamala Harris
* Bernie Sanders
* Elizabeth Warren
* Cory Booker
* Beto O'Rourke
* Andrew Yang
* Julián Castro
* Amy Klobuchar
* Tom Steyer

Tulsi Gabbard, on the other hand, announced that she had secured a third qualifying poll, but the DNC confirmed that it will not count towards her qualification due to the poll's methodology. Gabbard's campaign expressed frustration with the DNC's polling standards in the past, and she tweeted that the survey was her third poll, despite the clarification.

With less than a month to go until the deadline for qualification for the fourth debate, every poll counts, and Gabbard will need to secure two more polls to qualify.

Title: Senate Clears Human Trafficking Bill, Paving Way for Confirmation Vote on Attorney General Nominee Loretta Lynch

Article:
