The United States Senate is poised to finally confirm Attorney General nominee Loretta Lynch after a months-long delay, following a deal between Democrats and Republicans on an unrelated bill combating human trafficking. The agreement, reached on Tuesday, clears a legislative logjam and allows the Senate to move forward with Lynch's confirmation.

The confirmation of Lynch, who would be the first black woman to hold the nation's top law enforcement post, has been pending since late last year. Republicans had insisted on finishing the human trafficking bill first, which had been stuck in a fight over abortion funding. The two sides agreed to shelve the thorny abortion issue by rearranging money for a victims' fund so it comes from existing healthcare money.

Congress is expected to take final action on the trafficking bill on Wednesday, and Republicans have promised to move on to Lynch's confirmation vote afterwards. Lynch appears to have enough votes for confirmation, although just barely, with many conservatives planning to vote against her due to her defense of President Obama's deportation amnesty.

The White House has criticized Republican senators for insisting on completing the human trafficking bill first, saying Lynch has waited longer than any other attorney general nominee in decades. Some Senate Democrats have hinted at racial motives behind the Republicans' strategy, while Republicans argue that the bipartisan breakthrough on the trafficking bill validates their decision to insist on finishing the bill before voting on Lynch.

The trafficking bill had cleared committee on a unanimous vote and seemed destined for easy passage last month, but Democrats noticed a provision applying the Hyde Amendment restrictions, which prohibit federal funds from going to pay for abortions, to fines the government would collect from convicted traffickers. The two sides eventually agreed to a compromise, where money collected from traffickers will not go to health-related services but will be spent on services such as legal aid for victims, while health services for victims will be paid for by existing community health center funds with abortion restrictions.

The deal was hailed as a victory by Planned Parenthood Action Fund, a pro-choice group, while other pro-choice groups expressed disappointment that Hyde language remained in the bill. Senate Minority Leader Harry Reid, a Democrat, boasted that he forced Republicans to back off their more expansive abortion restrictions, clearing the way for the deal.

Title: Turkey's President Erdogan Threatens to "Crush the Heads" of Kurds in Syria if They Don't Retreat from Border Zone

Article:

Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan has threatened to "crush the heads" of the Kurds in Syria if they do not retreat from the border's safe zone by Tuesday night. The threat comes as both Turkey and the Kurdish-led Syrian Democratic Forces (SDF) claim the other is violating the terms of a 120-hour cease-fire brokered by Turkey and the U.S. on Thursday.

Violence has continued in northeast Syria despite the five-day peace agreement, with a source telling Fox News that fighting has not stopped and movement in the area is severely limited. The Turkish-backed Free Syrian Army (FSA) was still conducting ground attacks, with artillery and ground attacks reported, according to Dave Eubank with Free Burma Rangers, a private military company providing emergency medical assistance.

The SDF has agreed to pull back from the border area and evacuate Ras al-Ayn, as long as there are no delays, according to a senior SDF official. The partial evacuation from Ras al-Ayn started on Saturday, with the SDF coordinating the withdrawal with the Americans. This is the first time the Kurds have publicly acknowledged they will pull back.

Turkey claims it is living up to the terms of the cease-fire agreement and accuses the Kurds of violating it. The Turkish Defense Ministry reported 14 "provocative" attacks by Kurdish forces in Ras al-Ayn over 36 hours, according to the BBC. The SDF, however, said there has been "no tangible progress" in solving the issues at the northeast border.

As of Friday, 86 civilians had been killed since Turkey launched its military offensive into Syria on October 9, according to a war monitor, the BBC reported. The U.S. had teamed up with the Kurds to fight ISIS in the region, but nearly all U.S. troops have been removed and will be redeployed in the region in the coming weeks.

Title: Trump Campaign Manager Corey Lewandowski's Role Shrinking Amid Battery Charges and Internal Concerns

The role of Corey Lewandowski, Donald Trump's campaign manager, is reportedly shrinking as the campaign faces mounting internal concerns and external scrutiny. Lewandowski is facing battery charges related to an incident with a reporter in March, and his authority within the campaign is being gradually transferred to other staff members.

According to sources close to the campaign, Lewandowski's grip on the campaign has been loosening since voting started this winter. In early March, he ceded authority over many hiring decisions to a lower-ranking staffer, and the campaign's press office has been overriding his decisions on issuing press credentials.

The shift is partly due to the campaign's maturation and the need for a more experienced hand to manage the remaining primaries. Paul Manafort, Trump's newly appointed convention manager, is expected to take a leading role in the selection of delegates and the remaining primaries.

Lewandowski's lack of national experience, perceived unwillingness to challenge Trump, and brash temperament have raised concerns among some members of Trump's inner circle. The incident with the reporter, Michelle Fields, has sparked renewed attention on these concerns.

Lewandowski's once-outsized grip on the campaign began to loosen after Michael Glassner's title was changed from national political director to deputy campaign manager. This change sparked resentment among Lewandowski's loyalists on the campaign, including friends he hired from his home state of New Hampshire and fellow alums of the Koch brothers-backed Americans for Prosperity.

The campaign has also promoted Stuart Jolly, who had served as Southeast political director, to national field director, giving him primary authority over the hiring and firing of field staff. Lewandowski had brought on the former AFP employee.

Trump has forcefully defended Lewandowski, blaming Fields for the incident and threatening to file charges against her. However, the campaign has scrapped Lewandowski's scheduled appearance on Fox News' "The O'Reilly Factor" following the battery charges.

The campaign's habit of denying press credentials to reporters whose coverage displeases the candidate and his staff has also been scrutinized, with the press office overriding Lewandowski's decisions on issuing credentials. Many news organizations have had reporters excluded from Trump's rallies and events, often after publishing stories critical of the candidate or his aides.

Title: Experts Debate Effectiveness of Online Extremist Monitoring in Preventing Mass Shootings

The recent mass shootings in El Paso, Texas, and Dayton, Ohio, have sparked a renewed debate about the role of online extremism in fueling violence. The pattern of hate-filled manifestos posted on white supremacist websites, followed by gun attacks against various minority groups, has raised concerns about the need for law enforcement to take action.

President Donald Trump has called for police to do more to stop extremists who are active online before they can turn to murder. However, experts say that identifying and stopping these individuals is a complex task. According to Dave Gomez, a retired FBI agent, the constitutional right of free speech means police cannot arrest someone simply on the basis of extremist rants online, unless they make a specific threat.

Law enforcement officials acknowledge that monitoring online activity is crucial, but it is a challenging task. "You can't just open a case on the words," said Gomez. "Posting something like that on the internet doesn't harm anybody." Police can only successfully investigate a white supremacist when they can "connect his words to an overt act."

The White House has announced plans to discuss violent extremism online with representatives from internet and technology companies. Social media companies are reluctant to spy on or censor their users, but they are increasingly responding to demands to take down obvious incitements to violence. Civil rights groups warn that tighter monitoring can lead to unconstitutional abuses of power.

The FBI has requested bids for a contractor to help detect national security threats by trawling through social media sites. The agency has also met with top law enforcement and domestic security officials from other countries to push for help in tracking suspicious users.

However, experts say that even with increased monitoring, it is difficult to predict and prevent mass shootings. "You can't stop crazy," said a former FBI agent who wished to remain anonymous. "You can't even predict crazy." The Electronic Frontier Foundation, which promotes internet civil liberties, notes that the sheer amount of users posting aggressive content online makes it almost impossible to identify and track those who pose an actual threat.

The FBI Agents Association has called on Congress to make domestic terrorism a federal crime, giving agents more tools to investigate and prosecute hate crimes. The debate highlights the complex challenges faced by law enforcement in balancing individual rights with the need to prevent violence.

Title: House Speaker Boehner Rules Out Conference on Senate-Passed Immigration Bill

Article: House Speaker John Boehner has reiterated his opposition to the Senate-passed comprehensive immigration reform bill, stating that the House will not consider the legislation and will not engage in conference negotiations with the Senate. This decision comes as the House is in session for only 15 days before the end of the year, leaving little time for any significant progress on the issue.

Boehner's stance is consistent with his previous statements, and he has expressed his desire to address immigration reform in a piecemeal fashion, focusing on border security and enforcement. However, a significant bloc of House conservatives opposes any measure that provides a path to citizenship or legal status for the 11 million undocumented workers in the United States.

The House has passed a series of targeted immigration bills, mostly focused on border security and enforcement, but has not scheduled any floor votes on them. Boehner's statement was designed to put concerns about negotiations with the Senate to rest, as some opponents worry that any talks would increase pressure on House Republicans to address questions of citizenship.

Boehner emphasized that immigration reform is a complex issue that requires a common-sense approach, involving hundreds of issues that need to be addressed. He stated that the House is working to ensure that both members and constituents understand the process and its implications.

Title: President Obama Announces Plan to Shield Undocumented Immigrants from Deportation

President Barack Obama delivered a national address on Thursday, outlining his plan to shield up to 5 million undocumented immigrants from deportation. Astrid Silva, an undocumented immigrant who came to the United States with her parents at the age of four, expressed "complete relief" upon hearing the news. Silva, who was watching the speech alongside a group of immigration reform activists, was surprised to hear Obama mention her story.

According to Obama, his administration will focus on deporting "felons, not families" and "criminals, not children." Silva did not initially hear her name mentioned during the speech, but was moved to tears when Obama described her story, including her arrival in the US with only a cross, doll, and frilly dress.

Silva's motivation to advocate for herself and other undocumented immigrants began after her grandmother's death, when she was unable to travel to Mexico for the funeral due to her immigration status. Obama's actions will grant temporary legal status and work authorization to up to 4 million undocumented parents of US citizens. Silva's father, who is facing deportation orders, will benefit from this action, thanks to his son's US citizenship.

Silva will meet with Obama on Friday in Las Vegas, where he will continue to make his case at a high school. While relieved by Obama's actions, Silva emphasized that a law passed by Congress is still needed to address the issue. She noted that many parents of students who are undocumented are not included in the current plan and will continue to fight for their rights.

Title: Celebrities' Venomous Tweets: A Reflection of Social Media's Toxic Environment

Article:

The world of social media has become a breeding ground for venomous rhetoric, with celebrities like Charlie Sheen taking to Twitter to express their political views. Sheen, a liberal Hollywood actor with a history of personal struggles, recently tweeted "Dear God; Trump next, please!" in response to the deaths of Carrie Fisher and Debbie Reynolds. While some may see this as a harmless expression of frustration, others believe it crosses a line.

The tweet sparked a heated debate, with some defending Sheen's right to express his opinions, while others condemned his call for the death of the next president of the United States. The discussion highlights the toxic environment of social media, where even the most outrageous comments can go unnoticed.

The article also references the example of Carl Paladino, a former Trump campaign official who made racist and offensive comments about President Obama and his wife Michelle. While Paladino later apologized, the incident sparked outrage and condemnation. The article argues that while people have the right to express their political views, there is a line that should not be crossed.

The article concludes that social media has become a toxic stew, where even the most outrageous comments can go unnoticed. It highlights the importance of responsible communication and the need for people to be mindful of the impact their words can have on others.

**Trump Cancels Summit with North Korean Leader Kim Jong Un**

In a letter released by the White House on Thursday, President Donald Trump announced that he has canceled the highly anticipated summit with North Korean leader Kim Jong Un, which was scheduled to take place on June 12 in Singapore. The decision comes after recent behavior by the North Korean regime, which Trump deemed "tremendous anger and open hostility."

In the letter, Trump expressed his disappointment and frustration with North Korea's recent statements, which he felt were a departure from the progress made in previous negotiations. He stated that he was looking forward to meeting Kim, but felt that the current circumstances made it inappropriate to proceed with the summit.

The letter also acknowledged North Korea's release of hostages, which Trump described as a "beautiful gesture" and a positive development. However, he emphasized that the cancellation of the summit was necessary due to the regime's recent threats, including nuclear war, and its derogatory comments about Vice President Mike Pence.

The decision to cancel the summit marks a significant setback in the efforts to achieve a lasting peace and prosperity on the Korean Peninsula. The world will continue to monitor the situation for any further developments.

Title: Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel Steps Down Amid Speculation and Criticism

Article:

Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel has resigned from his position, effective immediately, following a tumultuous tenure marked by criticism and speculation about his future. According to Senator John McCain, a key lawmaker, Hagel had become "very, very frustrated" in his role. McCain, who served with Hagel in the Senate from 1996-2008, opposed his appointment as defense secretary but acknowledged that Hagel was an "honorable man."

Hagel's resignation comes amid multiple foreign policy crises, including the rise of the Islamic State group, and criticism from some quarters that he was not adequately addressing these challenges. Obama praised Hagel as an "exemplary defense secretary" and a steady hand for strategy and budget, but sources close to the White House suggest that the president had lost confidence in Hagel and was seeking a change.

Senator McCain criticized the White House for a whispering campaign that accompanied Hagel's ouster, saying that administration sources were wrong to assail Hagel on his way out the door. McCain noted that Hagel had characterized the Islamic State as the greatest threat in the Middle East, while Obama had previously referred to them as the "jayvee" (junior varsity) team. He also criticized Obama for failing to address other issues, such as the Middle East, Ukraine, and China.

Hagel's resignation was met with a mix of reactions, with some praising his service and others criticizing his performance. A senior U.S. official with close knowledge of the situation told Fox News that Obama's dissatisfaction with Hagel, as well as a desire to shake up the cabinet following the midterm elections, played a role in the president seeking Hagel's ouster.

Hagel's resignation letter was submitted to Obama on Monday morning, and he agreed to remain in office until his successor is confirmed by the Senate. The president is not expected to nominate a new Pentagon chief immediately.

Title: VA Hospital Allegations of Secret Appointment Lists and Falsified Wait Times Expand to Chicago Location

Article:

A whistleblower has come forward alleging that the Hines VA Medical Center in Chicago maintains secret lists to falsify appointment wait times, similar to the Phoenix VA hospital scandal that has been under scrutiny. According to social worker Germaine Clarno, the lists are not only used to manipulate wait times but also to collect bonuses for doing so. When asked about the extent of the fraud, Clarno stated that it is "hospitalwide," affecting various specialties and clinics.

This alleged systemwide fraud raises concerns about the treatment of veterans, who are supposed to be the primary focus of the VA healthcare system. The allegations suggest that the VA prioritizes budgetary concerns over patient care, potentially putting lives at risk.

The situation is particularly egregious given the sacrifices made by veterans who have risked their lives to protect their country. It is essential to investigate this matter thoroughly and take immediate action to prevent further harm.

In a separate development, the Pentagon has approved the transfer of convicted traitor Bradley Manning, now known as Chelsea Manning, from prison to a civilian facility for gender treatment. Manning was convicted of leaking classified documents to WikiLeaks and has been diagnosed with gender dysphoria. The treatment plan includes hormone therapy and other medical interventions, which could cost over $100,000.

While prisoners are entitled to healthcare, some critics argue that Manning's treatment is excessive and should be reconsidered. The situation highlights the disparity in treatment between convicted traitors and veterans, who often face delays and inadequate care.

Title: Study Finds Multiple Paths to Reducing Partisan Hostility, with One Intervention Standing Out

A recent study aimed to determine which strategy is most effective in reducing partisan hostility between liberals and conservatives in the United States. Researchers from the Asteroids Club and the Village Square, along with collaborators Matt Motyl, Brian Nosek, and Jon Haidt, tested the effectiveness of five interventions designed to promote civility between opposing parties. The study, which involved liberals and conservatives completing online measures of political attitudes and hostility, found that each intervention produced a reduction in hostility, but with varying degrees of effectiveness.

The five interventions tested were:

1. Self-Affirmation: Participants wrote about a valued personal characteristic and a time they embodied that trait.
2. Learning Political Membership Last: Participants read about a positive group of individuals who later revealed they were from the opposing political party.
3. Observing Civility: Participants watched a video describing a friendly and respectful relationship between Republican Ronald Reagan and Democrat Tip O'Neill.
4. Superordinate Threat: Participants read an article about the threat of cyber warfare attacks on the United States, concluding that bipartisan efforts could eliminate the threat.
5. Reducing Zero Sum Perceptions: Participants read an article describing the consequences of viewing legislation as a zero-sum game and the ways it inhibits progress.

The results showed that each intervention reduced hostility, with Reducing Zero Sum Perceptions being the most effective, although it did not quite reach statistical significance. The study also found that none of the interventions reduced explicit or implicit liking for one's own party relative to the other party, but most interventions increased partisan preferences relative to the control condition.

The study's findings suggest that there are multiple paths to reducing partisan hostility, but not all strategies are equally effective. The most effective intervention, Reducing Zero Sum Perceptions, was the least based on past psychological research. The study's authors advise adapting attempts to bridge the gaps between opposing parties to the nuances of the current sources of hostility, as the issues that divide us change over time.

Title: Federal Judge Blocks Obama's Executive Actions on Immigration

The U.S. District Judge Andrew Hanen in South Texas has issued a ruling to put on hold President Obama's executive actions on immigration, which were set to take effect on February 18. The new rules aimed to provide legal status to millions of people, including parents of U.S. citizens and lawful permanent residents, as well as expanding the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) program.

Judge Hanen halted both the Deferred Action for Parents of Americans and Lawful Permanent Residents and the planned expansions to the DACA program, stating that President Obama overstepped his authority. The judge wrote that "the genie would be impossible to put back in the bottle" if the executive actions were allowed to take effect.

The Justice Department has announced its intention to appeal the decision, with President Obama expressing confidence that his executive actions are "well within my authority." Homeland Security Secretary Jeh C. Johnson stated that the agency will not begin accepting requests for the expansion of DACA and will suspend the plan to accept requests for DAPA, citing the court's injunction.

The ruling gives 26 states more time to form legal arguments against the actions, which were expected to protect as many as 4 million people who are in the U.S. illegally from being deported. The plan also included an option for applicants to apply for work permits.

The states had argued that the changes would cause "dramatic and irreparable injuries," citing the example of Texas spending $1.3 million to deal with border security during the surge of unaccompanied minors that crossed the border last summer. On the other side of the issue, 12 states, the District of Columbia, and 33 mayors across the country support the Obama administration's executive action, stating that it would benefit them by having workers who are here illegally come out of the shadows and work and pay taxes.

The Texas lawsuit against the president's executive orders was initially filed in December by then-Attorney General Greg Abbott, who accused the president of violating several provisions of the U.S. Constitution. The current attorney general in Texas, Ken Paxton, welcomed the injunction, calling it "a victory for the rule of law in America and a crucial first step in reining in President Obama's lawlessness."

Title: Mueller's Latest Indictment: A Puzzling Connection to the Russia Investigation

The special counsel's office has released another indictment, this time targeting Alex van der Zwaan, a Dutch attorney based in London, for making false statements to the FBI. The connection to the Russia case runs through Rick Gates, former Trump campaign chair Paul Manafort's deputy, who was indicted in October on charges of money laundering and illegal lobbying.

The indictment reveals a convoluted connection to an internal Ukrainian political dispute from over a decade ago. Van der Zwaan's work at Skadden Arps, a powerful corporate law firm, focused on the former Soviet Union. During this time, Manafort and Gates worked for Ukrainian President Viktor Yanukovych, a Kremlin-backed leader with questionable democratic credentials.

Yanukovych was embroiled in a power struggle with another prominent Ukrainian politician, which he resolved by jailing her in the fall of 2011. Manafort and Gates' job was to run cover for this undemocratic prosecution, and they retained a team from Skadden Arps, including van der Zwaan, to produce a report concluding that there was no political motive for the jailing.

The Mueller investigation is now investigating the Skadden report, and van der Zwaan's indictment alleges that he made false statements to the FBI about his communications with Gates and an unidentified Person A. The indictment states that van der Zwaan secretly recorded a call with Gates and Person A in September 2016 and deleted an email between himself and Person A around the same time.

The timing of the alleged conversations is significant, as Manafort resigned as Trump's campaign manager on August 19, 2016, weeks before the alleged conversations. If Gates and van der Zwaan were discussing the Skadden report in September 2016, and van der Zwaan felt the need to lie to the FBI about it, it suggests that there may have been something criminal about the report's production or release.

The indictment also raises questions about the potential connections between van der Zwaan, Gates, and Person A. Gates has reportedly struck a plea deal with Mueller and is expected to testify against Manafort, his former boss. It's possible that evidence provided by van der Zwaan, such as his surreptitious recording of his call with Gates and Person A, helped build a strong enough case for Gates to flip.

The Mueller investigation is known for its methodical and wide-ranging approach, and this latest indictment is no exception. By starting at the lowest level and working its way up, Mueller's team is willing to investigate seemingly unrelated individuals like van der Zwaan to get to the truth about the Trump-Russia scandal.

Title: Senate Approves Legislation to Require Online Retailers to Collect Sales Taxes

The US Senate has approved the Marketplace Fairness Act (MFA), which requires online retailers with over $1 million in annual sales to collect sales taxes on goods delivered to states that normally charge such taxes. The bill, which passed with a vote of 69 to 27, now moves to the House for consideration.

The legislation aims to "level the playing field" between online and brick-and-mortar retailers, who have been required to collect sales taxes for years. Proponents argue that the MFA will bring in additional revenue for states and local governments, estimated to be around $23 billion in 2012.

However, conservative groups and some lawmakers have expressed concerns about the constitutionality of the bill, citing the 1992 Supreme Court decision Quill Corp. v. North Dakota, which barred states from requiring retailers to collect sales taxes unless they have a physical presence in the state.

Representative Bob Goodlatte, chairman of the House Judiciary Committee, has expressed reservations about the bill, stating that it does not simplify tax collection and could lead to aggressive state tax bureaus targeting out-of-state companies. He has also suggested exploring alternative approaches, such as "origin sourcing," which would require businesses to collect sales taxes based on their own physical location, rather than their customers'.

The bill's proponents, including conventional retailers and state governments, argue that the MFA is necessary to ensure fairness and bring in much-needed revenue. They point out that software now makes it possible for retailers to calculate sales taxes as easily as they calculate shipping charges.

The outcome of the bill's passage in the House remains uncertain, with some analysts predicting that Representative Goodlatte's reservations could lead to a more cautious approach. However, proponents of the MFA hope that the bill will ultimately become law, bringing an end to the long-standing dispute over sales tax collection.

**US Abandons European Missile Defense System, Citing Development Problems and Lack of Funding**

The US has announced the cancellation of a critical part of its European missile defense system, citing development problems and a lack of funding. The decision involves the removal of 14 interceptors from Poland and Romania, which were intended to be deployed early next decade. The move is seen as a potential opening for new arms control talks with Russia.

The Obama administration cited development problems and a lack of money as the reasons for the cancellation. Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel stated that the decision is part of an overall restructuring of missile defense plans aimed at stopping missiles from North Korea and Iran. The US will instead focus on adding 14 new interceptors to the 26 already in underground silos in Alaska, with the goal of having them in place by September 2017.

The decision has been met with criticism from some US allies, including Poland and Romania, who see the system as a sign of US engagement in the region and a counterweight to Russia. However, the move could also provide an opportunity for new arms control talks with Russia, as the US has been seeking to reduce tensions with the country.

The US missile defense system has been a contentious issue since its inception, with Russia believing it was aimed at countering its own missiles and undermining its nuclear deterrent. The system has a spotty test record and has never been used in actual combat. The decision to cancel the long-range interceptors in Europe was made after the US determined that the technology was not yet ready and that the system was not effective in countering the threats from North Korea and Iran.

The US remains committed to other parts of the missile defense plan, including the first three phases, and will continue to work with its allies to address the threat posed by North Korea and Iran. The decision is seen as a pragmatic move by the Obama administration to prioritize the most effective and efficient use of resources to address the evolving security landscape.

Title: Market Insights: COVID-19 Data and Market Trends

The COVID-19 pandemic has forced fund managers and analysts to become amateur epidemiologists, as the market reacts to the latest data and trends. Christopher Wood, global head of equity strategy at Jefferies, has shared his thoughts on the current situation. He notes that the median age of new positive cases in Florida has declined from 50 in April to 33 in recent days, and deaths are declining even as new cases pile up. Wood raises the possibility that COVID-19 could mutate into a less virulent form over time, which could be bullish for investors.

In other news, Western Europe has seen a significant decline in new cases and deaths, with numbers roughly 90% lower eight weeks into reopening. Wood recommends a barbell strategy of owning both growth and value stocks, as growth stocks have outperformed recently due to second-wave concerns, while value stocks should rally when V-shaped recovery talk hits the market.

The personal savings rate has fallen to 23.2% from 32.2% in May, as personal income slumped 4.2% and consumption rose 8.2%. The Federal Reserve has conducted stress tests on big banks, requiring them to preserve capital by suspending share repurchases and capping dividend payments.

In corporate news, Amazon is reportedly set to acquire self-driving car developer Zoox for $1.2 billion, while Cannae Holdings and Senator Investment Group are offering $65 per share in cash for CoreLogic. Nike swung to a fiscal fourth-quarter loss due to a 38% revenue decline, while Big Lots reported sales ahead of expectations.

The Trump administration has urged the Supreme Court to overturn the Affordable Care Act, and US stock futures lost ground as the open approached. Oil futures turned lower, while gold edged higher. Bank of America has projected that the S&P 500 could land between 3300 and 3600 if markets follow previous bear-market rallies.

Finally, NASA is offering a $20,000 prize for a space toilet that can work on the Moon.

**Koch Network Fights Disclosure of Donors' Identities in South Dakota**

The Koch network, led by billionaire Charles Koch, has launched an aggressive campaign to defeat a ballot measure in South Dakota that would require advocacy groups and others to disclose their donors' identities. The measure, known as Initiated Measure 22, also aims to create a state ethics commission, public financing of political campaigns, and limit lobbyists' gifts to elected officials.

The Koch network's Defeat 22 coalition has already run commercials on talk radio and country-music stations, contacted 50,000 voters through phone calls and door-knocking, and distributed mailers denouncing the initiative as a "money-grab" by politicians. The coalition argues that revealing donors' identities could subject them to threats and intimidation, driving them away from funding advocacy groups.

The South Dakota campaign marks the latest in a string of battles the Koch network has waged around the country to block efforts to disclose contributors' identities. Last year, the network opposed a bill in Georgia that would have required advocacy groups active in state politics to disclose the sources of their money. The measure died.

The Koch network is one of the most influential groups in conservative politics, with a network of over 700 donors pledging at least $100,000 annually to a mix of educational, policy, and political organizations affiliated with the Koch brothers. The network is on track to spend about $750 million during the 2016 election cycle, with a significant portion going towards politics.

The South Dakota measure would not bar donations to nonprofit groups active in politics, but it would require the groups running independent ads and distributing mailers to disclose the identities of anyone who gives more than $100 in a calendar year. The Koch network has not disclosed how much it is spending on the South Dakota effort.

On the other side, Massachusetts-based Represent.Us is waging bipartisan campaigns around the country to end anonymous contributions in politics and pass laws it says will curb public corruption. The group helped successfully pass similar measures in Seattle and Maine last year.

**International Efforts Intensify to Find Kidnapped Nigerian Schoolgirls**

A coalition of Western powers, including the United States, the United Kingdom, and France, has pledged to join the search for hundreds of Nigerian schoolgirls kidnapped by Islamic terrorists. The move comes as parents' frustration grows over the government's response to the crisis.

A small team of US military personnel is expected to arrive in Abuja, Nigeria, in the coming days to help in the search. The team will consist of around 10 uniformed soldiers from the AFRICOM headquarters in Stuttgart, Germany, who will assess the situation and advise Nigerian officials. The US military has no plans to carry out a rescue mission.

France has also announced it will send security service agents to help track down the Boko Haram terror group and its hostages. The group is believed to be hiding in abandoned military bunkers inside the remote Sambisa Forest, which is eight times larger than Yellowstone National Park and home to poisonous snakes.

China has offered to send satellite intelligence to help Nigeria's army locate the girls and the UK plans to send a team of experts. The pledges of support come amid mounting frustration among parents of the kidnapped girls, who are worried about what Boko Haram leader Abubakar Shekau and his army of jihadist fighters might do to their daughters in the days to come.

The group has vowed to sell into slavery the roughly 275 kidnapped teenage girls. "We don't know where they are and we don't know what is happening to them," said a parent, who declined to be identified. Some parents are so afraid of losing their daughters that they have stopped eating.

The Nigerian government is offering a $300,000 reward for information leading to Shekau's capture, and the United States is offering a reward of up to $7 million for information leading to his location. Local residents have reportedly pooled money for motorcycles to head into the forest in search of the girls missing since last month's abduction and those who have since been abducted.

The Nigerian government has come under fire over its response to the kidnapping. Former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton said the government has been "somewhat derelict in its responsibility toward protecting boys and girls, men and women, in northern Nigeria in the last years." However, a senior adviser to Nigerian President Goodluck Jonathan told The Washington Post that it was "not helpful" to fault the government and called for greater international assistance in the country's fight against terrorism.

At least two girls are reported to have died of snakebites, and roughly 20 others are thought to be ill. Shekau made his plans clear in a video released Monday in which he gloated about the kidnappings. "I abducted your girls," he said in the hour-long video that opens with fighters shooting guns into the air and shouting "Allahu akbar" and "By Allah, I will sell them in the marketplace."

Title: Senate Passes Tax Break Extension, Confirms 12 Judicial Nominees

The United States Senate passed a bill on Tuesday night, extending a package of tax breaks that had expired at the end of 2013. The bill also confirmed 12 more judicial nominees, marking a significant accomplishment for the Obama administration. According to NPR, the confirmations bring the total number of judges confirmed by President Obama to 88 this year, more than double the number confirmed last year. The increase is attributed to Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid's decision to eliminate the filibuster for most judicial nominations.

The tax break extension will last only until the end of 2014, with the Senate needing to work on a new plan for the tax breaks at the start of the new year. The bill was described by Sen. Orrin Hatch, R-UT, as "quite literally the best we could do," while Politico called it a bill "that nobody really wanted." The White House had previously issued a pre-emptive veto threat, complaining that the bill did not make permanent an expansion of tax credits for working families.

The Senate also failed to pass a bill authorizing the Terrorism Risk Insurance Act (TRIA), with Sen. Tom Coburn, R-Okla., blocking a vote on the bill. The Hill reported that this effectively killed the legislation.

Despite the setbacks, the Senate had a productive day, with President Obama signing a government funding bill that will last through September of next year, with the exception of the Department of Homeland Security, which is funded through February. The Senate also confirmed several other presidential nominations, including Anthony Blinken as Deputy Secretary of State and Vivek Murthy as the country's new surgeon general, a position that had been vacant for 17 months.

Title: FBI Director Wray Credits Swift Resolution of Bombing Campaign to "Phenomenal Work" of Investigators

The Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) Director Christopher Wray credited the swift resolution of a recent serial bombing campaign to the "phenomenal work" of investigators, saying it was a demonstration of the skill, capability, and determination of American law enforcement. The case involved a series of 13 unexploded devices, including one addressed to President Barack Obama and another to Representative Maxine Waters, D-Calif.

The investigation began when the first two devices were delivered to the FBI Laboratory in Quantico, Virginia, on Wednesday. Bomb technicians and analysts quickly discovered a crucial fingerprint on the envelope containing the device destined for Waters, which led to the identification of the suspect, 56-year-old Cesar Sayoc, a man with a lengthy criminal record in Florida.

Further examination of the devices revealed DNA among the components, which was matched to Sayoc through DNA samples taken from previous criminal cases. The investigation was completed just four days after the first device was found at the New York home of billionaire philanthropist and Democratic contributor George Soros.

Wray praised the work of investigators, saying it was "unbelievable" and reminiscent of TV shows and Hollywood dramas. Attorney General Jeff Sessions also commended the quick resolution, saying it demonstrated the skill, capability, and determination of American law enforcement.

Title: Michigan Enacts Right-to-Work Laws, Weakening Union Power

Michigan has become the 24th state in the United States to adopt right-to-work laws, allowing workers at union-represented employers to opt out of paying dues. The legislation was signed into law by Governor Rick Snyder on Tuesday, following approval by the state's House and Senate, both dominated by Republicans.

Thousands of protesters, many of them union workers, gathered outside the statehouse in Lansing, chanting and holding signs as snow fell. The move is seen as a significant blow to the labor movement, which has been declining in recent years. Michigan, the birthplace of the United Auto Workers, is now the most heavily unionized state to adopt right-to-work laws.

Advocates of the bill argue that it will help attract businesses to the state, while critics claim it will weaken labor's bargaining strength by cutting union financial resources without bringing in more jobs. According to Richard Hurd, professor of labor studies at the ILR School at Cornell University, employees in right-to-work states have lower wages, on average, than their counterparts elsewhere. This is because unions are weaker in those states and are less effective in bargaining for higher wages.

The Economic Policy Institute, a left-leaning organization, found that the average full-time, full-year worker in a right-to-work state makes about $1,500 less annually compared to those in other states. Additionally, the rate of workers covered by employer-sponsored health insurance is 2.6 percentage points lower, while pension coverage is 4.8 percentage points lower.

State Budget Solutions, an advocacy group that supported the measure, claims that right-to-work states have done better in terms of growing jobs. According to their analysis of Bureau of Labor Statistics figures, right-to-work states saw employment expand by 8.2% between 2001 and 2010, while those without the law experienced a 0.5% decrease.

The passage of the measure marks a significant shift in the labor landscape, with only four states passing right-to-work laws since the 1960s. The decline of the labor movement has been a long-term trend, and Michigan's decision to adopt right-to-work laws is seen as a symbol of this decline.

Title: Obama's Visit to Israel: A Complex Landscape of Rights and Freedoms

As President Obama arrives in Israel, he will face a complex and emotionally charged environment surrounding the Arab-Israeli conflict. The key to navigating this sensitive issue lies in upholding a moral compass rooted in inalienable rights, including equality and freedom from racial and religious intolerance.

The Palestinian side will likely emphasize the emotive language of discrimination, citing Jewish settlements on Arab land and the "apartheid walls" surrounding them. Settlements are a contentious issue, with the United States and Israel having differing views on their legitimacy. In 2009, Obama became the first U.S. president to demand a total settlement freeze, which Israel responded to with a unilateral moratorium that expired in 2010. Since then, the Palestinian Authority has refused to resume negotiations.

The Palestinian political machine has seized on settlements as the central sticking point, with the most recent example being a UN report from a "fact-finding mission" commissioned by the UN Human Rights Council. However, critics argue that the report's focus on settlements is part of a broader effort to delegitimize Israel and create an "apartheid Palestine."

The Middle East Road Map, endorsed by the Security Council in 2003, labeled settlements a "final status" issue to be negotiated between the parties. If negotiators decide that a particular territory will become part of a future Palestinian state, why should an exodus of current Jewish inhabitants be automatic? One-and-a-half million Arab citizens of Israel, 20% of the population, enjoy democratic rights, including the right to vote, run for office, and serve on the Supreme Court.

Jewish settlements have been uprooted by Israeli governments in the past under difficult circumstances. Israeli governments have put the issue of settlements on the negotiating table and are ready to negotiate immediately, without preconditions. The UN's settlement report, currently being applauded in Geneva, has been criticized for its biased language and pseudo-legal analysis.

The report's annex, which begins with the timeline "Israeli settlements in the Occupied Palestine Territory 1948," is seen as an allusion to the deportation "master plan" of Nazi SS chief Heinrich Himmler. The report's "selected sources" include claims that Israel is deliberately dumping waste in the territories to increase cancer and miscarriages among Palestinians and declarations that Israelis harbor "racist beliefs of Jewish supremacy."

The connection between the anti-settlement battle cry and the racist challenge to the Jewish state's legitimacy is also apparent from the General Assembly's recent fall session. The demonization and delegitimization of settlements is inextricably connected to the demonization and delegitimization of Israel itself.

In conclusion, the creation of apartheid Palestine is not a confidence-building measure and will not produce a peace partner or a law-abiding future neighbor. It is essential that President Obama and the international community recognize the complexities of the issue and work towards a peaceful resolution that respects the rights and freedoms of all parties involved.

Title: Obama Urges Global Cooperation to Combat Terrorism, Denies Link to Islam

Article:

President Barack Obama addressed a summit on "Countering Violent Extremism" hosted by the U.S. State Department, emphasizing the need for global cooperation to combat terrorism. In his speech, Obama emphasized that Islamist terrorist groups do not represent Islam, calling the idea that the West is at war with Islam an "ugly lie." He urged nations to remain unwavering in their fight against terrorist organizations.

The president's remarks appeared to be a response to criticism from some quarters that the White House refuses to use the term "Islamic" when referring to terrorist groups like al Qaeda, ISIS, and Boko Haram, who target Jews, Christians, and other non-Muslims. Obama explained that using the term "Islamic" would give Islamic radicals a tool to recruit new fighters.

The president acknowledged that groups like al Qaeda and ISIS deliberately target Muslim communities, particularly Muslim youth, with their propaganda. He emphasized the need to tackle the issue head-on and have honest and clear discussions about the root causes of terrorism.

However, critics have mocked the president and his administration for not using phrases like "Islamic terrorism." Cliff May, president of the Foundation for the Defense of Democracies, believes that radical Islam is behind terrorism and groups like ISIS, and that the president and his administration need to acknowledge this fact.

The summit came after the State Department hosted a meeting with members of the Muslim Brotherhood, which sparked outrage from the governments of Egypt and Saudi Arabia. Zvi Mazel, former Israeli ambassador to Egypt, questioned the decision to receive a delegation from the Muslim Brotherhood, citing its history and known affiliations.

In his speech, Obama emphasized the importance of addressing the root causes of terrorism and working together to combat the threat. While some critics may disagree with his approach, the president's message remains clear: the fight against terrorism requires global cooperation and a commitment to rejecting the notion that the West is at war with Islam.

Title: Military Tightens Vetting Process for Immigrant Recruits, Leading to Backlog and Discharges

The US military has tightened its vetting process for immigrant recruits, particularly those in the Military Access to Veterans' Education and Training (MAVNI) program, which was established in 2008. The program allows foreign-born individuals with valuable language skills or medical training to join the military. Since its inception, over 10,000 troops have joined the program, with most serving in the Army.

In recent years, the Defense Department has implemented additional layers of scrutiny, including screenings by the CIA and FBI, a review of personal finances, an exhaustive questionnaire, and lengthy interviews. This has significantly increased the time it takes for recruits to complete the process, resulting in a backlog of thousands of reviews. Many recruits have been waiting for years to receive the necessary clearances to advance in their military careers, and in some cases, the process has dragged on so long that screenings done at the beginning have since expired and must be done over again.

The Army has started discharging some recruits, even if there is no security concern, which has raised concerns among advocates for the program. A 2017 report by the RAND Corporation found no evidence that the MAVNI program had caused any security problems, and the recruits were generally better educated and performed better than the average enlisted soldier. The report also found no involvement in terrorism or espionage.

The military may be considering curtailing the MAVNI program due to administrative challenges and the sheer volume of regulations, according to Margaret D. Stock, a retired lieutenant colonel in the Army Reserve and an immigration lawyer representing some MAVNI soldiers.

Title: House to Vote on Resolution to Block Trump's Border Emergency Declaration

The House of Representatives is set to vote on a resolution to block President Donald Trump's declaration of a national emergency along the southern border, according to House Speaker Nancy Pelosi. The move is a response to Trump's decision to declare an emergency to free up billions of dollars for his proposed wall along the U.S.-Mexico border after Congress failed to provide the funding he demanded.

Pelosi called the declaration an "overreach of Trump's power" and an "dishonoring of the office" he serves. The resolution, if passed, would terminate the emergency declaration, but Trump has vowed to veto it, stating he will do so "100 percent." The president also predicted the resolution would not survive a veto.

The resolution has gained over 225 co-sponsors, with one Republican, Rep. Justin Amash of Michigan, signing on. The bill is expected to pass the Democratic-controlled House, but its future is uncertain in the Republican-held Senate. Under the National Emergencies Act, the Senate must take up the resolution within 18 calendar days of receiving it from the House.

Many Republicans have expressed discomfort with the president's decision to declare a national emergency to secure funding for the wall, but it is unclear whether they will vote to support the resolution. The move has also drawn legal challenges, with 16 states filing a lawsuit arguing the declaration exceeds the president's power and unconstitutionally redirects federal funds.

Pelosi and other Democrats are trying to recruit Republicans to sign onto the bill, emphasizing that it is not a partisan issue, but rather a matter of upholding the Constitution and defending the system of checks and balances. The resolution is expected to come up in the House Rules Committee on Monday night and then be brought to the floor on Tuesday.

Title: Memorable Moments of 2015: A Year of Stirring Oratory and Unforgettable Gestures

The year 2015 has come to a close, and as we reflect on the past 12 months, it's clear that it was a year of both stirring oratory and unforgettable gestures. From powerful speeches to awkward dance moves, 2015 had it all. In this article, we'll take a look at some of the most memorable moments of the year.

One of the most notable moments was the marathon hearing featuring Hillary Clinton, which lasted 11 hours and tested her iron will. The hearing produced a plethora of unforgettable quotes and a memorable moment of camaraderie between Secretary of Defense Ashton Carter's wife, Stephanie Carter, and Vice President Joe Biden.

Ben Carson also made headlines with his attempt at a high-five with Donald Trump, a rare instance of camaraderie between the two. Former Speaker of the House John Boehner was also in the spotlight, making a rare show of emotion and crying in public for the first time.

Bernie Sanders extended an olive branch to Hillary Clinton in defense of her role in Servergate, and Larry David even vied to be Bernie's Secret Service body double, with Sanders joking that David does him better than he does himself.

In other news, Marco Rubio demonstrated how children are harmed when he fails to practice gun control, and Supreme Court Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg slept through part of the State of the Union address, revealing the hundred-year secret of why cameras are banned in the courtroom.

Donald Trump also showed off his "Crazy Eyes" intimidation tactic, and a campaign aide taught Jeb Bush how to chest bump. Hillary Clinton, meanwhile, moved her extremities in coordination to a vaguely discernible tempo, a move that has left many wondering what she's got under her belt.

These are just a few of the many memorable moments of 2015. Whether it's stirring oratory, powerful gestures, or awkward dance moves, this year had it all.

Title: Trump Administration Shapes New Contours of War on Terror

The Trump administration has started to outline its approach to the war on terror, with a renewed bombing campaign against Al-Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula (AQAP) in Yemen and increased military involvement in Afghanistan and Syria. According to Foreign Policy, the Obama administration handed over plans for a stepped-up campaign to the incoming Trump team in January, and there has been an immediate change in the tempo of operations. The U.S. has now dropped more bombs on Yemen than in any previous year, with 34 bombs attributed to the country in 2016.

The Trump administration has also considered increasing troop levels in Afghanistan, where the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS) has recently established a presence. General Joseph Votel, the head of the U.S. Central Command, testified before the Senate Armed Forces Committee that a few thousand more troops were needed to break the stalemate with the Taliban. The U.S. has also redeployed troops to Iraq and Syria to battle ISIS.

In addition, the Trump administration has signaled its willingness to expand the use of the prison camp at Guantanamo Bay, with Attorney General Jeff Sessions calling it a "very fine place" to hold unlawful enemy combatants. This shift is in line with the Trump administration's prioritization of military decision-making in the conduct of the war on terror.

The Trump administration has inherited battlegrounds in the war on terror around the world, with few limits to how to interpret the post-9/11 authorization of the use of military force (AUMF). The administration has not yet sought Congressional approval for a specific AUMF for ISIS, despite a bipartisan push.

Title: PolitiFact's Credibility Questioned Amidst Clinton's High Truthiness Score

Article:

The fact-checking organization PolitiFact, founded by the St. Petersburg Times, won a Pulitzer Prize in 2009 for its coverage of the 2008 election. However, its credibility is now being questioned due to its seemingly generous assessment of Hillary Clinton's truthfulness. A recent NBC News poll found that only 11% of voters consider Clinton "honest and trustworthy." In contrast, PolitiFact rates Clinton's statements as true or mostly true 50% of the time, half-true 22%, and false or mostly false 26%, with only 2% being "pants-on-fire" false.

Clinton's campaign has faced criticism for her handling of her personal email server during her time as Secretary of State. PolitiFact rated her statement that she used a private server for convenience, not to keep public information from public scrutiny, as "false." However, the organization did not give her a "pants-on-fire" rating for this statement. When Clinton said she had handed over all her work-related emails to the State Department, PolitiFact rated it "half-true," and only revised the rating after FBI Director James Comey testified that "thousands" of emails were not returned.

PolitiFact editor Angie Drobnic Holan explained that the organization "purposefully didn't rate statements that we couldn't verify." Once Comey came forward, the factual record became clearer, and PolitiFact acted accordingly. The organization's goal is not to punish or reward politicians but to inform readers about what is known and what is not.

PolitiFact did not rate Clinton's statement linking an "awful internet video" to the Benghazi terrorist attack, as it was unclear at the time whether it was true or false. The Washington Post fact-checker gave Bill Clinton three "Pinocchios" for his attempt to downplay Hillary Clinton's use of a personal email account and play down the fact that she was the only secretary of state to use a private server.

The article concludes that while PolitiFact's efforts to remain neutral are understandable, its decisions have led to a high truthiness score for a candidate who has faced repeated accusations of dishonesty. The author questions whether the verdict is "rigged" and suggests that PolitiFact should rethink its operating procedures.

Title: US and Iraq Disagree on Reasons for Fall of Ramadi

The US and Iraq are at odds over the reasons behind the recent fall of Ramadi, a city in western Iraq, to the Islamic State (IS). The disagreement highlights the complexities of the conflict and the challenges facing the international coalition fighting against the extremist group.

According to the White House, Vice President Joe Biden spoke with Iraqi Prime Minister Haider Al-Abadi to reaffirm US support for the Iraqi government's fight against IS. The conversation came after Defense Secretary Ashton Carter blamed the weak state of Iraq's military as a major reason for the fall of Ramadi. Carter stated that Iraqi forces showed no will to fight and withdrew from the site, leaving behind weapons and vehicles for the extremists.

However, a spokesman for Abadi, Saad al-Hadithi, disputed Carter's assessment, saying that the situation on the ground is different and that the fall of Ramadi was due to mismanagement and poor planning by some senior military commanders. No action has been taken against those commanders.

Meanwhile, General Qassim Soleimani, the head of the elite Quds forces in Iran's Revolutionary Guard, offered his own assessment of American forces, stating that the US did not do enough to stop the extremists' advance on Ramadi. He also questioned the US's commitment to fighting IS, saying that Iran and its allies are the only forces capable of dealing with the threat.

The war of words over the loss of Ramadi highlights the fissures among countries that have become allies of convenience against IS. As Iraqi troops continue to flee their advance, governments across the world are questioning whether relying on Iraqi troops and militiamen on the ground alone will be enough to stop the extremists.

The US has launched airstrikes as part of an international coalition it leads, as well as equipped and trained Iraqi forces. Iran has offered advisers, including Soleimani, to direct Shiite militias fighting against IS. However, the possibility of a large-scale counteroffensive in Anbar province, involving Iranian-backed Shiite militias, has sparked fears of potential sectarian violence in the Sunni province.

Title: Impeachment Process: A Crucial Procedural Matter

The impeachment process against President Donald Trump has sparked debate over whether the House of Representatives has officially authorized an inquiry. The Constitution is clear about impeachment powers, but it does not specify the exact procedure. Matt Glassman, an expert on legislative procedure at Georgetown University, notes that the Constitution is "very clear about impeachment, but it is also not specific."

In the two modern presidential impeachments, the House did have an official vote on a resolution authorizing the way ahead. This precedent is important, as it makes the process more formal and serious. However, House rules do not require such a step, and it has not been used in impeachments of other officials, such as federal judges.

The House has not voted on any resolution authorizing an impeachment inquiry into President Trump. Speaker Nancy Pelosi has shown little inclination to take such a step, stating, "If we want to do it, we'll do it. If we don't, we don't." Many Republicans argue that without a formal vote, the current impeachment process is just a typical House oversight action and does not require extra White House deference in regards to provision of documents or witness testimony.

The White House has refused to participate in the inquiry, citing a lack of "any legitimate constitutional foundation, any pretense of fairness, or even the most elementary due process protections." The White House has also blocked the U.S. ambassador to the European Union, Gordon D. Sondland, from speaking with investigators from three House committees. President Trump tweeted that he would "love" to have Mr. Sondland testify, but the process was a "totally compromised kangaroo court."

The debate over whether the House has officially authorized an impeachment inquiry is a crucial procedural matter. The Constitution vests impeachment powers in the House of Representatives, and beyond that, the House votes on its own procedural rules. This leaves room for interpretation and leeway for alternate beginnings. The House has not voted on any resolution authorizing an impeachment inquiry into President Trump, and Speaker Pelosi has shown little inclination to do so.

Title: Intelligence Community Watchdog Raises Concerns Over Classified Complaint, Trump Denies Wrongdoing

The House Intelligence Committee has been briefed on a classified complaint filed by the intelligence community's watchdog, Michael Atkinson, regarding a potential abuse of power by Acting Director of National Intelligence Joseph Maguire. The complaint is currently under review, with Maguire scheduled to appear before the committee in an open hearing next week.

The controversy surrounds a phone call between President Donald Trump and Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky, which has sparked concerns about Trump's actions and potential abuse of power. The House Intelligence Committee has requested a transcript of the call, which is currently classified.

In a tweet, Trump denied any wrongdoing, stating that he would only do what is right and good for the United States. However, critics argue that Trump has a history of hiding details about his conversations with foreign leaders, including Russian President Vladimir Putin.

The intelligence community's watchdog, Michael Atkinson, was alarmed enough to inform Congress about the complaint, which has sparked concerns about the administration's efforts to keep the information from becoming public. The Senate Intelligence Committee has also expressed interest in the matter and expects Maguire to brief them next week.

The controversy has raised questions about the administration's handling of classified information and the role of Congress in overseeing the intelligence community. The House Intelligence Committee is investigating whether Trump tried to get the Ukrainian government to investigate business dealings of the son of former Vice President and current presidential candidate Joe Biden.

Title: The Battle for the Supreme Court: A Call to Action

The upcoming Supreme Court nomination process has sparked intense scrutiny, with many questions surrounding the judicial philosophy and approach to interpreting the Constitution and statutes of the nominee. Senate Democrats and others advocating for an independent and nonpartisan judiciary must seize this opportunity to educate the public about the importance of the court's role in the American system of government.

The article highlights the significance of understanding the nominee's stance on landmark Supreme Court cases, such as Brown v. Board of Education and Griswold v. Connecticut, which established constitutional rights. However, it also emphasizes the need for Senate Democrats to expose the true nature of the nomination, which is not solely about the individual nominee but about the conservative legal activists at the Federalist Society and their decades-long effort to reshape the federal judiciary and rewrite constitutional law.

The article notes that the Federalist Society claims to value the "strict construction" of the Constitution, but this approach aligns suspiciously well with Republican policy preferences, which could lead to the erosion of voting rights, reproductive freedom, and labor union protections. Senate Democrats must use the confirmation process to educate the public about the potential consequences of this ideological takeover and the importance of preserving the court's independence.

The article concludes by emphasizing the need for Americans to engage in the political process to restore the court's protections and create an environment where radical judges cannot be nominated or confirmed. It encourages readers to follow The New York Times Opinion section on social media and sign up for the Opinion Today newsletter.

Title: Davos Elite Faces Criticism for Lack of Action on Climate Change and Economic Inequality

The World Economic Forum (WEF) has come under scrutiny for its perceived lack of commitment to addressing climate change and economic inequality, despite its emphasis on these issues. Critics argue that the WEF's words do not match its actions, and that the organization's focus on corporate profits over people and the planet is unsustainable.

The WEF has been criticized for its decision to invite both US President Donald Trump and climate activist Greta Thunberg to its annual meeting in Davos, Switzerland. While some see this as a bold move to bring together opposing views, others view it as a sign of the organization's willingness to prioritize corporate interests over environmental concerns.

The WEF's focus on stakeholder capitalism, which emphasizes the importance of considering the needs of all stakeholders, including workers, customers, and the environment, has been met with skepticism. Critics argue that without concrete actions and incentives to support this approach, it will remain a "fad" rather than a meaningful transformation.

The article also highlights the need for drastic intervention to address the scale of the problems faced by the world, including climate change and economic inequality. The author notes that the WEF's emphasis on economic growth and profits may not be sustainable in the long term, and that a more drastic approach is needed to address these issues.

Regarding the Treasury Secretary's comments on Greta Thunberg, the article suggests that policymakers should listen to what economists have to say about climate change, rather than dismissing their concerns. The author notes that the gold standard of climate policy is taxing carbon dioxide emissions, and that this approach has been endorsed by thousands of economists, including Nobel laureates and former Federal Reserve chairs.

The article concludes by highlighting the need for influential Republican senators to remind President Trump of his promise to keep America out of foreign quagmires and to avoid stumbling into war with Iran.

Title: The Debate Debate: A Game of Perception or Reality?

Article:

As the presidential election season heats up, the media and partisans are gearing up for their own quadrennial fall classic: dissecting the first presidential debate. The debate, set to take place on Monday, has become a spectacle, with pundits and political zealots eager to grade the performance of the candidates. However, history has shown that this assessment can be misleading, with many experts confusing style with substance.

In 2008, Mark Halperin criticized John McCain's performance, calling it "cluttered, jumpy, and often muddled," while praising Barack Obama's "polished, confident, and focused" appearance. Similarly, in 2012, the media praised Mitt Romney's "style and debating points" despite his "petulant, aggressive, and lying" behavior. This dichotomy highlights the importance of fact-checking and objective analysis.

As the debate approaches, many are already planning to grade Donald Trump's performance on a severe curve, while setting the bar high for Hillary Clinton. Trump's surrogates have already begun "working the refs," warning Lester Holt, the debate moderator, that Trump won't be held to real-time fact checks. Clinton's camp has also been "working the refs," after Matt Lauer's embarrassing performance at the recent presidential town hall forum.

The key to a fair assessment is applying the same rules to both candidates, regardless of their previous experience. Both Clinton and Trump are selling their life experiences as reasons to think they're qualified to be president. Any media outlet that tries to grade either candidate on a curve is exposing themselves as biased.

In politics and sports, there are rules for competing fairly. Each candidate must follow those rules honestly, with no lies or spin. The debate is not a game, and judging which candidate is more successful in communicating their policies won't determine the outcome of the election. The media must strive for objectivity and fact-based reporting to provide an accurate representation of the debate.

Title: Vice President Pence's Political Maneuvers Spark Speculation About 2020 Presidential Run

Vice President Mike Pence has been busy building relationships and establishing his own identity, sparking speculation about his potential presidential ambitions in 2020. While Pence has publicly remained loyal to President Donald Trump, his aides have been more candid in private conversations, according to sources briefed on the matter.

In a June meeting with Al Hubbard, a former economic official in the George W. Bush administration, an aide to the vice president, Marty Obst, discussed the possibility of Pence running for president in 2020 and sought Hubbard's help, according to a Republican briefed on the meeting. Hubbard declined to comment.

Pence has also been making personal connections with influential Republicans, including Senator Joni Ernst, with whom he spoke at a key Iowa Republican event. He also held a private gathering for donors, further solidifying his relationships with key party figures.

The vice president has also transformed his residence at the Naval Observatory into a hub for relationship-building, hosting social conservative activists like Tony Perkins of the Family Research Council and representatives of billionaire kingmakers Charles G. and David H. Koch.

While Pence's aides have been more open about his potential presidential ambitions, the vice president himself has not publicly commented on the matter. His office has denied any suggestions that he is positioning himself for a 2020 run, with Marty Obst calling such claims "beyond ridiculous."

Title: Obama Visits University of Nevada to Push for Student Loan Solution, Amid GOP Criticism

Article:

President Barack Obama visited the University of Nevada at Las Vegas on Thursday to urge Congress to prevent interest rates on federally subsidized Stafford loans from doubling on July 1. The president has been pushing lawmakers to find a solution for over a month, and his visit was part of a multimillion-dollar campaign-fundraising trip.

During his speech, Obama called on Congress to "do its job" and prevent the interest rates from doubling. He did not mention the GOP's counteroffers, which were sent to the White House on May 31. Republican leaders in Congress have proposed paying for the $6 billion cost of subsidizing student loans through various means, including changing the formula for employer pension liabilities and increasing premiums for insurance provided by the Pension Benefit Guarantee Corp.

Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell, Kentucky Republican, criticized the president for not responding to the GOP's proposals and accused him of delaying a solution to fit in more campaign rallies. White House Press Secretary Jay Carney said the administration is working with Congress, but Republican leaders have resisted solutions prior to sending the letter last week.

Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid, Nevada Democrat, offered a "bipartisan" proposal to resolve the student-loan issue, which would involve changing the formula for employer pension liabilities and increasing premiums for insurance provided by the Pension Benefit Guarantee Corp. Reid said both offsets would provide enough revenue to fund the student-loan subsidies and an extension of the stalled highway-funding bill.

The president's visit to UNLV was part of a two-day trip aboard Air Force One, which included five campaign fundraisers in California that netted him over $5 million. The trip allowed the president to split the cost of the trip between his campaign and the taxpayers. Republicans have criticized the president for mixing business with campaigning and accused him of trying to exploit the student-loan deadline to curry favor with young voters.

Title: Election Results Suggest Americans Seek Bipartisan Governance

The recent election results in Virginia and New Jersey have defied traditional political expectations, with Republican Governor Chris Christie and Democratic candidate Terry McAuliffe emerging victorious. According to columnist Ramesh Ponnuru, it was logical to expect Republican Attorney General Ken Cuccinelli to perform better in Virginia, but logic played little role in this election. Instead, personality, specific issues, and bipartisan governing strategies played a significant role in the outcomes.

In Virginia, Cuccinelli's socially conservative views on issues like gay marriage and abortion were used against him in ads throughout the growing Northern Virginia suburbs. Additionally, his opponent, McAuliffe, benefited from over $35 million in expenditures and significant fundraising efforts from prominent Democrats like Bill and Hillary Clinton and President Obama.

In New Jersey, Governor Christie's bipartisan approach to governance, including his work with Democrats in the legislature and President Obama on Hurricane Sandy relief, helped him win support from Democratic-leaning groups. Christie also avoided taking a strong stance on same-sex marriage, which limited the fallout and allowed him to appeal to a broader audience.

The common thread between the two winners is their emphasis on bipartisan governing. While there are significant differences between the candidates, both Christie and McAuliffe have demonstrated an ability to work across the aisle and the ideological divide. This approach has been critical to their success, and their wins suggest that Americans are seeking politicians who can put aside partisan differences and work towards common goals.

The election results offer a glimmer of hope in an increasingly polarized America, where politicians are often seen as more focused on scoring political points than finding common ground. As someone who has championed bipartisan governance throughout their career, the wins for McAuliffe and Christie are a welcome development.

Title: Hackers Compromise North Korea's Government-Run Online Sites, Posting Humorous and Critical Content

SEOUL, South Korea (AP) - Hackers allegedly breached at least two of North Korea's government-run online sites, causing a disruption to the country's online presence. The affected sites include the North's Twitter and Flickr accounts, which typically feature content praising the regime and its leaders.

Instead, the hacked accounts displayed unusual and humorous content. A picture posted on the Flickr site shows a doctored image of North Korean leader Kim Jong Un with a pig-like snout and a drawing of Mickey Mouse on his chest. The accompanying text reads: "Threatening world peace with ICBMs and Nuclear weapons/Wasting money while his people starve to death." Another posting features the phrase "We are Anonymous" in white letters against a black background, which is a signature of the hacker activist group Anonymous.

A statement claiming to be from the attackers, which was widely circulated online, stated that they had compromised 15,000 user records hosted on Uriminzokkiri.com and other websites. The authenticity of the statement could not be confirmed, and the North's official website did not open on Thursday.

The hacked Twitter account displayed a "Hacked" message, along with a link to North Korea-related websites. One tweet read "Tango Down," followed by a link to the hacked Flickr page.

North Korea opened its Twitter account in 2010 and has over 13,000 followers. The account is used to praise the regime and its leaders, as well as to disseminate commentaries from the official Korean Central News Agency.

Tensions have been escalating between North and South Korea in recent days, with the North warning that it has been authorized to attack the U.S. The North is upset about sanctions against its nuclear program and joint military drills between the U.S. and South Korea.

Title: House Expected to Vote on $1.1 Trillion Spending Bill, Ending Government Shutdown Threat

The House of Representatives is set to vote on a $1.1 trillion spending bill on Wednesday, which would fund the federal government through October and bring an end to the recent partisan battles that led to a government shutdown and threatened to push the U.S. into default. The bill is expected to pass, with the Senate also expected to approve it by the end of the week.

The bill, which is 1,582 pages long, fleshes out the broad outlines of the budget agreement reached last month on Capitol Hill.
