According to NPR, the bill authorizes spending for nearly every aspect of government within the guidelines of the budget agreement. One notable difference between this bill and the December deal is the reversal of cuts to military pensions, which will benefit disabled veterans and relatives of deceased military personnel.

The spending plan provides an additional $45 billion for military and domestic discretionary programs for fiscal 2014, bringing the total to $1.012 trillion. It also provides an additional $85.2 billion for Afghanistan war funding, which is typically handled off-budget.

To avoid a government shutdown, lawmakers plan to pass a separate three-day stopgap bill at current funding levels, which would push the deadline to January 18. The House is expected to vote on this measure today.

The politics surrounding the bill are complex, with many Tea Party conservatives expected to oppose it. However, the bill is expected to pass, with the Senate also expected to approve it by the end of the week.

Title: The War on Drugs: A Failed Approach to a Complex Issue

The United States has been waging a war on drugs for decades, with a focus on criminalizing drug use and possession. However, this approach has not only failed to reduce drug use but has also led to a range of unintended consequences, including overcrowding in prisons and increased conflict between law enforcement and communities.

According to neuroscientist Carl Hart, former chair of Columbia University's Psychology department, the evidence does not support the idea that drug prohibition has been effective in reducing drug use. In fact, Hart's research suggests that drug prohibition has actually increased the harm caused by drugs, particularly in terms of violence and addiction.

Hart points out that drug sales are illegal, which means that profits from selling drugs are huge. This has led to the formation of gangs and the use of guns to protect drug trafficking operations. In contrast, tobacco and alcohol, which are legal, do not have the same level of violence associated with them.

The opioid epidemic is another example of the failed approach of the war on drugs. Hart blames the war on drugs for the opioid epidemic, as the illegal nature of opioids has led to the proliferation of tainted and dangerous opioids. He argues that if drugs were over-the-counter, there would be fewer deaths.

Hart's research has shown that drugs do harm many people, but he also notes that many people who use drugs are public officials, captains of industry, and they are doing well. He argues that drugs, including nicotine and heroin, make people feel better, which is why they are used.

The war on drugs has also created a prison-industrial complex, with the United States locking up more than 2 million Americans. This is a higher percentage of its citizens than any other country in the world, with a disproportionate number of black citizens affected.

Hart notes that countries with more permissive drug regimes, such as Switzerland and Portugal, have better outcomes in terms of drug use and addiction. Portugal decriminalized all drug use in 2001 and instead of punishing drug users, offers medical help. As a result, deaths from overdoses have dropped sharply.

In conclusion, the war on drugs has been a failed approach to a complex issue. It has not reduced drug use, but has instead led to a range of unintended consequences, including overcrowding in prisons and increased conflict between law enforcement and communities. It is time to rethink our approach to drug policy and consider alternative solutions that prioritize public health and safety over punishment and incarceration.

Title: Cracking Down on Visa Overstays and Employers Could Be More Effective Than Building a Border Wall

The United States has invested heavily in border security since 2005, with the addition of hundreds of miles of walls and fencing along the U.S.-Mexico border, a doubling of the Border Patrol, and increased spending. However, a closer examination of the data suggests that a more effective approach to immigration enforcement may be cracking down on visa overstays and employers who hire illegal workers.

According to statistics, the estimated number of undocumented immigrants has decreased from 12.2 million in 2007 to slightly more than 11 million today, thanks to a combination of increased enforcement, declining birth rates, and rising economies, particularly in Mexico. Additionally, an estimated 35-50% of the inflow is comprised of individuals who enter the country legally but overstay their visas, a group not impacted by walls or other border control efforts.

In contrast, building a massive border wall, as proposed by President Trump, would likely be a costly and ineffective solution. The federal government already spends more on policing immigration than on all other law enforcement activities combined, and a significant expansion of physical barriers would not address the root issue of visa overstays and employer hiring practices.

Furthermore, forcing Mexico to pay for the wall, as Trump has suggested, could lead to a trade war and make U.S. consumers bear the cost. Instead, cracking down on visa overstays and employers who hire illegal workers could be a more effective and cost-effective approach to immigration enforcement.

Title: City Council Pledges to Replace Police Department with "Public Safety" System

The city council in Minneapolis has announced its intention to disband the city's police force and replace it with an alternative system of "public safety." This decision comes in the wake of the police killing of George Floyd, which sparked widespread protests across the US and around the world. The protests, which have resulted in over 10,000 arrests, have been largely peaceful, with many protesters calling for police reform and accountability.

The move to replace the police department is seen as a bold step towards reform, with some arguing that it is a necessary step to address systemic racism and police brutality. The Obama administration had introduced measures to hold police forces accountable, but the Trump administration has allowed those efforts to wither on the vine. The "defund the police" movement has gained momentum, with some calling for a complete overhaul of the system.

The protests have spread to cities around the world, including Bristol in the UK, where Black Lives Matter protesters pulled down a statue of 17th-century slave trader Edward Colston and tipped it into the harbor. The protests have also reached as far as Nigeria and Australia.

The killing of George Floyd has sparked a global conversation about institutional racism and police brutality, with many calling for systemic change. The phrase "I can't breathe" has become a rallying cry, with some suggesting it should be used as a mantra to challenge institutional racism.

The protests have also seen journalists being assaulted and arrested, with some reporting being pepper-sprayed while covering the demonstrations. The crackdown on journalists has been criticized, with some arguing it is a threat to a free press.

The protests have also had an impact on the fashion world, with the story of Willi Smith, a pioneering black fashion designer, being largely forgotten. Smith's story is a testament to the power of fashion to shape culture and identity.

The article also touches on other topics, including the impact of the coronavirus pandemic, the response to Tropical Storm Cristobal, and the discovery of a $1 million treasure chest hidden in the Rockies.

Title: Clashes Erupt During Peaceful March in Donetsk, Eastern Ukraine

A peaceful march calling for Ukrainian unity in Donetsk, eastern Ukraine, turned violent when a mob of pro-Russian separatists attacked the demonstration, leading to chaos and clashes with riot police. The incident occurred when the marchers had only walked about half a mile down one of the city's main boulevards. A large group of masked men carrying clubs emerged from side streets and attempted to block the road ahead, prompting the violence.

Fireworks and homemade bombs were thrown from the crowd, and the separatists responded by throwing stones and beating people with their weapons. Riot police, who had been trailing along beside the marchers, swiftly moved in to clash with the attackers and try to separate both sides. One member of the mob was hit in the head with an exploding homemade bomb, and a loud bang erupted at the feet of a police officer.

As the situation escalated, marchers scattered in all directions, with members of the pro-Russian mob chasing them down the street. One man, injured and bleeding, flashed a peace sign as he walked off to find help. An ambulance crew was seen treating the wounded, and a Ukrainian journalist with a bloody bandage on his head recounted his experience of being hit by a brick while trying to flee.

The demonstration had begun peacefully, with many marchers waving the sky blue and gold flags of Ukraine, singing patriotic songs, and chanting slogans of unity. However, pro-Russian separatists had been actively promoting their opposition to the march on social media, calling on their supporters to turn out and counter the demonstration. The city of Donetsk lies at the center of one of Ukraine's volatile breakaway eastern provinces, which has been simmering on the verge of all-out civil war for weeks.

Title: U.S. Intelligence Officials Struggle to Track Extremists as European Counterparts Differ on Information Sharing

Article:

U.S. intelligence officials are facing challenges in tracking American and European-born fighters who travel to the Middle East to join Islamic extremist groups like ISIS, due to differences in approaches to sharing information and homeland security among European counterparts. According to a report by The Wall Street Journal, U.S. officials are struggling to ascertain the movements of suspected extremists once they enter certain European countries. Despite close intelligence links between the U.S. and several European security services, gaps in information sharing are occurring.

A recent proposal by British Prime Minister David Cameron to revoke the passports of British nationals who have traveled to fight for ISIS has raised concerns among U.S. counter-terrorism officials. They argue that such a move could prevent individuals who have traveled to Syria and Iraq from speaking to authorities and providing intelligence about what is happening on the ground.

A report in The Times of London suggests that up to 30 British-born ISIS fighters are disillusioned with the group's brutal tactics and wish to return home, but are fearful of doing so due to the punitive measures advocated by Cameron.

Meanwhile, President Obama is set to meet with congressional leaders to discuss his plan to combat the ISIS threat. Few details of the plan have been revealed, but the New York Times reported that the White House is planning a three-phase campaign that could take at least three years to fully execute. The U.S. has already launched close to 150 airstrikes against ISIS in Iraq, and the final phase of the campaign would call for the extension of airstrikes into Syria, where ISIS has its home base.

The Obama administration is also pressuring allies to join a growing worldwide coalition against ISIS. Secretary of State John Kerry is scheduled to travel to Saudi Arabia and Jordan to meet with Mideast leaders and gauge their level of commitment to the coalition. The coalition currently comprises the United States, the United Kingdom, France, Australia, Germany, Canada, Turkey, Italy, Poland, and Denmark.

As Obama weighs his next move, he is seeking advice from prominent foreign policy experts from across the political spectrum. The White House has also congratulated new Iraqi Prime Minister Haider al-Abadi on the approval of a new government, and Obama spoke with Australian Prime Minister Tony Abbott on the need to address the ongoing threat from ISIS.

**White House Shifts Focus to Economic Devastation Amid Pandemic**

The White House is planning to shift President Donald Trump's public focus to the burgeoning efforts aimed at easing the economic devastation caused by the coronavirus pandemic, following two months of frantic response to the crisis.

As part of this shift, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) has released new guidance for businesses, schools, churches, and other organizations to safely reopen as states gradually lift their coronavirus restrictions. The guidance includes recommendations for spacing desks six feet apart in schools, using disposable menus and plates in restaurants, and having students eat lunch in their classrooms instead of the cafeteria.

The CDC has created "decision trees" for at least seven types of organizations, including schools, camps, childcare centers, religious facilities, mass transit systems, workplaces, and bars/restaurants. The guidance still amounts to little more than advice, as state and local officials will be responsible for adopting and enforcing the recommendations.

Some state and local governments have already put rules in place for businesses operating during the pandemic. For example, Michigan requires businesses to limit the number of customers in a store at one time. New York Governor Andrew Cuomo has also announced that each business that wants to reopen will need to submit a plan to the state on how to do so.

The new guidance could give state officials cover if their requirements for businesses are challenged in court, said Lindsay Wiley, an American University public health law expert. "It allows the state to say 'well, the CDC said to do it this way,' and the judge then is very happy to say 'well, yes, you consulted CDC and that's the appropriate body,' and then uphold the restrictions and say they're appropriately evidence-based."

The guidance recommends various measures for different types of organizations, including:

* Schools: space desks six feet apart, nix field trips and school assemblies, and have students eat lunch in their classrooms instead of the cafeteria.
* Churches: hold services through video streaming or at drive-in or outdoor venues as much as possible, encourage everyone to wear cloth face masks, use a stationary collection box, and schedule extra services if necessary to make sure church pews are not packed and congregants stay at least six feet from each other.
* Restaurants: consider using throwaway menus, single-service condiments, and disposable forks, knives, spoons, and dishes, install sneeze guards at cash registers, limit the number of employees on a shift, and avoid having buffets, salad bars, and drink stations.

Various trade groups have also started coming out with their own recommendations. For example, the National Restaurant Association has released guidance to restaurants considering reopening, recommending cleaning and sanitizing reusable menus, while the CDC suggests using disposable menus. The CDC and the association both recommend seating dining parties at least six feet apart.

The restaurant industry is already heavily regulated to prevent foodborne illnesses, said Larry Lynch, a senior vice president at the National Restaurant Association. "The fact is we're probably already 80% of the way there with the mandates coming out of the food code," he said.

Many companies, especially those with strong remote work capabilities, are already drawing up plans that go beyond the CDC's guidelines, said Bhushan Sethi, global people and organization leader at PwC, a consulting firm. "It's a bare minimum compared to the playbook that many firms are putting in place," Sethi said.

Title: David Brock Takes Over Citizens for Responsibility and Ethics in Washington, Expanding Liberal Influence

Article:

David Brock, a self-proclaimed "right-wing hitman-turned-Clinton enforcer," has taken over as chairman of the board of Citizens for Responsibility and Ethics in Washington (CREW), a leading watchdog group. The move is seen as a significant power play that aligns liberal muscle more fully behind the Democratic Party and Hillary Clinton.

Under Brock's leadership, CREW will expand its focus into state politics and donor targeting, and operate in close coordination with his growing fleet of aggressive Democrat-backing nonprofits and super PACs, including Media Matters, American Bridge, and the American Independent Institute. The reconfigured CREW is also searching for a new executive director.

Brock confirmed the shakeup in an interview, stating that the reconfigured CREW will add a more politically oriented arm and operate in close coordination with his other organizations. The new arm will be registered under section 501(c)(4) of the Tax Code, allowing it to engage in more political activity than CREW's traditional portfolio.

CREW was founded in 2003 by former federal prosecutor Melanie Sloan and white-collar lawyer Norm Eisen, who went on to serve as President Barack Obama's chief ethics lawyer. The group carved out a reputation as a leading watchdog by relentlessly pursuing litigation and ethics complaints against primarily Republican public officials. However, under Sloan's leadership, CREW demonstrated its willingness to pursue Democratic corruption as well, stating in its mission statement that it works to ensure government officials, regardless of party affiliation, act with honesty and integrity.

CREW has won media attention each year with its annual "Most Corrupt Members of Congress" report, which has included 25 Democrats among its 88 featured members. The group has called for the resignations of embattled New York Democratic Reps. Anthony Weiner and Charlie Rangel, and has pending requests for investigations into the Obama administration.

The reconfigured CREW will be supplemented by the formation of a new overtly partisan watchdog group called The American Democracy Legal Fund, which is already preparing complaints against high-profile Republicans, including Michigan GOP Senate candidate Terry Lynn Land. The group will be run by Brad Woodhouse, the president of American Bridge, and will be registered under section 527 of the Tax Code, allowing it to engage in more political activity.

Title: Trump Threatens Protesters Ahead of Tulsa Rally, Claims Big Crowds and Lines Already Forming

Article:

President Donald Trump has announced his first campaign rally in months, set to take place in Tulsa, Oklahoma, on Saturday. In a tweet, Trump warned protesters who plan to attend or disrupt the event that they will not be treated the same as they have been in cities like New York, Seattle, or Minneapolis. He did not specify what actions he plans to take to enforce this threat.

The rally was initially scheduled for Friday, June 19, which is Juneteenth, a holiday marking the emancipation of the last enslaved people in the United States. Trump later rescheduled the event for the next day, citing a conversation with two black Secret Service agents.

The city of Tulsa is on high alert, with a curfew imposed from Thursday night to the weekend, citing concerns about organized groups coming to the city. However, the mayor later rescinded the curfew, stating that intelligence received by the United States Secret Service had deemed it unnecessary.

The rally is expected to draw around 100,000 Trump supporters, with some already lining up outside the Bank of Oklahoma Center, the venue for the event. Trump claimed that over a million people have requested tickets, with his campaign exploring possible venues for an overflow crowd.

Oklahoma Governor Kevin Stitt has backed the rally, assuring that it will be safe despite concerns from the city's health official that the event poses a significant risk for spreading the coronavirus. Trump has taken a hostile tone towards protesters in recent weeks, blaming "antifa" for violence at protests without providing evidence.

The Trump campaign has taken precautions to ensure the rally's safety, including checking attendees' temperatures and providing face masks and hand sanitizer.

Title: WHO Criticism Mounts Amid Pandemic, but Experts Warn Against Drastic Measures

The World Health Organization (WHO) has faced intense scrutiny over its handling of the COVID-19 pandemic, with some critics accusing the organization of being too soft on China. However, experts warn that drastic measures, such as cutting funding or withdrawing support, would be counterproductive and undermine global efforts to combat the virus.

The WHO's decision to praise China's response to the pandemic has been met with frustration from some quarters, with many arguing that the organization should have been more critical of Beijing's actions. However, experts point out that the WHO is a multilateral organization that must navigate the sensitivities of its member states, including China, which is a major donor.

Amanda Glassman, executive vice-president and senior fellow at the Center for Global Development, noted that the WHO's low budget and relatively toothless structure make it difficult for the organization to effectively respond to crises. Unlike other international organizations, such as the International Atomic Energy Agency, the WHO has no redress against governments that do not cooperate.

Despite disagreements with the WHO, experts argue that the organization is still essential for setting standards, collating data, and coordinating global responses to the pandemic. The WHO's role in providing authoritative guidance and leadership is crucial, especially during a crisis.

Some critics, including President Trump, have accused the WHO of being too close to China. However, experts point out that Trump himself has repeatedly praised China's efforts and downplayed concerns about Beijing's transparency. The WHO's assurances about China's response were not without support from other world leaders, who were hesitant to criticize Beijing publicly.

Global public health expert Stephen Morrison noted that the WHO is an organization made up of its member states, and taking on one member without the backing of others is not feasible. The WHO's decision to praise China's response was not a reflection of its own judgment, but rather a pragmatic choice to maintain access to important data and findings from Wuhan.

In conclusion, while the WHO may not be perfect, experts warn against drastic measures such as cutting funding or withdrawing support. The organization is still essential for global efforts to combat the pandemic, and any attempts to decapitate the agency would be counterproductive.

Title: Pitfalls to Watch Out for in Immigration Reform

The debate surrounding immigration reform in the United States is ongoing, with no concrete bill yet presented by Republicans. As the discussion continues, several key issues remain to be addressed. One crucial aspect is the potential path to citizenship for the 11 million undocumented immigrants. While the principles outlined do not rule out eventual naturalization, the details are still unclear.

Another concern is the proposed enforcement measures, which include significant fines and punishments for the undocumented, as well as the expansion of the E-Verify hiring database and a new entry-exit visa system. These measures could create new barriers for immigrants, potentially preventing them from leaving the shadows. Additionally, increased powers for states and localities to enforce immigration laws could lead to racial profiling and other abuses.

Reforms to legal immigration, including visas for farmworkers, high-skilled workers, and others, must be comprehensive enough to address the crushing backlogs that discourage millions of people overseas from seeking legal entry into the country.

Meanwhile, deportations continue, with the Obama administration having expelled nearly two million people, breaking up thousands of families. If Congress fails to pass a bill, President Obama may consider taking administrative action to protect certain unauthorized youths.

The road to reform has been long and arduous, with previous attempts dying due to Republican filibusters. The current situation is uncertain, with Republicans showing signs of moving towards legal status for millions of undocumented immigrants. It remains to be seen whether this is a genuine step towards rational and humane reform.

Title: House Approves One-Week Extension of Homeland Security Funding, But Funding Impasse Remains

The House of Representatives has approved a one-week extension of funding for the Department of Homeland Security, which was signed into law by President Obama. The move came after a day of scrambling, during which a longer three-week stopgap measure was rejected by the House. The extension was seen as a temporary fix, as the clock is now ticking on resolving the impasse over a longer-term funding bill.

The main sticking point remains the insistence by Republicans that any funding bill include a push-back on President Obama's executive action on immigration. The Senate had passed a longer-term funding bill, but the House rejected it, leading to the one-week extension. Many House Republicans resented being pressured by the Senate to pass a long-term funding bill, which led to the pushback with a shorter-term bill.

According to NPR's Ailsa Chang, the tension between the House and Senate was evident, with Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell and House Speaker John Boehner not being in sync on their strategies. This led to frustration among many House Republicans, who felt pressured by the Senate to pass a long-term funding bill.

Some Republicans have expressed optimism that the House will eventually come around to supporting the Senate's bill, with Rep. Charlie Dent (R-Pa.) stating, "I don't think there's any alternative. When we're at the end of next week, what do we do?" An aide to House Speaker John Boehner (R-Ohio) said that the speaker had made no commitment, while House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.) expects the one-week measure to buy time to pass a funding bill covering the remainder of the fiscal year.

The setback on Friday has raised concerns among Boehner's allies that he may face a challenge to his speakership if he puts a long-term DHS funding bill on the House floor next week. While Boehner shrugs off such speculation, close friends believe that such a move is a real possibility. The earlier DHS debacle on Friday, in which 52 Republicans voted against the three-week plan, was seen as an attempt to topple the speaker.

Title: Democrats Express Concerns Over Hillary Clinton's Remarks on Election Loss

Article:

Hillary Clinton, the 2016 Democratic presidential nominee, has been facing criticism from within her own party over her recent remarks on her election loss. According to a dozen Democrats interviewed, including former aides and supporters, Clinton's string of explanations and public blaming of the Democratic National Committee (DNC) for her defeat are hurting the party and making her appear bitter.

While some Democrats empathize with Clinton's anger over former FBI Director James Comey's handling of the investigation into her private email server, they believe she needs to rethink her public blaming tour. A longtime aide described Clinton's remarks as "not helpful to Democrats, not helpful to the country, and I don't think it's helpful to her."

Former Obama aides are also scratching their heads over Clinton's strategy. At a recent conference, she said she inherited a "bankrupt" Democratic Party from Obama's eight years in office. A former senior aide to Obama stated that part of the problem Clinton had was that she didn't have a vision for the Democratic Party and needs to take a break and let others come to the forefront.

Clinton's remarks come at a time when the Democratic Party feels somewhat leaderless after the eight years of Obama and the surprise Clinton defeat. Obama has largely gone out of public view, although he recently reappeared with a statement criticizing President Trump's decision to withdraw the United States from the Paris climate deal. Advisers to Obama have said he wants to give a new generation of leaders room to grow.

The article notes that Clinton's criticisms of the DNC can make it harder for new leaders to come forward. A former Obama aide stated that it's hard to do that when you have the former nominee out there in a newsy, aggressive manner. While Obama has made public appearances since leaving office, he has generally refrained from talking about Trump, instead focusing on getting young adults active in civic engagement.

Longtime aides and advisers say Clinton will not run for public office again and feels liberated to finally speak her mind. They anticipate she will continue to discuss the election, particularly to promote her upcoming book, which is expected to be published this fall.

Title: Trump Urges West Virginia Voters to Oppose Blankenship in Senate Primary

Article:

President Donald Trump has made an unusual appeal to Republican primary voters in West Virginia, urging them to oppose former coal baron Don Blankenship in the upcoming Senate primary. In a tweet, Trump stated that Blankenship "can't win" in the general election and instead encouraged voters to choose one of his two rivals, Attorney General Patrick Morrisey or Rep. Evan Jenkins.

The tweet warned voters in West Virginia ahead of the Tuesday primary, as Trump seeks to avoid a potential loss in the general election against Senator Joe Manchin, a Democrat. Morrisey and Jenkins have also stepped up their attacks on Blankenship, citing concerns about his ability to win the general election.

Blankenship, a former coal industry executive, served a year in prison for a misdemeanor conviction related to a mine safety violation. His parole is set to end on Wednesday, the day after the primary. Morrisey has called for Blankenship to be disqualified from the race for failing to submit a financial disclosure, a violation of election law.

Blankenship's campaign has responded to Trump's tweet, stating that they are confident they will win the primary and that the president does not understand West Virginia politics. Morrisey has also launched a series of "robo-calls" to potential voters, highlighting Blankenship's criminal record and his residency in Nevada.

The controversy surrounding Blankenship has drawn comparisons to the 2017 Alabama Senate race, where Republican candidate Roy Moore lost to Democrat Doug Jones amid allegations of sexual misconduct. Trump's eldest son, Donald Trump Jr., has also come out against Blankenship, citing the Moore example.

In addition to West Virginia, North Carolina, Ohio, and Indiana will hold primary elections on Tuesday, with Trump having won each of those states in the 2016 presidential race.

Title: Supreme Court Rules Unanimous Jury Verdicts Apply in Both Federal and State Courts

The Supreme Court has reversed its 1972 decision, ruling that the Sixth Amendment guarantees a right to a unanimous jury verdict in both federal and state courts. The 6-3 vote overturned the conviction of Evangelisto Ramos, who is serving a life sentence in Louisiana for killing a woman after a jury voted 10-2 to convict him in 2016.

The decision is significant, as it continues a trend where the court has held that protections in the Bill of Rights that originally applied only to the federal government also apply to actions by state governments. This means that the Sixth Amendment's guarantee of a unanimous jury verdict now applies to both federal and state courts.

The ruling is also important because it addresses the issue of wrongful convictions, particularly in Louisiana, which has a high rate of exonerations. According to the New Orleans Advocate, Louisiana has the second-highest rate of exonerations per capita, with the city of New Orleans having the unfortunate title of exoneration capital of the United States.

The court's decision is seen as a step towards ensuring fairness and justice in the criminal justice system. Justice Alito pointed out in his dissenting opinion that Louisiana and Oregon now face a potential "tsunami of litigation" as defendants seek new trials for convictions that weren't decided unanimously. However, this crush of appeals signifies the necessity of the ruling, as it highlights the importance of ensuring fair and just trials.

The decision is also seen as a step towards addressing the issue of racial disparities in the criminal justice system. A 2018 report from the New Orleans Advocate found that black defendants in Louisiana were 30 percent more likely to be convicted by a split jury decision. When jurors don't have to agree on a decision, jury members with strong dissenting opinions are effectively silenced, which can lead to unfair outcomes.

The ruling is a significant step towards ensuring that the Sixth Amendment's guarantee of a unanimous jury verdict is upheld in both federal and state courts. It is a reminder that the criminal justice system must prioritize fairness, justice, and the protection of individual rights.

Title: President Obama to Discuss Strategies for Combating Islamic State Influence

Article:

President Barack Obama will spend the coming week discussing his strategies for combating the influence of the Islamic State (IS) militant group at home and abroad. The president has taken a more soothing tone in recent weeks, urging Americans not to let fear and distrust divide them. In his weekly address on Sunday, Obama emphasized that terrorists like IS are trying to divide people along lines of religion and background, and that this is how they recruit and stoke fear.

The president's efforts come as a new survey reveals that 7 in 10 Americans believe the risk of a terrorist attack in the United States is high, despite government assurances that there are no credible threats. The survey also shows that the number of Americans who believe the risk is high has increased since the terrorist attacks in Paris and San Bernardino, California.

In an effort to publicize the government's counterterrorism efforts, Obama will visit the Pentagon and the National Counterterrorism Center this week. The visits are seen as a response to the increased fear and concern over terror attacks in the public and in the presidential election campaigns. The president will also address reporters after a briefing at the National Counterterrorism Center, where he will provide an update on the US strategy against IS.

The recruitment strategies employed by IS, including an online approach that focuses on inspiring lone attacks, have forced US intelligence officials to engage in a war on multiple fronts, from the Middle East to social media. The fact that the shooters in the San Bernardino attacks managed to remain under the government's radar until they killed 14 people at a health department holiday party has fueled fears that the government may not be doing enough to identify and prevent lone-wolf radicals.

Obama's visits are seen as a counterweight to the increased fear and anxiety over terror attacks, and his message is clear: "We can't turn against one another by letting this fight be defined as a war between America and Islam," he said on Sunday.

Title: Clinton Campaign Accuses Sanders of Threatening Obamacare, but Critics Say It's a Misguided Attack

The Democratic presidential campaign has seen a heated debate over healthcare, with Hillary Clinton accusing Bernie Sanders of wanting to dismantle Obamacare. However, critics argue that this attack is misguided and divorced from reality. Sanders' proposal, which would establish a national single-payer healthcare system, is seen as more progressive than the Affordable Care Act (ACA). The plan would require each state to set up its own single-payer program, with a federal board overseeing and regulating these state programs.

Clinton's campaign has been pressing this attack hard, with Chelsea Clinton even joining in to slam Sanders' proposal as a plan that would "strip millions and millions and millions of people of their health insurance." However, critics argue that this attack is a desperate attempt to distract from the campaign's own struggles and may alienate Sanders' supporters.

The debate over healthcare is an important one, and it's worth having it in the primaries to sharpen the Democratic party's platform. However, it's essential to remember that any healthcare proposal, whether it's a public option or single-payer system, faces significant hurdles in Congress. The major barrier to enacting such a plan is Congress itself, along with the army of industry lobbyists who will oppose it.

In reality, the next president will likely spend most of their time trying to protect the Affordable Care Act from Republican attempts to repeal it, rather than pushing for new reforms. Adding to or fixing the ACA's flaws will likely have to wait until the political landscape changes or the Republican Party decides to start governing again.

Title: Texas Authorities to Pursue Adult Prison Sentence for Ethan Couch, Who Fled to Mexico

Texas authorities have taken Ethan Couch, the 18-year-old who used the term "affluenza" as a defense to avoid jail time for a drunk-driving accident that killed four people, into custody along with his mother, Tonya, in Puerto Vallarta, Mexico. The pair was arrested on Monday, nearly two weeks after Couch failed to show up for a probation appointment.

Couch will have a court hearing on January 19, where the district attorney will motion to move the juvenile case to adult court. The juvenile judge will make the decision on where the case will be heard. Authorities believe the two planned their escape, with Couch's mother, Tonya, facing charges of hindering an apprehension.

Couch's attorneys, Scott Brown and Reagan Wynn, have declined to comment on the case until they speak with their client, who is currently being held at immigration offices in Guadalajara, Mexico. The pair is expected to be returned to the United States aboard a commercial flight to Houston sometime Tuesday.

Mexico's Jalisco state prosecutors' office said its agents had been working with American authorities since December 26 to track down and capture Couch and his mother. They were found in a dowdy section of Puerto Vallarta's old town, far from the city's glitzy resorts and hotels.

Couch was previously sentenced to 10 years' probation and a stint in a rehabilitation center after pleading guilty to four counts of intoxication manslaughter and two counts of intoxication assault causing serious bodily injury. If found to be drinking, his probation could be revoked and he could face up to 10 years in prison.

Title: McAuliffe's Campaign Focuses on Virginia, Not the Clintons

Article:

Terry McAuliffe's 2013 gubernatorial campaign in Virginia is serving as a testing ground for Hillary Clinton's political clout, according to several donors and operatives. While McAuliffe and his top allies have not explicitly pitched his campaign as a way to get in on the ground floor of Hillary 2016, some donors and consultants have made this suggestion. This has led to concerns that McAuliffe's campaign is being used as a way to build support for a potential Hillary Clinton presidential bid.

McAuliffe's campaign has attracted top-tier talent likely to be involved in any Hillary Clinton presidential effort, including campaign manager Robby Mook, senior adviser Patrick Hallahan, and bundlers Jonathan Mantz and Jackson Dunn. The campaign has also raised nearly $2 million in March alone at out-of-state fundraisers featuring former President Bill Clinton or other Clinton insiders, including James Carville, Harold Ickes, and Dee Dee Myers.

The success or failure of McAuliffe's campaign is seen as a chance to measure Clinton's strength and organization in a critical swing state that now rivals Ohio as a pivotal state for winning a presidential election. However, McAuliffe's campaign and most of its surrogates have officially discouraged the perception that he is running a Hillary Clinton farm team, while some Clinton insiders privately bristle at suggestions by McAuliffe's allies that his campaign will pave the way for her potential run.

It is unclear whether Clinton has privately endorsed the McAuliffe team's fundraising pitches, as she has left the campaigning and fundraising to her husband. The talk of 2016 could also muddle McAuliffe's message in his tight race against Republican state Attorney General Ken Cuccinelli. McAuliffe has sought to portray himself as a moderate Virginia businessman, rather than the legendary Washington money man who co-chaired Bill Clinton's 1996 campaign, chaired Hillary Clinton's 2008 effort, ran the Democratic National Committee in the early 2000s, and mentored a generation of Democratic fundraisers.

James Carville, a longtime political strategist and Clinton loyalist, said he hadn't heard McAuliffe or his team pitch his campaign as a Clinton effort-in-waiting, and stressed that McAuliffe has his own political base. Carville also noted that McAuliffe was very close to the president and first lady, but emphasized that he has his own friends and supporters.

The article highlights the close ties between McAuliffe and the Clintons, as well as the potential for his campaign to be seen as a testing ground for Hillary Clinton's political clout. However, it also notes that McAuliffe's campaign has officially discouraged the perception that he is running a Hillary Clinton farm team, and that some Clinton insiders privately bristle at suggestions that his campaign will pave the way for her potential run.

Title: US-Mexico Tariffs: Companies and Consumers Face Uncertainty Amidst Trade Tensions

The recent announcement by BD, a medical technology company, to shift some of its manufacturing from China to Mexico due to the Trump administration's tariffs has sparked concerns about the potential impact on consumers and the economy. The tariffs, set to take effect on June 10, will impose a 5% tax on Mexican imports, with the rate increasing to 25% by October if immigration issues are not resolved.

The tariffs may have an immediate effect on consumers, particularly those who purchase fresh fruits and vegetables, as distributors may pass on the costs to consumers. Emily Blanchard, an economist at the Tuck School of Business at Dartmouth College, noted that consumers may feel the pinch, citing the example of avocados and strawberries. However, the impact may be more gradual for other products, as companies may initially absorb some of the costs to avoid losing business.

Economists warn that consumers will ultimately bear the brunt of the tariffs, as companies may initially absorb some of the costs. Katheryn Russ, an economist at the University of California, Davis, noted that the tariffs are essentially a tax on American goods, as many imports from Mexico contain parts or materials from American factories.

The direct effects of the tariffs may be small, especially with a strong economy and low inflation, but the disruption they could cause for automakers and others who rely on international supply chains is a larger concern. Brian Dunch, a trade expert at PricewaterhouseCoopers, noted that while supply chains will not fray overnight, they could break down over time if companies decide they cannot trust trade rules to be consistent from one year to the next. The cumulative effect of uncertainty could lead to supply chains "Balkanizing," or fragmenting, as companies seek to protect themselves from potential disruptions.

As the tariffs take effect, companies and consumers alike will be watching to see how the situation unfolds and what the long-term consequences will be.

Title: Sanders Fails to Win in States Where Income Inequality Is Worst

The 2020 Democratic primary election has seen a surprising trend emerge: Bernie Sanders, a self-proclaimed champion of income inequality, has been losing in states where income inequality is worst. In contrast, Hillary Clinton has been winning in states with higher levels of income inequality. This phenomenon has been observed across all 50 states, with Clinton winning in the most unequal states and Sanders winning in the most equal states.

According to the Gini index, a widely used statistic that measures income inequality on a scale from 0 (total equality) to 1 (total inequality), the states are lined up from left to right, from the most equal (Alaska, at 0.4146, or 0.455 from the median) to the most unequal (New York, at 0.5048, or 0.447 from the median). The data shows a striking pattern: Clinton wins in the most unequal states, and even in the one fairly equal state she won – Iowa – she barely won, and only among "state delegate equivalents," not voters.

The University of Iowa's Sarah Bruch, a sociology professor who studies inequality, notes that the difference between one state and one a handful of places away is significant, and the broader trends are also meaningful. According to Bruch, one common yardstick for an "important" difference is 0.024, and the distance between No. 1 and No. 50 is more than 0.09.

Regional variations in inequality are also notable, with Southern states tending to be more unequal, and the most equal Southern state, West Virginia, coming in as the 28th most equal. However, there are some big geographic trends: Southern states tend to be more unequal, and the most equal states are often located in the West and Northeast.

While some may argue that Clinton's wins in the most unequal states suggest that she is more effective at appealing to voters on the basis of inequality, experts like Bruch doubt that inequality plays a big direct role. Instead, primary turnout is more about party organization and campaign mobilization.

The article also notes that other factors may be at play, such as race and rural vs. urban demographics. The South is both heavily unequal and heavily black, and American blacks are more economically disadvantaged than whites nationwide. Additionally, Sanders' gun control stances may have helped fuel his performance in states with larger rural populations.

Overall, the data suggests that while Sanders' focus on income inequality may not be directly translating into electoral success, other factors are likely at play in the 2020 Democratic primary election.

Title: Senate Minority Leader Schumer Criticizes Trump's Nominees, Threatens to Delay Confirmation Process

Article:

Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer (D-N.Y.) expressed concerns about the Trump administration's nominees, calling them a "swamp cabinet" filled with bankers and billionaires. Schumer made these comments during his weekly press conference, where he also criticized Republicans for scheduling multiple hearings without ensuring nominees had completed necessary paperwork.

Schumer specifically mentioned Education Secretary nominee Betsy DeVos, stating that lawmakers did not receive all of her paperwork before her hearing. He warned that if Democrats feel Republicans are rushing nominees, they will force "extensive debate" on the floor, which could slow down the confirmation process.

The Senate minority leader also brought up the case of Rep. Mick Mulvaney, Trump's pick to lead the Office of Management and Budget. Schumer compared Mulvaney's failure to pay taxes on a household employee to a scandal that led to the withdrawal of President Obama's initial Health and Human Services pick, Tom Daschle. Mulvaney has since paid the $15,000 in taxes, as well as penalties, and the Trump team has dismissed criticism, stating that Mulvaney has taken "appropriate follow-up measures."

Schumer's comments come as Senate leadership negotiates over how many nominees will receive a vote before the full Senate on Friday. The threat of extensive debate could potentially slow down the confirmation process, which may impact the Trump administration's ability to fill key positions.

Title: Jack Lew's Confirmation Hearing to Focus on Fiscal Policy and Controversial Comments

Article:

Jack Lew, the White House chief of staff and President Obama's nominee to lead the Treasury Department, is set to face a grueling confirmation hearing on Capitol Hill today. The hearing will focus on his fiscal policy expertise and controversial comments he made as the director of the Office of Management and Budget (OMB) in 2011.

Lew's tenure at OMB was marked by his claim that the administration's spending would not increase the national debt, which has raised eyebrows among lawmakers. Senator Jeff Sessions, the ranking Republican on the Senate Budget Committee, has accused Lew of "deliberate artifice" for making this claim, which has sparked concerns about Lew's ability to manage the nation's finances.

The hearing will also delve into Lew's lucrative stint at Citigroup, where he received a $940,000 bonus just before the bank received a government bailout. Senators will likely question Lew about his role in amassing bad mortgage debt that contributed to the 2008 financial crisis.

Additionally, Lew's decision to shelter his wealth in the Cayman Islands will be scrutinized, with some critics arguing that it raises questions about his commitment to transparency and accountability.

As the nominee for Treasury Secretary, Lew will be responsible for issuing bonds to finance the expected $4 trillion in additional borrowing during the president's second term. His answers to these questions will provide insight into the administration's fiscal policy and its plans to address the mounting national debt.

The hearing is likely to be a contentious one, with Republicans seeking to hold Lew accountable for his past statements and Democrats defending his expertise in fiscal policy. The outcome of the hearing will set the stage for a potential filibuster of Lew's nomination, which could have significant implications for the administration's ability to implement its fiscal agenda.

Title: USDA's Sugar Market Intervention: A Complex and Self-Defeating Cycle

The United States Department of Agriculture (USDA) has been criticized for its role in maintaining the domestic sugar market, which some argue operates as a federally-sponsored racket, benefiting a select few farmers but harming the economy as a whole. The USDA's efforts to boost sugar prices through loan programs, import barriers, and production quotas have led to artificially high prices, with consumers paying the price.

According to a USDA economist, the agency is likely to purchase 400,000 tons of sugar this year to drive prices up and prevent defaults on loans made to sugar processors. This move would account for about 4.4% of projected U.S. sugar production in the marketing year ending September 30. The USDA's Commodity Credit Corporation plans to sell the sugar to ethanol producers at a loss of about 10 cents per pound, or $80 million total.

The USDA's actions aim to boost sugar prices to an "acceptable level," as determined by the agency. However, this intervention has been criticized for its potential economic ripple effects and the benefits it provides to a select few farmers. The article questions the wisdom of the USDA's actions, suggesting that the free market should be allowed to function without government interference.

Title: Study Highlights Diminishing Role of Facts and Analysis in Public Life

A new study by the Rand Corporation, a research institution celebrating its 70th anniversary, has shed light on the alarming trend of diminishing facts and analysis in American public life. The report, titled "Truth Decay: An Initial Exploration of the Diminishing Role of Facts and Analysis in American Public Life," highlights four trends that are eroding the public's stock of truth and trust: increasing disagreement about facts, blurring of the line between fact and opinion, increasing quantity of opinion relative to facts, and declining trust in formerly respected sources of factual information.

The study's authors, Michael D. Rich and Jennifer Kavanagh, suggest that the public's mental bandwidth is being stretched by the torrent of information pouring in from the internet, social media, cable television, and talk radio. This has led to a decline in the public's ability to distinguish between fact and opinion, making it difficult to engage in fact-based discourse and policymaking.

The report also notes that the increasing quantity of opinion relative to facts has led to a decline in the public's trust in formerly respected sources of factual information. The authors attribute this trend to the blurring of the line between fact and opinion, as well as the increasing disagreement about facts.

The study highlights several factors contributing to this trend, including the rise of social media, the proliferation of opinion-based content, and the decline of traditional news sources. The authors also note that the increasing availability of information has led to a decline in the public's ability to distinguish between fact and opinion.

The report concludes by suggesting several research projects to combat truth decay, including the development of critical thinking skills in schools and the support of long-form and investigative journalism. The authors also emphasize the need for a better understanding of the consequences of the new media and intellectual landscape.

Overall, the study highlights the importance of fact-based discourse and policymaking in American public life. As the authors note, a default position of skepticism is defensible, given the history of misinformation and manipulation. However, it is essential to recognize the importance of fact-based information and to take steps to promote critical thinking and media literacy.

Title: Romney Criticizes Obama Administration's Handling of Libya Attack

The Republican presidential candidate Mitt Romney and his running mate Paul Ryan have accused the Obama administration of failing to provide a clear explanation about the attack on the U.S. Consulate in Libya, which resulted in the death of the U.S. ambassador and three other Americans. Romney stated that the administration has not been transparent about the incident, claiming that it was a terrorist attack carried out by Al Qaeda.

Romney's comments echo the concerns of Republican lawmakers who have questioned the administration's shifting explanation of the events surrounding the attack. Initially, the administration described the incident as "spontaneous" violence tied to protests over an anti-Islam film produced in the U.S. However, Obama officials later acknowledged that it was not just a mob action, but the exact nature of the attack remains unclear.

Ryan criticized the administration for not being on the same page as its own officials, citing the testimony of National Counterterrorism Center Director Matt Olsen, who described the attack as a terrorist attack. Romney also questioned why the president has not taken a more definitive stance on the attack.

In his address to the United Nations General Assembly, Obama paid tribute to Ambassador Chris Stevens, who died in the attack, and reiterated the administration's support for the Arab Spring. However, he did not mention terrorism in his speech, and has yet to elaborate on how extremists were able to launch the coordinated attack on the consulate.

Obama has condemned extremist elements in the Muslim world and vowed to bring those responsible for the attack to justice. In an interview with ABC's "The View," he stated that there was "no doubt" that the assault was not just a mob action, but a sign of extremism in nations lacking stability.

Romney and Ryan have criticized Obama's leadership abroad, accusing him of minimizing the death of Ambassador Stevens and leaving American foreign policy at the mercy of events instead of working to shape global politics in America's interest.

Title: Congress Considers Gun Control Bills, Awaits Trump's Guidance

The House Judiciary Committee is set to consider legislation aimed at preventing mass shootings, as lawmakers and the White House respond to a recent spate of attacks across the country. The bills under consideration include measures to limit access to high-capacity gun magazines, block individuals convicted of hate crimes from obtaining firearms, and provide incentives for states to adopt "red flag" laws, which allow the government to temporarily bar individuals in crisis from obtaining guns.

While the House is moving forward on these bills, it remains unclear what legislation may come up for a vote in the Republican-controlled Senate. Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell has stated that he will not hold any votes on the issue until President Trump outlines what he will support. So far, Trump has called for action but has not publicly identified what policies he would back.

The absence of detail has created frustration for some of his allies in the Senate, who are urging the president to provide guidance on what he would support. "The president needs to step up here and set some guidelines for what he would do," said Sen. Roy Blunt, R-Mo.

The White House has been meeting with members of Congress and those affected by mass shootings to gather feedback on next steps. "We hope the president can take the lead," said Tony Montalto, president of Stand with Parkland, which is calling for more to be done to prevent these tragedies. Montalto's 14-year-old daughter, Gina, was killed in the 2018 shooting at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School in Parkland, Fla.

The White House has not publicly disclosed what specific measures it is considering, but various options are being weighed, including expanding background checks and federal support for red flag laws. "It's a deliberative process," said White House spokesman Hogan Gidley. "We want to do something that will actually help... not just something that will make people feel good."

Democrats in Congress are pushing for gun control measures, citing overwhelming public support for proposals like the House-passed bill requiring background checks for almost all gun sales. "We are not taking no for an answer. We are not going away," said House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, D-Calif. Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer, D-N.Y., said he has spoken to the president several times in the past month and "he's all over the lot" on the gun issue.

Title: Secretary of State John Kerry Arrives in Cuba as President Obama Pursues Nuclear Deal with Iran

Article:

Secretary of State John Kerry arrived in Cuba on August 14, amidst ongoing efforts by President Obama to secure Congressional approval for his nuclear deal with Iran. The two developments are seen as emblematic of the administration's approach to foreign policy, which has been criticized for its perceived concessions to dictators and its potential consequences for global security.

The article highlights the concerns surrounding the nuclear deal with Iran, which has been criticized for allowing the country to retain its existing nuclear infrastructure and for not securing "anytime, anywhere" inspections. The deal has also been criticized for providing Iran with $100 billion in sanctions relief, which could be used to fund terrorist organizations and promote instability in the region.

The article also discusses the administration's approach to Cuba, which has been criticized for rewarding the Castro regime for its repressive tactics and persistent opposition to American interests. The deal has been seen as a concession to the regime, which has only increased its repression of the Cuban people since the President announced his new policy.

The article concludes by outlining a three-part plan to roll back the President's deal with Iran and a separate plan to roll back his concessions to the Castro regime. The plans include reimposing sanctions on Iran, ensuring the country's forces in the Middle East are positioned to signal readiness and restore a credible military option, and linking any talks to Iran's broader conduct. The plans also include giving the Castros a choice between continuing to repress their people and receiving increased U.S. trade, investment, and support, and restoring Cuba to the state sponsor of terror list until it stops supporting designated Foreign Terrorist Organizations.

Title: Science Education Activist Confronts Wall Street Journal Writer Over Misconceptions on Science Funding

Article:

On the April 5th edition of Real Time with Bill Maher, science education activist Zack Kopplin confronted Wall Street Journal writer Stephen Moore over misconceptions about science funding. The discussion centered around Moore's questioning of the need for research on "snail mating habits," which Kopplin pointed out was not a valid critique. However, it appears that actual scientists are conducting research on snail biology because snails carry parasitic worms that can be deadly to humans.

According to experts, snails in tropical freshwater in Africa, Asia, and South America serve as intermediaries between disease-causing parasitic worms and humans. People in developing countries without access to clean water and sanitation facilities are often exposed to infected snails, which can lead to the parasitic worms infecting humans. The worms' larvae emerge from the snails, penetrate human skin, and mature in internal organs, causing schistosomiasis, a disease that affects 74 developing nations, as of 2009.

Stephen Moore, a senior economics writer and editorial board member for The Wall Street Journal, is not a fringe figure. He is a prominent conservative media personality who, along with Rush Limbaugh, has been accused of peddling anti-science rhetoric. This includes denying the importance of climate science, economics, and other scientific fields. The logic behind this anti-science stance is that scientists are inherently biased because they care about science, which is a flawed and outdated argument.

The scientific method, on the other hand, is a rigorous process where scientists present arguments with data and test ideas until a consensus emerges. This is a free market for scientific ideas, where experts can engage in open discussion and debate. It is essential for media outlets to respect the scientific method and provide accurate information to the public.

For more information on the scientific method and research projects, readers can visit Zack Kopplin's petition.

Title: Virginia's Republican Party Faces Challenges in Swing State

The Republican Party in Virginia is facing challenges in the state's off-year elections, which are seen as a crucial test for the party's national brand. The state's legislative body has been rocked by controversy over redistricting and a proposal to divide Virginia's Electoral College votes by congressional district, which has raised concerns about the party's ability to appeal to a broader audience.

The controversy surrounding the redistricting plan and the proposal to divide Electoral College votes has drawn national attention and has been seen as a setback for the party's efforts to refocus on a winning agenda. The Virginia House of Delegates is expected to decide soon whether to take up the Senate's new legislative map, which has been criticized for being too partisan.

The controversy has also raised concerns about the party's ability to appeal to women and moderate voters, who have been turned off by the party's stance on issues such as reproductive rights and healthcare. The party's nominee for governor, Ken Cuccinelli, has been criticized for his hard-right stance on issues such as contraception and the Affordable Care Act, which has raised concerns about his ability to appeal to a broader audience.

The stakes are high for the Republican Party in Virginia, which has become one of the most important swing states in the country. The party's success in the state's off-year elections could help to turn back the tide of Democratic gains in the state and send a message about the direction of the party nationally. However, the controversy surrounding the redistricting plan and the party's nominee's stance on key issues has raised concerns about the party's ability to achieve that goal.

Title: Republican Lobbyist and Gateway Pundit Writer Exposed for Promoting Fake Sexual Assault Allegations Against FBI Special Counsel Robert Mueller

Article:

A recent investigation has revealed that Republican lobbyist Jack Burkman and Gateway Pundit writer Jacob Wohl were involved in promoting false sexual assault allegations against FBI Special Counsel Robert Mueller. The allegations, which were being promoted online, claimed that Mueller had committed sexual misconduct in the past.

According to NBC News, Burkman and Wohl were offering money to women to make false claims against Mueller. The allegations were referred to the FBI for investigation, and Mueller's office requested that the agency look into the apparent hoax.

Reporters began digging into the source of the claims, which were being promoted by Wohl and Burkman online. Wohl tweeted on October 19 that a "prominent DC insider" told him that women were "prepared to make credible allegations" against Mueller. Burkman announced that he would reveal the first of Mueller's accusers at a November 1 press conference.

However, further investigation revealed that the allegations were likely false. The law firm where Mueller allegedly committed the sexual misconduct, Pillsbury, Madison and Sutro, told NBC News that there was no record of the woman ever working there. Burkman claimed he was investigating sexual misconduct and alcohol allegations, but the evidence suggested otherwise.

The investigation also found that Wohl's company, Surefire Intelligence, was likely a fake company. The domain records for the company's website listed Wohl's email address, and the phone number for the company redirected to Wohl's mother's voicemail. Alleged employees of the company had fake LinkedIn profiles using headshots of random people pulled from the internet. One alleged employee even looked suspiciously like Wohl himself, under the name "Matthew Cohen."

Additionally, the company's LLC was only incorporated a few weeks ago, and the address listed was occupied by a law firm that said it had no connection to Surefire. Wohl stopped responding to NBC News when they called him out about the phone numbers.

The documents posted on Gateway Pundit, which were later taken down, contained a slogan tied to Surefire Intelligence and alleged that one woman would accuse Mueller of sexual misconduct at a New York City hotel on August 2, 2010. However, Mueller was serving jury duty in Washington, D.C. on that day, making the allegations false.

In an update, Gateway Pundit founder Jim Hoft tweeted that the site has taken down the documents and is investigating the allegations that Wohl was involved in the scheme.

Title: Amtrak Train Collides with Freight Train in South Carolina, Killing Two and Injuring 116

A devastating train collision occurred in Cayce, South Carolina, on Sunday, when an Amtrak passenger train derailed after hitting a parked freight train. The incident resulted in the deaths of two crew members and injured at least 116 others. This is Amtrak's fourth fatal crash since December.

The Amtrak train, carrying nine crew members and 136 passengers, was traveling from New York to Miami when it collided with the CSX Corp freight train, which was stopped on a side track, or siding, at around 2:35 a.m. local time. The section of track was operated by CSX, and the Amtrak train was diverted onto the siding at a switch where a padlock had been attached to steer train traffic that way, according to Robert Sumwalt, chairman of the U.S. National Transportation Board.

The NTSB investigation team was at the scene, and the agency's chairman emphasized the importance of understanding why the switch was lined that way. The damage to the locomotives was described as "catastrophic." Two of the 116 people injured were in critical condition.

The two crew members killed in the crash were identified as Amtrak engineer Michael Kempf, 54, of Savannah, Georgia, and conductor Michael Cella, 36, of Orange Park, Florida. Autopsies were underway, according to Lexington County Coroner Margaret Fisher.

The incident occurred about 5 miles southwest of the state capital Columbia. South Carolina Governor Henry McMaster described the scene as "a horrible thing to see, to understand what force was involved." The first engine of the freight train was torn up, and the single engine of the passenger train was barely recognizable.

Amtrak said it was "deeply saddened" by the deaths and stated that CSX owns and controls the dispatching of all trains, including the signal systems that control access to sidings and yards. Amtrak President and CEO Richard Anderson said the passenger train hit the tail end of the CSX train, which had two locomotives and 34 empty auto racks used to transport cars.

The passenger train's locomotive was left lying on its side, and the first car was bent and also derailed, although it remained upright. At least four of the freight train's cars were crumpled, looking like crushed tin foil, but remained on the tracks. The passenger train was part of Amtrak's Silver Star Service. Officials said some 5,000 gallons of fuel leaked as a result of the collision, but there was no threat to public safety.

U.S. President Donald Trump received regular updates on the crash while at his resort in Palm Beach, Florida. "My thoughts and prayers are with all of the victims involved in this morning's train collision in South Carolina," he tweeted. "Thank you to our incredible First Responders for the work they've done!"

The NTSB did not release details on the speed at which the Amtrak train was traveling. In December, three people were killed when an Amtrak passenger train derailed in Washington state. The engineer later told the NTSB he had misread a signal and tried to brake before the accident. In late January, an Amtrak train carrying Republican members of the U.S. Congress killed one person in a garbage truck with which it collided in Virginia. A Federal Railroad Administration Investigative team was also on the scene in South Carolina to help establish what happened.

Title: Facebook Removes Anti-Lockdown Protest Content, Sparking Free Speech Concerns

Facebook has removed content related to anti-lockdown protests, citing concerns over the potential for physical harm and the spread of misinformation. The move has sparked concerns over free speech and censorship, with some arguing that the company is prioritizing government restrictions over individual rights.

Senator Josh Hawley (R-Mo.) questioned the decision, asking, "Is free speech now illegal in America?" Senator Ted Cruz (R-Texas) expressed similar concerns, stating, "Given Big Tech's history of bias and censorship, I'm deeply concerned that they and government officials are partnering to shut down views with which they disagree."

However, Connecticut Democratic Senator Richard Blumenthal praised the company's move, tweeting, "Powerful special interests are using astroturfing and dangerous tactics to undermine the fight against COVID-19. Facebook is right to take a stand against harmful misinformation."

Facebook initially removed the content at the request of states whose authorities said it violated restrictions on large public gatherings. The company later clarified that it sought guidance from states but ultimately made its own decision to take the posts down.

Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg explained the decision, stating that the company removes content that disputes social distancing practices and poses a "risk of imminent physical harm." He emphasized that while Facebook allows debate on policies, it removes content that disputes scientific facts and can cause harm.

The move has sparked debate over the role of social media in facilitating free speech and the balance between individual rights and public health concerns. Some argue that Facebook's decision to remove the content is a necessary measure to prevent the spread of misinformation and protect public health. Others argue that the company is overstepping its bounds and infringing on individual rights.

The controversy is the latest in a series of free-speech flaps to hit Facebook, which has faced criticism for its policies on removing content ranging from misleading political ads to vaccine misinformation. The company has faced criticism for its lack of clear guidelines on what speech it allows on its platform, which reaches more than 2 billion people worldwide.

Experts weigh in on the issue, with some arguing that Facebook's decision to remove the content provides an objective yardstick, while others argue that it can be difficult to judge the fairness of the decision without further clarity. The debate highlights the complex and often opaque nature of social media companies' content moderation decisions and the challenges they face in balancing individual rights with public health concerns.

Title: US Lawmakers Struggle to Reach Deal on Fiscal Cliff, Deadline Looms

The US Congress and President Barack Obama are racing against the clock to reach a deal on the fiscal cliff, a combination of tax increases and spending cuts set to take effect on January 1. With hours to go, the two sides have narrowed their differences, but a deal remains elusive.

Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid, a Democrat, said there is still significant distance between the two sides, but negotiations will continue. The Republicans have dropped their demand to change the Social Security cost-of-living adjustment formula, and both sides have traded offers on the income level at which taxpayers will see an income-tax rate increase.

A deal would need to clear both the Senate and the House, where conservative Republicans hold sway. In the absence of an agreement, Senate Democrats are preparing to force a vote on their own fallback solution, which would raise taxes on families making more than $250,000 and extend unemployment benefits.

The fiscal cliff is the combination of across-the-board tax increases and $110 billion in automatic spending cuts imposed as a result of last year's deal to raise the debt ceiling. Analysts say the combination will plunge the economy into a short, sharp recession, but in the long run, the deficit would drop, government debt would return to manageable levels, and the economy would be stronger over the next decade.

Both sides have moved substantially, with the Republicans conceding one of their major principles in agreeing to higher tax rates and President Obama accepting tax increases beginning at income levels higher than those on which he campaigned. The latest offer from Republicans is to let rates rise on individuals making more than $450,000 and families making more than $550,000, according to Democrats.

It remains unclear whether any final deal will cancel the other part of the cliff: the $110 billion in automatic spending cuts looming on Wednesday. Republicans say Democrats want to use the money from higher tax rates to cancel the cuts and cover new unemployment-benefit spending, which would mean the deficit wouldn't go down and defeat the purpose of a deal on taxes.

Despite the impasse, some senators are preparing their own workarounds. "I will tell you that I've talked with numerous Democrats and Republicans on the floor, and there are a lot of subgroups who are eager to tackle this issue and try to come up with a solution if the negotiations break down at the leaders' level," said Senator Susan Collins, a Republican.

**NASCAR Investigates Noose Found in Garage Stall, Determines It Was Not a Hate Crime**

NASCAR, the National Association for Stock Car Auto Racing, has investigated an incident involving a noose found in the garage stall of Bubba Wallace, its only full-time Black driver. The discovery sparked concerns about racial tensions and safety, but federal authorities have concluded that the noose had been hanging in the stall since at least last October and was not a hate crime.

According to the FBI, the rope had been hanging in the garage stall since at least October 2019, and NASCAR has defended its decision to call in federal authorities. The investigation found that the rope was a pull-down rope used to close the garage door, and it was not a hate crime directed at Wallace.

Wallace, who has been a vocal advocate for racial equality and has worn an "I Can't Breathe" shirt and a Black Lives Matter paint scheme, expressed anger and frustration over the incident, stating that the rope was a noose and that he had not seen it before. He also expressed concerns for his family's safety.

NASCAR President Steve Phelps has defended the organization's reaction to the incident, stating that it was important to investigate and that the evidence showed the rope had been in the garage since last October. The organization has not provided any further details about the incident, citing health protocol restrictions.

The incident has sparked a wider conversation about NASCAR's handling of racial issues and its response to Wallace's advocacy. The organization has not yet provided a plan to address the display of the Confederate flag, which has been a contentious issue in the sport.

Title: Yazidi Volunteers Trained to Fight Islamic State in Iraq

The Yazidi community, a peaceful minority group, has been subjected to brutal attacks and kidnappings by the Islamic State (ISIS). While the exact number of Yazidi men, women, and children killed by ISIS is unknown, reports have been disturbing, and many Yazidi girls and women continue to be forced into slavery and unwanted marriages. In response, Kurdish forces in Syria have trained hundreds of Yazidi volunteers to fight against ISIS in Iraq.

According to Reuters, the training camps in Syria have seen hundreds of Yazidi volunteers, including young and old men, learning how to use assault rifles and rocket-propelled grenades. The training is conducted by the Syrian Kurdish armed group, the YPG, and lasts for several days before the volunteers are sent back to Iraq to fight.

The Yazidi volunteers are motivated to return to Iraq to fight against ISIS, despite the danger, as they believe it is safer for them to stay in Syria. The training camps are located in the Serimli military base in Qamishli, northeastern Syria, near the border with Iraqi Kurdistan.

The training is intense, with the volunteers learning weapon use and fighting tactics in a short period. However, the Yazidi volunteers are determined to take a stand against ISIS, which is a highly sophisticated fighting force. The all-women battalion fighting ISIS in Iraq has shown that even the most unlikely groups can make a difference, and it is hoped that the Yazidi volunteers will soon start making a positive impact as well.

Title: Trump Seeks to Regain Momentum After Healthcare Defeat

President Donald Trump has launched a series of executive orders and policy announcements in an effort to restore momentum after his administration's failed attempt to repeal and replace the Affordable Care Act. The moves, which include rolling back some of President Obama's key policies on climate change and carbon emissions, as well as the creation of a new White House Office of American Innovation, aim to shift the focus away from the healthcare debacle and onto other issues.

The administration's efforts have been met with skepticism by some critics, who argue that Trump's unwillingness to acknowledge and learn from his mistakes will only lead to more problems.
