Others believe that Trump's ability to drive media coverage and change the subject can be a valuable asset in navigating the challenges ahead.

The next big-ticket item on Trump's agenda is tax reform, but any push towards that goal will be subject to the same treacherous cross-currents on Capitol Hill that sank the healthcare push. The administration is also facing ongoing investigations into alleged connections between Russia and people in Trump's orbit, as well as controversy surrounding the conduct of Rep. Devin Nunes, the chairman of the House Intelligence Committee.

While some Republicans, such as Speaker Paul Ryan, are vowing to revisit ObamaCare, there is no clear path forward. Trump has taken to Twitter to blame the conservative House Freedom Caucus for his defeat and has insisted that ObamaCare will "explode." The president has also considered firing an official who reported a whistleblower complaint to Congress.

Despite the challenges, Trump loyalists remain optimistic that the president can bounce back and continue to drive the agenda. "I am still very optimistic," said Barry Bennett, a former senior adviser to Trump's presidential bid. "We had bad days in the campaign. Next day, we're on to the next fight."

Title: Congressional Efforts to Defund Obamacare Face Skepticism from Karl Rove and Others

Article:

Karl Rove, a prominent Republican strategist, has expressed skepticism about the chances of the congressional effort to defund Obamacare, which has been a key goal for some conservative lawmakers. Rove, who was a key advisor to former President George W. Bush, believes that the defunding effort is unrealistic and unlikely to succeed. According to Rove, the defunders would need to convince some Democrats in the Senate to join their cause, which he considers unlikely. Even if they were to succeed, President Barack Obama would likely veto the measure, and overturning the veto would require a significant number of Democratic votes in both the House and Senate.

Despite Rove's skepticism, some conservative lawmakers continue to push for defunding Obamacare, even after Senator Ted Cruz admitted that the votes were not there. The defunders have also been criticized for staging a "palace coup" against House Speaker John Boehner and Majority Leader Eric Cantor, who had proposed a plan that would have required the Senate to vote on defunding Obamacare while still allowing a spending measure to pass.

The defunding effort has set the stage for a potential government shutdown, which could bring most federal activities to a halt. This would likely lead to public outrage and pressure on Republicans to back down, as happened during the 2013 government shutdown.

The article also notes that while some Republicans are pushing for spending reductions, the defunding of Obamacare is not the only way to achieve this goal. The Congressional Budget Office has reported that the nation's long-term fiscal trajectory is unsustainable, and that real and deep cuts to entitlements are needed to address the national debt.

In conclusion, the article highlights the skepticism surrounding the congressional effort to defund Obamacare, as well as the potential consequences of a government shutdown. It also notes that while some Republicans are pushing for spending reductions, the defunding of Obamacare is not the only way to achieve this goal.

Title: Kushner's Coronavirus Task Force Raises Ethics Concerns Over Potential Conflict of Interest

Article:

A recent report by The Washington Post revealed that Jared Kushner, a senior advisor to President Donald Trump, has led a "shadow task force" on the coronavirus, separate from Vice President Mike Pence's official committee. The task force, composed of federal officials and outside corporate executives, has met at the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) headquarters. According to an Oscar spokesperson, a senior official at HHS called Oscar to ask for its help on March 13, the day of Trump's press conference.

Kushner's group has focused on expanding and publicizing coronavirus testing, especially at drive-through locations. Oscar's website would have asked users if they were experiencing symptoms of COVID-19 and surveyed them about other risk factors, including their age and preexisting conditions. The website would have listed a limited number of testing locations nationwide, including some of the drive-through sites that Trump promised. The site was designed to look like a government-developed product, provided freely by HHS to the American public.

Oscar posted the source code for the site to Github, where it was reviewed by ███. The site resembled a version of a tool Oscar had already built for its customers in response to the crisis, but it was "adjusted to meet the specifications and requirements set by the federal government," according to Jackie Kahn, the Oscar spokesperson.

The coincidence that Oscar had already been working on a coronavirus-testing website when HHS called to ask for help was unrelated to Kushner, Kahn suggested. She declined to say whether Oscar had discussed the site with Joshua Kushner or any board members or investors before Trump's March 13 press conference.

Oscar donated its work freely and never expected to be paid for the project, Kahn said. The company is "not, nor has ever been," a contractor or subcontractor for the government, which would make it harder for the government to pay Oscar for its work. The work was "all at the direction of HHS," she said. "The website never saw the light of day," she added in an interview today.

Experts have raised concerns about the ad hoc nature of Kushner's task force and its potential conflict of interest. Jessica Tillipman, an assistant dean at the George Washington University School of Law and an expert on anti-corruption law, said, "It's not typical. It's usually not allowed." Oscar's involvement deepens Kushner's ethics and conflict-of-interest problems.

Oscar's relationship with the Trump administration could breach federal law in two ways, experts said. First, companies are generally not supposed to work for the federal government for free, though some exceptions can be made in a national emergency. "The concern, when you have some free services, is that it makes the government beholden to the company," Tillipman said.

Title: Obama Faces Criticism from Fellow Democrats on Military Sex Crimes and Trade Issues

Article:

President Barack Obama is facing growing criticism from within his own party on two key issues: military sex crimes and trade policies. Senator Kirsten Gillibrand, a Democrat from New York, has expressed disappointment with the administration's lack of progress on reforming the military's judicial system, which was promised in 2013. Gillibrand's criticism comes after her amendment to change the way sexual assault is prosecuted in the military was voted down in the Senate.

Gillibrand stated that the administration has not taken the issue of military sex crimes seriously enough and has not made sufficient progress in reforming the system. She believes that the military justice system should be professionalized, but the administration has resisted these efforts.

This criticism comes on the heels of House Democratic Leader Nancy Pelosi's surprise decision to vote against two trade bills, which were seen as a key part of the administration's trade agenda. Pelosi's opposition was motivated by concerns that the bills did not do enough to protect American workers and provide adequate support for those who have lost their jobs due to foreign trade.

Pelosi's decision was seen as a significant blow to the administration, and it has sparked further divisions within the Democratic Party. Hillary Clinton, the Democratic front-runner in the 2016 presidential election, appeared to back Pelosi's efforts to challenge the administration's trade policies, stating that the president should listen to and work with his allies in Congress to ensure the best possible deal for American workers.

The failure of Gillibrand's amendment and Pelosi's opposition to the trade bills highlight the growing divisions within the Democratic Party on key issues. The criticism of the administration's handling of military sex crimes and trade policies is likely to continue, with some Democrats questioning the president's leadership and commitment to these important issues.

**Ferry Sinking Death Toll Rises to 146, Authorities Confirm**

The death toll from the South Korean ferry disaster has risen to 146, according to the joint task force leading the search and rescue operation. The news comes as authorities continue to investigate the circumstances surrounding the sinking of the Sewol ferry, which occurred on its way to a popular vacation island.

The first distress call from the ferry did not come from the crew, but from a boy who used his cell phone to contact emergency services from aboard the sinking ship. The boy's fate remains unclear. The crew made a distress call to maritime officials three minutes later.

The revelation is likely to add to questions about the conduct of the crew, nine of whom are facing charges in connection with the accident. Authorities have questioned why an inexperienced third mate was guiding the ship at the time of the accident, why few of the ferry's life rafts were deployed, and why crew members ordered passengers to don life vests and stay put.

The search efforts are still ongoing, with divers focusing on the third and fourth decks of the five-level ship. No bodies have been found in the cafeteria, where many passengers were thought to be when the ship began to experience troubles. The death toll had been expected to climb as divers were able to reach the ship's cafeteria.

The investigation is ongoing, with authorities trying to determine what happened to make the ship list before finally capsizing and sinking into the ocean. Initial criticism has focused on the captain and some crew members, with South Korean President Park Geun-hye saying their actions were "akin to murder." The captain has defended his decision to tell passengers to stay put, citing concerns about the sea's strong currents and cold water, as well as the lack of rescue ships.

Title: U.S. Intelligence Agencies Conclude Coronavirus Not Manmade or Genetically Modified, Still Investigating Origins

The Office of the Director of National Intelligence (ODNI) has released a statement confirming that U.S. intelligence agencies have concluded that the new coronavirus was not manmade or genetically modified. The statement also notes that the agencies are still examining whether the origins of the pandemic trace to contact with infected animals or an accident at a Chinese laboratory.

The ODNI's statement comes as President Donald Trump and his allies have touted the theory that an infectious disease lab in Wuhan, China, was the source of the global pandemic that has killed over 220,000 people worldwide. The Trump administration has accused China of failing to act swiftly enough to sound the alarm to the world about the outbreak and stop the spread of the virus.

The intelligence agencies' conclusion aligns with the wide scientific consensus that the COVID-19 virus was not manmade or genetically modified. The ODNI statement emphasizes that the agencies will continue to rigorously examine emerging information and intelligence to determine whether the outbreak began through contact with infected animals or if it was the result of an accident at a laboratory in Wuhan.

Secretary of State Mike Pompeo has pressed China to let outside experts into the lab to determine the origin of the virus. However, a U.S. intelligence official disputed the notion that there was any pressure on agencies to bolster a particular theory.

Scientists have said the virus likely arose naturally in bats, and the Wuhan Institute of Virology, run by the Chinese Academy of Sciences, has done groundbreaking research tracing the likely origins of the SARS virus. The institute is located about 8 miles from the market that is considered a possible source of the outbreak.

The Chinese government has denied any claims that the coronavirus was released from a laboratory, stating that the institute strictly implements bio-security procedures that would prevent the release of any pathogen. Foreign Ministry spokesman Geng Shuang emphasized that the origin of the virus is a complex scientific issue that should be studied by scientists and professionals.

The article highlights the ongoing investigation into the origins of the pandemic and the differing opinions on the matter.

Title: Democratic Lawmakers Praise Trump's Handling of Coronavirus Crisis

Article:

In a rare display of bipartisanship, Democratic Representative Ilhan Omar and other lawmakers have praised President Donald Trump's recent efforts to combat the COVID-19 pandemic. Omar took to Twitter to express her approval, stating that Trump's recent flurry of activity is "incredible and the right response in this critical time." She also retweeted comments from fellow Democratic Representative Ayanna Pressley, who emphasized the need for "unprecedented leadership" in times of crisis.

Omar's praise for the president comes as other prominent Democrats, such as MSNBC's Joe Scarborough and New York Governor Andrew Cuomo, have also expressed support for Trump's handling of the crisis. Scarborough, a longtime Trump critic, acknowledged that the president's efforts to combat the virus are crucial and urged viewers to rally around him. Cuomo praised Trump's sincerity in wanting to work together with states to combat the virus, a notable shift from their previous disagreements on the issue.

CNN's Dana Bash also had kind words for the president, describing him as a leader who is "being the kind of leader that people need, at least in tone, today and yesterday." Trump has taken several steps to combat the virus, including declaring a national emergency, promoting a $1 trillion stimulus bill, and ordering military hospital ships to the Atlantic and Pacific shores of the U.S. to treat coronavirus victims.

Title: Nick Sandmann Discusses Encounter with Native American Activist Nathan Phillips at Lincoln Memorial

Article:

Nick Sandmann, a junior at Covington Catholic High School in Kentucky, sat down with Savannah Guthrie for an interview on TODAY, discussing his encounter with Native American activist Nathan Phillips at the Lincoln Memorial in Washington, D.C. Sandmann, who was wearing a "Make America Great Again" hat, has been the target of criticism online after a widely circulated video showed him appearing to grin close to Phillips' face as the activist sang and played a drum during an Indigenous Peoples March.

In the interview, Sandmann stated that he does not believe he was disrespectful to Phillips and expressed a desire to talk to him. He acknowledged that he wishes the situation could have been avoided and that he had every right to be at the Lincoln Memorial.

Sandmann's family released a statement over the weekend, which provided additional context to the encounter. According to the statement, the students had been subjected to "derogatory insults" from African-American protesters before the incident with Phillips, and Sandmann had led school spirit chants to counter the hateful language. He claimed that he never interacted with Phillips and was startled and confused as to why he had approached him.

Phillips, on the other hand, has said that he approached the students, hoping to defuse the tension from a heated exchange he saw the group have with Black Hebrew Israelites. He has placed blame on the school chaperones, questioning their role in the incident and suggesting that the students should undergo sensitivity training or cultural education.

Covington Catholic High School has stated that the students were in Washington, D.C. to attend the March for Life rally. The full interview with Sandmann will air on TODAY.

Title: Trump's Tax Reform Plan Faces Scrutiny Over Deficit Concerns and Lack of Spending Cuts

The latest spending bill passed by Congress has set the stage for President Trump's long-awaited tax reform plan, which promises to slash corporate tax rates and lower the top income tax bracket. While the plan has been touted as a boon for conservatives, it has also raised concerns about the potential impact on the national debt. The plan is estimated to add around $6 trillion to the national debt over the next 10 years, with some experts predicting that economic growth will make up only a third of the deficit.

The Trump administration has acknowledged that the plan will increase the deficit, but Vice President Pence has argued that economic growth will make up the gap in the short term. However, Democrats and some nonpartisan watchdogs are skeptical of this forecast.

The article highlights the need for spending cuts to offset the increased deficit, citing examples of potential savings from eliminating duplication and fragmentation in government programs, reducing administrative waste, and addressing improper government payments. The Government Accountability Office's 2017 study identified at least $20 billion in potential savings per year, while former Senator Tom Coburn's estimates put the figure at $95 billion per year.

The article concludes that while no spending cut is easy, policymakers should consider the potential savings from eliminating waste and inefficiencies. If Republicans are unwilling to make these cuts, they should question their role in Washington.

Title: Midterm Elections: Democrats Gain Ground, Republicans Face Setbacks

The 2018 midterm elections did not deliver the same level of losses for the Democratic Party as the 2010 elections, but President Trump's "big victory" is looking less impressive as the days pass. The Republican Party suffered losses in the House of Representatives, with at least 35 seats slipping from their grasp, and the total could reach 40 once all too-close-to-call races are settled. The Democratic Party also flipped a second Senate seat from red to blue, with Kyrsten Sinema declared the winner in the Arizona race.

The results solidify the Democratic Party's takeover of the House and maintain the Republican Party's thin majority in the Senate. Democrats also took over at least seven governorships, won back majorities in eight state legislative chambers, and flipped at least 329 state legislative seats.

Senate Minority Leader Charles E. Schumer, a New York Democrat, boasted about his party's "Women of the West," referring to Sens.-elect Sinema and Jacky Rosen, who won a Republican seat in Nevada. The results are a significant blow to President Trump's claims of a "big victory" for the Republican Party.

In Florida, Republican Gov. Rick Scott's lead over Democrat Sen. Bill Nelson is being threatened by an ongoing ballot recount. As of Tuesday, Scott led by more than 12,500 votes, or 0.15% of the roughly 8.2 million votes cast. Republican Ron DeSantis had a 33,000-vote advantage over Democrat Tallahassee Mayor Andrew Gillum in the recount of the Florida governor's race.

Last week, President Trump declared the midterms a Republican success for blunting a blue wave and said they "defied history" with Senate gains. However, the results now suggest that the Republican Party may have gained only one or two Senate seats.

The White House did not respond to questions about the growing Democratic wins. Despite the setbacks, it is the first time a president's party gained Senate seats in the midterms since 2002 under President George W. Bush and the fourth time since 1914.

The Republican Party's losses are a significant blow to President Trump's claims of a "big victory" and a "great victory." The setbacks are a reminder that the 2018 midterm elections were a tough night for the party, with Democratic candidates raising more money than Republicans through ActBlue, a fundraising platform that allowed small-dollar donors to give to a variety of Democratic candidates across the nation.

Title: Senate Republicans Block Chuck Hagel's Nomination to Become Defense Secretary

The nomination of Chuck Hagel to become President Obama's second-term defense secretary has hit a roadblock, with Senate Republicans blocking a vote on the nomination. The vote, largely along party lines, fell short of the required 60 votes needed to proceed to a final vote, with 58 votes in favor and 40 against, with one senator voting present.

Four Republicans, Mike Johanns of Nebraska, Thad Cochran of Mississippi, Susan Collins of Maine, and Lisa Murkowski of Alaska, voted with Democrats to end debate and proceed to a final vote. However, the nomination still requires 60 votes to move forward, and it is unclear where the remaining three votes will come from.

Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid, D-Nev., plans to schedule another procedural vote for the week after next to try to advance Hagel's nomination to a final vote. Republicans have raised concerns about Hagel's speeches and financial dealings, while Democrats have accused them of filibustering the nomination.

The nomination has been met with opposition from some Senate Republicans, who have expressed concerns about Hagel's past statements and actions. Hagel, a former senator from Nebraska, has been criticized for his views on Iran and Israel, and some Republicans have questioned his ability to lead the Department of Defense.

The nomination has also been delayed due to questions about Hagel's financial dealings and his involvement with an Arab-American group. Senate Republicans have requested more information about these issues, but Democrats have accused them of unfairly targeting Hagel.

The outcome of the nomination is uncertain, and it is unclear whether Hagel will ultimately be confirmed as the next defense secretary. If he is not confirmed, President Obama will have to find an alternative nominee.

Title: Senate Hearing on Russian Hacking Raises Questions on Cybersecurity and Political Rhetoric

The recent Senate Armed Services Committee hearing on Russian hacking has sparked controversy and debate, with some questioning the intentions behind the investigation and others criticizing the lack of concrete evidence to support the claims. According to top U.S. intelligence officials, Russia hacked into the Democratic National Committee's emails in an attempt to undermine the U.S. presidential election. However, the officials have not provided concrete evidence to support this claim.

The hearing also saw criticism aimed at the Obama administration's handling of cyber threats, with some arguing that the U.S. has been under cyberattack from various countries, including Russia, China, and Iran, for years. The lack of effective measures to prevent these attacks has been a concern, and some have questioned the effectiveness of President Obama's national security team.

The hearing also saw a focus on the security measures taken by the Democratic National Committee, with some criticizing the use of weak passwords and lack of cybersecurity measures. However, it was also noted that the hacking of the DNC emails was not the only instance of cyberattacks on the U.S. during the election.

The hearing also saw some political rhetoric and finger-pointing, with some criticizing President-elect Donald Trump's security team and others defending the Obama administration's handling of cyber threats. The hearing highlighted the need for a more comprehensive approach to cybersecurity and the importance of protecting the integrity of the U.S. election process.

It is essential to note that the article does not provide concrete evidence to support the claims of Russian hacking, and the lack of transparency and accountability from the intelligence officials has raised concerns. The article also highlights the need for a more comprehensive approach to cybersecurity and the importance of protecting the integrity of the U.S. election process.

Title: Trump Announces Plan to Buy Crude Oil for Strategic Petroleum Reserve, Boosting Prices

The United States' oil industry is facing a crisis due to the decline in crude oil prices, which have fallen by nearly 20% in the past week. In an effort to stabilize the market and help the industry, President Trump announced that the Department of Energy will buy crude oil for the nation's Strategic Petroleum Reserve. The move is expected to save taxpayers "billions and billions of dollars" and help the oil industry, which has been reeling from the decline in prices.

The news sent oil prices up nearly 5% on Friday, but the increase was still a fraction of the amount they lost earlier in the week. The collapse in oil prices has had a significant impact on the rural communities that depend on the oil industry, such as Karnes City, Texas. Local business owner Rudy Martinez has seen a significant decline in revenue due to the drop in oil prices, which has forced him to reduce his prices for out-of-town oilfield workers.

The oil industry is the largest producer of crude oil in the world, and the decline in prices has significant implications for the global economy. The price war between Saudi Arabia and Russia, which began last Sunday, has led to a surplus of oil on the market, causing prices to plummet. Industry analysts warn that if oil prices remain at their current level, which is around $30 per barrel, many oil companies, especially smaller ones, may be forced to make deep cuts or even go bankrupt.

The town of Karnes City, Texas, was transformed by the oil drilling boom that started about a decade ago. The town's economy was boosted by the influx of oil workers and the revenue generated by oil royalties. However, the current decline in oil prices has put a strain on the local economy, with many businesses struggling to stay afloat.

There are reports that the Trump administration may be willing to help the oil industry in other ways, such as reducing federal royalties for oil pumped on government land or offering low-interest government-backed loans. However, some environmental groups, such as Greenpeace, have expressed concerns that the government should not be bailing out the oil industry, which they blame for contributing to the climate crisis.

On the bright side, lower oil prices will mean cheaper gas for motorists in the coming months. While this might normally lead to increased consumption and a boost to the economy, many people are limiting their travel due to concerns over the coronavirus, which could offset the positive impact on the economy.

Title: Bipartisan Report Blames Obama Administration for Failures Leading to Benghazi Attack

A new bipartisan report from the Senate Intelligence Committee has concluded that the Obama administration was responsible for a series of failures that led to the September 11, 2012 terrorist attack on the US diplomatic mission in Benghazi, Libya, which resulted in the deaths of four Americans, including Ambassador J. Christopher Stevens.

The report, released on Wednesday, finds that the State Department failed to increase security at the diplomatic compound despite warnings and ignored requests from its own ambassador for more security. The report also faults intelligence agencies for not sharing information about the existence of the CIA annex with the US military.

The report confirms that the attacks were preventable, citing extensive intelligence reporting on terrorist activity in Libya and known security shortfalls at the US mission. The report concludes that the US military command in Africa did not know about the CIA annex and did not have the resources to defend the diplomatic compound in an emergency.

The report's findings are largely in line with previous investigations and reports, but it does not provide a complete picture of the events leading up to the attack. The report does not address some key questions, such as the role of the CIA and the State Department's handling of intelligence before the attack.

The report's release comes as the Obama administration is facing criticism for its handling of the attack and its aftermath. The report's findings are likely to be used by Republicans to criticize the administration's handling of the attack and its response to the subsequent investigation.

The report's conclusions are based on more than a dozen findings regarding the attacks on the diplomatic compound and CIA annex in Benghazi. The report states that the State Department failed to increase security at the sites despite warnings and ignored requests from its own ambassador for more security. The report also faults intelligence agencies for not sharing information about the existence of the CIA annex with the US military.

The report's findings are likely to be used by both sides of the political aisle to criticize the Obama administration's handling of the attack and its aftermath. The report's release is likely to be a major topic of discussion in the coming weeks and months as the political debate over the attack continues.

Title: Global Stock Markets Plummet to Three-Year Low Amid COVID-19 Pandemic

Global stock markets experienced a volatile session on Wednesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average sinking to a three-year low as the number of coronavirus cases worldwide surpassed 200,000. The ongoing pandemic has led to widespread panic selling, erasing all the gains made since President Donald Trump's inauguration in 2017.

The economic fallout from the crisis is already being felt, with several indicators deteriorating sharply. JPMorgan Chase economist Bruce Kasman noted that the longest global expansion on record will likely end this quarter, and the key outlook issue now is gauging the depth and duration of the 2020 recession.

The Dow Jones Industrial Average settled below the psychologically-important level of 20,000, its lowest close since February 2017, and deep in bear market territory. The S&P 500 plummeted, triggering a market-wide temporary halt to trading before closing down by over 5% on the day. This was the second time in three days the blue-chip index invoked a so-called "circuit breaker" during regular trading, which is intended to prevent extreme losses.

Traders also booked some profits after a brisk rally helped investors recoup some of Monday's ugly losses that saw the Dow Jones Industrial Average sink in its worst day since the Black Monday sell-off of 1987.

The coronavirus pandemic continues to keep investors on edge, as one major economy after the other shuts its borders to stem the outbreak, and considers measures to fight the rising financial and economic disaster that COVID-19 is leaving in its wake. Over 100 countries are battling the virus, and the Trump administration is putting the final touches on a fiscal pump-priming package to ward off the effects of the COVID-19 outbreak.

The stimulus package is likely to top $1 trillion, with both Democrats and Republicans coalescing around the urgent need to backstop consumers. The Senate approved a bill that would pay for sick leave, expanded job benefits, and coronavirus testing.

Monetary policymakers also stepped in with further stimulus, relaunching the Federal Reserve's Commercial Paper Funding Facility, a program helping give U.S. companies increased access to financing amid the pandemic-related disruptions.

The volatility stemming from the outbreak has seen the Dow move up or down by 1,000 points or more for eight straight days, and 11 times total in the last month, according to Yahoo Finance data.

Title: Obama's Promise to Keep Insurance Plans Proves Impossible to Fulfill

The Affordable Care Act (ACA), also known as Obamacare, has been plagued by controversy since its inception. One of the most significant issues is the promise made by President Barack Obama that individuals could keep their current health insurance plans. However, millions of Americans have received cancellation notices from their insurance companies, despite the president's assurance.

Former President Bill Clinton has weighed in on the issue, stating that the president should honor the commitment the federal government made to these people and let them keep their current plans. However, the problem with Clinton's advice is that it is impossible for President Obama to fulfill this promise.

The promise to keep insurance plans was not just an unintended consequence of the law, but a central premise of the ACA. The law's intention was to force people out of their current plans and into the exchanges, where they would be required to purchase more comprehensive coverage. This is necessary to ensure that the exchanges are not overwhelmed by older and less healthy consumers.

The White House has proposed a fix to the problem, which involves allowing people to keep their current plans, but only if they are deemed "substandard." However, this fix is not a solution, as it would require people to make a sacrifice and give up the benefits of the ACA.

The Obama administration's strategy is to muddle through the issue and hope that it will blow over. However, this approach is unlikely to work, as the costs of the ACA are immediate and concrete, and the politics of the issue are becoming increasingly toxic.

In conclusion, the promise to keep insurance plans was always an impossible promise, and the Obama administration's attempts to fix the problem are unlikely to succeed. The ACA is a complex law that has far-reaching implications for the American healthcare system, and it is unlikely that the administration will be able to muddle through the issue without significant consequences.

Title: Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez Criticizes Amazon's Tax Breaks for New York Headquarters

Article:

Representative-elect Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, a Democrat from New York, has expressed concerns over Amazon's decision to locate half of its second headquarters in Long Island City, Queens. Ocasio-Cortez criticized the reported tax breaks the company will receive, stating that they may come at the expense of critical infrastructure projects, such as the city's mass transit and public housing.

In a series of tweets, Ocasio-Cortez questioned the fairness of the deal, suggesting that the tax breaks may benefit Amazon at the expense of the local community. She emphasized the need for substantial benefits for the surrounding community, including good healthcare, living wages, and affordable rent.

The representative-elect's stance on the issue puts her at odds with some of New York's top Democrats, including Governor Andrew Cuomo and Mayor Bill de Blasio, who have been involved in negotiations over the deal. Ocasio-Cortez's position may further solidify her reputation as an outsider among New York's establishment Democrats.

Amazon's decision to split its second headquarters between Long Island City, Queens, and Crystal City, Virginia, is expected to bring 50,000 jobs and approximately $5 billion in investment to the selected locations. The company's decision beat out other contenders, including Newark, New Jersey, Boston, and Austin, Texas.

State and local officials are expected to make an official announcement on Tuesday, according to a source with knowledge of the plans. Ocasio-Cortez's district includes parts of Queens adjacent to Long Island City, including Sunnyside and parts of Astoria.

**Bush's Frustration Spills Over as Supporters Weigh Their Options**

As the New Hampshire primary approaches, frustration within Jeb Bush's campaign is growing, with even his most loyal supporters acknowledging that it may be time to consider moving on. Despite his struggles in the polls, Bush's network of donors and supporters remains strong, with many bound by their long-standing connections to the Bush family.

However, some influential supporters are beginning to question whether Bush's campaign has a viable future. "I acknowledge reality," said former Minnesota Rep. Vin Weber, a Jeb Bush adviser who worked on George W. Bush's presidential campaigns. "The field is going to narrow pretty quickly. We'll see what happens in South Carolina, and from there, you can see the dynamic starting to winnow the field pretty quickly."

While Weber said he would remain with Bush as long as he's in the race, others are considering their options. "If he doesn't do well in New Hampshire, I think he needs to think long and hard about what he wants to do," said a top Bush fundraiser who played a key role in his brother's administration.

Bush's top aides are working to keep restless supporters in line, but some donors are already looking to the South Carolina primary on February 20 as a turning point. "That's when they say, 'Enough,'" said a high-profile Bush financial backer who has been close to the family for years.

Despite the challenges, Bush's campaign still has some reason for optimism. He has climbed to within striking distance of second place in recent polls, putting him in a head-to-head competition with Marco Rubio. Additionally, he may have more upside after Saturday night's GOP debate, where he emerged relatively unscathed while Rubio stumbled under attacks from Chris Christie.

However, the question of whether to desert Bush is a complicated one for his supporters. His network of loyal donors and political supporters is extensive, and the ties between them and the Bush family are strong and long-lasting. For some, the thought of him dropping out is almost unthinkable, particularly if Rubio emerges as the leading establishment candidate.

Title: Republicans Pledge to Reversal of Obama's Foreign Policy Achievements

Article:

In the 2016 presidential election, Republicans have made a vow to repeal not only the Affordable Care Act, but also President Obama's signature foreign policy achievements. This includes his efforts to restore diplomatic relations with Cuba and negotiate a deal to limit Iran's nuclear program.

Several GOP presidential contenders, including Senator Marco Rubio, have pledged to reverse these policies, regardless of what may happen between now and the next Inauguration Day. Rubio, a Cuban-American, is a fierce critic of Cuba's government and has called for a reversal of warming U.S. relations with the island nation.

Rubio believes that the U.S. should not lift sanctions on Cuba until "free and fair elections" are held, and that U.S. policy can provide "major leverage" to achieve this goal. He also opposes the Iran nuclear deal, stating that the U.S. should reimpose sanctions, even if other world powers and the United Nations do not follow suit.

The prospect of such dramatic foreign policy reversals raises many questions. While a president can break diplomatic relations with Cuba, it is unclear whether a president can unilaterally tear up an agreement made by their predecessor. Supporters of Obama's Cuba policy expect a different dynamic, as the U.S. opening to Cuba may bring economic opportunities and American entrepreneurs may not be eager to rupture ties again.

The debate surrounding Obama's foreign policy legacy is likely to continue, with Republicans running against the retiring president's record and Democrats defending his accomplishments. While most elections do not turn on foreign policy, this election may be an exception, with plenty of discussion and debate surrounding the issue.

Title: Debate Surrounds Gun Control Measures in Wake of Las Vegas Massacre

The recent mass shooting in Las Vegas has sparked a renewed discussion about the need for stricter gun control measures. However, opinions on the issue remain divided, with some advocating for stronger laws and others opposing them. The debate centers on the effectiveness of existing laws and regulations in preventing such tragedies, as well as the potential consequences of implementing new measures.

Proponents of stricter gun control argue that the Las Vegas shooting highlights the need for more robust laws and enforcement. They point to the fact that the shooter used a type of rifle commonly used in mass shootings and that the existing laws and regulations did not prevent the tragedy. They also argue that a total ban and confiscation of certain types of weapons could help prevent such incidents.

On the other hand, those who resist calls for stricter gun control laws argue that the problem lies not with the guns themselves, but with the individuals who misuse them. They point to the fact that the vast majority of gun owners are law-abiding citizens who use their weapons responsibly. They also argue that a ban on certain types of weapons would not have prevented the Las Vegas shooting and could lead to unintended consequences, such as a black market for illegal weapons.

The debate also touches on the issue of gun ownership and the cultural significance of guns in American society. Some argue that guns are a fundamental right and that attempts to restrict them would infringe on personal freedoms. Others argue that the Second Amendment does not protect the right to own any type of weapon and that stricter regulations are necessary to prevent harm.

The debate surrounding gun control is complex and multifaceted, with valid arguments on both sides. While some argue that stricter laws and regulations are necessary to prevent mass shootings, others believe that the problem lies with the individuals who misuse guns and that a ban on certain types of weapons would not be effective. Ultimately, the solution to this issue will require a nuanced and balanced approach that takes into account the rights and freedoms of all individuals involved.

Title: US-China Agreement on Emissions Cuts: A Step Forward, But Not Enough to Meet 2-Degree Target

The United States and China have announced a historic agreement to reduce greenhouse gas emissions, with the US committing to cut its emissions by 26-28% by 2025 compared to 2005 levels, and China pledging to peak its emissions by 2030 and increase the share of non-fossil fuels in its energy mix to 20% by the same date. While this agreement marks a significant step forward in international cooperation on climate change, it falls short of the goal of limiting global warming to 2 degrees Celsius above pre-industrial levels.

The agreement is seen as a political signal from both countries, with the US seeking to create a level playing field for its industry and China aiming to show its commitment to reducing air pollution and addressing climate change. However, environmental groups and some countries are cautious about the agreement's impact on global emissions, with Samantha Smith from the World Wildlife Fund stating that it "does not put us on a pathway to 2 degrees."

The agreement also highlights the need for developed countries to take on a greater share of the burden of reducing emissions, with some countries resisting attempts to limit their use of coal for development. The deal may also put pressure on other developed countries, such as Japan, Canada, and Australia, to take action on climate change.

The real significance of the US-China agreement lies in its impact on the United Nations political process, with every nation committed to agreeing a new deal by the time the parties meet in Paris next year. The agreement may also signal a shift in China's position on climate change, with Liz Gallagher from environmental think-tank E3G noting that it "signals a shift" in China's stance.

However, the agreement does not address the financial mechanism needed to compensate countries most vulnerable to climate change, with many nations seeking a legal responsibility for those who have contributed most to the problem. The lack of a clear financial mechanism may hinder the progress of the Paris negotiations, with Tosi Mpanu-Mpanu, a senior negotiator from the Democratic Republic of Congo, stating that "there is a need for the developing countries to see that there would be certainty in terms of future flows of finance."

Title: Many Voters Unaware of Congressional Candidates' Names Ahead of Midterm Elections

A recent poll conducted by Ipsos found that about a third of registered voters in the United States do not know the name of their party's candidate for Congress, with 34% of Republican registered voters and 32.5% of Democratic registered voters unaware of their party's nominee. This lack of name recognition is a critical factor in motivating voters, as candidates spend millions of dollars on TV ads and incumbents often have an advantage in fending off challengers.

The poll, which surveyed 2,597 registered voters between September 24-30, found that the level of congressional candidate name recognition is about in line with recent elections. According to Marc Hetherington, a professor of political science at the University of North Carolina, "people aren't voting for their side as much as they are voting against the other side. It really doesn't matter what the names are these days."

The poll also found that generic party interest is not working to Republicans' advantage nationally, with 54% of U.S. adults disapproving of President Donald Trump's handling of the presidency. Democrats need to pick up 23 seats in the House to win a majority that they could use to more effectively oppose Trump's agenda.

Beyond party and name recognition, gender may play a role in voters' decisions this year, according to Michael Cornfield, an associate professor of political management at George Washington University. The #MeToo movement and protests around Trump's Supreme Court nominee Brett Kavanaugh have played into this trend. "In these cases, it's not just the name," Cornfield said in an email. "Gender relations may be the top issue."

Title: Trump Stumps for Cruz in Texas, Calls Opponent "Radical, Open Borders Left-Winger"

Article:

In a rally in Houston, Texas, President Trump reflected on his evolving relationship with Senator Ted Cruz, describing him as "a really good friend of mine." Trump urged voters to re-elect Cruz next month, citing the importance of defending the fragile Republican majority in the Senate and passing his proposed border wall. The event was held at the Toyota Arena, which was crowded but not at capacity, with 100,000 people expressing interest in free tickets.

Trump praised Cruz's efforts to defend freedom and his stance on immigration, calling him an ally in the fight against "radical, open borders left-wingers." He also referenced their past disagreements, saying that "we had our little difficulties" but that Cruz has since become a strong supporter of his agenda.

Cruz faces Democratic challenger Beto O'Rourke, who has gained significant attention and raised a record-breaking $38.1 million in the third quarter. Trump characterized O'Rourke as a "gun-grabbing liberal" and vowed to fight for Second Amendment protections if re-elected. O'Rourke has stated he would vote to impeach Trump and supports relaxed immigration policies and gun control.

Texas Governor Greg Abbott also joined the rally, urging voters to support Cruz and calling O'Rourke "hostile to Texas values" and "against good quality judges." The Trump campaign reported that the event was shifted to a larger arena to accommodate the high demand for tickets.

While some attendees, like retired oil industry executive Rick LaBlanc, attended the rally primarily to see Trump, others, like Suzanne Asevedo, a greater Houston resident, expressed support for Cruz and Trump's policies. Asevedo believes that Texas remains a conservative state and that O'Rourke's views are not in line with the state's values.

The article does not provide information on the exact polling numbers or the likelihood of O'Rourke's chances of winning the election.

Title: Global Coronavirus Death Toll Tops 2,600 as Alabama Rejects Plan to House Infected Cruise Ship Passengers

The global death toll from the coronavirus has surpassed 2,600, with over 79,000 confirmed cases reported worldwide. In the United States, there are currently 35 confirmed cases. A federal plan to house infected passengers from the Diamond Princess cruise ship at a facility in Alabama was met with resistance from state officials, who may have forced the plan to be shelved.

The plan, which was announced by the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services (HHS), aimed to use the FEMA Center for Domestic Preparedness in Anniston as a quarantine center for passengers with minor symptoms or no symptoms at all. However, the plan drew a swift and negative response from local officials, including the mayor, governor, and several congressmen.

"We do not want the coronavirus brought here," said Rep. Bradley Byrne on Twitter. "I'm fighting to bring this to a full stop. Leave these people in the place they came to, don't spread them around the US, and keep them out of Alabama. The risk is much too high."

Rep. Mike Rogers also expressed his opposition to the plan, stating that he had spoken with President Donald Trump, who agreed that the HHS plan was the "wrong decision."

Alabama Governor Kay Ivey expressed her concerns over the potential risks of housing infected individuals in Anniston, citing "grave concerns" over how the facility was chosen. "First and foremost, my priority is to protect the people of Alabama," she said in a statement. "While locating these folks in Alabama is currently a backup plan, this is a serious issue and we need to be fully aware of the facts regarding the potential of housing them in Anniston."

Meanwhile, South Korea has raised its virus alert level to red, the highest in its four-tier system, after reporting its sixth and seventh coronavirus deaths. The country has surpassed 760 cases, with schools set to reopen on March 9.

In China, President Xi Jinping has pledged to take "unrelenting efforts" to control the outbreak, which has killed over 2,400 people. More than 77,000 cases have been reported in mainland China, with over 24,000 patients confirmed as "totally recovered."

In Iran, President Hassan Rouhani has set up a national committee to manage the epidemic, which has killed eight people and infected 43 others. Cultural centers, schools, and universities in 14 provinces have been ordered closed, and Turkey has closed its border with Iran. The World Health Organization has expressed concern over the "very rapid increase" in cases in Iran.

Title: Glenn Greenwald Warns of Permanent Erosion of Civil Liberties Under Presidential Power

Glenn Greenwald, a prominent journalist and author, has expressed concerns about the potential long-term consequences of the erosion of civil liberties and the concentration of power in the hands of the president. In a recent article, he emphasized that the acquisition of abusive powers and civil liberties erosions often become permanent, not just limited to current leaders, but also future officials who may be less benign.

Greenwald noted that many Obama supporters are optimistic about the president's commitment to civil liberties, but he believes that this shortsightedness is a major concern. He pointed out that few are urging the president to limit executive power before it's too late, even when he is a lame duck. Greenwald also criticized Republicans who are critical of Obama's policies, but remain silent about his secret kill list.

The journalist argued that it is crucial to defeat Romney and Ryan, who are seen as malign and bellicose bullies with no regard for anyone but the rich. However, he also expressed concerns about Obama's institutionalized kill list and the precedents he has set, which could have long-term consequences.

Greenwald's comments highlight the importance of balancing national security concerns with the protection of civil liberties and the need for transparency and accountability in government. His warnings serve as a reminder that the erosion of civil liberties can have far-reaching consequences, regardless of the intentions of current leaders.

Title: Hurricane Sandy Dominates Media Coverage, Making it Tough for Romney to Gain Momentum

The devastating effects of Hurricane Sandy have taken center stage in the media, overshadowing the presidential election and making it challenging for Mitt Romney to gain momentum in the final days of the campaign. The storm's impact has been intense, with many news outlets dedicating extensive coverage to the disaster and its aftermath.

Romney's campaign has been sensitive to the situation, with the candidate collecting donated food in Ohio, calling for donations to the American Red Cross, and sending messages of sympathy. However, he has not been able to command the same level of attention as President Obama, who has been touring New Jersey with Republican Governor Chris Christie, praising Obama's handling of the disaster.

Experts suggest that the storm's impact on the election is unlikely to be significant, as voters are already largely decided and millions have already cast their ballots. The storm's destruction primarily affected northeastern states that were considered certain to vote for Obama, making it unlikely to reshape the electoral map.

While Romney's campaign may struggle to gain traction, experts believe that the media attention will eventually shift back to the election. The jobs report on Friday could potentially change the subject, particularly if unemployment numbers worsen. However, even if Romney is unable to get much attention, it may not significantly impact the outcome of the election, as voters have already made up their minds.

In the end, the presidential election will likely take precedence in terms of media coverage, and voters will have the opportunity to make their choices known.

Title: House Republicans' Lawsuit Against Obama's Healthcare Law Delayed

The House Republicans' lawsuit against President Barack Obama's healthcare law, announced last June, has yet to be filed, despite initial expectations that it would be done by September. The lawsuit, which claims the president exceeded his constitutional authority by failing to implement certain provisions of the Affordable Care Act, was seen as a way to rally Republicans ahead of the midterm elections. However, the delay has led some to question the seriousness of the legal challenge.

According to lawyers close to the process, the lawsuit was initially expected to be filed in September, but it is now unlikely to happen before the elections. The delay has sparked speculation that Republicans may be hesitant to raise the issue again, fearing it could energize the Democratic base and alienate some voters.

Some Democrats have suggested that the delay is a sign that the lawsuit was never more than a political stunt, while others believe it may be a strategic move to avoid controversy before the elections. A spokesman for House Speaker John Boehner declined to comment on the reasons for the delay, stating that the timing of the lawsuit remains uncertain.

Conservatives, however, see the delay as an opportunity to focus on the substance of the lawsuit and its potential consequences for the president's authority. Todd Gaziano of the Pacific Legal Foundation argued that the lawsuit can have "very helpful consequences for a principle that I think liberals and conservatives should both be concerned about, and that is the president's unilateral authority to rewrite a statute in dozens of ways."

The delay has also led to questions about the motivations behind the lawsuit. Some Democrats believe that the announcement of the lawsuit was a way to placate conservatives, while others see it as a way to distract from the real issues facing the country. Regardless of the reason, the delay has left the fate of the lawsuit uncertain, and its potential impact on the healthcare law and the president's authority remains to be seen.

Title: Pentagon to Allow Transgender Individuals to Enlist in Military Starting January 1

The United States Defense Department has confirmed that transgender individuals will be allowed to enlist in the military starting January 1, 2023, following a federal court order. This decision comes after President Trump's announcement in July 2020, which banned transgender servicemembers, was challenged in court.

According to Pentagon officials, potential transgender recruits will still need to meet a strict set of physical, medical, and mental conditions to join the armed services. These conditions include being clinically stable in their preferred gender for 18 months and free of significant distress or impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas. Transgender individuals receiving hormone therapy must also be stable on their medication for 18 months.

The new policy reflects growing legal pressure on the issue and the difficulties the federal government would face in enforcing Trump's demand. The Defense Department is still studying the issue and will disqualify potential recruits with gender dysphoria, a history of medical treatments associated with gender transition, and those who have undergone reconstruction.

Last year, then-Defense Secretary Ash Carter ended the ban on transgender service members, allowing them to serve openly in the military. However, Trump's tweet in July 2020 stated that the federal government would not accept or allow transgender troops to serve in any capacity. A month later, he issued a formal order telling the Pentagon to extend the ban, giving the department six months to determine what to do about those currently serving.

The decision has been challenged in court, and two U.S. district court judges have already ruled against the ban. The government had asked that the January 1 requirement be put on hold while the appeal proceeds, but the Pentagon's move signals that authorities are likely to lose the legal fight.

Title: NSA Whistleblower Edward Snowden's Potential Return to the US Hinges on Amnesty and Security Assurances

The possibility of Edward Snowden's return to the United States is still uncertain, with the whistleblower living and working in Russia under a one-year asylum. Snowden, who was indicted by the Justice Department in June on charges of espionage and stealing government property, has stated he would return to the US if offered amnesty. However, it is unclear whether the Obama administration would make such an offer, given the alleged damage Snowden's leaks have done to national security.

The NSA is still uncertain about the extent of the classified information Snowden took, with government officials sometimes learning about specific documents from reporters preparing their articles for publication, leaving the State Department with limited time to notify foreign leaders about upcoming disclosures. The Justice Department has continued its investigation into Snowden's actions, with FBI agents from the Washington field office believing he methodically downloaded files over several months while working as a government contractor at a Hawaii facility. Officials also believe he worked alone.

The investigation is ongoing, with some American officials placing blame on the NSA for being slow to install software that can detect unusual computer activity carried out by the agency's workforce, which is the largest of any intelligence agency, with approximately 35,000 employees.

Title: "Tahrir al-Sham: The Emergence of a New, Nimble, and Potentially More Destructive Extremist Group"

The article discusses the rise of Tahrir al-Sham, a militant group that has gained notoriety for its use of technology to spread its message and recruit new members. The group, which emerged from a merger between the al-Nusra Front and other militant groups in Syria, has adopted a more nimble and adaptable approach compared to its predecessors, such as ISIS.

Tahrir al-Sham's recruitment video, which was uploaded on Telegram, features a young man in military attire calling on viewers to join the fight against various enemies, including Bashar al-Assad, the United States, and Russia. The video's production quality and the speaker's media training suggest a well-planned and executed campaign.

The group's use of Telegram's end-to-end encryption channels and Dark Web social networks makes it difficult to detect and censor their activities. They have also experimented with platforms like Sarahah, which allows users to send anonymous messages, and have used a honeypot approach to test different messages and gauge their effectiveness.

Tahrir al-Sham's goals are not focused on governance, unlike ISIS, but rather on disrupting critical infrastructure and causing chaos. They have bragged about adapting drones to deliver explosives or biological agents and have posted encrypted videos of their efforts. Their ability to shape and deploy information to their advantage makes them a significant concern for Western intelligence agencies.

The article concludes that Tahrir al-Sham's emergence highlights the need for a better understanding of the digital battlefield and the importance of staying ahead of their tactics.

Title: Congressional Report Reveals Decline in ObamaCare Penalty Payments, Raising Concerns for Insurers

A recent congressional report has estimated that over 25 million Americans without health insurance will not be required to pay a penalty in 2016, due to an increasing number of ObamaCare exemptions. According to an analysis by the Congressional Budget Office and the Joint Committee on Taxation, the number of people expected to pay the fine has decreased to approximately four million, down from the previous projection of six million. This decline is attributed to the growing number of exemptions granted to individuals who are not required to purchase health insurance.

The report highlights concerns among insurers, who argue that the exemptions are resulting in a smaller pool of young, healthy individuals signing up for health insurance. This could lead to higher premiums for those who do purchase insurance, as the pool becomes skewed towards older, less healthy individuals.

Under the Affordable Care Act, the penalty for not purchasing health insurance is either $95 per adult or 1% of family income, whichever is greater. This amount is set to increase to $695 per adult or 2.5% of family income in 2016, with a total family penalty capped at $2,085.

The Act provides exemptions to the penalty for certain groups, including illegal immigrants, members of certain Native American tribes or religious sects, and individuals experiencing hardships such as domestic violence, property damage, or having a health plan canceled. The Obama administration has also added exemptions for individuals who "experienced another hardship acquiring health insurance," which does not require documentation.

Residents of 21 states who have opted not to expand their Medicaid program under the health law may also be exempt from the penalty. Additionally, more than 4 million Americans who receive subsidies through the federal ObamaCare exchange could qualify for hardship waivers if the subsidies are struck down in court.

The Affordable Care Act was narrowly upheld by the Supreme Court in June 2012, with the court ruling that the individual mandate was not a tax. Republicans have argued that the Obama administration has undermined its own argument by issuing so many exemptions and should scrap the mandate completely.

As of April, approximately 77,000 individuals and families have requested an exemption, with this number expected to rise as many exemption requests can only be claimed on tax returns filed in 2015. The Obama administration has given people whose insurance plans were canceled due to not meeting ObamaCare's minimum coverage requirements an exemption that runs until October 2016, and they are also allowed to buy a minimum amount of coverage originally available to people under 30.

Title: Supreme Court to Hear Cases on Same-Sex Marriage, a Major Shift in a Decade-Long Debate

The Supreme Court has agreed to hear two cases related to same-sex marriage, a significant development in the decade-long debate over the issue. The court will consider the constitutionality of the Defense of Marriage Act (DOMA), which defines marriage as between one man and one woman, and the California Proposition 8, which banned same-sex marriage in the state.

The court's decision to hear both cases is a departure from its earlier cautious approach, which saw it avoid taking on the issue of same-sex marriage. The justices will now consider whether the federal government can discriminate against same-sex couples married in states that allow such unions, as well as whether the Constitution requires states to allow same-sex marriage.

The court's decision to hear the California case, filed by Theodore B. Olson and David Boies, seeks to establish a constitutional right to same-sex marriage in remaining states that prohibit it. The case has been ongoing for three and a half years, and advocates are bracing for a potential split decision.

The court's consideration of the cases has some supporters of traditional marriage expressing optimism, while others are concerned about the potential implications. The court could strike down DOMA, saying that the meaning of marriage is a matter for the states to decide, or it could reject the idea that the Constitution requires states to allow same-sex marriage, saying that the meaning of marriage is a matter for the states to decide.

The court has left itself several options to consider, including affirming a California-only rationale relied on by the appeals court, which said Proposition 8 must fall because voters had withdrawn a constitutional right from gay men and lesbians. The justices could also pursue what some call the "eight-state solution," which would affect California, Delaware, Hawaii, Illinois, Nevada, New Jersey, Oregon, and Rhode Island, which give gay and lesbian couples all the benefits and burdens of marriage but withhold the name "marriage."

The court's decision to consider the cases marks a significant shift in its approach to same-sex marriage, which has been a topic of debate for decades. The court's consideration of the cases is a major development in the ongoing debate over same-sex marriage, and its decision is expected to have significant implications for the rights of gay and lesbian couples across the country.

**Iran Denies Using Live Ammunition Against Protesters, Amid Widespread Anger Over Plane Crash**

Police in Tehran have denied using live ammunition against protesters who took to the streets over the shooting down of a Ukrainian airliner, killing all 176 people on board. The incident has sparked widespread anger and protests across Iran, with many Iranians venting their fury against the government and the powerful Revolutionary Guards.

The protests began on Saturday, following Iran's admission that its military had mistakenly shot down the Ukraine International Airlines jet. The admission came after video emerged of a missile appearing to hit the plane. The incident has been met with widespread condemnation, with many Iranians expressing outrage and grief over the loss of life.

Videos posted online showed what appeared to be gunfire and an injured woman being carried away. A protester who witnessed the incident told the BBC that security forces used sticks and beat protesters, and then began firing live ammunition when people started shouting slogans.

Despite these reports, Tehran police chief Brig-Gen Hossein Rahimi insisted that his officers did not fire live ammunition at protesters. "The police treated the people who had gathered with patience and tolerance," he said.

Iranian government spokesman Ali Rabiei dismissed US President Donald Trump's expressions of support for the protesters as "crocodile tears." Fresh protests reportedly took place on Monday outside universities in Tehran and the city of Isfahan.

The incident has also sparked international outrage, with Ukraine's Foreign Minister, Vadym Prystaiko, saying that Iranian President Hassan Rouhani had assured the Ukrainian government that "no one who is to blame will escape punishment." Canada's Prime Minister Justin Trudeau also vowed that his country would "not rest until we get the accountability, justice, and closure that the families deserve."

The Iranian government has denied any cover-up, with spokesman Ali Rabiei blaming a "lack of valid information" and "US psychological warfare" for the initial denials of responsibility. However, the Revolutionary Guards' Aerospace Force Commander, Brig-Gen Amir Ali Hajizadeh, had said that he had informed officials about the missile strike on Wednesday, contradicting the government's earlier claims.

Title: NSA's Middle East and North Africa Group Updates Sigint Collection Capabilities

The National Security Agency's (NSA) Middle East and North Africa group has undergone an ambitious scrub of its Sigint collection capabilities, resulting in a significant reduction in the number of search terms and messages added to its Pinwale database. In 2008, the agency reduced its selectors from 21,177 to 7,795, and the number of messages added daily from 850,000 to 450,000.

According to a report, this reduction allowed for new collection on Iranian leadership and Saudi and Syrian diplomats. The NSA analysts also discovered major glitches in their search software, including not searching for email addresses, which resulted in missed targets.

The agency's former inspector general, Joel F. Brenner, believes that much of the criticism is unfair, citing the agency's role in national security. However, he also acknowledges that technology has outrun policy at the NSA, and that targeting close allies is bad politics and foolish.

Another former insider, William E. Binney, a former senior NSA official, shares concerns about the agency's potential threat to American citizens. He believes that without new leadership, laws, and reforms, the agency will pose a threat of "turnkey totalitarianism," where its power could be turned against the American public.

Former NSA Director Bobby R. Inman suggests that the agency should take the leaked information and get it out in the open, rather than keeping it secret. He believes that bad news doesn't get better with age and that the sooner the agency addresses the issue, the faster it can begin to rebuild.

The article highlights the ongoing debate about the NSA's role in national security and the need for transparency and accountability. While some argue that the agency's actions are necessary for national security, others believe that its actions pose a threat to American citizens and the democratic process.

Title: Trump's Record of Contradictions and Controversies Raises Concerns Among Experts

Article:

Donald Trump's presidential campaign has been marked by a series of policy shifts and contradictions on major issues, leaving many experts and voters concerned about his ability to deliver on his promises. According to NBC News, Trump has made 117 distinct policy shifts on 20 major issues, including three contradictory views on abortion in an eight-hour period.

Trump's record on immigration and national security has been particularly concerning. He has used anti-immigrant and nativist rhetoric to build his base, and has made statements that have been criticized as racist. He has also denied his own record on the "birther" conspiracy theory, which questioned President Obama's legitimacy.

Trump's economic plan has been criticized for its lack of detail and potential negative impact on the national debt and global financial markets. His plan to cut taxes for the wealthy has been estimated to cost $10 trillion in tax revenue, with no clear indication of how it would be paid for. His plan to renegotiate the Iran nuclear deal has been met with skepticism by experts on national defense and international affairs.

Trump's views on global warming have also been criticized, as he has repeatedly called it a "hoax." However, his own golf course in Ireland has cited global warming as a reason to build a protective wall against rising sea levels. His admiration for Russian President Vladimir Putin has also raised concerns, as Putin has been accused of abusing critics and dissenters, and cracking down on the press.

Experts have expressed concerns about Trump's ability to deliver on his promises, citing his lack of experience and his tendency to make contradictory statements. Former Secretary of State Colin Powell has even called Trump an "international pariah." Voters should be asking themselves whether Trump's record of contradictions and controversies is a recipe for success or a recipe for disaster.

Title: Biden and Bloomberg Push for Tougher Gun Control Measures Amid Political Roadblock

The push for a federal gun control law has hit a roadblock, but Vice President Joe Biden and New York Mayor Michael Bloomberg are not giving up. On Thursday, they joined families of the victims of the December 2012 shooting at Sandy Hook Elementary School in Newtown, Connecticut, to advocate for stricter gun control measures, including a national requirement for background checks on all gun sales.

Bloomberg cited public opinion polls showing widespread support for background checks, stating that "there's no real debate" among Americans on this issue. He emphasized that nationwide background checks on all gun sales would save lives and that the only question is whether Congress has the courage to do the right thing. Bloomberg noted that guns purchased in states with "weak gun laws" often end up in states with stricter requirements, highlighting the need for a national standard.

The proposed ban on semi-automatic weapons, styled after military assault weapons, appears to be facing an uphill battle in the Senate, with Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid stating that it would likely receive fewer than 40 votes, short of the threshold needed to defeat a filibuster or pass the Senate. However, Reid suggested that the ban could be offered as an amendment to the gun legislation on the Senate floor to get a vote on it.

Biden, who praised Bloomberg's "immense" and "committed" gun control work, criticized those who claim that the proposals would violate constitutional rights. He argued that limiting ammunition clips to 10 rounds does not infringe on anyone's rights and pointed to the positive impact of previous gun control measures, such as the 1994 assault weapons ban and the Brady Bill.

Biden also expressed admiration for the Newtown families, who have been instrumental in pushing for gun control reform. He noted that the Sandy Hook Elementary School shooting was conducted with a weapon of war and emphasized that such weapons have no place on American streets. Biden also referenced conservative Supreme Court Justice Antonin Scalia's acknowledgment that the government has a right to limit certain weapons from being possessed by American citizens.

The proposed reforms aim to reduce gun violence and save lives, with Biden stating that they will not solve every problem but will substantially reduce gun deaths. The push for stricter gun control measures is ongoing, with Biden and Bloomberg determined to make progress despite the political roadblock.

Title: The Broken Process of Selecting Supreme Court Justices

The retirement of Justice Anthony Kennedy has brought attention to the broken process of selecting Supreme Court justices. The chaotic and ugly realpolitik that followed Justice Antonin Scalia's death has led to a situation where the minority party no longer holds any power over Supreme Court picks. The majority party can now jam whomever they want onto the Court, where they will serve for life.

The past few years have seen the elimination of the filibuster on Supreme Court nominations, and the precedent set by Senate Republicans in 2016, where they refused to hold a hearing for President Obama's nominee, Merrick Garland, has led to a situation where Supreme Court seats may remain unfilled for years.

The stakes of Supreme Court nominations are too high, with justices serving for life and having the power to decide on issues such as election funding, abortion laws, and healthcare. This has led to a situation where both sides take Supreme Court nominations as seriously as they deserve to be taken, resulting in a disastrous outcome.

One possible solution to this problem is to limit the terms of Supreme Court justices. Holding justices to a 10-year, non-renewable term would lower the stakes of individual Supreme Court nominations and make the timing of fights more predictable. This reform could have bipartisan support and would move the court closer to the people by ensuring that every President would have the opportunity to replace two Justices per term.

In conclusion, the process of selecting Supreme Court justices is broken and needs to be reformed. Limiting the terms of justices is one possible solution to this problem, and it would be a step toward repairing and normalizing a process that is now dangerously broken, infuriatingly random, and distorting both our politics and the judges we choose to interpret our laws.

**Booker Drops Out of Presidential Race, Citing Lack of Funds and Debate Exclusion**

Democratic presidential candidate Cory Booker has ended his campaign, citing the inability to raise the necessary funds to continue his bid and his failure to qualify for the December primary debate. This marks the end of a campaign that struggled to gain momentum, with Booker polling in low single digits in early primary states and nationwide.

Booker, a U.S. senator from New Jersey, launched his campaign in February, emphasizing a message of unity and love. However, he struggled to raise the necessary funds to support his bid, and his campaign was unable to meet the polling requirements needed to participate in the December debate.

In an email to supporters, Booker acknowledged that his campaign had reached a point where it needed more money to scale up and continue building a campaign that could win. He stated that his failure to make the debates prevented him from raising the necessary funds and that the looming impeachment trial of President Donald Trump would further hinder his campaign.

Booker's departure leaves a field of 12 remaining Democratic presidential candidates, with only one African American candidate, former Massachusetts Governor Deval Patrick, remaining. His exit marks a significant blow to the once-diverse field, which had been the most diverse in history.

Booker's campaign had focused on building a strong and seasoned campaign operation in Iowa and South Carolina, but this early focus may have hampered his campaign in the long run. He struggled to land on a message that would resonate with voters, and his campaign rarely drew a contrast with his opponents on the trail.

Booker's exit from the presidential race further narrows the field, which now stands at 12 candidates.

Title: Rolling Thunder Ride for Freedom Sees Numbers Wane as Vietnam Veterans Age

The annual Rolling Thunder Ride for Freedom, the largest single-day motorcycle rally in the United States, took place on Memorial Day weekend, with over 1 million riders and spectators attending the event. The ride, which began in 1988, was started by Vietnam veterans to demand the U.S. government account for all prisoners of war and soldiers still missing in action from the Vietnam and Korean wars. The event has grown steadily over the years, but organizers are concerned about the dwindling numbers of Vietnam veterans participating.

According to Artie Muller, executive director of Rolling Thunder Inc., the nonprofit foundation that sponsors the ride, the organization is facing a challenge in the coming years.
