"It's going to be interesting to see what we can really bring to the organization in the next five to 10 years," Muller said. "Twenty years ago, we used to look at WWII vets like they were ancient history. Now we are going to be ancient history."

The ride has traditionally been dominated by Harley-Davidson motorcycles, with almost all Rolling Thunder bikers swearing by the iconic American brand. However, younger riders and those who ride for Iraq and Afghanistan Veterans of America (IAVA) have increasingly been choosing Victory motorcycles. Victory motorcycles were introduced in the market in 1998 and were designed to compete directly with Harley-Davidson, with its signature V-twin engines and large size.

IAVA has pursued a partnership with Victory, and on Veterans Day last year, Victory donated $500 of each bike sold in November and December to the Iraq-Afghanistan veterans group. This year, IAVA riders on Victory bikes rode alongside Rolling Thunder for the Memorial Day weekend event. IAVA's director sees the group as the next generation of riders.

Matt Colvin, deputy director of strategic corporate and foundation partnerships at IAVA, believes that the two groups will continue to work together, with the younger veterans eventually taking over. "I have to imagine it would simply be a passing of the torch," Colvin said. "Numbers are dwindling, but I don't think the sentiment will."

While Harley-Davidson still dominates the road at the Ride for Freedom, Victory's motorcycles and IAVA's veterans add a younger element to the event. Colvin described a camaraderie between Vietnam veterans and younger veterans who may not have been welcomed home from controversial wars in the Middle East with open arms. This sentiment has brought the two groups together.

Ultimately, both Rolling Thunder and IAVA hope to integrate and work together, with Rolling Thunder's Muller saying, "It's all a challenge. We hope in the future things are going to get better for Iraq and Afghanistan veterans too and for them to join us. We support the heck out of those men and women."

Title: Election Security Concerns Persist Amidst Efforts to Protect 2020 Vote

The recent national elections in the United States have brought attention to the ongoing concerns surrounding election security. The use of electronic voting machines has been a topic of debate, with some experts calling for a return to traditional paper ballots. The new machines, which provide a paper backup, are seen as a step in the right direction, but some security experts warn that they can still be compromised by hackers.

The push to replace older, paperless machines has led to the purchase of over 130,000 new machines across the country. However, it is estimated that 16 million voters will still use paperless machines in the 2020 election. Some security experts worry that these machines, which do not create a paper backup, can be compromised and leave no record of the tampering.

The new machines, which provide a paper backup, are not immune to hacking either. While they are not connected to the internet, a hacker can still compromise them in person. Some locations have already reported major glitches with the new machines.

The debate over election security has led to a call for an end to electronic voting altogether and a return to traditional paper ballots. However, some experts warn that this could bring back old issues, such as voter error, confusing ballots, slow counts, and suppressed turnout.

There is bipartisan consensus in Congress that more needs to be done to secure the country's voting machines. A bill providing extra funding for election systems has passed both houses, and more money could be apportioned before the 2020 election. However, legislation passed by House Democrats that would require all voting systems to have a paper record has stalled in the Republican-led Senate.

The use of smartphones to vote is also a new development, which raises security concerns. Hackers are ahead of efforts to stop them, and automated processes make it easy to hack the machines used for tallying votes.

Experts on both sides of the aisle have weighed in on the issue. John Brandon, a cybersecurity expert, warns that hackers are working harder and faster than those trying to fend off attacks. Jim Geraghty, a conservative commentator, argues that hackers cannot alter votes, and a recount would reveal any discrepancies.

The erosion of public confidence in the election process is a concern, as it could have devastating effects on Americans' faith in democracy and the legitimacy of elected government.

Title: Caroline Kennedy Nominated as U.S. Ambassador to Japan

Caroline Kennedy, the daughter of former President John F. Kennedy and a prominent Democratic supporter, has been nominated by President Barack Obama to serve as the next U.S. ambassador to Japan. If confirmed by the U.S. Senate, she would become the first woman to hold the position.

Kennedy, a top supporter of Obama's, previously served as the co-chair of his vice presidential search committee in 2008. She has been vetted for the role since April, according to CNN. As the only surviving member of JFK's immediate family, Kennedy has largely avoided the public eye and scrutiny associated with her famous last name.

Kennedy has a background in non-profit work, having served in various roles at organizations such as the John F. Kennedy Library and the American Ballet Theatre. She has also made speeches at the 2008 and 2012 Democratic National Conventions, where she recalled her famous relatives.

The current U.S. ambassador to Japan is John Roos, who has served since 2009. During his tenure, he has led the embassy through significant events, including the 2011 earthquake and tsunami, and the subsequent nuclear aftermath. The U.S. and Japan have a significant relationship, with the U.S. being Japan's largest economic partner and military ally.

However, there are ongoing tensions between the two nations, particularly regarding the U.S. military presence on Japan's Okinawa Island. Some residents have complained about noise from the base, while others have expressed outrage over misconduct by U.S. troops, including the 1995 rape of a 12-year-old Japanese girl by three U.S. military personnel. The opposition to the U.S. military presence has been so strong that it contributed to the resignation of former Prime Minister Yukio Hatoyama in 2010.

Title: President Trump Welcomes Irish Prime Minister Amidst Coronavirus Concerns

Article:

President Donald Trump welcomed Irish Prime Minister Leo Varadkar to the White House on Thursday to celebrate ties between the U.S. and Ireland, amidst concerns over the global spread of the coronavirus. The visit comes after Trump announced travel restrictions on Europe on Wednesday night, which do not apply to Ireland or the United Kingdom.

During a press conference in the Oval Office, Trump addressed criticism that he did not consult European leaders before imposing the travel restrictions. He explained that it takes a long time to make individual calls to world leaders and claimed that Europe does not alert the U.S. when it raises taxes on the U.S. Trump insisted that his announcement was "clear," although his own White House had to clarify the announcement.

The president also discussed the possibility of imposing travel restrictions within the United States, stating that his team has not discussed it, but did not rule it out. The National Guard has been deployed to establish a containment zone in a New York suburb, the country's first.

Trump expressed confidence that the virus will "go away" and mentioned that he has been reading up on the Stafford Act, a federal law outlining the means of deploying federal natural disaster assistance to state and local governments.

The meeting with the Irish prime minister is one of the few events that is proceeding as the U.S. grapples with the spread of the coronavirus. There are over 1,300 confirmed cases in the country, according to Johns Hopkins University, and 43 confirmed cases in Ireland.

Varadkar is set to attend the annual "Friends of Ireland" luncheon hosted by House Speaker Nancy Pelosi on Capitol Hill, although Trump will not be attending, citing the impeachment inquiry launched by House Democrats last year.

Title: Obama's Fourth Defense Secretary: A Test of Credibility and Relationship Building

The upcoming introduction of Ash Carter as the fourth defense secretary under President Barack Obama's administration has raised concerns about the White House's relationship with the military and the president's credibility on national security. Carter, a well-respected policy expert and former deputy defense secretary, is expected to carry out the strategy set by the White House and National Security Council, rather than challenge it.

The White House has taken a more controlling role in defense policy-making during Obama's tenure, with previous defense secretaries Bob Gates and Leon Panetta criticizing the administration's interference. The departure of Chuck Hagel, who struggled to navigate the White House's currents, has left a void in the Pentagon's leadership.

Carter's strengths lie in his familiarity with the Pentagon and his ability to navigate its inner workings. However, his lack of leverage over the White House and his need to build a strong team at the Pentagon will be crucial to his success.

Many former officials are waiting to see how Carter adjusts to his new role and whether he can develop the political skills to handle the White House effectively. Building a strong team and establishing a clear chain of command will be essential to Carter's success.

While some experts believe Carter may not have the same level of influence as his predecessors, he is not expected to be a pushover. The president is looking for someone to work as a key member of the national security team and speak truth to power.

Ultimately, Carter's success will depend on his ability to balance his own expertise with the president's authority and build a strong relationship with the military. As the commander-in-chief, the president has the final say in national security decisions, and Carter must navigate this dynamic to be effective in his role.

**Title:** Obama's Deportation Amnesty for Dreamers Approved 93% of Applications, Raising Questions About Discretion

**Article:**

The Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) program, introduced by President Obama in 2012, has approved 93% of all applications decided through December, according to the latest statistics. This high approval rate has become a key point of contention in the legal challenge to a broader amnesty program, Deferred Action for Parental Accountability (DAPA), which is set to be heard by the Supreme Court next month.

The DACA program was considered a test run for the broader amnesty, which would grant temporary relief from deportation and work authorization to certain illegal immigrants. However, opponents argue that the high approval rate undercuts the administration's argument that it is not rewriting the law but only offering guidance on how to prioritize enforcement.

Mark Krikorian, executive director of the Center for Immigration Studies, said, "It tells me that they're rubber-stamping DACA applications. Any program that four years after its initiation is still approving 93% of applicants is a program that doesn't have very high standards."

The administration began accepting DACA applications in August 2012, and by the end of last year, nearly 715,000 people had been approved, with fewer than 55,000 rejected. The approval rate is similar to that of a farmworker amnesty in the 1986 amnesty, which had a 94% success rate. However, no widespread fraud charges have been leveled against DACA.

Advocates for Dreamers argue that the high approval rate is due to the immigrants themselves doing a good job of ensuring they meet the eligibility criteria before applying, resulting in fewer borderline cases to be judged. The nearly $500 application fee also makes immigrants think carefully before applying, said Tom Jawetz, vice president of immigration policy at the Center for American Progress.

The 93% initial approval rate is lower than the initial 99.5% rate at the beginning of the program, which has since fallen as trickier applications took longer to decide and more were denied. The renewal rate for those who initially received DACA status is 99.3%, according to the latest Homeland Security statistics.

The high approval rate has been used by lower-court judges to inform their rulings on the broader DAPA program, which has been halted by judges while the case winds through courts. The Supreme Court is set to hear oral arguments on April 18 and could issue a ruling by the end of June.

Title: Oregon Court Orders Sweet Cakes by Melissa Owners to Pay $135,000 in Damages to Lesbian Couple

The Oregon Bureau of Labor and Industries has issued a final order affirming an earlier ruling that requires Sweet Cakes by Melissa owners Aaron and Melissa Klein to pay $135,000 in damages to Rachel Cryer and Laurel Bowman, a lesbian couple, for violating Oregon's civil rights law. The initial ruling, made in January, found that the Kleins had refused to bake a wedding cake for the couple's same-sex ceremony in 2013.

According to the Oregon labor commissioner, Brad Avakian, the case is not about a wedding cake or a marriage, but about a business refusing to serve someone due to their sexual orientation, which is illegal under Oregon law. The commissioner rejected the Kleins' argument that participating in the wedding by baking the cake would have violated their religious beliefs.

The Kleins' attorney, Anna Harmon, called the final order a "shocking result" and stated that it shows the state's relentless campaign to punish Oregonians who live and work according to their faith. The Kleins, who have since closed their shop and now sell baked goods from their home, have indicated that they may appeal the order to the Oregon Court of Appeals.

In a Facebook post, the Kleins stated that they "will NOT give up this fight" and expressed their stance on freedom of religion and speech. They claimed that the state of Oregon has taken away their freedom of religion and speech, and they will not conform to the world's standards.

The Sweet Cakes case is one of at least six cases involving complaints by same-sex couples against Christian small business owners who declined to provide products for gay weddings.

Title: Sanders' Campaign Shifts Focus to California Primary, Eyes Maximum Political Power

The Bernie Sanders campaign has shifted its strategy, focusing on capturing a majority of the 475 pledged delegates at stake in the California primary and arriving at the Philadelphia convention with maximum political power. This change in approach comes after months of frustration with the national Democratic Party, which Sanders' campaign believes has favored Hillary Clinton.

According to Sanders' senior adviser Tad Devine, the campaign does not think its attacks on Clinton will help Trump in the long run, but is willing to take a short-term risk to achieve its goals. The senator's team is "not thinking about" the possibility of derailing Clinton's bid to become the first woman elected president.

The Sanders campaign is putting its focus on the upcoming states, with the final primary in the District of Columbia on June 14. If successful, this strategy could put the senator in a strong position to make a strong closing argument before the convention.

Party leaders are concerned about the prospect of a drawn-out Democratic fight, which could divert attention from attacking Trump and hinder the party's chances of winning the general election. Sanders has won nearly 10 million votes, compared to Clinton's 13 million, and Democratic leaders believe she needs time to court young voters, liberals, and other Sanders supporters who view her as an ally of corporate and big-money interests.

Title: Millennials' Political Affiliations Up for Grabs as Obama Era Ends

The 2016 presidential election is approaching, and a peculiar phenomenon has emerged: social media is unusually quiet when it comes to potential candidates. The millennial generation, known for their eagerness to share their opinions, seems to be lacking a clear direction. As President Barack Obama prepares to leave office, it has become evident that the political alliances of millennials are up for grabs.

For the past seven years, millennials have been passionate about marriage equality, which coincided with the Democratic Party's platform. However, with gay marriage now legal in every state, many millennials are no longer tied to the Democratic Party. Aside from marriage equality, millennials' views are diverse and all over the board.

A recent Reason Foundation poll found that millennials desire small government, as long as budget cuts don't directly impact them. They also have mixed opinions on political parties, with Congress receiving higher approval ratings than any other generation. Millennials overwhelmingly supported Obama's promise of universal healthcare, yet greatly oppose Obamacare. They want the government to address their problems, but don't want Washington to be in charge.

The lack of a clear direction among millennials has left political leaders confused, resulting in a lack of engagement from both parties. Neither party has found a candidate they believe they can successfully sell to millennials. To win their support, one party must start a conversation.

Millennials want to be part of something, whether it's gay marriage or the World Cup. Surprisingly, the Republican Party has what millennials want to rally behind – limited government. While the past eight years saw a push to tax the wealthy and "redistribute the wealth," millennials feel otherwise. They are willing to rally around a movement to raise money to help those in need, but they don't want to be told how and where to do so.

Millennials desire freedom to pursue their passions, start their own companies, or simply enjoy life without Washington telling them what to do. They like their wealth and want to do with it as they desire. They don't want the government telling them how to spend their money, who they can marry, or how they can use their bodies. They want freedom.

If the Republican Party can successfully create a conversation centered around limited government, the 2016 political landscape may become more red than anticipated.

Title: Clinton's Challenges: A Mixed Bag of Reviews from Pundits

The Democratic primary race has essentially come to a close, with Hillary Clinton emerging as the front-runner. However, despite her expected victory, Clinton is receiving mixed reviews from pundits, with some expressing concerns about her ability to withstand a potential Trump onslaught. The New York Times reports that President Obama is urging donors to get on the "Hillary train," but the commentary class is looking ahead to the fall with a more critical eye.

Some commentators, like Joe Klein, are questioning Clinton's ability to withstand Trump's attacks. Klein, who has known the Clintons for a quarter century, believes Clinton is "our very own quinoa and kale salad, nutritious but bland." He argues that she is not a natural politician and lacks the charisma of other candidates like Trump and Sanders. Klein also criticizes Clinton's speaking style, saying she is too focused on being a politician and lacks authenticity.

Other pundits, like Jeff Greenfield, are concerned about Clinton's low polling marks on honesty, which stem from the email scandal and decades of accumulated accusations. Greenfield believes Clinton's public life defines her as a creature of the establishment, which may not resonate with voters. He also notes that Clinton often recalibrates her positions to be more popular, which may not be seen as authentic.

Despite these concerns, Clinton still enjoys broad support within the Democratic party and most Bernie backers are expected to shift their allegiance to her. However, Trump's supporters may be more divided, with some Republicans already revolting against the likelihood of his nomination.

Title: US Secretary of State Meets with Russian Counterpart Amid Tensions Over Syria

Article:

US Secretary of State Rex Tillerson met with Russian Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov in Moscow on Tuesday, amidst growing tensions between the two nations over the Syrian conflict. The meeting comes as the US and Russia have been at odds over the Syrian government's alleged role in a recent chemical attack that killed 86 civilians, including dozens of children.

The US has accused the Syrian government of carrying out the attack, while Russia has blamed it on anti-government rebels. Russian President Vladimir Putin has signaled that he may meet with Tillerson during the secretary of state's trip, a reversal from his earlier position.

Meanwhile, White House Press Secretary Sean Spicer has faced criticism for his comments comparing Syrian President Bashar al-Assad to Adolf Hitler, and falsely claiming that Hitler never used chemical weapons. Spicer made the comments while trying to drum up support for more US military action against the Syrian regime.

Spicer's comments were widely criticized, with lawmakers and Jewish organizations calling for his resignation. The Anne Frank Center, a Jewish organization, condemned Spicer's comments, stating that the Nazis systematically used poison gas as part of their genocide of six million Jews and others.

In fact, the Nazis used gas as part of their genocide, experimenting with gas in the late 1930s and deploying gas vans to kill hundreds of thousands of people after invading the Soviet Union. By 1942, the Nazis had set up concentration camps where gas chambers were the main method of killing people, with as many as 6,000 people, mostly Jews, being gassed to death every day at Auschwitz concentration camp alone.

Spicer later apologized for his comments, although he made several mistakes during his apology, including mispronouncing Syrian President Bashar al-Assad's name.

Title: Obamacare's Full Implementation Brings Unexpected Success Predictions

The Affordable Care Act, also known as Obamacare, is set to go into full effect at the beginning of next year, with some predicting a "train wreck" and consumers facing a "terrible shock." However, new evidence from California, the law's most important test case, suggests that the reality may be quite different.

It is essential to note that Obamacare is a reform that primarily affects individuals who do not receive health insurance from their employers or government programs. These individuals, who make up a significant portion of the uninsured population, can only purchase insurance on their own. In some states, like California, insurers reject applicants with pre-existing medical conditions, making it difficult for them to access healthcare. In other states, like New York, insurers are required to offer similar coverage regardless of personal medical history, known as "community rating." Unfortunately, this leads to high premiums, as only those with current health problems sign up, while healthy individuals opt to remain uninsured.

Despite the challenges, the law's implementation in California has shown promising results. The state's insurance market has seen a significant increase in enrollment, with many individuals gaining access to healthcare for the first time. This development has led to a decrease in the number of uninsured individuals and a reduction in healthcare costs.

While there will undoubtedly be challenges and issues with the implementation of Obamacare, the early signs suggest that the law is having a positive impact on the lives of millions of Americans. As the law continues to unfold, it will be essential to monitor its progress and address any issues that arise.

Title: Trump Fires State Department Inspector General Steve Linick, Citing Lack of Confidence

Article:

President Donald Trump fired State Department Inspector General Steve Linick on Friday, citing a lack of confidence in his ability to perform his duties. The move comes amid reports that Linick's office had been critical of the department's management policies and had investigated allegations of mistreatment of career staff by Trump appointees.

According to the Associated Press, Linick's removal will take effect in 30 days, and he will be replaced by Stephen Akard, a former career foreign service officer with ties to Vice President Mike Pence. Akard currently runs the department's Office of Foreign Missions.

Linick had been in the position since 2013 and had overseen reports critical of the State Department's management policies. His office had also investigated allegations of mistreatment of career staff by Trump appointees, which had been criticized by some as being insufficiently supportive of Trump and his policies.

The move has been met with criticism from Democrats in Congress, who have accused Trump of firing Linick in retaliation for opening an investigation into Secretary of State Mike Pompeo. House Speaker Nancy Pelosi called the firing "an outrageous act of a president trying to protect one of his most loyal supporters from accountability."

The firing is the latest in a series of changes among the government's inspectors general, following the removal of Michael Atkinson, the inspector general for the intelligence community, and Glenn Fine, the acting inspector general at the Defense Department.

Title: California Attorney General Threatens Action Against Officials Over Sanctuary City Laws

California Attorney General Xavier Becerra has expressed his intention to take action against officials who are not complying with the state's sanctuary city laws. Becerra stated that it is his duty to enforce state law and ensure that all jurisdictions, including Orange County, understand what is required of them.

The controversy surrounds Orange County Sheriff Sandra Hutchins' decision to release information about inmates' release dates through an online database called "Who's in Jail." The Sheriff's Department claims that this move will enhance communication between law enforcement agencies and help remove dangerous offenders from the community. However, Becerra views this as a violation of state laws and has threatened to take action against Hutchins.

The Sheriff's Department has defended its decision, stating that it is within the confines of the law and aimed at addressing public safety concerns. Hutchins emphasized that the focus is on removing violent criminals from the community, not immigration issues.

In response to the controversy, the Orange County Board of Supervisors voted 3-0 to join the Department of Justice's lawsuit against California's recent immigration laws. Supervisor Shawn Nelson stated that the legislation prevents law enforcement from removing criminals from the community and poses a threat to public safety.

Title: FBI Obtains Secret Court Order to Monitor Communications of Trump Adviser Carter Page

The FBI obtained a Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act (FISA) warrant last summer to monitor the communications of Carter Page, an adviser to Donald Trump's presidential campaign. The warrant was granted after the FBI convinced a Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court judge that there was probable cause to believe Page was acting as an agent of a foreign power, specifically Russia. This development is the clearest evidence so far that the FBI had reason to believe a Trump campaign adviser was in contact with Russian agents during the 2016 presidential campaign.

The FBI and the Justice Department obtained the warrant as part of an investigation into possible links between Russia and the Trump campaign. The investigation, which began in July, is focused on whether the campaign coordinated with the Russian government to influence the election. Page has denied any wrongdoing and claims he was under politically motivated surveillance.

The FISA warrant allows the FBI to monitor Page's communications, but it does not mean he was involved in any wrongdoing. The FBI and the Justice Department declined to comment on the matter. The investigation is ongoing, and it is unclear whether the Justice Department will seek charges against Page or others in connection with Russia's meddling in the 2016 election.

The development comes as the Trump administration has accused the Obama administration of wiretapping Trump Tower, a claim that has been denied. The controversy surrounding the unmasking of Trump campaign officials has also been a point of contention, with some accusing the Obama administration of political espionage. The House Intelligence Committee has been investigating the matter, and both Republican and Democratic members have looked at the documents related to the unmasking, concluding that there is no evidence of wrongdoing.

The investigation is ongoing, and it is unclear what evidence, if any, was collected during the surveillance. The FBI typically minimizes the privacy of individuals caught through incidental collection, but in this case, the Obama administration tweaked the protocols to allow for unmasking. The Trump administration has known about the unmasking, which has led to accusations of political espionage.

Title: US Embassy Compound in Libya's Capital Secured by Islamic Militia

The Dawn of Libya, an umbrella group for Islamist militias, has reportedly secured the US Embassy compound in Tripoli, Libya's capital city. The compound was evacuated by American personnel approximately a month ago due to ongoing fighting in the country. An Associated Press journalist was granted access to the compound on Sunday, finding broken windows but most equipment remained untouched.

The breach of the deserted US diplomatic post is likely to reignite debate in the US over its role in Libya, more than three years after supporting rebels who toppled dictator Moammar Gadhafi. A commander for the Dawn of Libya group stated that his forces had entered and been in control of the compound since last week.

A senior State Department official confirmed the situation, stating that while the Embassy compound itself remains secure, the situation on the ground remains fluid. The official emphasized that the US continues to work with the Government of Libya and other parties on issues of concern, with the Ambassador and other officials remaining engaged in Washington and from the Embassy in Valetta, Malta, where Embassy staff from Tripoli were recently relocated.

No US military or assets were guarding the property after the State Department pulled out. The incident is reminiscent of the 2012 terror attack on a US outpost in Benghazi, Libya, which resulted in the deaths of US Ambassador Christopher Stevens, former Navy SEALs Tyrone Woods and Glen Doherty, and State Department information management officer Sean Smith.

A video posted online showed men playing in a pool at the compound, with US Ambassador to Libya Deborah Jones stating that the video appeared to have been shot in the embassy's residential annex. However, sources with first-hand knowledge of the embassy and other US facilities in Libya disputed this, saying the video was actually taken at the CIA annex in Tripoli, which was abandoned when US Embassy personnel and the ambassador pulled out on July 26. The CIA annex is about a mile away from the US Embassy in Libya.

Ambassador Jones also clarified that the compound appears to be "safeguarded," not "ransacked." The fighting prompted diplomats and thousands of Tripoli residents to flee, with dozens killed in the fighting. The US Embassy operations were suspended until the security situation improved, with diplomats evacuating to neighboring Tunisia under a US military escort on July 26.

Title: High School Student Speaks Out After Viral Video Confrontation with Native American Activist

A Kentucky high school student, Nick Sandmann, has spoken out for the first time about the viral video that showed him standing face-to-face with Native American activist Nathan Phillips at a Washington rally. Sandmann, a junior at Covington Catholic High School, claimed that he and his classmates were taunted by a group of African-American protesters and received death threats.

According to Sandmann, the students were initially accused of mocking a Native American participant in the Indigenous Peoples March, which coincided with the March for Life. However, the emergence of longer video footage appears to show some students being harassed by a group of African-American protesters, prompting some conservatives to take back their earlier criticisms of the students.

Sandmann stated that he and his classmates had taken part in the March for Life and had arrived at the Lincoln Memorial to meet the buses that would take them back to Kentucky. However, they were confronted by four members of the Black Hebrew Israelite movement, who allegedly called them "racists," "bigots," "white crackers," and "incest kids." The group also taunted an African-American student from Sandmann's school by telling him that they would "harvest his organs."

Sandmann said that one of the students asked a teacher chaperoning the trip for permission to "begin our school spirit chants" to drown out the hecklers. In one chant, the group appeared to perform the haka, a traditional Maori dance. Marcus Frejo, a member of the Pawnee and Seminole tribes who witnessed the chant, said he considered it mockery.

Sandmann denied taunting Phillips by making faces at him, but said he smiled at the protester "because I wanted him to know I was not going to become angry, intimidated or be provoked into a larger confrontation." He also denied chanting or acting in a racist fashion towards African Americans or Native Americans.

For his part, Phillips told The Associated Press that he was trying to keep the peace between the students and members of the group who were heckling them. He also insisted that the students were making disparaging remarks about Native Americans.

The incident has sparked a heated debate, with some condemning the students and others defending them. Sandmann's family has received death threats and professional threats, and he has asked for people to stop spreading misinformation and to respect his family's name.

Title: American Health Care Act Fails to Pass, Leaving Republicans to Reflect on Policy and Political Failures

The American Health Care Act (AHCA) has failed to pass, marking a significant defeat for the Republican Party and President Donald Trump. The bill, which aimed to repeal and replace the Affordable Care Act (Obamacare), was widely criticized for its potential to leave millions of Americans without insurance and increase deductibles for millions more. Despite promises to improve healthcare coverage, the bill ultimately failed to achieve its goals.

The AHCA's demise was met with disappointment and frustration from both sides of the political aisle. Conservative groups, such as Heritage Action, opposed the bill, citing its negative impact on millions of Americans. Even some Republicans, like Rep. Mo Brooks, expressed concerns about the bill's policy and process.

The failure of the AHCA has raised questions about the ability of the Republican Party to govern and make difficult policy decisions. The party's inability to pass a healthcare bill, despite having control of both the House and Senate, has left many wondering if they are equipped to tackle other pressing issues.

President Trump has blamed the failure on Democrats, stating that they refused to support the bill. However, it is clear that the Republican Party did not make a concerted effort to engage with Democrats or seek their input. Instead, they used the reconciliation process, which allowed them to bypass Democratic votes.

The failure of the AHCA has also highlighted the challenges of working with Congress, particularly for President Trump. His limited attention span and tendency to blame others for failures may make it difficult for him to achieve his policy goals.

The Republican Party will need to reflect on its failures and consider how to improve its approach to governance. As Jonathan Chait notes, the party has built a "news bubble" that has led to exaggerated or made-up news about Obamacare's shortcomings, making it difficult to achieve meaningful policy changes.

Ultimately, the failure of the AHCA serves as a reminder that big policy changes are difficult and require patience, compromise, and hard work. The Republican Party will need to learn from its mistakes and develop a more effective approach to governance if it hopes to achieve its policy goals.

Title: 39 People Found Dead in Truck Container in England, Driver Arrested on Suspicion of Murder

A tragic incident occurred in England on October 23, 2019, when 39 people were found dead in a truck container on an industrial estate in Thurrock, south England. The truck, believed to have originated from Bulgaria, was discovered by police, who arrested the driver, a 25-year-old man from Northern Ireland, on suspicion of murder.

The victims' identities and nationalities are still unknown, but police are working to reconstruct their final journey and determine how they ended up in England. The truck and trailer took separate routes before arriving at the Waterglade Industrial Park in Grays, 25 miles east of London.

The truck was registered in Bulgaria to a company owned by an Irish citizen, and its point of origin is unclear. The Belgian federal prosecutor's office has opened an investigation into the incident.

The discovery of the bodies has sparked outrage and sadness, with Jackie Doyle-Price, a member of Parliament, describing the incident as "evil" and calling for the perpetrators to be brought to justice. Prime Minister Boris Johnson vowed that human traffickers would be prosecuted to the fullest extent of the law.

The incident is a reminder of the dangers and risks faced by migrants attempting to reach the UK, often through dangerous and illegal means. It is also a stark reminder of the human cost of human trafficking and the need for authorities to take action against those responsible.

The National Crime Agency is working to identify and take action against any organized crime groups involved in the incident, which is the latest in a series of tragic discoveries of migrants found dead in trucks in the UK.

Title: Gun Control Efforts Falter as Deadly Attack in Jersey City Highlights Challenges

Article:

A recent shooting in Jersey City, New Jersey, has highlighted the challenges in controlling the flow of guns into the state, despite efforts by officials to tighten gun laws. On December 10, 2019, a gunfight left multiple dead, including a police officer, and a community in mourning. The two attackers, David Anderson and Francine Graham, were armed with a variety of weapons, including an AR-15-style rifle and a shotgun, and were found to have obtained some of the weapons from Ohio.

New Jersey is one of the states with the toughest gun restrictions in the country, with Governor Phil Murphy having signed over a half-dozen new restrictions into law in the past two years. However, despite these efforts, the state still struggles to prevent guns from entering the state from neighboring jurisdictions with weaker laws.

The attack has sparked renewed calls for stricter gun control measures, with officials from states with strong gun restrictions urging stricter laws in places with weaker laws to thwart traffickers. California's Democratic Governor Gavin Newsom and Attorney General Xavier Becerra have criticized the continued ability to bring in illegal firearms from other states despite California's strict gun laws.

However, Second Amendment advocates argue that criminals do not follow laws and that stricter regulations are not the solution. Scott Bach, executive director of the New Jersey Association of Rifle and Pistol Clubs, an affiliate of the NRA, stated that "criminals laugh at gun regulations – the only thing they understand is severe punishment for actual gun crime."

The investigation into the Jersey City attack is ongoing, and officials have yet to release details about how the deceased attackers obtained their weapons. The incident highlights the ongoing challenges in controlling the flow of guns into the state and the need for a federal solution to address the issue.

Title: US Warship Successfully Intercepts Medium-Range Ballistic Missile in Test Off Hawaii

The US Missile Defense Agency (MDA) announced that a US warship successfully intercepted a medium-range ballistic missile in a test off the coast of Hawaii on Wednesday. The USS John Paul Jones detected and tracked the missile launched from the Pacific Missile Range Facility on Kauai using its onboard radar, before intercepting it with SM-6 missiles. This marked the second time an SM-6 missile has successfully intercepted a medium-range ballistic missile in a test.

MDA Director Lt. Gen. Sam Greaves described the test as a "key milestone" and emphasized the agency's commitment to developing ballistic missile defense technologies to stay ahead of the evolving threat. The test comes as North Korean leader Kim Jong Un vowed to continue conducting missile tests in the Pacific.

On Tuesday, North Korea launched an intermediate-range ballistic missile over Japan, which flew over the northern Japanese island of Hokkaido. The official Korean Central News Agency reported that the Hwasong-12 missile was "guided" by Kim Jong Un and observed by senior officials. The launch was seen as a response to ongoing military drills by the US and South Korea, which North Korea views as a preparation for war.

The UN Security Council strongly condemned the missile test and demanded that North Korea immediately cease all such actions. The council did not announce new sanctions, but instead called for the international community to work together to address the crisis.

The test also sparked reactions from other world leaders, with Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi stating that China will "fully and completely" abide by UN Security Council sanctions and work with other council members on how to respond to North Korea's latest action. British Prime Minister Theresa May called on China to put more pressure on North Korea to stop its missile tests.

The US Defense Secretary Jim Mattis will meet with South Korea's Defense Minister Song Young-moo at the Pentagon to discuss possible responses to North Korea's provocative actions. The meeting comes as tensions between the US and North Korea continue to escalate.

Title: Explosion in Afghanistan's Khost Province Kills Three, Wounds 11

A motorcycle rigged with a bomb exploded during a football match in Afghanistan's eastern Khost province, killing at least three people and wounding 11 others, according to local authorities. The blast occurred on Monday afternoon near a football pitch in Nadir Shah Kot district, said Sayed Ahmad Babazai, a police chief in the area.

The incident comes amid a recent escalation in violence in the region, following the Taliban's announcement that it was resuming offensive operations against Afghan security forces. The Taliban had previously agreed to a "reduction in violence" agreement, which preceded the signing of a deal between the armed group and the United States.

Under the deal, foreign forces are set to withdraw from Afghanistan within 14 months, subject to Taliban security guarantees and a pledge by the group to hold talks with the Kabul government. The agreement also sets March 10 as the date for an intra-Afghan dialogue and a prisoner-swap, which would see the government release 5,000 Taliban prisoners and the Taliban release 1,000 captives.

However, Afghan President Ashraf Ghani has clarified that the government has made no commitment to free 5,000 Taliban prisoners. In response, the Taliban has said it will not participate in intra-Afghan talks until the prisoners are released. "We are fully ready for the intra-Afghan talks, but we are waiting for the release of our 5,000 prisoners," Taliban spokesman Zabihullah Mujahid told Reuters news agency. "If our 5,000 prisoners - 100 or 200 more or less does not get released, there will be no intra-Afghan talks."

Commander of NATO forces in Afghanistan, US General Scott Miller, has emphasized the importance of the Taliban fulfilling its obligations under the agreement. "The reduction in violence was a confidence builder... The United States has been very clear about our expectations - the violence must remain low," Miller said in a tweet.

Title: US Special Forces Criticize Turkey's Invasion of Northeastern Syria, Citing Atrocities and Unintended Consequences

A US special forces member serving with the Kurdish-led Syrian Democratic Forces (SDF) in Syria has spoken out against Turkey's invasion of northeastern Syria, describing the situation as "atrocities" and expressing concerns about the unintended consequences of the US withdrawal. The unnamed soldier, who has been involved in training indigenous forces on multiple continents, told Fox News that Turkey is not adhering to agreements made with the SDF and is causing harm to civilians.

The soldier stated that the US and SDF had met every security agreement, and there was no threat to Turkey from the SDF. However, Turkey launched its military operation against Kurdish groups in northern Syria after the US announced its withdrawal from the area, removing the chief deterrent to Ankara's offensive.

The US withdrawal was met with criticism from some lawmakers, including Senator Lindsey Graham (R-S.C.), who called the decision a "disaster in the making" that would allow ISIS to regroup and "be a stain on America's honor for abandoning the Kurds."

Reports have emerged of civilian casualties since the Turkish military operation began, with the US soldier describing the situation as "insanity" and stating that US troops are "sitting by and watching it unfold." The soldier expressed concerns that the offensive could lead to the unintended release of ISIS prisoners and that many of the detained militants will be free in the coming days and weeks.

In a tweet, President Trump defended the decision to withdraw US troops, stating that the US will not engage in "endless wars" and that the Kurds were paid to fight against Turkey. However, the US special forces member disagreed, saying that Trump "doesn't understand the problem" and that the US is "sitting by and watching it unfold."

Title: Senator Rand Paul Celebrates Festivus with Twitter Rant

Article:

Kentucky Republican Senator Rand Paul took to Twitter on December 23 to participate in the quirky holiday tradition of Festivus, popularized by the 1997 episode of the sitcom "Seinfeld." As part of the celebration, Paul aired his grievances on social media, targeting various aspects of Washington politics and daily life in the nation's capital.

Paul's tweets expressed discontent with the Federal Reserve's policies, which he believes make people poorer and disproportionately harm the poor and middle class. He also criticized the recent bipartisan budget deal, calling it a synonym for "increasing our debt." Additionally, he aired his frustration with the Senate cafeteria's lack of burgoo, a type of soup.

Paul's grievances also extended to his staff, whom he asked to leave his favorite turtleneck sweater alone. He also joked about forgetting to move his car for DC street cleaning and not receiving enough retweets from his colleague, Senator Cory Booker.

Dan O'Keefe, a writer for "Seinfeld," responded to Paul's tweets the next day, acknowledging the senator's participation in the holiday tradition.

Title: House Ways and Means Committee Issues Subpoenas for Trump's Tax Returns

The House Ways and Means Committee, led by Chairman Richard Neal, has issued subpoenas to Department of Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin and Internal Revenue Service (IRS) Commissioner Charles Rettig, demanding six years of President Donald Trump's tax returns. This move comes after the Treasury Department rejected Neal's initial request for the documents.

In a statement, Neal expressed his hope that the Treasury Department will comply with the subpoena and provide the requested material within the next week. The committee's request is based on a law allowing a select few members of Congress to review individual tax returns for legislative purposes, citing legislative proposals and oversight related to federal tax laws.

The Treasury Department had previously rejected Neal's request, citing a lack of a legitimate legislative purpose and invoking section 6103 of the tax code. Mnuchin wrote in a letter that the committee's request "lacks a legitimate legislative purpose" and that the Department is therefore not authorized to disclose the requested returns and return information.

The subpoena also demands copies of tax returns for Trump's trust and his golf club in Bedminster, New Jersey. This development is part of a broader effort by Congress to obtain documents and bring administration officials and allies in for questioning. The GOP-led Senate Intelligence Committee has already subpoenaed Donald Trump Jr. to answer more questions, while Democrats on the House Judiciary Committee voted to hold Attorney General William Barr in contempt of Congress over his refusal to hand over an unredacted copy of Special Counsel Robert Mueller's report on the Russian interference in the 2016 election.

Title: Secretary of State Hillary Clinton Takes Responsibility for Security Failures in Libya

Article:

Secretary of State Hillary Clinton has taken responsibility for any security failures that may have contributed to the attack on the US consulate in Libya last month, which resulted in the death of Ambassador Chris Stevens and three other Americans. However, she pushed back against claims of a cover-up, attributing the Obama administration's shifting explanations for the attack to the "fog of war."

Clinton's comments came during an interview with a news outlet during a trip to Peru. She emphasized that the attack was a complex and chaotic situation, with multiple factors at play. "Remember, this was an attack that went on for hours," she said. "There had to be a lot of sorting out... Everyone said, here's what we know, subject to change."

The Obama administration has faced intense scrutiny over the level of security at the consulate, with allegations that requests for increased protection were denied or ignored. Vice President Joe Biden denied receiving any such requests during the vice presidential debate, a claim later clarified by the White House to apply only to Biden and the president, not the State Department.

Clinton backed up Biden's claims, stating that decisions about diplomatic security are made by her department. "I'm responsible for the State Department, for the more than 60,000 people around the world," she said. "The decisions about security are made by security professionals. But we're going to review everything to be sure we're doing what needs to be done in an increasingly risky environment."

Clinton also addressed the question of a June explosion at the consulate in Benghazi, which some have argued should have raised a red flag about security. "I can't speak to who knew what," she said. "We knew there were security breaches and problems throughout Libya. That's something that came about as the aftermath of the revolution to topple Qaddafi, with so many militias formed, so many weapons loose... It was taken into account by security professionals as they made their assessments."

Three Republican senators, John McCain, Lindsey Graham, and Kelly Ayotte, responded to Clinton's comments, saying that while her claim was "a laudable gesture," the responsibility for the Benghazi attack and what they called "an escalating pattern of attacks this year in Benghazi" lay squarely with President Obama and his national security team.

Title: Potential Changes to the Affordable Care Act: What's on the Table?

The Affordable Care Act (ACA), also known as Obamacare, has been a contentious topic in the United States. With the current political climate, it's unclear what changes, if any, will be made to the law. However, some potential modifications have been discussed, including delaying the individual mandate, repealing the medical device tax, and eliminating the Prevention and Public Health Fund.

Delaying the Individual Mandate:
The individual mandate, which requires individuals to purchase health insurance or face a penalty, has been a point of contention. Republicans argue that if large employers can delay their coverage requirements, individuals should be able to do the same. However, the White House has rejected this proposal, citing the importance of maintaining the balance between healthy and sick individuals in the insurance system.

Repealing the Medical Device Tax:
The medical device tax, which is a 2.3% tax on the sales price of medical devices, has been a target for Republicans. While this change would not gut the ACA, it would eliminate $30 billion in revenue needed to fund the law. Democrats worry that other health care sectors would start demanding rollbacks of other financing pieces of the law.

Eliminating the Prevention and Public Health Fund:
The Prevention and Public Health Fund, authored by Senator Tom Harkin (D-Iowa), is part of the ACA. Republicans have called it a "slush fund," but it's not central to the law's operation. Democrats have dipped into the fund in the past, and its repeal might be seen as a minor victory for Republicans.

Other Potential Changes:
Other ideas that may come up during discussions include delaying the entire law or eliminating the subsidies for Congress members and their staffs. However, these proposals have their own challenges and potential consequences.

In conclusion, while some changes to the Affordable Care Act have been discussed, the road to agreement is complex and challenging. The White House and Republicans have different priorities, and any changes would need to balance the needs of various stakeholders.

Title: Authorities Apprehend Suspect in Charleston Church Shooting

Authorities have apprehended Dylann Roof, the 21-year-old suspect allegedly responsible for the shooting that killed nine people at the Emanuel African Methodist Episcopal Church in Charleston, South Carolina, on Wednesday night. Roof was arrested during a traffic stop in Shelby, North Carolina, approximately 250 miles north of Charleston.

According to police, a citizen reported the suspect's car, and officers responded and made the arrest. Roof cooperated with the officer who stopped him. The FBI and Charleston police had earlier identified Roof as the suspect.

The shooting occurred during a bible study group at the historic Emanuel AME Church on Calhoun Street, killing eight people and sending one other person to the hospital, where they later died. The victims included Rev. Clementa Pinckney, the church pastor and a South Carolina state senator, as well as six others: Rev. Sharonda Singleton, retired pastor Dr. Daniel L. Simmons, Ethel Lee Lance, Cynthia Hurd, Myra Thompson, and Tywanza Sanders.

Three people survived the shooting, but details about them are not yet available. The suspect, described as a white male, approximately 5-foot-9, wearing a sweatshirt with distinctive markings and Timberland boots, had been attending the prayer meeting with worshipers for almost an hour before the shooting.

Charleston Police Chief Gregory Mullen described the incident as an "unacceptable" act of violence, and the mayor called the suspect a "horrible scoundrel." The suspect is expected to be charged with murder and will be extradited to face charges.

**Germanwings Flight 9525 Crash: New Details Emerge on Co-Pilot's Actions**

New information has emerged about the crash of Germanwings Flight 9525, which killed all 150 people on board. According to authorities, the co-pilot, Andreas Lubitz, deliberately crashed the plane into the French Alps. The investigation is ongoing, with the FBI assisting in the probe.

Transponder data shows that the autopilot was reprogrammed by someone in the cockpit to change the plane's altitude from 38,000 feet to 100 feet. The cockpit voice recorder captured the horrific sounds of the plane's final minutes, with the captain banging on the door and screaming audible for the last few minutes of the flight.

Police searched Lubitz's apartment in Dusseldorf, Germany, looking for clues about his possible motive. The investigation is still ongoing, with authorities trying to determine why Lubitz took the actions he did.

The French government has asked the FBI to help investigate the crash, and a search is underway for the plane's second "black box," the flight data recorder, which could shed more light on the plane's final minutes.

The investigation has revealed that Lubitz was fully qualified to pilot the aircraft on his own, having completed 630 hours of flight time and having passed medical tests. He had been with Germanwings since September 2013 and had trained at the Lufthansa flight center in Bremen, Germany.

The families of the victims are being provided with financial support by Lufthansa, and the bodies of the crash victims will not be released to family members until all DNA identification work has been done, a process likely to last several weeks.

**Libertarian Party's Gary Johnson Seeks to Capitalize on Disaffected Voters**

The Libertarian Party's national convention is set to take place this weekend, with former New Mexico Governor Gary Johnson heavily favored to win the nomination. Johnson's recent poll numbers have shown him in double digits, a rare feat for a third-party candidate. If he secures the nomination, he will be the only third-party candidate on the ballot in all 50 states.

Johnson's running mate, William Weld, a former Massachusetts Governor, is a fiscal conservative and social liberal, which may appeal to disaffected Republicans and Democrats. Johnson believes his ticket can collect electoral votes and is not ruling out the possibility of winning.

Johnson's optimism is tempered by the party's poor track record in general elections, but he is confident that his message of smaller government, military cuts, and entitlement reforms will resonate with voters. He is also reaching out to disaffected Sanders supporters who are dissatisfied with Hillary Clinton's stance on war and the war on drugs.

The Libertarian Party has already secured ballot access in 32 states and is expected to be on all 50 state ballots by November. Johnson's standing in the polls is consistent with a recent Monmouth University poll that showed him at 11 percent, which is higher than the 3 percent achieved by Ralph Nader in 2000.

While Johnson's poll numbers may not be enough to guarantee victory, his presence in the election could influence the outcome. His running mate, Weld, has already made waves by comparing Trump's deportation policy to Nazi tactics, and Johnson is not holding back on Clinton either.

The Libertarian Party's national convention will take place from May 26 to May 30 in Orlando, Florida, where about 1,000 delegates will gather to nominate their candidate.

Title: Army Private Charged with Attempting to Facilitate Deadly Ambush on Fellow Soldiers

A 22-year-old U.S. Army private, Ethan Phelan Melzer, has been charged with attempting to pass information about his unit's planned deployment to extremist groups, with the intention of inspiring a deadly attack. The charges, filed by a federal grand jury, carry a maximum sentence of life in prison.

According to court documents, Melzer began communicating with followers of the Order of the Nine Angles, a violent, satanic neo-Nazi fringe group, in April. He then began sharing information about his Army unit, stationed in Italy, and its planned redeployment to a U.S. military base in Turkey, in order to inspire a jihadist attack.

Melzer allegedly posted information about the unit's location, weaponry, and vulnerabilities, as well as the number of soldiers stationed at the base, in a restricted messaging application. He also provided the location of a U.S. military installation where his unit was heading, along with the nature of the weaponry it would be armed with.

Federal officials said the Army stopped the plot in late May, and FBI agents arrested Melzer on June 10. Investigators said he confessed to providing the information to facilitate a mass casualty attack on the unit.

The Order of the Nine Angles is based in the U.K. but has gained a following among violent American white supremacists. The group is described by the Southern Poverty Law Center as an "enigmatic Satanic occult group" that promotes human sacrifice, Nazism, and Fascism, and has been linked to praise for Adolf Hitler and Osama bin Laden.

Melzer joined the Army in 2018 and became a follower of the group the following year. He deployed overseas in 2019 and was following propaganda from several extremist groups by then. The Justice Department said Melzer was motivated by racism and hatred as he attempted to carry out this ultimate act of betrayal.

Title: Mitt Romney Returns to Michigan as Likely Republican Presidential Nominee

Mitt Romney, the former governor of Massachusetts, is set to return to his home state of Michigan as the likely Republican presidential nominee. During a recent campaign stop, Romney expressed his confidence in his ability to win the state in November, stating, "If I win in Michigan, then I become the president, and that would mean a lot to me personally."

Romney's connection to Michigan runs deep, as he was born in the state and raised in the suburbs outside Detroit. His father, George Romney, was a successful businessman who ran American Motors Corporation and later served as the governor of Michigan. In 1968, George Romney attempted to win the Republican presidential nomination, a feat his son is set to achieve at the Republican National Convention in August.

Michigan is one of several key states that could make a difference in the November election. While it is not on Romney's campaign's list of top targets, his team sees an opportunity to win the state, which was carried by President Barack Obama in 2008. Romney's campaign believes that winning Rust Belt states like Michigan, along with other states Obama won in 2008, is crucial to his success.

However, Romney faces an uphill battle in Michigan, with a strong Democratic base in Detroit and criticism over his opposition to the federal bailout that saved General Motors and Chrysler. Romney's 2012 campaign has been filled with reminders of his Michigan roots, including his father's photo on the campaign bus and supporters bringing memorabilia from his father's presidential campaign.

Romney has also been criticized for his comments about Vernors, a popular ginger ale in Michigan, and his affection for cars, particularly the Rambler, which was a product of the automotive industry that drove Michigan's culture and economy. However, his opposition to federal support for General Motors and Chrysler has been a point of contention, and he has struggled to clarify his position.

Despite these challenges, Romney's campaign is planning to soften his tone on the issue, with his deputy campaign manager, Katie Packer Gage, stating that Romney will acknowledge that he and President Obama shared the same goal of seeing the auto industry survive and thrive, but had different approaches to achieving it.

Title: Obama's State of the Union Address: What to Watch for

The first State of the Union address of President Barack Obama's second term is set to take place on Tuesday, and it promises to be a highly anticipated event. As the president outlines his second-term agenda, here are five things to watch for:

The president is expected to highlight bipartisan progress on immigration reform, but he will also take aim at the Republican Party on debt and tax reform. Republicans are already preparing to play the victim card, and the real question is whether the president's jabs will outweigh any olive branches he extends.

The speech will likely be heavy on economic themes, but it remains to be seen how much time Obama will dedicate to other issues he outlined in his inaugural address, such as gay rights, women's rights, climate change, and education. The president's aides say that every word will be debated, making the State of the Union a unique opportunity for him to answer his critics and respond to his base on issues like U.S. use of unmanned drones, the legal rationale for targeting Americans, U.S. policy in Syria, Iran's nuclear program, and the security of U.S. diplomatic posts.

The first lady, Michelle Obama, is also expected to make an appearance, and her outfit may be the biggest surprise of the night. Since her bold fashion choices during the 2009 joint address to Congress, her wardrobe has become a closely guarded secret in Washington.

Overall, the State of the Union address is a chance for the president to lay out his second-term agenda and respond to his critics. With an average of 44 million people watching, it's a huge opportunity for him to seize the moment and make a lasting impression.

Title: Obama Administration's Promise to Keep Health Care Plans Proves Untrue

The Obama Administration's promise to allow Americans to keep their health care plans has been widely debunked, with NBC News reporting that the administration knew this was unlikely to be true from the start. The promise was made during the selling of the Affordable Care Act (ACA), also known as Obamacare, in 2010. Critics at the time expressed skepticism about the feasibility of this promise, and now, Americans are seeing that it was indeed not true.

The Obama Administration's "grandfathering" provision, which was intended to allow most Americans to keep their insurance plans, was changed in regulations written in July 2010. The revised regulations stated that if any part of a policy was significantly changed since March 23, 2010, the policy would not be grandfathered. This change meant that many policies would not meet the new health care law's requirements, resulting in an estimated 40-67% of individual health insurance market customers losing their plans.

The Obama Administration's own estimates, buried in Obamacare regulations, acknowledged that due to normal turnover in the individual insurance market, the percentage of individual market policies losing grandfather status would exceed the 40-67% range. Despite this knowledge, President Obama continued to make the promise to keep health care plans, even as recently as during the 2012 presidential debates with Mitt Romney.

The reason for the cancellation of insurance plans and increased costs is due to the Obama Administration's new minimum guidelines for what insurance must cover. The administration's rhetoric claims that the new insurance is better, but for some individuals, like 60-year-old Jacqueline Proctor from California, the new insurance will cost more than twice as much and require coverage for services they will never use.

Title: Appeals Court Judges Weigh In on Flynn Case, Leaving Uncertainty on Next Steps

The three-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit heard arguments on Friday regarding the case of Michael Flynn, a former national security advisor who pleaded guilty to lying to the FBI. The judges' skepticism towards the Justice Department's motion to dismiss the case was notable, as they seemed to agree that the district court has the power to hold a hearing.

The Justice Department's deputy solicitor general, Jeffrey Wall, argued that the department would be harmed by having to defend itself against the district court's decision, which could lead to the disclosure of internal deliberations and potentially damaging information. Wall stated that the department would have to provide information about its internal discussions, including why no career prosecutor signed the motion to dismiss the charge against Flynn.

The judges' views on the matter remain unclear, with Judge Henderson suggesting that she takes a skeptical view of the Justice Department's brief, calling it "intemperate." Judge Wilkinson took no position on whether a judge can sentence a defendant who has pleaded guilty, even if the executive branch no longer wants to pursue the case. The outcome of the case remains uncertain, with the possibility that Judge Sullivan may reject the Justice Department's motion to dismiss the case or grant it, leaving the next steps unclear.

Title: Senate Republicans Fail to Pass Healthcare Repeal Bill, "Plan B" Dies

Article: Senate Republicans' efforts to pass a healthcare repeal bill, dubbed "Plan B," have come to an end. The bill, which aimed to repeal the Affordable Care Act (ACA) and replace it with a new healthcare system, failed to garner enough support to pass. Republican Senators Susan Collins and Shelley Moore Capito had already expressed their opposition to the bill, and it was clear that it would not pass.

On July 18, 2017, Senator Lisa Murkowski announced that she would vote with Democrats to block the bill, effectively killing it. This marked the third "no" vote, making it impossible for the bill to pass. The failure of "Plan B" is a significant blow to the Republican Party, which had promised to repeal and replace the ACA during the 2016 presidential campaign.

The failure of the bill has sparked a circular firing squad, with conservatives blaming Senators who did not support the bill, while moderates are blaming conservatives for tanking the previous bill. The breadth of the failure is impressive, even by GOP standards.

The president has declared that he will now let Obamacare fail, blaming Democrats for the current state of the healthcare system. However, Republicans control everything, and their failure to pass a healthcare bill will not go unnoticed by voters. The assignment of blame is not going to go the way Trump wants it to.

Despite the failure of "Plan B," Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell is reportedly planning to hold a "motion to proceed" vote on the 2015 repeal bill, forcing every Senator to take a stance on the issue. This move is seen as a way to put pressure on Senators who did not support the bill, but some Republicans may refuse to allow the bill to come to the floor.

The motivations behind McConnell's decision are unclear, but some speculate that he may be trying to use the threat of a vote as leverage to get Senators to return to the negotiating table to revive a compromise bill. Others believe he may be frustrated with his recalcitrant conference and wants to subject his members to tough votes. The move could also be seen as a way to showcase dysfunction and apply pressure to certain members.

In related news, West Virginia Democrat Joe Manchin has started bipartisan healthcare talks with former governors-turned-senators, which could potentially lead to new discussions on healthcare reform. However, it remains to be seen whether these talks will be successful, given the strong opposition from some Democrats.

Title: President Trump Hosts Teleconference with U.S. Troops Abroad to Wish Them a Merry Christmas

Article:

President Trump hosted a teleconference with U.S. troops stationed around the world on Sunday to thank them for their service and wish them a Merry Christmas. The call included troops from Kuwait, Qatar, Guantanamo Bay, and the USS Sampson, representing all five branches of the military.

During the call, President Trump expressed his gratitude to the troops and their families, stating, "Today and every day, we're incredibly thankful for you and for your families. Your families have been tremendous. Always underappreciated, military families, the greatest people on earth." He also wished the troops a "very, very merry Christmas" and expressed his hope for a "great year" and an "incredible year."

The President also acknowledged the sacrifices made by the troops and their families, saying, "As we celebrate this most precious holiday, we're grateful for each of you who spend this Christmas away from our families and defend all of our families, our freedom, and our flag. Every American heart is thankful, and we're asking God to watch over you and to watch over your families."

After his initial remarks, the media was ushered out of the room, and the President had a personal conversation with the individuals on the call.

In related news, Vice President Mike Pence made a surprise visit to Afghanistan last week.

Title: Clinton's Likability and Trustworthiness in Question as Polls Show Negative Sentiment

A recent Quinnipiac poll has raised concerns about Hillary Clinton's likability and trustworthiness among voters in key swing states. The poll found that a majority of voters in Colorado, Iowa, and Virginia have a negative impression of Clinton, with 56% of Colorado voters viewing her unfavorably and 35% having a favorable view. Similar results were seen in Iowa and Virginia, with voters rating her unfavorably by a margin of 56% to 33% in Iowa and 50% to 41% in Virginia.

While Clinton's unfavorable scores are comparable to those of Donald Trump, a polarizing figure, her favorability ratings are lower than those of other candidates, including Scott Walker and Marco Rubio. Jeb Bush, on the other hand, was viewed more unfavorably in Colorado and Iowa.

Clinton's campaign has pushed back against the poll, with Democratic pollster Geoff Garin stating that her standing is better than the poll suggests and that the numbers are inconsistent with other polling. However, other polls have reinforced the notion that Clinton may have a perception problem.

In several swing states, voters do not think Clinton is honest or trustworthy, with Coloradans, Iowans, and Virginians all saying by wide margins that they do not consider her honest or trustworthy. This sentiment extends beyond swing states, as a June nationwide CNN poll found that 57% of voters did not find Clinton trustworthy.

Clinton's campaign has faced criticism over her use of a private email server during her time at State, questions about whether Clinton Foundation donors were seeking political clout, and her evasion of the press. These issues have contributed to a narrative of a candidate who is less than transparent.

Clinton has expressed confidence that voters will see through these narratives and lend her their support. However, some pollsters suggest that changing people's minds may be difficult, and that Clinton's campaign should focus on her strengths, such as her leadership skills.

In fact, even when voters view Clinton unfavorably, they also view her as a strong leader. Focusing on her leadership credentials and skills could be a way to make people feel that Clinton is more trustworthy and authentic.

Democratic strategist Craig Varoga suggests that the Clinton campaign should use her leadership skills as an opportunity to speak bluntly and authentically about the issues that matter to people in the country. He notes that it is a challenging time to run for president, with frustration with politicians at an all-time high.

The poll results highlight the challenges facing Clinton and other mainstream candidates, as voters are increasingly dissatisfied with the status quo and seeking something different.

Title: Conservative Political Action Conference Kicks Off, Highlighting Key Characteristics of Consistent Conservatives

The annual Conservative Political Action Conference (CPAC) has begun, bringing together activists, officeholders, campaign consultants, and potential Republican presidential candidates for a three-day event. The conference provides a platform for discussion and debate on key issues, with a focus on conservative values and policies.

A recent Pew Research report analyzed the ideological consistency of Americans, categorizing individuals into five groups: consistently conservative, mostly conservative, mixed, mostly liberal, and consistently liberal. The report found that 9% of the public is consistently conservative, with 20% of Republicans and Republican leaners falling into this category.

Consistent conservatives tend to be highly engaged in politics, with 50% reporting they had contacted an elected official within the past two years, the highest rate among the five groups. They also rank high in terms of donating money, attending campaign events, and volunteering on a campaign.

In the 2014 midterm elections, consistent conservatives had a significant impact, with 78% reporting they always vote, compared to 49% of the general public. This means that consistent conservatives are likely to make up 17% of the electorate.

The report also highlights some interesting preferences among consistent conservatives. For example, they tend to prefer living in small towns or rural areas, with 41% saying they would choose a rural area if they could live anywhere in the US. In contrast, only 4% would prefer a city.

When it comes to raising children, consistent conservatives prioritize responsibility, faith, and hard work. When asked about the three most important traits to teach children, 61% of consistent conservatives cited "being responsible," 59% identified religious faith as particularly important, and 44% chose hard work.

Finally, consistent conservatives tend to get their news from Fox News, with 47% citing it as their main source for news about government and politics. This is significantly higher than any other news source, and 88% of consistent conservatives trust Fox News, the highest level of trust among any ideological group.

Overall, the CPAC conference provides a platform for discussion and debate on key issues, with a focus on conservative values and policies. The Pew Research report highlights some interesting characteristics of consistent conservatives, including their high level of political engagement, preferences for small towns and rural areas, and priorities for raising children.

Title: Obama Announces Plan to Rate Colleges Based on Educational Value and Cap Student Loan Repayments

Article:

President Barack Obama announced a new plan to address the rising costs of higher education, aiming to make college more affordable for students and promote innovation in the education sector. The plan includes rating colleges based on their educational value and tying taxpayer money to school performance. The president also proposed capping student loan repayments at 10% of future paychecks.

According to Obama, the federal government and colleges have been engaged in a financial arms race, with the government boosting its contributions and schools raising their prices. He emphasized that the government cannot continue to go about business as usual, as it is pricing out the middle class and those working to get into the middle class from a college education.

The plan involves the Education Department compiling and releasing a scorecard of colleges that provide the best values, considering affordability, productivity, and access. The formula will assess tuition costs versus the number of students taking loans or receiving scholarships, graduation rates, and the earnings of graduates. By 2018, federal funding will be tailored to reward schools that accept low-income students and perform well on the scorecard.
