The plan also encourages colleges and universities to explore new avenues of education, such as lower-cost online courses or awarding degrees based on what students have learned, rather than the number of classes taken. However, Congress will need to approve the plan and pass legislation to cap student loan repayments at 10% of postgraduate incomes.

Some lawmakers, such as Rep. John Kline, a Minnesota Republican, agree with the idea of promoting innovation among colleges but question the proposed ranking system, calling it "arbitrary" and potentially stifling innovation. Sen. Chuck Grassley, an Iowa Republican, sees areas where his party can work with the president to control costs but urges the president to call on colleges to limit salaries for executives. Grassley also emphasized the importance of helping the consumer side of the equation, stating that the more students and parents become savvy shoppers, the more colleges would be forced to rein in rising costs to compete for students.

Title: CNN to Host Seven-Hour Climate Change Town Hall, Featuring 10 Democratic Presidential Candidates

Article:

CNN has announced a seven-hour climate change town hall, scheduled for September 4th, featuring 10 Democratic presidential candidates. The event will provide each candidate with 40 minutes to discuss their plans to address climate change. The moderators for the event will be Wolf Blitzer, Erin Burnett, Anderson Cooper, Chris Cuomo, and Don Lemon.

The candidates will be interviewed in the following order: Julián Castro, Andrew Yang, Kamala Harris, Amy Klobuchar, Joe Biden, Bernie Sanders, Elizabeth Warren, Pete Buttigieg, Beto O'Rourke, and Cory Booker. The event will take place in prime-time, with the first candidate, Julián Castro, scheduled to appear at 5 p.m. ET.

According to a previous CNN poll, 96% of Democratic voters want "aggressive" action taken to address climate change. The town hall was announced after the Democratic National Committee voted not to host a debate focused on the issue.

Title: Sen. Tom Coburn Warns of "Worst for the Republic" in 2013

Sen. Tom Coburn, an Oklahoma Republican, has expressed concerns that 2013 may go down in history as one of the worst years for the United States, not only in terms of productivity but also in terms of the erosion of the country's founding principles and government responsibilities. In a recent article published in The Wall Street Journal, Coburn wrote that the rule of law gave way to the rule of rulers, citing the disastrous rollout of President Obama's health care law and his promise that Americans could keep their health care plans, which was later deemed the "Lie of the Year" by PolitiFact.

Coburn also criticized the President's actions, stating that he has conformed to the political culture rather than challenging it. He pointed to instances such as the delay of the employer mandate and the Internal Revenue Service's targeting of political enemies. The Senator also noted the Congress's 6% approval rating and the Senate's decision to change its filibuster rules, allowing for the confirmation of executive appointments with a simple majority.

In his article, Coburn also highlighted his annual Wastebook report, which revealed examples of wasteful government spending, including funding the study of romance novels, providing military benefits to the Fort Hood shooter, and helping the State Department buy Facebook fans. He concluded that the coming year presents an opportunity for Americans to demand a course correction and hold their leaders accountable.

Coburn's comments come as the country approaches the end of 2013, a year marked by political gridlock and controversy. While opinions on the performance of the government and its leaders vary, Coburn's words serve as a reminder of the importance of accountability and the need for effective governance.

**Sri Lanka Bombings: Deadly Easter Sunday Attacks Kill Nearly 300, Wound Hundreds**

A series of nine bombings on Easter Sunday in Sri Lanka killed nearly 300 people and wounded hundreds more, making it the country's deadliest violence since the end of a 26-year civil war in 2009. The attacks targeted churches, luxury hotels, and other sites in and around the capital city of Colombo, with most of the blasts believed to be suicide attacks.

The Sri Lankan government has arrested 13 suspects, but no one has claimed responsibility for the attacks. Defense Minister Ruwan Wijewardena described the blasts as a terrorist attack by religious extremists.

The explosions caused widespread destruction, with ceilings collapsing and windows blown out, killing worshippers and hotel guests. Victims were carried out of blood-spattered pews, and many were injured. The majority of those killed were Sri Lankans, but at least 27 foreigners from various countries were among the dead.

The U.S. has confirmed that "several" American citizens were among the dead, while Britain, China, Japan, and Portugal also reported losses. The Sri Lankan government has imposed a nationwide curfew and blocked most social media to prevent the spread of false information and ease tension.

The attacks have sparked widespread condemnation from around the world, with Pope Francis expressing condolences to the Christian community and all victims of the violence. The Archbishop of Colombo, Cardinal Malcolm Ranjith, called for those responsible to be "mercilessly" punished.

The bombings have also raised concerns about the potential impact on Sri Lanka's tourism industry, which has been a major source of revenue for the country. Locals who work in the industry are shocked and upset by the bloodshed, with many fearing that the attacks will set the country back significantly.

Sri Lanka's Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe has vowed to "vest all necessary powers with the defense forces" to take action against those responsible. The country's Foreign Ministry has confirmed that at least 290 people were killed and at least 500 wounded in the attacks.

Title: Shake Shack Executives Call for Improvements to Paycheck Protection Program

Shake Shack Inc.'s top executives are urging changes to the Paycheck Protection Program (PPP), a program aimed at providing financial relief to businesses affected by the COVID-19 pandemic. The burger chain announced on Monday that it is returning a $10 million loan it received after struggling to navigate the application process.

According to a joint letter posted on LinkedIn by Chief Executive Randy Garutti and Danny Meyer, founder of Shake Shack, the PPP came with no user manual and was extremely confusing. The executives stated that the onus was placed on each business to figure out how, when, or even if to apply for the loan.

The PPP is part of the $2.2 trillion CARES Act and is open to any business with 500 or fewer employees. Shake Shack has an average of about 45 workers per location, with 189 restaurants in the U.S. and nearly 8,000 workers. The company has reported $1.5 million in weekly operating losses due to the pandemic.

The coronavirus pandemic has had a significant impact on the restaurant industry, with 40% of restaurants having closed, some permanently, and eight million workers having been furloughed. The National Restaurant Association has asked Congress for $240 billion in relief, citing estimated losses of $240 billion by the end of the year.

Shake Shack's executives are not alone in their concerns about the PPP. Media reports have noted that larger restaurant chains have managed to secure loans, sparking backlash. The executives suggest that the program needs more funding and "some necessary tweaks," such as assigning a local bank to each applicant to avoid issues that arise if a restaurant doesn't have a pre-existing loan or banking relationship.

The Small Business Administration (SBA) announced that the program ran out of money last Thursday.

Title: The Evolution of John McCain's Political Identity

The article discusses the transformation of John McCain's political stance over the years, from his early days as a rebel against the Republican establishment to his later years as a loyal partisan. In the late 1990s and early 2000s, McCain was seen as a maverick who defied the Republican Party's stance on issues such as taxes and social issues. However, as the political landscape shifted, McCain's views became more aligned with the party's mainstream.

The article suggests that McCain's decision to join the Republican Party and support its candidates, including George W. Bush, was a result of his desire to remain relevant and influential in politics. However, this move ultimately led to his reputation being tarnished, as he became seen as a partisan and partisan.

The article also highlights McCain's presidential campaign in 2008, which was marked by both highs and lows. While he took a stand against bailing out the banks and stuck to his pledge to use public financing for his campaign, he also made some questionable decisions, such as selecting Sarah Palin as his running mate.

In the years following his presidential campaign, McCain's political views became increasingly divisive, leading to frustration among both Democrats and Republicans. Some saw him as a phony and a hack, while others accused him of being actuated by sanctimony and spite. However, the article suggests that a simpler explanation is that McCain, while sometimes expedient or partisan, preserved more independence of mind than is customary in his trade.

Overall, the article provides a nuanced and balanced view of John McCain's political evolution, highlighting both his strengths and weaknesses, and the complexities of his political identity.

Title: Trump and Clinton Win Big in New York Primary, Narrowing Path to Nomination

The 2016 presidential primary season saw a significant shift in momentum on Tuesday night, as Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton won the New York primary in convincing fashion. Trump and Clinton each secured about three-fifths of the vote, widening their leads among pledged delegates. This development has opened a pathway for them to win their nominations outright before the conventions begin in July.

The primary results have put pressure on the challengers, who will face fewer opportunities to narrow the gap in delegates with each passing week. The next-to-last round of multistate primaries will take place next week, with Pennsylvania, Maryland, Connecticut, Rhode Island, and Delaware holding contests. A total of 144 delegates will be available for Republicans and 392 for Democrats.

A sweep for either front-runner next week would make stopping Trump or Clinton not only daunting but mathematically infeasible. Even the chances of a second ballot at either convention would become remote. Trump was declared the winner shortly after polls closed, tallying 60 percent of the statewide vote. Clinton did almost as well, with 58 percent, and outpolled Trump in the raw vote by nearly half a million.

The outcomes may have been discouraging for challengers in both parties. Ted Cruz and Bernie Sanders, winners in Wisconsin and in a handful of caucus states, stumbled badly in the Empire State. Cruz finished a weak third with scarcely 1 vote in 7, earning zero delegates. New York Republicans preferred Ohio governor John Kasich, who got 1 vote in 4 statewide and gained perhaps three or more delegates.

The results have significant implications for the remaining primary contests. Trump, with his delegate lead growing again, can look to another stretch of promising ground next week. Polls give him an edge in all five contests, with 144 delegates at stake. A sweep would greatly enhance his chances of reaching the majority of delegates needed for a first-ballot nomination (1,237).

Clinton, on the other hand, can look to build on her momentum and continue her delegate lead. She has already secured an estimated 135 new delegates to Sanders' 104. The real pain for Sanders' team was the opportunity cost, as they had given it their all in New York, outspending Clinton on TV and hoping visibly for an upset or a narrow loss that could be spun as a moral victory.

The outcome of the New York primary has significant implications for the remaining primary contests and the general election. While neither candidate's race is over yet, weeks and months of pre-convention politicking remain.

Title: Obama's State of the Union Address Focuses on Government Spending and Taxes

The 45th President of the United States, Barack Obama, delivered his annual State of the Union address on Tuesday night, outlining his vision for the country's future. The speech focused on government spending and taxes, with Obama emphasizing the need for increased investment in various areas. He used the term "invest" 11 times to emphasize the importance of government spending, which was met with approval from the media.

The speech received widespread praise from the media, with MSNBC's Ed Schultz calling it "a stunning speech" and CNN's Jessica Yellin describing Obama as "relaxed and confident." Politico summarized the media's reaction as "State of the Union reaction: Media gives Obama thumbs up."

However, Senator Marco Rubio's response to Obama's speech was met with a different reaction. Rubio, a Republican from Florida, delivered a speech that emphasized the importance of individual opportunity and responsibility, rather than relying on government intervention. He also grabbed a bottle of water during his speech, which was met with ridicule from the media.

MSNBC and CNN both dwelled on the water bottle, with MSNBC's Rachel Maddow joking about Rubio's "big reach for the water glass." CNN's Chris Matthews blasted Rubio's speech, saying it was "tinker toys" and "primitive." Former RNC head-turned MSNBC analyst Michael Steele also criticized Rubio's speech, saying he did not like the water bottle.

In contrast, Obama received more positive treatment from the media, with CNN's Wolf Blitzer describing his speech as "strong" and "emotional." The speech focused on government spending and taxes, with Obama emphasizing the need for increased investment in various areas. He also called for a hike in the minimum wage to $9 an hour, which was met with some surprise from left-leaning analysts.

Rubio's speech, on the other hand, was seen as a call to individual responsibility and limited government intervention. He emphasized that opportunity is not bestowed upon us from Washington, but rather from individual effort and hard work. He also reminded viewers that the sequester and cuts were his idea in the first place, and that Obama's solution to every problem is to tax more, borrow more, and spend more.

The media's reaction to Rubio's speech was overwhelmingly negative, with many analysts criticizing his decision to grab a bottle of water during the speech. However, Rubio's speech was seen as a call to individual responsibility and limited government intervention, which was met with criticism from the media.

Title: Romney Takes Aim at Media Bias in Joking Remarks at Al Smith Dinner

Article:

Mitt Romney, a Republican presidential candidate, made joking remarks about the media's perceived bias during the Al Smith dinner, a charity event that benefits Catholic humanitarian causes. In his speech, Romney poked fun at the media's job, saying, "My job is to lay out a positive vision for the future of the country, and their job is to make sure no one else finds out about it." He also referenced headlines that criticized his campaign, saying, "Let's just say that some in the media have a certain way of looking at things."

Professor Paul Kengor, an author and expert on media bias, was not joking when he told Breitbart News that the job of the major media is to "protect Obama, not expose him." Kengor has experienced media bias firsthand since his book, "The Communist," was published in July. The book exposes Obama's relationship with Communist Party operative Frank Marshall Davis.

Kengor's book reveals that Davis was a Communist Party member and that Obama's relationship with him is a significant aspect of his life. The media have largely ignored Kengor's book, and he believes that they are more interested in protecting Obama than in investigating his past.

Tim Groseclose, author of "Left Turn: How Liberal Media Bias Distorts the American Mind," believes that the leftward bias of the media has shifted the political quotient of the average American by about 20 points on a scale of 100. This could potentially translate into millions of votes.

Pollster Pat Caddell urged Romney to openly run against the "mainstream media" and the Democratic Party, saying that they have made themselves a "fundamental threat to democracy" by hiding information critical to making informed decisions. However, Romney has decided not to attack media bias, even though liberal media strategies of distortion and omission can cost a Republican candidate critical voter support.

The media have largely ignored Kengor's book, and he believes that they are more interested in protecting Obama than in investigating his past. The media have also ignored the existence of the 600-page FBI file on Davis, which was released in 2008.

Kengor believes that the media are not real journalists but rather political partisans who have sacrificed their noble profession to an ignoble political ideology. He believes that they are more interested in protecting Obama than in investigating his past.

The influence of Romney adviser Ed Gillespie, who has said the campaign has a "no whining rule" about media coverage, has also contributed to the campaign's decision not to attack media bias. GOP strategist and SuperPAC sponsor Karl Rove has also advised Romney and other Republicans not to attack Obama as a socialist or a left-winger, as the charges would be met with denials.

The media are starting to take note of the DVD "Dreams from My Real Father," which explores Obama's relationship with Frank Marshall Davis. The DVD is being mailed to millions of households in swing states, and it cites factual data about Davis's relationship with Obama and notes the existence of the 600-page FBI file on Davis.

Kengor believes that if there is nothing to hide in Obama's relationship with Davis, then why did Obama delete the references to "Frank" in the audio version of his book, "Dreams from My Father"? Kengor notes that Obama narrates the audio version and that the back cover of the audio states, "This abridgment has been approved by the author." Kengor believes that the deletion of the references to "Frank" is a clear concealment and a deliberate attempt to hide information.

Title: Italy Extends Coronavirus Measures, Imposes Travel Restrictions and Public Gathering Bans

Italy has extended its emergency coronavirus measures to the entire country, imposing travel restrictions and a ban on public gatherings to protect the most vulnerable individuals. Prime Minister Giuseppe Conte ordered people to stay at home and seek permission for essential travel, stating that the measures were designed to contain the spread of the virus.

The number of confirmed coronavirus cases in Italy has increased by 24% from Sunday, with 463 deaths reported, making it the worst-hit country after China. The virus has been confirmed in all 20 Italian regions. Conte emphasized the importance of staying at home, saying, "We're having an important growth in infections... and of deaths. The whole of Italy will become a protected zone."

The measures include a ban on public gatherings, with only those with a valid work or family reason allowed to travel. All sporting events, including football matches, have been suspended nationwide, and schools and universities will remain closed until April 3. Passengers departing on flights will have to justify their travel, and there will be controls at train stations to check passengers' temperatures.

The Italian government has also taken measures to control the spread of the virus in prisons, suspending all visits and imposing strict controls on inmates. Riots broke out in several prisons, with at least seven inmates dying amid the unrest.

Globally, the number of confirmed cases has surpassed 111,000, with over 3,890 deaths reported. The World Health Organization (WHO) has warned that the threat of a pandemic is "very real."

Title: Trump Administration Unveils Immigration Plan with Focus on Merit-Based Immigration and High-Skilled Labor

The Trump administration has released a new immigration plan, which prioritizes merit-based immigration and high-skilled labor over family-based and lottery-based immigration. The plan aims to reshape the way people are allowed into the United States, with a focus on attracting highly skilled workers.

The centerpiece of the plan is a shift towards a "merit" system, similar to those in place in Australia and Canada. The reform would increase skill-based immigration from 12% to 57%, while decreasing family-based and lottery-based immigration by 50%. This is seen as a positive development for employers seeking high-skilled workers.

The plan also includes a proposal to increase the number of H-1B visas for temporary, skilled workers, and to double the cap on employment-based green cards. However, it does not address the issue of "Dreamers" and does not provide a pathway to legal status for the current illegal population.

The plan has been met with mixed reactions, with some praising the focus on high-skilled labor and others criticizing the lack of comprehensive reform. The plan's failure to address the needs of low-skilled workers and the "Dreamers" has been particularly criticized.

Title: Former FBI Director Comey Says Trump Likely Committed Crimes, Could Face Indictment After Leaving Office

Former FBI Director James B. Comey stated during a CNN town-hall-style meeting that he believes President Trump likely committed crimes that could lead to indictment once he leaves office. Comey based his judgment on his reading of special counsel Robert Mueller's report and specifically mentioned Trump's order to White House Counsel Don McGahn to fire Mueller. When asked if he agreed with an open letter from federal prosecutors that Trump would have been indicted on obstruction of justice charges if he were not president, Comey was emphatic.

The former FBI chief noted that it has been a longstanding Justice Department policy that a sitting president cannot be indicted. However, Attorney General William P. Barr has stated that Mueller's decision not to charge Trump was not based solely on this policy. Comey suggested that Mueller was balancing Justice Department policy with building a factual record that could be used in other circumstances, such as Congress's power to impeach a president.

When asked if Trump could be indicted in the future, Comey said it was possible. "The Justice Department will have to take a serious look at that," he said. Comey also dismissed another defense of Trump, that the president cannot obstruct justice by exercising his legitimate constitutional powers to run the executive branch. "The president is not above the law," he said, calling the theory pushed by some, including Harvard law professor Alan Dershowitz, "crazy and a recipe for lawlessness."

Title: Trump Denies Knowledge of Russian Intelligence on Bounties for American Service Members in Afghanistan

Article:

President Donald Trump claimed in a tweet that he was not briefed on intelligence about a Russian unit offering bounties on American service members in Afghanistan because the U.S. intelligence community deemed the information not credible. Trump also suggested that details of the intelligence, first reported by The New York Times, may have been fabricated by the media to "make Republicans look bad."

The White House and the Office of the Director of National Intelligence (ODNI) have not directly addressed the credibility of the intelligence as described, but have disputed the Times' account that Trump was briefed on the information. White House press secretary Kayleigh McEnany said on "Fox & Friends" that Congress would be briefed on the matter, without providing further details on who specifically would participate in the briefing.

The Times reported that intelligence assessments concluded that the Russian intelligence unit known as the GRU secretly offered payments to Taliban-linked militants for successful attacks on coalition forces in Afghanistan last year. The newspaper reported that Trump had been briefed on the intelligence and that officials had deliberated potential response options but that the White House hadn't authorized any further action.

The revelations have prompted criticism of Trump, who has been consistently scrutinized for his friendliness toward Russian President Vladimir Putin and resistance to taking firm action against Moscow over its interference in the 2016 presidential election. Presumptive Democratic presidential nominee Joe Biden criticized Trump's handling of the situation, calling it a "betrayal of the most sacred duty we bear as a nation to protect and equip our troops when we send them into harm's way."

The White House denied that Trump or Vice President Pence was briefed on the intelligence, but did not refute the accuracy of the intelligence as described by the Times and other news outlets. The CIA Director, National Security Advisor, and Chief of Staff confirmed that neither the President nor the Vice President were briefed on the alleged Russian bounty intelligence.

Title: Trump Criticizes Judge's Ruling on Travel Ban, Appeals Court Rejects Justice Department's Request

The President of the United States, Donald Trump, has continued to express his discontent with the recent ruling by U.S. District Court Judge James Robart, which overturned his executive order restricting travel from seven Muslim-majority countries and suspending refugee admissions. On Sunday, Trump took to social media to express his disappointment, stating that he "can't believe a judge would put our country in such peril" and that "people pouring in. Bad!"

The President also instructed the Department of Homeland Security to "check people coming into our country VERY CAREFULLY," citing the court's decision as making the job more difficult. The Justice Department had requested that the appeals court reinstate the travel ban, but the court rejected this request.

Judge Robart's ruling on Friday granted a temporary restraining order, prohibiting federal employees from enforcing Trump's executive order on a nationwide basis. The order was challenged by Washington Attorney General Bob Ferguson, who argued that it was illegal and unconstitutional. The Justice Department responded with a strongly-worded statement, claiming that halting the travel ban "harms the public" and "second-guesses the President's national security judgment."

In response to the court's decision, the Department of Homeland Security announced that it would not continue to implement Trump's order, effectively allowing business as usual at airports. The State Department also stated that it would not cancel or revoke any more visas, and that individuals with valid visas may now travel. Prior to the court's decision, up to 60,000 visas had been revoked.

Judge Robart's ruling stated that Trump's order is harmful to "residents in areas of employment, education, business, family relations, and freedom to travel."

Title: The Elusive Conversation on Gun Control: A Critique of the Liberal Elite's Approach

The article argues that the liberal elite's push for a "conversation" on gun control is nothing more than an attempt to impose their own agenda on the American public, rather than engaging in a genuine discussion. The author criticizes the liberal elite, particularly Chris Cuomo, for their perceived hypocrisy and lack of self-awareness regarding the role of teachers' unions in the decline of public education.

The article claims that the rise of school shootings is not due to the lack of gun control laws, but rather the absence of a civilized culture that teaches students to follow rules and respect authority. The author suggests that the liberal elite's focus on gun control is a distraction from their own responsibility in the demise of civil society.

The article also questions the effectiveness of adding more laws to address the problem of gun violence, citing the example of the Florida shooter who violated numerous existing laws. Instead, the author argues that the focus should be on the capacity of citizens to respect existing laws and the importance of civilizing institutions, such as the family.

Overall, the article presents a scathing critique of the liberal elite's approach to gun control, accusing them of seeking to impose their own agenda on the American public and undermine the principles of a free society.

Title: China and US Agree to Roll Back Tariffs in Phases if Trade Talks Progress

The Chinese Commerce Ministry announced on Thursday that Beijing and Washington have agreed in principle to roll back existing tariffs in phases if trade talks between the two countries move forward. According to Ministry spokesman Gao Feng, both sides have agreed to simultaneously cancel some tariffs on each other's goods, with the size of the reductions dependent on the agreement.

Gao emphasized that one important condition for a limited trade agreement is that the US and China must remove the same amount of charges at the same time. The news about a "phase one" trade agreement prompted US stock index futures to rally, with Dow futures poised to open up more than 120 points.

The two governments have raised tariffs on billions of dollars of each other's goods in the fight over China's trade surplus and technology ambitions, which weighs on trade and threatens to depress global economic growth. President Trump agreed to postpone a planned tariff hike while lower-level officials hammered out details, and he stated that China had agreed to buy up to $50 billion of American farm goods.

The agreement to postpone the tariff hike was reached on October 12, easing market jitters, but the two sides have yet to announce progress on major disagreements over technology and other irritants following 13 rounds of talks. Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross said that any "phase one" agreement would be general and cover trade in specific areas such as soybeans and liquefied natural gas, with more complex issues to be tackled in later negotiations.

Title: Facebook Removes Page Denigrating Women in Marine Corps After Congressional Complaint

Article:

Facebook has removed a page that denigrated women in the Marine Corps after a House member, Representative Jackie Speier, complained to the Pentagon and called the page another example of the military's lax attitude toward sexual harassment. The page was cited by Speier in a letter to Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel and top military brass, released on Wednesday. She also addressed it to Marine Corps Commandant Gen. James Amos and asked officials to explain how they plan to respond.

The Marine Corps, in a statement released by Capt. Eric Flanagan, emphasized that Marines are responsible for all content they publish on social networking sites, blogs, or other websites. The statement also noted that there is no tolerance for discriminatory comments, which go against good order and discipline.

It is unclear who created or updates the page. In later online posts, Speier was called a vulgar four-letter word, incorrectly called a senator, and threatened for causing the page to be taken down. Speier's office said the posts were referred to U.S. Capitol Police, which declined to comment.

Facebook removed the page on Wednesday after determining the administrators were fake, according to a company official speaking on condition of anonymity. Facebook regularly removes pages that bully or harass people in general.

The page and others like it, Speier wrote, contribute to a culture that permits and seems to encourage sexual assault and abuse. The Marine Corps statement said that based on complaints received, both active-duty and reserve Marines have been involved, and all instances are referred to commands for appropriate action.

The removal of the page comes as the Pentagon is facing increased scrutiny over its handling of sexual assault cases. On Tuesday, the Pentagon released a report estimating 26,000 troops had been sexually abused in 2012, up 35% since the last survey in 2010.

Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid, D-Nev., sent letters to the chairman and ranking member of the Senate Armed Services Committee asking them to add anti-sexual assault provisions to the 2014 defense authorization bill. Reid urged lawmakers to eliminate the ability of military commanders to arbitrarily reverse convictions under the Uniform Code for Military Justice for sexual assault.

Key White House aides are scheduled to meet with a bipartisan group of about 12 members of the House and Senate on Thursday to discuss potential legislation to address the issue.

Title: Trump Responds to Emotional Speech by Khan Family, Media Criticizes Him

Article:

Donald Trump, the Republican presidential nominee, has faced criticism from the media and some political opponents after his response to an emotional speech by the parents of Captain Humayun Khan, an immigrant soldier who died in Iraq in 2004. The speech, delivered by Khizr Khan, the father of the fallen soldier, was a powerful rebuke to Trump's stance on immigration and terrorism.

In an interview with Maureen Dowd of The New York Times and George Stephanopoulos of ABC News, Trump was asked to respond to the speech. He told Dowd, "I'd like to hear his wife say something," referring to the subordinate status of women in Islam. Trump also suggested that the Clinton campaign had scripted Khan's remarks and defended his own "sacrifices" for America.

The media has responded with criticism, with some outlets calling Trump's comments "horrifying" and "slanderous." However, some have pointed out that Trump's comments were not entirely out of line, citing the fact that Clinton's actions as Secretary of State contributed to the death of Sean Smith, a Benghazi victim.

Trump has issued statements on Twitter and his campaign website, stating that Captain Khan was a hero, but that the real problem is radical Islamic terrorism. He also criticized Clinton's role in destabilizing the Middle East and her handling of the Benghazi attack.

The controversy has sparked a wider debate about the role of politicians in responding to emotional appeals and the media's role in fact-checking and context.

Title: Sen. Rand Paul Criticizes President Obama's Handling of Border Crisis During Guatemala Trip

Article:

During a recent trip to Guatemala to perform pro-bono eye surgeries, Senator Rand Paul (R-Kentucky) criticized President Obama's handling of the border crisis, stating that the main problem lies within the White House. In a closed-door meeting with Guatemalan President Otto Perez Molina, Paul expressed his concerns about the administration's policies, saying that the mess at the border is a result of the White House's policies.

Paul supported the House bill to end the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) program and believes it would "go a long way to fixing the problem." He also condemned President Obama for not doing enough to secure the border, stating that without a real solution at the border, there can be no reform.

The senator emphasized that the problem and solution reside within the White House, rather than in Guatemala City. He criticized the administration for offering amnesty without securing the border, saying it creates "beacons or magnets" that attract more undocumented immigrants.

The Democratic National Committee responded to Paul's comments, calling his trip to Guatemala a "crass campaign photo op" and criticizing him for condemning the president in the presence of a foreign leader. The committee also pointed out that Paul voted against Democratic immigration reform legislation and opposed an emergency supplemental package to address the border crisis.

It is worth noting that Senator Paul's trip to Guatemala was part of his pro-bono eye surgery mission, where he performed sight-restoring surgeries in the rural town of Salama.

Title: Trump Suggests "Rogue Killers" May Be Behind Jamal Khashoggi's Disappearance

Article:

President Donald Trump said Monday that Saudi Arabia's King Salman offered him a "flat denial" regarding the disappearance of Saudi journalist Jamal Khashoggi, who was last seen entering the Saudi consulate in Istanbul, Turkey, on October 2. Trump also suggested that "rogue killers" could be behind Khashoggi's disappearance.

According to Trump, Salman denied any knowledge of Khashoggi's disappearance, saying it was a "strong denial." Trump added that the king's denial was "very strong" and that it "sounded to me like maybe these could have been rogue killers, who knows."

The Saudi government had previously maintained that Khashoggi left the consulate the same afternoon of his visit, but provided no evidence to support this claim. Khashoggi's fiancée, Hatice Cengiz, who was waiting outside the consulate, said she did not see him re-emerge.

Turkish authorities believe 15 Saudi men who arrived in Istanbul on October 2 were connected to Khashoggi's disappearance and possible murder. At least some of them appear to have high-level connections in the Saudi government. Turkish officials have also obtained audio and visual evidence that shows Khashoggi was killed inside the consulate.

International pressure is mounting on Riyadh to explain Khashoggi's disappearance, with the UK, France, and Germany demanding a "credible investigation" into the events. The US has also warned of serious retribution if the Saudis are found to be behind Khashoggi's possible death.

In a related development, Saudi officials have granted permission for the Saudi consulate in Istanbul to be searched, and Turkish investigators, including forensics officers, entered the premises on Monday evening. The search is part of a joint investigation with Turkish authorities, who believe Khashoggi was killed inside the consulate.

The case has caused friction between Saudi Arabia and Turkey, with Turkey accusing the Saudis of failing to cooperate with their investigation. The Saudi government has threatened to retaliate if the US imposes sanctions, but later softened its tone.

The disappearance of Khashoggi has also led to a diplomatic rift between Saudi Arabia and the West, with several international firms pulling out of a high-profile investment summit in Riyadh. The Future Investment Initiative conference, dubbed "Davos in the Desert," was due to take place later this month, hosted by Saudi Arabia's de facto ruler, Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman.

Title: Trump Should Avoid Reaction to Russia Indictments, Experts Say

Article:

The recent indictment of former Trump campaign manager Paul Manafort and his associate Rick Gates, as well as the plea deal with former Trump foreign-policy adviser George Papadopoulos, has sparked a wave of negative press coverage for President Donald Trump. However, experts advise Trump to avoid reacting to the news and instead focus on maintaining a calm and composed demeanor.

The indictment of Manafort and Gates is primarily focused on their individual actions, with no direct connection to the Trump campaign. Manafort is accused of failing to register as a foreign lobbyist and laundering millions of dollars, while Gates is accused of lying to the FBI about his contacts with Russians. Papadopoulos's plea deal involves his work for the Trump campaign, but it is unclear whether his actions had any significant impact.

Experts warn that Trump's instinct to lash out in response to the news could be his worst enemy. Firing special counsel Robert Mueller or issuing pardons could lead to a catastrophic outcome, as it would only fuel speculation and further investigation. Instead, Trump should focus on maintaining a calm and composed demeanor, allowing the investigation to run its course.

The article concludes that the calculus is simple: if Trump is guilty of serious wrongdoing, there is nothing he can do to stop it from being uncovered. If he is innocent, firing Mueller or issuing pardons would be a catastrophic error.

Title: Brexit and Beyond: The Uncertain Future of the UK's Global Role

The UK's departure from the European Union has sparked a mix of emotions, with some celebrating the country's newfound independence and others lamenting the uncertainty that lies ahead. Despite the fanfare, the reality is that the transition period will not bring significant changes on the ground, with the UK being treated as if it were still part of the EU for the next 11 months. This temporary arrangement is expected to last until the end of the year, when the UK and EU must agree on a trade deal governing their future commercial relations.

The stakes are high, as the UK's failure to reach an agreement could lead to a no-deal scenario, which would be damaging and disruptive, especially for the country's largest trading partner, the EU. The uncertainty surrounding Brexit is not limited to the UK, as the EU is also trying to carve out its place on the world stage, dominated by the US and China.

The UK's aspirations for a "Global Britain" as a free-market counterweight to the protectionist EU have yet to be realized, and the country's departure from the EU has exposed the complexity of the relationship between the two entities. The period since the referendum has seen the careers of two prime ministers, eight cabinet ministers, and over 80 MPs end, and the real decisions are still to be made.

The choices stemming from Brexit are significant, and the UK must navigate the challenges of negotiating a trade deal with the EU while also addressing its own internal issues, such as the impact on its economy and the potential for a no-deal scenario. The country's Prime Minister, Boris Johnson, has promised not to extend the transition period beyond 2020, giving the UK and EU less than 11 months to figure out their future partnership.

The article also touches on the potential consequences of a no-deal scenario, which could lead to expensive disruption and shortages in goods and services. The UK's departure from the EU is not the only challenge it faces, as it must also address its own internal issues, such as the impact on its economy and the potential for a no-deal scenario.

In conclusion, the UK's departure from the EU is a complex and uncertain process that will have far-reaching consequences for the country and the world. The choices made in the coming months will shape the UK's future and its role on the global stage.

Title: Obamacare Premiums to Increase by Average of 22% in 2017, Administration Reports

The Obama administration has acknowledged that premiums for the Affordable Care Act (Obamacare) will increase by an average of 22% in 2017, with the price of the most popular benchmark plans jumping by 22%. This comes as the law continues to rely on older and sicker customers than initially envisioned, making it difficult for insurers to make the economics work.

The number of insurers participating in the federally run exchange will also decrease, with companies such as UnitedHealth Group and Aetna withdrawing from most states. This could lead to lower competition and potentially worse premium increases. Roughly one in five customers will have only one insurer as an option next year.

The administration has urged consumers to shop around to find the best deals, with 80% of customers qualifying for taxpayer-funded subsidies. The Health and Human Services Department (HHS) reported that nearly three-quarters of customers will be able to find a plan for $75 or less per month after tax credits kick in.

However, several million customers do not qualify for government subsidies or purchase insurance off the exchanges, so they will feel the full brunt of the increases. Taxpayers will also have to shell out more money to cover the subsidies for those who do qualify, meaning Obamacare's costs will continue to rise.

The House Energy and Commerce Committee has asked the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services to detail how much of a burden taxpayers are shouldering. Congressional Republicans have seized on the news, warning voters that electing Democrats would cement the Affordable Care Act into law.

Analysts had warned of massive premium increases, saying the Obamacare program is still struggling to entice healthy customers who are needed to make the economics work. Minnesota Governor Mark Dayton, a Democrat, recently said the law "is no longer affordable for an increasing number of people." Tennessee Insurance Commissioner Julie McPeak said the state's Obamacare exchange is "very near collapse."

Increases will vary widely from place to place, with some areas seeing significant jumps. In Arizona, a 27-year-old's average monthly premium for the second-lowest silver plan jumps $196 to $422, a 116% increase, before subsidies. In Oklahoma, that same customer would get a 69% increase. Customers in Indiana and Massachusetts, which runs its own exchange, would be the only ones to see a decrease, of 3%.

The administration said things could get worse if the federal courts do not overturn a judge's decision in May that sided with House Republicans, who say the Treasury is unlawfully reimbursing insurers for losses under the 2010 health care overhaul.

Title: House Judiciary Committee and Democrats at Odds with Attorney General William Barr over Congressional Oversight

The House Judiciary Committee and Democratic lawmakers are at odds with Attorney General William Barr over his refusal to appear before the committee, citing concerns over the executive branch's defiance of the Constitution and the rule of law. Barr declined to appear before the committee, citing a desire to only be questioned by members, not committee lawyers. Democrats refused to accommodate his request, citing a bigger constitutional principle at stake.

The Trump administration has made it clear they will not play nice with Democratic demands, with White House Press Secretary Sarah Sanders calling the Judiciary Committee's request for staff lawyers to question Barr a "pathetic" moment. Democrats are now considering all options, including holding Barr in contempt and seeking further legal recourse.

House Judiciary Chairman Jerry Nadler has given Barr an ultimatum, requesting an unredacted Mueller report by May 6. If Barr does not comply, Nadler says he will proceed with contempt proceedings and seek further legal action. Nadler has also sent a letter to Barr, stating that the department's refusal to comply with congressional oversight requests is unacceptable and that Congress's constitutional, oversight, and legislative interest in investigating misconduct by the president and his associates cannot be disputed.

Some Democrats are already calling for Barr's impeachment, while others are considering censure or exploring Congress's "inherent contempt" powers, which have not been triggered in nearly a century. Speaker Nancy Pelosi has reminded reporters that ignoring Congress has consequences, citing the Articles of Impeachment for President Nixon.

A spokesman for Barr has called Pelosi's comments "reckless, irresponsible, and false." Not all reactions have been as serious, with Rep. Steve Cohen, D-Tenn., bringing a bucket of KFC to the empty hearing room to make a theatrical point. Some Democrats, like Rep. Pramila Jayapal, D-Wash., are no longer interested in hearing from Barr and would rather hear from Mueller, who has been invited to testify on May 15.

Title: Yahoo News Confirms Katie Couric's Continued Employment Despite Editing Controversy

Article:

Yahoo News has confirmed that Katie Couric will continue to serve as its global anchor, despite recent allegations of deceptive editing in two documentaries she executive produced and narrated. The company stated that it is "confident in the work of the Yahoo News team, which adheres to the highest standards of journalism." When asked if Couric's employment status had been affected by the controversy, a spokesperson confirmed that she is still with the company.

The controversy surrounds the documentaries "Under the Gun" and "Fed Up," which Couric executive produced and narrated since joining Yahoo News in 2013. Critics have accused Couric and director Stephanie Soechtig of editing out or manipulating audio and footage to support their narrative. The Free Beacon reported that in "Under the Gun," Couric and Soechtig edited out gun rights activists' answers to a question about background checks, replacing them with silence. The publication also accused the duo of inserting audio at a moment it did not occur during a separate interview in "Fed Up."

Industry sources and experts have spoken out against the alleged deceptive editing practices. Dr. David Allison, director of the Nutrition Obesity Research Center, stated that his portrayal in "Fed Up" was "antithetical to the spirit of science and democratic dialogue." The Healthy Weight Commitment Foundation also disputed the film's portrayal of their organization.

Soechtig did not respond to requests for comment from the Free Beacon but stood by the films in a statement to Variety. Couric's spokesperson did not issue a statement, directing Variety to Soechtig's statement instead.

The controversy has sparked a wider conversation about the importance of transparency and accuracy in documentary filmmaking. While Yahoo News has not taken any disciplinary action against Couric, the company's statement emphasizes its commitment to adhering to the highest standards of journalism.

Title: Egypt Declares State of Emergency After Deadly Palm Sunday Attacks

Egypt's President Abdel-Fattah el-Sisi declared a three-month state of emergency after two suicide bombings at Coptic Christian churches in the cities of Tanta and Alexandria, killing at least 44 people and injuring over 100. The attacks, carried out by the ISIS terror group, occurred on Palm Sunday, a significant holiday in the Christian calendar.

The first blast occurred at St. George Church in the Nile Delta town of Tanta, where at least 27 people were killed and 78 others wounded. Television footage showed the inside of the church, where a large number of people gathered around what appeared to be lifeless, bloody bodies covered with papers. The second explosion, which Egypt's Interior Ministry said was caused by a suicide bomber who tried to storm St. Mark's Cathedral in the coastal city of Alexandria, left at least 17 dead and 48 injured.

The attacks came just weeks before Pope Francis is due to visit Egypt, the Arab world's most populous country. Egyptian President Abdel-Fattah el-Sisi accused unnamed countries of fueling instability in the country, adding that "Egyptians have foiled plots and efforts by countries and fascist, terrorist organizations that tried to control Egypt." El-Sisi ordered the immediate deployment of troops to assist police in protecting vital facilities across the country.

The United States condemned the attacks, with President Donald Trump tweeting that he is "so sad to hear of the terrorist attack" and expressing confidence that el-Sisi will "handle the situation properly." The State Department issued a statement calling the attacks "barbaric" and expressing support for Egypt's efforts to defeat terrorism.

The attacks are the latest in a series of assaults on Egypt's Christian minority, which makes up around 10% of the population and has been repeatedly targeted by Islamic extremists. The Grand Sheikh Ahmed el-Tayeb, head of Egypt's Al-Azhar, condemned the attacks, calling them a "despicable terrorist bombing that targeted the lives of innocents."

Title: Trump Administration to Decide on Fate of DACA, a Program Protecting Undocumented Immigrants

The Trump administration is expected to make a decision on the future of the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) program, which was enacted by the Obama administration in 2012 to provide temporary legal status to undocumented immigrants who came to the United States as children. As a candidate, Trump had promised to eliminate DACA on "day one," but after taking office, he has struggled to make a decision.

While Trump had campaigned on a platform of tough enforcement of federal immigration laws, he has expressed empathy for the young people affected by the program. "I love these kids. I love kids. I have kids and grandkids. And I find it very, very hard doing what the law says exactly to do," he told reporters in February.

The program has allowed around 750,000 undocumented immigrants to remain in the country legally and apply for work permits. Many have built their lives in the United States, and advocates argue that deporting them would be unjust.

A group of 43 Democratic Senators, including Sen. Catherine Cortez Masto of Nevada, wrote in a July 27 letter to Trump, "These young people are known as Dreamers. They came to the United States as children and are American in every way except for their immigration status. We have already invested in them by educating them in American schools. It makes no sense to squander their talents by deporting them to countries they barely remember."

The Trump administration has been under pressure to make a decision on DACA, with a group of pro-enforcement state attorneys general urging action. In 2014, they sued to stop the expansion of DACA and another Obama-era program, Deferred Action for American Parents, which provided legal status for 5 million undocumented immigrants related to DACA recipients. The attorneys general prevailed in federal courts, and a 4-4 U.S. Supreme Court decision upheld their complaint.

The fate of DACA remains uncertain, with some predicting that Trump will ultimately decide to end the program. However, others believe that he may choose to reach across the aisle and pass a measure that protects so-called Dreamers while also bolstering enforcement, perhaps by funding the wall.

Title: US Intelligence Suggests Coronavirus Originated Naturally, But No Certainty

The Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, Army General Mark Milley, stated on Tuesday that US intelligence indicates the coronavirus likely originated naturally, rather than being created in a Chinese laboratory. However, he emphasized that there is no certainty either way. Milley's remarks may fuel speculation about the virus's origins, which China has dismissed as a conspiracy theory.

Milley was non-committal when asked if he had any evidence that the virus began in a Chinese laboratory and was accidentally released. He stated that there is a lot of rumor and speculation, and that the US has taken a keen interest in investigating the matter. While he acknowledged that the weight of evidence seems to indicate a natural origin, he stressed that it is inconclusive.

The comments may reignite tensions with Beijing, which has previously denied any involvement in the pandemic. Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesman Zhao Lijian had previously tweeted that the US Army might have brought the epidemic to Wuhan, a claim the US government and President Donald Trump have denied.

The scientific consensus holds that SARS-CoV-2, the official name of the virus, originated in bats. The Wuhan Institute of Virology has repeatedly denied any involvement in the virus's origin. A Washington Post opinion column published on Tuesday noted that the US State Department had warned about safety and management weaknesses at the Wuhan Institute of Virology in 2018, but scientists largely agree that the virus came from animals.

US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo declined to comment on the Washington Post column, stating that the US is working to piece together the facts about the pandemic's origin. A team of 27 scientists published a statement in the Lancet medical journal in February condemning conspiracy theories and emphasizing that scientists around the world overwhelmingly conclude that the coronavirus originated in wildlife.

Title: Democrats Test Boundaries of Privacy with Tracker Videos

Article:

In a move that has raised concerns about the limits of political campaigning, House Democrats have taken to recording video footage of the homes of Republican congressmen and candidates, posting the raw footage online for public viewing. While politicians generally acknowledge that they give up some privacy when running for office, this practice has sparked debate about when campaign tracking becomes an invasion of privacy.

The practice, known as "tracking," involves campaign staffers recording every public appearance and statement made by an opponent. However, House Democrats have taken it a step further by filming the homes of GOP congressmen and candidates, sparking concerns about safety risks and invasion of privacy. Wisconsin Rep. Reid Ribble, who has been followed by a cameraman while shopping for groceries, expressed his disapproval, stating that the practice is "totally inappropriate" and "disturbing."

Ribble's wife, DeaNa, echoed her husband's concerns, saying she feels "creeped out" by the practice and would call the police if a tracker were to set foot on their private property. Other Republicans whose homes have been videotaped, such as Ohio Rep. Jim Renacci, argue that filming a home and posting actual addresses should be off-limits, citing concerns for their families and neighbors.

While some may see this practice as a legitimate campaign tactic, others believe it crosses a line. The debate highlights the ongoing tension between political transparency and personal privacy in the digital age.

Title: Homeland Security Inspector General Finds Illegal Behavior in Implementation of Trump's Original Travel Ban

The Homeland Security inspector general, John Roth, released a memo to Congress on Monday, concluding that department employees illegally tried to prevent individuals from affected countries from entering the United States, despite court orders to the contrary. The memo, which covers the early days of the original travel ban implemented by President Trump on January 27, 2017, found that Customs and Border Protection (CBP) defied two court orders and issued "no board" instructions to airlines, attempting to prevent passengers from boarding flights.

The inspector general's report also concluded that CBP lacked guidance on the travel ban, leaving employees without clear instructions on how to implement the policy. However, Roth found that passengers who reached the United States were treated well by CBP officers, contradicting some reports from immigrant-rights activists at the time. The report also found that many CBP officers went above and beyond to provide food and water to passengers, using their own personal funds.

The administration made extensive use of waivers, allowing most passengers who reached the United States to enter the country despite the executive order. This suggests that the original travel ban was more bark than bite when it came to actual implementation.

The original order was blocked by several courts, and Trump responded with a revised order in March. The second version was also blocked by lower courts, but the Supreme Court partially overturned the blocks in June, allowing some of the ban to take effect. Trump then updated the policy this fall, and it is currently undergoing court scrutiny.

The inspector general's memo was submitted to the Homeland Security Department on October 6, but the department is still deciding whether to classify any of the report as secret. Democrats who released the memo on Monday called the attempt to hide the findings "frankly unacceptable."

Title: Trump's Challenges in Preparing for the Next Debate

The article discusses the challenges Donald Trump faces in preparing for the next presidential debate, as highlighted by author Michael D'Antonio in his book "The Truth About Trump." Trump's advisors must overcome his 40-plus years of doing things his way, which may be difficult to change. The article lists 10 things Trump could do to prepare for the next debate, but notes that it's unlikely he will be able to do any of them.

The article highlights Trump's poor sportsmanship, lack of responsibility, and tendency to brag and boast. It also notes his inability to take responsibility for his actions, his lack of maturity, and his tendency to use gamesmanship and exaggeration. The article concludes that Trump's advisors will have a difficult time getting him to change his ways and prepare for the next debate.

Title: Economist Bryan Caplan Questions the Value of Higher Education

Economist Bryan Caplan, author of the book "The Case Against Education," argues that most people should not attend college. In a recent YouTube video, he pointed out that many students spend thousands of hours studying subjects they never use again, and that the primary reason people attend college is to get a good job.

Caplan notes that while it is true that people with higher education tend to earn more money, this is not because college provides job skills, but because a college degree serves as a signaling device, indicating to employers that an individual is intelligent and capable. He believes that this signaling effect is the primary reason for the rising cost of tuition, as more people pursue higher education to increase their earning potential.

Caplan also argues that students can learn without incurring tuition debt, citing the example of attending college lectures without enrolling. However, he notes that few people take advantage of this option, as the value of a college degree is largely tied to its prestige and the fact that it is often subsidized by taxpayers.

The economist also questions the value of many college majors, such as social justice, diversity studies, and multicultural studies, which he believes do not provide practical skills or job training. He cites a study that found that a third of people have not detectably learned anything after four years in college.

While Caplan acknowledges that some fields, such as computer science and electrical engineering, do provide useful skills, he believes that the majority of college education is not worth the cost. He notes that professors, on the other hand, tend to benefit from the system, with tenured professors enjoying a comfortable income and minimal demands on their time.

Overall, Caplan's argument is that while college may be lucrative for individuals, it is not necessarily a good idea for society as a whole, and that students would be better off pursuing alternative forms of education or training.

**Search Continues for Missing Marines and Army Aircrew After Black Hawk Helicopter Crash**

A search operation is ongoing for seven Marines and four Army aircrew members who went missing after their Black Hawk helicopter crashed into waters off the Florida Panhandle on Tuesday evening. The aircraft was first reported missing at around 8:30 p.m. (9:30 p.m. ET) and debris was later found around Okaloosa Island near Eglin Air Force Base.

The search efforts, which involved around 100 people, are expected to resume midday Thursday, with boats scouring the waters throughout the night, weather permitting. Human remains have washed ashore in the area, but the search-and-rescue mission remains underway.

The crash occurred during a seven-day training exercise of amphibious operations, involving small boats and inserting and extracting Marines from the water via helicopter. The UH-60 helicopter was not alone when it went down, as a second Black Hawk safely returned to its base.

The identities of the missing service members have not been released publicly until the Coast Guard recovers their bodies or calls off the search. The incident is being investigated, with no cause specified, although heavy fog in the area at the time of the crash is not believed to have been a factor.

The UH-60 Black Hawk helicopter is a twin-engine aircraft introduced into Army service in 1979, and is regularly used in U.S. Army missions. The pilots involved in the crash were instructor pilots with several thousand combined hours of operation flying the Black Hawk.

Title: California Reinstates Obama-Era Net Neutrality Rules, Defying Federal Communications Commission

Article:

California has taken a bold step by reinstating Obama-era net neutrality rules, effectively defying the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) and the Trump administration. The state's decision, signed into law by Governor Jerry Brown, prohibits internet service providers from throttling or prioritizing certain internet traffic, and bans the offering of free data on specific apps. This move is seen as a significant blow to the FCC's efforts to roll back net neutrality regulations.

The FCC, led by Chairman Ajit Pai, has criticized the California law as "extreme," "illegal," and "radical," and has filed a lawsuit against the state. Pai claims that the law would hurt consumers by prohibiting free-data plans, which allow users to stream video, music, and other content without counting against their data limits.

However, proponents of the California law argue that the FCC has no power to interfere in state legislation, citing case law that states an agency without regulatory authority cannot preempt state actions. Barbara van Schewick, a law professor at Stanford Law School, agrees, stating that the FCC's repeal of the 2015 Open Internet Order removed its authority to regulate broadband internet access providers, making it impossible for the agency to prevent states from adopting net-neutrality protections.

The move by California is seen as a significant blow to the Trump administration's efforts to roll back net neutrality regulations. The administration has been critical of the Obama-era rules, and the FCC's repeal of the Open Internet Order was seen as a major victory for the telecommunications industry. However, the vast majority of voters support the Obama-era rules, and the move by California is seen as a major victory for advocates of net neutrality.

The Department of Justice's lawsuit against California is seen as a political move, with some experts dismissing it as "groundless saber-rattling" at the behest of a furious President Trump. The move is also seen as a way for the administration to attack California, which has been a thorn in its side on several issues, including clean energy and immigration.

Title: Former Governor Jennifer Granholm Urges Donald Trump to Withdraw from Presidential Race

Article:

Jennifer Granholm, a former governor and attorney general of Michigan, has expressed concerns about the impact of Donald Trump's rhetoric on the United States. As a senior research fellow at UC Berkeley and senior advisor to the super-PAC Correct The Record, Granholm has spoken out against Trump's behavior, stating that his lies and vitriolic rhetoric are causing irreparable damage to the nation.

In her commentary, Granholm references a best-selling leadership book, "The Leadership Challenge," which highlights the importance of honesty as a key characteristic of a leader. She notes that despite Trump's frequent fabrications and offensive remarks, he remains atop the Republican presidential candidate polls for five months. Granholm argues that Trump's refusal to acknowledge reality and his tendency to double down on his lies are concerning.

According to Granholm, Trump's actions have led the media to declare him "in a league of his own" when it comes to making claims that repeatedly fail to mesh with reality. She urges Trump to withdraw from the presidential race, citing the harm his behavior is causing to the nation.

Title: Obama Administration Allows Insurance Companies to Extend Current Plans for One Year

The Obama administration has announced that insurance companies will be allowed to extend previously cancelled policies for an additional year. This decision has been met with criticism from some, including former health insurance agent C. Edmund Wright, who appeared on Fox & Friends. Wright argued that the decision does not keep the president's promise to allow individuals to keep their insurance plans, stating that the one-year extension is equivalent to a "one-year death sentence" for insurance companies and customers.

However, the Washington Post's Wonkblog explained that insurance companies regularly change and cancel policies after one year, and the administration's decision is simply a request for insurers to offer their products for another year. The Post noted that insurers who take up this option would have to notify consumers of the health law benefits missing from the plan and inform them of other options available on the health law's marketplace.

MSNBC's Steven Rattner, a former Obama administration official, pointed out that half of people on the individual market are there for less than six months, and another 30 percent are there between six and 18 months. This suggests that many individuals are not staying in their original plan for an extended period.

A study by the Washington Post found that only 24 percent of individually insured people kept their plan for more than two years, indicating that the majority of individual insurance plans are temporary. The Congressional Budget Office (CBO) also noted that due to the naturally high turnover in the individual market, few plans would remain unchanged by 2016.

It is essential to note that the Obama administration's decision is not mandating that insurance companies offer their products for another year, but rather a request for them to do so. The decision aims to provide consumers with more options and flexibility in the health insurance market.

Title: Trump Issues Executive Order to Dismantle Affordable Care Act, Directing Agencies to Waive or Delay Penalties

The newly sworn-in President Donald Trump issued his first executive order, instructing federal agencies to dismantle the Affordable Care Act (ACA) to the maximum extent permitted by law. The order directs agencies to waive, defer, grant exemptions from, or delay any taxes or penalties they can. While the order does not give Trump new powers, it suggests he wants to move quickly on dismantling major parts of the health overhaul.

The executive order does not have an immediate tangible impact, but it signals the Trump administration's intention to start taking steps to unwind the ACA in various ways. This is a clear statement of Trump's priorities on the health care law, which has been a contentious issue in the past.

The order specifically directs agencies to use their authorities within the bounds of the law to dismantle any provision that would impose a fiscal burden on any state or a cost, fee, tax, penalty, or regulatory burden on an individual. This could potentially target the individual mandate, a key component of the ACA. However, the order does not repeal the mandate or any other part of the law, but rather sets up a long, drawn-out process to change the law's rules.

Health law expert Tim Jost, a law professor at Washington and Lee College, notes that Trump's executive order is more of a practical whisper than a political scream. Jost highlighted two important points about the order: most paragraphs start with the phrase "to the maximum extent permitted by law," recognizing that agencies can only take actions that do not conflict with the Affordable Care Act. This means Trump can revise rules and regulations, but cannot repeal the law itself.

The second point Jost emphasized is that Trump will follow the Administrative Procedure Act (APA) for new rules. This means that any changes will require a laborious process of issuing draft rules, accepting comments, and ultimately issuing a final rule that takes all feedback into account. This process takes time, and many important Obamacare regulations that govern how the law works have already gone through this process.

Overall, while the executive order is a significant move by the Trump administration, it does not have an immediate impact on the ACA. The process of dismantling the law will be a long and complex one, and it will likely take time to see the full effects of Trump's actions.

Title: Baucus Expected to be Nominated as Next U.S. Ambassador to China

The White House is expected to nominate Senator Max Baucus, a veteran Montana Democrat, as the next U.S. ambassador to China, according to sources familiar with the matter. Baucus, who has served in the Senate since 1978, has already announced he will not seek reelection in 2014. If confirmed, he would relinquish his position as chair of the powerful Senate Finance Committee, which is currently pushing for a dramatic rewrite of the Tax Code.

Baucus's nomination has been rumored in congressional circles for the last month, and it only became clear in recent days that the White House would make the appointment. The president and Baucus maintain friendly relations, and Baucus's long-time former staffer and close personal friend, Jim Messina, was Obama's campaign manager in his 2012 reelection effort.

As ambassador to China, Baucus would be responsible for balancing rising tensions with Japan, China's growing economic might, and thorny diplomatic issues involving tensions with North Korea and other regional hotspots. His departure would open up a key spot running the Senate Finance Committee, which would likely be taken over by Senator Jay Rockefeller, who is retiring at the end of next year.

Baucus has served on the Senate Finance Committee since 1979, making him the longest-serving senator on the committee in history. He has been a central figure in battles over trade, taxes, and health care for a generation. His nomination would be considered by the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, which quickly approved another senator to a diplomatic post earlier this year.

The decision to appoint Baucus stunned his colleagues at the tail end of a day where senators are sparring over wrapping up legislative business for the year. Baucus's departure would also open up a Senate seat in a competitive state where Democratic Gov. Steve Bullock would appoint the senator when there is a vacancy. Lt. Gov. John Walsh (D) is already running for the open seat against Rep. Steve Daines (R), the freshman congressman whom Republicans believe is in the strongest position to win the race.

It remains unclear when the appointment would take effect, but Baucus would have to win confirmation from his Senate colleagues. If he leaves before his term ends, Baucus would relinquish his gavel on the Senate Finance Committee at a time when he is still aggressively pushing for a dramatic rewrite of the Tax Code, putting its chances in peril this Congress.

Title: Former CIA Director John Brennan's Political Past Raises Questions About Objectivity

Article:

John Brennan, the former CIA director, has been criticized for his political bias and involvement in the 2016 election. On his Twitter account, Brennan describes himself as a "nonpartisan American who is very concerned about our collective future." However, his past actions and associations suggest otherwise.

Brennan's ascent to the top of the CIA began with a lie-detector test, which revealed his support for the Soviet-controlled American Communist party. He was later involved in the investigation into the Trump campaign, which some have criticized as a sham.

Recently, NBC signed Brennan as a "national security" correspondent, allowing him to continue promoting his views on the Steele dossier. This has raised concerns about the media's role in perpetuating political bias.

Another figure, Jonathan Winer, has also come under scrutiny. Winer, a former State Department official, has been accused of being part of the Obama administration's efforts to interfere in the 2016 election. He has been criticized for his role in briefing John Kerry and others on the Steele dossier and passing information from Cody Shearer, a Hillary Clinton supporter, to Steele.

Winer has downplayed his involvement, claiming he was simply sharing information with a colleague. However, critics argue that his actions were part of a larger effort to influence the election.

The article also mentions Susan Rice, who has been accused of emailing herself a "I am not guilty" note on her last day in office. The note appears to be a reference to a conversation with President Obama, who emphasized the importance of handling the investigation into Russian interference "by the book."

The article concludes by suggesting that the media's failure to hold these individuals accountable for their actions has created a culture of political espionage and manipulation. The author argues that the media's willingness to give a platform to figures like Brennan and Winer is a sign of a larger problem, and that the public should be skeptical of their claims.

Title: US Imposes New Sanctions on Russia, Russia Threatens Retaliation

The United States has announced a new round of sanctions against Russia, aimed at punishing the country for the March 4 nerve-agent attack on former spy Sergei Skripal and his daughter in the UK. The sanctions, which are required under the 1991 Chemical and Biological Weapons Control and Warfare Elimination Act, will limit exports to Russia of sensitive goods and technology, including electronics, lasers, and some specialized oil and gas production technologies.

The initial round of sanctions is set to take effect on August 22, with more sweeping measures possible 90 days later. The sanctions could block hundreds of millions of dollars in exports and may include restrictions on trade with Russia under a law passed earlier this year.

Russia has threatened to retaliate against the sanctions, with officials saying they may impose restrictions on trade with the US under a law passed earlier this year. This could include cutting off supplies of rocket engines needed for US space launches and aviation.

The Russian government has denied any involvement in the nerve-agent attack and has expressed little hope for compromise. The added sanctions could include a downgrading in diplomatic relations, blanket bans on the import of Russian oil and exports of "all other goods and technology" aside from agricultural products, as well as limits on loans from US banks.

The US sanctions are a response to the attack on the Skripals, which the US has attributed to Russia. The sanctions are also seen as a way for the US to hold Russia accountable for its actions and to deter future attacks.

Title: Trump Administration Imposes Tariffs on Chinese Goods, Threatens Escalation

The Trump administration has announced plans to impose tariffs on $34 billion worth of Chinese goods, with President Trump stating that this is just the first wave of measures. The tariffs are intended to pressure China to address what the White House describes as unfair trade practices and intellectual property theft. The administration has also placed restrictions on investment and visas for Chinese nationals.

The tariffs on Chinese goods are expected to be followed by levies on an additional $16 billion worth of products, with the total value of affected goods potentially reaching $450 billion. China has vowed to retaliate against the tariffs, leading to a stalemate that will require one side to blink first to avoid a prolonged trade war.
